reviews.review: Something for everyone. This is a wonderful mid size museum with an eclectic portfolio. The armoury houses a very fine collection of interesting objects beautifully displayed. The clocks are mostly, if not all, French and fine examples. Porcelain abounds at every turn and there is a super collection of Majolica. Being just north of Oxford street it is a step away from frenetic shopping and offers a peaceful and educational respite! There is a good restaurant too.

Hidden gem!. What an amazing collection of armour, china and art. This is one of the best private galleries I have visited - and it's FREE! The guides are friendly, well informed and happy to answer questions. Well worth a visit.....even if you don't think you like art galleries, give it a try, you will love this one.Tip: The cafe is overpriced - very small helpings - take a short walk to a nearby restaurant for lunch and then go back for afternoon tea.....even then, you will get 4 tiny sandwiches and a small scone. Guess they have to make money somehow.

Rare find in the centre of Marylebone.. I have visited the Wallace collection twice now.It is a beautiful house ,with rooms full of paintings, sculpture, various artworks, furniture, all housed in a lovely building.There is also a lovely restaurant area in a central atrium.Well worth a visit if you are in the area.

more than one visit is needed.. I returned having felt that I didn't take everything in the first time I visited.The armory section is so special with lots to see and an abundance of swords and shields amongst other things. Considering the specialty of some of the pieces and paintings its not a busy museum, perhaps it isn't advertised enough which is a shame.The restaurant can be popular with queuing sometimes, prices are expensive, there are many other eateries in the area.

Freindly staff and fine collection. The Wallace Collection is housed in a beautiful and well decorated mansion in Marylebone. The art is particularly good and the armoury very beautiful. The restuatrant in the central atrium is quite expensive for the dainty portions offered (definitely a ladies who lunch venue) but the menu was interesting and very tasty (as was the sauvignon blanc). I had the salmon quiche, which was delicious but my husband's crab and prawn salad was particularly small. A great place to spend a half day.

Hidden Gem!. I had some time to kill in London and wandered into the Wallace Collection. What a joy! I was amazed by the eclectic mix of art, porcelain, furniture and ancient weaponry. I arrived just in time to participate in one of the guided tours which added so much colour and information to the collection. When you get the history behind the item, it brings it so much more to life and makes it so much more relevant.

Excellent Free Museum. The Wallace Collection is housed in Hertford House just off Marylebone. It a free attraction. The collection is quite amazing, including an incredible armoury collection and an outstanding collection of paintings & jewelery.
Hidden Jewel !. Great place to visit to view a large number of English treasures. Great collection of weapons, suits of armor, rare and beautiful paintings.
The secret gem. The less popular of the London Museums, the Wallace collection is a one of the most surprising for the quantity and quality of the pieces exposed on it.

What a beautiful museum!. Have been wanting to come here for many years and finally made it recently. This is a beautiful London house converted to a museum in Manchester Square and being a little bit away from the main tourist areas was not too crowded and made the experience a delight.There are many many wonderful artifact and works of art here a real treasure trove of exhibits its just amazing and you wander round feeling like you are in someone's mansion.A must for London visitors everything about this place is good!

Delightful restaurant in a wonderful gallery. Eating at the Wallace Collection restaurant is almost as worthwhile an experience as exploring the gallery. This must be one of the finest small galleries in the world, with fabulous little-known exhibits beautifully presented and never crowded. The food and ambiance in the restaurant are exceptional too. What more could anyone ask?

Interesting. A nice quite place to visit. The wallace collection has one of the biggest collection of French antiquity in the whole of london.
We visited being ironic that my name is wallace and my partner is French.
Hidden away and pretty small. Impressive array of swords

TOP GALLERY - HIDDEN JEWEL. The Wallace Collection is the finest small gallery in the world....bar none. An ecclectric collection, fabulous furniture, antiques, armor, just a collection of great stuff....great art. Do not miss this. I visit every time I am in London...last ten years been there 8 times. See new things every time....love this museum.

Lovely and uncrowded museum. There was no charge to enter The Wallace Collection. It would be worth every penny if they did charge. The ability to walk without crowds was great, but more important, it's the art that brings people in. So much great art collected in that building as well as ornate furniture and ceramics. The Laughing Cavalier and Girl on a Swing are the famous pieces, but there is so much more. The volume of great art was way beyond what I expected to see, and of such fine quality. There was a donation box and we gladly put in 5GBP. It was one of the nicest museums we visited while in London, and I think we saw most of them.

A lesser-known gem. The Wallace Collection is a delightful small museum in quiet Manchester Square, London, just a 100 metre walk from the relentless shopping throngs and bustle of Oxford Street. It is the former townhouse of the Seymour family, Marquesses of Hertford; an immaculate 3 storey building.It is beautifully kept, with a collection of riches which reminds you of why you visit London. In 25 galleries there are displays of French 18th-century painting, beautifully preserved furniture and a brilliant armoury. Splendid works of the greats - Rembrandt, Canaletto (The Canaletto Room is one highlight among many), Van Dyck.It is a quiet, contemplative museum, made all the more memorable by being our first visit.

Should be better known. Overlooked by me for a long time, passed in a taxi without a thought. But get out and visit. A private permanent collection set out as it may well have been in everyday use. Very informative guides and the ability to get insights and linger that you don't get elsewhere.Period furniture really adds to the experience as does the collection of porcelain, miniatures and snuff boxes. Everyone will find a favouriteThe temporary Tom Ellis - well at least it's only temporary!

Grander than Buckingham Palace, and free. After doing both the pricey Buckingham Palace tour, and the free tour here, I found myself feeling that the Wallace was actually more grand than Buckingham. Opulent rooms, a huge picture gallery, and really interesting tour guides, an often overlooked must-see in London.
beautiful place to visit-furniture divine. Loved the armour, the furniture, the overall layout of this not so well known museum. Highly recommended!

Fascinating and free!. A beautiful period house full of exquisite furniture, chandaliers, porcelain and all manner of art and artefacts. Situated just north of Oxford Street this really is a hidden gem. Bequeathed to the nation by an avid and expert collector the house contains some of the most beautiful rooms I've seen in England. Also a lovely courtyard to sit and eat. Unforgettable and worth more than one visit.
Lovely Compact Museum. Wonderful furniture and miniatures collections. Spent about 3 hours and would like to go back. A loud cafe in central courtyard.

Tally Ho!. The Wallace Collection is lovely, especially if you like suits of armour, but the collection is huge and by the time I got to the painting galleries I think I was a little worn out by the, what appeared to be, largely un-curated collections on the way there. The rooms themselves are magnificent and I think that if you can avoid being bogged down in the armoury and actually just go for the specific paintings that you're looking for it would probably be better. My husband loves the suits of armour so we spent quite some time in the armoury meaning that the sheer volume of the place had weighed us down by the time we got to the paintings. It was also quite busy in the galleries and people didn't seem to heed gallery rules not to make a racket as they would in a traditional art gallery, perhaps because it's mixed. I recommend the guided tours as they looked very promising. We took tea in the courtyard restaurant which was nice.

Amazing experience. We had planned to visit during the summer but with various holiday trips we never got round to it!enjoyed a fabulous lunch in the restaurant and then had an amazing tour of the museum and whilst I admit its not my normal cup of tea I was amazed at what is after all a private collection!As a classy girlie day out I cannot recommend highly enough.

Brilliant treasure house - often overlooked. Quite brilliant place to visit. Spectacular collection of artwork, artefacts and antiques. The renovation over the last few years means the rooms are exhibits in and of themselves - all different, but each of them presented in vivid, beautiful colours, and with decoration that fits in with the theme.We received a great welcome from the team, as well as help throughout our visit.Overall, the Wallace Collection really is one of London's best.
The best museum in London?. This place was amazing seeing as it is a private collection. I could go back over and over as it holds so much of such quality and variety.
Fabulous Free Attraction. Very worthwhile place to visit with some very good paintings and beautiful rooms. The cafe was very good as well.

Full of surprises...brilliant museum!. This is an impressive museum with artwork, European and Oriental armoury and Sèvres porcelain collections. All collections are very well displayed and the staff is friendly and helpful. Suitable for a day trip. The restaurant is lovely and ideal for a short break while visiting the museum.

An absolute Treasure - and FREE. We spent only a couple of hours in the Wallace Collection due to time restraints, but could have spent much longer. This is a fabulous collection of furniture, art and much much more collected over the years by the family (nothing to do with Wallis Simpson). We had lunch in the Orangery which was absolutely delightful, excellent value for money and very substantial.

Wow!. I've lived in London for years but had never been to The Wallace Collection before. I'd be missing out!What a gem of a place. Free entry for one of the most incredible collections I've seen anywhere.We spent almost a full day looking around - breaking for a delicious lunch in the cafe. Leave yourself plenty of time to really take it all in.

Brilliant Place!. Had a really enjoyable visit to the Wallace Collection recently. We had a few hours to spare before our train journey home so we decided to pay a visit and I'm so pleased we did! It is a wonderful building with some many beautiful works of art. The cafe was great with a good menu.Really would recommend a visit here

an often overlooked London museum. very close to Oxford street and with a wonderful collection of weapons and armour and art why not deposit your menfolk/womenfolk not interested in shopping here whilst everyone else hits up the department stores and rendezvous back at the excellent cafe a couple of hours later for tea and cake.

TUCKED AWAY. I had read about this museum/gallery and didn't think we would get to it but happened upon it by accident. With free admission we couldn't resist. At least an hour to walk around and view - it's bigger than you think!
well worth a visit,. well worth a visit, interesting and very well designed, go if you get a chance, this is a thing to see, good cafe as well

The Wallace Collection housed at Hertford House in Manchester Square, London.. My wife and I were due to have a dinner in Seymour Street but had a couple of hours to spare before. So I typed in “Attractions near to Marble Arch” and up came quite a list. One that caught my eye was The Wallace Collection, which for all I knew could have been about the writer Edgar Wallace. I really need to broaden my horizon of knowledge. So with no more ado we set off for London. After a quick stop at Hamilton Hall in Liverpool Street Station for a cappuccino for me and a chocolate with cream on the top for Lola, off we set for the Central Line Underground. Eight stops later and we got off at Marble Arch Underground station. As you exit the station turn to your LEFT. Cross over Portman Street, same again for Orchard Street, Selfridges the store is on your side of the road. Just past it is Duke Street, turn left into here and straight ahead you will come to Manchester Square. Hertford House is on the opposite side of the square. One great thing is that entrance is free; such magic words in to-days world. As you enter, their gift shop is on the left, most items I found to be on the high side price wise. There is an exit from here that takes you into rooms containing swords, helmets and rifles. Further around you can even see in the largest glass case a full size horse with a figure seated on it clad in a full suit of armour. Beware, you will need to spend a long time here in order to fully appreciate the collection that has been put together. However there is a place where you can purchase a complete meal or simply a drink. It would appear that money was not an option when this collection was first started. Richard Seymour-Conway, 4th Marquess of Hertford originally started this in about 1897, who left both it and the house to his illegitimate son Sir Richard Wallace . His widow bequeathed the entire collection to the nation. However a condition of the bequest was that no object should ever leave the collection, not even for loan exhibitions. Should you like to view paintings, then this place has some really fine examples. There are two paintings by Titian, five Rembrandts, nine Rubenses, four Van Dycks, eight Canalettos, nineteen Bouchers, plus masterpieces by de Hooch, nine Teniers, Frans Hals, nine Murillos, two Velázquez and paintings by Domenichino, Cima, Daddi, Reni, Rosa, Thomas Gainsborough, Joshua Reynolds, Antoine Watteau, Nicholas Lancret, Jan Steen, Aelbert Cuyp and nine Guardis. On the top floor there is the great gallery. We entered from the left door, and there on our right was that well known portrait by Frans Hals. The name of the painter meant nothing to me before, but the moment you see his work of art you recognise it immediately; it is of course The Laughing Cavalier, painted about 1624. There is just so much to take in that we will have to return yet again to fully understand the breadth and importance of this collection. Lower floors down you will find displays of gold boxes, miniatures, sculpture and medieval and Renaissance works of art such as maiolica, glass, bronzes and Limoges enamels. What it doesn’t let you know is how much fine furniture there is here as well. Some absolutely gorgeous pieces that simply take your breath away. One is a brilliant desk; and one can only guess at the kind of house this was used in and who was it that sat behind it? There are also some cabinets in a long shape that have small works in them. Puzzling though are that around the outside there are leather type covers which you have to lift up; do not miss these. Under each one, there may be for instance, a small miniature portrait that has to be protected from the light or to stop it from fading. Cabinets of maiolica porcelain full to the brim, just a delight as you take in more of this wide ranging collection. Could this collection be one of the most underated or unknown collections awaiting discovery? My narrow range does not give me the gift to fully describe just what a pleasure it was for us both to find this collection on the off chance, and for that we are so glad. If you have some time to spare do visit it, you will not be disappointed; and like us may return time and time again to see what new item you can find to take your breath away.

My Favourite Stop in London. I truly believe that there is nowhere in London that matches the Wallace Collection. House in a magnificent building, this collection of artwork and antiquities is evocative, awe-inspiring and breathtaking. You really do feel as though you've stepped back into another world and the surroundings are tranquil, whilst the staff really cannot be praised enough.

Twice daily free guided tours. Very interesting museum with great collection of paintings, pottery and tapestriesJoin the guided tours to learn about the historyHighlight has to be the Laughing Cavalier

Wonderful experience. We went to see this collection because my son-in-law is into the practice on ancient Martial arts and when we were in London this was a must for him. But what a surprise! There were several rooms with different types of armorer, Swords, knives and all types of weapons and shields used in ancient wars. But more rooms full of paintings, including several Rembrandts, furniture and more. We had planed to be there for a few hours, but spent nearly the whole day. There was a lovely restaurant and very good service.If you are interested in old instruments of war or are a pursuant of social armed combat, this is a must. Even otherwise like me, it is well worth a visit

Excellent small museum. Wonderful museum. Been twice and will go again. Incredibly helpful and knowledgeable staff. Layout of rooms is v.good. Its not crowded and there are some real gems to be found. Also got an excellent restaurant - good food, helpful polite staff.

Like stepping back a century or five.. The Wallace Collection offers a very manageable site to view several different museum collections -- an attractive collection of fine paintings (including a Rembrandt portrait of his son) and fine furniture arranged as they would have been in a 19th century mansion (which this is) plus a basement full of medieval weaponry including full suits of armors and lots of muskets, rifles, pistols, swords, pikes, and assorted instruments of brutality. A pleasant way to spend a couple of hours and end up far less tired than after visiting one of the great museums.

Wonderful visit. We spent a delightful morning wandering around this fabulous house.The condition of the rooms was excellent. The display of the furniture and paintings were tasteful and thoughtful.The entrance was free but there was a donation box conveniently placed near the entrance.We joined a group who were with a guide.The guide was so knowledgable and entertaining . Her obvious love for the home and it's history was infectious.I don't remember her name but she carried a resting stool with her.Thank you Madam for a most enjoyable experience.

Beautiful museum, wonderful collection. My second visit to the Wallace collection; loved it even more. Enjoyed fine paintings, exquisite ceramics, beautiful furniture, and extensive collection of armor without being overwhelmed. Check the museum website for the schedule of free tours. I didn’t take the tour, but had a chance to listen to the commentary behind the purchase and current speculations of The Laughing Cavalier at the last stop of the tour.If you can afford it, please support the free museums with your donations.

Exceptional. The Wallace Collection is without a doubt one of the finer attractions to visit while in London and I would urge anyone that is a fan of heritage homes and vintage culture to make this a must-see at least once while in the capital.The rooms are each elegant creations filled with interesting deco and furnishings and art enough to keep anyone interested for some time. The house is a combination of a heritage home, a museum and an art gallery, giving you so much to take in. When you consider it is a free attraction then there is little to stop you from visiting the Collection as much as you wish.One of my favourite parts is the courtyard restaurant, a wonderful open air venue perfect to detach yourself from the bustle of the collection and enjoy some tea in a relaxed environment.

A gem of an art museum. The art is unusual in that it reflects one family's collecting over several generations. The curation is superb. It was easy to get a sense of why the art was in the collection and the individual tastes of the collectors was explained and then demonstrated. So, it's a great combination of a state owned museum but at a more personal level. Another benefit was that the museum was lightly attended. No crowded rooms. The art is exquisite. Also, there is a nice cafe in a covered courtyard where one can relax with a snack or lunch.

A London favourite. I've visited the Wallace Collection on 4 different occasions and would definitely go and see it again. This time I initially took one of the in house guided tours but found it to be rather boring and long winded. It is easily possible to find your way around and to locate the best parts of the collection just by using the little map provided. There are many paintings by great artists, an impressive collection of armour and dozens of superb porcelain and furniture pieces, and more! All of this is contained in a grand house and there is a very nice restaurant as well.

Brilliant and a Great Breakfast. Loved this collection. Entry is free and so is the excellent tour. A 5 pound donation is recommended, and really seems like the least you can do given the quality of the collection and tour. Highly recommend the tour. It was intimate and extremely informative. The collection is just amazing. Really enjoyed the armor. We arrived just as it opened and went for breakfast. The courtyard (now covered) serves as the restaurant, and is a lovely space. Had some of the best Eggs Benedict and at an affordable price for London.
Fabulous collection of art and artifacts. Free and no lines!. This is an amazing collection featuring art by Canaleto, Gainsborough and many,many others. It also has an astounding armory.

I was there first and last time. This place is just average. Lovely building and not really great collection of paintings. The people who work there are usually old and unfriendly. There were plenty of people with bags or backpacks but only I was sent back to the cloakroom. The staff member in her early 70's even called me loudly! Never again!Is there an equality policy in this place?

The knight in armour is incredible. The Wallace collection is an absolute gem. It is crammed full of outstanding paintings, furniture, ceramics, weapons and armour. You must see the knight in armour on his war horse.The house itself is magnificent and beautifully looked after. The collection is just the right size and after walking around all the rooms there is a lovely cafe in the middle of the building to relax in. Years ago this was an open area but it has been glassed in and is a delightful place to have coffee. Entrance to this remarkable collection is free but after being treated to such benevolence it would be mean spirited not to make a donation.

The best private collection on show to the public in the world.. It's only a matter of taste. Better and more comprehensive than the Frick ,the Morgan Library ,Chateau de Chantilly in fact anything other than the Royal Collections, the Wallace Collection is an absolute must see for anyone interested in pre 20th century art. The definitive collection of 18th century French furniture and one of the great collections of armour.

The Wallace Collection is a little known jewel just off Oxford Street. Having lived in London for five years and later visited many times, only last year did I discover the Wallace Collection. It is in a beautiful mansion in downtown London, just off Oxford Street on a little square, and houses a marvelous collection of paintings and armor. Seeing such a beautifully maintained historical mansion is a real treat, and makes you feel like an honored visitor.
This is one of the best museums in London.. This museum has something for everyone and even if one part doesn't capture you others will. It is also of a manageable size so you dont feel overwhelmed.
Beautiful building and collection. Amazing time at the Wallace collection, you can lose yourself in amazingly beautiful rooms full of the most amazing French furniture and objects.

An oasis or culture 2 minutes from Oxford Street.. Escape the throng. The collection is superlative in several fields. The ambience is always peaceful. The staff are friendly and helpful. The dining facility is excellent, with astute and friendly waiting staff. The wine list is interesting too.If shopping, take a break and return refreshed. You could repeat the process each day you visit Oxford Street, as there is plenty to view; arms and armour, painting, porcelain, miniature carvings and hard-stone cameos etc

Fascinating Gem of a Museum. Wonderful small museum with a quirky collection of European armor and French Baroque furniture which a lovely gallery including choice Titians, Hals and Rembrandt . There is a free tour offered daily which is a treat. The little cafe is a perfect place to lunch . We loved the older gentleman who was at the front entry . He encouraged us to take the tour. Good advice!

Superb collection, housed in one of London's finest 'secret' houses.. The Wallace Collection is a wonderful place to spend an afternoon. Very much a reflection of one man's personal taste, it is a testament to eighteenth and nineteenth century decorative arts. The staff can be a bit snippy, so don't get too close to the exhibits, but the central courtyard cafe (and the loos), are perfect. The gift shop is a great place to find reasonably priced stocking fillers that won't be seen elsewhere.
Fabulous collection and building . The Wallace is a great and unusual collection, where the building is as much of the star. Great for 10 min of rest from the madness of Oxford st

Worth having a guide!. The Wallace Collection is free and very well run mostly by volunteers. The rooms were beautifully furnished and the silk wall coverings quite sumptuous! There are many, many paintings so unless you know your art, I would recommend a tour. The guide we had was very informed, fun, knowledgable and full of snippets of gossip about the artists and their models!

A hidden gem. I don't know if I really want to write this with you because I don't want everybody knowing lolI've been here several times now eating in the restaurant and the Brasserie had breakfast and then back for lunch can't sort the service at all 5 star all around their staff can't do enough for you and nothing is a problemThe actual collection in this building is stunningWith a wide selection of artefacts from military to China to paintings absolutely out of this world things you would never see anywhere elseWould highly recommend this venue if you're planning to go and only have a couple of hours it would be a wasted trip could spend the day there and still not see everything in detail

Beautiful art collection and museum!. This was my second visit to The Wallace Collection and the experience was just as wondrous and magical as the first. Wandering around the richly decorated rooms you feel like you are in someones private home. I went just before lunchtime on a Thursday and the place was relatively quiet. On my first visit a couple of years ago I overheard one of the tour guides mention that Vivienne Westwood was a regular visitor to the Wallace, finding inspiration for her fashion collections. We were standing in front of the painting 'The Swing' an 18th-century oil painting by Jean-Honoré Fragonard. This place is a must visit for anyone who loves art and interiors. And its free! Highly recommend.

Amazing restaurant . Went for lunch and as first visit booked the restaurant. The space is shared with their cafe which surprised me and made me think should try that another time. Food excellent I ate vegetarian with hindsight a starter and main too much for lunch even though my starter was the watermelon salad. Looking forward to visiting again

One of the Best Museum in the world. This is my 5th time to London but the first time I went to the Wallace Collection, as highly recommended by a Londoner. It's so beautiful and stunning, which exhibits a wide range of fine and decorative arts from the 15th to the 19th centuries, and into 25 galleries. It also includes an extensive of French 18th century paintings, furnitures, arms & armour, porcelain. Now, it holds a special exhibition titled "The Middle" created by Tom Ellis, a contemporary London-based artist, from now till 27 November 2016. Free admission, including temporary exhibitions. After 4-hour tour, I went to the cafe at the Wallace Collection to enjoy a coffee and snack. A prefect end. Definitely, worth a visit if you are interested in fine & decorative arts.
Restaurant here is great. Really nice food and a great setting. Defintely worth a visit, even if the collection itself is a bit boring - unless you love suits of armour, guns and that sort of thing.

A must see collection. This is the 1st time I have been to London in years that I did not get to see The Wallace. I made a mistake. It is truly a wonderful collection and always worth the visit. They are constantly changing things but all the old favourites are on dispaly. Several huge Canalettos, the so called Laughing Cavalier, and many more amazing pieces. The collection of Sevres porcelain is world class. They have one of only 6 pieces in the world in their collection, the other 5 are held by the Queen, The Met in NY, the Getty in LA and the Waddesdon Manor collection north of London. All housed in a superb London mansion tucked in a street behind Selfridges. You will really enjoy it..and it's FREE!

Hidden gem. Tucked away at the back of the busy West End streets you will find that the Wallace Collection is a good way to while away an hour or so wandering around. The collection includes art, armour and furniture and other antiques. The place has a lot of "character" and does not offer the visitor a bland experience or corporate kind of image that some places can have. Well worth a visit and very near Marylebone High Street which has some nice shops. Toilets impressive and also a lovely restaurant situated in the centre of the building courtyard, but heated in winter. Good afternoon teas there.

My favourite gallery in London. Superb collection in the most wonderful setting. I am a frequent visitor and never tire of this lovely house. I normally go quite early but I have never found it over crowded or too busy to enjoy.

hidden collection. Lost in that era and beautiful house and collections.... The cafe/restaurant in the middle of the house is a great place to lay about and have a tea, shame about the afternoon teas cakes! Overall nice and friendly staffs

An amazing place. The name of this place would not stir the imagination much but prepare to be blown away. The history behind it is something to find out for yourself. But I urge anyone to go I not a big history fan and I was amazed and fascinated by the place and everything in it.

Beautiful interior. Beautiful and opulent interior with great Old Masters art. Well worth a visit. Family friendly place I found. A bit hidden away maybe because of that not many people knows about this amazing place.
A house of treasures. A fascinating collection of art, silver, furniture, weaponry etc. Beautifully presented with very helpful guides. Wonderful central atrium restaurant for afternoon tea.

Fantastic restaurant with a nice museum attached. This place is a gem, a great restaurant that's quiet, civilised and delightful just off Oxford Street. All around it are one of the most enjoyable collections in London. Don't miss the armour which is spectacular - the charging knight in full medieval get-up is unforgettable - makes you glad you're not fighting a battle in fourteenth century Europe. Don't read about what a Landesknecht could do with a sword if you're planning on ordering the steak.
Very well worth a visit. We really enjoyed our time here. You need about an hour or so but the displays and decore are just superb! Highly recommended if in London.

Hidden treasure. I've been to visit the Wallace Collection three times. Every time I have joined the free guided tour on a Sunday afternoon which lasts about an hour and is always so interesting. The guides always take a slightly different route through the collection and I always learn something new. The collection is jam packed with 18th century French paintings, furniture and ceramics as well as 1.5 paintings by Rembrandt and numerous paintings by Caneletto. The house is a few streets back from Selfridges and definitely worth a look. The restaurant in the covered courtyard is also really lovely.

Fantastic small museum. To say this museum is quite small, they have some fabulous artifacts and paintings on display including three Rembrandts! It should be advertised more widely. And it's free but donations are of course welcomed. Nearest tube is Bond Street. A must-see!

A lovely collection. This is a fabulous collection in a fantastic and extremely well-kept building. Entry is free and staff members are friendly and welcoming. Just walking from room to room and appreciating the interiors is an experience in itself! The humourously minded visitor will do doubt take great delight in The Temptation of St. Hilarion painting! There's also a sizeable armoury collection downstairs, if that's your thing.

Lovely museum. Free national museum (donation only) in an old house (closest tube stop is Bond St). Good variety to the collection. Armor, paintings, sculptures & furniture. 3 Rembrandts which is kind of amazing for a museum of this size. Spent about an hour there. Photos are allowed if you don't use a flash. Popular tea room inside which was packed on a Saturday afternoon, but museum was not crowded.

A Hidden Gem. How did we almost miss this one? When you see the first floor, it's ok--the art is all of a certain type, with an emphasis on hunting and country scenes. But, wait until you get to the 2nd floor. The art is truly amazing, with many Old Masters and a vast European collection.

Breakfast in the restaurant. Lovely setting, efficient staff but not the breakfast I was expecting. Ordered the continental at £5:50 but what arrived was 2 slices of toast with butter and a pot of jam. Disappointing and overpriced.
so much to see, should be something for everyone's taste.. Lots of things to see, various collections, my personal interest was downstairs ,armour, weapons and medieval pottery very interesting.
Great collection of art for a small museum. I love this museum because it has great collection of art and it is not overwhelming. I prefer smaller museums.
Best hidden gallery in London. Lovely coffee shop.Great collection of art.Peaceful and serene. Staff helpful. Location is a haven from the busy Oxford Street
Very nice collection. I went there because it was close to my hotel. I do not regret that at all. It was so nice. Collection is quite big, so reserve enough time to enjoy it.

Lovely space for a relaxed afternoon visit. The Wallace Collection is a beautiful and worthwhile visit in a city with no shortage of museums and galleries. The number of variety of pieces is incredible for a private collection and Hertford House, the building in which the collection is housed, is a work of art in itself. Allow at least 2 hours to roam the vast rooms, more if you plan on using the audio guide or attending a tour.Special notes: - I paid four pounds for the audio guide, which was very informative, however there are also free highlights tours during the day (which I missed) so be sure to inquire about those if you are interested in a more interactive experience. - There is a lovely restaurant located in the courtyard of the gallery, serving afternoon tea for only £18.50 per person or £26 with a glass of champagne (a total steal in London!). I didn't do the full afternoon tea but instead opted for the cream tea (at £6) and was very happy with my choice.

Love this place. Not to big, not to busy, just off oxford street, can be looked around in under an hour if you wish, and its free.Some great famous paintings, but theres a lot of death in every room in many paintings, or maybe its just me

Definitely worth a visit. We were shown The Wallace Collection by a friend who lives in London otherwise we would never have found it. Absolutely stunning insight into the splendour of a bygone era. The paintings and furniture are stunning.
Interesting Collection. Very good display of a staggering collection. The staff is extremely friendly, helpful and has a great sense of humour. Go there!

a lovely afternoon surrounded by stunning artwork. The beauty of Wallace Collection, besides the amazing 15th-19th century European artwork and an impressive collection of medieval and Renaissance armours is that it's not nearly as busy as some of the more touristy museums in London so you can spend as much time admiring each piece of art that your heart desires, take as many photos as you'd like (without flash of course) without getting photo bombed and simply get lost in the individual gallery rooms that once was a luxury private home for the Marquesses of Hertford. Thanks to the widow of it's last owner Sir Richard Wallace, we can now all enjoy their family collection for free(donation is welcomed and recommended) and marvel at their impressive collection of art created by some of the most well known grand masters such as Rembrandt, Rubens, Titian, and Velazquez. There is also a great little bookstore/gift shop inside and a nice terrace cafe where one can enjoy a delectable afternoon tea as well as free wifi.

It's all about the armoury. My two young boys were mesmerised by the eclectic collection of armour from around the world. The opportunity to actually try bits on in the basement was the icing on the cake. Staff were friendly and very helpful. An ocean of tranquility just a stone's throw from Oxford Street.
best small museum in london. the exhibits are well laid out and the museum is not so bigthat it overwhelms the visitor,plenty to see and something for every interest

Like a very rich meal..... This London town house is beautiful art collection treat...Its free, its open early on Sunday 10-5 (seven days actually) you can combine it with a mooch around Marylebone High Street and nearby Cramer Street SundayFarmers Market.The interior of the house is jaw dropping and there is art everywhere - loads of gorgeous Canalettos, Rembrandts, French,Dutch and Flemish masters - Don't miss THE Laughing Cavalier...his eyes do follow you around the room! Also look carefully for a small collection of Erotic miniatures. Staff are pretty unapproachable but you can take photos throughout!

Fabulous collection. A superb art collection in a beautiful old building. You can wander around on your own or take a guided tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and had some amusing anecdotes. A great way to pass a few hours on a wet day and it is free. The cafe is definitely worth a visit

A fascinating collection. My wife and I visited this fascinating collection during our first visit to London, thirty years ago. The main reason was “The Strawberry Girl” by Joshua Reynolds, which is one of my wife’s favorite paintings. From that visit, this museum is on my schedule whenever I have time to visit it. It is a marvelous collection, with more than five thousand objects - arms and armor, ceramics, furniture, miniatures and sculptures, including a sensational collection of almost eight hundred paintings and drawings. Amazing and different from any other London’s wonder.

Wonderful institution. This is a wonderful place.
Just a lovely old grand building in an amazing setting.
I'll let somebody else comment on the art, but this is a stunning visit and well worth seeing.
Cafe is also decent and a calm, relaxed spot with decent food for the area it is in.
Time machine. Museums are free of charge but it is a private museum, what means you have to pay for a ticket. But it is worse. You are driven back to 19 Century immediately. It's a real time machine

Wow. I was totally surprised by the glamour of the house alone, never mind the art and armouries..i am going to have to go back and do it again! Truly fascinating the kind of art a heathen like me actually takes notice of. It really is amazing.

A hidden gem!. I was told about this place by someone who had chanced upon it. It was lovely to be able to just visit for an hour and I had afternoon tea too! The fact that it is free is superb and it means you can afford to have a pot of tea and a slice of cake! Fabulous exhibits.

Classy Afternoon. We decided to go to the Wallace Collection for a comfy, romantic afternoon. To tell you the truth, we were there primarily for The Swing, Fragonard, but left mesmerized at the beauty of the location. This is not your ordinary whitecube, the building has a lot of personality, which I haven't seen in a while, being used to visiting modern art museums. It made us travel in time, revisiting a XVII-XVIII century Europe. The collection is most impressive and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

A beautiful and interesting place to visit. A lovely building hosting an amazing collection of paintings, sculptures, armour and so much more.We noticed several people having afternoon tea in the light and airy conservatory space & thought that's something we would like to return and do at a later date. This place is a real hidden gem and well worth visiting.

Great, different. Large house now a museum with furniture, paintings, china, fabulous wall coverings, armour and more. Laughing Cavalier here and it's worth the trip just to see this. The art is amazing and the style outlandish and colourful. Cafe on site, free entry. Could easily spend a long lazy day here. Oh and plenty of seats to sit and take it all in.

A hidden gem in London. The Wallace Collection is one of the finest art collections in England, if not Europe, and the nation is incredibly indebted to Lady Wallace for her bequest. As a condition of the bequest was that no be allowed the leave the collection, this is the only place you can go to see some of the most famous paintings in the world, and so well worth a visit.The only downside is (as has been stated in quite a few other reviews) a small number of over-zealous members of staff. I have always wanted to see The Swing in the flesh, and so waited for quite a while whilst a lady took many close-up photos with her camera barely an inch from the canvas. After she left, I leaned towards the painting for a closer look (not nearly so close as the lady's camera lens had been), and the gentleman posted in the room bellowed across for me to get back. It seems the museum different policies for men than for buxom blondes in a low-cut tops!

A bit stuffy but with some good items. Visited with some friends who really wanted to see this. The collection is vast and has some wonderful pieces. The staff is friendly if a little stuffy and I didnt feel very comfortable but I am glad I visited.

Spectacular. I was left to wander around at my own pace. A homage to gilt. This unequalled townhouse just off of Oxford Street is thankfully not to busy , even at the height of Summer. It is free to enter but you are encouraged by a lovely old man to buy a book for £6.99. I was more than happy to & it will serve as a lovely reminder for many years to come. While there we came across the courtyard which is a lovely restaurant & café. I can highly recommend it & the staff are very helpful & friendly. Don't forget to look up while you are there. You will see some spectacular ceilings and chandelier

Lovely, intimate art gallery. This is a simply wonderful art collection in a classic 19th century house on Manchester Square in Marylebone just north of Oxford Street and west of Regent Street. It has a pleasant restaurant in what used to be an outdoor courtyard (now covered), too. I'm not much for the porcelain, furniture, and armor. Instead, I concentrate on the paintings, which are exquisite. It's a top collection spanning the 14th - early 19th centuries probably surpassed only by the National Gallery. One feature I particularly appreciate is that in each room sets of small guidebooks explain the background and themes of each painting in the room. I spent a rainy afternoon in here recently to reacquaint myself with the collection. Enjoyed nearly three hours of reading the descriptions and taking in each painting. Emerged refreshed and peaceful.Pair a visit with a walk up Marylebone High Street (the extension of Thayer Street) and stop in a pub or cafe. Then, for the ambitious, a walk up through Regent's Park to Primrose Hill.
Beatifull collection. We definitely enjoiyed our visit at Wallace collection, quiet and not crowdy, excellent exposition of art and weaponry.

Almost 5-stars!. It's truly an amazing collection of paintings, furniture, porcelain, glass, armor, etc. in a most beautiful luxurious mansion.Daily Highlight Tours are very informative and recommended, just get a button fromReception when you arrive at the museum to ensure a spot on the tour.Staff were all very courteous and helpful.Now why isn't this a 5-star review?The route going to restaurant or restrooms is through the elegant Dining Roomwhich makes that area very noisy and hectic, and similarly affects the 2 adjacent rooms (Billiard Room & Porcelain Room).This really makes it much harder to enjoy and focus the art & furnishing in these 3 main rooms on the ground floor.This was an unfortunate downside to this otherwise top museum.

Wonderful collection of art and antiques away from the crowds. This was a great place to visit away from the crowds of tourists. The mansion houses an extensive collection of beautiful art, antiques and furniture. We especially enjoyed the collection of medieval armor and weapons. Beautiful home with lots of history!
Lovely. You should take a badge from the reception if you want to join a guided tour. The tour was very informative and I could see and learn the essentials of the collection.

Don't miss this. This was a private residence and has one of the most extensive private collections of art. It is a lovely home that you can visit and tour with an audio guide. There's a lovely restaurant outside when your legs get tired. Don't miss this. It's about 3 blocks from Selfridges.

Tucked away. Behind Oxford Street is the Wallace Collection, a little known gem in central London with a wonderful collection of paintings as well as suits of armours which are really quite spectacular. A lovely quiet place behind the Oxford Street bustle where the courtyard is a great place to have a coffee.

A lovely, enjoyable visit.. One of the lovliest private collections in London. Exquisite porcelain collection. Beautiful furniture and art works...small and intimate museum, sensory overload...lovely restaurant also. Well worth a visit.

Amazing art, stunning place. The Wallace Collection is a static collection meaning that there are no additions and no sales. Also the collection does not borrow or lend. So, in essence the art you see here will never be seen anywhere else. The collection really is stunning, I guess the most famous painting here is the Laughing Cavalier by Hals this really is the tip of the icebrg. There are stunning pieces throughout. I was lucky enough to join the 2.30PM tour and I would highly recommend joining one of the tours. I do appreciate art but the curators here have an immense knowledge and their description of some selected plus the history and context are wonderful. It is also a lovely place to enjoy lunch. We dined in the courtyard restaurant which has a limited menu but nice food with a great ambience and good service. I believe that the restaurant offers a wider menu on a Friday and Saturday evening. One to try as you can dine under the stars in Central London.A great place to visit for the art lover.

Hidden Gem!. The Wallace Collection is a real hidden gem, it has a fabulous art collection and a wonderful European armour collection. Amongst the treasure is a courtyard restaurant with a fabulous glass roof. We only had tea and cakes but it was just lovely. The location is so central sitting behind Selfridges in Oxford Street. Unfortunately, we spent so long in the museum we had missed lunch and didn't have time for dinner but we will certainly be returning.

A tranquil feast for the senses. Great place to meet with friends or vistors to London especially on a rainy day. Even better as a place for solitary thinking and a bit of time out. Free entry and some amazing exhibits. Every room has a well informed guide. Apart from the paintings, portraits, porcelain, clocks and furniture I love the armoury. A mixture of ancient international weaponry, armour and real-size horse armour. The horse armour room has to be my favourite collection in London. It is enthralling for kids. The Peyton and Byrne café has a decadent feel and the cakes are to die for. As a minimum it's possible to share an amazing salad and tasty fries, have an afternoon tea, or go the whole hog and indulge in some fine dining. It is seriously breath taking and if you have never peeked in you will find it awesome. Although entry is free of charge, a contribution is deserved.
We go there every visit for the Canalettos and Bouchers. Small museum packed with paintings, furniture, even armor. Restaurant is excellent, but the cafe on the side is reasonable and quick.

Amazing art collection in period house.. We spent a very enjoyable afternoon in the Wallace collection, such a variety of art from paintings, porcelain and furniture to suits of medieval armour! It is all displayed in a period setting so you go through various rooms of the house seeing objects in context There is so much to see that we only managed about half so we very much want to go back; also there is an excellent cafe in a lovely courtyard selling delicious cakes!

A gem.. Wonderful place. Lots to see without feeling overwhelming. Beautiful paintings and objects many from the Eigteenth century France. Probably not of huge interest to small children but a joy for adults who have an interest in beautiful quality art.
Very special small gallery. This is the sort of gallery you will want to re-visit over the years. Although quite small it offers the highest quality art in a beautiful building.

A gem just behind Oxford Street. The Wallace Collection amazes me. Such an amazing collection of beautiful furniture, paintings, objet d'arts and lots f interesting things. Hidden away behind Oxford Street with a great place for tea too.

Nice visit. The Wallace Collection offers art, furniture and armor from the French 18th century on display in what used to be a London town house. It is a nice place to spend some time, especially on a cool or rainy afternoon. It is free to the public.

Top Notch. This is now my favorite museum. It puts others to shame. Deceiving from the outside - looks small, I assure you that it is not! Every floor offers something different. It appeals to young and old, male and female and well behaved children. The building itself is pristine, the collections inside vary from enamels, to swords and armor to statues and much more. We attended a classical music concert in the former ballroom upstairs. There is a full service restaurant in the large solarium and an auditorium showing various topical films and lectures. One could spend an entire afternoon here. Loved it!

Fabulous art and artefacts collection and lovely restaurant. This is an especially lovely setting for an art and artefacts collection. What is more the admission is free. Staff are very friendly, and there is a beautiful atrium for the cafe/restaurant. It's a fine old house. It's well worth a visit, and not just for its famous paintings. It's a very pleasant, relaxing experience.

Free guided tour. Can't miss it. The extremely proficient guide will take you through the most amazing private art collection and the story of the patrons who started collecting the fantastic pieces of art.Also they will explain why it is named The Wallace collection,housed in Hertford House in Manchester Square.

hugely enjoyable. This amazing collection of painting, miniatures furniture, porcelain , chandeliers and weaponry is a must. It is not an enormous house but contains so much it should be visited and revisited, This is our second visit and will go again if I get the opportunity. ALSO it has an excellent courtyard restaurant.

Awesome Collection Walking Distance From Oxford Street. After 30+ trips to London I finally managed to spend an afternoon here recently. I wasblown away by the quality of the paintings, furnishings and armor on display here. This is an absolute gem of a museum housed in a former grand house that gives a different dimension to wandering from room to room. Admission is free and it is a large enough collection to warrant a return visit on my next trip. Excellent place.

A Must-See Collection of European Masters. Surpassed only by the National Gallery, the Wallace Collection displays, among many other exceptional pieces of art, an amazing number of Dutch and Flemish paintings from the 17th through 19th centuries - all in newly, beautifully restored galleries. Another highlight is the gallery with exquisite Canaletto and Guardi Venice paintings. All for free every day of the week.

Stunning furniture, pocelain and paintings. This amazing collection was built up by one family who decorated the house to show it off in rooms of authentic period design. Then they gave it to the nation and it is free to visit.This must be one of the finest collections of French 17th and 18th century furniture, porcelain and paintings in the world. All beautifully displayed in rooms with contemporary decoration.In addition there is a very fine art collection, much of it displayed in a purpose built gallery.There is also an armoury collection but we did not have time to visit this

Compact Collection. A beautiful house that has been converted to a stunning collection of paintings, furniture and armory. Relatively easy to move around and examine this fine collection. Friendly staff and good location in London's Manchester Square make this a must for those who appreciate the fine craftsmanship of the past. Seeing Frans Hals' 'The Laughing Cavalier' at close quarters was a real bonus.

Hidden Gem behind Oxford Street. I never knew the Laughing Cavalier picture was hung here!A great gallery with pictures, cameos and all sorts of memarobilia from the past.Just north of Oxford Street with a quiet restaurant included within.

Stunning building & location.. It's hard to miss The Wallace Collection in Manchester Square, and the rooms inside are even more beautiful - if you're an art lover, you'll find plenty to love. There are lots of paintings, artifacts, and objects (mostly French), and a little cafe behind the building. Well worth a look.No flash photography nor filming.

One of London's Best Kept Secrets. I love the Wallace. I come here frequently when I need to get away from busy bustling London. The collection is extensive, and is set in the beautiful interiors of the house on Manchester Sq. There is a large collection of Dutch Genre paintings, including Rembrandt and De Hooch. There are also many orientalist/exoticist paintings by artists such as Delacroix and Delaroche.

Treasure for the eyes. This is a static collection. It is a treasure of beautiful pieces, art, etc. It is truly amazing and is a must for a visit. Room after room reveals the most amazing objects. It has a friendly and accessible feel to it. Do please visit. You really will not be disappointed.
Fascinating collection of truly beautiful things.. A beautiful collection of silver and porcelain. Also some wonderful doors. A quite unique collection.

Must see!. I go to London once or twice a year and each time I come to the Wallace Collection. It's a free great place to visit, one of the few places where you can see a lot of Boulle furniture, beautiful clocks, fireplaces, and superb paintings. A lot of these coming from France and being acquired during or after the French Revolution. It's never crowdy, you have plenty of space and time to visit.

A little gem. a wonderful small intimate art gallery and museum. Well worth the visit. Not overwhelming and a little bit of wonder fro everyone, from paintings to furniture to porcelain to armour. Nice modern courtyard restaurant.
Little gem. A nice collection in a beautiful stately home. Its fun to see collections housed in a home - after you've seen them museums for so long.

Wonderful Porcelain. This is a wonderful place to visit - for the house, for the art and because it's my passion, the porcelain. It's a free museum with a good restaurant/cafeteria and plenty to see - and most of the furniture and art is up close and almost touchable.The Wallace Collection is one of the highlights of any visit but, whilst discovered by many, it is still a secret for even more, especially the tourists. Get there early to enjoy it the most and visit time and again as you will always spot something unique that you missed on any of your previous visits!

Excellent collection of arts. What a collection of incredible art and artefacts. A family collection never to be added to or taken away and expertly informed by the tour guide giving an insight into the family and the history of the art. A free entry museum in a superb house with a small but well stocked gift shop at very reasonable prices and a lovely cafe/ restaurant. One cannot stress the quality, variety and rarity of the vast collection as you wander casually around each room of the house marvelling at the amazing pieces in the setting of an amazing building. We took the guided tour and would recommend everyone to take for an hour to get an understanding of the family who built and donated this collection to the British people

Just glorious. This small but full loaded museum is a delight to visit. Recently refurbished all the rooms now sing with colour. The porcelain art and miniatures are truly glorious. Not too much to take in, though give yourself a few hours.

A lovely museum, full of treasures - and completely free!. I was introduced to the Wallace Collection 20 years ago when studying history of art at UCL. I remember being amazed then that I had never heard of it, having visited a great number of museums and galleries in the capital growing up. I don't think much has changed, with this wonderful museum maintaining its best hidden treasure in London reputation.The are endless treasures to discover, but our favourite rooms are the suits of armour for both men and horses and also 'Brizo, the Shepherd Dog' and the Landseer animal paintings, all on the ground floor. Then there is the plethora of French frou frous to be found on the 1st floor by Boucher, Fragonard and similar. However, there is so much more and they helpfully identify a different treasure within the collection each month; this has been going since 2003, so they've got quite a few.As well as the riches on display, the Wallace Collection also has a very lovely restaurant in the central courtyard of the building, providing the perfect London al fresco experience; trees, flowers... and a roof. The shop also deserves a mention, a good source of somewhat less naff than usual fine art related pressies.
Amazing paintings and furniture. So good to see The Laughing Cavalier - a wonderful portrait. More art than you can take in on a single visit. Visit the armoury downstairs too.

An amazing collection! Highly recommended.. It would be remiss of any visitor to London to pass up the opportunity to enjoy this superb collection. I particularly enjoyed the 13 pieces by Dutch artist Jan Weenix although I daresay there will be something within the vast collection to cater for most tastes. A must-see. Highly recommended.
Glorious!. Stunning collections, an oasis of calm off Oxford Street (behind Selfridges), smart cafe and just a joy. Go!!

Wow what a collection!. A huge eclectic collection of art and historic curios and it's free! Loved our visit here. The building is recently refurbished and the interiors are gorgeous. One of the museums in London that gets overlooked. If you are in the capital make sure the Wallace Collection is on your itinerary it really is fantastic .
Fascinating record of a golden age. The china and glass is beautiful in this house, originally a private home. There are several floors with vitrines full of priceless artefacts and a very good shop.

Excellent and free!. During my year-long residence in London, I've visited the Wallace four times. So vast and spectacular is the arms and armor collection alone that I've yet to make it upstairs to the art galleries. Each time I go, I see something new and the visiting family members I drag along with me are impressed and more fascinated than they expected to be.It's open 7 days a week and costs nothing--add it to your must-see list!
Private tour. I was fortunate enough to get a private tour of the Wallace collection as part of a corporate day. I will defiantly be heading back as not all of the collection was open at this time

SUPERB COLLECTION OF OLD MASTERS. The Wallace Collection is a wonderful gallery/stately home just a few minutes from Oxford Street. The collection is really amazing with Old Master paintings in every room. There is a whole room devoted to Canaletto and other Venetian artists. Gainsboroughs, Dutch painters and of course the iconic Laughing Cavalier (Franz Hals) Even if you don't know anything about art you will recognise many of the pictures as they are on posters, chocolate boxes, book jackets, etc. A very accessible and user friendly gallery for those who might find the National or Tate a bit overwhelming. And it is free! It is a place you could keep visiting as it has so many wonderful paintings.

Londoners' best secret. The world stops at Oxford Street... Londoners instead walk 100 yards more and end up in Manchester Square, cross it, and find refuge from the world and its chaos at the cafe' and brasseries at the back of Hertford House.For those more interested in art than food, the collection is absolutely outstanding: nothing to envy to the National Gallery in terms of Old Masters (Guardi, Canaletto among others) without the queues and noise. A step into another world!

Great collection. This was a private collection and was left to the state at the end of the nineteenth century. It is still housed in its original location. It is made up of armour, furniture, ceramics, glass and paintings & miniatures. The collection is strong in French Rococo with works by Boucher and Frogonard. There are two rooms largely devoted to Venetian vedutes by Canaletto and Guardi. Their collection of Dutch works are very strong. The most important works are displayed in the Great Gallery including works by Rubens, Titian, Poussin and the painting most associated with the gallery, the Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals.One condition of the bequest transferring the collection to the state was that no items could be loaned or sold. Despite this the museum does run temporary exhibitions with objects loaned from other museums.Entrance is free with donations accepted. There is a restaurant on site in the central courtyard.

Surprising and delightful. Glassed-over conservatory with choice of restaurant or cafe. Peaceful, airy and spacious. Super spot for a nice romantic lunch after a browse in the remarkable Wallace Collection gallery. Best to book for lunch as can be busy.

Great Attraction in London. I read an article in an English magazine so thought I would go to see this. Its like the Frick Collection in New York in that it is set in a grand private house only much more so as the collections here of art, furniture, armour and porcelain are huge. You follow the house through and see room after room stuffed with Rembrandts, Vermeers and countless other important artists ( I am really not doing it justice) , the beautiful furniture is like art in itself and the collections of porcelain are again amazing to look at and study the detail. Its all free and all belonged to one family who owned the house and gave it to the nation. Unlike other London Museums its not crowded.Finally there is a great cheap restaurant in the middle of the place that serves nice food. If you are mobility challenged this again is for you as its a good size to get around and has ramps and lifts to ensure you see everything an able bodied person does. Visit it as you won't regret it.
Afternoon out. A smaller but no less interesting Museum . Great for an afternoon of culture and education . We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves .

An astonishingly eclectic collection, even for a very rich family in the 18th and 19th centuries.. In real terms art prices are now at astronomic levels; during the period of over a century in which successive Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard and Lady Wallace were assembling this collection - or in reality series of different collections - they were more reasonable, but one still had to be seriously rich to build up even one of many different categories within this gallery: and it's free.Manchester Square is slightly off the beaten track, which may be why the collection receives fewer visitors than some less impressive museums and galleries, but it's within easy reach of Oxford Street (Bond Street underground) and Baker Street.Different areas house different collections. There was one point at which I felt slightly overwhelmed by the ornate French 18th century furniture, displayed with appropriate paintings, but then suddenly found myself in a room with an astonishing collection of Canalettos and other Venetian paintings. Then one suddenly sees a self-portrait of Rembrandt, looking across the room at a portrait of his son. Much copied paintings such as 'The Laughing Cavalier' (by Hals) live here.The collection of arms and armour is another collection that could justify an gallery of its own.I don't think it possible to absorb everything that is here in one visit. Having lived in London several times, and still visiting fairly frequently, I am wondering why it's been on my list for quite so long without my managing to visit, but I shall be back.There is also a cafe in the orangery (although some reviewers seem only to have noticed the cafe).A visit is highly recommended, but I also recommend being selective.

One of my favourite things to do in London!. The collection is awesome. The staff are just amazing and the restaurant is very good value and lovely. Excellent for afternoon tea or just a place to spend a delightful afternoon.

SUMPTUOUS. Haven't been here for a couple of years and have forgotten how great it is. Free, but a donation recommended.The painting are of great quality, the furniture and fitting outstanding.As a bonus we were treated to a 15 minute talk by an expert on some of their object d'arte; in this case two exquisite gold plaques.You could spend hours here, limited only by your stamina.And you have the covered courtyard restaurant as a bonus.An underused London attraction.

Interesting, uncrowded, and free. This private home and collection were well worth a look. The treasures inside were many and the docents helpful. Downstairs there was even a place to try on the armor worn in ancient times.

Stunning collection of paintings & objets d'art. The museum is filled with the most amazing collection of porcelain, furniture, armour, beautiful objects and fabulous paintings including The Laughing Cavalier. Free entry & quite close to the centre of London. The perfect way to spend a few hours!

Delightful and relatively off the beaten track. We came here primarily to escape the incessant rains and to allow our children to try on the replica medieval armor in their basement. We were pleasantly surprised that the entire building was filled with treasures, all presented in a very digestible and manageable way.

a true gem and a place I keep coming back to. This is bar far the best private house museum I have ever visited. Wallace Collection is a must see to all classic art enthusiasts. With a great collection of antique furniture, paintings, rare porcelain, armours and weaponry you won't get a chance be bored. I easily spend two hours there on each visit. It is a gem!

Everything and More!. My favorite museum by far! I have been to at least five other ones and this one has been the most amazing of them all. There is a variety of paintings, armor, jewelry, small ornate items, etc. in this museum. The employees of the museum were nice and were extremely helpful. The most famous painting in the museum would be the Laughing Cavalier which you can find in the largest room of the museum on the 1st floor.There is a beautiful courtyard where you can enjoy a meal and the area was not crowded at all.Fun fact, if you are a Frozen fan, you can see the girl on the swing as you saw with Anna as she jumped in the air in front of a painting.

Breathtaking Collection. Just a beautiful collection of furniture, porcelain and artworks. Hard to believe such a volume of works could be collected by a family. over two levels you need well over an hour to do justice to this visit. A lot of French furniture and porcelain. stunning.

Stylish venue, tasty good and attentive service . We enjoyed a leisurely Saturday lunch. This is a wonderful venue located in the courtyard (now covered by a glass atrium) of a town mansion. The ambiance is enhanced by the wonderful collection of art & antiques which are displayed in a rooms suitably decorated and furnished. It is a hidden gem. Food was tasty and beautifully presented and the service was polished and attentive. Make the effort to visit and enjoy this venue.

A gem of a find close to the West End. Small but beautiful.Fabulous range of exhibits from art to armour.Some lovely paintings and fantastic porcelain and all free!.Not too big to be overpowering-a couple of hours will be sufficient.Good restaurant on site.

Interesting visit. Interesting property that is worth a visit if you have a few days to see the sights of London. It's free to get in. The cafe was lovely. Very nice ambience and I'd recommend the cream tea.

Best Value in London. Best value because it's totally free. One of the worlds greatest collections of paintings, armour, weapons, and other historical artefacts.Leave the Metro at Bond St and walk North to Manchester Square. The Collection is North of the Square.I suggest leave a donation to help with the upkeep of this fabulous house and it's contenrpts.Do NOT forget to have a light lunch in the orangery. The food and wine and extremely good.

Wow. Great interior decoration, furniture, porcelain, armoury, it's all there in abundant quantity and quality. But the Dutch and Flemish masters are also here: Van Dijck, Rubens, Hals, Rembrandt, Brouwer (!) and Teniers. Don't forget to make a small donation, the admission is free. Highly recommended.
oasis of calm in a manic city. Situated in the manic bedlam near Oxford Circus this is a wonderful Museum and well worth a visit. Enjoy

non famous and charming place. This wonderful small museum has a great interesting collection of oil paintings, furnitures, pocelain items etc. its not very famous so it's not a crouded place. very magical in my eyes

Very beautiful art.. A free art collection which is not so well know but very worth going to . Not for those who prefer modern art but good for those who appreciate good old fashioned aesthetic art . Paintings from the 18th century as well as armory, furniture and china. Very beautiful building.
A surprisingly lovely museum. My son and I visited 12 museums on this vacation. This was one of the finest. Highly recommended for families with children.

Lovely small museum. This is a gem . A museum in what was a private house. Packed with French, Dutch and English old masters as well as a display of armour. Some ceramics. Courtyard garden restaurant ( covered) good servic
A Hidden Gem. This museum is not far from Selfridges and deserves to be better known. Its French collections are superb. The restaurant is terrific with interesting food and excellent service.

Surprisingly wonderful. This was a totally new discovery for me in London. Added it to our itinerary because it was conveniently close to our hotel and helped to fill out our program during a short city trip. I must say I was pleasantly surprised. The collection was much richer than I had expected with some really excellent paintings and much besides. The rooms themselves are quite a sight themselves.I venture to think that many people who visit London have never heard of this Museum and only discover it by chance. It is a real gem though, and I would recommend it to anybody.

A museum/collection that you can 'do' in just a few well spent hours. The Wallace Collection is certainly worth a visit, too much to list here but you can spend an enjoyable few hours stepping back in history and staying for lunch or dinner at either of their dining options.

An exquisite museum in the heart of London. The Wallace Collection is the home of the famous painting: The Laughing Cavalier. it's a beautiful building with many historical features. There are a huge range of other paintings of different styles and eras, to enjoy, as well as a super collection of clocks ( you really want to be there when they strike) and armour . When my son was younger, he absolutely loved all the armour. The jewel in the crown is the beautiful restaurant. it's a huge-domed feature in the building, but also very cool and spacious. They serve wonderful food and drinks there and it's a wonderful place to relax during your visit. There is no charge for the Museum, but please make a donation - we need places like this to share our wonderful heritage.

Wonderful Wallace Collection. Fabulous place with well arranged exhibits such as the Laughing Cavalier. One of Londons' hidden gems that will enthrall all visitors.Also a first class cafe/restaurant in a fantastic environment, a bit like an Orangery, Light and airy.

A serendipitous find. Wandered past with no set plans for my last day in the UK and decided to just pop in and see if it was worth a visit. After climbing the stairs and turning into the first room I was hooked. Absolutely amazing rooms filled with 17th and 18th century art, antiques and furniture. No crowds so you could wander around and enjoy. I had been to the National Gallery, Portrait Gallery and Tower but if you are short on time you could just visit this collection and see famous art work and a nicer display of armour and weaponry downstairs. To my delight I spotted one of my favourite paintings - "The Laughing Cavalier". If I'm ever back in London I will put this on top of my list of things to see. Definitely worth leaving a donation as admission was free.

Very interested place. I read about this place in a travel book.You can take your time. Going thru This beautiful place. It's not crowed.It has so many beautiful paintings and furniture and rooms of armor.the building it self is beautiful.

Mesmerising!. I remember hearing about Rembrandt and Titian during high school art classes and never imagined I'd see their work in reality rather than in text books - the artwork alone at The Wallace Collection is amazing but when you add the furnishings, chandeliers, armoury and everything else, it's like a magical trip through history. Thank you for an amazing afternoon - I highly recommend this venue!

Quite a formal atmosphere. This is a beautiful house and it's full of top quality pictures and furnishings. The original family were clearly very wealthy, but generous in donating this to the Nation. Maybe it's that history that made me feel it's a formal atmosphere, but staff were generally very welcoming. Where it's delightfully informal is on the fairly small piece of grass outside the front entrance. Lunchtime found it full of young office workers sitting on the grass eating their varied lunches, from Greggs to Pret a Manger! Enjoy your visit

Gorgeous interior with even better collection. Not only is the decoration of the inside of this stunning, the collection is just as amazing. It was nice to explore the beautiful works of art. Besides me and my friends, there were a few other people. It was great to have so much space to look at each work without having people over your shoulders. Recommend for art lovers.

Interesting private museum with excellent tearoom. A great free collection located in a beautiful old house in central London. Not on the beaten track, but only a short walk from Bond Street tube station. (not far from Selfridges)An outstanding collection of paintings by a number of well known English, Dutch and Italian artists. There is also an extensive collection of period furniture, China, armour and other collectiblesYou need quite a lot of time to see all there is. We spent four hours there (including a long lunch!) and didn't see everything.There is a small gift shop as well.There is an excellent café in the covered atrium which serves lunches and teas
Interesting spot. This if an off the grid attraction with an excellent restaurant in the square. how the wealthy once lived
Amazing Collection and a great restaurant. Meet here and view the exoansive collection and then dine in the covered patio restaurant, Avocado on toast and the best Victoria Sponge ever!

A Great Collection of Porcelain, Furniture Pieces, and Paintings of Good Taste. A great collection of porcelain, furniture pieces, and paintings of good taste. I found a piece of lacquered wood furniture with Mt. Fuji on it. I had a light lunch here. Tea is served in Nambu ironware from Japan here.

One of the Best. Slightly off the beaten path, Wallace Collection is one thing: AMAZING. A previously private collection, it was opened to public for free (probably one of the request of the owner). Here, you can see one of the best art collection in Western hemisphere, hosted in one of the most beautiful building in London. I went there just because I was in the area and had a few hours to spent, and I regretted that I did not come here sooner. I am not a fine art enthusiast, but Wallace Collection is still amazing!

Don't Miss This One. One of the reasons TripAdvisor works so well is people find places like The Wallace Collection and post reviews for others. That is the only reason I heard about it! I had plenty of things planned in London, but based on the rave reviews, I dropped by one day to visit, and this was one of the highlights of my entire trip. Beautifully decorated rooms, uncrowded, treasures of art and furniture (each room done in different hues, with matching draperies and wall coverings), all sorts of wonderful things to see. After you visit all the "obvious" spots in London; Windsor, Westminster Abbey, etc., make sure you take time to discover this hidden gem.

A long held wish fulfilled. Many, many years ago I read an article about the Wallace Collection and despite many visits to London since then, had never managed to find time to view the collection. I was not disappointed. Mainly interested in the paintings but saw many other interesting items on display. Was still in the building at closing time, so perhaps I shall have to make another visit.
