Another interesting famous Museum. If you love ostentation and gilt galore you will love this collection. Mostly boring for me but loved the miniature snuff boxes. The building is another architecturally designed attraction and superb restaurant with delightful surroundings
Delightful. This is a gem of a museum, charmingly intimate despite an interesting assortment of items on view. Well worth a visit.

Great place to visit, more should know about this place!. The antiques are amazing, the armour is visually stunning from around the world. Each room has a different collection from sevre pottery, miniatures, pill boxes. Then you go upstairs to more collections. Paintings are beautiful from Rembrandt to titian then to the famous laughing cavalier. Restaurant in the middle serves great food. Basement allows the children to try on armour. Great place to go not just once as you'll miss things the first time around.

Free gem in the heart of the West End. It is the greatest collection of 18thC furnition and 17th and 18th painting in the heart of the West End. It is absolutely massive and free. Fragonard's "swing" is there as well as Boule's 17th and 18th century numerous cabinets. Basically, when the Bourbon had to leave France they sold their lots and there it is.... after a few memorable auctions. Magnificient.There are free tours. Just Turn up and wait in the front hall. The staff are lovely and very knowledgeable.The restaurant is great.It is 3 minutes walk from the famous departement store Selfriges.It is an oasis of culture in the West End

A Hidden Gem. Before I worked in Baker Street, I didn't know this museum existed. I found it by chance when I went for a walk during a lunch hour and was astonished by the quality and number of paintings and other objects that it contains. I have been back several times since then and I always find something new and unusual. Highly recommended.

Can't believe I have not been before. A small easily accessible collection with some amazing antique furniture as well as paintings and miniatures. The cafe is a lovely spot to stop for tea afterwards or for any reason really !

Hidden Gem. There is just about enough art to see and appreciate. The house itself is impressive! It is located near the shopping area of Oxford Street. My teen-aged daughter and I have visited 3 times. We love their collection of paintings by Rembrandt and Titian. They have an extraordinary collection of armoury. The museum is simply beautiful!
A hidden tranquil place in London. Never been here before, but it was fantastic, not as crowded as some, we booked an afternoon cream tea in a beautiful atrium

Stunning art and antique collection in a stunning stately London home setting. The Wallace is a private collection of art and antiques located in central London. The collection of art, antique furniture and crockery and armory displayed in a stately London hone over two floors is almost overpowering.This is simply one of the most stunning displays we have ever encountered outside a National museum is a great experience. There is also a lovely restaurant in an enclosed inner courtyard with a glass roof.Entry is free which is even better!
amazing !. This is a great experience for any art or antiques lover...there are a wealth of treasures here AND its free admission !Recommended

The hidden gem near Oxford Street. The Wallace collection is one of those museums you never forget once having visited. It is packed with extraordinary treasure from centuries of past. Particularly impressive is the collection of arms and armour, which is an unexpected plus in a museum full of so many beautiful art exhibits. If you get a chance, take a couple of hours to go and see, then you can go shopping after!

An out of the way treasure. I had never heard of the Wallace collection but my son who is into medieval weapons had to stop here and we were not disappointed. A bit out of the way but then, it wasn't crowded like the big museums. We enjoyed it very much.
Wallace Collection. A lovely display of antiques. Sadly we spent toooooo much time over coffee in the lovely conservatory. Must visit again
Hidden Gem. What a great experience ! Lots of interesting exhibits. Tea rooms and restaurant at the centre of the Museum. Great location to visit and spend a day. Would revisit, also it is free !

woWallace Collection. We visited on a soggy day in May 2016. The collection is the accumulation of five generations of one family sheltered in the historic residence of a marquis. Each generation added their own twist to their exquisite acquisitions. Italian and French Renaissance paintings. Masters. Armory. Porcelain. Snuff boxes with musicale masterpieces. Furniture. Silver. Decorative pieces. All tastefully displayed as a private collector might, in an opulent residence, now 25 galleries including one grand gallery that has just been refurbished.I have loved the Louvre, the Rijksmuseum, the National Galleries in the US and the UK, The Chicago Art Institute and the Detroit Institute of Arts. But this was my very favorite art experience. It was more up close and personal in a grand space. And it seemed largely low key and FREE. I almost hate to reveal its appeal for fear next time I visit it will be over run. It is the perfect place to visit on a rainy London day-- or any day. If I lived in London, I might visit a gallery a month, taking two years to consider the details of the collection and then begin again. The galleries were serene and uncrowded. Embraced by the rich decor, quiet visitors carefully consider the works Van Eyck, Rubens, Rembrandt, Titian and Hals-- just in ONE of the 25 galleries. Miniature scenes in unbelievable detail layered jeweled snuff boxes. Hard armory and silver shine reflected in gilded mirrors. The intimacy and perfection of the space was alluring, making a departure, especially onto the soggy streets, seem a ridiculous notion. We had hoped to have tea or lunch in the Wallace Collection's courtyard restaurant, but it was closed for filming of a television segmen. That will have to wait till next time.
See "The Swing"!. A lovely half day activity. Great fun to see "The Swing". Wonderfully curated. Nice gift shop.Grab a cup of tea in the courtyard!

'Little Secret'. London has and will always keep surprising you. As it happens when you find yourself wondering through the various rooms at the Wallace Collection. Dutch, Flemish, French and Italian masters are dotted on the walls. No cues, peaceful and additionally an incredible collection of miniatures and armoury. And for those hungry and looking for a unique lunch place... try the centre court restaurant.
Amazing tour by rosanna. Excellent day today looking at the collection. Staff are amazing, especially rosanna who did the tour (I think that was her name, very glamorous Italian lady)

Treasure Trove of Art in Central London. Pros: high-quality and comprehensive collection of paintings and furniture, gorgeous historical setting, highly informative booklets available for perusal, free.Cons: the information booklets were quite heavy/ unwieldy.

Amazing fine art and furniture . My wife and I enjoyed a wonderful time here. We had the tour which gave us insight into the lives of French and English royalty in the 17th and 18th centuries. The lady giving the tour talked briefly about a couple of pieces of art in each room giving taste of the collection and then we went back and spent more time on our own. Highly recommend.
A fantastic collection in a gorgeous setting. This is a truly fantastic collection hidden away in Manchester Sq.the collection is the best of the best.

Remebrant, Boucher, and the finest armory collection I've Ever seen.. It's FREE for those traveling on a budget but donations are welcome.Not only are you seeing some of the finest maters paintings in the world but helped by a wonderful museum staff who are so informative and pleasant to guide you. There are free tours of the collection also through out the day.Do take one mine was excellent. If you have any knowledge of metal smith techniques you will be blown away by the armory collection from India and England. Never have i so many jewels inlaid in such beautiful enamel that were not in jewelry but weapons.. GO GO GO you will be amazed. There is a Court Yard restaurant with delightful fresh options. On a budget eat outside in the grass under a tree in front of the museum. Lots of people were enjoying lunch in this little greensward.

An intimate, enchanting venue I can't believe I had missed before. Mum and I spent a good few hours in this amazing venue. The story behind the Wallace family and the collection is fascinating. The condition and presentation of the pieces second-to-none and extensive visitor notes are available at all displays. There are enough rooms to switch around if you encounter a noisy school group and it's easy to return to a room you may have skipped earlier. No queues, free entry and a brasserie set in the stunning glass-roofed courtyard all made this a very pleasant visit indeed.
A Hidden Gem. A free art and historical collection. Numerous original paintings, medieval artifacts, furniture and the like. Located on a quiet street in a beautiful setting not far from Selfridges.

Favorite art museum in London. A truly gorgeous collection that somehow still feels like a secret, though I'm sure it's not anymore. It's not as huge or flashy as the National Gallery, but the building is gorgeous, chock-full of incredible paintings, and more intimate and cozy-feeling by far. It gives the impression that you're walking through a great London townhouse of yore, and it's a lovely place to wander on a rainy day.

stayed locally. Wouldn't normally have gone here, but it was just down the road from our hotel.A rather fascinating place and well worth spending an hour or so visiting.Knowledgeable staff, a restaurant and shop. Free admission.

A gem. I have been to London many times but just found out about the Wallace Collection this year. We loved it and wished we could have spent more time in this beautiful museum. The art collection was wonderful as was the collection of arms and armor. We didn't eat at the restaurant but it looked lovely. The Wallace Collection should be on any art lovers radar.

A little gem off the beaten path. For those museum goers who are into houses rather than large less personal spaces for the display of cherishable art, the Wallace Collection will be right up their alley. A rather large mansion nestled behind Manchester Square, this museum houses numerous paintings from the Dutch Old Masters including the famous Franz Hals Laughing Cavalier as well as Canaletto's many views of the Venetian canals from different perspectives. There are many 18th century French paintings as well. Those into home furnishings will delight in the Sevres porcelains, vases, mantlepiece sculptures and clocks. The basement has an impressive array of suits of armor and medieval weaponry. It is mind-boggling to thinks that these various items were collected by a single family. Well worth the visit and for those wishing an American frame of reference, think New York's Frick Museum.

Well worth a visit. This is one of London's best kept secrets. Not unlike The National Gallery, but much smaller, more intimate and thankfully without the throng of humanity. A total of 28 rooms and 5,500 artworks—far too many to be seen in one go, so plan for a second visit and make sure you take advantage of the free tours that occur almost daily. The overall feeling is French: sculptures, Boulle furniture, Sèvres porcelain, and oodles of 17th and 18th century objets d'art. There are also a variety of temporary exhibitions, medieval and Renaissance armor (some of which you can try on) and paintings by masters including Velàzquez, Reynolds, Delacroix and Van Dyck (don't miss The Laughing Cavalier by Hals). The Wallace Restaurant is dramatically lit by a spectacular glass atrium. The menu is (not surprisingly) French, but the service can be a bit hit-and-miss.

A wonderful collection of paintings, furniture and armoury. I was delighted to see this wonderful collection of paintings, furniture and armoury. Go in the morning so you can have morning tea or lunch in the atrium café. Fun to do with family or friends you could spend hours there and it's free entry. The gift shop has a great range of reasonably prices gifts including jewellery and books

My second visit in 10 years, well worth it and my 13 yr old daughter loved it.. Wonderful collection of porcelain, beautiful paintings and a good collection of armor and weapons. My daughter loved trying on the reproduction armor downstairs below the cafe.

Another world class collection of art to enjoy while visiting London. If you enjoy the works of the great masters, do not miss a visit to this collection. The entire experience was fantastic, one of my best while in London. Much less crowded than the National Gallery (which is still feasible and worthwhile) and the British Museum (a disaster thanks to overcrowding), but with a world class collection nonetheless. Highly recommended!!

Great venue. Attended a private function there. The eventing started with cocktails and canapés in the large gallery which houses a massive collection of masterworks, most famously the Laughing Cavalier.A long day could be spent just in this gallery but remember there are others and of course there is an amazing collection of weapons and armour.We then moved into the covered courtyard and then the food flowed fast and beautiful. Amazing selection of finger foods varying from fish and chips to mini shepherds pies and way beyond . Desserts a plenty , chocolate moose, strawberries etc etcAll beautiful This must be one of the best private function rooms in all of London, fantastic highly trained and charming staffA night to remember and savour for years

Free entry. This is a great museum tucked behind Selfridges in Manchester square, plenty to see including great painters such as Rembrant, Canneletto, the most famous painting is The Laughing Cavalier, had a very enjoyable 2 hours here but could have stayed longer, this a museum you could visit every week, there is much to see, loved it.

Excellent Sunday morning/early afternoon activity. We went to the Wallace Collection after spending part of the morning in the markets. I love how easy it is to hope on the tube and go to the next sight fast. Get off at the Bond street stop and head up Duke street toward Manchester square. When you get to the square, go around to the right. The entrance is at the back of the garden. There is so much beautiful art to see here. Plan on two or more hours. When you are done, you can pop over to Oxford Street for some shopping or walk a little further to Hyde Park.

Beyond Impressive!. If you go off the beaten path, you will find one of London’s finest small galleries. Most tourists miss this gallery completely and it should not be missed. The collection is a captivating glance into 18th-century aristocratic life, set up in a sumptuous, restored, Italianate mansion crammed with 17th- and 18th-century art works. The gallery is most famous for its old master paintings and 18th century French porcelain and furniture displayed in breathtaking rooms. They also feature an excellent collection of arms and armor in Britain as well as gold boxes, miniatures, sculpture and medieval and renaissance works of art such as Majolica ceramics, glass and Limoges enamels.Free - Tube Stations: Bond Street or Baker Street

Well worth a look! And FREE!. The Wallace Collection was amazing. It was lovely to be able to get so close to the artworks and displays without being roped off and having to view from afar. The rooms and decor were stunning. Weaponry section was huge. We had our 11 year old, and whole family enjoyed it. I think we would have been there for about an hour or so, which was enough time for us as a family.It was wonderful to have a "free" activity as many of our other London attractions cost so much money.

A Somewhat Hidden Gem. If elephant's armor doesn't tickle your fancy, or assorted pieces of remarkable nature, then don't bother with the Wallace Collection. On the other hand, if you're keen on some truly extraordinary and remarkable pieces, this venue is well worth a visit.

Excellent Period Museum, Free Entrance . This is a beautiful old house in central London. A short walk from Bond Street tube station.Has some wonderful old masters and generally a huge collection of paintings by a numerous of well known English, Dutch and Italian painters. It includes the famous Laughing Cavalier. Worth the trip just to see it. An outstanding collection of paintings.There is also an extensive collection of miniatures, China, carriages, armour and other collectiblesYou need quite a lot going time to see all there is. There is a small gift shop as well.There is also a cafe in the covered atrium which serves lunches and teas which although we didn't stop this trip I have in the past and remember it to be quite good.Best of all its free.

Stunning. This may be one of the most beautiful galleries in London. It is a legacy of successors to the 4th Marquis of Hertford and was granted as a gift to the state in 1897. The legacy imposed several restrictions on the works of art in the bequest: they could not leave the home, they could never be sold or loaned and they must be available to the public to enjoy. The museum is free, tours are offered throughout the day and there is a beautiful enclosed courtyard restaurant. We went early in the morning on a Saturday and it was not too crowed. We took the first tour available and it was very informative, covering the major works in all the rooms. This is a place we will go back to many times: the art collection is stunning in its historic sweep and here is so much to absorb it is best to take it in small chunks. I think this is one of the true gallery gems in London.

Solid museum especially for armor. I think the rating of this museum collection depends on your taste in art. We enjoyed the armor collection quite a bit, but the paintings were really not to our tastes. The furniture was incredible as well as the fully dressed rooms, but there was just so much stuffed into one house that it made it difficult to appreciate the art fully.

March. This is an excellent museum. The collection, which displays wonderful works of art collected in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, is very accessible and quite personal as it is situated in a beautiful grand house. Everyone is so helpful and the restaurant is well worth a visit. It is a gem of a place, tucked away behind all the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street. Take time out and visit a place of calm and charm.

Lovely place for a day trip. Been here twice, 1s time was catching up with friend in the lovely cafe. Finally I get to visit the house. It is pretty and with a lots of character. Can't believe it is free administration and free tour. The tour guide is very good, we learn alots. Love the ceramics and arms and armour collection. The restaurant and cafe are really nice if you like to have a short break during the visit. I have not complete my visit, I will back again.

Sophisticated, interesting, perfect size. Lovely shop & staff (took a tour) & interesting art pieces with a great cafe. It's beautiful, not often too busy, near Marylebone so cool shops around there.Some of the art is stunning and it allows you the space to have a look. Recommend going on a tour to also get a history of the house.

Beautiful and not too big . Lovely collection, centrally located and not as enormous as some of the other museums in this town of art gems.
Free entrance and a plush cafe/restaurant in the nice court yard. Reduction on the afternoon tea if you have a visitors Oyster card.
Hidden Gem. Exquisite paintings , lovely furniture and a huge armory collection in a beautiful " home " setting! Enjoyed and definitely recommendEd.
Awesome. If you like fine antiques , clocks and good food you wil thoroughly enjoy this venue. I enjoyed all three. Booking is essential.

Fabulous museum and a great place for tea. Fed up with forcing your way through the crowds at the National Gallery? Cross Trafalgar Square and get on the bus to Bond St station, head towards Selfridges, and at the end of Duke Street you'll find the Wallace Collection, set in quiet and leafy Manchester Square.With its impressive if eclectic collections of paintings, furniture, porcelain and arms and armour, it's very reminiscent of New York's stately Frick museum but with one important difference: the Frick costs over $20, and the Wallace is free!On our last visit we treated ourselves to afternoon tea in the pretty atrium restaurant: not cheap, even with a 20% voucher it came to £33 for two and you couldn't have called it a huge spread, but it was all delicious and the service was excellent. You can book online to guarantee a table, and it closes at 4.30.

Impressing Collection. Now, this is not only paintings but a whole collection of art (china, jewelry, sculptures, furniture and paintings and a lot of more)And also offers a nice restaurant in the garden.A bit offsite but certainly worth a visit.
Eclectic Collection. Love this house and its rooms full of interesting collections. The conservatory for meals and afternoon tea is delightful!

What an amazing hidden gem. Found it by chance looking for something to do today. Easy to get to off Baker Street down a quiet street. Amazing residence with wow factor entrance hall. Went straight to the conservatory restaurant which seemed to do excellent afternoon teas - huge scones and cakes looked amazing. Just had salad for lunch which was great and service immaculate and first class. Excellent guide book taking you around all rooms in a house refurbished to its old grandeur with such style . All the pictures and furniture are in excellent condition by all the old masters, and then came across the laughing cavalier, who knew it was there !!! There was a guider son in each room who knew where everything was and explained all we needed to know. 3 hours passed so fast with only a brief look at everything. Will definitely be back, a huge congrats to all who work there and those who sponsor its upkeep, no crowds so a place to go anytime

The Wallace Collection is not to be missed!. I went to the Wallace Collection because my Mother wanted to see "Girl on a Swing" It was so much more! Our guide, Julia was amazing and gave us such an informative tour. SO much better than the pat audio tours one finds everywhere else. It was my favorite museum on our London tour and Julia brought the artwork to life with her stories of the artists and their sitters. Please take the time to see this wonderful museum!
Marvelous!. So much beauty. Free but not crowded. We spent about 1.5 hrs here. There's a cafeteria that serves lots of items including tea.

Amazing quiet secret away from bussle. What strikes you first is the quietness. You can wander about at your leisure and get information if and when you want. The rooms are packed full of interesting artefacts in this collection but my favourite bit is the enclosed glass topped orangery in the courtyard where a pot of tea and slice of cake is the amongst the best in the West End without the noise and bustle.

Amazing and Free!. The Wallace Collection is a gallery that is free to the public and has an impressive collection of art, weapons and armor. The gallery is in a large house and has many rooms to explore. Each room has different displays from paintings to collectibles to armor and weapons. You can easily spend hours in this place. I recommend you include it in any visit to London.

Dont leave London without visiting the Wallace Collection. Each time we visit London we always visit the Wallace Collection in Manchester Square just off Oxford Street.The collection of Artifacts Furniture Paintings and excellent workmanship in vases clocks and a multitude of fascination itemsneverfails to amaze me. Each visit is always as enjoyable as the previous . A Must when in London. Glorious

Best Display of 18th-century Art Ever!. If you want to experience the white-powdered and perfumed age of Marie-Antoinette, go to the Wallace Collection! It has a rich collection, especially of 18th-century French paintings (Watteau, Boucher, Fragonard), sculpture, furniture and porcelain---probably the best outside France. It's also known for its collection of arms and armour displayed in four rooms, plus a small but select group of 17th-century Dutch and Flemish paintings, including the most famous one in the collection: Frans Hals' humourous portrait "The Laughing Cavalier," where the soldier seems to be giving the viewer "the eye"!The gallery is tucked away in small, quiet Manchester Square in an elegant district just two blocks north of Oxford Street and Selfridge's Department store. It's the former home of a 19th-century politician and art collector, and the art objects are displayed much as they would have been when he lived there.The thing I like about this museum is that it's quiet, not overly crowded, and has only 24 manageable-sized rooms, so you can take your time. There's a beautiful sweeping staircase greeting you in the entrance hall, plus a good (though pricey) French-themed cafe/restaurant in the glass-covered courtyard. Also, there's a well-stocked gift shop to the left of the entrance where you can buy mini replicas of some of the pretty French snuff-boxes, jewellery boxes and china that you saw in the gallery spaces.A tip: make sure you're there when the hour changes, as a lot of the 18th-century clocks in the rooms announce the new hour with tinkling chimes!

So worth a visit!. This beautiful house really showcases an amazing collection of paintings, furniture and armory. I am so glad we made time to visit. The rooms are spacious, laid out well and just full of incredible work from renowned artists. I had no idea Rembrandt's self portrait would be waiting here for us! The weaponry rooms also held a vast number of gorgeous pieces from Asia and the Ottoman Empire, plus full suits of armory from Europe and India. We passed through a lovely cafe in the center housed by a glass roof. Would have made for a perfect break if we weren't on a tight schedule.

Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection is very highly recommended for those interested in old master paintings (Rembrandts), exquisite clocks, chandeliers, objets d'art, armoury collections, and lots more.It is almost directly behind Selfridge's, so relatively easy to find.Moreover, it is free, and also has free wifi.

An amazing visit. The following is a quotation from the Wallace Collection promotional material. It is accurate. The visit was truly amazing. Any person interested in London of the era - 1700 to 1900 - must not miss the collection. The armoury display is superior to that at The Tower of London.The collection of porcelain was amazing in its beauty, The Wallace Collection is a national museum in an historic London town house. In 25 galleries are unsurpassed displays of French 18th-century painting, furniture and porcelain with superb Old Master paintings and a world class armoury.

Best collection no crowd. The Wallace Collection is an amazing museum quality collection of impressive period antiques, armory, furniture and more. Great access to the collection, and best of all no crowds! Definitely worth the time.

Nice dining is a lovely setting. I am reviewing the cafe attached to the Wallace Collection.. Had lunch here with three friends after viewing the museum. The outdoor seating is just lovely and the food was really good. Service was good.

Quiet less crowded small London musuem. Prior to our visit to the Wallace Collection I have never heard of it, I would have to say that it is my favourite small museum in London and if ever we return to London it would be on my list to revisit.The Wallace Collection is located in Hertford House in Manchester Square, it is a free national musuem; open everyday expect over Christmas from 10am to 5pm. On the afternoon of our visit we joined a free guided tour lead by Nini who was very excited to be showing our group of 18-20 around, Nini wanted us to get the most of our her tour and our visit to the house, and that's exactly what we did over the next hour and twenty minutes. The collection is astounding, incredibly valuable and full of exquisite 18th century French artwork and objects. At the time of our visit there was a temporary exhibition of porcelain from Jean-Claude Duplessis from Serves, stunning craftsmanship.There are also paintings by Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Titan, Velazquez, Murillos, Frans Hals to name just a few to seek out. On the ground floor there is an extensive collection of arms and armour which is also well worth a visit. Overall visiting the Wallace Collection was a wonderful experience, a small and intimate museum with dedicated staff with very small crowds, and I very much look forward to revisiting.

A group of collections, really. We spent the better part of the afternoon at this huge old home which houses the multiple collections of the Wallace family, from old paintings, other works of art, old arm our and weaponry, and so on. I am not crazy about such things, but the size, grandeur and architecture of the house itself is what held my attention here. The house has been a foreign embassy and other uses, but its current life as a museum suits it just fine.

Wallace Collection.. An eclectic collection of paintings to suit every taste. When working nearby this was a wonderful place to visit. And not many people know of it, and so are missing a treat. I used to amuse myself by thinking of taking away the 'Laughing Cavalier' which seems to have pride of place.

A worthwhile visit. One of the very few "free" museums in London. It was a very worthwhile visit of a large and diverse private collection of fine European 16-18th century art and armor in what was a private residence. Walking distance from the Marble Arch area of London where I was staying. Add this to your repertoire of "things to see/do" in London. It will not disappoint!

Lovely boutique museum in the heart of London. This was a very interesting collection with something for all ages. For the kids there was an area in the basement where they could dress up in chainmail and other interactive exhibits. Upstairs was an interesting collection of antiques, art, and many oddities. Put aside a couple of hours for this place and you will not be disappointed. Unlike the mega-museums, this one is accessible and inexpensive.

A gem in the heart of a leafy London square. Stunning collection of paintings, sculptures, porcelain and other artefacts including the famous 'Laughing Cavalier' in a one-time city centre mansion... and it's free to enter. Excellent atrium restaurant for lunch, afternoon tea or dinner.
Best Art Museum in London!. This was such an intimate and lovely museum. The staff was kind and helpful. The art was fabulous and it wasn't over crowded. I will certainly go every time I'm in London.
Live the history. The rooms are just mesmerising. The art first class and then tea in the wonderful atruim...ahhhh BLISS

A hidden gem in Marylebone! . This is an amazing hidden gem not far from the crowded Oxford street - it locates in the Manchester square. The decoration is so grand and splashing - true rococo style. You often see many French people here to explore and absorb the culture. There is also a lovely cafe/restaurant in the courtyard - always busy but not noise at all - so you can enjoy a nice cup of tea to give your eyes a rest.

Beautiful free art collection. First visit to this lovely collection but we would very much like to go back. It is fantastic that such a beautiful collection is available free of charge to the public. I was introduced to some artists for the first time and there is still more for us to see. Also lovely light filled cafe with very nice cream tea. Recommended.

One of the most fascinating armouries you'll find. The armoury is one of the most jaw dropping you'll ever see. The variety of the weapons and armours, the fantastic condition they're in, the amount of historical detail you will find in the books available in each room... it's just an amazing display. Some of the highlights are the horse armors, but everything is incredible, including the oriental items.Apparently this place also contains portraits, china plates and stuff. You'd have to ask the wife, I spent the whole 3 hours in the armoury. Maybe she'll do another review.

Stunning art collection. The main reason for us visiting here was to see 'The Laughing Cavalier' and a wonderful sight it is. It hangs in the red room and is so inconspicuous that I watched many people walk past it without giving it a second glance but the whole collection is much more than just one painting and is well worth a visit.Unlike other museums this one feels very' homely' and friendly and you are even allowed to take photographs without being told off.Rain or shine this is well worth a visit and they have a really good restaurant/cafe we even had the company of Roger Daltrey no less. The Pimm's is also worth a try especially on a warm sunny day.

Amazing Docent Tour. The Wallace Collection was amassed by four generations of the same family. I had not expected much but a docent tour made the whole thing exceptional. The Collection is primarily 17th and 18th century Baroque and Rococo though it includes works by Dutch Masters too. This was stuff I normally would have little interest in. Yet the docent’s insights in a 1½ hour tour brought it alive. Bronze/turtle shell marquetry used in the period furniture was explained. In addition to furniture and paintings, the Collection houses the finest examples of European armor around. Who knew that armor imitates the clothing style of the period (makes it easy to date). Then there are the decorative arts displays, again one of the best collections to be seen in one place. Apparently that is the primary draw for this little museum. Each piece is more exquisite than the next. This was one of the most enjoyable museum visits ever for me (and we’ve been to plenty). We went out for lunch and actually reentered the museum for another hour.

Perfect afternoon . We have been here many times and always enjoy the experience. Starting at the imposing entrance the building has so much character. It's a FREE collection but please leave what you can to support the wonderful items, security and future additions. So much to see and explore that I will let you discover everything from arms, pottery, artworks, tapestries, glassware, jewellery etc etc etc. Finish of the experience with a fabulous British High Tea served in the covered atrium cafe. Perfect place to spend a morning or afternoon.

A Jewel of Rococo Art. Located in the Hertford House in Marylebone (just a few blocks from Selfridges), this charming museum maintains the feeling of what it would have been like to live in the Victorian townhouse of the Marquess of Hertford. Period furniture and paintings fill each of the lavish rooms--including the added on exhibition hall at the back. On the lower floor is a comprehensive collection of weapons and armor. Fragonard's The Swing is the most important Rococo work in the collection.The cafe and restaurant in the open-air central courtyard is a real treat!

Great Museum often overlooked. Ofter recommedn this place to freinds and visitors, a bit off the beaten track but wonderful decor and worth taking the guided tour. The courtyard was covered over a few years ago to make a restaurant that sadly has become expensive and an older "Afternoon tea" clientelle. But do visit here , amazing place!

a day in the most amazing museum. I was invited by colleague to have a spot of tea in the amazing atrium and could,nt resist walking through this treasure trove of antiquities. it was once of the best collection of armour, weopons and bespoke antiquities. A treasure trove in marlebone

A House of Treasures. My passion for pictures knows no bounds, and, not having been to the Wallace Collection for fourteen years, I decided that it was time for a return visit. My friend and I made our way to Manchester Square, Wigmore Street, behind Selfridges, and were just in time to join a guided tour. We began in the Billiard Room of this magnificent mansion, Hertford House, where we learned about the skillful technique of Boulle marquetry with an exquisite cabinet and desk. This fine craft is named after its inventor, André Charles Boulle (1742-1732), who perfected the technique of inlaying brass and tortoiseshell in wood.The Back State Room is home to a fabulous collection of dramatic Sèvres porcelain, particularly the work of one Jean-Claude Duplessis (1699-1774), a goldsmith and sculptor who designed gilt-bronze mounts and vase models of unprecedented technical and stylistic skill for twenty-five years. He took his inspiration from a variety of bizarre sources, including elephant trunks and royal table ornaments, to create the most beautiful and exuberant Rococo porcelain. (I would rather say Baroque, as it is too heavy and ornate for the Rococo style.) I particularly liked the pot-pourri vase in the shape of a ship, designed to dispel the human odours of the day, and the inkstand made for a princess, complete with a little bell with which to summon her maid.Organic shapes taken from nature, the principal source of the Rococo artists, manifest not only in the pieces displayed in great glass cases, but the fabulous chandelier which graces this room. A Louis XV chest of drawers has no straight lines; the designs are curled, like leaves, curved and sinuous, and decorated with gold.Forty percent of the Collection is arms and armoury, and the ornate Tudor armour on display are all works of art; it is sculpture, designed to make the wearers look larger than life, and more magnificent. Lord Sackville’s “Garniture of the field” has interchangeable pieces, and a rare 15th century Gothic German exhibit includes plate and chainmail armour for the knight’s horse as well as for the knight.The Large Gallery, the walls of which are covered with beautiful crimson silk, displays a collection of paintings which represents a “dialogue” between the great European masters - teachers and their pupils: Rubens, Rembrandt, Titian, Velasquez, Frans Hals, Van Dyck and Poussin. A highlight for me was Poussin’s A Dance to the Music of Time (1634-6), which depicts Jupiter’s gift to the world: wine. The four Seasons, and Saturn and Apollo, the gods of Time, dance to the music of Time’s lyre. It is a representation of the cycle of the human condition: day and night, life and death, and conveys a deep philosophical message.Three Dutch Galleries, lined in royal blue silk, display works by Rembrandt and his contemporaries. The dénouement, my favourite picture in all of London, hangs in the Oval Drawing Room: Jean-Honoré Fragonard’s The Swing (1767), displaying all the gloriously carefree and unbridled joie de vivre of the French Rococo.

A range of art in a location I would not have found. Set a bit away from the crowds, I particularly liked the Canalettos but also Dutch artists and porcelain and furniture from what was a private collection donated to the nation.Nice cafe in the courtyard as well with fab range of cakes
Art collection worth visiting. A lovely collection in a beautiful part of London . The house and eatery are a hidden delight, the art is amazing.

The best museum in London!. A collection that has a bit of everything. Some famous paintings hang here. Nice courtyard to have a bit to eat or some coffee. Truly on of the nicest, small collection museum I have ever been to. All at the top of my recommendation list.

Do Not Miss This!. We were overwhelmed with the collection of art in this museum. It rivals the other larger galleries in London. It is definitely well worth the visit. Just a small distance off Oxford Street.

Spectacular mansion in town. This home of Richard Wallace contains his incredible art and furniture collection. There are free tours at 2:30 each day. The audio guides are not great. They touch on only a small percentage of what's contained in the house. They should be better. The cafe is in a wonderful interior courtyard.

One of My Favorite Museums. This was the second time that my wife and I visited the Wallace Collection. The first time was several years ago when we visited London. The picture gallery there is wonderful and the paintings are very good. It is very nice to just sit there on a bench and view the huge room. The other collections like the furniture collection are very good too.

Surprisingly Fascinating. I am not a huge fan of viewing "collections" especially large ones. I humored my husband and tagged along. I have to admit I was impressed and intrigued. The collection is very large and very well presented. If you are detailed you could spend hours here.

Worth a visit !. This was recommended late in our trip, so glad we went to see this fabulous collection of art, jewellery, sculpture and much more in a beautiful location. And the atrium style cafe restaurant is a lovely way to end the visit.

Fabulous, under visited, perfect for an early lunch. This exquisite small museum has some of the most fabulous art in London. It was our pleasure to have discovered by way of a recommendation from someone from Oxford. The area where the museum is located is charming and the garden nearby is beautiful even as it is locked. The best art gift shop in town. Lunch was delicious and the setting was serene.

Beautiful oasis in central London. This museum is an oasis of calm in the middle of the city. Set in a quiet square behind Selfridges, it is a huge house crammed with mainly French historical treasures - artwork, furniture and porcelain and even an armoury. It is different from other museums in that it is set out just as it would have been when the family lived there. It is extremely opulent with silk covered walls and extravagant drapes and to get the most out of our visit we joined the free tour which was about 45 minutes long. The charming guide really knew the background of the house well and also the exhibits she showed us. It made a vast difference to our visit. Bear in mind the Wallace Collection is free to enter. We also enjoyed a very good cup of tea there.

Artwork & Armour Oh My!!. A delightful visit that let us just dip our toes into the museum visiting experience that is such an important part of any trip to London for us. Small enough to be exciting without being overwhelming and yet still offers a real sense of stepping into another age.

Takes you back to another time. This is truly a gem. As you explore the collection of art, sculpture and the decorative arts ( which is amazing) you'll find the pieces you've seen in art history books, you'll discover new favorites by known artisst and you'll discover new favorites. The experience of roaming a home where art was displayed among wonderful pieces of furniture truly takes you back. There is excellent signage so you can come to an understanding of just who might have worn that armour. There were no crowds when we arrived at opening, and the lunch on the enclosed pation was relaxing as well as delicious.

"Highlight Tour". Attended the above tour yesterday-a "must" for any one interested in the Collection .Have been there many times but when one is taken around in the company of such a knowledgeable guide-it is a joy! Thank you.
Go Check it out in a nice part of London. You can even take photos of the art works, I loved this place, had a great feel to it, well curated and interesting

A good compact collection. Nicely displayed and excellent collection. Interesting history on how the collection came to be.
Great to have either lunch or tea ( nice selection) in the court yard. Friendly service as well!
Great Lunch or Afternoon Tea. Excellent Museum, followed by an excellent lunch &later for tea on the patio. Need to go early as it tends to fill up at noon. The deserts are great.

Amazing Discovery, Deserves to be Better Known. This is an amazing place to visit, packed full of history and art. Immaculately well kept and presented. It seemed spacious and certainly not crowded. Highly recommended.

What a joy! So tastefully done, so eclectic and so without crowds.. This is a little known gem. It reminds me of the Burrell collection in Glasgow. The great news is that, unlike most well known art galleries/museums, there are so few people who know of the Wallace so you can actually SEE and appreciate the exhibits without crowds of unappreciative and bemused tourists seeing what they think they ought to see rather than because they want to see it and thus getting in the way. What a joy it is to wander round quietly with unrestricted views. I remember when most European museums and art galleries were like this, but that is no longer in this age of mass tourism, so make the most of the Wallace before it gets 'discovered' as it deservedly should be.The large hall on the first floor is the best of what is already very good. It is a concentrated cornucopia of excellent European art mostly for the 16th and 17th century. They do not have everything, but almost one of every kind of genre. The lighting is excellent and the pictures hung so well for viewing; a very model of how an art gallery should display.It is not just the pictures either: the furniture and general decor is so tasteful and right and dare I say it, opulent. Then they have some very good porcelain, not a lot, but what is there is good and again beautifully displayed.And what about the enamelled miniatures!There is even a good collection of armour and so beautifully displayed and like everything else well curated to educate.The staff seem to be largely volunteers, well informed and knowledgeable, another welcome feature.There is even a nice cafeteria and a small but good shop.It is free! It ought not to be because it is so worth paying for, so give a good donation when you leave. It deserves one.

It deserves SIX stars!. The Wallace Collection should not be missed. It is an oft overlooked gem in London. The Wallace Collection - house, art, and furniture - was willed to the people of Britain by the 5th Marquisse of Hertford. At one point the family was among the wealthiest in Europe and this is evident in the brilliant collections of paintings, silver, armour and porcelain. Housed in what was once the family home, the collection is quietly looked after by some of the most knEowledgeable docents familiar with location of pieces and the history of the family and their works of art. Rembrandts, Hals, and much more! Each room is a work of art in itself. Admission is free of charge. The Wallace Collection house is located opposite a quiet little private park just a block behind Selfridges. It is worth repeat visits and there is so much to enjoy. Treasures abound. There is a nice restaurant in the courtyard.

Only for art enthusiasts. Before you decide to visit, make sure you know what to expect. We are fans of old manor houses and their decor and we hoped to see a nice, antique house and learn its story. Somehow, looking at trip advisor reviews, we believed we are going to find these, on top of the art collection. Sadly, the art is the only thing to see at this place, as most of the rooms were renovated petty recently and there is nothing to discover regarding the story of the house. If it is art you're looking for, you should be more than satisfied, as the collection is immense. If it's something else, it's probably not the best place for you.Some tips:There's a guided tour at 14:30.There's also an audio guide available for 4 pounds at the reception.

Amazing collection will need to visit again. My husband & I were looking for something to do before a booked lunch appointment. Unfortunately we had a little difficulty finding it so we saw only a fraction of the rooms & pictures. It is free to enter & they have free guided tours so we will go back & see more hopefully but from what we saw I would highly recommend it.

Great food. Atrocious service . This is a delightful spot for lunch. Not cheap but the day I visited the food was excellent. However the service was abysmal. Erratic. Unprofessional and very very slow. 2 hours for a two course lunch for 4. I won't be rushing back

Neat little art collection. Went here on a Sunday afternoon in June. Free admission which was nice but I made sure I bought something from the gift shop and added to the collection box. Allowed to take pics which was nice. not terribly crowded. Nice take step back in time and get away from the London crowds.

Pure luxury. Let the names of painters speak by themselves: Rembrandt, Van Dyke, Rubens, Fragonard, Canaletto, Vatteau... I was more than surprised with the paintings and rich interiors embellished with 17th century (and latest periods) pieces of furniture. Everything is extremely well preserved.

Very quite and enjoyable exhibition. A really remarkable collection of paintings and armoury, set in a very luxurious house. Without spending a single pound, you can enjoy a very singular exhibition and enjoy an afternoon tea in the very nice cafe inside.

undiscovered gem. Beautiful, FREE, and barely anyone there. This is sort of a shame, but also rather nice not to have to fight the crowds. I loved the beautiful decorations, and my kid loved the ancient armour displays.

Surprising museum luncheon. Our "family" was my daughter, daughter in law and her mother. All of us loved the experience and wouldn't hesitate to return. And it's free! Loved everything about this venue. And as a bonus our luncheon was especially tasty.

Fantastic hidden gem. The Wallace Collection is one of the best museums in London containing a varied and interesting collection of exhibits. It's particularly good if you're interested in arms and armour.

Wonderful collection of art and artefacts. This modest Collection hosts some wonderful paintings, but also artefacts from various centuries. Important is that the Wallace hosts live musical performances on the weekend - well worth it, a treat, but you must check in advance.
Lovely House. This is a beautiful museum with lovely settings and lots of beautiful pictures and furniture. Free tours are available which are very interesting. The cafe is pricey but nice.

A small collection, originally private, with some first class works. If you're interested in seeing art works in an almost private setting, you must go here. Very centrally located, and first class paintings

Rather Overwhelming!. My wife said it well after we left the mansion "glad we stopped in but no reason to return" we both agreed there is so much art that it reaches the point of overwhelming. The location provides a nice break from the pandemonium of High Strret which is 2 blocks away and the outside cafe at the gallery is very god and relaxing. As mentioned there is a lot of art but we had difficulty understanding the flow

What a great surprise!!!!. Such hidden gem! We loved exploring this house museum. So many treasures to uncover (literally you lift up the covers in cases) and art works to see. The armor room was also impressive. The bonus is the fanciful Rococo-inspired decor throughout. Be sure to have high tea in the restaurant as well! Such a great experience!
Excellent collection! Wonderful and rare items of armor and weaponry.. Excellent collection! Wonderful and rare items of armor and weaponry. Beautiful space as well. Definitely worth a visit.

Don't miss this!. Just a short walk from the bustle of Oxford Street. Free entry. Excellent cafe serving lunch or drinks with a bit of style. You don't have to be an art expert to appreciate just wandering around in a beautiful building. Take your loved one. You will be rewarded!

One of the best things in London, and it's FREE!. 10 minutes from Oxford Circus you can see some of the finest Dutch paintings, incredible French furniture, and a ridiculously extensive collection of armour. The Hals is the big draw, of course, but the Van de Veldes are stunning, as are many others, including a pair of stunning Rembrandts. It always puzzles me that it's so quiet in there, but I'm not complaining. The building itself, recently renovated, is crazily opulent. Sometimes you feel like you're in Ronaldo's house. But it's very impressive and well worth dropping into for an hour.
Free and fabulous. So many wonderful pieces of art, porcelain and furniture here to see. Was bigger than I expected and it's free to to enter. Totally worth a trip here.
Beautiful mansion. On a quiet side street, lovely museum with 16th century art off the beaten path. Great for kids too with lots of armour and awords

Treasure trove. Impromptu first visit to the Wallace Collection - wow, what a treasure trove. Delighted to find some well-known masterpieces - The Laughing Cavalier, loads of Reynolds' ladies, Fragonard's The Swing amongst sumptuous Louis 1V and V chandeliers and furniture.There's a grand staircase opening into the marble hall - perfect for swanning down in a big ball gown!Surprisingly, entry is free and I recommend buying the glossy guide (£6.99) as it walks you through the rooms and contents. We didn't have time but there is a large, conservatory cafe to the rear.

you must go.. As I just said you must go. It was not something I wanted to go to but a friend talked me into it. I had a great time there are so many things to see with so much history attached. I will be going back again as we never had time to see it all. A stunning collection and a must see.

Amazing!. Really really nice, I was impressed i did not expect that many portraits and rooms, that's beautiful, well displayed and I would definitely recommend if spending time in london for holidays or even if you live here.Probably more for adults and teenagers.

Fascinating Look into a Past Century. This collection is one of the grand houses of London is so full of art, artifacts and armor that it almost staggers the mind. But it is of a scale that it can be easily visited in a few hours without feeling too aesthetically overwhelmed. The history of the family and its penchant for amassing this collection are also of great interest.

Great place to spend an afternoon. Really interesting place to visit just off Oxford Street. Definitely worth visiting and seeing the impressive European armouries collection, there is also a lovely cafe in the central covered courtyard. Also pays to look online as they run lectures and special events.

Beautiful. Not the most famous museum in London, but this place deserves more credit. The collection is big and beautiful, the audio guides well done, the people working there very helpful and, last but not least, it's entirely free! A must-go.

A hidden gem. Tucked away in Manchester Square, with a bit of everything: Armour, porcelain, furniture and most of all paintings; but don't be put off by the "bit of everything" - they are all quality pieces, some exceptional in the field and all displayed in a homely environment where you can get up close. It's a joyous experience compared to the hordes of tourists at better known galleries and the cafe is a rather nice environment in which to take cake and a coffee or lunch, but don't expect Dave's Diner prices

Stunning Opulence. A superb collection of paintings and furniture on show in spacious galleries full of light. When we visited there were hardly any visitors and we had the luxury to look at the wonderful paintings in great detail and close up, including a famous Canaletto, a Rembrant, a Franz Hals, and a Fragonard, all these paintings are world class. Admission is free but a donation is advisable. Very highly recommended.

Excellent museum with lovely slightly upmarket café. We were at a loss to entertain ourselves on a Saturday afternoon, so essayed the Wallace Collection as recommended by a relative. The, um, traditional array of paintings and porcelain was better than we'd expected; we suggest you organise some sort of competition based on counting the number of dead animals in the Weenix paintings. The real star, for us, was the Armoury. Galleries of items that document industry and craftsmanship, but on items intended to maim and kill. I found it absolutely fascinating, both admiring the workmanship and contemplating the use of these things. Not to mention their history, particularly those from Asia and India. These are tangible reminders of the fraught relationship that Britain has with these countries, but it's important to remember that we live in a different age with different forms of Imperialism. The European armour is simply astounding. Declarations of wealth, of intent, of desire to protect. There are cuirasses bearing the impact scar of the bullets that 'proved' them. There are pikes, boar spears, two-handed swords, rapiers, knives, jousting armours, horse armours. Come and be amazed. And remember to refer to the bound catalogues for more information about each item - the catalogues themselves speak volumes about people fascinated by the items they catalogue. just writing this review makes me want to go back, spend more time wondering at the items and the implications of their existence. The café food is excellent. Like the Museum itself, it has a very Adult ambience: although I daresay some children will enjoy the Wallace Collection - and they do have some things that will appeal to kids - to me this seems a fundamentally adult place to spend time. There is some seating for visitors in most rooms.

My favourite gallery in London.. More Canalettos than Venice. Also Guardi, Fragonard, Titian, Rembrandt, Hals (The Laughing Cavalier) etc. plus the best miniatures collections in the world. Top that with a beautiful house and a great restaurant - what else could one wish for? My favourite place in London.

Could have been much better. Did not enjoy this museum. The audio guide was soooo poor and signage sooooo bad, it was a big effort to enjoy anything. The audio guide described only a few of the items- how can you not talk about Rembrandt's or Velazquez paintings? How hard would it be for the curator to say a few words about many more things. There are few signs on the walls identifying items and the small gold strips with names on the frame of pictures was very difficult to read, in some cases impossible as they were too high to see.

large private collector. large collection of pretty much everything. he collected loads fo stuff from pretty much everywhere he went, bit of a horder really, but collection is well worth seeing and FREE.
great gallery, not much visited. a beautiful building with wonderful things. Well worth a visit. Good restaurant too. It is tucked away behind Oxford Street.
Brilliant free museum. Make the effort to visit The Wallace Collection to see an amazing period house and a wonderful art collection .It also has one of the prettiest cafes in London .

What a wonderful surprise. I stumbled across this collection while out wondering aimlessly. It is a wonderful collection of art that rivals some of the bigger galleries. What I loved is that it is so compact - masterpieces nestle alongside each other fighting for space in the most beautiful London townhouse. Definitely worth a visit.

Awesome. Awe inspiring...but be selective to a avoid being overwhelmed. Terrific Canalettos, Reubens, and van Dykes. A ton of interesting furniture and armor. Very pretty majolica. Pick and choose and you will be delighted.

Avoid tearoom unless you like lukewarm stewed tea!. Art collection is outstanding. Pity about the service in the tearoom.My daughter booked the set afternoon tea as part of my 70th birthday celebrations. The setting is lovely but it was quite hectic and I observed from watching other tables that there was a long delay before the food arrived so the tea was stewed,lukewarm and virtually undrinkable. Consequently when we were eventually served I asked for the food and drink to arrive at the same time. The waiter claimed this was not possible.... Our not very exciting finger sandwiches,scone and 3 tiny cakes came 20 minutes after the pots of tea. I did get fresh tea brought when I expressed my dissatisfaction but this is not acceptable and it ruined what was supposed to be a special occasion. At £40 for two people the service fell far short of what I hoped would be a real treat.
Less Crowded Than Some. This is an enjoyable collection, very varied, lots of memorable items, and not too well known to be full of visitors.

A hidden gem of a gallery. This beautiful now, now art gallery and museum is tucked away but really close to the Selfrdiges end of Oxford Street. The highlight has to be the gallery where you can see The Laughing Cavalier. Restaurant is great too.

A hidden gem with rich and varied treasures. The Wallace Collection has a vast and impressive collection of treasures, ranging from paintings (including Canaletto, Rubens, Rembrandt, Franz Hals) to porcelain, clocks, armour and furniture, with a particular focus on 18th-century France. Taking a daily guided tour (note: can get fully booked) with Debbie Misuri-Charkham was excellent in every way; she is a fount of knowledge and brings each artefact to life with the story behind it. Cafe is in a pleasant covered courtyard (though service can be slow). Overall far more than one can see in a single visit! Well worth going, especially as entry is free!
Great tour. Fabulous museum featuring famous paintings the Swing & the Laughing Cavalier. The tour guide was fascinating.

Fantastic personal collection of art and weapons!. My husband makes his own armor so this mueseum is on our list of must sees every time we visit London. It is free and on a beautiful tree lined circle. If you are interested in seeing some beautiful art and one of the largest collections of ancient weapons The Wallace Collection will not disappoint .

Hidden Gem, I love it. I was introduced to the Wallace Collection three years ago, we had a group tour and later my group did a couple of projects with museum as part of community projects. I fell in love with this museum and everyone else I went with fell in love with it too. There are so many master pieces and each of them tell an interesting and an intriguing story.The Staff are very welcoming and the museum have a beautiful café that we relax in it when we feel tired.I wish everyone can pay this museum a visit, they wont be disappointed.

A visit to an amazing Grand House.. When entering this house you are in huge rooms with Historic Furniture and Fittngs . This is also home to some of the greatest armour and arms collection in London . Hertford House also has the Wallace Restaurant where you can have Afternoon Tea, a lovely meal or just a drink of wine in peace and quiet.

A Nice Hidden Gem. The Wallace collection is the complete art collection of the said family over 3 generations housed in a gorgeous stand alone house in the middle of the city. You can reach it on the center or jubilee tube line, getting off at Bond Street. It is away from the touristy areas and therefore not crowded. It is free with a restaurant in the covered courtyard for lunch and tea. The collection spans baroque, rococo, and neoclassic styles from the French artists of the Louis XIV and Louis XV. It has one Titian and some Dutch masters as well. Definitely worth a visit if you are into French art.

Wallace collection cafe. The Wallace Collection must be one of the most charming and amazing places to visit, but is badly let down by its cafe. Very slow service, grossly expensive dishes, so tiny you need to go somewhere else to eat. Very disappointing. High expectations, but really unacceptable. Cafe situated in a lovely area, so you really do think you will have a special experience, sadly not. Leave before you order, or you will be sitting there waiting. And be disappointed, sadly I could not find a separate way to review the cafe, but the Wallace Collection itself is quite wonderful, so this review should not be read about the collection, but only THE CAFE.

Beautiful house. We had a very quick visit ! But intent to go back for the tour ! Amazing collection , and restaurant looked amazing !
Very helpful staff !

Try not to miss a visit. Had a few visits here, well presented displays, FREE ENTRY, place to sit outside and snack.The contents is a private collection, many armoury based exhibites and very centrally. Located, Ideal if shopping in that area and want a break.Check it out on google, but even if not your thing, still worth a visit as this place was once a house in the country, difficult to imagine as london has expanded alot.
awards ceremony. This fantastic art and furniture collection sits right in the heart of the west end and is well worth a visit

A hidden gem with a great art collection in what was a family home.. This is one of the hidden gems of London Museums. A great collection and a very interesting house. Take a walk off the main street and miss the crowds in the better known museums. You will be very pleasantly surprised.

A quiet gem. A really great small museum / art gallery. Its a beautiful building absolutely packed with paintings, china, armour, weapons, and furniture from the collections of 5 generations of English aristocracy. Its a wonderful place to drift around for an hour or two without the hoards you find in the more high profile national collections.Only a minutes walk from Oxford Street and yet a million miles away. There's a pleasant cafe in the basement courtyard if you want to feed the body as well as the mind.

Amazing collection of armouries. My husband chose to go there based on trip advisor reviews and we found a great collection of armory. you can access this collection for free. If you are interest in 18th century then you can spend a couple of hours there. you can see 18th century French paintings as well.

Small and fine. It is a less visited museum in a brilliant private home. Hundreds of paintings, other art objects makes this visit really enjoyable. The visit is free, which is another plus point. Just off the house a nice little pak.

You're laughing!. Over the years, the Wallace Collection has become more user-friendly. The addition of the very acceptable café was a welcome bonus. This is an eclectic collection of great interest in many areas - and nowhere else will you find 'The Laughing Cavalier"!
The Marquess of Hertford's home. Stunning house. Free to visit. Well worth it for history lovers. If you like art there are hundreds of wonderful paintings.

Perfect size museum with less tourists. I've visited the Wallace Collection during both times visiting London, and it was as excellent as always. It is situated in a quiet area without crowds, and the size of the collection is just perfect. Not too big to make you feel pressured, and includes a great huge collection of art pieces and artefacts. The audioguide was good too. I especially like how all the rooms feel spacious and comfortable, and each room has a distinctive "theme colour" that is very memorable. There's also a glass-roofed courtyard restaurant where you may have lunch or afternoon tea. Really recommend having a relaxed afternoon here.

Perfect size for a museum. I tend to get overwhelmed in the big museums but this museum is in a mansion and is the perfect size. Each room was decorated beautifully in different colors and kept me interested for about 2hours. Easy to get to and near Oxford street for some shopping after.
Stop off point. I'd forgotten what a great building this is with such an outstanding collection. Paintings, armoury and miniatures. There is a lovely airy cafe
Wonderful Collection. You won't be seeing any "famous" works of art, however, the collection in its entirety is quite impressive. Well worth an hour or two of your time.

Nice collection of Renaissance art. Staying in the Paddington area and with menacing skies, I decided to visit the Wallace Collection. We were able to go through in about an hour, at less than a leisurely pace, but it has an amazing collection of art, ceramics, and armour. Well worth the trip and as an added bonus - it's free! Wonderful example of 19th century architecture and decor as well.

2 hrs was not enough. A unique collection of paintings, object d'art ,and the finest collection of armour in Europe-and so much more-in a country house setting-and it is FREE .Also fantastic restaurant in a beautiful setting.Allow at least 4hrs to do justice to this unique display, collected over 4 generations

Large collection and nice cafe. Massive collection of art and historical objects, also very well kept building which is beautiful in itself. Cafe was good too, a little pricey but had speciality teas and cakes.

The best in the Private home/Art Collection Category. If you would like to see how the .0001% used to live in England, The Wallace Collection will give you a peek into it. This huge home is loaded with artwork and furniture (& Armor) that the family had collected. Admission is free and there is a fee for a head set (which I recommend). You could spend a hour or a long afternoon here, depending on your interest.

Mayfair Pearl. Wonderful museum and i am very happy that came across it occasionally. The collection is comprehensive and includes paintings of 16-19 centuries period. The interiors are also very impressive; interior scenes are saved in original furnitring. Great collection of watches.

ONE OF THE BEST ATTRACTIONS IN LONDON !. Absolutely amazing, how one family was able to collect this amount and variety of high quality antiques from all over the world.Absolutely priceless collections.
Charming house full of beautiful art and furniture. A little known house full of fine art and antique furniture with a lovely coffee shop at the back of building which is always popular

Highly recommended, every Londoner should experience this Museum. Highly recommended, every Londoner should experience this Museum even if just one in their lifetime , I was captivated by the atmosphere here. What was set out to be an hours visit, turned into en entire morning

A surprising find, tucked away off busy Oxford Street. Beautifully furnished house with an amazing collection of furniture, paintings and most surprisingly, arms and armour. A real treasure trove, and only a few minutes walk from Oxford Circus.

Amazing.... I don't want to share though. This place is so amazing I don't wantt to tell anyone about it and keep it for myself. It should be top secret. Every time you visit you will find something you didn't find on your last visit. The coffee shop is a perfect place to relax. So, what can I say ? .... don't go there or you will love it and then I will have to shre it

Hidden Gem off the beaten track. I return to this little museum to walk around and enjoy the collection of paintings, porcelain and weapons. It's one of the best in London with usual items and well arranged cabinets and rooms. It also has an excellent cafe where you can sit, relax and enjoy a typically English tea. This place is excellent for enjoying a lazy afternoon and soaking up a bit of history and culture. It is never too busy so there is ample time and space to enjoy the place to yourself. Heaven.

A must do. There's nothing like taking tea at the Wallace Collection. The outdoor canopy covered court cafe is beautiful, relaxed and quintessentially something or other. This is where I take my family and friends for a relaxed, un-rushed fun as well as elegant good time. And then there is the collection itself! A great place to get lost in!

Beautiful Collection in an Intimate Atmosphere. Highly recommend this museum for both its diverse collection and easy accessibility. You can come in for a few minutes or stay for a few hours. Many beautiful paintings from famous artists such as Watteau, Canaletto, Gainsborough, and Rembrant. Other interesting items as well including a large armor, porcelain, and furniture collections

A hidden gem - and crowd-free!. This is such an eclectic collection, and such an interesting house, that you can visit again and again and still enjoy it - or do it in bits, one day the arms and armour, one day the paintings, one day the china, etc. Free to visit (though it really deserves a voluntary donation to keep it as lovely as it is!) and whenever I have visited have never found it crowded. Lovely postcards of lots of your favourite paintings, that maybe you didn't know were here!

What a find!!!!!!!!!!! And it is free. I did not visit this collection until now due to the fact that in the past was not free. Yesterday we decided to give it a go and learned that nowadays is not only free but is one of the most amazing collections I have seen in such a small place: surely I will come back at least once per year.If you like beautiful things, trust me you are in for a feast: not only is the building beautifully kept with gorgeous ceiling and chandeliers, fabric covered walls (staff telling rather rudely not to touch the wall when you are mesmerised by a certain fabric and delicately touch it with the tip of the fingers!!!!!!!!!!!!!) but beautiful painting by Rubens, Boucher etc or small portraits of Mazarine, Madame de Pompadour or different English and French kings, besides busts of general Conde, Lady Wallace etc or beautiful Sevres porcelain (as interesting as the china found in museums in Vienna), amazingly sculpted furniture spread over 3 floors. On the ground floor there are several rooms packed with European and Middle Eastern armours, most amazing being the daggers, long guns and knives encrusted with precious stones or simply having different texts on them, lying next to gorgeous armours in the fashion of the Ottoman empire (although not as many as in museums in La Valetta). You do not know where to look first as the collection is simply amazing and there are plenty of sitting areas to relax and enjoy everything. If you are into these kind of things, trust me, you will pat yourself on the shoulder for visiting it.
Great Art in Idylic setting. beautiful gallery- helpful staff and very nice cafe at the end of the art experience to cap a lovely visit

Beautiful and extraordinary collection of art and armour.. This is a beautiful old mansion with an incredible collection of art of all types. beautiful paintings and a truly outstanding collection of arms and armour

Outstanding. My favorite museum crammed with world class collections. The building is beautifully presented and the historic house feel is at least hinted at. You will find canonical paintings furniture and applied art. It is hard not to fall in love with this oasis behind Oxford Street. Great to linger or as a flighing visit to see one object. Pity the fabulous old Minton tiled toilets disappeared but the substitute for galleries etc in the basement outweighs this. I loved the old Wallace as it was and the new cheerful one. Just go and be amazed.

هgreat place to visit. Amazing place to visit lots of visitors from all around the world and thanks to a shop in George street called Janna Organic Remedies the lady there ,she helps us with the direction.

Fascinating less well known gallery. Great collection of primarily French art, porcelain and furniture made especially interesting by the excellent guide that took us round and showed us many of the highlights. Note that entry and the tour are free but you need to get a badge to join the tour from the reception desk.There is also a large collection of arms and armour but we did not have enough time to do this justice. To do the whole thing you probably need 3 hours or so - or repeat visits!Pleasant cafe/restaurant in the roofed over courtyard.

Outstanding collection in central London. Wonderful collection on view in Manchester Square, just behind Wigmore Street. Only comparable collection I know is the Frick in New York. Most certainly worth a trip to see it.

A gem just off Oxford Street. The Wallace Collection is best described as eclectic. The place is stuffed with lovely things and, at least when I visited, the entire museum was free. Escape the bustle of Oxford Street and central London by visiting here and then go and have a drink at Durant's Hotel which is just across the road. It is as if you have stepped out of time and the bustle of modern London fades away. Yet it is right outside the doors of the museum

Best gallery in London. London is certainly not short on art galleries and the like but for me The Wallace is the pick of the bunch. A stunning collection, an exquisite building and wonderful staff.And the restaurant is reason enough to visit on it's own. I always try to take visitors to The Wallace for a wander around and then afternoon tea. Love it.

The best art gallery you've never seen.. London has many hidden treasures and in Manchester Square, just off the crowded nightmare of Oxford Street, is the finest of them all - The Wallace Collection. Hertford House - formerly known as Manchester House when it was built in 1778 - once belonged to the Marquesses of Hertford, among the world's greatest art collectors. They were immensely wealthy and could outbid even the Rothschild family - something they took great pleasure in doing. The collection was founded by the 1st Marquess of Hertford and continued through the line of succession, but it was the 4th Marquess, Richard Seymour-Conway, who bought most of what you see today. His collection of 18th century French paintings is unrivalled except by the Louvre. He adored beautiful things and what you see at the Wallace Collection is the cream of the paintings, furniture, porcelain, armour and many other artefacts acquired by the Marquess and his antecedents. As you wander around this opulent London townhouse you will find paintings by Rembrandt, Titian, Velasquez, Rubens, Gainsborough, Reynolds, Murillo and many more, including the famous "Laughing Cavalier" by Frans Hals. There are exquisite collections of Sevres porcelain, French furniture and miniatures. There is an extensive collection of arms and armour and exquisite collections of miniatures. Eye - popping stuff, to be sure.But this is no mere art gallery, oh no. This is a ravishingly beautiful house in its own right and every room is hung with paintings as though it were still a house lived in and loved. This is London's finest example of an aristocratic town house, open to the public. As you enter through the pillared portico, you enter into a world of beauty and no little privilege. The grand staircase, hung with several huge paintings by Francois Boucher, gives you a tantalising glimpse of what delights await. There is also a fantastic restaurant in the great courtyard. Hertford House and the greater part of the art collection were left to the nation by the widow of Richard Wallace, the illegitimate son of the 4th Marquess - although there is little actual proof that he was the father. Wallace, and his wife Amelie, used Hertford House - as it was now known - as their London base after moving back from Paris, and they brought the greater part of the extensive collection with them.The 4th Marquess lived in Paris most of the time and used Hertford House to store much of his ever expanding collection. When he bought Ruben's painting "Rainbow Landscape" in 1856 he outbid both the National Gallery and the Rothschilds. The painting was sent to Hertford House and the Marquess, who preferred to live in Paris, never saw it.If you only have time to visit one gallery in London, let it be the Wallace Collection.
