beautiful collection and house (+lunch). It's nice to be able to enter one of these exclusive london houses. The art collection is impressive. French, Flemish, UK artists are well present as well as furniture, jewels and clothing.
Hidden Gem. This is another of the special small art museums in London. Most people don't know it exists, but if you are traveling in the a oxford St area, stop in.

what a treat to the soul and sight!. worth a visit, exquisite items on display and not crowded.Take your time at the cafe as they have delicious cakes and their tea is actually served after being brewed properly. What a treat.

Wonderful museum and excellent courtyard cafe'/restaurant. The museum is beautiful, in a wonderful townhouse: eighteenth-century French paintings, Sèvres porcelain, French furniture and paintings by Titian, Rembrands, Rubens, Van Dyck, Canaletto and many more.It is a homely place with a beautiful restaurant in a covered courtyard.The place, food, drinks and service are all excellent.I was also there for afternoon tea: best scones I had for a long time.

Beautiful collection in an ornate and elegant setting. Visited the Wallace on a lovely afternoon. The house truly feels like a grand home that has been filled with the most amazing collection of art. Definitely worth a visit when in London

Exquisite Craftsmanship. The Wallace Collection is a free museum in a grand house. The treasures within cover all aspects of fine art and craftsmanship back to medieval times. There is also a very pleasant restaurant in a bright and airy atrium.

"forced" initially to visit for tea, I now love this place!. Ok, I admit that my wife insisted we visit this place for their afternoon tea on a trip to London in the past. Then I was pleasantly surprised to find they had other options on the menu, including sandwiches and beer, so we both got what we wanted! On our most recent trip, we enjoyed a simple lunch in their peaceful and relaxed atrium restaurant. On every visit, I now enjoy seeing the collection of paintings, furniture, carvings, and sculpture. It is a fascinating variety of pieces, displayed in an accessible and elegant manner. It's not a large place, but I have never seen it crowded. Easy walk from Selfridge's, another of our standard stops when visiting London.

Stunning collection. This collection is far better than many larger, well known museums. Our tour guide was outstanding. She is doing a PhD in art history, and her engagement with the collection was terrific.

DO NOT MISS THE FIRST FLOOR. The "courtyard" café/restaurant is very nice, too. There are several temporary exhibits (don't miss the -1 floor!) and special events, so check their calendar. Just have a look at my photos. Did I mention it's free? There are audio guides and guided tours, too, and a shop that includes several publications exclusively focusing on the different aspects of The Wallace Collection. Staff are friendly and helpful.

Do NOT miss this museum!. Free museum and so much to see. Great area also. Cannot believe all the priceless pieces included within the collection. You can spend days here.The building alone is fabulous. Nice setting for the cafe.

Not overwhelming in size but overwhelming in exhibits. A beautiful building housing a private collection donated to the Uk for the whole world to enjoy. Some exquisite collections of art and objets d'art in a beautiful building. See The LaughingCavalier by Franz Hal's or the exquisite miniature boxes encrusted with jewels. The whole experience is mind boggling but because the building and collection is not enormous it is possible to view the whole in a few hours and finish off with an excellent lunch or afternoon tea. Free of charge but please give a donation.

Only in London!. This wonderful eclectic display of four generations of the Wallace family, Marquesses of Hertford from the 18th century. The collection in what was the family town house was given to the nation in the 1890's. Free admission to wonderful paintings, Frans Hals, Boucher, Rubens and many others. French and English furniture, Sevres porcelain and a fine armoury are part of this unique collection. There is even a restaurant in a stunning, covered courtyard.

Sophisticated Wallace Collection. Now that I've discovered what gems can be found here, I am determined to return on a quieter day and have a good look at the paintings and other precious collections displayed in the multicoloured flock-papered rooms. Events such as this must be a major money spinner for the museum. Unfortunately, bar staff seemed unprepared for the sheer number of visitors, and it just seemed ridiculous to have to queue twice, once to order and again to pay for your drinks. Not very sophisticated. Perfectly understandable that you are not allowed to walk about with your drink, but rather annoying when you've paid more than a tenner for a glass of bubbly and David McAlmont is about to hit a high note in one of the upstairs galleries.

Hidden Gem. For the 3 day tourist of London Im sure this place is one off the agenda. However, to avoid the crowds of the places like the National Gallery, the Wallace Collection is well worth the time.

Certainly worth visiting. This is such a wonderful museum. We really enjoyed our visit - the paintings are superb and so is the armoury. There is an excellent restaurant. We will be going back there. There are some fantastic items.
Amazing. This museum is a gem well worth a visit. Good restaurant in a lovely setting. Situated in central London easy walking distance off Oxford street.
Hidden treasure. A wonderful museum full of interesting treasures, not busy so really enjoyable to walk around. Would recommend.

Afternoon Tea. Not far from Bond Street tube and Selfridges, Hertford House is somewhere you would probably strumble across when exploring London. The Wallace Collection is a free national museum in an historic town house that houses a beautiful collection of historical antiques; although I have to confess to not looking around too much but heading to the central atrium cafe for afternoon tea. The cafe boasts a space that offers al fresco dinning in a lovely setting, with trees and sculptures and lots of lovely natural sunlight. The afternoon tea features classic homemade scones, with jam and cream; a selection of finger sandwiches, including a vegetarian selection on request and a number of delicious cakes to enjoy. Not forgetting a choice of teas or coffee served in Chinese t-pots. My one and only complaint is that a second pot of tea is extra although not enough to break the bank. Recommended for a relaxing and enjoyable afternoon.

It's free: you'd be foolish to ignore stunning venue.. A breath of fresh share and just behind Oxford Street, the one street I attempt to avoid at all cost.The art here is jaw dropping, amazing and bloody opulent. You may have seen stuff like this in museums but now you get the experience in a home of the upper class. It's incredible and we found it accidentally.

Beautifully displayed old master collection, plus much more. The collection is free to visit, but an audio guide (well worth getting) costs £4. Start on the top floor and after two hours go for lunch at one of the many excellent nearby restaurants. Then return and do the ground floor for a further two hours before going to dinner. A great day out.

Beautiful and fascinating.. The Wallace Collection is a beautiful collection of antiques. As a militaria and general weapons enthusiast - the Armouries were my preferred rooms. I spent a good two hours just scouting them alone, examining each piece individually. I had arrived mid-afternoon so only had a few hours to visit - I quickly discovered this was not sufficient. I had to skip a lot of the upstairs rooms, even rush through some as I simply did not have the time to properly appreciate all the stunning collections. I would recommend visiting first thing in the morning, so as to allow yourself enough time to see the entire house.I decided to tag along on the 2PM tour - the tour guide was knowledgeable but due to the amount of rooms was only able to talk about one item per room, which was a little frustrating as it felt we were missing out on so much. I wouldn't recommend the tour for the simple fact you would be better exploring it yourself.I also found the information on the pieces to be a little lacking. I am a tour guide myself, and had been advised by a friend there was a Vernis Martin desk which I would be intrigued to see. It took me a very long time to find it! I eventually found a tiny label indicating it was the one I had been searching for, but it had no further details which was a little bit of a let-down. In terms of location, it is central however a little difficult to find. I ended up having to set up google maps on my phone to direct me towards the house. Getting back to the tube station was even more confusing.Overall, I would very much recommend the Wallace Collection for anyone interested in history or antiques, particularly that of the armouries.

Quirky and unexpected, lovely cafe in the centre. I like this place, eccentric, not to big, quirky and a great café for tea and cake. I feel like a step back in time, always a little special while too stuffy.

Relaxing Afternoon Educational. Great restaurants in the neighborhood to grab a bite after as well. One of the best collections around. Definitely a hidden jewel. Refreshing that something this fantastic is still free. The armor and swords are really neat. Each room is done in a different color and creates a different feel as you move around the house. An educational and relaxing afternoon.
hidden gem. thanks to my hotel's receptionist I ve discovered this hidden gem just minutes from bond street. Time very well spent

Quite the surprise. Had not heard of this place. Just a short walk from Selfridge's. A delightful step back in "English" time. The porcelain collection was riveting. We arrived a bit late in the day & will return for a longer visit.

Wow! This sis Superb!. Stumbled upon the Wallace Collection by accident. This is extraordinary. The collection of art is amazing. The paintings are world class. It is free to enter - donation encouraged. Tip: Go at a time when there is a complimentary tout - our tour guide was knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Ideal rainy day visit. Not ideal for young children but it is well worth visiting.

Thsi is a hidden and outstanding gem. Walking back from Regent' sPark, I came across this museum off Manchester Pl by complete accident. I was rewarded with some outstanding displays and a good starter in understanding 18th century Britain
Wonderful. An extraordinary collection of the weird, wonderful, beautiful, frightening, exotic, mundane. (Don't miss the peculiar miniature wax women.)A great 90 to 120 minutes-worth.

A beautiful tranquil museum in a serene London town house. If you are into big old paintings and huge Dresden pots, heavy furniture and dramatic chandeliers then this is just the place for you.There are saucy paintings by Fragonard and chubby nudes by Rubens. You get the gist.The paintings are from the 'who is who' of old world-famous artists.If you are not into this kind of stuff you will enjoy the house nonetheless!This is one of the very few museums which feels as if it is really loved.It is a place which feels ''alive'.The volunteers working there are fabulous - friendly, attentive and kind.There is so much love and attention to detail that even people like me who are definitely not into that kind of stuffy art get interested. I was never into porcelain but I became interested when I visited the Wallace collection.The Wallace collection is a delightful treasure trove with a wonderful atmosphere. There is a nice cafe /restaurant in a light-filled courtyard. It is upmarket and on the pricey side but a real treat, though the waiters like to ignore customers so you have to wave very hard to get their attention.Everything feels happy and peaceful.There is a delightful petite shop in the Wallace collection. Nothing is tacky there. They got a good selection of books relating to the art displayed as well. I bought the larger guidebook - I think it cost seven or eight quid. But it is on high gloss paper and the colours of the reproductions in it are good.I wouldn't bring small kids. Leave them at home and give yourself an art and educational treat!But if you try to educate stroppy teenagers - they probably will - like me - suddenly get an inkling of a period and styles which up to then was not accessible.My personal highlights were the miniatures of Napoleon. The oval drawing room was delightful in its proportions and in its 'feminine' theme.By the way: The Museum feels very romantic! It might be a great place for a rendezvous - for 'golden oldies'.For me the visit was an eye- and mind-opening experience. It trained my eyes to see styles of art, I was never into, in a new way. So I definitely will be back - to learn more.

A Hidden Gem. Take time from shopping on Oxford Street for a dose of culture in this hidden gem. Free entrance. Don't miss the Laughing Cavalier. Excellent place for a well - earned cuppa in the covered courtyard restaurant too.
Have to see the Cavelier!. A beautiful location, easily accessible walking from Baker Street, Marylebone or Bond Street (in particular).A wonderful collection - I especially like the armoury.

A haven of art & tranquillity with wonderful teas. The Wallace Collection doesn't disappoint, it has wonderful displays of art, china, miniatures, furniture - all set within a beautiful town house just off Oxford Street. There is also a wonderful tea room, with fabulous teas and food - all served beautifully.

Excellent museum of fine and decorative art. An excellent museum of European fine and decorative art. Very relaxing ambience and not nearly as crowded and overwhelming as the British Museum or Victoria & Albert. The museum has a stunning and world-renowned collection of fine porcelain, Old Master paintings, furniture, silverware, sculptures, armoury, clocks and delightful trinkets from the Medieval period up to the 19th c. Many of the rooms are finely-decorated, making you feel like you're wandering in a palace or a stately home rather than a museum.

Magic Wallace Collection. Hertford House is a beautiful 18th Century building, and there are lots of stunning objets d'art. The highlights for me were the Laughing Cavalier and the overly ornate French furniture. The Wallace also gives the visitor a good impression how the later Victorian and Edwardian elite in London actually lived. Plan to spend 90 minutes here, and then do some shopping on nearly Oxford Street. Visited the Wallace Collection for the first time this weekend, despite living locally for many years. Given that there's free admission, you really have no excuse not to while away an hour or two at the Collection. This impressive Edwardian mansion on Manchester Square (three blocks from Selfridges) is a gem! Yes, there is plenty of third-rate art and an overabundance of objects d'art scattered throughout the Wallace, but there are also occasional gems - paintings, minatures, armor and furniture.

Fabulous. This fabulous free museum / gallery is only a few minutes walk from Oxford Circus in the centre of London.It contains a wonderful collection of armour from Europe and Asia together with beautiful furniture and works of art from many centuries.It is home to some great paintings by Van Dyke, Rembrandt, Poussin, Canaletto, Reynolds, Valazquez, Titian and many more.It also houses the popular "Laughing Cavalier. It is worth visiting several times in order to do it justice.

A hidden gem of a museum.. This is a place you have to seek out but worth the time. It has an amazing collection of furniture and art but to me the most interesting was the armor collection. On the lower level the most amazing collection is on view. Armor and chain mall in full suits for both men and their horses. There is also a lovely restaurant where we had a delicious lunch after wandering the museum. Would not recommend for young children as it is intimate and crowded with furnishings and antiques that would be tempting for little ones to touch.
Lots of history.. A place with alot of heritage and an interesting story, I would definitely return and show this to my family.

A hidden gem!. So you've been to all the major tourist attractions in London and you're shopping Oxford Street, turn right into Duke Street and make your way to the Wallace Collection in Hertford House, Manchester Square where you will find 25 rooms full of old Masters and the armoury downstairs. If you are a fan of Joshua Reynolds, and don't mind paintings full of dogs and dead birds, you will not be disappointed. The Wallace Restaurant is a great place to rest for lunch - the food is delicious and the service is very attentive. I want to live there!!

House was stunning restaurant pricey. I didn't know this existed until a friend suggested we meet there in London. The house was stunning, especially the decor and furnishings and some of the art was lovely. We had lunch while there. The menu is very limited (which isn't necessarily a bad thing) but the food was really quite pricey and not that spectacular.I wouldn't rush back to dine there again

Not what I was expecting one bit but enjoyed it. I thought this was Wallace AND GROMIT. I looked forward to seeing Nick Parks funny little plasticine dogs and men. But once I realised this wasn't the same Wallace I had a great time. Very fancy but nice.
Wonderful place!!. Lovely place to visit in london . Very nice historical collection to see here . Absolutely wonderful museum nice and quiet.

beautiful house,art and hidden military museum. It's a rather huge house , near oxford circus, and has such a fine collection of paintings and art and furniture and clocks. They also military gems, like some swords of Tipu sultan. easy to finish in 3 hours.

A great way to refresh you mind in a peaceful location. I often pop in here when passing. Not only is it a great collection, it is a wonderful building. Very peaceful and serene, yet right in the hub-bub of central London.I recommend extending the visit to lunch in the restaurant, excellent service and food at good prices.

Amazing Art and Armour Collection. Charming afternoon tea.. Wonderful location with an unexpected great collection of painting and armour.
Quaint and delicious afternoon tea.

Collection-to heart for.. For those who wish to enjoy the museum in rococo style without feeling tooo tourist. Walking in the hall of Lady Wallace is very much here just in the centre of london and later u can just walk to have a cup of coffee at the monocle cafe.

More than I expected.. My daughter and I are gallery nuts. I was expecting this one to fall in an average category. I am not a fan of military museums. But to my surprise, the art part of the gallery was pleasing, but the military part was quite impressive! To see such a large collection of armor for men and horses, and such a large collection of battle weaponry was much more impressive than I would have imagined. The detailed workmanship in these pieces was amazing. It was a very enjoyable visit.

Fabulous collection of weaponry. This is a fantastic collection of weapons from across the ages. All laid out in displays in fine rooms. I spent several hours walking around the the rooms and would do it again.There is a decent restaurant in the building too. So that is worth a visit as well.This is a hidden gem in the centre of the West End. Do visit even if weapons are not your thing. There is history here and it shows how warfare evolved with mans ingenuity.

Beautiful Museum. Beautiful collection, couldn't believe it was totally free to look around! Not many other museums in the UK match this collection. Myself and my partner spent hours wandering the beautifully redecorated rooms and then had tea in the cafe which was right in the heart of the building. Very enjoyable Sunday afternoon.
fascinating. If you love the Frick you will love the Wallace collection.What an amazing amount of varied treasures in this wonderful setting.This really is a must when visiting London.

Hidden gem of a museum. The Wallace Collection was recommended by a work colleague some years ago. I had no idea it was just behind Selfridges. Since then I have been a regular visitor. I was astounded to find their collection of Old Dutch masters paintings which I had previously wrongly assumed were held at the National Gallery. You will recognise many of the original paintings there but seeing the originals is rather special. The rooms have been renovated over the past few years and the colours are wonderfully vibrant and give a good sense of what the house would have been like when it was lived in. The Wallace restaurant is the perfect place for an afternoon tea treat after spending time looking around the collection. If you want to visit a museum not many know about, visit the Wallace Collection
FOR THE FANS OF FRANSECO CANAL. A fantastic collection of Canalletos, a unique display in an old mansion. The lighting should be improved

A gem - wonderful art collection, artefacts, porcelain, furniture. A joy to visit, beautiful house, amazing art collection, furniture, porcelain. Unforgettable collection - a must see. A restaurant in the centre - booking advisable.

Wonderful Collection . From Bond Street station and a 5 minute walk brings you to this treasure trove. It's near Oxford Street but seems somehow off the well beaten tourist track. Incredibly admission is free. Part of the family agreement apparently. Pictures, furniture, armour, porcelain there is lots to see. I never tire of coming here. And when you need a sit down and a cup of tea, there is a good Peyton and Byrne restaurant in a covered central area. I have included photos to give you some idea of what to see. You will need at least a morning. Highly recommended.
Beautiful collection housing some surprising treasures. This is an intimate collection housing some fantastic treasures without the enormous crowds that you encounter in some of the bigger galleries

Love this place. One of my best places to take visitors to London too
Small enough to see everything in an hour and intimate with a feeling for how it was many years ago when in private hands

fantastic art & a decent armoury at the rear. fabulous collection of furniture, oil paintings & a great gun collection featuring pre Napoleonic short & long arms . the best museum for weaponry in Central London & a nice cafe

good food and good portions. we had a lovely meal at The White Hart Inn
The service was good and they are very helpful and friendly
The food was very good and at a fair price
it has been refurbished so every where looks fresh

Beautifully preserved 'home'. A lovely place to visit for the first time. Reminds us of the Frick in New York, Isabella Gardner in Boston and the Musee Jacquemart-Andre in Paris. Also pleasant place to meet people - easy to find, nice tea shop as well!
No Gromits there!. A great place for a rainy day - good restaurant, with a great selection of dishes, teas and coffees and a super place to meander around.

What a collection!. You could spend hours wandering through this amazing house. I chose to go here based on reviews I read on trip advisor and I am glad we did! The vast collection housed here is amazing, especially the suits of armour for people and horses. My 15 year old daughter said it was her favourite museum visit of our trip!
wonderful hiden gem. nice restrearant for coffee and lunch PLUS an amazing collection of art and the most 18th century French furniture with royal connections in the world

Lovely exhibition. The Wallace Collection is a wonderful find, right in the heart of London behind Selfriges. There is something for everyone, lovely paintings, furniture, the building itself and lots of interesting items to see. Everyone was really helpful and informative and w=it was an amazing place to spend a couple of hours

A real gem. The Wallace Collection makes a marvellous morning or afternoon visit - and the great thing is that you can see it all in a couple of hours. A unintimidating and wide-ranging collection without feeling bitty or eccentric, there some some really good things here. It is free, and there is a tempting courtyard cafe/restaurant. In a lovely part of London, not on most tourist routes.

A MUSEUM, WELL WORTH A DEVIATION. The original paintings and furniture in this exhibition are very well worth a visit. Many great artists paintings are displayed here (Hals - the Laughing Cavalier + many more). Plus a lovely courtyard restaurant. Would thoroughly recommend a visit, when in London.

Fabulous furniture, paintings and object d'art.. Have wanted to visit for 20 years and finally made it! Easy to get to from Oxford St, in a little oasis, sits this beautiful house. We took the guided tour( free) but sadly like most tours these days the guide spent far too much time talking about one item before proceeding to the next. It was worth listening to at the beginning to find out about how the collections was gathered but we broke away after about 1/2 hour to search for other things . Restaurant is expensive so we took ourselves off to another one that I know, but the loos ( if I can write about them) are probably the best public loos in London !

Gorgeous!. What a beautiful house and what a collection! Well considered hang and display of objects - every room was a design dream. Treasures at every turn and so many OMG moments! Highly recommend to anyone with an interest in sculpture and furniture, armoury, ceramic and silverware as well as painting. Highlight was 'The Laughing Cavalier' by Frans Hals and the multiple armour and antique weapons rooms.

FAR FROM THE USUAL MADDING CROWDS. A wonderful gallery and collection of hidden gems a stone's throw from bustling Oxford Street with a fantastic, reasonably priced restaurant. Take people here to impress them away from toddlers, buggies and annoying crowds. A grown ups cultured visit with beautiful paintings, miniatures and the most glorious crystal chandeliers I have ever seen.

The Wallace Collection Revisited after more than twenty years. I visited The Wallace Collection as a twen. But it was not where it is now because they were restoring the current premises. I remember that I was really fond of it. So It needed another visit. It still is beautiful and interesting. What a huge collection of items from the old days, I liked it a lot.
So much to see here. Have been here before and love just wandering in the house. Some of the collections such as the medals can take you hours to examine.

Amazing collection hidden in the middle of the West End. An oasis of calm at the north edge of Manchester Square five minutes from Oxford Street with a wide range of paintings and other artifacts. Free admission helps to make this a must if you are in the area

Small and Eloquent. Beautiful artwork and furniture. Can sit and sketch without being disturbed too much, as generally quiet surroundings unlike other galleries. Some staff can be a little aloof like most galleries in London. If you like to see weapons and armour then this is a great place to go.

Well worth a visit. Did not stop in for long as it was at the end of a full day of walking around London but they have a rather impressive armory and some lovely paintings. There seemed to be a lot of people enjoying what looked to be a very nice afternoon tea in the cafe on site. Will definitely be going back for another look (and probably for tea and cake to)

Nice Place for Tea!. We visited the Wallace House for tea. The museum is nice, but wouldn't be on top of my list of British museums to go to. The art work was beautiful, but what made the Wallace stand out was the exquisite furniture.The restaurant room was beautiful It was light, bright and airy. We really enjoyed having tea there and feeling very British. They served Coronation Chicken which was our favorite! I would recommend the tea there if you are looking for a traditional British tea!

Not bad if you are in the area but not worth a long trip. Some nice pieces - furniture, art, etc. Very hands off and lots of breakable stuff - unsuitable for children. Free and so worth a quick look if you are in the area but not really worth a long trip out of your way.
The weapon gallery. The swords and the armour were the true show winner alongside all the countryside portraits and china figurines.

Worth to visit this private house. Wallace collection is the place we always recommend to our friends who first visit London.
It is a great collection amazing paintings, Canaletos or Guardi, Frans Halls to name a couple. Wonderful furniture from Versailles and a very attractive armoury sale.
All this at the heart of London, Manchester Sq behind Selfridges.
Great Place. It was very worth it to see and go through, but it was a little less accessible than other museums we went to, however the art pieces are enough to make it a worthwhile trip.

A Beautiful Mansion with lots of Art and Porcelain. This is free art museum-mansion and it is a beauty. The House is gorgeous with lots of beautiful rooms filled with chandlers, art, and antiques. Paintings by Rembrandt, Reubens and Van Dyck grace the walls. I especially loved the beautiful porcelain dishes. The museum is generally quiet and allows you to really enjoy your visit.

An impressive collection.. The Wallace Collection is housed in a really exquisite small museum in Manchester Square, just behind Selfridges. It contains a stunning display of fine porcelain, 15th to 19th century paintings, furniture and armour. It is free to enter.Once inside, you will love this beautiful house, it has exhibits in every room. You are allowed to go from room to room at your own pace and you can get really close up to the exhibits.No need to worry about large crowds here, a truly wonderful place to visit.

Secret treasure house. This collection is tucked away behind Oxford Street, housed in an amazing historic house. The collection of furniture, paintings and porcelain is wide ranging and mixed, well worth a visit. Best of all, admission is free! Also the restaurant in the glassed-in courtyard is wonderful.
Very lovely afternoon out. Very much enjoyed my afternoon out with friends here. Beautiful rooms with lovely paintings and the chandeliers were amazing. Worth a visit, i could of spent hours here.

A great visit for a day out with the family. We found ourselves in Mayfair, and decided to see the Wallace Collection at Hertford House.What a great place to visit. We mostly looked at the Armoury galleries, since we visited with young children and couldn't bank on them having a long attention span. What an amazing place to learn more about the past. Highly recommended. As we left, our children told us they had a great time looking at the guns, armours, shields and spades from hundreds of years ago, what better complement than that?The stuff was ever present, and very helpful. Visit it, you won't regret it!

A Wondeful Surprise. Like the Frick in New Youk or the Jacquemart Andre in Paris this is a wonderful insight into the home and collections of a single family. from Valsquez and Murrilo to Rembrant, Hal's and Cannelletto the collection is an amazing set of gems housed in the home they were purchased for. While not my interest, the collection or arms and armour is similarly impressive, and in its own way, equally beautify. If you plan to shop at Selfridges while in London, take an hour or two to walk a couple of blocks north for this "must see" lesser known a gallery. Like at British public museums, it is free, but a donation of 5 to 10 pounds is recommended and appreciated.

Not to be Missed. An incredibly interesting museum with works of art of unimaginable excellence. Canneletto, Rubens, Rembrandt and a host of other artists both well known and less so; armour; sculptures in miniature plus, plus.
Also an elegant cafe restaurant.
I cannot believe I have lived to be an old man without having visited this museum before.

Fantastic !! Not to be missed.. The Wallace Collection is housed in the former Wallace home (more of a palace than a home) and is a short walk from Oxford Street. It houses an amazing collection of artifacts accumulated by the Wallace family over five generations and was donated to the nation in 1897. The house and it's collection opened as public museum in 1900.Among the treasures are 17th-19th century paintings including works by Rembrant, Reynolds, Canaletto, Rubens and other notable painters and sculpters of the period.There is also a magnificent display of arms and armour, furniture and clocks.This really is an amazing collection not to be missed.Allow 4 hours at least for a visit.Entrance is free but they ask for a donation which we were happy to give.There is a Cafe within the museum if you want to take a break.

Great for a particular audience. I'd always been aware that the Wallace Collection was impressive but it has taken me a while to visit. We had a two hour window in London to fill and there was too much here for two hours.I'm not very good at appreciating art, but if you are, then you will love the really impressive collection of famous artists' work. I was more impressed by the building's interior decor and the armour rooms. Some of the miniatures of Napolean caught our eye but we didn't see all of the collection at all and I'll have to go back.The cafe/restaurant is table service and the service charge of 12.5% will be added to your bill. The cakes aren't cheap but the ambiance is great and, given that entrance had been free, I didn't object to the prices. The thing that was irksome was the slow service. I should have perhaps been more assertive when I wanted the bill but we spent about 20 minutes in here waiting for the bill when we could have been looking around.As you're looking around you need to refer to the books in the rooms for descriptions of the items as the guides in the rooms won't necessarily know. Even then we found a glaive, as described in the book, and it looked fearsome, but we couldn't quite figure out how it would have been used. Research via smartphone wasn't overly illuminating either. None of the online images quite matched what we'd seen although I now have a new word to use if I ever take up Dungeons and Dragons.

Absolutely Fantastic!. There's so many kinds of items in this collection, it's amazing! The restoration in the rooms is also incredible, I especially liked the wallpapers and the armchairs. If you're looking for a relatively quiet museum that's part house museum, part Victoria and Albert, I highly recommend the Wallace Collection!!
Another nice day-out visit. If you have an appreciation for old houses of worthiness , with old antique furniture and art then do pay this a visit. Summer time would be a good time to go.

Fabulous and eclectic and it's free!. But please give a donation for this wonderful collection of one family. Very well displayed and worth a couple of hours visits. Amazing what wonderful artefacts that are there. Must be worth a fortune.
Lovely gallery. Lovely 30 min to 1 hour experience, lots of beautiful paintings and absolutely no crowds or queues. Great cafe

Perfect attraction not just in a rainy day. Unlike the Imperial War Museum which we visited afterwards, this time we had an unexpectedly pleasant surprise. We found paintings, ceramics and lots of armoury in an art museum. It's a place where one can spend around 2 hours among beautiful things.

Amazing Historic Town House with fine Decorative Art and Porcelain from Sevres. I was on a London Walk of Old Marylebone and we stopped in front of hertfprd House, Manchester Square, and John Walker our thoroughly entertaining blue badge guide told us the stories about Lady Hamilton and Mrs Robinson (Perdita) and that their paintings were in the Wallace Collection. so after our walk I paid a visit to see these paintings in this amazing Town house with its fine decorative 15-19th century art and it's huge collection of porcelain de Sevres, the largest collection outside of France. Plus Rococo art. I was gobsmacked, simply beautiful, especially the Great gallery. Wonderful paintings of the 'laughing Cavalier' and Mme Pompadour. Mrs. Robinson by Gainsborough. the visit is free and they have a wonderful restaurant in the atrium. This is a must visit next time you are in London
Wonderful small museum without crowds!. Lovely afternoon wandering around this beautiful house and seeing the lovely collections. Great cafe too.

Hidden Gem!. The most wonderful collection of art and armoury. The rooms are stunning and you get a real feel for how they must have lived in these beautiful town houses. The cafe/restaurant is well worth a visit......as are the toilets!! Absolutely wonderful plus no crowds, and free entry.
Interesting Collection. This place have a very beautiful and interesting collection. It's really nice to learn that the collection per se it is the work of different collectors in the same family.
A hidden delight. Had not intended to visit here, however so pleased we did, a real delight! A wonderful collection covering a world of delights.
A very interesting collection. A very varied and interesting collection.Enjoyed a delightful afternoon tea here. Not really for very young children as much reading and quiet is required

An excellent, underrated place. This museum offers a glimpse at what a family of art collectors could find trendy in their time. Like all speculators (word used here in the neutral sense, as guessing an uncertain future, not as dirty capitalists), they sometimes get it right, sometimes less so. Whether the buyers exercised judgement all the time or pursued opportunities as they come, is untold. The result is a somewhat disparate collection of what was anticipated to be fashionable then. Visitors should not impose themselves to visit all, but can discard what, in their own judgement, went to the dead ends of history of art.The rooms are arranged with the constraints given by the original set up. However, a lack of imagination has struck. Labelling of works is on the minimal side. A lot of staff members show their boredom and their longing for retirement. The use of digital technologies seems unknown. This may be part of the visit, I guess?

Remarkable. On visiting London recently, my wife and I dropped in to the Wallace Collection; a most remarkable aspect of this collection is that essentially it is the work of four collectors in the same family over less than 100 years; not a collection built up by governments over centuries; no - just the work of a small number of seriously dedicated collectors; (and I thought that we are hoarders!); in addition to the many fine pieces in the collection, there is a lovely restaurant in the middle of the building where you can have a small snack or a substantial meal for a reasonable price; over lunch we discussed what we could do all the stuff in our home.

A very good afternoon in London. Went here as i remembered the laughing cavilier from school art lessons. Enjoyed the whole trip far more than i expected. Excellent knowledgeable guide on free guided tour. The house is jam packed full of good paintings, antique furniture and beautiful porcelain. Very conveniently positioned behind selfidges and free admission. I would return and recommend. Thanks for a very good afternoon.
Pop in for a tour or stay for a few hours. A wonderful place in the heart of the west end. Free admission.Just see for yourself. Restaurant is very up-market.

A Must See. This museum is really for the traveler who has been in the UK before and wants something beyond the Changing of the Guard and the National Gallery. It houses a lot of works purchased by the Wallace family in the wake of the French Revolution. Gallery includes many Ancien Regime paintings of LaBrun and David as well as Dutch masters, armor, objets d'art (Sievres, Misen etc.) Well worth the visit, located in Manchester Square near Bond Street
Great collection. Great collection of furniture and paintings. Especially the furniture! 2 minutes walk from Selfridges.

A beautiful experience.. I loved everything about The Wallace Collection. This will from now on be one of my favourite places in London.I am embarrased to say that it has taken me 46 years of frequent visits to London to discover this wonderful place. Fragonard´s The Swing has been a favourite of mine for many years and there it was , unbelievable.

Amazing collection. I could have stayed all day. Quite the collection of paintings, arms, miniatures, etc. The restaurant was lovely in the atrium. But I was thrilled with the art books in the gift shop! I quickly purchased 2 for my collection.

Quality Displays at a Leisurely Pace. Superb displays of porcelain, armoury, paintings in lavish surroundings of a luxury house. Well worth a visit and just off Oxford Street. The surroundings are quiet and you would not think that you were in central London. Excellent.

One of my favourite galleries. The Wallace Collection is housed in a beautiful building in Manchester Square, W1. It feels like you are visiting a collection in a private house, where not only the pictures are superb, but also the furniture and decor.
There is an excellent restaurant, but we only stopped for coffee, so I cannot comment on the food. Next time, hopefully !
Brilliant Collection. Go for the Caravaggios, the setting, the furnishings, the armor, the portraits and Fragonar's The Swing. Go for the miniatures. Go. Just go. You will not be disappointed.
An absolute must. I stop by the Wallace Collection whenever I am in London. The collection of art and decorative objects is first rate and the mansion galleries are stunning.
Stunning Pieces. Loved our visit to this stunning house. Beautiful art and furniture. So many fine pieces to admire - will certainly return for another visit.

Interesting variety. Amazing collections of a family. spanning many generations from ancient saracen armour to fine bone China. The French kings mistress risqué portraits to the laughing Cavalier and Jesus. Definitely going back to see more of it.

Such a 'civilised' day out to a London tourist attraction.. I can't believe I've only just discovered this tourist attraction after living in Greater London all my life! Beautiful Georgian townhouse just behind Oxford Street. Huge collection of famous paintings, and large collection of armoury (some of which you can try on). I don't know anything about paintings but the guided tour taught me so much, and brought the house and its contents to life. Imagine the opulence of Windsor Castle state rooms, Tower of London Armoury rooms, National Gallery paintings, on a smaller scale in a Georgian Town House. The café/restaurant is beautiful, with delicious food. Your coats can be left at the front foyer, the toilets are clean and well equipped, no queues anywhere despite it being a Bank Holiday! Even my teenagers enjoyed themselves!! We only did the guided tour and had lunch, I need to go back to see all there is to see.

A must see museum. Off the beaten path for tourists.Amazing collection of arts and other collections in a beautiful house without the crowds.The restaurant has nice cake and a lovely atmosphere.What a nice gem !!

Old mansion transformed in museum. I would say for French tourists : if you enjoy Jacquemard Andre or Nissin de Camondo museum in Paris, you will love Wallace.
There some masterpieces (too bad that Canaletto's are hung too high on the wall)
you can bring children if they love Knight armor

World class art collection without the crowds. Having been to many great art galleries the one thing that sets this one apart is the lack of crowds.This is a top notch collection of art 200 yards from Selfridges. If you leave Selfridges by the Duke street exit you can see the House in the square as you look north.We went on Good Friday afternoon, its free to enter and the quality of the art was fabulous. As for the crowds, they did not exist. We stood in the great gallery, looking at the Laughing Cavalier, great detail, no one else in the gallery other than a curator. We went to the National Gallery the next day, wow it was busy in comparison.There's Titian, Rubens, Gainsborough, a room of Canaletto and so much more with time and space to appreciate the artLots of really good interesting pictures a short walk from Oxford Street.Yes we did pop into to Selfridges afterwards. So great art and great shopping.Go

Historic London Townhouse. This place is amazing. A nice slow stroll to have a giggle at the laughing cavalier, a good look at the Bust of Madame de Sérilly and then off for some great food in the restaurant.

Hidden Gem. This is off the beaten path for tourists, but what a find. This isanother museum that you don't want to miss if you are in London. We spent 2 hours there and only saw the first floor. There are several rooms covering the history of Armour and weapons. Several other rooms full of art, furniture etc. Also the home is amazing. There is a cafe in the courtyard area. We did not eat there but the cakes looked wonderful. Well worth an visit.

Beautiful house and diverse collection. I used to live in London and have since been back over a dozen times and I had never heard of the Wallace collection until a friend introduced me to it last year. Set in a former private 'country' estate (the city has since swallowed up the country around the house), the collection includes a huge amount of 18th and 19th century interior design and jewelry, as well as an enormous collection of weapons. Yeah, *that* diverse. Many pieces came from the royal collection at Versailles and Madame de Pompadour's estate, purchased after the Revolution. These collections are really stunning, and you should view them during a tour, which can provide the context and detailed information on the pieces that you'll see. In addition, the central courtyard has been glassed over and is now an all-weather cafe - really a nice place to come and have tea or a full meal. I'd highly recommend this hidden gem.
Historical Gem. A wonderful collection of art works in the most elegant setting not to be missed if visiting London.
A quiet gem. After visiting the large galleries in London, the Wallace Collection was a delight. Not too busy but crammed with wonderful things.

First visit but certainly not my last. So much to see we just didn't leave long enough time.I had no idea it was such a diverse collection. (I even enjoyed the Armour and weapons!).There is a very nice cafe/restaurant for lunch and a well laid out shop. You will need a full morning to see it all.

small but with a great collection of weapons and paintings. close to Oxford Street its easy to get to and well worth a visit for not only the collection but the rooms themselves. The weaponry and Armour collection is fantastic as is the collection of paintings and furnishings. a must visit place when in London.
Great small museum. One of the most fascinating small museums i have visited. The armory rooms are definitely my favourite.

A visit to the Wallace Collection with my mother. A collection that one cannot take in on one viewing but a place to return to again and again. Having lunch in the atrium was a particularly nice experience.
Worthy for visit collection. Free Admission. Rich collection of armor, weapons; great collection of vintage jewelry, interior design, tableware, personal care products.

if you like cottonwool type realism, this one is for you. great traditional art but not for the imaginative.. An excellent place to see 18 & 19th century art, though not everyone's taste. lovely building and collections, beautifully put together but not for the post modernist.

Amazing collection - not to be missed. This is a most amazing collection of art and other collections in a beautiful house right in the centre of London. And entrance is free!! Really need more than one visit to absorb everything. Staff are helpful and friendly. Useful details in all rooms. Plenty of seats on which to rest and view the collection. Spent the whole morning here. Lovely courtyard restaurant serving good food.

It is - as every one says - a gem and a "must-visit" location. There is a good selection of paintings - including a Rembrandt self-portrait and the Laughing Cavalier. There are also good collections or porcelain and statuettes. However, the best is the arms and armour collection.People complain about the tea; yes it is on the pricey end of the scale but we had excellent coffee and cakes!

A gem of a collection of classic art. A little out of the way, perhaps as it is not on the tourist trail but this gorgeous museum rewards the visitor who looks it out. Behind Oxford Street on the north side, the museum houses the collection of Sir Richard Wallace and includes classic art including paintings, sculpture, china and furniture. Of predominantly French origin, the collection also includes works by English and Dutch artists of varying notoriety. Do your research to identify the world-famous paintings one can see here. I would liken this museum to the Frick in New York City as the types of works are similar as is the setting of a family house. WELL worth a visit - allow at least 90 minutes to get a taste and then return to appreciate it even more, as is our intention.

Fascinating, Educational and such a beautiful museum - a must !!. One of the best showcases of English living in inner LOndon.I rank it as one of the top ten museum/art galleries of London. Not to be missed

A treasure trove or wonders in central London. One of my favourite hideaways in London, the Wallace Collection is a worthwhile visit for Londoners and tourists alike. An array of masterpieces line the walls and for anyone interested in armour, this is a must see. Staff are also incredibly helpful and the gift shop is divine (albeit a tad pricey.)
A Gem!. Wonderful collection of art tucked away in a great building, with a lovely courtyard cafe. Free Entry so can pop in and see a few rooms when ever passing....

Lovely visit. Recommended by a friend and as it was just around the corner from our hotel we decided to pay a visit before leaving London. Went not long after opening on Sunday so nice and quiet, plenty of room to look around. Lots of variety so whether you stay for a short or long time, there will always be something new to see. Well worth a visit.

Hidden Museum Gem. Located at Manchester Square, this is one of the most spectacular collections in London. Donated by the family for public viewing, this is a free museum that is not to be missed by art aficionados. The museum is free, so save your cash for a lovely (if a bit pricey) tea or lunch at the cafe in the courtyard. Or head over to Marelybone High Street to one of the many world-class restaurants in the neighborhood.
Bit of a hidden gem of a museum.. Loved the Wallace Collection, fantastic collection of paintings and various other items. Armoury items are superb.
Hidden gem. This is a hidden gem of a museum less well known than many in London but so worth a visit tucked behind selfridges easily combined with shopping

Really interesting museum in the centre of London. As the collection developed from the interests (and potential) of an aristocratic family mainly in 18-19 century it displays very different and attractive objects - valuable paintings, decorative art objects, armoury. The museum is located behind Selfridges; the entrance is free.

DON'T visit the restaurant...appaling behaviour from management . I visited this place on a recommendation from a close friend who had suggested this as a pleasant day out with affordable afternoon tea. I decided to pre-book our visit to cater for our group of 11, who had planned a visit for our friends baby shower as part of her weekend of pampering. The telephone booking was very informal, I informed the lady on booking that the numbers are not completely confirmed but she was quite happy to take the booking, no reservation fee was taken, no terms and conditions stated. We were very excited because the gallery looked beautiful from the pictures and it certainly didn't dissapoint with beautiful paintings, artefacts, exquisite furnishings and decor. We had pre-booked our afternoon tea and we were seated at our table by one of the waiters. We informed them that 2 of our party had cancelled that morning due to childcare issues and therefore we no longer needed as many seats at our table. The extra small table was removed from our party and set up to accommodate for other guests, as the restaurant takes walk in customers for their afternoon tea. Unfortunately it went downhill from there. The whole afternoon was ruined by a completely unpleasant man who I assume is the manager. A chap dressed in a suit who couldn't be more unhelpful or rude if he had tried.Having made some dietary requests on pre-booking, we were promptly told that those changes may not have been made and he would have to check with the chef but they would try to accommodate nonetheless. Well this was fine, it happens. We told him that was fine and appreciated that he would try. We were then handed the menu for the afternoon tea. We asked if we could order any sides with our afternoon tea and were told that we couldn't because the restaurant doesn't open alongside the afternoon tea (this was strange as others who had visited recently had recommended ordering sides because the tea wasn't quite filling enough and had done so themselves without any difficulty).On choosing our preferred teas from a range of teas available on the afternoon tea menu, we were told by this man that because we were a group of 11, we could only choose from breakfast or mint tea. Well this baffled us, surely if you book afternoon tea, you should be able to choose the teas from that menu? And why should the number of your party restrict your options? When we raised this point, the gentleman had no response as to why this rule applied. Nonetheless we prompted to choose from the 2 options available. A member of our party remembered that in fact we were no longer a party of 10 so we clarified if we would now be able to have a choice of teas. The man then informed us that whether they had turned up or not, we would have to pay for their afternoon tea also?! When we questioned why that was the case, he tried to suggest that it was because we had pre-booked and that was their policy. Then when we probed why this hadn't been mentioned on booking, he changed his tune and tried to suggest that this was because of the dietary changes we had made. The same dietary changes he had told us earlier he wasn't even sure had been implemented. He suggested they had turned customers away because they were fully booked and therefore would be losing business. The afternoon tea runs for about 2.5hrs and having arrived at the start, we couldn't see why having a table now free and plenty of guests still in the gallery and trickling into the restaurant, the table would not be filled. Having completely ruined the atmosphere at this point, he stated that if they get walk in guests requesting afternoon tea and they managed to fill the table then we would not have to pay for the extra 2 afternoon teas for our party. Within 30 minutes the table was filled. The whole experience was abysmal. As much as we tried to enjoy our day, the sour end left a bitter taste in our mouths.On a final note, our waiter was very attentive and friendly. I recommend the restaurant management be reviewed because service like that doesn't belong in such a beautiful place. I certainly will never return and have told friends and family the same.

a true gem of a museum , hidden away but a must place to visit. a beautiful well-maintained house. stunning rooms. excellent armoury exhibition. very nice restaurant. Well worth a visit. just a short walk away from the hustle and bustle of Oxford St.Staff very friendly and extremely knowalagble

A gem I never knew existed!. What a wonderful collection of art in a beautiful house! It houses the largest collection of Canaletto's work I have ever seen, plus Rembrandt, Gainsborough and Titian! The furniture is amazing and we enjoyed a free guided tour. We had tea and scones in the lovely glass covered courtyard. Well worth a visit!

Outstanding. The Wallace Collection houses an extraordinary range and variety of art. You could spend an hour or a day here. One of London's best museums with a justifiably highly regarded restaurant. Worth seeking out.

Most interesting. The Wallace Collection is really a hidden jewel in London. Friend recommended and we loved it. It is close to Oxford St., Selfridges and M&S - so take 2 hours and enjoy this most interesting place.
Hidden gallery gem. Wonderful quiet hidden gallery just off Oxford Street. Great place to meet for lunch and a quick spin round the gallery.
Loved it!. It was a fantastic collection! We could have spent all day! Look for the miniatures of Napoleon and ask one of the docents about it.

excellence. This is an outstanding gallery visit.
Superb collction of course in a beautiful house.
Excellent musuem shop too and of course a very good restaurant
Hidden jewel. Lovely place to wander around and see all the fabulous paintings and ceramics -had a lovely coffee and cake with friend
The Hidden Gem. I've been here twice, and would urge visitors to see the place. It is behind Selfridges, and could be missed. Beautiful place, but one that is not well advertised.

Exquisite works of art. I hadn't heard of this collection until a friend told me that I must visit and am so glad I did. Expect to be bowled over by stunning displays of armour, fine porcelain, furniture from the court of Louis 14th of France and perhaps most impressively, paintings by Reubens, Rembrandt, Titian and Caneletto. I was lucky to arrive at the right time to join a wonderful guided tour with a most charming and knowledgeable guide, who gave us lots of inside information on the interpretation of some of the paintings and the intriguing signs and symbols within them. And it is all free of charge, though I think, given the huge Wow factor, that many will feel happy to make a donation after their visit.
Antiquities Gallore. Definitely a must see, an easy museum to walk around with some very interesting displays . Nice to go to a place that didn't charge an arm and a leg to get in

Overwhelming, somewhat eclectic, and absolutely fascinating. Not to be missed -- and certainly requiring revisiting. The grouping of related items is fascinating: The armour, guns, and swords of imperial England; the portraits; the long period of collecting paintings of Venice; and the culminating large ballroom of large paintings.

Exciting collections. This a less known smaller museum tacked away in a little nook of Manchester Square behind Selfridges. Exciting collections of armoury, porcelains and period furnitures. The rooms are beautiful ornate and fabulously shimmering in gilded regency decor. Visit the Wallace Collection for a truly fabulous day.

Business over a coffee . A delightful place to meet in the West End , a stones throw from the Marble Arch end of Oxford Street. If you arrive too early then there's the wonderful art collection to wander around. There was no problem in just ordering two coffees and no hassle from the ever willing waiting staff. The food on other tables looked perfectly fine, simple fare nothing too fancy, perfect for either a quick lunch or a longer business meeting.

A real beauty...... It is a very well-thought collection with some very interesting pieces that will amaze you. It is worth a visit if only to see the area and admire the outside of the museum. Make sure to spend some time at the gift shop as it has some very interesting things to buy that you won't see elsewhere.

An absolute gem.. We have lived in the South -East for years but have never been here before .What a mistake! It is an absolute treasure trove of wonderful collections of art (Italian and Dutch especially good), ceramics, armour and curios such as exquisite 3d wax portraits, with jewel embellishments. The guide we met was friendly, informative and enthusiastic and obviously loved the being there.It wasn`t busy for a Saturday and had a peaceful, unhurried ambience. It also has a lovely enclosed courtyard dining area which was very popular. You need to go more than once to truly appreciate this special place.

Easy to find, off the beaten path, great collection, and free. How can you beat a free museum with a great collection of artwork and mid-evil armory, no crowds, and easy to get to from the Bond Street Underground station. Some folks we met on the plane over to London highly recommended this place, and I have to agree with their recommendation. Lots of 15th, 16th, and 17th century artwork. And, an amazing collection of armor, armory, guns, pistols, knives, and other war tools. A short walk from the Bond Street Underground station. We went mid-afternoon on a nice Saturday in March...no crowds and easy to take our time in the exhibits.

Amazing private collection. We came here following a morning at Madam Tussaud's, for a different kind of display altogether. By now we already have been to quite a few galleries and museums. Even then we still found this quite worthwhile, and it's free!We spent the most amount of time looking at the armours and weapons used in the past. Impressive!

Nice collection if you have a guide but not a must-see. I recently attended an event here, where we had tour guides show us around the collection. I very much appreciated it, as I only recognised one painting ('The Swing' was featured in the Frozen movie!). Alot of the furniture is Marie Antoinette's, which I really loved. Definitely make use of the guides if you can! If this is your visit to London though and aren't that big of an art buff, don't bother putting it on your list.

Absolutely blown away!. I'm a military history buff so went to this museum initially to see the extensive arms and armour collection. However the collection of art just grabbed me and didn't let go. Being able to get so close to so many works by the great masters of European art in relaxed, quiet galleries was amazing. Spent hours here just absorbing.I will be back!

Lovely collection if you know what you are looking at!. A friend took me here - she has a degree in Art History so this was right up her street. To be honest there was not much in the way of guidance and I am sure if I didn't have her with me, I would have sped past most of the works without really appreciating what I was looking at.
Love this place. Beautiful place to go and lose yourself. I have been twice already this year and i always spot something i missed previously.
Fantastic Collection. We could stay all day in this lovely building filled with beautiful objects. What an inspiring place to visit.

Tea Time at the Wallace. A friend recommend going for tea at the Wallace. Even though the place is beautiful and the staff was super friendly, we found tea very expensive (and they charge full price for children! ). We paid 40 pounds for us both with a tea pot and a variety of sweets and little t-sandwiches ( my son who was 10 hardly touched his tea) and next time I think ordering just one set of tea would be the better option.

Great for an afternoon visit.. Wonderful small museum just behind Oxford Street. Not intimidating in size and a great selection of almost everything - we particularly liked the porcelain, art and armoury. Beautiful restaurant in the atrium.

Lovely collection of art and artefacts. This collection is so intimate, presented throughout the house on Manchester Square. Always a delight to visit with treasures such as Fragonard's Girl on a Swing; Frans Hals' Laughing Cavalier; and each room's unique decoration.

Wonderful small museum of Art and furniture with famous "Laughing Cavalier" painting. This museum is a London gem that more people should visit. Donated to the Nation- hence the free admission. Lovely restaurant. Each room takes your breath away with the beauty of all the items. Only a 5 mins walk from Oxford or Baker Streets in a small quiet square.Don't miss it on any visit to London !Perhaps not a museum to take kids to- I'd be frightened of them breaking something, and it is not really suitable for youngsters

Very good collection. Its a nice museum to visit to see something besides the most popular attractions. There are not so many visitors and you have all the freedom to contemplate the works displayed. The weapons and armors collection is interesting and there are also some famous paintings to be seen.
Perfect tea. Had a family get together with high tea in the cafe and it was delicious. Great room and comfortable seat in a relaxed setting.

Fantastic museum collection. it s definitely one of the best places to visit in london. Absolutely superb. Been there on a saturday morning with my husband and friend and we enjoyed this awsome collection which we heard about from a friend. You won t regret this visit surely.
Totally amazing!. We had a free guided tour of the collection and it was great!! Especially loved the still life collection! Very stunning interior!

Stunning, fascinating and free!. The rooms are often as beautiful as the treasures they contain. What an amazing collection! You could easily spend a very long time combing through every piece of it and being captivated by the beauty. It's wonderful that it's free and kept in such beautiful condition with great facilities and a nice cafe. Perfect for a rainy, cold winter's day!

Amazing!. We literally stumbled accross this collection.It is amazing. And free!!Well presented throuout with guided tours on offer and an ecclectic mix of art, porcelain and armour on dispaly.It also has a fantastic cafe.Hunt this place out and you won't be disappointed
Nice place for a brows and lunch. Perfect little stop when you have a few hours on hand to peek back into the past. Lunch is unhurried and in such a pretty setting.

A splendid way to spend a few hours on a winter Sunday. Free admission to a peerless collection of fine art, armoury, antique French furniture combined with a guided tour in a superb setting is a must see. There's also a very acceptable restaurant for relaxing - delicious crab salad.
highly recommened to visit. Just amazing! lovely staff and a beautiful building with very interesting items on display. highly recommened.
Good place to visit.. An ideal place to spend a few hours. Rooms are very interesting, paintings, armoury, weapons. Lovely cake in the restaurant and lovely surroundings.

A real joy!. The collection is amazing, and our guide on the free highlights tour was extremely knowledgeable, easy to listen to and witty! I would highly recommend a visit (we were there on Monday 29th Feb 2:30 tour) and allow plenty of time as there is so much to see - will definitely return!

A cultural must. This is a great place to enjoy a cultural day out in London. Anyone who has visited Versaille will appreciate some of the furnishings and antiques here. A pleasant way to spend an afternoon and the added bonus is that its free entrance!

Just Fabulous. Hand over your bags etcetera at the door and turn off your camera's flash setting before setting off on an enthralling encounter with this museums exhibits. The world class armoury collection is amazing and features an awesome array of long bows and cross bows, fire arms, and suits of armour. To top it off there is a magnificent 18th century assembly of French furniture, paintings (Old Masters), clocks and porcelain. We could easily have spent a whole day wondering through the various galleries if we had known in advance what was in store.

An Oasis of Tranquility Behind Selfridges!. This is one of London's finest collections. It is never busy. It is always fascinating. It is world-class. Franz Hals' Laughing Cavalier is there - but its fame is far outshone by by the gallery it sits in and its fellow exhibits.The Wallace Collection also boast one of London's secrets - its fine restaurant that occupies the glass ceilinged former inner courtyard and is now an elegant conservatory that Oscar Wilde himself would have no doubt found solace in. You can actually spend an entire day here, hiding away from the hideousness of Oxford Street.

A hidden gem of amuseum of fine art French furnishings and Armour. The armour collection on the ground floor is stunning. The flemish art collection with Rubens Rembrandt De Hooch Frans Hals etc one of the best apart from the Queen's. Admirers of Sevres pottery and french furniture will be delighted. There is also a room dedicated to medieval artifacts.The covered restaurant in the courtyard is OK but service has been slow.
One of my favorites museum in town!. I loved this collection in this beautiful mansion setting. The great gallery has amazing art as well as the European armoury is great to look around!

Great little window on history. My partner and I always stay in this area of Marylebone on our yearly trips to London. The Wallace Museum we usually visit biannually and think it's very interesting slice of history. Recommended if you don't have a lot of time.
huge collection to view. this has a huge collection of a range of items from miniature boxes and paintings to full sets of armour. fascinating building with much to see

A little gem tucked away off Oxford Street/Baker Street. An old private town house housing the collection of former owners this gallery has a collection of all kinds of works of art - from old coins to Louis Quinze furniture [there is a big emphasis on French objets d'art] not to mention its marvellous collection of paintings - the most well known being The Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals.Its free to go in and there are free tours at 11am and 2pm [check times] with a guide which last about 75 minutes and look at a small selection of the exhibits in some detail.
Upper class art. Agem of a building tucked away in London. A place for art connoiseurs really. Nice building and gift shop, but quite stuffy staff and not a place to take young children.

A stunning collection. The Wallace Collection is a jewel, figuratively and literally. The collections of arms and armour, works of art and paintings are superb, assembled by the Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace. The gold snuff boxes are world class, and the collection includes what is arguably the best Mughal dagger in the world.

An amazing collection. Put this on your list of things to see in London. It is a collection of many different collections - from paintings to miniatures to ceramics to armor, and more! All in one place. Do try to get on a tour that points out some of the highlights.

Interesting place. I found this place very interesting. I have never heard of it before I came to London, but it was a nice surprise. It has a lot of different stuff in there, but my favorite part was the one dedicated to war pieces, especially guns and armors. Must visit if you have a time.

Best museum for French Versailles furnishings and paintings. Unbelievably this fantastic house museum has free entry. I visited Kensington Palace which has nothing much to see and too much fake ambiance and had to pay £16 to enter, it is quite incredible that one of the best museums in London is free. The Wallace Collection is in an elegant mansion townhouse in central London, easy to get to from a number of underground stations, and a haven back to a more beautiful era. The original owner of the collection bought several items at auction from France after the French Revolution government ruthlessly emptied the wonderful collections within the French palaces. The Wallace Collection holds the largest private collection in the world of French pieces and paintings from Versailles and other royal chateaus. Fortunately, the art and furnishings have been kept in perfect condition, a tribute to the owner's foresight and great love of beautiful things. The Wallace Collection is a very special place as it manages to do two very hard things: every artpiece is displayed magnificently and the house still retains the ambiance of a living home. One of my favourite places is the mezzanine floor with corner windows and large Edwardian-style plants that gives the feeling of a miniature conservatory and the great staircase that takes you up there. The staircase was saved from a former bank in Paris. When I have enough money I want to become a lifetime Friend of the Wallace Collection and be able to donate to this really wonderful place.

Fascinating display. This is an exceptional collection of art, furniture and ceramics, to say nothing of dozens of other interesting items. It does not get over-crowded so it is possible to view at leisure.

Hidden gem of London. When tourists visit London, they don't think of this museum, however, it really is wonderful, quieter and a wonderful place to spend time. They also have a nuce cafe with a glassy roof. You won't be disappointed.

A jewel. This is one of my favourite places in London. The 4th Marquess of Hertford, who had the advantage of not being poor, amassed an extraordinary collection of art-works in the late 19th C., which his widow bequeathed to the nation with the stipulations that admission should forever be free, and no objects should ever leave the collection.No city boasts more or better museums and galleries than London, but none of them are as accessible as this. In a couple of hours you can whizz round and sample its delights, but a dozen visits will still yield rewards.Thoroughly recommended.

One of the untold secrets that London has to offer !!!. I have been going to the Wallace Collection for over 15 years, an exception collection of the highest order, Ceramics, Paintings, Furniture, Weapons, Amour, Glass, Sculptures, Carvings and Tapestries plus so much more.Very good dining facilities and cafeteria. Parking can be a pain but there is good public transport. Baker Street or Oxford Circus underground stations are nearby as are many buses.

A tranquil place. An interesting but narrow range of classic pre impressionist mainly French paintings.not usually busy with a good cafe and restaurant in an impressive setting,so a good meeting place for friends.temporary exhibitions can be worth a look

he was nowhere to be seen. Ive been a fan of Wallace and indeed Gromit for years so was delighted a the prospect of seeing a collection. I was disappointed to see that its just a load of old stuff, no machines that make breakfast, no motorcycle and sidecar just pictures and furniture. Really not what I was expecting.

excellent place to visit. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Wallace Collection. Wonderful collection of paintings and objects and certainly recommend it for a visit - will visit again in the future.

wonderful and free. what a wonderful place to visit and especially because it is free. every room has such beautiful artwork and design. you can wander for so long room to room. if you're peckish there's a restaurant too on the ground floor.

Wonderful place for lunch. Perfect place to meet for lunch as you can view the gallery if one of you is early. Food is terrific and the café not expensive - with the alternative of the restaurant. A real hidden gem!

Great Central Location to Hang Out and Feed Your Head. The Wallace Collection is located in Central London and is very easy to get to. The permanent and changing exhibits are always interesting and the cafe is a nice place to have a snack and hang out and read. There are other very 'Wellcoming' public spaces in this place where one can read, relax and people watch.

Opulent elegance at it's best.. This amazing place is free, always good. Conveniently located not far from Bond Street underground. Was previously a private residence on a grand scale. Full of beautiful paintings, portraits and furniture. There is very interesting armoury too. The rooms have been refurbished over the last decade or so to the highest standards, sumptuous fabrics and rich colours, the chandeliers glitter and sparkle. Conveniently located seating allows the visitor to sit and admire. There is a lovely cafe, and shop with a good selection of art books and delightful gifts sensibly priced.We looked at most items, visit took just under 2 hours. Guides were very helpful and knowledgeable.

Afternoon Tea. A group of 5 friends met at The Wallace Collection for afternoon tea - it was traditional with little sandwiches, scones with jam and cream and a daily changing selection of little cakes

A jewel of a museum. Amazing knowledgeable staff particularly the 1 hour highlights tour (free). The collection of old masters is amazing as is the arms and armoury.. Only 10 mins walk from Marble Arch. Go there.

Wow, wow, wow..... I remember visiting here as a child and obviously the Laughing Cavalier stands out as a memory (why have they moved it to such a poor location?) What I didn't remember was the cornucopia of stunning world class artworks, furniture,miniatures, crafted pieces - some of which I think are unique or don't recall seeing anything similar anywhere else.Amazingly entry is free and the room settings are beautiful. And yes there is a lovely restaurant/tearoom. I'm definitely going back again soon as there is so much to see you can't take it all in on one visit.

What a surprise. We were only killing time until Selfridge's opened at 11:30 on Sunday. We were so happily surprised with this home and art collection. It was wonderful to be able to see how the wealthy lived in the 1800's. And the art collection that the family amassed is spectacular. We especially appreciated the postings on each doorway of a photograph of how the room looked when the home was lived in by the family.
Worth seeing. A very impressive home museum in a lovely location. Excellent artwork and sculptures. High tea in the cafe a highlight.

The home of the Laughing Cavalier. I took my Meetup group here which was delightful - this is a little gem that is tucked away... It has sumptuous rooms to marvel at and an exquisite array of artefacts - so much to see I need to go again.
Great museum, off the touristy galleries. Great history in this house. The art collection is magnificent. Do the free guided tour to get an understanding of the home and art history.

Art Lovers.. I adore this art gallery as it never seems to be busy. It is a delight to wander around without being rushed and crushed by the crowds so prevalent in other London galleries. The art is spectacular and is housed in the most gorgeous buiding. A must see in London.l

Hidden gem. This museum is absolutely amazing. I can't stress enough how great the collection is and how interesting it is because everything is exhibited in what was formerly a house. I highly recommend this museum, especially since it is somewhat off the beaten track.
gorgeous. love this and had a massively romantic stroll through it. The atmosphere is wonderful and the Laughing Cavalier reason enough to visit.
A day out with a friend. Excellent collection, not too big to get around in a couple of hours. I thought that the pottery was outstanding

Impressive collection!. The location of the museum does not reflects its value - it's a unique place where you can peacefully enjoy one of the greatest collection of art, jewellery and antique weapons I have ever seen. Exhibits there are very diverse, information attached to every item is comprehensive and the museum itself is not very crowded, so you can admire the art in total peace. Highly recommend!
