Architectural gem hidden away behing Bond Street. If you're an Art lover this is a "must see" when visiting London.The story behind the collection and how it was bequeathed to the nation is as interesting as many of the artefacts. Marvellous French 18th century Art and furniture , lots of rococo and a fine collection of antiquities. It has a marvellous restaurant , cafe in the central courtyard.

A treasure trove assembled by one family over three generations. The Wallace collection is an amazing collection off paintings, furniture, china and artefacts gathered over a long period of time. The collection reflects the tastes and interests of the individual family members, and it is amazing that it is all together under the original family roof. Whatever your interests, The Wallace is a place you can visit again and again.

Exquisite building full of treasures. The Wallace Collection is well worth the visit - open 7 days a week and admission is free. The collection houses so many artefacts, furniture, jewellery and beautiful paintings - I loved the Gainsborough paintings. Do yourself a favour and do visit this attraction when you are in London

Wonderful secret museum and delightful cafe. What a find, I'd been years ago then recently my son recommended we go to see the museum but also to have coffe in the restaurant / cafe there. Just beautiful

Superb collection. Not too large to overwhelm.. Great great collection. Something for all and free! One spectacular watch to find and the armour rooms brilliant. How did they fight in all that stuff? Variety by the bucket load. Highly recommended.
Better than the National gallery. I prefer this one than the national gallery, especially the portray section. Very pretty and free entry.

An Unknown Treasure. We return every couple of years and always marvel at the treasures within - brilliant art in a serene environment. Hertford House is small enough to get around in one visit - and great restaurant.

Secret place. I had been meaning to visit the Wallace collection for years and finally got there in January. It's the kind of place that you need to visit on a number of occasions as there is so much to see and take in. It oozes richness and a lif spent collecting.I didn't visit the cafe but the space where it is located looked wonderful. A place to visit again and again

An Oasis of Beauty and Style. Friends of ours recommended we go see this and, boy, were they right! This you'd almost call it one of the best kept secrets (in that few people seem to realise how good it is) in Central London. Just a 6 minute or so walk away from Bond Street underground you have this wonderful mansion full of the most intricate paintings, furniture and excellent decoration generally (the only bit of art you are allowed to touch is the staircase....). We got there well in time for the daily 2:30pm free tour (so had a coffee and hot chocolate in the excellent cafe first - must go there for something more extensive next time) which was conducted by a very capable Polish volunteer lady. After the tour we walked round the same rooms once more to take everything in at leisure and study in more detail what we'd seen. But we are very aware that we haven't seen everything yet by a long way so we plan to return here to see more on some future occasion we happen to be in London with a few hours on our hands.

A great visit. Not huge but definitely magnificent collection. The paintings are more than world class and there is a fantastic collection of armour and weapons. All in a beautiful historic mansion with a very intimate atmosphere.

Unbelievably Good. The finest art collection in London, but please don't tell anyone in case it gets too well known.You'll see art that you only ever saw in books or on the net.You'll see arms and armour about which only historians know.The Laughing Cavalier will laugh in your face. Almost literally.All within 10 minutes walk of Oxford Street.But please don't tell anyone.

A hidden gem just minutes from Oxford St. Enter the world of a sophisticated traveller and avid collector from a bygone age. See some stunning paintings from very famous artists and enjoy a delicious meal in the cafe. A complete and a delicious day out.

Wonderful Museum. This is one of the most beautiful places in London, just a few minutes walk from Bond Street station, the house is so beautiful, and the museum and art gallery make it even better, many beautiful paintings, Canalettos etc, lots of French antiques furniture etc,,perhaps too much to see for one visit, nice coffee shop too, and its amazing for London, because..... its actually FREE ! really recommended.

We Loved the Wallace Collection.. A smallish wonderful mansion full of all the things one would expect in such a home. It was a chilly rainy day and this was the perfect place to spend time indoors. I absolutely recommend a visit here.
A hidden treasure. Having lived in London for 30 yrs what a free pleasure just to pop in the Wallace to view a rich and world class collection
Beaytiful collection of paintings. we walked from the apt. to the museum. Like other museums in london, theres no entry charge. The collection is vey impressive/

Definitely worth a visit. The displays of artwork are well set out and there is a sense of space as you move around. You never feel crowded or under pressure to move on. The array of paintings is vast and caters to most tastes. I would recommend it to anyone with an interest in the history of art

A place to visit more than once. Having a couple of hours to kill pre Cirque Du Soleil I decided to visit the Wallace collection, and I will certainly return. Free entry, although they encourage donations & to purchase the guidebook, 3 floors of eclectic works. From Frans Hals' The Laughing Cavalier (which I assumed was in the Louvre or some National Gallery), to Canaletto, Joshua Reynolds, many illuminated manuscript paintings, & miniatures. Many exquisite pieces of furniture, sculptures, snuff boxes, porcelain, majolica & glass are scattered throughout the richly decorated rooms. There are several rooms devoted to English, European & Middle Eastern armoury including 2 life sized armoured horses. Nice shop, individual toilets and a cafe complete the experience. Top class

What a day. I went to the Wallace Collection last year with my partner for our anniversary. I was embarrassed that I had never been before, especially as its only down the road from where I used to live in Marylebone High street! What a delightful, eclectic collection, and the story behind its genesis is remarkable. It is an absolute feast for anyone who goes there, I know we I'll be back! If you haven't been already, you really should, it's inspiring to say the least!

Fabulous. It's free, it's close to Oxford street and is packed with amazing art, what other reason do you need? What a collection, a complete oasis in the metropolis worth popping in just for an hour and there is a nice cafe too to relax in.
Fantastic Collection. I never tire of visiting this fantastic venue. It is amazing how someone can collect such a wide and diverse range of artifacts. Not to be missed.

Hidden gem!. That's one of the best attractions in London for art lovers! I could stay the whole day, it's very big and have great pieces of furniture and paintings. We attended to the guided tour and our guide was truly amazing! I wished she could go on explaining us in her captivating and passionate way all the pieces. It's a free attraction in central London and would require at least 2 hours for a short peak! I will definitely go back and carry on enjoying the beautiful pieces of art work!

Great place to dip into and admire. It's free, so pop in when you have an hour to kill. Fantastic collection of art, furniture and ornaments. See what you have time for then come back again for another short visit later...or stay for the morning or afternoon there's plenty to see. An awesome looking restaurant in amazing surroundings in the rear of the building I've yet to try, but I'm sure others have reviewed

As near perfect as could be possible.. We had time for a short visit here before our pre-booked tour at Broadcasting House nearby.It wasn't nearly long enough to appreciate any part of the Collection as there is so much to see and admire here and a superb café/restaurant in lovely surroundings.Being familiar with this marvellous attraction in its handsome building in a nice quiet location yet close to the bustle of Oxford Street, I was able to show my family-member guest some of the highlights. I have always found the staff to be polite and attentive here and I appreciate that they often have a very difficult job; as I have witnessed, on more than one occasion, the way they are mistreated by some visitors.Hours could be spent here on a single visit.Anyone who reviews this place negatively must be very hard to please. If I didn't like it I would simply turn back and use the door through which I entered!
Heaven!. I forget how many times I've been here. One hundred maybe, and I always find something new. So much beauty hidden away. Never too crowded and always a great refreshment.

Wallace Collection - what a collection!. On the recommendation of my English neighbour back home, my husband and I spent 3 hours at this wonderful house/palace/museum. And we could have spent more time. The collection is amazing - there's something there for everyone - art, sculptures, porcelain, décor, furniture. It's wonderful that everything is as it was - thank heavens for families like this who collected artefacts over several generations, and then donate them to the public so that we can enjoy them. And the audio guide was excellent, and free! The café was well patronised, with an adequate menu, although we didn't partake.

Exquisite furnishings. We spent just a short time at this museum. (Note that it is free) We enjoyed the downstairs "Conservation Department" with armor and a display about how marquetry for furniture is made.

Hidden Gem. What a gem in the very centre of the commercial shopping area. A haven of peace and tranquility. Paintings on display for the romantics and rooms of such beauty and elegance. I have often been to the Wallace and never have enough of its treasures.Tip Try to coincide the visit with one of their free guide sessions

Most interesting Collection. We were delighted to have visited the Wallace Collection. The collection of armors and weapons was most impressive. The rooms were beautifully furnished and we especially liked the desk and other furniture with hidden drawers. The paintings were interesting but not the highlight of the collection.

Beautiful exhibition of art. Went here with work colleagues last year as we work in a related industry. This is a beautiful building and the artwork collection is so beautiful. I was particularly interested in the armoury exhibition also. Well worth a visit

What a lovely surprise!. We celebrated a friend's baby shower here with afternoon tea. I loved the museum & thought it was unique & made the whole occasion very memorable. Great for anyone visiting the city.

One of our favourite place in London. This is a great place - brilliant collection of armour, some wonderful paintings (including some great Canaletto's) and loads of other wonderful bits in the collection.
Its not too big and its FREE.
They have a lovely covered courtyard for lunch - not cheap but worth it for a bit of a treat!
Wallace Review. Fantastic Collection, huge amount to see, put aside at least 4 hours. The display covers a wide range of interesting artefacts.

Wonderful museum. This is a museum unlike any other in London. It feels like a miniature stately home, crammed full of fabulous eighteenth century furniture, Gainsboroughs, Rembrandts, suits of armour from the sixteenth century, miniatures, marquetry furniture, just a treasure chest of the decorative arts. There's a brilliant cafe/restaurant AND the museum has no admission charge (voluntary contributions are welcome)! A great way to spend a morning and a haven of culture close to the shopping mania of Oxford Steeet.

Nostalgic. More than 40 year ago I visited the Collection and was very impressed by a small painting representing a scene with horses at an inn. Could not remember the name but with my limited description the lady host immediately pointed me exactly in the right direction (taking into account the number of items in the museum that is impressing! Thank you for your kind assistance.The painting is by "Meissonier". Title 'Halt at an Inn'.Salvador Dali was influenced by Meissonier.The total collection is spectacular, however because of the many items 'lightning' is far from perfect.The Tearoom/restaurant is very good.
A must when visiting London. Most amazingly sumptuous and spectacular place to visit. The art works are not to be missed and the colours of each room a real treat.

Great way to spend a rainy Sunday afternoon.. Beautiful house and a magnificent collection, we had a great time just wondering around and then stopped in the cafe for afternoon tea. Had a lovely afternoon.

A secret waiting to be enjoyed. The Wallace Collection is one of my favourite places in London. A private collection of the most beautiful Art, from paintings to sculpture, divine furniture and exquisite porcelain to weaponry -it has it all. Guided, costumed tours and interesting talks and displays are held regularly as well. And all for free and just a stone's throw behind busy Oxford St /Selfridges.An absolute must see.
Hidden Gem. So much to see, especially some of the beautiful paintings. But the best bit is the restaurant in the centre courtyard.

Just lovely!. Been here a couple of times with my sister. The art and building are lovely, interesting and quite unique. We have had lunch and afternoon tea here too and both were very nice. Will come back next time my sister visits.

Unique and varied collection. This is not a big museum experience, however anyone with an interest in porcelain, miniatures, armory and more won't be disappointed to step into the world of private collectors. We were fortunate enough to have a docent tour the house with us which I would really recommend for the story of the house's architecture. The collection is so eclectic as it was acquired by many generations over time that you just have to go with it.
A London gem. Tremendous collection of paintings, statues, armor, and decorative arts.Plan to spend 4-5 hours, including lunch or tea at the wonderful cafe.

A hidden gem with a really nice restaurant attached.... An eclectic mix of artifacts and art - free to visit. Delightfully accessible and tucked out of the way. An oasis of calm and class a few moments walk from the madness that is Oxford Street. A very pleasant restaurant is attached and a an hour or two taking in the collection followed by lunch is a pretty cool way to spend half a day.

Once you are done with all the rest. Wonderful London Museum. Located just a block away from Oxford Street, this Museum offers free entry to a very intimate but excellent collection of art. Do not miss the fabulous Watteaus and the two materpieces of the collection, 'Dame with a Fan" by Velazquez and "the Laughing Chevalier' by Franz Hals. It is easy to miss the imposing armory in the bottom floor. Don't.

Former private palace with great art collections. This charming old family palace has a wonderfull setting and a unique history. It is filled with great art - like Fragonard's The Swing från 1767 and Hals' The Smiling Cavallier - and also a wonderful restaurant in the conservatory. I've stopped by a least four times by now...
Wonderful English town house with French masters and armoury collection. free and unique insight into London Society of the late 19th C. Sumptuous furniture and architecture

Wonderful place full of beauty and lovely staff. This is one of my favourite places in London. I've never found it crowded and I always find something I've not noticed before. The room attendants are very knowledgable about the items and are happy to tell you if you'd only ask! And the cafe is quite wonderful too!

London's Hidden Gem. If you're into armour, and weaponry, this is probably one of the best collections in town. Be prepared to spend a lot of hours (as with most London museums) as there's also a lot to see. The collections are not as extensive as other museums, but it's not underwhelming; there's certainly a lot to see. Good scones and tea at the cafe, and the ambiance is not too shabby either, with its glass ceilings.

Amazing art collection. An amazing collection of art, wonderful paintings, furniture, fine bone china and many more items. You can easily spend a few hours there discovering the two floors. Highly recommended.
Wallace Collection. Very nice place to spend the afternoon exploring. Beautiful collection of history and goods. Great place to visit.

Stunning collection and room settings. My first but not last visit last week A really useful guided tour of the highlights of the collection which took 1hr 15. The Sevre porcelain furniture , and pictures were magnificent,. tHe rooms are also styled with traditional window hangings and fabric walls in colours which enhance the collection. The walls are full of picture to enable comparison between styles and artists. Need a few more visits to see it all in detail . dOnt often buy guidebook butthink I will to appreciate it better.

Oh my goodness. Having many years ago studied the history of art I couldn't believe just how many pictures I recognised . Loved the ambience of the house , the collections are amazing should have had more than the morning there .

Key cultural venue - but there's a rub..... While it is an excellent reminder of what idle rich folk did with their money - while poor folk toiled and struggled to live - see past that and you will find a visit to the Wallace Collection time well spent. It is a fascinating and uplifting tribute to arts and crafts of the past. The stunning fine illustrative work on ancient armouries, through the vivid (if not gaudy) splashes of the chunky ceramics, to the ornate and facile fussiness of the showy furniture and flash fittings, to the captivating subtlety of Reynolds and Gainsborough. Magnificent.There remains a strong feeling of the private residence here and although one imagines not everything displayed now was there when successive Marquesses of Hertford got by here when up from the country for 'The London Season".Therein lies the rub. A privileged and noble London residence it no longer truly resembles because it is cluttered. On the other hand, it's intimate nature prevents it from being a proper gallery because it is too small. It is near impossible to step back to drink in a piece of work, either due to lack of space or because someone is trodden on.So, while this wonderful collection is not to be missed, I fear it is niether one thing nor the other and 'tis a pity. Perhaps to see the house as the Lords Hertford and all the little Hertfords saw it would provide a more complete experience. Otherwise, thin out the goodies and give us space to wallow in their majesty.The Wallace Collection is free entry for everyone and, in my book, one of the greatest free shows on Earth.

A worthy and enriching diversion. Set in a beautiful house a few blocks behind Oxfor Street Selfridges, this was a real treat to visit. Excellent website and essential to plan visit and to avoid peak times. We received a generous welcome and were offered a guided tour at the next set time (about every two hours). We did not have time for that but had a short visit, then later regretted we had not spent more time! Everything was there to facilitate the visit, cloakroom, excellent gift shop, cafe and restaurant. We have to return soon, and it it is still free admission. It is a must to get a break from central shopping! Brilliant thank you.

a wonderfully delightful hidden gem. visiting the wallace collection is a must do for the avid museum and art enthusiast. This beautiful mansion is filled with the most lovely decorative pieces and amazing art. Each room is exquisitely appointed. I also had a lovely breakfast and tea with my friends there. This is truly a special place to visit. Put it on your list!!!

Free entrance to large majestic home with art galleries in every room. This lovely home has exhibits in every room--some very famous artists' paintings such as Rembrandt. Very nice atrium restaurant in centre of home that is nice for meal or tea.
hidden gem !. stunning collection. doesnt feel like you are in a museum, it seems like you are visiting someone's house.

What a great find. We came across this free museum while on a scavenger hunt. This place was amazing. It had art galore plus antique furnishings and even armor and arms from the 1500's. You can even try on a real set of armor. A must visit and a great collection of art and artifacts.
Fabulous collection. Loads of eclectic bits and bobs set in a lovely building on Manchester Square and the cafe is fabulous!

A super collection for free. Collected art, pottery, weapons all in a restored house.........much of it french from the time of the revolution.. All free.....not far from Selfridges behind Oxford Street.A central restaurant in the atrium sells excellent food.Set aside a couple of hours for the full tour. Not really for children.
A wonderful surprise. This is an amazing collection. There is so much to see, we will have to come back many times to take it all in.

Amazing Armory Collection. The Wallace Collection is well worth the visit. Admission is free (donations encouraged). They have an amazing armory collection in addition to a lot of nice artwork. There is a restaurant in the courtyard area that appeared quite popular. In the basement (near the bathrooms) there is a nice exhibition for marquetry (inlaid wood) as well as the names of all the pieces in a suit of armor. In addition, you can even try on some pieces of armor--be prepared, the chain mail is quite heavy.

Fabulous and interesting.. I thoroughly enjoyed my time walking around the beautiful Hertford House viewing the Wallace collection. Easy to locate and not crowded at all it was lovely to view its art works and furniture.
Tourist . A wild mix of arts and crafts from all sort of periods. A bit too eclectic for my taste but some excellent works make it a worthwhile experience. A great deal for a zero entrance fee.

Don't miss this!. This was one of our favorite things to see in London. We read about it in our guidebook and decided to give it a visit. We love old, restored homes. We were surprised by what all this house had . . . paintings, sculpture, misc artwork, and a wonderful two room exhibit full of armor, guns, and items pertaining to ancient warfare. Don't miss this museum . . . and it is free.

Delightful surprise, a refuge just behind Oxford St.. Eclectic collection of art , armour, and household artefacts housed in an approachable setting - a former town residence.Nice cafe for a glass of wine!!

Fantastic art gallery. The Wallace Collection is an art collection in London open to the public. It comprises a world-famous range of fine and decorative arts from the 15th to the 19th centuries. Must visit if you love arts.

Umissable Gem. To visit the Wallace Collection is unmissable if you are visiting London. The house just off oxford Treat is quite stunning and has a remarkable collection of 17th and 18th Century paintings. It was busy on a saturday afternoon but there was an obvious feeling of respect and admiration amongst visitors for the collection.The Laughing Cavalier is the star painting, but there are so many more to look at and admire.I didnt use the cafe but it looked like a lovely place to spend a while.I look forward to many more visits!
best collection of art in london. hidden away this gallery holds the most wonderful miniature collection and an Lanseer painting that horse lovers will be overwhelmed by.

Off the radar screen - unfairly.... A bit in the shadow of the larger establishments but that translates to smaller crowds.London's sorta kinda counter to NYC's Frick.Great Canaletto's. Worth going just for those, but most famous for the "Laughing Cavalier", itself interesting in that he is neither laughing nor a cavalier...In-and-out in a respectful 90-minutes. Very central to Oxford Street/Marble Arch corridor.

What a fantastic house and art collection!. How wonderful that some collections like this have been kept intact so that you can see them in the surroundings they were meant to be in .. a home. Very much the same feeling as The Frick in New York ... a real pleasure to visit and be able to immerse yourself in such a collection.

Talk about collecting..... Impressive house, chock-a-block with amours (they must have at least the armours of a full Persian squadron), furniture and paintings. Not to be missed Velazquez's Lady with a fan, the portrait "Laughing Cavalier", Reynold's lovely portrait of Nelly O'Brian, which in itself justifies the visit. In addition Hertford House has a great atrium to sit and have tea and cake.

Hidden Jewel. This museum has a collection of wonderful items collected privately over many years, including an extraordinary arms and armour section. Excellent cafe in a beautiful building; and it's free!

A grand day out. The Wallace collection contains 15th to 19th century paintings, furniture and armour. It's an ideal place for those who prefer a less crowded place to peruse such things as it isn't heaving like museums akin to Victoria and Albert. It allows you to really immerse yourself in the artwork which really is a sight to behold. Like most museums in London it's free entry and what with it being close to Paddington station there's no excuse not to visit.

Hidden oasis. Hidden away in the backstreets behind Oxford Street this truly is a hidden gem. As you enter the imposing front door, you quickly forget that you are in the middle of London and the fact that it is free makes it even more attractive. You can wander from room to room at your leisure, taking in the wonderful displays and the day we were there it wasn't particularly crowded. The restaurant, on the other hand, was very busy so is obviously a popular meeting point. We had a light lunch which was excellent and the gift shop is also,worth a visit. All in all I would definitely recommend that you stop off here whilst in the West End.
Go for free!. Excellent place to visit far from the madding crowd that is Oxford StreetHouse is full of painting antiques & other interesting thingsGreat cafe too
Lots of art and it is free!. A stately house with an amazing collection of older art. Many interesting artifacts as well. Can walk to nearby shopping and restaurants after a visit
Great day out. Plenty to see, a real feast for the eyes. Everything about the place is opulent & beautiful, from the items on display to the sumptuous surroundings. The Armoury is impressive.

Incredible collection of paintings, sculpture, miniatures and armour. Amazing collection of some beautiful things. The art collection alone is worth the visit. The Laughing Cavalier is probably the most famous art work here, but the walls were adorned with masterpieces from the 18th and 19th centuries. The Collection is free to visit and is conveniently situated just off Oxford Street.
Lovely collection. A nice museum to wander round on a rainy Sunday. Very glamorous. Fun for mid-teens up I would say, Dont think they charge for entry either.
An Amazing space, and a visual feast. Popped in for a breakfast drink and coffee to kill time whilst we went for a Spa. The restaurant is in a covered Courtyard.

An AMAZING collection of everything you have every heard of.... Again, let me say that a winter visit is best. The Wallace Collection has the most complete and eclectic accumulation of the rare, excellent and precious artifacts gathered from all over the civilized world. Faint praise. Works of art in marble, ivory and porcelain, gold, silver and jade, maiolica, paintings, miniatures and furniture, weapons and armour, all things weird and wonderful. The mind boggles. And they have a nice restaurant, too.

Wonderfully amazing. As italian tourist, I'm always amazingly fascinated by the splendour and organization of english museums and exhibitions, that are often for free!This year was the time of the historically famous Wallace Collection, I wasn't prepared for the magnificence of the rooms with their colourful upholstery and famous pictures.I wasn't prepared to stare at the famous Fragonard's The Swing.This is almost the best art exhibit that I ever seen.

Hidden Gem for Art Lovers. Lovely old house showing fascinating art collection in wonderful original surroundings. This is an art gallery with a difference. Collection ranges from old masters, ceramics, statues, furniture and its heterogeneous nature reflects the fact that it is the personal collection of one family over time. The items are displayed as they might have been when the house was lived in. The paintings alone are worth the visit, never mind the surroundings and other art. The artists include Rembrandt, Poussin, Canaletto ... Visit and enjoy.

Outstanding free art collection. If you like the "Laughing Cavalier", or Sevres porcelain, or just want a quiet moment away from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street- this is yer place- and it's FREE!

Great venue. Free entry. Well worth a visit. . Great building with some amazing paintings and furniture. You can get up really close. Many pieces of art by famous painters. Stayed for afternoon tea. Decent. Fresh warm scones but a bit tight on the jam and clotted cream for £18 although they did provide more on request. Free entry so not so bad to buy food there which was good quality and pleasant setting. Staff were attentive and helpful. Would go again and recommend.

"Extreme Hoarders" of the past. If they were not so rich, this family would have probably been put away for obsessive hoarding. On a serious note - this house is quite amazing. I was thrilled to discover the original Fragonard's painting "The Swing" on one of the walls. To think one family could get its hand one such a collection... amazing. I wasn't expecting it to be so huge.

Great for Rococo and the like. You have to go to this mansion turned museum to get a glimpse of the turn from Baroque to Rococo and beyond. What a great gem that most will not see in favor of the larger museums. But if you have a 3-7 day visit in London, check it out and travel back in time while getting a feast for the eyes. Very well done.

How can amazing get 3 out of 5?. The very large Collection is housed in a relatively small space. The curators advise that the remarkable picture density reflects the hanging style of the period when the works were assembled, but it does undermine the experience.Faced with a dense array of paintings the "ordinary visitor " has to guess at what might be worthy of a pause and can easily guess wrong or give up on a room that deserves more time. Depending on which way you tour, you might easily have seen a dozen very similar Weenix still lives - slight variations on "Pheasant in pantry" - then find a bunch more in the next room. Are these such masterpieces that we must study them and their differences closely, or did old Mr Wallace have a penchant for partridge, or was he duped into buying a job lot? At that point your confidence in the quality of the collection begins to wane. No doubt some expert guiding would answer the question and help the inexpert visitor maximise their time, but I could not help feeling that the "jam the aisles, pack 'em high" presentation undermined rather than enhanced the possible enjoyment. The "amazing" is for the beauty of the interiors and paradoxically, for the sheer size of the collection.The café - the entire glassed over inner courtyard - is a physical gem; when we visited the maitresse d' was very attentive but the actual waiting staff could barely be bothered
Sunday Brunch Location. I regularly arrange for Sunday Brunches at the restaurant of the Wallace Collection, as you can combine food, art and architecture and shopping (Oxford Street).
Near Marble Arch. It has lots of pictures and a lot of stuff so it is worth taking one of the guided tours to take in a little of the history of the items displayed. Allow hours for your visit.

Wonderful Wallace Collection. This wonderful House and Collection continue to draw me back to visit every time I am in London. It is filled with stunning art works and was so very quiet on the day I called in. Who needs the overcrowded National Gallery when this treasure house is waiting for you to visit. Go now!

Wonderful collection. I live close by and go to the collection often as it always offers a wonderful atmosphere. The employees are very attentive, and the sights themselves will surprise you in the most positive way.
A stone's throw from Oxford Street. One of the UK's great collection, free, in the West End, and often missed by visitors. Also a good place to stop for coffee or a quick meal/

Great birthday meal for 80 year old. we had a family gathering to celebrate my mother's 80th birthday and sunday lunch for 10. Service was good and attentive and food very tasty despite having to pre order which was a bit of a faff and several mistakes with the pre orders we had made. We were not rushed and explored the collections after a long lunch

Great collection of antiques. I love the fact that it is free to enter this, which makes it perfect for anyone on a budget. The collection is quite impressive, and it is located right in the heart of London with easy links to get there and away to your next destination.You could easily spend a few hours here, but for my opinion, I thought the Armoury was quite interesting!

Stunning! The Wallace Collection should definitely be on your "to do" list!. The Wallace Collection considered to be one of the best collections of fine arts including paintings, porcelain and furnishings in the UK. It is quality, not quantity, that pervades and the whole experience of a visit is both inspirational and rewarding. The cherry on the cake is the wonderful restaurant in a glass domed atrium within the walls of the Wallace Collection. The food is excellent and, whether you stop for coffee, lunch, or afternoon tea, it is well worth the visit. The cost is mid-range and good value for money. Sitting there, it is really hard to believe that you are in central London, and not sitting outside in somewhere like Kew Gardens! The building itself is beautiful and so well placed to fit in with your day in London. If you've not yet been, it's a must!

Wallace Collection Visit. An absolute gem of a place in Mancheter Square, London. I went with a group of people on a conducted tour which cost £9 per person. The French lady, Eva was our guide and she was so passionate it made the tour so successful. The Collection was housed in a magnificent building and the contents blew my mind. I will definitely return to wander the Collection at my leisure
Interesting Art Collection!. Beautiful House! Interesting but limited art collection. It was helpful to take a tour to learn about the history of the collection.

Beautiful house and furniture. I have been several times and see something new each visit. The antique French furniture, all in beautiful rooms is special. There is also a huge collection of French china.
great free attraction!. we took american freinds around here and then went to the tea room after and it was a great outing. Interesting paintings and freindly staff to discuss them.

Fabulous. This is one of London's many hidden gems. Located close to Selfridges and it is completely free. Impossible to see in one visit necessitating multiple returns !!We were enthralled for several hours and still didnt see all that is on offer.My only criticism was our lunch in the restaurant…a lovely setting but we had a very long wait for our food. My salad was supposedly broccoli with goats cheese..I actually never found the later and thought it was poor value for leaves, a few nust and broccoli !!

Beautiful house, fabulous selection of art. Fabulous hidden gem in London - beautiful house with a fabulous selection of art. Visited for the 1st time today and will definitely go back again. You can view the art collections at your own pace. There are also free tours of the collections lasting an 1hr which you can join - best to check the website before going to see when these occur. There is a café there if you want a coffee/rest between viewing the rooms. Toilets are in the basement and were clean.

Anglo/France visit. We visited with French friends and their 11 year old grand-daughter. They were pleased to see so much French art. Visiting near to the anniversary of the Battle of Agincourt it was interesting to see the interest of of the girl in the armour, pictures and exhibits reflecting that time. Always worth a visit - especially the cafe/restaurant.

Face to Face with the Laughing Cavalier. One of the best galleries I have been to. Intimate and easy to get to the collection was far larger than I had imagined. At the time I was able to get to stand right in front of "The Laughing Cavalier" it seemed alive. Will never forget it.

Hidden jewel, great restaurant on site for afternoon tea. If you are tired of the massive crowds at the larger national museums, treat yourself to this intimate and worthwhile place that is free. The collections of art, furniture and yes, armour, is amazing and you can wander from room to room of this mansion and pretend what it would like to call this your home. There is an intimacy you can not get at the larger museums. Reminds me of the Jacquemart-Andre Museum in Paris or the Frick Collection in New York City...museums made from former private homes. Visited near closing (3:30) and had afternoon tea (18.50 GBP) which was so much more reasonable than at hotels (Savoy - 40+ GBP) yet was still a tranquil experience in a refined setting under the glass ceilings of the central courtyard restaurant. After tea, still had 30 minutes to wander the museum rooms and the armoury on site is extensive and more impressive to me than the Tower of London or British Museum. Visit and enjoy being a tourist minus the jostling crowds. I will go back again and have afternoon tea and a wander again...
An hour to spare. This was our second visit but found more things of interest. The refurbished East galleries were worth a visit.
quick visit and great cafe. great find and because its free there's no need to cram it all into one sitting. I'll be back to see the rest and for more cake and coffee
A hidden gem!. What a beautiful hidden gem. Fabulous art, a free tour, beautiful restaurant even for just a coffee. A fabulous way to spend a couple of hours.

do not miss it!. The collection is exceptional and you can get very close to the works of art on display (paintings, furniture, porcelaine, armouries...) and appreciate them fully. It's a wonder for the eyes and it is free! (leave at least £5 in the money box for support!)
amazing museum. I really enjoyed museum especially loved the the high tea at Wallace museum cafe. It is very beautiful collection.I recommend everyone to visit
Beautiful. Worth the visit, especially enjoyed the lovely collections of porcelain. Catherine the Great's dinner service!
Loved.. Loved the Wallace Collection. Would definitely go back next time we are in London. You can take your time and go through the rooms and really enjoy the Collection.

Best place for tea (after viewing collection of course). The Wallace Collection is a gem and quite different than the better-known London museums. Wandering around the house and seeing the collection in situ makes you feel like you're visiting a distant -- and slightly stuffy -- aged relative. And then there's the courtyard restaurant. No better place for whiling away a grey and chilly afternoon with tea and cakes or celebrating summer with a glass of fizz!

French furniture and acres of gilt!. I love this place.... a fine small museum, wonderful paintings in sumptuous Rococo rooms furnished in opulent splendour. A good small exhibition space with interesting temporary exhibitions too. And its free. What more could you want? Oh, yes, for central London, it's also rarely busy and never packed.

Beautiful collection - free entry. The Wallace collection is one man's collection over the years and it has some great art pieces from all over the world, including armory from different countries. The place was lovely, the people were extremely polite and the paintings were absolutely lovely.

Gorgeous hidden gem in central London. Reminiscent of Versailles as you walk in and see the grandeur of the silk paneled walls. Would have been lovely to have a bit more information available as you go round

Great museum. This is a wonderful little museum in the heart of London. It's full of great items. Beautiful Sevres porcelain, exquisite pill boxes, suits of armour and flintlock guns, paintings.In one room, there are no fewer than 7 Canaletto and 9 Guardi paintings, plus a number of School of Canaletto. And then there are the Rembrandts.Each room has good notes explaining the contents.There is a good, if not cheap, restaurant in the centre, lit well by the natural light of the enclosed courtyard.And best of all, there is no entry charge.

Unique collection, not to be missed. We had been to the better known museums and chose the Wallace Collection on a rainy day. This is an exquisite collection of paintings, sculptures, china, furniture, and even some amazing armor and early guns. All situated in an historic house with a wonderful story. When visiting London, don't overlook this true gem

Exceptional collection . The Wallace collection is truly remarkable with a wide tame of artistic and historical pieces. The layout and presentation is well done with exceptional preservation. The working clocks are also a treat to listen to, as they're cleverly offset to ring at slightly different times for your enjoyment.

Centrally located, easily accessible. Situated just behind Selfridge's, the Wallace Collection is located in a lovely "town house" and offers a wide selection of armor, paintings, and objects. In addition, in the covered courtyard is a café which is perfect for afternoon tea, or just to sit and relax with a snack. And, admission to the Collection is free. What more could one want when "shopped out."

An exquisite stately house! A must see!. What a lovely stately house! From the furnishings to the chinas and the Rembrandts and Canalletos, it was a suberb experience! And all with no admission fee! The staff always willing to offer knowledge! Even my daughter didn't get bored! Excellent in every way! Would highly recommend it!
Nice hidden place. Not everybody know about this collection which is rather big and with a good variety of masterpieces... and for free. A must-see for art lovers.

A wonderful place to visit. An exceptional collection, beautifully presented. Take time to see this while you are in London. It's a pleasure to stroll through the rooms enjoying the fine art set in a beautiful building.

Nice collection, just not the usual art I go in for. This is a museum you can get away with viewing for an hour or two. No great, (in my opinion) show-stopper works of art. Don't get me wrong, their are works in here by very famous artists, just not their great masterpieces. I was in the Louvre just two days previous, so don't go by me considering what I am comparing it to.

A fascinating collection - good for a rainy day visit. The Wallace Collection contains furniture, paintings, glass and silverware and a permanent display of arms and armour. My particular favourites are some of the paintings - there a couple of superb Rembrandts as well as top-quality examples of other British and European artists' work. It's a great place to amble round for a morning, and the atrium restaurant is lovely.

The most amazing antique collection!. If you are in love with antique weaponry this is the place to visit, it has also a great collection of porcelain and painting from the likes of Canaletto, it is free they only accept donation and it's a great day out for the all family.Highly recommended!

Nice museum but avoid the cafe. Enjoyed this smaller but well appointed museum, but was very disappointed by our lunch in the museum café. Ironically this was the only place in London that added a tip to the bill (18% extra) that was "optional" but no clear device on how to remove it when the chip and pin card is already running for their predetermined amount. The service was surly and the food not very good - cold when should be hot, meat fatty, not fun or nice.
What a find!. A friend told us to visit the Wallace collection and what find it was.Breath-taking rooms crammed full of antiquities and works of art. Fab café and gift shop.
Hidden Gem. What a hidden gem, an absolute treasure to find. An awesome collection of "collections" of the highest standards, some which may make you laugh :)
Beautiful collection. I love going to visit the Wallace Collection - it's very centrally located but tucked away. It has a beautiful collection of art and furthermore does a delightful afternoon tea!

Wonderful Treat. We dropped by here this morning and could have stayed all day. The exhibits are not to be missed. They have a restaurant but we did not eat lunch there although it is in a very nice setting.

UNEXPECTED. Nobody can loose these paints and sculptures collections.
Me and my family had an unexpected but very good visit.

Interesting private museum. We had a friendly welcome, and were able to take photographs ( though asked first). Rooms and rooms of armour and ancient weaponry for man and horse. Hundresds of beautiful pictures by famoous artists such as Lanseer ( the Arabian tent with mare and foal is magnificent and well worth seeing ) Rembrandt self portrait, and that of his son, and work by many other World famous artists. Ancient engravings are encased and protected from light by leather sheets. Some beautiful chairs and furniture. A small museum, though very interesting. Much to see- Go!All this is displayed in a beautiful building, relying solely on donations, and income from the on site coffee bar/ restaurant.

Wonderful Collection. The Wallace Collection is a jewel tucked away in Manchester Square behind the bustle of Oxford Street. There are wonderful collections of arms and armour, porcelain, majolica, paintings and furniture all displayed in sumptuous room settings. It is free to the public. There is an upmarket restaurant housed in an atrium in the centre of the building. Labelling of the exhibits could be improved. Would highly recommend.

Fantastic collection... I have been here three times now, but still find it fascinating. The last time was with a guide, so much more interesting with lots of stories and additional information. So many treasures. You have to see it.

Spend a Perfect Day .. This is my city and I am deeply ashamed that it has taken until my 65th year to visit the Wallace Collection. I entered on a Saturday as it opened and spent the rest of the day in stunned reverance looking at a collection started by a very discerning eye. These are some of the very best pieces of art you will see - full stop! Every work here represents the best of it's type, be it painting, armour or ceramics. Where else would you find one of only three full sets of 15th century horse armour along with the most dazzling Sevres pottery and art by Holbien, Gainsborough and Frans Hals? Even a day does this collection little justice, take a decent magnifying glass (although some are provided) to fully appreciate the experience. The staff are friendly and knowledgable, there is a decent restaurant in the covered courtyard and the toilets are clean.
Jewel. A very nice small quaint museum that houses many interesting things with a lot of entertaining stories to go with it. Highly recommended

AGINCOURT ITEMS CROWNED AN EXCELLENT MORNING. Two friends met me at Hertford House after my recommending the venue. None of us were disappointed by the range of objects on display, the helpfulness of the staff or the quality of coffee in the restaurant. For all who appreciate beautiful items of furniture, statuary and paintings all informatively displayed, the Wallace Collection is a must. Though we did not have children with us there were plenty of activities available for these in the craft and discovery areas. This is a collection to be informed by as well as enjoyed. The Agincourt items of weaponry - replicas and originals alike - crowned an excellent morning's visit; we reflected on Henry V's victory six centuries ago when disease,tactics and conditions could so easily have ensured defeat.

A Stunning Private Collection. The Wallace is a impressive collection of paintings, furniture and art objects. French furniture of the 18th century is particularly well represented. All is housed in this beautiful townhouse tucked away on a quiet square not far from bustling Oxford Street. It is a fascinating glimpse into the mind of a collector! I will return.
Lovely secret find. Really good kids art and craft activity set up for half term. Very friendly and welcoming helpers, interesting finds round the collection and fun for my 8 year old.

An undiscovered gem. The Wallace Collection is one of those places in London that you stumble upon. I've been a few times and it has a fantastic collection of art, particularly from Dutch artists and armour.

Beautiful. I have visited here several times and love the architecture and exhibits. The paintings are amazing and there are some of Marie Antoinette's own furniture here - bought in a sale after her arrest I believe!

The place to be when the wife is busy in Oxford Street.. The Wallace collection is a very eclectic conglomeration of artifacts that a single person managed to accumulate in a single lifetime, actually in the house designed for them. There are collections of Boulle furniture, miniature bronzes, busts, statues, clocks, potteries, ceramics, paintings, including what is probably the finest collection of François Boucher in the world. And to cap it all there is a very extensive collection of arms and armour from all over the world, from the antique to his day. This collection is a must see on a visit to London.

Laughing Cavalier and much more.... Nicely tucked away on the north side of Oxford Street is Manchester Square with the Wallace Collection as it's centrepiece. Paintings, suits of armour, porcelain and so many other fascinating works of art made this an enjoyable couple of hours. Also contains a very posh restaurant that wouldn't look out of place in Harrods. Definitely worth going to see.

Absolutely Charming with some real gems. This collection is not too big to be overwhelming. The rooms are well laid out and most of the staff are very helpful. I loved the porcelain and and furniture however my husband liked the paintings. The Laughing Cavalier is housed here. There is also an armoury which enthralled my ten year old grandson. Well definitely return and will always be a place to pop in if only for ten minutes as a respite from shopping. The restaurant was packed out which is always a good sign although we didn't visit on this occasion.

Fine small gallery. This gives you an enthralling glimpse into 18th century aristocratic life. It's a sumptuous restored mansion with an absolute treasure of paintings, porcelain, furniture and artefacts. The Great Gallery is stunning. A lovely glass-roofed restaurant too. A wonderful place to pass a rainy afternoon!

A true gem, well tucked away. The Wallace Collection is one of those rare gems that few know about. Parts of their collection have been seen in magazines and various publications, yet not that many have been there.The Wallace Collection is actually very easy to find. It's at the back of Manchester Square, and a block or two behind Selfridges. If you are walking towards Selfridges from Oxford Circus, turn right when you get to Selfridges and a few minutes walk and you are there. It's also very near Wigmore Hall, if you're into classical music. As a museum, there is a mixture of porcelain, silverware and a very fine collection of fine paintings. These include Canaletto, Guardi and Fragonard. Dutch, French and Italian paintings are well represented. Perhaps not so well known is the collection of arms and armour. You will be hard pressed to find a finer collection in London apart from the Tower of London. You could spend several hours here. There is a nice restaurant in the courtyard and there is an interactive area downstairs for children, where you can try on armour. The good thing is, is that it's free to get in. Personally, I think The Wallace Collection is one of the finest collections in the UK and highly underrated. Think of it as all the good bits from the other major art galleries and museums in London under one roof.

Nice small museum close to regions park. In some sense it is a completely "typical" small collector museum with the requisite multi colored rooms with a varied selection of dutch and English masters, with an extensive but fairly standard armory (the Indian arms are a bit of a departure from a normal European museum).This said, the seating in the halls is comfortable, it is not crowded, so if you like to sit and take in a Rubens or a Rembrandt (as I do), this is a nice place for it.

So many staggeringly iconic paintings under one roof. This free attraction (although donations are appreciated) houses some amazing works of art collected over many centuries. The Laughing Cavalier and a host of Canalettos are just two of the highlights of thus very impressive array of unique and priceless artefacts and works of art. Definitely worth a visit, and nearby Marylebone High Street and other streets off it, are worth visiting some intriguing independent shops.

Excellent place to visit. This was part of a Sherlock Holmes activity we were undertaking with our daughter. What a complete surprise this beautiful building is let alone to paintings, armour, clocks etc were. This is is really worth visiting when in London from a historical and aesthetic perspective. Lunch was also of good quality however the staff were a bit slow and distracted amongst themselves.

One of London's 'hidden' gems. Anyone with one oita of real interest in the arts, of the nineteenth century and before should make the Wallace collection a must see ,when rounding off a basically round education . Here in a mid nineteenth century home ,of an affluent Englishman ,is a mouth watering collection of English and French art and furniture . For those interested in arms and armour there is a fine 'world ' collection . The whole collection gives one an insight in to one man's tastes and interests . Unless you are a complete Phillistine , some of this experience will enrich your soul ,. and to quote Nicholas Goodison , there is joy in the perpetual enjoyment of looking . This is NOT the place for small children ,well behaved or otherwise. There is also a fine dining experience in a covered courtyard of the old hose . The Wallace Collection also has a fine shop where the discerning might be tempted to purchase art/ postcards/CDs etc

Not to be missed. Great amount of paintings including the Laughing Cavalier.Beautiful,Sevres China and magnificent armour including two full sized armoured horses.Beautiful house and superb inner courtyard restaurant.Idea for a rainy day .

Biggest Armour collection i have ever seen!. If you want to take a man of any age to somewhere spectacular this is it! Vast collection of famous paintings, armour and guns from all ages. The best part it is free of charge and has an incredible restaurant at the back which is worth a visit for afternoon tea.
Amazing collection!. Hidden gem in the heart of London with an eclectic collection of paintings, silverware, armor, guns... A must see!

A hidden gem being the bustle of Oxford Street. I was mesmerised by the miniature portraits, beautiful collection of snuff boxes and the rich decor of the many rooms. So much to see that it was quite overwhelming, so I will return soon.

Suitable for art lovers and anyone interested in armour!. A gem of a museum moments away from Oxford Street. A wonderful oasis and full of beautiful objects. Entry is free and there is a restaurant in the covered courtyard. Well worth a visit!
History. One of the most interesting places in London , but do be carful with the armour , do not touch otherwise alarm bells will go off

Impressive. This is a must do. The collection includes some wonderful Rembrandts and Canalettos, amongst others. Also a tasteful cafe sits in the centre courtyard. I will return to eat there. Notable was the self portrait of Rembrandt located purposely across the room from the portrait of his only son. Sweet.

Hidden gem. I was alerted to this by seeing that the Countess of Wessex is patron. Just a short walk behind Selfridges towards the direction of Baker Street. Great peek into stately home and wonderful and eclectic art collection. It is free so spend twenty minutes wandering around - or take an hour or more! The restaurant was great too.
Fanatstic collectin. You must spend hours here to see it all, suitabloe for all ages . Room after room with top paintings and other interesting things. Also suitable for children, Easy to find.

Little Louvre. If u like the Louvre you will love this little gem.
Beautiful exhibition of paintings from th 16-18th Century European painters. Great pieces of furniture and other pieces of decoration. Worth a short visit.

Great little museum. Go for the art but appreciate the house. Manageable size for such a collection and you get a good appreciation of how a titled family kept their city house. Being free is icing. Well worth a visit.
An amazing random eclectic collection. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area; a real eclectic mix of items, beautifully presented.

Beautiful collection; short visit. It is a beautiful facility with an impressive collection. We had just a brief time to see the collection so I don't think we were able to fully appreciate it. My daughter had gone here a few months ago for the tea and really enjoyed that.

An interesting art collection. Small by the standards of the large and better known London Art Galleries, but well worth a visit and it is free, so you can visit it several times and take in a little at a time.

Eclectic rich mens' collection. The marquises who collected a large bunch of French stuff found some very interesting items. There's a wonderful dog painting by Rosa Bonheur, lots of guns, silverware, armor, other interesting paintings, and a fine mansion not far from Oxford St.
Wonderful. This is absolutely stunning, and I will definitely go there again .The staff were helpful.The location is perfect .

A Hidden Gem. I paid a quick visit here, only had just over an hour to spare but I will be back! This beautiful place is a treasure trove and so well set out, very professional staff, clean, bright and I just can't wait to return.
A brilliant museum. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum. The staff were helpful and knowledgeable particularly in the Armoury when we discussed the funeral cortege of Richard III recently.
School visit. Loved the display of Indian artefacts and some very well known paintings. The children respected the beautiful venue and drank in the atmosphere appropriately.

“In Awe....". The Wallace Collection is a national museum in an historic London town house. In 25 galleries are unsurpassed displays of French 18th-century painting, furniture and porcelain with superb Old Master paintings and a world class armoury.
Close to Oxford Street with lovely restaurant. Great collection which anyone would enjoy as small enough to please even the least 'arty' visitor. No charge but donation appreciated.

Great day out and a lovely afternoon tea. Went her last minute on a grey saturday afternoon My partner is interested in armoury and really wanted to see the exhibition. I will be honest I can get bored easily but it was so interesting. You have to see the horse armoury. Outstanding. Then to finish it off we sat in the tea room/ restaurant and had afternoon tea. Lovely setting in the center of the building under the glass roof with plenty of light. Food was yummy. Only complaint is that the portions were a little small

If you are interested in the materials in the collection this is a good, small museum. The collection contains a limited amount of art and artifacts from a limited time period. If you are not interested in the period you will find the collection boring. It does not contain "something for everyone." The tea in the cafe was quite good and the price was not out of line with other similar teas. Service could be a bit better.
What a find. Stumbled across this place one day whilst walking around. The art and setting is absolutely stunning! A must see!
Hidden gem in London. Excellent, even if you just go for tea, it lunch. Well worth a visit whenever in town.Go see the cavalier and a whole host of other great arts

All over the show, but well worth a visit!. The Wallace Collection is somewhat "disjointed" in the sense that they seemed to collect anything and everything that was of value! It is however well-maintained and shows clearly how "new money" would have manifested in 19th century London!
Tour. Very interesting display of paintings throughout the ages, well hidden at the back of Selfridges in Oxford Street

Wonderful Small Museum. It is very rare to find a small museum that doesn't charge an entrance fee, but this is one. Both the mansion and the collection are first rate and the location, near Oxford and Bond Streets, is very convenient.

Great way to spend a windy Sunday afternoon. Great museum, beautifully curated in a fantastic building. Great cafe to have afternoon tea too. The collection is laid out in the many rooms and it is a credit that these places are still free!

You know you want to try on proper old school, chain mail!. This is a great little local museum, good for all ages and any time of the year. They do good stuff for the kids in school holidays, but the clear standout for me is the armour - dress yourself and your mates up in chain mail, cuirasses and helmets and do some chest bumps. You know you want to...
Really interesting place, a must see!. The Wallace Collection has some spectacular art, collections and sculpture on display. And it's in a beautiful building too. Highly recommended!
Excellent afternoon tea. Worth visiting the museum and then stopping for a bite to eat in the cafe/restaurant. We have had lunch and afternoon tea and cakes and both were very good.

An excellent visit in this hidden gem in the heart of the West End.. A superb visit with a highly professional guide in this ornate and elegant building. So much to see (paintings, china and furniture from Marie Antoinette.

Fascinating collection, with a focus on 18th and 19th Century. There is a fine collection of 18th and 19th Century paintings, including by Canaletto, Gainsborough, Reynolds and Dutch masters, magnificent period furniture and porcelain, and a remarkable collection of armour. The long gallery is a particular highlight (and includes the famous Laughing Cavalier which their excellent notes point out is neither laughing nor a Cavalier!), and the gallery is free to enter. We enjoyed a cream tea in their elegant courtyard restaurant.

Unusual and fascinating museum. Unusual and fascinating museum, just minutes from Oxford Street. Lovely and elegant area.The collection is beautiful and very interesting if you are into armours and china of great beauty and interest.I suggest you to include this wonderful place in your schedule.
Best collection in London. Superb collection of paintings and furniture and I would recommend everyone to visit. It is as Wallace left it.

Don't go for the afternoon tea!! . The venue is beautiful, grand, historical and worth the visit. But the afternoon tea is truly disappointing. But then the price is relatively low priced. The sandwiches were mediocre and more like a supermarket triangle and the cakes were quite disappointing too. Our advice is, visit half the museum,So your taste buds are awakened by the beauty of the venue, then have your amazement quickly taken away by the afternoon tea, then finish off the rest of the tour and you will forget the tea and leave with great memories and pictures!!!

Enjoy the pictures and the armoury. The Wallace has been brought up to date since I regularly did research there and is now a great place to see all sorts of interesting artefacts and paintings, though the latter are not smartly displayed and (I have an art dealer's eye here) not all restored. This for me, adds to the charm. There is a restaurant/cafe if you have the budget.
A lovely building and gorgeous interior!. This is one of London's hidden secrets, a beautiful gallery house and holding some stunning contemporary and classic arts! A must.
Excellent art decor collection!. Absolutely delightful! Keep in mind, that it the art of decor collection. The exhibition had so many gems. My favorite is the miniatures collection.

Calm oasis of tranquility.....Terrific treasures to behold !!. Always a pleasure to visit the Wallace Collection.....reduces the blood pressure as you slowly walk through grand,rooms in glorious colours.
Don't forget to stop for tea at the elegant tea room/ restaurant.
Will be back soon.
Absolutely Wonderful!. A really wonderful place full of hidden gems in an amazing building. Definitely worth a visit when you're in London
Lovely venue. This is a beautiful gallery just a short walk from Oxford Street, it is tranquil and usually uncrowded. Well worth a visit.

Excellent for art and historic building lovers. After being to London many times, finally made it to the Wallace collection and was not disappointed. Once you've done the standard tourist agenda, check it out. Great art and furnishings in a lovely building.

Fabulous. One of london's best kept secrets in my estimation...Fantastic experience with plenty to see and exparience - great restaurat as well.
Fantasic venue for conferencing/ product launch and company functions.
A hidden part of London. If you enjoyed the National Art Gallery, then you will like this. Not so crowded but the rooms are beautiful. Recommended if you like art of British buildings

Always a delight. This is a very special experience.. The collection is housed in what was a private house, and retains a quiet calm uncrowded atmosphere. It includes collections of arms, porcelain and paintings. My interest was in the latter and I was certainly not disappointed. A beautiful reflective and specialplace to visit.
Don't Miss This Gem. This is an art collection other museums can only drool over; the Wallace doesn't lend out its treasures. Be prepared to spend at least a few hours.

Like a home. This unique museum was once a private home and has, sensibly, been kept that way. The atmosphere is quiet and private. You almost fear that you disturb the inhabitants. There are only a dozen such museums in the world.
Little known gem. Obviously it is not in the premier league of London museums, but we really enjoyed the visit. Not a typical museum and quite intimate. Worth the effort to find.

Fantastic also for an afternoon tea. One of the hidden gens in London, just go! Paintings, ceramics and a wonderful huge collection of armouries spanning 500 years or more. Try to have you cream tea there!

Amazing private museum. Highly recommended exhibition, in a beautiful house. Paintings of Rembrandt and other famous painters. This visit we enjoyed very much the amunition rooms from various period. Very impressive.

outstanding and it is free. Escape from the traffic, noise and crowds in Oxford street and relax a few hours in this magnificent house. You will never forget it.I have been there 3 times to relax and found something new and interesting every time.Cosy pubs around Manchester Square for a pint afterwards.

Fantastic, free attraction.. An amazing collection owned by one family and collected over five generations. Numerous paintings and art works. Many great masters. Also a huge collection of armoury which was very well displayed. Pottery, ceramics, sculptures and china also on display. This collection is housed in a beautiful house, not far from Edgeware Tube Station. It is incredible and free!

Fantastic visit - can't believe that I haven't been here before.... I have lived in London but never visited the Wallace. I am so happy that I visited - it is a beautiful house and the collection is amazing. Don't miss the Laughing Cavalier.
This is a less known gallery but well worth a visit as it is an easy detour off Oxford Street.

Stupendous . If you like art, paintings, porcelains, miniatures, armory, furniture or sculptures this jewel of a collection is worth your time! Amazing and beautiful four generations of collectors display their love for art.

A second Visit to the Wallace Collection. The Wallace Collection is a must and a bit of a secret for travelers. There is so much to see and take in, that it does take a few visits. I found it much better than "Buckingham Palace". Highly recommended!

An oasis of peace and quality art.. Allow at least two hours to take in the superbly presented works. I joined a tour at 2.30 p.m. A fluent, knowledgeable and very personable guide took us on a selected route to introduce various works. A real gem. There is no entrance fee, the tour also without charge. A quality cafe serving attractive food in genteel surroundings complements the visit.The collection is owned by the state and welcomes donations towards the considerable costs of running and maintaining the collection. After experiencing a visit a generous donation is fully warranted

The Wonderful Wallace Collection - Unmissable!. This is one of my favourite tourist spots in London and a fascinating insight into the life of this family. The house has incredible treasures of antiques, armoury and various artefacts from around the globe. The rooms are all beautifully decorated and there is so much of interest here with a wonderful restaurant and cafeteria. Highly recommended!
Too much for one visit, but do go. The sheet size of the collections here make a visit almost overwhelming, but there's no admission charge, so go as often as you like.

A bit of culture and tea. Wallace collection is absolutely incredible. A must visit when in London.After a tour we decided to try out the cafe. Again the way it is set up is absolutely wonderful. Ended up having tea and champagne. Tea was as good as can be for £18. The lady that gave us a table for tea was very tactless and totally judges the book by its cover.
An eclectic collection of finest art. A great eclectic collection of arts in a beautiful building with a good but steeply priced cafe - your portions are seriously small

a place to visit and revisit every time you are in London. if you have had enough of trendy, overrated , "must see" exhibitions in modern-design buildings filled with junk, then you should visit the Wallace Collection, a place where you can really enjoy masterpieces by the best artists + numerous beautiful objects made by unknown craftsmen. When all this is getting too much for you, you can take a break and enjoy a quiet cup of tea or coffee + a light bite in the beautiful restaurant.

Filled with so much history!. An amazing building hidden in the streets of London! From the stairs you see as soon as you enter the building to the armour and painting the Wallace museum is perfect for a rainy day activity. Tons of paintings throughout beautiful exquisite rooms. Downstairs is also filled with armour from all over the world. Including a few sets of horse armour!

Outstanding. Been going to visit here, for years, what a treat!Spent six hours just mesmerised with the place.If you dont go, you will regret it for ever, and its free!Of course we left a generous donation, it was worth it
sunlit lunch. perfect service, lovely food, elegant clientele. only experienced lunch here on a couple of occasions
A hidden gem. Not one of the "big" London attractions, but better than some. A wonderful collection of painting and sculpture. I could have spent all day here.

A hidden treasure. A smallish museum just behind Selfridges in Manchester Square. A large collection of priceless works of art and furniture. It has been refurbished to an excellent standard. A large collection of armory too and a very nice restaurant. Not suitable for children unless they are art lovers.

A treasure house in London.. This is a museum that even appeals to non museum types . If you are limited on time go straight to he Great Roomto see some of the most famous paintings in the world, in a grand domestic setting.

Extraordinary collection of paintings, furniture, sculpture, porcelain and armor. Just a five minute walk north off busy Oxford Street behind Selfridges is the magnificent Wallace Collection in Hertford House on Manchester Square. Considered one of the finest private art collections in the world, the Hertford family bequeathed their collection to the British nation in 1897. The colorful galleries contain priceless furniture, sculptures, porcelain and old master paintings. Rembrandt's Titus, Fran's Hals's The Laughing Cavalier and superb portraits by Gainsborough, Reynolds and Romney are highlights. Oriental and European armor rooms will interest the youngest visitors. Open daily from 10am - 5pm and free to enter, do discover this special museum.

Incredible collections. Fantastic collections of art, furniture, weapons and much more in a building just a few minutes off Oxford street. We visited on a Sunday and had a great time - not at all crowded and the restaurant is excellent.

Eat in a museum in a great location. Booked having seen the restaunrant on a previous visit to the Collection.Great location, wonderful ambience quite high quality menu with helpful serving staffIf you want a different location for a special lunch do give it a try.

Vivid Colours for Great Photos. We had never been to the Wallace collection. It was quite different from most places and very good for photos since the colours of the walls and paintings were so vivid. In addition to furniture and paintings there was an armoury collection.

A hidden gem. We have travelled to London for years, and many times per year - yet we have never visited "The Wallace".An amazing collection of thousands of items, all in a really nice setting with lovely staff.Well worth going. And it's free - please donate though, they do need to keep it running.
We have to come again!. Wow, what a fabulous treasure! We will definately come again, next time in London. Lunch was excellent too.

The guidebook says it's outstanding - and it is!. One of the staff said that they often thought of themselves as working at the little sister to the British Museum, and it was easy to see his point. The collection of paintings, porcelain, armour and furniture is not huge, but it is very impressive.The Wallace Collection is probably best known as the home of 'The Laughing Cavalier' by Frans Hals. But many of the other works are also superb, and the claim that the gallery houses some of the best French 18th Century Art may well be true.Also, that essential part of any good museum these days - the café / restaurnant - is a most pleasant, if somewhat pricey, place to sit and study the guide book.All in all, this is a place which is definately on my 'to be returned to' list.

A surprising little gem. You drive past it hundreds of times and wonder what's there so we went and it was quaint and charming, the staff were knowledgeable and very friendly. The biggest surprise was the restaurant which was lovely had a good menu and really great value

exquisite items - worth a visit. The collection is absolutely superb and very well presented. Not too overcrowded on the day I visited which was a bonus and I loved the restaurant afterwards - great afternoon tea
biggest private collection in the former private house of the family Wallace. Very well organised , kind receprtion and interesting museum shop and libraryVery good restaurant in a very nice space

Haven of Rococo splendour just minutes from Oxford Street. So many visitors to London and indeed residents of the city 'stumble' across the Wallace Collection, which is surprising given its central location. A wonderful place to come to escape the Oxford Street crowds or as part of a visit around Marylebone. There is a wonderfully intimate atmosphere, it really does feel like stepping into someone's house, albeit a rather opulent, aristocratic one! It reminds me of the Frick in New York, albeit without the Vermeers, but lots to please the eye instead, including Titian, Rubens, Canaletto, Velazquez and Canaletto alongside plenty of French Masters. They have an interesting programme of exhibitions as well. Thoroughly recommended, but my one caveat is that the security guards at the entrance can be quite unwelcoming and officious, but worth persevering to the treasures beyond!

Opulence in abundance. I highly recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection. I stumbled upon it by accident on my way back from somewhere else and I did not regret venturing inside. There is an endless selection of art, fascinating historical objects, and the collection of armoury easily rivals that in the Tower of London. It was quite a treat.

Ducked in out of the rain. We ducked in to get out of the rain, not knowing what we were getting into...and hit the jackpot. Honestly, if you have the time it is worth the effort to get to this little gem. The house alone would be worth the trip, but include the collection and it's a huge plus.

Complete Surprise. I was looking for some respite from Oxford St crowds and saw this pop up on my iPhone map. It was a very well maintained collection in a stunning mansion just a few min walk off Oxford St near Selfridges. There's a particular emphasis on the Dutch School of painting which was fine with me and toward the end there were some really interesting war exhibits which I'd not seen before. Well worth the detour even if it's just to catch your breath for a while. Oh and not that I tried it but the restaurant looked a class above the regular gallery offerings with waitstaff in black ties.
Small museum. This was a bit difficult to find but what a gem. My only problem was that I had been visiting so many museums that I was overwhelmed looking at all of the treasues

A world class collection displayed in a beautiful setting. • We love London’s galleries but there is a special place in our hearts for the smaller collections, usually private, displayed in a more intimate setting. Hertford House could hardly be considered small but when compared to the Tate Britain. That smaller scale really seems to enhance the viewers experience; perhaps because its less overwhelming, we’re not really sure. In any case, the Wallace Collection at Hertford House should not be missed! In addition, there is a delightful and elegant courtyard café to take advantage of!

An absolute treat if you have a couple hours. The Wallace Collection is beautifully situated, with a great collection of fine paintings and decoratives, especially from the 1500s to 1700s. There are several noteworthy paintings, both in terms of the artist, as well as the subject. It is far less overwhelming than the National Gallery, and the crowds are far more manageable.
