Definitely worth an afternoon visit.
Love this place. Fabulous private collection. Particularly like the miniatures on display. A lovely place to while away an hour or so and it's free. Fantastic eating area too.

A fascinating visit. This was a visit with my Son and we both thought it was one of the most amazing visits to a museum of this type anywhere. Fascinating exhibits beautifully and thoughtfully presented.

A truly privileged home and collection. This is grandeur on an amazing scale and when you think Hertford House was someone's home - albeit an aristocratic someone - it's absolutely stunning and so worth visiting. Tucked down a side street, you would never know this mansion was here and that was the case with me. Lived in and visited London many times and this was my first visit here and certainly won't be my last.The collection is laid out throughout the home and walking up the grand stairs is a thrill, imaging all the grand people and occasions these stairs have seen.It just gets better after that.I very highly recommend this attraction in London.

Fantastic and less well known museum. This is a fabulous place - always find something new to look at here. The collections are of the very highest quality. Downstairs children can try on chain mail and other bits of armor - my grandsons loved it. The ceremony of winding the clocks is great fun. Their lectures and talks are almost always very, very good and highly intelligent people work here.
Wow!. I've lived in London and only happened to be walking past with an hour to spare and decided to go in.What an amazing place with an exquisite courtyard restaurant. Well worth a visit.
Took my sons. My children enjoyed this, because it has a great armoury collection. I enjoyed the paintings and the fact it was free!

Make the effort to visit. Have been to London 5 or 6 times & have not before made the effort to visit. I really enjoyed The Wallace collection. The paintings are great & it is the home of the Laughing Cavalier however what I enjoyed the most was the french furniture & the fabulous collection of Antique weapons & armor. Ground floor there are several rooms of Armor for humans but also 3 full sets of armor for horses. Not only European but also Middle Eastern.Very interesting. Was able to buy in the gift shop a pack of note cards of some of the items as a gift. Getting hard to find them theses days.
fantastic. Great museum - free entry. So much to see here and it warrants several visits. The house itself is marvellous and worth seeing. Restaurant in the museum.

Beautiful house with an interesting and varied collection. My favourite museum in London - always a joy to while away a few hours here. A private collection including paintings, furniture, ceramics, armour, jewellery...not somewhere you can get bored easily! The central courtyard has a lovely restaurant which does the best afternoon teas in London.

Should not be missed. We took some American friends, and the family to the Collection on Sunday. It was a great experience, as the Collection was very quiet. The Collection was as fabulous as ever, with a topical Agincourt special exhibition. It is just wonderful to wander around the richly decorated rooms and admire the paintings, porcelain, and the furniture, especially the clocks! The Boulle is outstanding. Above all the Collection is manageable, ie not too big, and has plenty of chairs, very important in a gallery. No modern art, but the Rembrandts, Rubens, Murillo, Canaletto, Hals, Cuyp, Bouchard, etc are all a treat. They also had drawing events for young children which our grandchildren, 4 and 6, enjoyed. A special word for the toilets. Though down a long flight of stairs, the toilets are all individual cubicles, gents included, with delightful tile decoration, and their own sink. Really first class. We also ate in the restaurant, see separate review.
Outstanding. In my opinion the best museum in London which is located in Manchester Square but hidden behind Sainsburys department store

One of London's gems. Extraordinary personal collection of an illegitimate aristocratic tourist, brought back to his London mansion for everyone to enjoy, with adelightful courtyard restaurant in the summer. A magnificent tribute to the advantages of being filfthy rich, available to everyone free of charge.
Fabulous Art Gallery. Wonderful collection set in a beautiful house in Manchester Square. Great location and slightly off the beaten track. Great cafe. Highly recommended.

a stones throw from oxford street. This lovely house and collection is perfect for a rainy day in london. It houses it mixture of paintings, fine porcelain and armour in the lovely and ornate Hertford House which dates from the late 18th Century. There are paintings by Titian Rubens Rembrandt and the iconic lady on the swing. A few years ago I saw an extraodrinary exhibition of the work of Bonnigton. The collections are very important and of national significance. It is worth visiting just for the Sevres and Meissen ceramics. There have been major armoury exhibitions and I believe there is one relating to Agincourt on now. I usually go to meet friends in the restaurant which is the best courtyard al fresco dining experience in London. Afternoon tea is fabulous. The facilities are great. The toilets are clean and modern. The museum is open daily and its free admission. Manchester Square is a 5 minute walk or short cab ride from Selfridges on Oxford Street.

Supeb collection. The entry is free and staff was helpful . Can see a lot of things and can get an idea how wealthy people live a century and half back .Easy access it is about 200 meters from Selfridge

Phenomenal collection, incredibly engaging - great way to spend an afternoon!. With little to no expectations, I visited The Wallace Collection on a rainy London afternoon.I was blown away by the sheer magnitude of the collections, as well as the varied nature of what the site contains, from crockery, to paintings, to armour! A really interesting collection, beautifully laid out, well worth a visit.

Wallace Collection--WOW. We stumbled onto the Wallace collection by accident and it turned out to be one of the gems of our two week trip. Amazing collection in private hands, now a private trust. Find it and give yourself a wonderful art afternoon

Stunning Art and Antique Collection. A visit to the Wallace has been on my to-do list for many years, and finally made it this week. What a revelation! Room after sumptuous room, stuffed with fine art, furniture, glassware, ceramics, miniatures, manuscripts, armour and weaponry - you name it. Highlights for me were the Canalettos, Rembrandts and some exquisite Dutch landscapes. Oh and the fabulous Sevres ceramics! One visit was just not enough to take it all in properly, so my friend and I will definitely be making a return visit. It does not appear to be widely advertised, so for such a major collection, was really quite quiet. And admission is free! Eleven out of ten.

What a great small museum!. I would never have found this gem of a museum except for a friend. I loved it, and when my husband and I found ourselves in London last month, I introduced him to it. What a wonderful collection of two and three dimensional art!

Fantastic- well worth a visit. A visit here is a wonderful relief from the busy life outside. A beautiful building and fabulous collection of old sorts including armoury. Great restaurant too - may need to book this

A hidden gem!. This family collection is well worth visiting - the highlights include The Laughing Cavalier, The Swing, some fabulous Sevres porcelain, Marie Antoinette furniture and a large armoury. We were able to join one of the free tours which gave a fascinating overview of how the collection came about.

Beautiful Collections!. We've been here last year and it was a good experience. We took the free tour in the afternoon and the lady has explained the collections very well indeed. One of my favourite space of Wallace is the main restaurant. It is full of natural lights but it looks very busy when we were there.I will definitely come back again.

A wonderful experience. The Wallace Collection is a truly wonderful cornucopia of art and art items. The staff are welcoming and there is a relaxed atmosphere. Guided tours are available, as are fascinating lectures. And it's free!!Go - you won't regret it.

The hidden treasure. If shopping is not your cup of tea, go one step beyond Oxford street to visit this unique magnificent art collection. Wallace had a taste for painting and art in general. You will be surprised with the quantity as well as with the quality. The paintings are hanging in three rows surrounding all four walls of the main gallery. This amazing place right in the heart of London's shopping center reopened 1 year ago and you will not regret for taking this extra art dose.

DISCOVER BYGONE ELEGANCE AT THE WALLACE COLLECTION, LONDON.. Do you want to see how the upper classes lived through the eyes of this avid collector? Spend around an hour being transported back in to the time of 'Upstairs, Downstairs' and the lives they all lived.

Weird and Wonderful. Give yourself at least 3 hours, there is plenty to see. And all day if you want to eat or have tea. The collection of art is amazing and if that is not enough for you have a gander through the armory collection which is not to be missed. Nice getaway from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street/Bond street.
Excellent day out. beautiful collection, paintings, sculpture, furniture and other. General exhibitions and some very beautiful special collections. easy reach of central London

Great for all lovers of antiques.. The Wallace is a fine collection of paintings, furniture, armoury, and ceramics. It is of particular interest if you like French 18th century painting. There is a lot to learn and, when you've finished enjoying the art you can have a fine meal in the restaurant there.
Fantastic!. First visit there this year - an amazing collection. And a great cafe as well. Very helpful and friendly staff who are only too happy to talk about the treasures in the collection.
EXCELLENT MUSEUM. The museum is free to enter and is really interesting with a superb collection.The military section is well worth the visit.

Delightful atrium. Hertford House in Manchester Square is a serene oasis of calm just a short walk from bustling Oxford Street. The collection of art - which can be seen free of charge - is well worth a visit, and the cafe was a wonderful surprise. We had a lunch appointment elsewhere so I cannot comment on the food, but our time in the cafe was very pleasant. It was once a courtyard but has been covered by a glass roof to form an atrium, so it is warm when the weather is not. We enjoyed a coffee there and look forward to our next visit.

Amazing customer service. Last weekend I throw a bridal shower afternoon tea at the beautiful Wallace collection. I am happy to say that the staff at the restaurant made this experience amazing, especially Andrew, who works in the restaurant, went above and beyond for us. I will definitely be returning & recommending all of my friends & family. The tea was amazing and the layout and decor was simply beautiful. Thank you once again!

Wallace Collection Hertford House | Manchester Square, London W1U 3BN, England Excellent. spend hrs walking round there, take in some food also in the restaurant , then go onto more paintings over all the floors , no admission fee , just pop something in on way our at reception

A hidden gem. The Wallace Collection is housed in an aristocratic town house not far from Selfridges department store. Assembled over several generations by the Marquesses of Hereford, the collection includes Old Master art works, fine furniture, armor, and miniatures. It is an impressive experience for art lovers..

Nifty but.... Despite being a big fan of art and furnishings I wasn't as impressed with this as much as others have stated in their reviews. It was indeed cool and free which can't be beat but when I inquired about the audio guide I was talked out of it and suggested I buy the book instead. There are some really wonderful pieces in this museum and the courtyard tea garden is really nice. But overall I felt like it didn't match my expectations after what I'd read. BUT - I was also dead tired and had just seen Apsley House so it may have been a day of overkill. It was free - pop in and if you don't like it you've lost nothing.

wonderfull place to go and enjoy. porcelain , weapons , miniatures , furnitures. These are collected during 18-19 centuries by Sir Richard Wallace, then all of his collection was denoted to the state by widow of Sir R Wollace. it has alot of small collections that needs to be observed, if you have a free day, then it is a must to do.
A hidden gem. Worth taking a short side trip off Oxford Street to see this amazing building and it's well- kept treasures.

The Perfect Museum. I first visited this museum more than twenty years ago and despite working in the west end for the last 7 years this was the first time I had returned. It always beckoned but I never seemed to have the time. This is museum worth savouring but I realise now it is also a museum worth popping in for a browse every now and then like your favourite bookshop. There are sufficient seats (it was sparsley populated even on a drizzly Saturday afternoon) to allow you to admire the rooms at leisure (the paintings of Venice my favourite). And the cabinets of hidden gems will take you hours to discover. Now with a restaurant which I am keen to try on my next visit this is an oasis away from the hustle and hustlers of Oxford Street. Entry is free but a large donation is definitely warranted on at least one of your visits.

up close and personal. In addition to the great collection of paintings, there are also many classic furniture pieces. The way the collection is arranged, you can get up close and personal to all of the art. I have yet to see it crowded so it is great for a date or a meander as there is never the rush to get moving. The collection size is such that you don't feel like you're going to miss anything. Highly recommended.
Welcome oasis. Great collection of paintings and a convenient short walk from Oxford Street. Has a lovely attached restaurant. A welcome break from shopping!

Slide off Oxford Street and really enjoy!. When you can't bear Oxford Street anymore - and even Selfridges has lost its appeal, forget thoughts of shopping and give yourself a REAL treat. Sidle off to the North corner of Manchester Square and move thru' the heavy, dignified doors of the Wallace. Unbelieveably, still free (very generous bequest), this is a powerhouse collection of fine and decorative arts - with every period and nationality (well, European, that is) of the history of art beautifully represented. You'll glide round this mansion (it's laid out as a grand 'house' collection with sumptuous room settings) and just let everything sink in. Aside from the pleasure of the place - it's spot on for research and holds monthly events/tours/lectures etc. to suit most levels (incl. family/children/seasonal). On a more basic level - beautiful cafe/restaurant in the 'atrium' of the house pricey but well worth the treat; gift shop likewise, but possibly not quite so worth it! GO.

Spectacular Collection. Always something great to see and in a lovely environment. Easy to reach and accessible. Wonderful paintings, many favourites that you will have seen in magazines and now you can see and admire hanging in very well lit rooms, from Frans Hals to Rubens and Rembrandt. Plus amazing suits of armour, porcelain etc all well displayed. Drinks and snacks available and an excellent restaurant if you want a treat.

Most enjoyable and instructive teatime visit. We loved the guided visit and really enjoyed the scones and finger sandwiches which were perfect!On pointing out that the tea had gone Luke warm, a fresh pot was brought over with a big smile. My friends were Canadiens and simply in awe of this gem of a place.

Wonderful cafe just off Oxford Street - ok, and great paintings too!. Thinking about shopping on Oxford Street? Forget it. Instead, less than ten minutes away, head to the Wallace Collection. It is an oasis of calm in central London - wonderful building, beautiful paintings (Laughing Cavalier is here plus SO much more), stunning French furniture, friendly staff and the most fabulous cafe. Fig, beetroot, blue cheese and hazelnut salad? Yes please - and I'll be trying that one at home. Oh, and if you really need retail, they have a small but perfectly formed gift shop full of interesting bits and bobs (and a good postcard selection). A lovely place to hang out.....And it's free to go around - amazing. Rude not to leave a donation to such a fabulous organisation.

British classic Bling-Bling. What a beautiful, fascinating place this is, very rich in history. This hidden gem, although not that large, rivals the Palace of Versailles in grandeur. It is housed in what looks to be a former mansion, located in an obscure location a few short blocks north of Selfridges Oxford Street department store. This is how the very wealthy lived back in the day. There are many opulent furnishings, suits of armor (for both men and horses) and great works of art on display. You could spend several hours here. Like all the great museums of London, there is no charge for admittance and the employees are friendly and polite. Highly recommended!

Beautiful artifacts. The Wallace Collection is filled with amazing artifacts, from everyday use objects to arms and armor. The exhibits can be seen up close, and even those encased in glass cabinets can usually be viewed from all around. The entrance is free, however, to learn more about the collection, one may require a guidebook (£4) from the shop.

One of the best art collections I have seen. I read about this attraction on TA and really wanted to visit it. What an experience, a magnificent house in a hidden square off Baker Street, full of magnificent art works and treasures. Well worth a visit, and it's free! Lovely staff too, it was pouring down and they had plastic bags for our umbrellas! Made us feel really welcome. The café is an outlet of Oliver Peyton and isn't cheap, but then entry to the house is free as I said! A nice place to treat yourself to lunch. Lots to see and keep you busy on a very wet day.
a hidden gem. we both enjoyed this house. Well displayed portaits and the armour section was very enjoyable for me!!

Breathtaking collection of European history. What a fantastic collection of European art and artefacts a truly stunning house decked out to the rafters with the very best artists work over the last 400 years. When it's time for refreshment then the courtyard cafe is a must. Some great dishes to choose from and scrumptious cakes. This is a great place to visit just a short walk from Bond Street underground.

weekend visit. A really interesting collection well thought out in presentation. Guided talks are interesting for those pictures included but you will want to then peruse at your leisure. Nice eating place as well.
Free. Well worth a visit. So many famous artists - Canaletto, Reynolds, Landseer and many more. Well laid out and amazingly, free. Cafe/restaurant n the centre also attractive

Enjoyed the collections. Being a keen naturalist it was nice to accompany my nieces school trip to the House. It's an interesting collection and nicely laid out. I don't know about entry prices but it was a pleasant day out.

A jewel. If you don't want to be overwhelmed this is a great place to come. It is genteel. The paintings are well displayed and the scrumptious colours of walls and beautiful furniture make it really worth a visit. It's never crowded so don't tell anyone.

Great colelction of Armour and nice tea room. Fantastic collection of armour and weapons that my hubby and son really enjoyed. The rest of the collection was mainly paintings of varying styles including some old masters. The tea room in the covered court yard was bright and airy and served a fab Swiss Roll!
Beautiful. Beautiful place - lovely art work and a great display of armour which the kids always enjoy! The cafe is quite special and worth a visit too.

Great art collection in beautiful mansion. Great art collection in beautiful mansion. Free of charge, 5 minutes away from Oxford street at Manchester square a hidden gem of art; forget the overcrowded big museums and go for the smaller gems in the city
a hidden gem. I had a wonderful time visiting . It was a novel experience being able to go close up to the furniture and knights.

Nice collection of arms. Private museum, family collection, low level is full of medieval arms and Knight Armour, furniture and pictures give impression hoe rich people used to live and what did they like.

Hidden from Sight just behind Selfridges. What a fabulous find for art lovers, so many rooms to go and experience beauty and colour there is something for everybody young or old in here. Finish off the day with Afternoon Tea in the smart restaurant £18 per person

Poorly Curated & Rude Staff. There are lots of very interesting items to be seen but unfortunately if you want to read about them, you must go to the catalogues that are in each room. I can only think that the Curator is either very old or does not have much experience of curating works of art. With the right Curator and some staff customer service training this would be a little gem, but unfortunately I just found the whole experience hard work!

Not to be missed. So nice to receive such a warm welcome on arrival. Amazing place. Take your time, there is so much to see. Enjoyed lunch and a glass of Prosecco - absolutely delightful. Staff so pleasant and service superb. Have visited many times and it never disappoints. Enjoy a leisurely visit.

Relaxed atmosphere, great artwork.. There is plenty to see here, not least the art work. The building itself is a lovely setting for an art gallery. I enjoyed the art on display, but I also enjoyed the furniture, the fireplaces, and the antiques too. Plenty of clocks and other pieces exhibited. I also enjoyed the armoury section, which was a section I didn't expect. The artwork, The Laughing Cavalier included, is wonderful. The staff and atmosphere is nice and relaxed and a lovely way to spend my Sunday Morning. The restaurant did look a bit expensive and the selection a little limited, so decided not to bother.

Pleasant surprise. We stumbled upon the Wallace Collection while strolling along the streets in London. Walked in and hooked up with a small tour (10 people) that lasted over 2 hours. Our guide was wonderful and gave us an extensive background on the history of the house and the collection. This was a very enjoyable experience.

Another classic.. Not as well known, this is a good little museum. Art, suits of armour.
Expensive restaurant, that only the wealthy can afford.

Surprisingly Wonderful. We finally got to the Wallace Collection after several London trips. It is better than expected. The converted mansion has a huge collection of armor, weapons, fine art, and historic collectibles.The house itself is interesting as well. Don't miss the chandeliers; they are spectacular. Take your time to peruse the displays. There is a lot to see.
So many things to look at.. This collection was amazing. So many amazing thinks to see. So much for your eyes to take in. Well worth a visit.

Best galley in London. The Wallace Collection has everything! Amazing building, great paintings, porcelain, armour, weapons, furniture, the list goes on. We took a guided tour and the guide was fun, knowledgeable and full of fascinating facts. Even without a guide this is a brilliant voyage of discovery, enough to warrant repeated visits.
Best collection in London. Best collection in London. This is Londons best kept secret. Wallace's art, sculptures, furniture, etc are all here

Art and arms. The Wallace Collection is tucked away in a back street in Marylebone. It contains many old masters (Rubens, Rembrandt, Velasquez, Van Dyck etc) and an incredible collection of Roccocco furniture. However, for me the highlight is the armoury. It contains examples of some of the rarest and most artistically exquisite weapons over produced. Incredible.

One of the finest small galleries in the world. The building itself is beautiful. It houses a major collection of Dutch Genre paintings, including The Laughing Cavalier and a glorious portrait by Rembrandt of his son. There are also 2 fine paintings by De Hooch, several Jan Steens and many more first rate Dutch paintings. The collection of French art is outstanding and includes Boucher and Fragonard. It is hard to find a better collection of Canalettos and Guardi's paintings. The Spanish school is well represented and there is a fine collection of French porcelain and furnitures. The list is LONG. The Wallace Collection is not to be missed!

Absolutely stunning. Decorative arts in their full majesty. If you get in there, you will come out amazed by the craft of each item. And let's not forget to mention the beautifully renown paintings that are exhibited in their full glory: housed among furniture in beautiful rooms.

A hidden gem in the heart of London.. Packed full of stunning works of art and beautiful furniture the Wallace collection is a must see. The elegance of the surroundings adds to the enjoyment. I have never seen so many famous works of art in one place outside of major art galleries and the collection of miniatures is simply mouth watering. Well worth a visit or even two!!

First class collection, great meeting place in Central London. Take a stroll around this museum, a stone´s throw from Oxford Street. A haven of peace. Lovely paintings, sculptures, and (for those who like such things) armoury. Indulge yourself in this remarkable atmosphere, above all if you like history, Victoriana, etc, and add a decent lunch or even afternoon tea in their lovely, spacious patio restaurant.tyu

Worth visiting. Went here briefly on a previous visit to London and knew I had to come back for a proper visit. A great collection. Took the tour and she was very informative. You need minimum 2 hours.
Didn't have lunch here but the cafe looks nice and it was busy.

FEELS LIKE HOME. Stare at the Lady with a fan, the Swing, the Rembrandts, the Canalettos. Wonder around the palacial home picturing yourself living here. Dream of collecting art as if budget were not really a problem. Have a coffee or a tea and a cake or a salad, and drink to those who gave us a chance to enjoy such stunning collection in the heart of London. Wouldn't it be nice to open all the windows facing Manchester Square and when the sun set prepare to dance in the ballroom ...and glance at the same statues and paintings in the candlelight!

Hidden gem. A stone's throw off Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is small but imposing, a grand house hosting a serious art collection - from paintings through furniture to ceramics and clocks, this is an important collection well worth viewing. Great restaurant in the courtyard worth going for alone, but do take some time to browse. Excellent tours offered too - well worth the hour or more it takes to go through the collections highlights. And it's free - incredible!
A hidden Gem to me. Spend a little time here and you will be blown away with the exhibits, they are fantastic and it is free entry as well. I will be back
Fabulous museum. Little known museum well worth seeking out. Unexpected art works and fabulous armoury display. Superb cafe and a lovely day out.

Unexpected pleasure. We were recommended to visit the Wallace collection by the concierge of our hotel and had no expectation for our visit. We happened on a tour that was commencing, given by a volunteer at the Wallace Collection and we were mesmerized by the collection and its presentation.
Wonderful Place in City. Grand mansion in city with beautiful artifacts on display. Within easy walking distance from Department stores, yet on a tranquil street that feels far away from it all.

Best gallery in London if you like history. Fantastic collection with the Laughing Cavalier the most well known portraits. Also many Louis XIV and XV artifacts and one of the best galleries I have been to in London. I think this is better than the art galleries. Free entry and the tour is well worth the information on the building and artwork. Highly recommended and easy walk to Oxford Street.

A very interesting museum, it you are looking for something different :). A quirky and different museum running very interesting exhibitions! Also a nice place to read a book and see the permanent collection.I have been there for the Hubbub event and it was very entertaining and interesting. I learnt a lot and had fun! I will join their future events for sure.

A Marvel. With a few hours to kill in the area before a booked dinner one in our group suggested we have a look at the Wallace Collection. I must admit I hadn't heard of it before.And what a collection it is!Truly remarkable specimens from all over the world all set in an incredible building.Not to mention it is all for free (donations are possible).Highly recommended, not just for a time killer but a proper planned visit

Sunday Walk-a-bout. Popped in as we were local and went straight to the basement as directed so my son could try on the armour for size. It's changed in recent years with access to a wonderful atrium and cafe.
Works of art and weapons are superb and the attending guides were very helpful!

A Hidden Gem!. This collection is one of the hidden gems in London, tucked away in Manchester Square about 500 yards from Oxford Street it houses some of the finest art works you will ever see in a private collection. There are Rubens, several Rembrandts, Van Dyck and probably one of the most iconic & valuable masterpieces in the World, The laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals the Dutch painter.There is also a fantastic armoury with weaponry & suits of armour dating back many centuries on display.Entry is free, but please donate as this is how the Collection is funded today.

delightful insight into a private art collection. While competing with prestigious large museums in London, the Wallace collection stands on its own for what I enjoyed as a good balance between a nice historical building (the family house where the collection is hosted) and the variety of the pieces on display. Not being too big, it makes an easy visit; the display is logically organized among the different rooms, and you can quickly decide what you want to focus on; however, it pays to go through each room, at least quickly, to get a full flavour of the house itself, the original use of each room and how the collection grew in time to fill them. The web site is well done, it gives a good description of what is displayed inside (porcelain, armour, furniture, in addition to paintings of various nature). The position is central and easily reachable (nice complement to a day in the centre of London), the staff is kind and helpful while watchful of the artwork on display (often unprotected, thus giving the real flavour of a private collection). I was very happy to visit, and will go back possibly trying the café (though I have read many unfavourable reviews - anyway, plenty of places are available around the house).

Well worth a visit. I had a hasty visit due to bus transport problems but spent an hour viewing the paintings and other artwork in this impressive collection. I skipped the armoury though this also looked impressive - if you are interested in weapons & armour. I will be back for a more extended visit some other time. I would have given it 5 stars except the cafe had shut at 4.30 just before my sister arrived and would not serve her a cup of tea. Seeing as the museum did not shut until 5pm this seemed a little churlish.
some very excellent paintings. This collection is so overfull of atifacts that they swamp the outtanding exhibits. It needs weeding! But do go to see Frans Hals and the young Rembradt.
Must see. Loved everything on display. So interesting, a place not everyone would think of visiting. Do yourself a favour and visit the Wallace Collection

Hidden Gem in Central London. Friendly, knowledgeable and approachable staff make visiting this small museum a great experience. A great location for escaping the hustle and bustle of London for an hour or two.
How to spend a lovely Sunday. This museum is a condensate of talent, history and worldwide treasures. The tea room is absolutely fantastic and the staff is lovely.

Beautiful location, eclectic collection, and a restaurant.. I like museums and enjoyed the eclecticism of this collection. Truly remarkable and yet the museum feels approachable and manageable. It is in a lovely, quiet location and there is a restaurant which looked interesting but we didn't have time to dine. A friend once recommended tea at the Wallace to her son as an impressive yet inexpensive destination for a first date.
Wonderful experience. Wonderful experience, beautiful collect of the very best in antiques and statues. Would highly recommend.
Fabulous collection. You will probably recognize something you have seen before in this wonderful collection. So much to see and enjoy and the building itself is beautiful.

A surprise in the middle of London. This building is huge, a former home and the front drive is quite a surprise when taking into account how built up London is. Inside the collections especially of porcelain are very impressive, the furniture is also excellent. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful collection set is a fabulous building, all for free!. Where to start? Fabulous collection of mainly French paintings, porcelain and furniture set in beautiful, sumptuous Hertford House. There is so much to see here, including an extensive armoury and arms collection. We went on the tour and our guide Ann was so interesting and knowledgable. I have been to London many times and never knew about this place, only a stone's throw from Oxford St and all for free!. Because people don't know about it is it not so crowded as the National galleries. The restaurant is in the covered courtyard is also a lovely place to go. Free wifi as well. Will definitely be going back, loved it!.

visiting with friends. I often go to visit the Wallace collection in london every time I go to the capital! The whole collection is truly outstanding! With works by Francois Boucher and Fragonard and brass inlaid furniture by Andre charles boulle this collection is one of the worlds greatest and most inspirational! My keen interest in vivienne westwood fashion also helps as dame vivienne is often here looking at the art and treasures and drawing inspiration herself to add to her historical fashion designs! A true gem nestled neatly behind Selfridges! Free entry, a well stock gift shop and a beautiful court yard outdoor cafe that serves lovely refreshments all day long! If it was good enough for Madame pompadour it's good enough for us! Remarkable day out ❤️

A Must Do when in London. One of the best Collections of Fine Art Paintings, Collectables, Clocks and exquisite precious pieces in the world ,I am sure. To be compared with the Frick collection which we enjoyed seeing last october in NY>

Hidden Gem near oxford Street. charming collection of paintings,golden furniture from Louis 14 france, weapons , knights in shining armour, porclain tactivities for children and a pretty covered cour yard for tea

Something of interest for everyone. Extensive range of different types of collections from pottery through art to military uniforms from around the world. Knowledgeable staff who give talks about individual items. Worth a number of visits. The building is also a fine example.

A pleasant break from shopping. This is a great place to take visitors to London for a pitstop of lunch or tea in the gorgeous conservatory. Before or after you can take in the opulence of a life once lived by the aristocracy in the collections of art, armour and room settings.

The Hidden Housen of Wonde. This really is a must do when in London. Every where you turn you see something fantastic. From a world renowned painting to a fabulous piece of furniture. I live in London and I have never got bored of spending a rainy day gaping at the marvels on display. Goyou will regret it if you don't

The Wallace Collection Is Spectacular!. I have been to this gorgeous collection twice now at Hertford House. The 18th Century French paintings, porcelains, furniture, and other objects d'art are just breathtakingly beautiful. The romantic, lush paintings by Boucher & Fragonard are delightful. I plan to go back again. The café and restaurant looked very inviting. It is not crowded and is a lovely way to spend several hours

Finest collection 18th Century French paintings and furniture . Wallace Collection is one of the finest 18th century French collections of works of art, absolutely beautiful furniture, paintings and porcelain. In 1897 Lady Wallace bequeathed this lovely family's art collection to Britian. If you love art and appreciate fine details, this place is a must visit. An absolute treat!!I've been to some other museums and collections around the world but my visit to the Wallace Collection surpassed expectations by manifold!!Admission is free. I visited the place with ACCA group at a dinner arranged in the beautiful courtyard. The guided tour given by Madam Midori was so nice and informative.

A must when you are in London. We have lived in London for many years and finally made it to the Wallace collection. Really interesting and informative. The restaurant does very good coffee and the food also looked good.

Its like mini buckingham place. This building is not far walking from bond street underground station.I saw the building looks like mini Buckingham place. The Admission is free.Has 25 galleries displays of French 18th century painting and furniture.Its is a great day out I spend around 1 hour walking on all first floor and ground floor.There is shop and toilets there.

Brilliant Armoury and Interesting Paintings. This was recommended to me by several seasoned Londoners and it didn't disappoint. If you enjoy the detail of armoury, and views on the world that has passed through the eyes of artists I'd recommend. The paintings and room dedicated to the Arab world was probably my favourite, though not sure that is part of the permanent collection.

a nice way to spend a morning if you are in the marylebone area. Fragonard's "The swing" is to the Wallace museum as "Mona Lisa" is to the Lourve. So, if that is your only goal, the trip here would be worth your while. If coure, If you have no interest in 17th or 18th Century art, this place can be challenging. It houses paintings by artists such as Titian, Rembrandt, Hals and Velázquez . Apart from paintings, you also see an exquisite collection of eighteenth-century French paintings, porcelain, furniture. The intimate nature of the museum makes viewing quite special. Though I have no strong interest in 17th century or 18th century French, Flemish or Dutch paintings, I was intrigued by the opportunity to have an insight into how the really privileged build up their own private collection. The curatorship in itself is an interesting story. So, I would resist the temptation to whisk through the room as you would miss much of the context and the narrative behind the collection. The restaurant in the atrium is a fine place for a meal and drink. Compared to the extortionist price and terrible food you get in the lourve, the cafe in the Wallace museum is a 3 michelin star restaurant.

World class collection of porcelain, paintings and furniture. An extraordinary collection housed in a beautiful building in central London. Spectacular porcelain and furniture- collected in France by Hertford ancestors and then Sir Richard Wallace. Highlight paintings include the Laughing Cavalier, The Swing, many Canalettos etc. also a collection of arms and armour but we didn't have time to visit this. Excellent cafe/restaurant on site.
A birthday treat to remember. I had a wonderful lunch on the terrace of this remarkable place. I was invited by a cousin to join me for a birthday treat and this was a very special and memorable day.
For European Art Lovers. A fine collection of paintings, furniture, porcelain and an armory collection. It specializes in 17th-18th century works.
15th to 19th centuries paintings. Excellent collection of paintings, other art works and furniture in a large house on Manchester Square. Free entry.

Fantastic!. This private collection is definitely a must to see when visiting London. It is just astonishing to see that one person could accumulate such wealth of paintings and antiquity.This is a real treasure and is fantastic to see that it is so well preserved in it's natural setting.
wonderful collection of 17C-19C art and porcelain. Outstanding collection in a relatively small gallery, making it nicely viewable in less than a day. Located near John Lewis' on Oxford street

out of the wet. i didn`t know this place existed. in london visiting friends who took us to see it. was late in afternoon 4.15, so i rather got the impression they didn`t want us their that late in the day as they closed at 5. we managed to get a rather expensive of coffee. had a quick tour of the ground floor and left. will visit again when in london next

A great gem. Tucked away behind Oxford st in a quiet leafy square is one of Londons greatest private collection of Antique furniture,paintings and memrobilia. This is one of those lesser known museums and thank god for that as you have a very serene ambiance to view this prestigious and unique collection. The cafe/restaurants is a great addition and well worth using even if you do not view the museum !

Enjoyable but not the best. Easy to reach and in a very impressive building. A mixed collection of paintings, furniture, armour, fire arms and other bits and pieces. The quality varies as at most galleries but there are some fine paintings. It gets four stars as there are better galleries in London.

Highly recommended if you appreciate antiques and fine art.. Having mostly lived in London since 1992, I only visited the Wallace Collection this year. Its like going back in time to walk around inside, and best of all its free.

Cozy, charming museum. A much smaller museum in size compared to the British Museum but still packs a punch in terms of things to see. It feels a lot more like you are walking thorough a mansion then a museum. And with such smaller volume of visitors ( at least on the day I went) you can truly spend more time enjoying each room. Make sure you see the armoury. Some of the most magnificent collection of medieval armour and weapons I have ever seen.

Must see if you love art. This private collection which is nevertheless free is one of the best art museums we have been to. Very reminiscent to the Frick collection in NY. Well worth an afternoon wandering through this beautiful mansion.
A magnificent old museum. Houses some of the world finest works of art and decorative furniture . It is a very good attraction to visit especially if it is a rainy day.

A fine introduction into the British world of art. Located within walking distance of Oxford street, entrance free, this mansion contains a fine collection of art and period furniture. Recommended to take the guided tour with a most knowledgeable guide.

There's fantastic stuff in it!. Really worthy to take the tube (Oxford Street) and see it. The paintings are beatiful and there are also other interesting artworks including old firearms. Unlike other big museums, in my opinion its size is the best for an half-a-day trip.

Perfect! Easier and more enjoyable to visit than the British Museum!. This museum is a delight to visit. The collection is superb! The objects are of the highest quality, beautifully displayed and just a joy to view. Be sure to pay close attention to the furniture as well as the art. The furniture in the home is just as spectacular as the art collection itself.

Great collection in a stunning setting. The Wallace collection is one of London most underrated museums. It has an incredible collection of paintings in a stunning setting, without being as overwhelming as some of the larger institutions. The Canaletto room is outstanding.
Wonderful Wallace experience. Stunning collection. Well worth a look. Excellent cafe. Helpful staff. Thoroughly recommend it. Too much to see in one go though.
A cultural delight. A cultural delight. Very famous but a hidden gem, a little off the beaten track. Well worth a visit. Take your time to look round. The collection is splendid.
Charming collection. It left me inspired and with increased 'joie de vivrej! The Rainbow Landscape, The Armenian Woman and Les Charmes de la vie have especially remained in my memory.

outstanding collection. This was my third visit to this collections. I did one of the docent tours this visit and it was outstanding and guide was one of the best I have encountered. Plan would be to do more tours on future trips to London and likely I will make visiting this place a regular occurrence.

Tour at The Wallace Collection. A relatively interesting tour, kids found it a bit dull at times. However, the tour guide did her best and I think all the staff there work hard. I would go their again... but only if I had to.
What a great find!. My friend recommended visiting this place and I am so glad I did. It is a beautiful house in the middle of London with amazing furnitures and history. I loved it!

Charming. This is a wonderful museum - a little off the beaten track so not as large and crowded as some of the others. You can discover the collection on your own or take a free guided tour - I suggest the tour and then wander on your own.

Great Collection. The place is amazing and quite accessible to everyone who has a love of the British Art
Establishment. They show inspiring work all the time, what more can I say.
Edward of York

A Gem of a place. Tucked away just off Oxford Street is the Wallace Collection. Lots of beautiful furniture, clocks, paintings etc set in lovely rooms. Not to be missed it puts some N.T. places to shame. A super restaurant too. So much detail to study in each room, free but I couldn't leave without donating a fiver and even then its a steal. Definitely go.

Perfectly Formed. Some years ago a friend said to me ' I bet you've been to the Wallace Collection' and I admitted I hadn't nor had I even heard of it ....... I looked at some pictures she'd been sent and it looked great I then googled it and I filed the info in my brain but only recently when thinking of possible places to take a friend for her birthday remembered it. So glad I did we met for lunch in the beautiful airy courtyard which was delicious then spent the afternoon viewing the myriad delights on offer. So many beautiful items to see displayed in lovely rooms. There is nothing stuffy or serious about the place despite the grandeur its inviting and relaxed. Such a brilliant place I loved it I even tried on chain mail which although heavy was surprisingly comfortable. We left saying we couldn't believe we had never been before and both agreed to visit again soon as there is so much to see it deserved more time than we had allotted. We left feeling happy and uplifted that we'd discovered such a gem of a place to visit.
A DIFFERNT TYPE OF MUSEUM. this is a lovely visit as it is small and intimate. There was a guide from the museum dressed in costume telling children a story which was very sweet. It's more of a home.
My favorite painting in the whole world is here. This is a beautiful gem of an art museum. You can visit and combine with a some retail therapy at Selfridges, which is just around the corner.

A hidden gem. One of London's hidden gems - especially as it is free entry. Many famous works are on display (eg, the Laughing Cavalier), but many unfamiliar works to discover. The staff are a little austere, but don't let that put you off. The collection is incredible.
Worth Visiting. A mixture of old furniture, objet d'art and of course paintings. Well laid out and worth a visit on a rainy cold afternoon
The artwork. Very interesting full of things to enjoy and marvel at. Artwork and furniture of the highest quality.
Fragonard's, Staircase made of money, Armor. By far the most unsung of all London's top level museums. Also the restaurant and tea room are first drawer.
My all time favorite. My favorite museum in London, never crowded and so many paintings to admire and wonder at. I wish there would be more guided tours though.

Amazing collection and escape the crowds of Oxford Street in this beautiful building. You can't come into Central London and not visit this beautiful small Museum. It is such a tranquil oasis in the centre of London, just of Oxford Street. The collection is amazing and there are lots to see from portraits to weapons and all for free(please leave a donation as it helps places like this survive). It also has a fantastic little restaurant/cafe that serves great food and is a wonderful meeting place for lunch or breakfast. This gem of a place should be on every visitors list as you will not be disapointed

I have loved the place for years. Some years ago I worked locally and visited the Collection regularly. In those days they ran a series of lunch-time guided lectures. You'd walk around with someone who would turn out to be a leading authority on 18th century French painters and perhaps Fragonard in particular. He or she might pause before The Swing to explain that this sort of painting was meant to titillate and invite us to consider the fact that the young woman depicted would be grossly deformed if she ever got off the swing. Her proportions were all wrong: rather like Barbie Doll.My wife and I were there again this week. There's so much there to enjoy whether it be paintings, furniture, clocks, snuff boxes miniatures and armour, the list goes on. Each time we're there we gaze in awe at The Laughing Cavalier. He looks ready to step out of his frame and talk to us. There's so much to see and yet the setting makes the exhibits seem more accessible than they might be in the great museums.There's a café/restaurant which is very good. My wife tells me that the ladies' loo is splendid. She had her own little bathroom as it were, with the luxury of your own hand basin. There are a few benches outside the main entrance. A perfect place to relax and enjoy the sunshine for a while.
Amazing Collection. This collection of art works, furniture and armour is a must-see. Located off Oxford Street it's the perfect antidote for the shopping blues.

Amazing collection - A Visit is worthwhile. This was an amazing house to visit. No as imposing as some from the outside, but once you are inside the amount of things on display, the amour, guns, swords along with painting and other elements of history is incredible. Walking from room to room each offered something different and were packed with items which easily outdid some of the more expensive places we visited. A worthwhile visit.
Pleasant surprise.. Wonderful art collection and pleasantly surprised to view the "Laughing Cavalier" among other masters' pieces. Enjoyable lunch in the atrium restaurant, although not inexpensive.

A splendid house that takes you back in time. Vast, opulent collection. A fascinating look at beautiful period furniture, china and crockery, rare famous paintings and armor that you won't see anywhere else. Situated in a very central position just off Oxford Street and totally free.

Unmissabe. The trustees are forbidden from changing the collection and so nothing is ever lent out. Some of the most amazing works of art and fine furniture in Europe that you can see nowhere else. Truly world class and worthy of multiple visits.

Amazing Art Gallery plus Armour, Ceramics, Furniture and much more. This collection of so many well known paintings is mind blowing, and it's free. Ok donations are suggested but not outright asked for. Edwin Landseer, Joshua Reynolds, Thomas Gainsborough, Peter Paul Rubens, Rembrandt and Canaletto are just a few of the artists and of course there is the Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals and I could go on but that's just the paintings. There's furniture, porcelain and lots of armour too. So interesting and well worth a visit.

Avoid the crowds. A little known gallery that has some wonderful pieces but without the crowds of the Tate or the National. This allows you to get close to some fantastic pieces with being jostled or straining for a look.A great attraction not too fare away from the chaos of Oxford Street

A very imposing and beautiful London mansion!. Amazing space, this house is a true gem! the size of the rooms is overwhelming! Lots of paintings. A very interesting insight of the life of the rich and how many paintings can one accumulate over a lifetime! Well worth the visit.
Wonderful. An outstanding collection thoroughly enjoyed my private view such a treat. Been meaning to come for a while and now regretted not coming sooner.

a superb, small, accessible museum (with a very English high tea!). The Wallace Collection is housed in a private house, given to the country in 1900. It has a fine (if idiosyncratic) coillection. Some excellent art: a Hals, a couple of Rembrandts, etc. -- some very good Boucher, if you like pre-French Revolution French art. And a lot of not quite first rate painters (and some rather academic 19th c. French art). It has wonderful furniture -- in every room. Statues. Miniatures. 15th c. maiolica plates and vases. And three or four rooms of armour, daggers, and guns.It is well worth a visit, and it does not have the hordes of tourists of the National Gallery. (If you know the Frick in NYC, the Wallace is like that, but with more space and more items.)It also has a restaurant, which serves lunch and -- 2.30 to 5:00 -- high tea, for about L17.50. Delicious. Choose your tea (black, green, or herbal). You get three half sandwiches, a scone with clottted cream and jam, and three sweets. We ate at 2.30, instead of lunch. Delicious, and fun

Amazing paintings, beyond compare.. This is the most sublime of galleries. I'm not sure I like what they've done to the atrium and the staff are still pretty terrible but the art in here is beyond reproach.

Don't miss this gem!. A perfect place to enjoy beautiful things on a small scale - so much more manageable than the big museums, you can pass several pleasant and relaxing hours here and have time to enjoy another activity on the same day.
Cultural visit in the summer. very interesting collection of paintings, furniture, in a palatial london home of the eighteenth century.
a gemm. This is one of the places in London that very few know and it is an incredible experience, please go it is a very beautiful collection.
Splendid!!!. A well kept collection, containing some fine artworks.The armoury is impressive. The jewellery and the gold boxes are exquisite!!!

Real gem. We'd visited Wallace galleria three month ago during our short vacation in London. The galleria is very close to the busy Oxford street, just several bus stops from the Marble Arch tube station. All about this place is exceptional: the collection, the building and the stuff. If you are very short on time, you can skip a first floor exhibition of armory and go straight to the upper floor where the main masterpieces of painting are displayed. Among the painters represented are Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Velàzquez, Poussin, Canaletto, Gainsborough and Lawrence. But if you do have time, I'll recommend you to spend extra hour or two and explore the whole collection, including miniatures, furniture and armory. Take a break in the winter garden cafe and enjoy delicious, but expensive snake. If you want to have a lunch you can do so, but be prepared for a high price tag.
Unexpectedly good. Found this museum better than I expected - specifically with more exhibits and both a greater variety and better quality items than I expected.

A must see. Located in a great neighborhood, one gets the feeling for how the wealthy lived in by-gone days. The collection is filled with great works of art, and has a great sword etc. collection to make it a little different.
Varied, interesting and free!. You need a couple of hours to fully appreciate this collection.Very good art collection amongst other things.Also some interesting religious relics.

Wonderful gallery. Visited after the large renovation very impressive, some of the finest artworks your found are housed in the collection. If you have children the armoury is an impressive place for them to visit but adults will turn into children when they walk into the great gallery it's an impressive renovation

My Favorite, Don't Miss. Fabulous venue for the architecture and decor of the home, it's collection of paintings, home decor, furniture, porcelain, various manuscripts, miniatures, armor collection - an enormous amount of stunning treasures, beautifully presented.

An eclectic mix. This museum is an excellent counterpoint for the (wonderful) big galleries and museums across London. Set in what was once a private residence, it is a small collection that you could easily walk through in about 2 hours. An eclectic mix of weaponry, porcelain minatures, paintings and furniture, it's well worth a visit.

Quirky Gem in Central London. The Wallace Collection is quirky and individual. I love wandering around here, when I am nearby. You can spend a brief time looking at stuff or you can take hours and still not see everything.Staff and volunteers are pleasant and knowledgeable. And the cafe provides an excellent cup of coffee. I really enjoy this museum. It never feels crowded, even in the height of summer and there's always some new object that delights the eyes.

Who knew it was there? A hidden gem. Well worth a visit.. A secluded spot in the heart of London. Plenty of space to walk around. The Laughing Cavalier is a joy to see ( although much smaller that I had imagined ) . I'll return as there is lots to view,

Well worth it. The docent tour is worth taking. My husband had been at the Wallace last year while they were restoring the Great Room. It is fabulous. They have an extensive collection of armor which is fascinating.The art is extensive and impressive for a small building.There is a glass ceiling cafe which is nice.I will return hopefully next year.

Well worth a visit.................. This is a little known venue that should not be missed. It is worth doing some research before you go as there is so much to see. The history of the family who and why the collections were made is fascinating. There are various collections of art, jewellery, furniture and fabulous china all displayed in this lovely house. The armory alone is worth a visit. The staff are volunteers who are well informed and enjoy imparting their knowledge. There are various high quality objects that can be purchased from the shop as gifts or just kept as a momento of the visit. There is a cafe/restaurant - Peyton and Byrne see review.
Wallace Collection. Beautiful house crammed full of exquisite works of Art. It is an oasis, so close to the hustle & bustle of Oxford St.Would thoroughly recommend.

Worth a visit. Perhaps lesser known than most other exhibits and museums, this is an impressive collection of art and artifacts in a similar fashion to the V&A museum, except for the excellent selection here of European armour and weaponary from previous centuries.Not far from Bond St station, so check it out.

One of London's gems. Had another wonderful visit here. Unlike other London galleries the staff here seem to enjoy the art and the place they are working in and actually have customer service training. The cafe is in a wonderful space. The toilets are modern and clean. The collection is quirky, interesting and occasionally breath taking. I'm so glad it hasn't moved with fashions, it is like a snapshot of the tastes of a particular time. People walking around really looked like they were enjoying themselves. I hope it continues to be accessible and free.
Wonderful museum, go on the free tour. Free tour is fantastic, not to be missed, some of the background stories are so interesting, puts a whole new spin on the artwork.

One Man's Treasures in Mayfair. A marvelous collection of art, antiquities, armor, in the heart of Mayfair. More approachable than the Tower of London. Charming mansion converted into a museum. And best of all free access though a contribution is always appreciated.
More than one visit is essential. Magnificent collection - impossible to take in at one visit; the remarkable range of the collection is awe-inspriring

Nice surprise. Had lunch here with a colleague, really nice food, the service is a bit haphazard, but the food is good. Quirky place and enjoyed looking at the collection afterwards, have some great art to see. I had not come across this place before - after many visits to London - so was delighted. It's also free entry.

Wonderful Paintings and Porcelain. I went on a guided tour which was so informative and very interesting. On the guided tours it is not possible to see the whole building, as that would take many hours with explanations, but the story of the ownership and the history of Hertford House is really extremely amusing as well as entertaining. I think that it is an absolute must to go on a guided tour as the staff are so knowledgeable and make this visit so very extra special.Paintings are explained how they came to be there, as are details of the furniture and the porcelain etc. etc. This attention to detail make this a wonderful experience.Suggest having tea at the restaurant which has a glass roof and a few small trees, very unusual and a delight.I do not usually write this - but the toilets were very very clean - which was good too.Will definitely go again.

Absolutely charming. This restaurant is absolutely charming. A gorgeous setting. A bit expensive, but it is worth it. The service is great and having a little mooch around the collection afterwards is a delight. It has the Laughing Cavalier on display.

A National Treasure!. What a revelation this Wallace Collection is! From the warm reception by passionate professional staff to this consumate collection of furniture and paintings to rival the Royal families collections. The covered courtyard Restaurant serves delicious coffees, pastries and lunches. At 11h30 our guide took us on the most unforgettable 'highlight' tour. She spoke well and obviously knows her history and this collection.Don't miss the opportunity of visiting this unique collection!

Okay a bit expensive for what it is. Had lunch here on a Saturday The food is very average for the price,although the location is pretty specialPortion size is a bit small and it tries to be more than it achieves If you want a haven from the mad world of Oxford street it is a reasonable choice otherwise you can get much better for less in other areas
The armour collection is good. What a wonderful place have been here many times never tire of seeing the collection and the restaurant is good too

A Complete Treasure Trove. I've wanted to go and see the Wallace Collection ever since I saw a programme on TV many years ago and I wasn't disappointed. A wonderful collection of paintings, particularly the Dutch painters. Add to this the eclectic collection of other stuff makes this a definite place to visit.
Very interesting!. Well worth the visit, lots of interesting things to see and it was good to have a long time to wonder round.

We love the Wallace Collection!. We love the Wallace Collection. It is one of the best art museums in London and a hidden gem. The rooms themselves are wonderful. One of the rooms has the walls covered entirely in emerald green Dupioni silk brocade. It is gorgeous to look at, and even more amazing when you realize the silk "wallpaper" probably cost over $100,000. The art are very interesting. For example, in most museums you will find one or more Canaletto paintings. In the Wallace Collection, there are six ... and they are all in one relatively small room. So, instead of having them spread throughout the museum, they are all in one place where you can easily see and compare them without moving. It is magical.

Dazzling!. One of the great museums of the world -- and it's free -- and it's often almost empty when more well-known galleries are chock-a-block. Fabulous collection of British painters, as well as objet d'art from Europe.
wonderful collection. free they will ask you to purchase a guide book which is worth the money. wonderful collection....Hals was my favourite

one of my favourite places in London. The restaurant and cafe here are excellent. They also have two fabulous Canaletto's which are hung opposite each other and have opposing views of Venice. There is a huge amount of other great art and china here as well and the building itself is worth going to see. An oasis of calm and beauty not far from Oxford Street. Ideal if you are not a shopping fan

Excellent. This is a very unique museum collection tucked away in a beautiful area with a very wide range of art and museum pieces. Best of all it's free & less crowded than some of the bigger & more well known museums but just as good.
Wonderful Collection. An eclectic collection of wonderfully diverse objects. I think it requires more than one visit to appreciate its qualities
London house at its bedt. Our 2nd visit, just wonderful historic house full of wonderful China and art works, just behind Harrods superstore, definitely a place to visit

The Atrium cafe is a good place for a light lunch, it is airy and light. We visited the café for a light lunch. The Salmon tart we had was delicious and we ordered some chips which were very nice. They also serve a nice glass of Rose wine but there are some nice non alcoholic cocktails which one of us had and enjoyed. The tea, English Breakfast was very good. It is a lovely quiet spot away from the hussle and bussle of Oxford Street.
Richard Wallace collection. Excellent collectionUnbelievable painting such as Rembrandt, Velasquez, franz halts etc...Free entranceNice cafeteriaGreat staffNot to be missed

Historic and special. How this charming museum isn't top of everyone's list as a tourist in London baffles me. Tucked away in a neat square, the Wallace Collection is like a trip back in time to the 18th century. Their courtyard is also stunning and a very smart place to go for tea with the in-laws.

Art, Furniture , Armour and More!. I had never visited the Wallace Collection and made it my first museum stop. I exited Bond Street station and it was a few minutes walk from behind Selfridges. This gallery/manse contains an eclectic and historic collection displayed beautifully in well designed interiors. You will find period paintings by reknowned Old Masters and other European artists, as well as sculptures, ceramics, furnishings, clocks and arms and armour. If you already have seen all the major museums in London this is a good secondary stop. Admission is free and there is an attractive cafe in an interior courtyard. Note: I consider this museum to be more of an adult attraction despite the armour display since space is limited and there is not really enough room for young children to wander around. You will especially enjoy it if you like period furnishings and interiors.

Priceless. Gainsboroughs, Reynolds, Hals, Van Dyke, Murillo, Canalletto, Sèvres, Boulle.......!! Lovingly displayed in a beautiful setting. Open to the public for free - 7 days a week!! What a treat in store for art lovers...

A Gem of a Museum. In a city in which museums are packed to the gills and too trendy for their own good, The Wallace Collection excels because it has outstanding offerings in a select range of artists, including Gainsborough, Canaletto and other exponents of 18th and 19th century landscape paintings, you can immerse in these works quietly and contemplatively. It is a pleasure to discover works that are not "blockbuster" but are instead the achievements of masters who do not often command our full attention. We pay attention in new ways and this enables us better appreciate art in general. There is one famous work--Frans Hals's "Laughing Cavalier"--and paintings you might not know by Rembrandt and Velasquez. The building itself is fascinating and historic and in its rooms you can envision a life of privilege in bygone days. There is also a lovely cafe/restaurant with outdoor tables in a central courtyard that makes a worthy destination even if you don't spend much time looking at the art.
Nice surprise. Walked into this by accident and we stayed much longer than we had anticipated. Splendid collections in a lovely setting.

Well Done. Fantastic to say the least. Because here you can admire the best of free time, culture and british spirit. Visit to believe, pictures really exceptional and full of history.Not to be missed, it is a pleasure to visit
Hidden museum, lovely. I love the Wallace Collection. I enjoy how it's slightly off the beaten track, so it's never hugely rammed with people. Make sure you visit the laughing cavalier if you go!

Could easily spend a day here!. This is my absolute favourite place in London. I can spend days there and have taken everyone I know to see all the incredible objects, arms and works of art. My favourite section is the armour room just after the outdoor cafe. Upstairs has some wonderful paintings too.

a great find just off the main tourist beaten track, worth the 10 mtr detour!. great museum with lots of beautiful treasures. Well worth a visit, you could do a quick visit or you could wander all day. Have a coffee and lunch too.

I've changed my mind. I didn't want to review the Wallace Collection as it isn't my cup of tea. But, I have been there a few times for afternoon tea and enjoyed that. So, on a rainy day shopping in Oxford Street I took visiting friends there for high tea. They valued the experience and we're glad the day turned out that way. For me, gawping at Victoria wealth expressed through oil paintings and ceramics isn't an aesthetic experience, it's a political revulsion! But, my friends were more tolerant and especially appreciated the guns and armoury. We all appreciated the tea, sandwiches, and cakes had in the central glass covered inner courtyard. So, there you are; even if you're like me it's worth a visit on a rainy day. If you're like my friends it's worth a visit anyway. It's a very short walk off Oxford Street.
Great collection. This is an excellent little museum that always seems to be quiet but has a very good collection that is well worth a visit.

Very good collection, intertesting - at a good location. We enjoyed our visit to this collection of art, paintings, furniture, arms and other objects. There are notices next to the items, and it's not too big- just the right size. The Wallace Collection is conveniently located in Central London, just a few minutes walk from Oxford Street, Baker Street etc.
UNAMUSED. I don't find this place very amusing. Not too much to do here. Nothing too see also. The walls make it very unattractive. Don;t go to this place.
Stately Home behind Selfridges. a great place to go on a rainy afternoon in London - art, antiques, armour, lots to look at. We took an elderly relative who enjoyed it as much as we did.

Relaxing day out, with much more to see.. I came here with a friend and spent a good portion of our day here. I feel as though it gets forgotten compared to the bigger names however the insides are luxurious. The different colours of each room are exquisite and highlight the pieces in each room. The staff are very friendly - which is not always the case in places like this. I want to visit again as I do not think we were able to see everything. Located in a very central spot, with great transport links.

For those curious about how nobility lived. Interesting visit for enthusiasts of Victorian Art, swords and armory, and impressionist paintings. Atrium cafe is worth a try. Just a short walk from Bond Street so the museum offers a nice counterpoint to tourists who would otherwise merely fill up their day with retail therapy.
Apart from the art - lots of old tat. The furniture and the ceramic is very out there, over the top kitsch. For art lovers, some fine pieces so worth going.

Hidden gem full of information. If you're a lover of historic arts and architecture then this place is a must on your list to visit. Tucked away behind Baker St this large building in itself is worth a visit. Quirky in build, an intriguing procession of spaces houses a wide variety of works of art, and not just wall hung items. Although as a modernist, and therefore not my 'cup of tea' the content is impressive in context of its era.Partially refurbished, the building displays interesting design and building techniques worth reviewing even for those designing today's buildings and interiors. A huge and invaluable library of built data for UK architecture may be found here also.

Loved the porcelain collection. wonderful collection of paintings and memorabilia in a beautiful house in London good souvener shop and restaurant and no problem for people with disabilities as lift to take you up or down to the restaurant

Well up in the top ten of London attractions. A most impressive collection of artworks, previously a private collection but now owned by the State. As with all state-owned museums, entry is free, although donations are solicited.

Interesting but unspectacular. The free walking guide is definitely the way to go, otherwise it is quite difficult to take it all in. It is a very attractive collection, but no stand out "wow" moments.
The restaurant is amazing, with beautiful glass ceiling.

Wonderful. Amazing private collection in the beautiful mansion a short walk from Oxford Street between Bond Street and Baker Street underground stations. It was a little busy during my visit but it was possible to find a quieter room to explore in peace and quiet.

Gorgeous. A secret that's been well-kept from the tourist hordes, Wallace Collection hides in plain sight just a few yards from Oxford Street. The art on display is exquisite, as are the surroundings in this 18th century mansion. Come here for elegant and sensual artistic delights.
Amazing place to celebrate.. Had lunch there to celebrate our Silver Wedding Anniversary, food and service was wonderful, previously had tea there after visiting collection.

If you love arms and armours this collection is a must!. In the heart of London is a less known art museum, the Wallace Collection, collected by this aristocratic family and bequeathed to the British nation. While it has splendid collections of paintings, sculptures, ceramics, goldsmith objects, etc., my personal favourites are two collections: the French furnitures and, above all, the splendid princely collection of arms and armours, maybe unique globally.Free admission and open every day!
A wonderful glimpse into a period house. Interesting paintings ad furniture in a lovely central location. A nice cultural break if you are shopping in Oxford Street.

Paintings by Vernet, a glass of wine, step out of this century for an elegant break. My favorite small museum to date in London. Near Baker Street, and not far behind the shops on Oxford Street. Many Vernet paintings as well as beautifully appointed rooms much as they were when this was a grand house. The atrium covers a central coutryard where two restaurants offer fancy and casual fare - delicious and restorative after viewing the art and furniture. A graceful and sweet return to the past, a balm for the weary shopper who would like a break from the commercial rush.

Great Collection. A beautiful building showing some great works of art and sundry other things. Plenty of places to sit down which appeals to me as I have a back problem. Lots of items under cover in cases and you have to lift the lid to see them. Far too much to see in one visit. I avoided the armour room as that is not one of my interests.
Excellent small museum with beautiful collection. Excellent museum not often visited by the tourist crowds.The collection is impressive and the fact it was a private house makes it even more special
Beautiful museum. Very interesting museum. Art and old weapons. Especially loved the armor for horses. Entrance is FREE!

Add this lovely little museum to your list. The Wallace Collection was extremely beautiful and interesting. Paintings, tapestries, china, furniture, the works, are all housed in this fabulous building. We were very impressed, and there is just enough to see that it is not too overwhelming.

A hidden gem in London. I am reliably informed that the Wallace Collection has the best loos in London. I can confirm they are quite ritsy. However the collection is wonderful; especially the art works. You can easily spend a whole day there and it is free. The restaurant is expensive but wonderfully open and relaxing; the food is not bad. For a free entrance, one cannot gripe at the prices. There are tours of the collection, quite excellent.
An oasis In busy london. Excellent collection, most interesting and beautifully presented. An oasis in busy london! highly recommend .
Wonderful collection. My husband and I both loved this collection. Such wonderful paintings, miniatures, armour etc. Easy to get to and a joy to visit.
Well worth a visit. Visited by chance. Amazing museum. Beautiful building. Too much to see in one go. Will have to visit again

Sublime art & stunning cafe. One of the most off-beat and enchanting collections in London — wonderful & surprising paintings, sculptures, and armour...PLUS an excellent, civilized cafe/restaurant with an enormous light-filled glass roof. Treat yourself like a human for once, nourish your body & soul!

Worth a journey if you are into either Loius XIV or medieval armor.. Great daily tours and lectures, free! Incredibly curated exhibit of medieval and Indian armor and weapons.Nice inexpensive food court for lunch or snack.
A gem!. A great location to unwind and enjoy great pieces of art and history. I would recommend taking a guided tour and to enjoy the courtyard restaurant.
Sophisticated place. It inspires anyone.. Great experience.. Sophisticated place. It inspires anyone. Great location as well. you can go shopping afterwards.
Hidden gem in central london. Lovely grand house. Full of over 5000 artefacts. Great for lovers of history and especially antique armoury.
fabulous art and building. fabulous art and building, free of charge. A perfect way to spend an afternoon. Extensive artworks, as well as armour.

Be still my heart, a small museum with a jewel of a collection.. From Rembrandt to Murill, from Gainsborough to Reynolds, from Cezanne to Corot, this collection is exquisite. Housed in a mansion in the Marylebone district of London, this is the most beautiful collection of 16th Century to 19th Century paintings. Italian Renaissance to Flemish masters, and so much more, all the art is beautifully displayed. Don't ignore the tremendous furniture and porcelain collection. There are only two drawbacks. First, The audio tour is seriously deficient given the size and importance of the collection. Second, I did not schedule enough time to really get enough out of the museum.
