On my next trip to London I will book a private docent tour and spend most of the day at the Wallace Collection. There is a charming cafe in the courtyard for lunch or tea.
Hidden Gem in London. Amazing House in the middle of london... what a gem and not at all crowded on our visit. The staff were very knowledgeable and greatly enhanced our enjoyment of the visit.

The Wonderful Wallace. My favourite museum in London. The range of great pieces in one place is almost unique. The basis of the endowment is also unqiue.If you have time for only a few museums in London, this should be one of them.

smaller museum with outstanding collection. This might have been my favorite museum in London, especially among the smaller museums. I still managed to stay a good part of the day because I enjoyed the collection so much and I particularly liked the free guided highlights tour I went on even though I do not usually like tours. Our guide was an arts professional and very knowledgable and interesting. The collection is amazing and because a portion of the building had once been a private home, it is set up as a house with exquisite furnishings that complement the paintings perfectly. I also had lunch in the covered courtyard and it was delicious though, as is common in museum restaurants, the lunch portions are small (but, I am a pretty big guy). I strongly recommend that visitors to London make time to visit this free museum.

Quick visit. Popped in here before going off on a stag do to get some culture beforehand! Amazing artwork and artefacts here, and there is a huge armoury room as well. Great just wandering around and soaking it all up.

Hugely recommended. My five and six year olds love this place - and I like it for evening functions too!If you are going with kids, maybe think about starting in the basement - there is some very unsung kids stuff there (hugely heavy suits of armour - a real lesson for the kids!) and then up via the armour. That said, my girls are very happy to potter round the pictures on the first floor. The volunteers are incredibly friendly, not pompous or off-putting and have really given an insight to both my kids on our visits. Would unhesitatingly recommend for a microcosm of great british history - and if you go on Sundays, you can park for free in the square. Very convenient for Oxford street, too!Nice shop, fairly high end - and how privileged are we as a nation that a place like this remains free to access.
My favourite !. If you have a little bit of time for yourself and you like be surrounded by beauty this is a unique place, were You can also enjoy an afternoon tea !

A great free museum in London. a lovely house full of all sorts of treasures. Conservatory area to have a drink if a little expensive, but then you don't pay to go in. Thoroughly enjoyed the 4 hours there.

Great collection of armory. Friends told us about this smaller museum which had a fabulous collection of art including amazing guns, knight's armor and lances. It also had a lovely restaurant in a center classed in courtyard.

Culture and a laugh. I love the paintings and ornate (slightly over the top :) ) rooms but by far my favourite part is getting to dress up in the chain-mail and armour in the basement, it's so heavy! and your travelling companions look very funny in armour too. Good fun.

A private gem. Entrance is free and the whole environment is friendly. Photography without flash is allowed. It's a private collection' moved from France in the 19th century with many notable items such as the laughing cavalier (Franz Hals) and many private miniatures of Boney and his family. The building is magnificent. Great to dip into.
I a quite area. Nice place but hidden away but that good as it is quite the tea room can get busy. So not good but the collection is free

Go, ask the guides. Lots of history, gorgeous furniture. Fabulous, free. Guides in every room. Most are extremely knowledgeable about the paintings and the family history. Location is a few streets behind Selfridges. Convenient short walk. I was there for a few hours

Beautiful Setting, Beautiful Objects, Welcoming Staff. This is one of London's little known but great value attractions. The collection is fascinating and diverse. The setting is gorgeous and the restaurant is delightful.
Interesting collections. Very interesting collections and display, taken care by a professional staff. We were lead by the staff which she gave a very informative tour for us.

Gem of a small museum. A jewel of a small museum off Manchester Squarevin a quiet area near Oxford Street. Very interesting collection. Plus two wonderful places to eat inside, a brasserie and a proper French restaurant, in a high, glass ceilinged room. Lovely atmosphere.

Surprising little find. Behind the bustling Oxford street, if you search hard enough you'll find a little place. A very hidden treasure that is not too crowded and allows you enjoy the atmosphere and decor of all the beautiful and intricate rooms. A very relaxing and quiet place to take a break from the city despite being in the city.

LONDON'S BEST KEPT SECRET. I have been to Wallace Collection many times being a Londoner but every time it never ceased to impress. The collection is simply exquisite. From the Canaletto paintings to the Boulle furnitures, Laughing Cavalier to Bronzes, amours to Van dyke, just simply stunning!The courtyard cafe is just delightful. This is simply my favourite museum in London and it's so underrated.A must visit when in London - Entry is free!

unforgettable. What a splendid collection. Couldn't stop walking around and enjoy the fine art. Will go back there a few times;The food in the restaurant is super; We had one of the better lunches in London.Another Must Go To

If you like art, you'll find something here. At first glance I thought I'd made the wrong choice to come here - lots of 18th century French paintings crammed into a room - but the more I explored the more I came to enjoy the Wallace. There's plenty of European painting up until the late 19th century, lots of furniture, ceramics, armour and weaponry, laid out in a house that's a bit like a British version of the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston. The cafe is is a lovely covered atrium and combined appealing food (endive & Roquefort salad - delicious; carrot cake - decadent) with good service. I'd suggest that the Wallace is ideal for an art-lover who's on their second or third trip to London, or who has a few hours to spare. And no crowds!

Impressive collection. I'm not a fan of any of the styles exhibited there, but indeed the place is impressive. They have massive collections of paintings, furniture, and armouries. It is useful from an educational perspective. And it's free too. Highly recommended.

The Wallace Collection. Although the decor is way too fancy and formal for my tastes, the art collection is phenominal with multiple old masters included. Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Hals (The Laughing Cavalier), Velàzquez, Poussin (A Dance to the Music of Time), Canaletto and Gainsborough. The collection also includes many French artists of the 18th and 19th centuries including works by Watteau, Boucher, Fragonard (The Swing), and Meissonier.

Just brilliant. I have visited this museum three times and will doubtless go again. It is full of treasures and the guided tours of the highlights are fantastic (and free but please do leave a donation).

Wonderful Art collection in a beautiful IXX century house.. I have been to the Wallace collection about four times. I always enjoy visiting it. It has a very good collection of art works, plus ceramic, Armours and antic furniture displayed in a beautiful IXX century house. I especially enjoyed seeing the painting of "The Laughing Cavalier", by Franz Hall, the masculine equivalent of The Mona Lisa and “The Swing”, by Fragonard.
Stunning collection!!. Stunning hidden gem just near Oxford Street. Had the whole place to my self the day I visited. Felt like a king in his palace. Go - its amazing!!

Favourite museum in London!. The museum is small, some would say human sized, but the content is so exceptional you could spend days there. The collection of paintings is one of the best in Europe and ranges from old masters to 19th century academie, but the highlight (comparatively) is the collection of arms and armours which is one of the best known in the world!

One of my favourite places in London. The Wallace Collection is a small gem of a museum art collection The galleries have been recently refurbished and art re-hung. The interiors complement some fabulous art and objects. The cafe/restaurant is a formal sit down venue which we booked to celebrate a family birthday with afternoon tea and champagne.

A must for those interested in 18th century French Painters. Had some spare time and decided to spend it at the Wallace Collection. Turned out to be a good choice, especially if your are interested in French painters of the 18th century. But they have also some very nice works by Flemish and Dutch artists, such as Van Dyck, Jordaens, Rembrandt,... And it is free...
A hidden gem.... Beautiful setting with beautiful art work. A lovely tranquil place a stones throw from hectic west end shopping area.

A great surprise with an amazing painting collection. I never visited before because I thought that they didn't have major art pieces. It was clearly a mistake. The house is lovely, with great collections. They have quite a few paintings from Greuze, Boucher and Vernet. Seeing them in this house ut them in perspective and create a very nice atmosphere. Not to be missed in London !
Gorgeous museum restaurant. Beautiful surroundings; food imaginative and beautifully presented. Very unexpected to find and absolutely worth visiting at any opportunity.

You must visit this. This is an absolute must on a visit to London. I cannot believe that they don't charge for entry, considering the masterpieces they have, the most well known being the 'Laughing Cavalier'. I was very happy to put a ten pound note in a gift aid envelope which will allow the Collection to claim back another £2.50 from HMRC. Pity they can't reclaim tax from foreign visitors.My main interest was in the paintings which range from the 16th to 19th centuries, but the place is full of sculptures, bronzes and ceramics too, as well as having an extensive range of armour. It is not too big to be overwhelming and, when we visited, it was not crowded (a Monday in the school holidays). My wife found the place and twisted my arm to go - how glad I am that I made the effort. Best gallery I've ever visited.
Beautiful place. Truly beautiful place, you find so many amazing artworks and beautiful rooms here, which is unexpected.

A hidden gem in the centre of London. The place I had wanted to visit in London was packed as it was the school hols and so I had found this in my 'Hidden London' book. Well what a joy of a place. Hidden behind Oxford Street it is in a little passed route and so is relatively quiet. Crammed with not only fabulous pieces of art but armour and all sorts of other stuff as well. Unlike the more well known galleries and museums it was warm and welcoming and it really felt like you were going into someone's home. We originally planned to pop in for a brief visit but ended up staying for hours. The painting ,'The Laughing Cavalier' is here. In the holidays there are activities organised for families with children. There is a splendid restaurant and cafe which has been created by putting a roof between two buildings which makes you feel as if you are in an orangery or glass house and is gorgeous. All of this for free - fabulous - aren't we lucky to have this available to us.
Excellent tour guide. Excellent tour guide who taught us enough to help us understand art a bit better in all of the museums. Beautiful collection in a relaxed atmosphere
A bit of French culture. Very beautiful but an audio guide would have been useful to really understand and appreciate the beauty and meaning of the objects and paintings on display

No other Art Gallery in The UK can beat it.. This is my all time favorite art gallery and the best thing is that it is free. The pictures and the artifacts are just amazing. If you ever come to London please make sure you visit it.
Lovely museum. A fantastic little gem of a museum that is just off the beaten path enough to be undiscovered. Would highly recommend spending an hour or two here!

Incredible place to visit. Once a true living house the Wallace collection is now open to the public which is so fortunate to see such an incredible collection of paintings, furniture and armoury from 16th to 19th cen. from France, Italy, India or the Otoman empire. It was a pleasure to visit.

Somewhere I visited a while ago that has not changed. Love the Wallace Collection. The portrait of the Laughing Cavalier by Franz Hals is there and a lot smaller than you think. The eyes of the portrait do seem to follow you as you walk past it. Facinating.

The best gallery in London. Fantastic! This opulent gallery is one of the best art galleries in London. It houses a large collection of 18th century paintings. It's a very different experience to visiting other major London art galleries as it calm, peaceful and opulently decorated. The cafe (Peyton and Byrne) is great.

Go there! One of the Greatest Art Collections in Europe. And it's FREE!. Superb. One of the great free art collections in London. I will never tire of visiting this place (It was my third time!). There is so much to see: *tons* of wonderful paintings, lot and lots of historic weapons and armor, coins, chinaware, sculptures, precious furniture. Every time you visit you will find new objects that you missed before. And it costs nothing (donation recommended!).Conveniently located in Marylebone (a short walk from Baker Street tube station: Don't visit Madame Toussaud's - visit THIS place! - *and* the Royal Academy of Music Museum!), and open from 10 a.m. every day. There are audio guides and guided tours, too, and a shop that includes several publications exclusively focusing on the different aspects of The Wallace Collection. Staff are friendly and helpful.The "courtyard" café/restaurant is very nice, too. There are several temporary exhibits (don't miss the -1 floor!) and special events, so check their calendar!Just have a look at my photos. Did I mention it's free?

Fantastic classical art collection. This is an overwhelming collection of classical fine art, sculpture, and furniture in a glorious building. You could spend days here and not feel that you have seen it all. I felt immersed in beauty, and found some quiet sitting areas to rest and absorb it all. I've been there three times, and will go back again on my next trip to London. They have a beautiful covered courtyard cafe, and the menu looks great, but I have not had a chance to eat there.
Awesome. Love this place, defo worth a breif visit when nearby oxford st. Especially the indo related weaponary and othr great historical items.
A lovely 3 hours. A surprising combination of fine art and armour gives appeal to different people. The guide book is a must.

Average. Although the rooms are beautiful, I found the exhibitions rather dull. I just don't think this place was good for me personally, there was little information and lots of things in all the rooms that you didnt know where to focus

Really interesting museum. This is a brilliant museum. It was a home until 1900 and pictures on the door of each room show how the family lived (rooms are still very similar) great art, armoury collection and miniatures collection
Good for French Art Lovers. Impressive building but not my favourite type of art as it is very ornate and over the top. However, definitely worth a visit.

So many treasures in one place. A lesser known museum with many delights and a particularly excellent collection of portrait miniatures. Lovely cafe and restaurant in the covered Courtyard for lunch. Laughing cavalier (through duplicitiously named) one of the highlights. A good place to come for a couple of hours, free guided tours a couple of times a day.

Fascinating, quirky, awesome. The Wallace Collection gets overlooked as one of the major tourism destinations for London - there is so much to see and do. But it is worth a special visit because of the quality of the exhibits and the ambiance of the place and amazing rooms. It is not too large, so can be visited in a couple of hours, including time for refreshment in the excellent cafe. It is not far from Oxford Circus, so is slightly away from some of those tourist sites - but better for it, probably.
Colorful museum!. I love the collections and the colors of wallpapers. It is not that big, so you can finish all in a day.

Great place to spend a Sunday afternoon. This is a fabulous find in London. The Wallace collection is superb and had afternoon tea there afterwards. It is a place that you can relax and wile away the hours. The afternoon tea was served in a beautiful court yard.

Excellent destination. Fantastic collection in a beautiful venue with free entry and such a great location this is a must see. The cafe is lovely with excellent service and great quality food. Well worth a visit.
Incredible ceramics. Amazing collection of paintings and ceramics. Don't miss the beautiful interior design. An oasis of quiet and elegance in the middle of london

Lovely oasis near busy Oxford Street. A lovely little gallery just of busy Oxford Street in the heart of London. Often overlooked, fans of Van Dyck, Rubens, Rembrandt, Delacroix or Titian should definitely visit. A pleasant place to while away a lunch hour if you work in the area.
hidden gem. tucked away but worth a visit. Good afternoon tea to be had as well. Look for the Laughing Cavalier and the armour
Arts and design. Several rooms with diverse histrorical and artistic artefacts to be seen within around two hour visit.
Musuem and cafe. Its a hidden gem in the heart of Marylebone area. The café is ideal for brunch or for couples still dating.

Wallace Collection. A very ornate and opulent building in a leafy part of town, with so much art to see, and free too. I didn't know what to expect as it was an on the spur visit, and was surprised to see some more famous paintings in there, like the Laughing Cavalier and The Swing, some Reynolds, Reubens and Valezquez too amongst a huge collection of other paintings, weaponry, artifacts and furniture, including Marie Antoinette's writing desk. None of the items are contemporary. The cafe was very calm and serene in a huge glass ceilinged area with a few trees, set in a quad in the centre of the building. We didn't have time to see everything as there was so much, but will go again to see what we missed and enjoy more tea and cake.

Outstanding. I feel ashamed that it has taken me so many years to pay my first visit to the Wallace Collection. A truly magnificent experience, starting with the location in Manchester Square, the house itself, the atmosphere as you enter. A great collection of paintings, many of which I have seen before in reproduction, and several wonderful pieces that were new to me. Incredible collection of Sevres porcelain, much of it previously owned by Louis XV, and fabulously over-the-top furniture. There is also a collection of arms and armour, which we did not have time to see, so we shall visit again soon. An unforgettable experience (and it is free! Amazing!).
Delicious lunch. Fabulous room, feel it was a little staid but we had a super lunch and would definitely return when next in the West End
What a History!. A really interesting collection of pictures in a beautiful building, with a tour that puts them all into the context of British and family history. Excellent restaurant .

Wonderful collection of art treasures in Marylebone, London.. We have travelled to London many many many times and did not know of this. Stumbled across it by chance whilst "googling"!If anyone is reading this, do yourself a favor, jump in a cab or public transport and wander through the many rooms of this beautiful home and absorb the amazing collection of artworks and ceramics and sculptures.There is also a cafe in the central courtyard, which we heard afterwards was worth trying.
Great place. Very nice and interesting place to visit, can be done in a whole day, which includes the armoury room. Nice classy area to have lunch or afternoon tea for a break.

Little gem. I have been to London many times,so had been to most galleries and museums,so sought out the Wallace collection which turned out to be a little gem. The beautiful building houses an unusual collection ranging from Ceramics from the French court to medieval armoury. I got the audio guide but thought it was quite useless. They tried to sell me a guidebook instead and seemed quite crestfallen when I declined! The art work was really quite interesting and well worth checking out. The armoury section is surely where Game of Thrones got their inspiration! Though why have one helmet when you can have 50 of the same one. Less is more? We had lunch in the Cafe which was nice, I treated myself to a chocolate dessert, which was to die for!
Visiting an old friend. This was a revisit for me and the collection is an absolute joy with something for everybody.The eatery in the central courtyard adds an extra dimension to any visit.

beautiful collection. A gem hidden in a leafy square just a block or two from Self ridges on Oxford St. A great collection of paintings from the rococo era and the museum is like a house from another period long ago like Louis 14th. A must for art lovers and history buffs or just a visit to enjoy a beautiful house in leafy london.

A quirky, interesting and free collection well worth a visit.. We went on the suggestion of a friend, never having previously heard of this collection. What an amazing collection - and it's free! There are three main themes- paintings, ceramics and weapons. The painting collection is large and eclectic with several big "names". The ceramics are mostly majolica and include some rare and early patterns. The weapon collection is quite extraordinary and you are forced to question whether some of the firearms were ever intended to be fired! There are some very special art pieces amongst the firearms and armour section and the quality of manufacture is of the highest quality. This collection of firearms would rival the Met or the Musee de Chasse in Paris. If fancy ancient guns are your thing, you will enjoy this collection. The building is wonderful and there is an attractive central covered courtyard which houses a cafe ( not sampled by me).
hidden gem. hidden gem tucked away in a london square.Full of great artifacts both medieval military and others. Well worth a vist and its free. Great place.
A hidden Gem. I knew noting of the Wallace Collection until taken by some friends. It is a charming museum/art gallery, spacious and well laid out.Well worth a visit while in and around Fitzrovia

Good visit for those who might find the larger galleries overwhelming. Very interesting and eclectic collection. The house is beautiful too. We had afternoon tea in the courtyard café - Tea was good - not fabulous but it was wonderful to have it in the beautiful surroundings.

Nice Building and cafe with unusual art collection. A beautiful building with an unusual art collection. The cafe in the inner courtyard is also a nice place to meet. After visiting the Wallace collection, wander up Marylebone High Street with its nice shops, cafes and restaurants.

A Must See in London. A collection of the finest objects in a widely varied selection of categories sited in one of the most beautiful historic homes in London. Thought smaller, the collection honestly rivals the Queen's at Buckingham Palace. For someone on a short trip without much time to sightsee this is a good choice.

A little gem. Tucked away on Manchester Square, this is a treasure trove of a museum. There is something for everyone here. Well laid out and plenty of helpful staff to advise. I think the cafe / restaurant is a bit pricey so, although the courtyard is very attractive, if you are on a bit of a budget, I'd try one of the many eating / drinking places around Baker Street or Marylebone High Street.

A hidden gem. We only found this collection thanks to Trip Advisor. What a gem. Quite a stunning collection and it is the largest armoury collection in London. The art galleries on the upper floor are fabulous too, especially the Great Gallery which contains the Laughing Cavalier amongth other magnificent items. We would strongly recommend taking one of the free guided tours. It covers the highlights of the collection, but thanks to our guide Victoria, we learned so much about the history of the family and the collection. Tour takes about 90 minutes but we spent almost 3 hours inside.

tea or gold?. The Wallace Collection is fabulous, but the tea room is appalling. Not enough staff, sloppy service and £2.80 for a cup of tea. The heavy metal teapots are a ridiculous idea and the tables are too small and crowded together.
The wonderful relaxing cafe. A peaceful retreat with a lovely glass atrium cafe. The Laughing Cavalier in the free art galley was memorable

One of the jewel's in London's crown. Hertford House is stunning, having been progressively updated room by room over the years to improve the lighting and the sumptuous period decorations. The art collection is contains is equally superb, well worth a dozen visits. To top it all, there are fascinating guided tours and talks by experts that are both highly entertaining and truly informative. There is also a lecture theatre with a programme of lectures, and the restaurant in the glassed-over central courtyard is a delightful venue. I have visited many times since 1998, and still love it to bits. It is also almost always beautifully quiet and peaceful.

Super collection .. Unmotivated restaurant . Fabulous collection really recommendedStaff lookBusy but avoid your eye... Quite an art but very wearing 12% service charge included ... Discretionary so we had it removed We were astounded they had run out of Earl Grey tea ... And the waiter said not the first time In London! Sounds a waitrose comment but. Being ignored and no tea .... Ridiculous !!!

Unbelievable riches. Unbelivable riches in so small a space.Furniture ,paintings ,arms and armour, porcelain, clocks,majolica, ivories and fakes.Good displays showing how some of the items were made.Excellent choc. cake in the grand tea room.

A must see in london. We went on a crispy winter grey morning and the exhibition and the building made up our day. The collection is very extensive and rich and we had the pleasure to go in a guide tour by a very knowledgeable lady that explain the history of the collection. A must-see London museum and a jewel hidden away from the crowds. We had been recommended the tea at the Wallace Collection but we didn't really like the menu, maybe because it was lunch time, we will try again for the afternoon tea.
Stunning chaotic wonderful. Read the reviews. This place is special for all who are interested in...well, everything really. Loved it!

Highly recommended. This is a brilliant space to pass a few hours, with some amazing exhibits and a great cafe, right in the heart of London but reasonably free of crowds. Fine art including Rembrandt, Canaletto, Rubens, Van Dyck, Gainsborough, Landseer and Turner, and the genius Laughing Cavalier by Hals. Anyone interested in the post-medieval world of art should visit this collection.
I love it. An absolute jewel hidden away and worth seeking out. A place of quiet and beauty - and it's free. Stunning pictures and furniture and extraordinary display. Brilliant.

Gem in central London. This important collection of the best and rare antiqeues and paintings must see everybody with interest in history and art. On one place you will see rarest treassures in very intimacy and friendly place with very professional staff.Great recommendation!

Lovely town house in central London. Very interesting museum and it's free! Restauarant expensive.Short walk to Marble Arch, Hyde Park and Marylebone High Street which a great place to browse and there are plenty of varied eating places

Jewel in the heart of London. Beautiful period house in Manchester Square just away from the hurly burly of Oxford Street. Superbly decorated rooms with antique furniture and truly fabulous collection of paintings by well known artists. A joy. The former courtyard is now an atrium with a restaurant. I have lunched there, the food is nothing special and quite pricey but you can enjoy tea in a very attractive setting. It has a good shop if you want to buy a little gift as a souvenir.

Must see. Many Londoners that I have spoken to have never visited the Wallace Collection - I would always highly recommend it. Tucked away behind Oxford Street in a lovely house it is a fascinating, eclectic collection. Also very good restaurant on site.

A unique dinner destination. A unique dining experience in London. Not much vegetarian choice, but what they do have is very good. Perfect for a romantic night out at an unusual venue. It feels really exciting to go into the Wallace Collection at night, when it's usually closed. (Also good for afternoon tea during gallery opening times.)

Interesting, eclectic - and do-able!. From Frans Hals' 'Laughing Cavalier', to incredibly complex clocks to delicate miniatures in oils, the Wallace Collection provides something to interest every visitor. But, because the collections reflect the shared interests and tastes of a father and son, rather than of a national body, it seems very personal and is certainly very accessible. If you enjoy your visit and are visiting Scotland, visit the Burrell Collection in Glasgow. Another very personal but wider-ranging, larger collection, assembled mostly over the following century. For either, allow not less than half a day, and if you can allow these collections a whole day in whichever city you are; you wont regret it!
Great easy to manage museum. This mansion museum is a great place to spend an hour or two. it's a manageable size and not too crowded. The rooms a little dark but well worth it.
A discreet and delicious gem.. Wonderful collection, beautifully presented. A feast for the eyes- and the stomach if you're lucky enough to combine with lunch in the orangery.

Experience of utmost beauty tainted by less than perfect service. The most amazing collection of Boulle furniture, Sevres porcelain, top quality paintings... a true joy and jewel but that restaurant.... Impolite and poorly organised staff. Guests started behaving rudely because of the long wait, even when seated. Similar experience with the guide having such a heavy Italian accent we switched off listening to her after a while. Obviously there is a lot of work to be done among the staff who really need to up it in order not to taint the beauty and riches that surround them. It is too exquisite a place to have such poorly trained staff.
A fabulous find!. WE had a wonderful time visiting this museum. There is a lot for the children and the painting are gorgeous!

An oasis for the eyes and palate in Central London. An oasis in Central London, particularly if you go at lunchtime and can indulge also in the Wallace Restaurant, the French brasserie set in the Wallace's atrium. The collection is a surprising treasure trove of 18th century French paintings, furniture, armor, etc. There are also regular events and activities related to the collection and its themes.
If in the area. Nice Rembrandt, impressive collection. Nice building in a charming area. Worth visiting from time to time.

Hidden gem and a perfect detour from shopping. So, you've been shopping in Selfridges and are thinking of walking up to Marylebone High Street for the little shops there?The perfect excuse for cultural detour (probably less than 50m out of your way depending on the exit you leave the department store from!). The Wallace Collection is an incredibly rich and visually 'dense' experience. Fascinating variety that while not everyone's taste lends itself to a great distraction from the retail therapy.

Lovely spot to take mum for a slice of history and afternoon tea. Stumbled across this place whilst looking for places to take my my mum for afternoon tea.Great location just off Oxford street - very peaceful building to wander around for an hour or so, and then there is a lovely conservatory in the centre of the building that serves lunch and afternoon tea. This does however get busy so i‘d reccomend booking in advance.The collection could potentially appeal to families - there is an area at the bottom of the building where you can try on armour - but i wouldn‘t really recommend this as an attraction for young children

Beautiful Collection. This is a beautiful collection, and the visit is not overwhelming. We spent about 1-2 hours here, and even had some time to enjoy some tea/cake. Lovely to see if you're in the area!

Superb collection, we'll run. The Wallace uses to be the best kept secret of London attractions, but now is very busy most days and rightly so. The wonderful collection is housed umongst a sublime and detailed restoration of the rich, vibrant decor (a fortune has been spent on this and it has been worth every pound, euro, dollar, Rubel and more of donations to do so).The art on offer is sufficiently varied to keep on interested for several hours on first visit, and many more on return visits when passing... The shop, restaurant and general facilities are also great.

Definitely worth a visit. Amazing collection inside.. What an amazing place. I have been parking just outside this place for as long as I can remember and never knew that this treasure of a place was until a friend of mine mentioned it. It's not your typical tourist spot and not overcrowded. But the artwork and collection inside is outstanding. I love it. Its definitely worth a visit. I went there with my friend and we both said how much we liked it. There's also an amazing cafeteria inside which is great to relax in if you are in the area for a spot of shopping as it's only 5 minutes walk behind Selfridges and Oxford Street.
What a great surprise! . This was a great surprise and is a fine museum. Some of the art was extraordinary and the armour was magnificent. Well worth a visit.....but......don't tell everybody!!
For lovers of ceramics, porcelins and beautiful decor. Probably the best collection of its kind in London. No of great general interest especially to most males but the ladies love it.

Great art, wonderful cultural evening. In the superb location of its Central London Villa, this hidden gem brings the visitor in contact with some of big names of the Western art canon. It feels sometime like breathing the air of Kubrick's Barry Lindon, very great place indeed!The coffee is superb, and a full roaster of cultural events (seminars, talks etc) are for free most of the time.Peaceful, inspiring, food for thought

A hidden gem off busy Oxford Street. This is one of my favourite places in London. It has a terrific collection of French painting and a good range of Old Masters! In addition to all this the restaurant and cafe offer good food at fairly good prices. It does seem incredible that one man could own such a wonderful collection of paintings, armour, furniture and exquisite snuff boxes.This museum also offers all kinds of events and courses and lectures. The lectures and practical art classes are reasonably priced and taught by experts with enthusiasm and knowledge.There are lifts for the disabled and knowledgeable warders in each room. The only downside to this wonderful place is the shop which needs improvement in my opinion.It is a magical place.

Wide variety of quality exhibits and lovely atmosphere.. We actually went here just to visit the restaurant but were seduced by a quick look round into coming back the next day when we had time for a more comprehensive visit. Although there are 25 galleries full of exquisite exhibits, it felt quite 'homely'. There is a wide variety of items including furniture, china, armour and paintings, including my favourites, the miniatures. It amazes me that a collection of such quality is available to be seen free of charge and I hope they get enough voluntary contributions to keep it viable.
Delightful museum, furniture, paintings etc... Interesting arms rooms, furniture & paintings. This is a charming museum just a hop from Marylebone High Street & Bond St. tube. Well worth visit.

Peaceful setting for serious art. We wandered in with an hour to kill in Marylebone and were delighted to find a spectacular collection of art and armor. After fighting the crowds at the V & A, the fact that only a couple of dozen other visitors were in evidence was an absolute treat. You can absolutely stand and admire a Rembrandt with no one to elbow you aside. The rooms are stunning, and the armor collection was amazing. I didn't even know I was interested in armor, but up close it's hard not to be riveted by the gloriously decorated swords and suits. My personal favorite was a tiny pistol no bigger than a pack of gum. Highly recommend.

Hidden Gem. Well worth finding this fantastic place with excellent facilities to view art such as the Laughing Cavalier "close up". Many many interesting exhibits to look at, well laid out.Excellent covered courtyard cafe serving delicious snacks and coffee.

Charming collection and a lovely location. This is an excellent museum and an oasis of peace just off hectic Oxford Street. The collection of French paintings, china, objets d'art is extensive and no matter how many times one visits, there is something new to discover. In addition, the restaurant is very good and it is a lovely place for an afternoon tea, too.

Free entry with A-class exhibitions. The Wallace Collection is home to some of the best pieces of weaponry I have ever seen... and your kids will love it! All the way from sneaky knives, to huge suits of armour and big axes. Not only do you get to see them, there are clothes and armour available to try on as well! Aside the awesome armoire, there are some good works of art that are unique and quite interesting; There are some brilliant sets of kitchenware and furniture. In fact, there are so many different collections, I would recommend visiting more than once just to fit it all in!

Good for killing time in Fitzrovia.. The Wallace collection is easy to find from Bond Street station. Although the collection was a little less exciting than many other collections I've seen in London, I did enjoy going from room to room, as they were all decorated differently. It's a good visit if you have some spare time and you're in the area. Otherwise I would focus on other sights first.

A hidden jewel of central London - get close to art like you wouldn't believe possible.. Just an amazing hidden jewel in the heart of London and it is free. Amazing restaurant. Well worth the money.Visited well over a year ago

Hidden Gem, worth a visit. The Wallace collection is a beautiful personal collection of art, artefacts and furniture. The building itself is also architecturally very interesting. Location is central yet feels like it is slightly off the beaten track. This is a truly beautiful house definitely worth visiting for a couple of hours. There are also guided tours throughout the day which we took and this certainly helped our understanding of the house. Our guide was a real character and also very knowledgeable.

Absolutely Amazing Collection....and Free!!. This is a truly amazing and diverse collection of art and collectables that captivated both my wife and myself. We spent 2 hours looking at the exhibits but could easily have spent 2 more.

Great Collection. A great collection with some beautiful items, helpful staff. It would be even better if it was open a bit later in the evenings! I didn't get chance to see the armoury, so will just have to go back!

'hidden' treasure not far from the most pulsating streets of London. For those, who love to see the 'old' masterpieces in a more intimate surounding than the National Gallery I can highly recommend the Wallace gallery. I very much enjoyed the guided tour through the collection and also bought the guide book, which contained explanations and descriptions of the place. Although, i had visited London several times, I have to admit that i was ignorant about the Wallace collection, though it is located not far away from the most pulsating streets of London. Not far from the Bond street station, you will find a quiet oasis, charming rooms and friendly staff to share their knowledge free of charge with you. Moreover, in each room you will find information sheets to guide you. Also well done is the composition of art master pieces (paintings, furniture, porcelain etc.) according to the era the stem from. Moreover, comfortable seating arrangements allow you to rest in the middle of the room to enjoy the athmosphere and masterpieces. I did not have time for the armourment exhibition, so i cannot comment on that part of the exhibition.
Fascinating place with a good restaurant. A very interesting museum with an excellent restaurant in the courtyard. We went on a guided tour of a particular exhibition and it was great.

Highlight of my two days. The Wallace Collection is stunning, made even better by the fact that it is often quite quiet because of the fact it is hidden away. It was recommended to me by a friend and I am so happy that she mentioned it to me; it was the highlight of my two day trip!!! The collection is so varied; from paintings, including works of Joshua Reynold, furniture and one of the largest collections of armour I have ever seen. You could easily spend one hour to a whole day in there, just exploring every room in detail. Truly beautiful, I would be quite happy to go back tomorrow and see it all again; especially since it is free entry.

"The most splendid private art collection in the world". The most charming and well selected private art collection in the world. It’s incredible to think the French didn’t managed to secure this gem for Paris, long story but worth reading up on! The splendour of the Fragonard and Boucher paintings in stunning room settings - so many!! not leaving out the Gainsborough and on it goes. The furniture and armoury collections unique.

Hidden Gem, worth the short walk.. This is a hidden gem, a short walk from Marlyebone High St and the northern parts of the West End or a southerly walk from Baker St Station. I hadn't been for a few years and was really impressed at the recent refurbishment of the rooms. Wow! I want to do my home up in some of those wallpapers! But it's the collection you're here to see and given the wide breadth of artworks here you'd find something to appeal to most people. The Laughing Cavalier is the star attraction for me, so make sure you make it to the long room at the back upstairs to see it.The courtyard restaurant looks as good as the last time I ate there, but that was several years ago. Didn't have the time to do it this visit but would look at doing it again.
Great art collection. A wonderful surprise when I friend took me to Hertford House. An impressive collection of art that rivals any top-notch art museum. The house alone is worth the visit.
Worth a Visit. Not to be missed! Lovely courtyard for lunch or tea or a beverage. Every room was beautiful. Lovely collection.
A lovely place to visit. An interesting place to visit and escape the pace of the city. Interesting things to see and a very pleasant café to sit and relax, well worth a visit/
good place. lots of good collection and nice to take kids there and show them. very busy place and cafe was very nice and cean. thank you

Beautiful house and collection, a hidden gem. A beautiful house, which transports you back a few centuries to French-style grandeur. Remarkably, all for free. You can easily spend a couple of hours here with lots of photo opportunities. However, flash photography is not allowed and you will be told off if you use it.
Brilliant collection. Interesting collection ... nice artifacts - armour - for the children to play with ... nice cafe / setting for a nice cup of afternoon tea ...

Visit the Laughin Cavalier at home. A little gem hidden behind posh shopping area Marylebone High St, the collection is housed in a stunning historic building, the home of its former owners, the Marquesses of Hertford and Richard Wallace, whose widow gave the collection to the nation. It's a European art collection and is particularly strong on eighteenth-century art of France, Italy and England. There's also some arms and armour, including an amusing Indian dagger with a smiling tiger's head! It's home to some lovely seventeenth-century Dutch paintings, including Van Dyck, Rubens and Rembrandt's intimate portrait of his son Titus at age 16. I use the collection for costume research, as the details on portraits such as Franz Hals' 'Laughing Cavalier' are excellent. There's a charming café at the back of the house with a good set menu at lunch, tasty cakes and a variety of refreshments. Truly a hidden London gem.
A pearl in the center of London. Always nice to come back and enjoy this marvelous peacefull place with the richness of its collections. Very much recommended.

Wonderful find. Just a short walk from the bustle of Oxford Street, this place is full of wonderful works of art. Whilst I have never used one of their kids days, I know they often have workshops for younger patrons. Well worth a visit - they also have a lovely atrium for lunch and afternoon tea.

Rapiers ! (years before 2014). Brilliant. If like me you're into Renaissance Rapiers this place is heaven. Gold mine.
It probably specialises in other things than rapiers - but I wouldn't know about that !
A good day can be spent here. Really nice place to visit. Just behind Oxford street. So shopping and culture can be mixed. Good place for boys.

Do not miss this London gem. Do not miss this London gem. I always recommend my friends to take tourists here as it is probably one of the best undiscovered tourist attraction right in the centre of London. The house is amazing and the items on display are all very impressive. All for free.

Wonderful art, porcelain and furniture. What makes the Wallace Collection really special is the fact that it is not just an art gallery, but also a collection of porcelain and fine furniture all together within a splendid London house. The whole really is greater than the sum of its parts. i am not a great fan of Rococo but in this setting the paintings by Boucher and Fragonard create a wonderful effect. But it is not just Rococo, there are paintings by Gainsborough, Reynolds, Velazquez, Canaletto and Hals to name but a few, as well as some impressive Sevres and amazing furniture. There is printed information in each room and you can also hire an audio guide.The cafe / restaurant is very pleasant with a glass roof almost creating the impression that you are eating outside. However, was not so impressed with the goats cheese salad which contained a few meagre crumbs of cheese although it was eventually replenished when I took it back.
Well worht it!. Very interesting building and collection. I would recommend joining a tour (free) as there is a real story behind the place.

Wallace Collection. This is a wonderful large London house where a large collection was made of hundreds of years of art. The wife of the last owner gave the house and the collection to the nation and now it is an amazing museum and art gallery. Like most others in London it is also free to enter. Among other things it has a large collection of 18th Century French art and furniture along with an impressive collection of arms and amour.

Something for everyone. Popped in for a short visit and could have stayed longer. Ideal place to stop if you want to get away from the Hurley burley of Oxford Street and you learn something at the same time. If you only look at one thing see The Laughing Cavalier it is magnificent.

Small is beautiful.. My favourite small (so easy to get round) London museum in a central area. Contains a wide variety objects from pictures to porcelain and from armour to furniture all in small rooms of a London town house.

Great experience. This is a small, interesting and free gallery in central London. It was not crowded as are some of the bigger well known attractions. We had an enjoyable afternoon here and would say it is well worth a visit. Didn't make it to the cafe as we had just eaten but walked through and it looked inviting. Would go again if in London.
Interesting. Went for a brief walkthrough after lunch on a Friday, a very interesting and somewhat eclectic collection of period art.

visit cafe, that was enough for me. whenever i visit museum, something remains in my mind. but i do not remember what were displayed. only impressive thing is the cafe in the buliding. worth to spend time.

Little gem in the west end! . This museum is an amazing experience thru a life of an aristocrat who lived in the house and left so many art pieces that you wouldn't believe. From paintings to weapons it is a travel thru time. I really recommend! And it is for free!
A Good Day Out. Hadn't been there for many years so decided to do so. One of my daughters accompanied me and we had a good day out. Café in central courtyard good for food but expensive
Not as expected. It seemed a lot more interesting on the outside. Perhaps due to hype etc that expectations were lifted. A nice place to visit still.

Good Tea with sandwiches, scones and cakes!. Had afternoon tea here. Beautiful setting and gorgeous restaurant, quite a surprise set in the middle of the old building - very well done. The service could have been better and we were disappointed to be charged an extra £5 because one of our party of 10 asked for a plain sandwich (I.e. Without mustard, relish, Mayo, horseradish) they really made a big fuss about providing a cheese sandwich and it so wasn't worth it. That was a bit if a shame but if you do lie dressings then the sarnies are yummy!

A Must.... A Visit to London would not be complete without The Wallace Collection. Visit online first and time the amount of time you need.This is a serious collection an warrants nearly a day.Small but perfectly selected. Restaurant excellent too.

CEntrally located free art gallery. Beautiful and free to enter art collection bestowed to the nation by the Wallace family. Also has an armoury which youngsters would enjoy or in fact anyone interested in historical armour and weaponry.

Awe inspiring. What a place. Such marvellous paintings, beautifully laid out and so accessible to view close up. Spent over 2 1/2 hours walking and sitting (so good to have seating). Then we had a cream tea in the cafe. Tea and scones excellent. A fitting finish to a great day. Will go back as we didn't have time to finish visiting all the rooms.

ARMOURRRRRR. SOOOOOO much Armour, well set up with descriptions of everything in these awesome old books. THIS PLACE IS AWESOME. There are also some nice paintings upstairs including the famous laughing cavalier.

A gem behind Selfridges. The building just looms out of nowhere. Quite a surprise if you have to wander around the back of the Selfridge store. Wonderful, thoughtful collections - plenty of space to look around and many objects that you do not see in the average museum. The restaurant is the star though and with the glass atrium above, you can feel fresh air in what otherwise is a hectic part of London.
truly mystical. How the other half live. Classy clothes and beautiful Exhibits.Well worth a visit if you are passinG.

Stunning!. This is a gift to anyone looking for a 'collection' experience. It is free entry, although with the funding cuts to the arts I would encourage anyone who can afford it, to spare a few pounds donation to keep it free. I have been visiting for over 10 years and love taking visitors here as it is always a surprise with its eclectic selection of items.

Incomparable. Every time I go I am bowled over again by the sheer quantity of top-quality art on display in this amazing place. It's particularly strong on French painting, but there's all sorts of stuff, and an art lover could easily spend the whole day here. It's free, and never seems all that crowded; you feel as though you have stumbled on a great insider secret. I defy anyone to be disappointed by it.

Eye Candy. The Wallace Collection is not only a peek at an elegant old house, it's also an art gallery and an art museum. The free guided tour is helpful and supplies the interesting, quirky and personal stories to explain the variety of beautiful pieces in the collection.

Impressive and not to crowded. not the most obvious choice for many tourist but its definitely worth visiting. Located in Mayfair, easy to reach if you go shopping on Oxford street, Marylebone high street or new bond Street. Beautiful interiors, free guided tours and nice cafe inside where you can have afternoon tea for just £17, really good deal for London.

A wonderful Gem of a museum. A couple of minutes walk from the manic Oxford St and you happen upon this absolute gem of a museum. The Wallace collection is one of my favourite places in London. It's a tranqil and intimate gallery / museum full of wonderful paintings and artifacts. You'll find Frans Hals' painting 'The Laughing Cavalier' along with many other wonderful pieces.The Wallace is also a fabulous place for lunch or afternoon tea. The restaurant is set in the beautiful glasshouse central courtyard. A lovely place to escape and relax.
Add to the London List.... A wonderful museum which is free to enter. The building itself is worth a visit. Priceless paintings and objects d'arts are on display.

Very Interesting Private Collection. I recall my visit with pleasure. So many things to check out in such a small room. Particularly interesting the swords and daggers room. If you like weapons this is your place. Very easy to access and with a lovely courtyard if you need a break. You can also go to the restaurant without needing to visit the Collection!

A little cracker and very intimate. Visited the Wallace Collection with my partner and her brother, both of whom like their art, whereas I am something of an arts philistine! However, even for me, I found the Wallace Collection to be really interesting. Most impressive for me was the intimate nature of the collection, you can get right up to most of the furniture with only small, delicate or breakable items put behind screens. It's a definite must see for anyone who likes their armour and swords/shields/pikes as it is one of the biggest collections of these going. It is all housed in a beautiful building a 10 minute stroll from Baker St tube station or from Oxford Circus. Its also presently free to enter, however they ask you to leave bags in a free cloakroom.
Nice place to spend a day. A must see place in London for Art lovers. perfect for a cultural day out. Brilliant collection of Paintings.
What a gem!. Beautiful house, and a surprisingly large collection of great art! Tucked away on a quiet square, it is a real hidden gem. Admission is free. Highly recommended.

Small museum full of wonderful treasures.. Something for everyone... Marie Antoinette's desk and sewing table for the romantics, vast collection of armour for the boys in the family and collections of pictures, miniatures, glass, porcelain and precious snuff boxes. The house itself is beautiful and the courtyard restaurant a lovely venue.
Superb. Superb collection of artwork and the building is a piece of art in itself. Great free place to visit to see authentic French style architecture and heritage in London.

A Jewel in the heart of the city.. A gem of a place in the heart of London. Tucked away in Manchester Square, the Wallace Collection is a rare collection of paintings, furniture and porcelain to admire. It feels as if you are waking through time, through a well loved home and invited to while away the hours. A particular favourite is The Wallace Brasserie. Light and spacious, set in a conservatory, if you want to get away from the bustle of the city, lunch or afternoon Tea here is a must.
Site seeing and Lunch with family. What a beautiful collection very nicely laid out, staff is very helpful in answering questions. If you want a brochure they just ask for a donation in return
A hidden gem. Magnificent armour and art collection displayed in 19th century house close to city centre. Dining in garden restaurant to add to the occassion.

Culture and lunch. The Wallis Collection is a must for visitors to London. Only 10 mins or less from Selfridges in Manchester Square. Get headphones you will be amazed at the info on each piece, on my first visit I only had time for two rooms. Had to go upstairs for The Laughing Cavalier of course, you can get right up to the painting and wonder how Hals painted that lace ruff! The restaurant didn't disappoint either. To the left of the airy room you can have a light repast, to the right a more substantial meal, both I can heartily recommend. I had Quiche/ salad on one occasion and a meal of fish on another both were excellent,and with that delicious white wine made the whole day perfect.

Fascinating Place!. What a fabulous place! Hidden behind Oxford Street's hustle and bustle lays this amazing home-come-museum that rivals even the best of the best of museums anywhere! Such a wonderful surprise in a location where I did not know there was a museum at all! Well worth a visit, there are some true gems here!

Wallace Collection treasures .. Renaissance art , silver , cameos, porcelain and amazing antique furniture in a lovely part of London. The snuff box collection and the Sevres China is very special. Well worth a visit and guess what ? It's free !

Include on your Tourist Scedule when in London. An incredible collection in one house. Thoroughly enjoyed it. You need more than an hour here .. Allow 4 hours and you can have a lunch in the courtyard ..very pleasant.

Fantastic.. This is similar yet much grander than the Frick museum collection in New York.
Collections are awesome. Each room the history the artifacts grandly dispalyed. The collection of armour and swords and even horse armour that made these mounted ny armed knights a force to be dealt with.
An absolute must see.

Worth a visit.. Quirky collection of a 19th century collector with some splendid pieces ( including the Laughing Cavalier). Nice restaurant/ coffee shop in courtyard of the old mansion. Right in the middle of London near Marylebone Village and Oxford St.

Swing back into time. Lovely place to visit for an afternoon just enjoying paintings and walking through the marvellous rooms! The interiors are beautiful, its as if you've stepped back into a very opulent time. It was a nice glimpse of their lifestyle before. The Wallace Collection also houses the very popular "The Swing" painting which was a inspiration behind the visual aesthetics and some scenes for the Disney films, Tangled and Frozen! Also enjoyed tea at their restaurant at the centre atrium, and it was quite lovely with the hint of sunshine through the skylights that would fill the pink room!
Great visit!. This is a wonderful place to visit. The artwork and decor are amazing. Consider having tea at the restaurant. It is lovely!

A must see when visiting London!. If you like art but Historic Old Town Houses (including antique furniture) as well, you just need to go! Because they have a fine collections of eighteenth-century French paintings, porcelain, furniture and gold boxes. I loved the paintings from Boucher, Fragonard and Pater. But all the snuff boxes with minitiature painting on it were beautiful too. They also have paintings from the Dutch painters Rembrandt and Hals (The Laughing Cavalier) You can take an audio tour or a guided tour, but there are booklets with information in each room as well. It is easy to find: just go to Selfridges in Oxford Street and walk through the street on the right from Selfridges, just walk straight ahead until you see a small park, the building is on the other side of the park.

Lovely collection in excellent setting and it's free!. The Wallace Collection is one of those places we've never quite got round to in London and decided to try it when we had a spare day. The collection is set in a beautiful 18th century house and there is a wide range of different items on display. They have a particularly fine collection of Sevres, along with 18th century French furniture, and the paintings. As always with a collection of this kind, the pictures are a mixed bag - for example, there are a large number of second-division standard French painters from the early 19th century that are not well known now, but when the paintings are good, they're very good. The best are in the Great Gallery - a couple of van Dycks, Valasquez' Lady with a Fan, and The Laughing Cavalier. For those who like this kind of thing, there is also a huge collection of armour. And to this a classy shop and restaurant and free entrance and you have a serious good day out. Well worth seeking out.

A piece of peace in the centre of London. What a delight this was, started the visit off with a delicious cup of coffee in the atrium the wandered through a very varied collection , spent about 2 hours there , Would definitely recommend a visit, so easy to find .

Excellent museum slightly off the tourist trail. A really great museum in Marylebone, excellent collection of art, silverware and furniture with a very nice restaurant/cocktail bar. Incredibly well located in a charming building on Manchester Sq. Very well worth a visit.
Excellent viewing, highly recommend. what a wonderful collection, in a great location. London's secret. Excellent restaurant, Great gardens.

Eclectic collection. An eclectic collection of art work and exhibits, including works by Canaletto, Rubens, Rembrandt, Gainsborough and Sir Joshua Reynolds among others. Fascinating collection of arms and armour from Europe and the far east. Well curated, in a magnificent setting.
Unexpectedly lovely collection of paintings, furniture and artefacts. What I liked best about it was that it had a bit of everything; not just art, not just furniture. Wonderful!

A small but lovely gallery. Although it is not a big gallery, it was very well set up to display many of the previously private collections of paintings, arts and antique furnitures.
There are usually a few guided tours a day.
We took one and found it informative to learn the history of the museum and the lay out of different collections.

undiscovered gem. Near everything around Oxford Street but hidden away and completely unexpected. Wonderful building, interesting history, sensational atrium, OK restaurant, Great gallery, interesting themes. An oasis of peace and calm with the frantic world well away.

Great gallery. Beautiful collection. Its a peaceful haven out of the hussle and bussle of the city. The house is stunning and there is something for everyone. The restaurant in the court yard serves wonderful meals, snacks and coffee once you are tired from walking around the house!

An amazing collection. This wonderful collection of art is housed in a beautiful mansion overlooking Manchester Square. We were there for over two hours and couldn't begin to take it all in. The painting collection of European and Flemish masters is impressive; our favorite was the Canaletto room,which housed more Canalettos than we have ever seen in one place. Well worth a visit; it's also free.
Hidden gem. Brilliant! Very relaxing way to spend several hours in London. The cafe is also very peaceful and a lovely place to enjoy a quiet drink in the heart of London.

A little-known treasure in central London. The Wallace Collection is just off Regent Street and yet is hidden away, waiting to be discovered. The house is fbeaurifully preserved and is filled with treasures collected over a lifetime. I found the items bought during the French Revolution particularly fascinating, and the Tudor armoury. Great diversity! The welcoming staff are happy to provide information, and the atrium restaurant provides snacks and meals in comfort.

Calm, fascinating and beautifully curated.. We visited with no prior knowledge or expectations and had a wonderful morning. This is an absolutely astounding collection of art, furniture and other historical effects. The rooms are beautifully curated, with the decor perfectly supporting the artwork. The range of works on display is amazing, including some really stunning surprises. The armour section was particularly impressive.The museum is far bigger than I expected and we managed a good couple of hours without covering everything.We visited on a saturday morning during school holidays but it was quiet and peaceful the whole time, a perfect place to visit for a little escape from the noise of modern life.The staff were friendly and helpful, the gift shop contains a wonderful selection of books (and minimal tat).
An absolute Gem!. When in London this is an absolute must to do! Fantastically charming house, beautiful decoration, gorgeous art work and furniture, a couple of hours is all you need. JOYFUL!
A Delight. Just off from the hurly burly of Oxford Street this place is a delight. A very fine collection and the perfect place for a high tea. Must see...'The Laughing Cavalier' Frans Hal.

An outstanding great house museum.. The Wallace Collection is one of the most outstanding house-based museums in London. The collection is extraordinary. the house is remarkable and beautifully preserved. The family were very wealthy and had incredible taste in all manner of art.

A peaceful yet memorable experience. While visiting London, if one needs some quiet and admires art- or not- this is the place to be. Two floors in this fascinating place- from late 16th century French paintings to 15th century artefacts- The Wallace collection displays a wide range of ancient furniture, sculptures, cutlery and much more to keep one's attention throughout the tour. If one would be tired, refreshments including one of the finest English breakfast tea and pastries are served under a glass roof overlooking the fine London weather. Make sure you have a lot of time to spend though as there is a lot to see!

Amazing.....and free!. An absolute gem. Darwin, eat your hat!Even in the height of summer you can mosey around without the British Museum crowds and find all sorts of treasures, from art to archeological findings from the Victorian era of colonial Britain. Fabulous!

Fantastic, if you have 5 minutes or 5 hours. This was the first time I visited this place (found on Trip Adviser!) It is free to get in and there are many useful notes and booklets around that explain a lot of the detail. You can pay for an audio tour (not expensive) and if I had more time I would definitely have done this - I will be back!

Nice place . We found this place by coincidence...Quite an interesting place to explore luxury collections of arts ... Also there's A nice cafe within to have a tray of finger sandwiches and to experience the real English tea time
Hidden Jem off from busy Oxford Street. Definitely worth visiting this place not only for admiring all the beauty of the collection pieces but for having chit chat over a cup of tea.
WHAT a setting. Went to a private unveiling of a picture by Pure Evil for some accountants & the setting together with the location could not be bettered.

Unexpected venue. Although I had visited the Wallace Collection in its normal guise as a museum & art gallery, my most recent visit, in May, was for a concert as part of the London Festival of Baroque Music. I had not been to a concert here before and was unaware that they were willing to act as a concert venue, though found that this was something they do on an occasional basis, a handful of times a year.Listening to Baroque music, excellently performed, surrounded by furniture and pictures of the same period, added to the ambiance and feel of the event.The Wallace Collection is worth visiting for its unusual position as the expression of the varied tastes and interests of one collector, but also, if you can get tickets, for events such as this.

Fabulous Collection and Friendly Helpful Staff. A collection of the highest quality housed in a London mansion. The building is relatively compact and easy to get around in a couple of hours but it is packed with treasures. This was my first visit and I am sure to return. Entry is free, with donations appreciated.I was particularly impressed with the knowledgable and friendly hospitality of the staff.

newly redone and well worth a visit. This collection is individually chosen by the collecting family which makes reflect their taste. Since their taste is fabulous, the Wallace Collections is well worth a visit.
Take your time!. There is a lot to see here. Take your time so as not to miss anything. Each room is jam-packed with paintings, armor, sculpture, and more.
What a find.... I absolutely adore the Wallace collection. A true treasure trove of various 'findings' and never over run. Highly recommended +++

Great museum, free, and does not take a ton of time. We stayed near.the Wallace and really enjoyed the visit. Great collection with some classic painting. It did not take a long time to see it all which was an added plus.

Great piece of history and fine art. Try to latch on to the talk. Great insight into the collection and family legacy etc. there are many things on display and many grand rooms of find art and furniture. A fabulous building.
A quiet gem. A charming museum/gallery, with a fine collection of rococo paintings including Fragonard's notorious and fascinating The Swing. Not to be missed.

Hidden treasure . Was told about the museum from a friend that visited earlier this year. Definitely worth checking it out. Armory and weapon exhibits on first floor - artwork exhibits on second. Surprising cafe in center - good food. Hidden gem!

A Gem of a Collection. I liked the size of the Wallace Collection as it was a private residence and perfect in that it focuses on art of the 18th Century, particularly French art before the Revolution. Perfectly located in Manchester Square, it is accessible and recommended visit.

Unfortunately this is not a "London dining experience just waiting to be discovered ". This is such a beautiful place to eat in,what a shame the food didn`t live up to my expectations.I had the prix fix lunch menu which was very limited for £19.00The confit of duck had such a tough overcooked skin I couldn`t get my fork through It ..It.was barely warm and the one mouthful I had was so tough I couldn`t chew it.I sent it back and requested a replacement .This was marginally better,but.It arrived with no sauce and was on a bed of very small chopped vegetables and some small pieces of toasted bread.I had ordered a glass of Sauvignon blanc for £4.75.When the bill arrived I saw I had been charged £6.00.I had this rectified.This was the most disappointing lunch for which I paid £25 The service was good,but I will never return whilst the food is so poor.Oliver Peyton should certainly visit about 1.30-2pm lunchtime to see what his chef is serving.

Little gem. Great free admittance. Super airy cafe. Behind the hustle and bustle of Oxford street, a really fabulous meeting point for friends meeting in London rather than say selfridges. Relaxed lunch or just a coffee

Well worth going to.. Many beautiful paintings and many of them by well known artists. Some very lovely rooms and works of art. One of the rooms overwhelmed me with beauty and I had to return to it several times- it may I think have been the oval drawing room- I didn't take photos and find it hard to match up what is online with the overwhelming impression of light and beauty and romantic prettiness.

I treasure the paintings most especially Rembrandt's Titus. I have been there at least twice and it's a beautiful stately home with lots of history and collected pieces of art and indoor architecture. it's unique that the collection belonged to four generations of the same family
A must!. A bit of a hidden gem. A little off the dreadful tourist path so reasonably unspoilt. Has a restaurant which is acceptable.

Truly a hidden gem. This is great. I attended a reception there which means I had the chance to look at all the stuff without the crowds. It's one of the most amazing places I've visited in London, truly a hidden gem. Incredible pieces of furniture on display.
Great Place to visit for a couple of hours. Wonderful place to visit and a great place to eat in the courtyard. You will need about 2 hours to do it justice.

One Family's gift to a Nation. This museum is unique in that it consists of artifacts collected by one family over about four centuries and it is housed in the building they called home. It includes a wonderful collection of paintings that includes Titian, Renoir, Gainsborough, Cannuletto , Sir Joshua Reynolds, just to name a few. To stand in front of The Laughing Cavalier by Hals and admire the intricate brushwork in the lace of the collar and cuffs is a treat. There is something here for everyone and admission is free. Photography is also allowed. The Peyton and Byrne cafe is excellent and the galleries making up the Armory are fascinating. if we lived in London we would be visiting on a regular basis. Most of our local friends have always meant to visit (if they were aware of it at all), but all are planning a day to visit now.

A Great Art Collection. Many collections there are in London to visit and enjoy. So it is with this Collection of grand paintings and furniture from a by gone age. The parquet floors gleam with loving care and you are welcomed by an attentive curator.

Well Kept Secret. This is one of the best art collections in London & yet so few people seem to know about it. We were fortunate enough to have a friend bring it to our attention & we were so pleased she did. Tours are run throughout the day by knowledgeable guides & we opted to take one of these. We only scratched the surface of the wonderful collection which is a very good reason to return. Their Facebook page frequently showcases individual items with pictures & background information. Although we didn't visit the café it did look inviting & the gift shop was definitely worth a look. The Wallace Collection is easy to get to & absolutely free - don't miss it!!!

Good museum, worth visiting. London has several museums. They all have large collections and are free of charge. This private museum is off the beaten track, but if you have visited the main museums it is worth visiting this one. It is a large and beautiful collection.

Quite a collection!. I first visited this museum 50 years ago when I was a child living in the same street so I was very happy when I returned last year to see that it was as I remembered it all those years ago. There is a very lame collection of art including did of armor and weapons and the building is very beautiful and well preserved. Manchester Square itself is a very interesting place with it's Queen Anne houses all of which are preserved so well they look like they have just been built.Well worth a visit.A good place to escape the bustle of Oxford Street which is nearby.

Amazing Art. One of the London's best art collection and if you get there at opening there is no lines! It is an overlooked art collection. 2 Titian, 5 Rembrandt's, and don't miss the weapon rooms. Check out the details in the carved ivory gun power flasks. Also the building itself is pretty amazing.
a little oasis in marylbone. been here a few times have alovely garden on the front for picnicthe gallery itself is great place to spend a couple of hours with some amazing paintings

Blockbuster small museum. Reminds me a bit of the Frick Collection in New York - a "residence" with just awesome objects, paintings, furniture. I was not expecting to be bowled over by the wallpaper and draperies but they were just gorgeous. Two hours should be enough for a quick view of the place, but you could certainly spend many more hours. A shame it is not open late.

An Oasis in the middle of the hustle of London. A beautiful building in Manchester Square. It has a little something for everybody. Masterpieces abound, there's some great history and an interesting armaments exhibition. Overall a very pleasant way to spend a couple of hours in London.

Peachy dining. The Cafe area is excellent for a breather as you take your time around this fabulous collection. Form the Armoury to the ornate dishes, it is detailed and interesting. A great Free Museum in London!
Hidden Gem. Beautiful building and collection, although less known than the museums in South Ken. I want to go back for afternoon tea.

Dining with Fantastic Atmosphere. A real feel good factor restaurant with excellent food, excellent service and fantastic ambiance. Very highly recomended. It's good for couples as well as large groups.
Loved Fragonard Girl on a Swing.. Wonderful collection and restaurant. Didn't dislike anything easy to get to, don't try to see too much.

Dont go - I want it kept a secret. Nicely tucked behind the shopping heavens that are Selfridges and St Christophers Place on Manchester Square - this gallery has a cornucopia of delights including Canalettos, Franz Hals' the Laughing Cavalier and Fragonard's (racy in its time) Swing. Open 7 days a week for free and excellent free group tours every day. Easy walk from Bond St tube but actually its usually easy to park right on the square too (the only place in that part of Central London). Restaurant / cafe is superb too in a glazed courtyard
Hidden Gem. Free to enter the collection has some wonderful exhibits, away from the hustle and bustle. The collection has a charming cafe/tea room/bar

Hidden gem (and it's FREE!). This opulent collection of art, furniture and curios is off the beaten track, but well worth the short walk to get there.The staff who stand around keeping an eye on things are also well-versed in the objects and history, so ask them what their favourite items are (this elicited a really good response when I was there with my girlfriend).The cafe area is bright and open, but service is slow, so don't be in a hurry if you go there.Best of all, entrance is completely free.
Must Visit. Fantastic collection, great house off the beaten track behind Oxford St. a hidden gem. Great armour and paintings, take a look, good place to eat too.

meraviglioso - wonderful. una delle collezioni più straordinarie che abbia mai visitato in una splendida casa del '700 - one of the most extraordinary art collections I have ever visited in a wonderful house of the 18th century - sindrome di Stendhal assicurata - you may live Stendhal syndrome

Taking a step into history. An amazing collection that you could spend hours enjoying. All the staff were very friendly and knowledgeable. It's free to visit and is a welcome relief from the bustle of Oxford Street. Not on all the usual tourist trails but not to be missed.

Visited before this date but no earlier option offered.. Great hidden little place in the city for people who like to quietly look at fine art in peace away from the crowds. Can't recommend this place enough.

Lots of Stuff but Little of Great Hisorical Interest.
