The Wallace is an interesting collection of art, armor, ceramics, miniatures, prints, furniture, etc. Overall, it gives on a glimpse into what a rich collector could accumulate in the late 19th century. While the collection is extensive, the individual pieces are not overwhelming. Please compare to the Frick museum from a decade later.

Beautiful. we didn't even no this place existed . It's approximately 5mins walk from Selfridges . Entrance is free , but they suggested a £5 donation. We were given a floor plan which we followed ,going from room to room and wow what rooms . They were full of paintings (some famous) China , sculpture ,military and furniture. The rooms were decorated to the themes of the collections, and everything seemed so fresh and clean . I loved this place

An experience of a life time. Do not miss being here if you are in London and have the time . One of the finest collection in an historical building . A treasure trove of The priceless art is unique for all those who have love for the fine things .

Beautiful collection!. The Wallace Collection is an absolute gem in the heart of London. The building itself isn't too large and consists of two floors with various galleries that include ceramics, weapons, armor, and paintings. When you walk in, you feel as if you are stepping back into a different time. Entry is fee and donations are accepted. They also have a lovely shop and a cafe. The building is easy to navigate and there are not too many people so you do not feel rushed through the collection. We stayed for about an hour and a half.
I always see something new. Every time I visit I see something I haven't noticed before. This time it was a beautifully decorated farrier's toolkit from Persia (17th or 18th century)

Very Interesting - a gem!. This museum is tucked away in a square behind Oxford Street and has much to offer with many differing collections under one roof and a charming place to have lunch, as I recall, in the atrium.

Restaurant meal during a weekend in London. This was a spur of the moment visit as we found this when searching the Internet. We were able to book online. It was a short walk from our hotel in Marble Arch. We started with an excellent cocktail from the bar. Service was excellent as was the meal, the wine selection was also very good and our waiter chose an excellent red to go with our main course. Overall a fantastic experience and one we would recommend.

Amazing Collection!. This amazing collection is shown in the fabulous home of the collectors. It is a treat to see how these people lived surrounded with Sevres and Meissen porcelains and world class art as well as fine furniture.Some people bring picnic foods and eat sitting on benches along the front walkway. There is an attractive dining room in the enclosed atrium that serves nice food. They give an opportunity to make a contribution upon entering, but one may enter without paying. We have been to London about 45 times and we usually go to Manchester Square to visit the Wallace Collection.
A228. This is a must! Atmosphere quiet and very grand. Beautiful collection of fine pieces, sculptures, paintings and furniture. Has audio equipment available. Give yourself plenty of time!

Amazing selection of arms & armor. Heard about this smaller museum on TripAdvisor and put it on the list for our vacation in London. Truly one of the most impressive and amazing collections of arms and armor I've ever seen in one location. My son (9 years old) and I were like kids in a candy store. Each room has books on the room's contents so we were continually looking up items to get more information (a fantastic option)! In the lower level they actually have some demo armor pieces (5 or so) you can try on. Heavy stuff! While my son and I spent a loooong time looking at the collection my wife and Mother-in-Law had a lovely tea in the garden cafe. They loved it and considered their "afternoon tea" box checked for the vacation. Truly a fantastic museum!
One of the best galleries in London. It now has a good restaurant in a very pleasant setting.The main gallery up stairs is one of the finest with many excellent paintings.

Have to go!. One of the most beautiful private collection of art. Everything is so nice : paintings ,sculpture, dishes, furniture, hanging... And this is free so no excuse to not go. Not far from regents park and Oxford street.

Can't believe I haven't been before!. I can't believe I haven't been here before, this place is magnificent! The building and artwork is fantastic with some very well known pieces such as the 'Laughing Cavalier' and it's all free!!! The restaurant serves high quality food, not cheap but good and beautiful surroundings.

Worth a look. This is fabulous collection. Diverse and stunning. There is too much to see to choose what is best. The French furniture, the armour and weaponry and the snuff boxes are all amazing. Many of the paintings are superb too... You just have to visit.

Another Gem for London. This is one museum that you can do without feeling too overwhelmed, and yet still be awed at the diversity of this collection. We managed it in a couple of hours. I just love how the city has these jewels all over London. They are exceptional; leaving you wondering how one person could possibly have acquired such an exquisite and eclectic bouquet of artifacts. If you want to be hand held, there seems to be someone on staff that can show you around, and the gift shop carried a lot of information as well.

Eclectic Collection of beautiful objects. Tucked in the back of a centrally located, but quiet London Square, is this beautiful mansion with a fascinating collection of art and artifacts. This feels more like a stately home than a museum. And if you have the time enjoy enjoy a scrumptious English Tea in the enclosed courtyard.

Not to be missed by art lovers. The Wallace Collection is arguably one of the finest gatherings of ceramics, paintings, armour, weaponry, and furniture not only in London but abroad. Staff were very nice and unobtrusive, although visitors will notice them checking on rooms regularly particularly when groups are visiting. The Collection offers something for everyone, and if you have no interest in painting, for example, you will find a number of rooms devoted to the history of weapons. Tours are available, but I found it very easy to just wander solo and skip over bits of little interest to me. For art lovers, be sure not to miss the Fragonards and Watteaus, in addition to Hals' "Laughing Cavalier."
great little find. What a way to see some of these great works up close, in an intimate setting. Do plan on lunch in their tea room - it was lovely.

Art is not just in the eye of the beholder!. The Wallace Collection is an art lovers paradise where one can view a private collection in the very house where the family that collected it lived. Great Masters, renowned paintings such as "The Laughing Cavalier" and other objects adorn the rooms of the house that is now a gallery. Informative guided tours help communicate the history of the collection and the history of art and its artistic contributors. The sunny court yard to the house provides a wonderful sheltered space to eat and drink between excursions into the various displays. Guest lectures are a regular feature of the outreach program of the Wallace Collection.A not to be missed gallery when visiting London.

Art-lovers must visit here first!. It took me 2 trips to London to take up a friend's recommendation to visit the Wallace Collection. What I had missed! A well organised collection of superb paintings, displayed in a manner which gave an insight into the background and history of the development of art and (much to the point) the collection of art in the UK. Every collection has its own flavour, but this one was coordinated and personal. A very special place. The classic example of the value of seeing the real painting and not a print - who knew the Laughing Cavalier was so alive! A very real, delightful and dangerous man...
A nice break in the day. Not near other museums, so nice break from the touristy areas. Enjoyable and it won't take too long to see.

a little gem. A beautifully kept museum, full of paintings and various works of art. The building itself is stunning and the entry is free! I really recommend it if you are in central London as it is relatively near to Oxford street. There was also an impressive collection of armours and antique weapons. I am not a fan of those so I went very quickly on that part but I took my time in enjoying everything else. There is also a coffee shop/restaurant but I didn't use it so I can't say anything about the quality of coffee/food.
Very nice museum. Very nice and not too large museum just a couple of blocks from the Hyatt Regency The Churchill. And its free. Extensive collection of armor and other artwork.

Class not Mass. A fascinating small museum with outstanding collections of, among others, Sevres pottery and military weaponry and armour. Everything is well-explained through room-by-room pamphlets and the docents are helpful and willing to engage. The dining room is superb and the souvenirs of exceptional and discerning quality. Plus admission is free and it's not too likely that you'll encounter school trips - a big plus!

Worth a visit. Nice little museum, in Manchester square, lots of millitary collections, combined with a small gift shop. There is also a nice restaurant in the artrium serves all types of food , from soup to nuts!!!

Oasis behind Oxford Street. Beautiful building with fantastic paintings and other exhibits. Free to enter and a lovely cafe. The 'Laughing Cavalier' is hanging there. Very pleasant way to refresh after a hectic shopping trip.
Free and Great. This is a right gem in the heart of London, just off Oxford street. The restaurant is fabulous. The collection is great and is definitely off the wall.
Business Breakfast. Beautiful setting and great place for a meeting. Very inspiring given the surroundings and extremely helpful staff. lovely for breakfast.

A little gem. We did part of the guided tour which the young lady made very interesting, and part on our own. Lots to look at, probably best to visit several times as with many museums etc. we ate in the restaurant which was presumably once a courtyard, now with a glass roof. Fabulous food! Unusual ingredients.

Little gem. Fine and extensive collection of art.
It is amazing how many gems this relatively small museum has to offer.
What a surprise. This is an excellent Museum with some fantastic paintings. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable. It wasn't busy which was a surprise. Very relaxed atmosphere.

The grandeur WOWed me!. About fifteen mins by foot from Bond Street station. Like most museum, the admission is free. (Please donate), Splendour collection of paintings and check out the beautiful mosaic wall and flooring!
London's hidden gem!. One of my favourite places to visit in London. A beautiful home filled with treasures from around the world. A definite must-see/visit/experience.
Collection sublime; restaurant cool in the wrong way. Wonderful museum. Restaurant good in terms of food but rather haughty staff (would it have killed our waitress to smile?!)

Beautiful building beautiful collection marvellous history. Free entrance, an amazing place full of beautiful paintings, pottery, armoury, gold, silver, and furniture.
You can make a donation, or buy in the gift shop or both. Cafeteria looks good never gone in as always too busy
Gorgeous artworks - splendour!. Room after room of amazing artworks by famous artists - exquisite furniture, wallhangings and decoration. A treat - senses overwhelmed! Must visit!

Best kept secret..... Manchester Square behind the bustle of Wigmore/Oxford street is a corner of heaven and as much Fragonard one can see outside Versailles! Wonderful tea room. Basement area with children's activities such as tile painting etc...it's a little gem. Go!

A wonderful museum and best of all, free admission. Amazing collections in a beautiful building, and FREE! Incredible artwork, whole rooms full of porcelain, suits of armour and everything in between.
Also the cafe/restaurant is lovely.

London Gem. This collection should be better known, but in some ways I am glad it is not, as it remains not crowded! It has a wonderful collection, and I would single out the Sevres, in particular. The tea room, outside, is also a good place for a drink.

Free museum. Well worth a look. This free museum houses an array of armour, weapons, artwork, trinkets and porcelain in the original home of Sir Wallace. A short walk from Bond station, the grand home houses 25 galleries in each of the different rooms. All of which are a different colour and furnished beautifully throughout.
Beautiful collection. Well worth a visit if you are an art lover. There are some amazing paintings by a variety of artists as well as furniture, armour and other artefacts

Lots of armor and old paintings. The Wallace collection is housed in a lovely building but the collection didn't interest me very much. Too many suits of armor and the art wasn't especially exciting to me. I hear from friends that the tea room is a nice place to stop by lunch or tea but I didn't get the chance to do that.

This is one of the best hidden gems in London. It's one of the best gallery/museum in London and everyone should see it. There's armour, paintings, weaponry and a fabulous café in the round foyer. Heaven!
loved it. a real treat don't want to spoil it, an opportunity for personal improvement and a useful conversational point for dinner. just go

if you art person, you should go there.. It is really fantastic place.
Not only for arts and furniture, but also cafe and place of the house are really lovely.
I recommend go there with strolling outskirt.

Beautiful ornaments in a stunning building. Small but interesting, this is another of London's free museums.
Gorgeous intricate porcelain......you can see the restorers at work right in front of you and art students capturing the detail of the many artifacts. Fabulous collection of armory as well.
We had morning tea in the central cafe, which is highly recommended. Beautiful setting, good service and food.

Treat yourself to something very special. Hartford House, the home of the Wallace Collection, quietly sits in Manchester Square, a seventeenth century building on the back of Oxford Street, with large and beautifully maintained rooms which retain their original homely charm, rather than that of a museum. Among other works of art, exhibits include paintings, furniture, swords. Free Tour Highlights of the Collection every day at 2.30 pm, as well as weekend concerts, and other cultural activities. Staff are instinctively polite and helpful and there is a relaxed feeling of quiet enjoyment which makes a visit so very special. Admission is free. Open 7 days a week. There is a very good shop and a stunning restaurant for breakfast, lunch, tea, events and dinner. For me, this building represents the essence of elegant Britishness and should not be missed.

Beautiful Museum. This is definitely worth visiting. It is so beautifully arranged and wish we would of had more time. There is a charming atrium restaurant and a good gift shop with wonderful books, cards and gifts about this amazing large collection. Really enjoyed the time we spent there.

Fantastic and free!. After roaming London and seeing all the prices for entry to the Globe, the Tower, etc. the Wallace Collection was a pleasant surprise. A beautiful place with few people and even Rembrandts on display! Everyone visiting London should pay a visit here!

Great art accompanied by great F&B. What a way to spend an evening surrounded by great art whilst being served in plentiful quantities good finger food and good wine. I would recommend this venue to event organisors
Interesting collection. Really liked it both times I went. Amazing portraits, my favourite is the cuckold. Always make a point of signing the book at the exit.
Wonderful collections.. The ambience of the whole place is very good.Takes you back in time.The restaurant is very good.It is an atrium.You could have a meal or just some tea and look around you.
Fantastic free museum. A quiet mansion which houses a large collection of paintings, sculptures, fournitures, coins, ... gathered by the Wallace family over multiple generations.
Beautiful. A must. A wonderful collection and a pleasure to visit.Well positioned in the centre of town amidst a lot of hotels in the Oxford street area.
Visit Manchester Square for a wonderful few hours. I like the range of art and the building is very attractive after its recent makeover. Lots of enjoy.
Skip Madame Tussauds and come for a treat. One of those museums in London that complements its larger and more renown cousins while offering a more tranquil setting to engulf in art-appreciation.
Don't miss it!. Don't miss lunch or tea here -- serene place near busy Oxford Street. Art is sublime. The building is interesting too and the courtyard really lovely on a nice London day.

a hidden gem. A little off the beaten track but we'll worth the effort to find. You'll find everything from the laughing cavalier, to fancy armour. This was a stately home now a fantastic museum/ art gallery
Terrific small collection--beautiful art in a beautiful building. Great cafe for tea or lunch! It's small enough that you can spend a couple of hours here and enjoy it all.
hidden highligths. hidden treasures abound,wallace collection was well worth the visit so much to see and admire made our day coming here

Wonderful. Just an interest for everyone. Great place to eat any meals especially afternoon tea.
Rather smart shop. Do visit ...no entrance fee either.

Superb collection of paintings, furniture,etc. This is lovely smaller place to visit for those who have done the main London art galleries and museums.
There is free guided tour in the morning which proved to be very interesting.
There is a lovely restaurant which is covered but has lots of natural daylight and is a delightful place for lunch or tea.

Afternoon tea at the wallace. Had afternoon tea for 11 of us at the Wallace in January. A really interesting place to have afternoon tea. The afternoon tea itself was pretty average but you don't go just for the food. The actual collection and gallery space is amazing.

What's not to love?. I confess, we live a stone's throw away, but even if we didn't, a manage-able sized museum with free entry; formerly a stately home; decorated in glorious period style; containing suits of armour and interesting art; the most charming clocks scattered through the collection; and a simply delightful cafe/restaurant for anything from coffee and cake to high tea to a full multi-course meal. It's a breeze from Baker St station or Oxford Street. It's a small oasis from the crazy of Central London.

The best museum in London. I regularly take trips to the Wallace Collection, and every time I am delighted anew. Situated in the incredible Hertford House just a stone's throw from the mad bustle of Oxford Street, it's always worth a visit for respite when you find yourself in the area. The collection of art, furniture, and ornaments (not to mention the sumptuous interior detailing) is vast and fascinating. Free guided tours are always illuminating; the Peyton & Byrne restaurant is in a beautiful, airy space with a fantastic menu of cakes, teas, booze, and meals; the staff are knowledgeable and friendly; and the toilets are the only ones I genuinely enjoy using in a public space. On top of all that, entry is free, and you can even rent out several rooms for events.
Well worth a visit. Spent a day at the Wallace Collection. Absolutely great and we were very pleased that we visited it. Can recommend.

Visited at advice of cabbie. I personally loved this beautiful place. My teens, not so much. I could've spent the day wandering around but they were ready to leave before we got to the second floor. Truly an amazing collection of art, suits of armor, weapons-stunning if you like that sort of thing.

Great museum. The trip to the Wallace collection was great. The tour guides are well informed. The staff their are very welcoming and polite. The restaurant/cafe was great. I have been there twice now and each time I have learnt so much more.

Small private collections are some of the most enjoyable museum visits. I love the Frick in New York and I love this place too-for the same reason: both are small private collections shown in homes. You get to enjoy the art and the architecture and feel you know a little bit more about the collector and why these works were once prized by someone (besides our own obvious enjoyment of them historically and aesthetically). This is personal.(My friend and I personally felt that the collection reflected a love for tatas. See pics.) ;) Other reasons for going here-1. It's in a lovely neighborhood. It's enjoyable to walk around Marylebone and there are some great restaurants nearby.2. It has "the swing" by Fragonard. Fun, saucy painting you should research before coming.3. Super book/giftstore. I love art but I also like to shop and they have fun things.

A quick culture fix. Good restaurant also. A quality Museum and an amazing Restaurant/Cafe that is not cheap but do go there and look up! Exhibits in what used to be an Aristocrats large London House are varied and of the highest quality. Easy to get around and not too large. West End location - used by locals and not crowded by groups of children.

The BEST was yet to come!!!. On our recent travels "high tea" was on our list of "to do's" so after some research we booked a table in Hertford House. Tea was beautifully presented with yummy sandwiches and cakes and our group of 7 friends felt very spoilt. BUT the BEST was yet to come!!!Inside this beautiful building is The Wallace Collection the most amazing collection of art, porcelain, miniatures, furniture etc., etc that I have ever seen.We had been travelling for 3 months through Europe, UK and Ireland and visited many museums and seen fine art but nothing like this. Every room in this house will take your breath away from the incredible pieces to the way it is displayed which has been given much thought and works so well.I could go on and on but I won't because if you're reading this you need to experience this amazing place yourselves!

Not really an afternoon tea . I was looking fowards to having afternoon tea here. The collection is lovely but I walked out on the tea. I was presented with scones that were cold and rock hard. The tea was made with a bag. The sandwiches were not fresh either. The tea for two is 18 £ each and consisted of one if these not fresh not hot scones: one per person. 3 small sandwiches each and some tired looking sweet cakes on top. I told the manager I was leaving (I had not touch anything to eat. The giant hard scone looked like the same ones at the British Library, but double the price. I didn't eat those things either. Ruined my afternoon but caught a cab to F&M for proper tea.

world-famous range of fine and decorative arts. The Wallace Collection is a museum in London, with a world-famous range of fine and decorative arts from the 15th to the 19th centuries with large holdings of French 18th-century paintings, furniture, arms & armour, porcelain and Old Master paintings arranged into 25 galleries.The Wallace Collection also displays many other treasures, such as two paintings by Titian, five Rembrandts, nine Rubenses, four Van Dycks, eight Canalettos, nineteen Bouchers, masterpieces by de Hooch, nine Teniers, Frans Hals, nine Murillos, two Velázquez and paintings by Domenichino, Cima, Daddi, Reni, Rosa, Thomas Gainsborough, Joshua Reynolds, Antoine Watteau, Nicholas Lancret, Jan Steen, Aelbert Cuyp and nine Guardis. The museum also holds a fine collection of arms and armour, featuring both European and Oriental objects, as well as displays of gold boxes, miniatures, sculpture and medieval and Renaissance works of art such as maiolica, glass, bronzes and Limoges enamels.
Wallace Collection. Great gem of a place, been meaning to go for some time and a spot of bad weather prompted a visit today, will definitely return. Wonderful collection set in glorious surroundings.
very interesting. a really nice collection - the building itself is worth seeing alone and the afternoon tea and lunch service was very professional and enjoyable

Don't miss a visit. One of London's hidden gems of a gallery.
Mos visitors don't know it exists which is such a shame as there is so much to see. And a visit to the restaurant alone is worth a tri[
A Wealth of visual stimulation. A stunning collection of artworks and ornaments. There's so much to see it almost becomes a bit overwhelming after a while. Look out for "The Laughing Cavalier".
Very Fine Collection. Everything about the Wallace Collection was inviting. The art and the way it is displayed are exceptional. It is also manageable and not overwhelming. We will return.
On of the best!. Love this museum - so interesting with some fascinating collections and the laughing cavalier! Great green house tea room too!

How could I never have been?. Well, I feel silly writing this as a Londoner who's been here more than 30 years. In my defence, i will say that my mother recommended this museum to me about 35 years ago, so of course I didn't go. (sorry Mum!) this was part of a wedding anniversary day out, and we timed our arrival to take advantage of the guided tour.(14:30 every day, I think). It was a really interesting tour with a knowledgable docent, and we really learned a great deal.We then wandered around a bit more - it is a BEAUTIFUL building, with a great somewhat eclectic collection (which adds to the total charm).So I would recommend this to anyone with some time to spare near Oxford Street.we also had a quick cup of tea in their courtyard, which is lovely, and where they do the three tiered tea, I noticed.I intend to return soon

A culture experience. A magnificent place.room after room ,full of beautiful furniture Sevres porcelains, armours ,paintings.intimate yet elegance style you cannot miss this experience when in London.The restaurant ,? We had a bad day ,waited hours for the main course the kilchen just could not come.very dissatisfied ,the staff where trying their best to make up for it....we still had to pay when we should have walked away.Still it is an absolute must ,go and enjoy sheer class of a bygone age.

A Must-See Attraction. The collection is housed in an early 19th century townhouse that borders on being palatial. It’s a short walk from the Bond Street Station and admission is free of charge. There were only a handful of visitors the day I was there, which meant NO queues! Plus, the museum offers guided tours, also at no charge.The numerous gallery displays represent three generations of collecting art, sculpture, weapons and armor. I would not hesitate to return and, if asked, would recommend, the Wallace over many of the other museums and galleries in London.

Hidden Gem of a museum. I saw this museum on the "Quizeum" show and dragged a couple of friends with me on our next visit to London. Its got some really good paintings and sculpture, a nice little cafe, and ITS FREE.

This collection is in a mansion that will know you out!. We toured this museum on one of our few rainy days and were amazed by its artwork, furniture, porcelain, books, etc. It is an incredible picture of how wealthy Londoners lived. And it's free!

Comprehensive collection. I loved the Wallace Collection. It was the first Museum I went to on revisiting London so the gallery had a big impact on me. It carries a wide range of art, ceramics and weaponry.

Wallace Collection. This mansion delights with beautiful rooms,art, furniture and armour. Admission is free but you will see famous paintings by Renoir, Velazquez and Murillo among many others. The outdoor covered cafe is beautiful with reasonable prices and perfectly presented food. Loved it.

A first rate relatively small collection. There are many first-rate paintings here. For the art lover in London, this is not to be missed. Among the pleasures, the admission is free. Good paintings by Boucher, Poussin, etc.
Eclectic and sumptuous. Beautiful gem, with a great restaurant. Lots to see and admire. Take the kids to see the armour....in a lovely part of Londoner near Marylebone. Free to get in too.
the Wallace Collection. I just loved this museum. It is a smallish museum just filled with beautiful works. The armory was stunning and my favorite part. I highly recommend it.

Beautiful. A hidden gem. Unfortunately I was on a group visit & only had 2hours to visit, including afternoon tea in the lovely light conservatory like dining room Another hour would have been nice. Amazing that it is free to visit. So many very beautiful things arranged in lovely rooms, with one leading into another, so no unnecessary walking, or wasted time. There were many outstanding pieces of furniture but as I was rushing, I mainly loked at the paintings,a huge collection, including many Canalettos.

Hidden Gem. A friend of mine who's a Londoner took me here for tea. What a great atmosphere - its old world and modern at the same time. They have a covered courtyard cafe with a great vibe and the art is something you don't see anywhere else. Don't miss it.

A FEAST FOR THE EYES. You must not miss this absolutely wonderful collection set in a beautiful building in itself. The rooms are so easy to navigate and enjoy with benches, chairs, settees sprinkled throughout to just sit and drink it all in. Gave me goosebumps. The painting, bowls, small pictures , the armor and weapons, furniture and sculptures were amazing. As an added treat we enjoyed English tea in the restaurant which was wonderful. This will be a wonderful day to remember again and again. Oh yes and there is no charge to enter.

You don't have to be big to be great!. The Wallace Collection is a small (on British standards) Art Gallery and Museum. Well worth the walk effort from Oxford Street. The Coffee Shop is also worth a visit. This Museum and Art Gallery is true to the saying you don't have to big to be great.

Fabulous - even better because it's free!. Myself and my mother stopped outside on one of the benches for a sit down, but decided that given the collection was free, we may as well have a look inside. What a surprise! Room upon room upon room of art, historical artefacts, sculptures, etc etc - very interesting - wish we could've stayed for longer!

The best free entry in London. Going here for years as often nearby having lived in London all my life. Superb way of spending a couple of hours. Has a vast range of art and something of interest here for everyone. Well worth a visit to anyone either visiting-or living in London.

Superb collection of major art works and artifacts. This is a fascinating museum with art works, armour, weapons and much more, collected by one family over many years. It is free and has a fine cafe\restaurant in the enclosed courtyard. We joined a highlights tour which takes about 1hour and is well worth doing as the knowledgeable guide explains the history of the collection and picks out the key exhibits to explain in more detail. Allow at least half a day for this fascinating place just off Oxford Street.

My Favorite Museum in London. Wallace Collection has everything for everyone. Rembrandt, Napoleon's game set, stunning paintings, an armory replete with thousands of guns, cannons, swords, full armor, shields; a delicious and bright cafe, furniture, jewelry and so much more. Most incredibly, it is the private collection of the Wallace family in the actual Wallace home. An absolute must see museum.

An Amazing Collection (Full Stop)!. This is the second largest collection of Dutch Masters that I have experienced. It far outpaces the Louvre in terms of number of exhibits, breadth of artists and breadth of subjects. To my knowledge ( and here come the comments) the largest collection on display other than at the Rijksmuseum. The staff are approachable, pleasant and very knowledgeable. Most rooms have a wonderful biography of each painting available. If this genre of art is your cup of tea, don't miss this one!

Beautiful artworks. The paintings here are just lovely. So many different things to look at. The rooms are so elegant. What a wonderful place to have lived in its heyday.My husband enjoyed the military section. Definitely worth making a trip to when visiting London.

Hidden Gem. This museum is hidden away behind Bond Street. It is just the right size – two floors that circuit around a centre area that is a café. The benefit of this museum is that it has a little of everything. From well-known paintings to armour. It is mind blowing the money that such families had sufficient to purchase so many priceless things. I for one am very pleased that we can now all benefit from this widespread collection.The house itself is also worthy of pause and naturally there is a gift shop as well as the café that seemed most popular. Entry is free, however I would always encourage donations – upkeep of such treasures is not cheap – measure the pleasure of the experience and pay accordingly.A must see.
A must for anyone visiting London. Fascinating collection of pictures (including the Laughing Cavalier) and furniture and a wonderful outside restaurant

Ten times and I keep coming back. Set in a stunning house in Marleybone sits one of the gems of London. The Wallace collection truly has something for everyone - whether your interests lie with arms and armour, paintings, sculpture, manuscripts, or glass.Pros: free for quests (though do suggest dropping in a donation to keep this available), variety of displays, children's area in basement where one can try on armour, cafe for nibblesCons: none reallyIf you find yourself with a free afternoon in London, jump on the Tube and get over to the Wallace Collection. You'll be glad you did.
Nice museum for a Novice. I'm not really a big fan of Museums, and I found this one visually pleasing. Some of the rooms are beautiful, and the guns and various weapons were very interesting.
The paradise for collectors. It is not a museum.It is the fantastic collection of any collectable item you can immagine extremely well organised and presented Need to pay a visit when in London
Eclectic collection. Fascinating mixture of items on display but not too much of anything to be repetitive. Well laid out and labelled.

Birthday outing. A lovely building, not well known so not too crowded, a relaxing and pleasant place to visit. In a nice part of london with plenty of places for a post visit lunch in walking distance
Totally Brilliant. I went to see the laughing cavalier and on found one of the jewels of london. Its an amazing gallery.

Very nice. It's not going to change your life, but the Wallace Collection is charming and beautiful to see. The gracious home which houses it wonderfully conjures another time (and another class) long gone. It is exceedingly well-run, easy to reach and simple to visit. Why not go?
Exquisite. So good my husband went twice. Wonderful collection of antiques, art and armour. Beautifully displayed in Edwardian house. Good restaurant and the visit is free, not the restaurant!

Wallace Collection. Lovely café with atrium, the Rembrandts were great to see. I would go back to see the armor, and while in the neighborhood stop in at the American Embassy. The building has clean bathrooms and helpful staff.

Wonderful Museum. A great museum to visit in a lovely area of London.
When we visited on a Tuesday afternoon it was not at all crowded.
Visited the lovely restaurant for a pot of tea and cake. Next time will have lunch or afternoon tea as the food looked very good and the staff where top notch.
Loved it.

Secret lunch venue. A secret place for lunch in a glass top court yard just behind selfriges . To have a place to rest from shopping so close to oxford street with a museum as well is a real treat. Make sure you have time to relax and enjoy

little gem in the middle of the shopping district. This is a great little museum, the are is top notch and worth going to if you want a bit of culture in-between all the shops. The free tours they offer are very good and I learned lots of cool facts about the different paintings making it far more interesting.

A private collection that stands tall in the pantheon of London Museums. A superb, if slightly eclectic, collection that is well worth a visit. Like all collections of its type, it reflects the taste of its patron but the quality and setting makes this well worth a visit.

Definite Hidden Gem. I visit this museum every time I go to London. It never fails to inspire. Each time I take someone new with me, whether family or friends that live in London or who I'm travelling with. Its kind of nice seeing their excitement at all the Carravagio's, Rembrandt's, El Greco's etc etc packed into one not so large place. I must say I never fancied the museum's centrepiece 'The Laughing Cavalier' but now after seeing it so many times, I love it. Its one of those paintings that 'the more you see it the more you like it'.This place is an absolute hidden gem!

Loved it!. Building it was housed in was beautiful and collection extensive.
Food was a little too top range for a snack whilst visiting.
Wonderful hidden gem in Marylebone. A beautiful small museum in a wonderful neighborhood, off of Marylebone High Street. Highly recommend it!

Easy to miss Please visit. An excellent oasis of calm and beauty, the family home of the Wallace's with an art collection that is fantastic, the building and contents are beautifully maintained. Also do not forget to stop at the beautiful cafeteria with a glass ceiling. Enjoy a glass of wine or an afternoon tea in this great well lit cafeteria
Small but good. For Victorian art you should not miss The Wallace Collection. It is a 2 hour visit and relatively quiet. A hidden gem in the middle of London

Hidden treasure. One of the finest collections of Renaissance art present in London will undoubtedly be in the family home of the Wallaces - art collected for four generations. Sir Richard Wallace's collection is fantastic, and the place is beautifully maintained.Do not forget to drop in at the beautiful cafeteria with a glass ceiling. Enjoy your afternoon tea with scones in this brightly lit tastefully done up cafeteria.
Surprising. I hadn't heard of this collection before we visited London but it was a real highlight. Lovely café as well
Worth a visit. There are some beautiful pieces here. The staff are very helpful and the cakes in the restaurant are really yummy too.
Elegance. lunch in this amazing building surrounded by treasures, small enough museum to Realy enjoy the whole experience and a few. Minutes walk from Oxford street. ,

Nice colletion. Good piece of art. Small and beautifull museum in a quiet neighberhood just behind selfridges. You can have an impression of how rich lived during the 17-19 th centuries. What a marvellous collection of art mr wallacw had

A wonderful collection that has such interesting exhibits. This Museum and former home has an amazing Collection of great Art and Furniture. It is well worth taking a free guided tour mid afternoon because you learn so much more, than just using the speaker phone guides. There is such a lot to see so it's worth returning.

Glad we added this stop to our holiday. We had not planned to visit the Wallace Collection until we met another couple at breakfast who highly recommended it. What we did not know was the collection included an impressive display of armour and arms in addition to the fine art and impressive 18th and 19th century furniture. Admission is free.

Astounding collection!. Amazing collection of paintings, sculptures and furniture.
And free! Will be back again to explore more.
Must be visited.. Could not have imagined how great it woud be, you surly must visit it when ever in London. From great paintings and chine, the armoury is the best I have seen.

Lovely place to visit. A fine collection of things to see, with very friendly staff, and in a beautiful building.
A lovely way to spend a couple of hours.

Wow!. Stunning private collection of top notch pictures, statues, porcelain,
guns, armour, and much much more, all acquired for the artistic merit and decoration, set in the original house. Good restaurant too, particularly for cakes and light snacks.

Restaurant v.disappointing . We came to the Wallace collection for lunch with family, and although it is an absolutely beautiful place the food and service at the restaurant was very disappointing, especially given the prices they charge. The service was slow, and the prix fixe menu was very limited. We were told that the confit duck was off the menu they said they couldn't replace it with anything. Since I can't eat shellfish that left only vegetable broth which was a small plate of peas and beans with some vegetable stock poured over - very uninteresting and not what you'd call a main meal. Very disappointing for such a beautiful and apparently top class restaurant
Hidden gems. Some very familiar old masters are here. Well worth a visit. It has a restaurant too which we haven't tried but has an interesting French menu.

Such a Secret!. We loved this small museum. Collection is varied and the number of visitors small. There is ample seating to sit and take in each beautiful room. The great works of art are elsewhere but this is a lovely collection to visit. Don't miss it!

Manchester squares best collection. Masters, armor , ceramics o my! A delicious way to spend a day , spa coffee, admire art and enjoy some of the small but fantastic collections of the 18thc. English eye.
A gem in the heart of Marylebone. A lovely place to visit and no entrance fee, with plenty to see. A tour is ideal so you don't miss the best bits. Restaurant is lovely too with excellent food.

A lovely way to spend a Sunday morning. We loved the Joshua Reynolds exhibition and also wandering around the other exhibits. Not all to our taste, but I think there is something for most people. It was the Joshua Reynolds exhibition that we really went to see. The restaurant, situated in the middle of the house is light, airy and relaxed. Although we only had coffee it was a memorable experience and we look forward to a return visit sometime.

Very nice small museum. This is a wonderful small collection and very nice opportunity for lunch of tea. Really enjoyed the glass, ceramics and cabinetry. Allow a minimum of four hours - there's a lot to see.

A hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection was an awesome experience that I didn't expect to find. It was a little hard to find at first, but once you step inside you are surrounded by some of the most beautiful rooms you've ever seen. The armories are great for anyone who enjoys looking at suites of Armor and medieval weapons. They also have a gorgeous collection of paintings all around the Mansion. I definitely recommend visiting it!
Spend an hour or two here if you are in the area. An amazing free museum in the centre of Marylebone. Take a guided tour for best experience to fully appreciate the treasures here
A secret delight. one of the hidden gems of London Galleries. No charge and worth every penny! Cafe to match. Brilliant!

Fantastic lesser known museum. This was a wonderful collection of 18th century art and furniture, and arms and armour. It is close to Marble Arch (north of it), and it is very worth a visit! The upstairs contains beautiful galleries of paintings and furniture, including some rather famous 18th century French paintings (plus a Dutch gallery), and the house (Hertford House) itself is a lovely. The downstairs retains an incredible collection of European arms and armour, as well as oriental weapons. The European armour, however, was my favorite. It is magnificently displayed, and there is a wonderful wide variety of dates and makes. For the weaponry and/or art buff, a must see.

A treat to be sure. Luckily for the world, this family, of the ancestral Hertford's, donated their mansion and art trove to the country for all to see for free! Do yourselves a favor art lovers and go! From perhaps the finest Collection of French porcelain to oils by Rembrandt, Canaletto, van Sykes and more plus an armory collection fit for its own museum, this is a 2 hour treat for sure. Art treasure that belonged to French kings, Marie Antoinette and much more to describe. Don't worry about going hungry since there is also a restaurant inside. Restrooms as well.

A must visit in the heart of London!. An amazing collection of artificats in beautifully decorated rooms in a lovely mansion in the heart of London. Friends took us and the first surprise was entrance was free, although donations are much appreciated. (Another must see exhibit that is free in London is The Imperial War Museum). The next surprise continued as we walked through this extensive exhibit and continued to be awed by the multitude of treasures. We did not take one but if visited again would take a guided tour. There is a very nice cafe where one can have a nice cup of tea and a delicious Victoria Sponge or other goodies.
School Trip (accompanying adult). What a fascinating place. Staff well informed and helpful, kept the school children enthralled. Will definitely revisit, probably with my sister.

Top class elevenses. The lovely courtyard. the attentive staff; the tasty food What could you ask for more. A hidden treasure in the Wallace Collection. A matching tribute to the art work. porcelain, armour and multitudinous beautiful 'things'. Try the victoria sponge - you will never have tasted anything like it!
A treasure trove. Amazing collection of paintings, furniture, armoury, ornaments - you name it the Wallace collection has got it! And it was free.

It fills a niche!. The Wallace is small and the collection is eclectic containing furniture, paintings, sculpture, armor, and some very fine pottery. The collection is housed in a former home, Mansion actually, and that is the effect, as if one was slowly walking through someone's home looking at their collected treasures. There is also a fine restaurant in an atrium and several exhibits that explain how restoration is accomplished and how different items were constructed during their time. It is, in fact, a school of art at the same time as being a museum. Worth a visit if you have managed to see the Top Ten attractions and are looking for something interesting to spend a couple of hours. Admission is free but donations are appreciated.

Thanks to the Hetfords who granted us such an amazing collection. A free entrance collection in the heart of London, 15 mins walk from Marylebone Station, not far from Madame Tussaud. You will be granted with works from Rembrandt, Rubens, Boucher, Frans Hals, and much more. Nice restaurant/coffeshop in the back, a stroll from Selfridge's. Don't miss it
Amazing collection. A beautifully rich collection in a nice and peaceful environment in the heart of London. A must go! Some very nice Rembrandt and Canaletto and amazing weapons' room.

Well presented. Light airy, well attended, Oliver shouldn't have to worry, We had breakfast here which was adequate for the day ahead.. I'm not into this thing but the woman is, so had to please her.A good walk and a strong coffee, sets you up.She'll be bringing the old girls here for Vals 70th soon, a dozen rowdies from Retford. can London cope with the influx?

Beautiful Things. This is an amazing collection of priceless and interesting piecesof art, furniture, pottery etc. This house has an amazing display of objects from different countries and ages. Well worth the visit. Staff in the rooms, were also willing to answer any questions.

One of the most memorable things I saw in London. Never to forget. My visit to this extraordinary house was not planned months before the trip like everything else. But as it is nearby to our hotel, I searched around the web and their youtube channel and unexpectedly this happened to be one of the main reasons I wanted to go to London. After the visit I can say that for me it was THE NEXT BEST THING AFTER THE CROWN JEWELS.We've only had one hour until closing time at 05:00 PM and were in a hurry to see everything, so if you really wish to enjoy this marvelous place give yourself at least 2-2.30 hours on your visit. I can't understand how it was free entrance, because they can easily charge you 10 GBP, and still it would be worth it. AND you can take as many pictures as you like inside the Wallace Collection UNLIKE most of the places that charge you for entrance.
Nice collection in a beautiful setting. The art is very nice and the setting is beautiful. Some outstanding, lesser know pieces. Off the beaten path so not a lot of crowds.
Brilliant, take a guided tour if possible. A very rare place, that will be the same every visit. That have some precious stuff, love the Fragonard and Boucher items.

Past excellence,put it on the bucket list. We stood a breath away from all the beautiful art without anyone breathing down your neck or shouting. A wonderful lady led us through the different rooms,she taught us more in 20 mins. It was obvious she loved her job. All the Sevres that Catherine the Great ordered, I could gaze forever at it.This place is different and the staff made it so our group was treated like welcome guests. It's a must do..

Great collection. Wonderful setting in a great part of London.
I can spend hours and hours in this stunning house and the collection is amazing!

Very warm. I visited this attraction in Summer so I guess the fact it was warm was little surprise. Be aware of this though. Whilst some of the pieces were interesting there was limited information available on them and no guides seemed to either be available or know an awful lot about the pieces. It was a shame because there was some fascinating items around, just limited information on them which detracted from the point. Be advised as well limited places to sit and take it all in.

Gem of a visit when in London, not far from Oxford Street, a wonderful and varied quality art collection. Such a wonderful variety of paintings, furniture, ceramics, armour and unique collectibles in a small space, well displayed, a real gem of a building with a lovely cafe restaurant at the back. I even better it is free.

Great small gallery if you like more traditional art or a pleasant restaurant. Walking distance from Baker St. and on the other side of Central London from most of the major galleries, the Wallace Collection, though small, surprises by having many recognisable gems, such as Franz Hals' Laughing Cavalier, and works by the Flemish artist Gerrit Dou (mentioned in the famous Christmas ghost story "Schalcken the Painter" - please show it again, BBC!)Also good for a quiet lunch in the central atrium, away from all the crowds in Marylebone High St restaurants.

Great place to visit for all the family and it's free. This is an amazing small museum in central London and it is free admission. The museum has a wonderful collection. Plus it has a fabulous courtyard restaurant.Something to view for all the family from medieval relics, wonderful paintings, armour, furniture, and religious art. etc Also tours available
London Family Vacation. Stunning collection inside luxurious mansion. Art and architectural exhibited are stunning. Well worth the visit! Don't miss it.
Facinating. Its a fascinating look into a family's wealth and their generational obsession with art! Worth a visit even if only to stare at the Wallpaper ...i am serious...its real silk!
Sevres at its best. The Wallace collection is a free entry and the porcelain is magnificent Well displayed in this London House A must see if you like French porcelain

Fabulous & Worth Seeing!. Walking down London's Oxford Street most people would have no idea they were within a short walk away from one of the best collections of art, porcelain & French military artefacts in the World.One of the most famous & iconic paintings ever is on display here, The Laughing Cavalier by Hals.This is more than just a gallery, it is a story of history and enlightenment about days gone by & how others lived and fought.If you are in London this is a must visit, it is Manchester Square which is about a 100 yards from Oxford Street & Bond Street Tube station.
hidden gem. Great collection in the middle of London, just the right size so it doesn't overwhelm. Well worth a visit.

Often overlooked - should be on EVERY visitor's list!!. Imagine being present, and with pockets full of cash, when the contents of Versailles were being auctioned off during the French Revolution? Well the founders of the Wallace Collection were just that and the collection is full of those treasures. Free entrance, convenient location, a lovely setting, and filled with Rembrandt, Rubens, Titian, Gainsborough, Joshua Reynolds, Sevres Porcelain and the contents of Marie Antoinette's bedroom - just to name a few! This is my 2nd favorite "secret" museum in London - (the first is Sir John Soane's) and my favorite place to while away an hour or two in-between just about anything whilst in London. It's SO close to Oxford Street / Bond Street Tube stations - so you could even squeeze in a visit on a long lunch during a business trip!

If you were to visit just one art collection, make it this one. So many priceless works of art, paintings and furniture, packed into such a magnificent building and arranged with such meticulous care, it takes your breath away. Nothing looks out of place, the whole is even more pleasing than the sum of its parts. Amazingly, admission is free!

The Laughing Cavalier. they have a fantastic selection of eastern armour, art and ceramics from all over. the restaurant in the courtyard looks amazing, gift shop very nice. needs at least 3 visits to do it justice, and so close to Oxford Street too.
Excellent special exhibition. Exhibition of Joshua Reynolds at no extra charge. Always a good place to visit. Not too big and wonderful classic works
Amazing Museum. Very accessible collection of world class art, armour and arms.Great restaurant.Well worth visiting .

Great. Fantastic collection close to Marble Arch and, even better, an easy walk from the Parkwood. The beautiful old site is very well laid out with a great range of art from around the world that keeps the viewer interested throughout.

Stunning venue hidden so close behind Oxford Street that it would be a shame not to go and investigate inside.. Hidden behind Oxford Street this is well worth a visit. Lovely paintings and antiquities in an absolutely gorgeous setting. I love the fact that a lot of the art is displayed in beautifully decorated rooms with fabulous wallpaper and matching curtains.The eyes of the laughing Cavalier really do seem to follow you around. There are some beautiful items of furniture, porcelain and there is the armoury for something a bit different. I am always happy to nip in for a look around when in the area. Certainly enough to keep any art lover happy for at least a couple of hours with the added bonus that there is no charge and there is a pleasant cafe for a sit down and some refreshment.

a magical place. this museum has a brilliant range of exhibits: armour, furniture, paintings, etc. It's just the right size to enjoy without being overwhelmed. The paintings - all pre-twentieth century - are some of the most beautiful I've seen -
ONLY ONE REALLY MEMORABLE THING. Laughing Caveraleir . The best and most memorable thing about the visit.I'm now rambling as I have to use up 100 characters

Excellent museum for art and antiques and for something a little different. Despite many years of living in London I had never visited the Wallace Collection - having had lunch in Baker Street we decided to stop here for a visit on Sunday afternoon. Hugely interesting collection and house - and the one hour tour we had was well worth it. The tour meant we didn't see everything in the house - but we learnt a lot about the collection and some specific pieces. Not really for kids - except perhaps the armour rooms. They have a very good cloakroom and lend out small folding stools so that the less able to stand can perch on a stool whilst listening to a guide or indeed just sit and look at some of the exhibits. If you are interested in art and antiques, this is a worthwhile museum to visit, and we will definitely be going back to see what we missed the first time.

Always a joy. Such an eclectic collection - from Masters to quite obscure pieces but a unique and deep resource for art lovers. The sculptures are delightful - it is such a joy to visit and discover something new every time.

As good as ever. This extraordinary collection never fails to delight. I have been going to the Wallace Collection on and off for 30 years and I always find something new. There is so much, it doesn't matter what you are "in to" at any particular time. I like clocks at the moment and the Wallace Collection has an amazing selection - it's great when you are there at midday!

Beautiful and free. Stunning rooms with picture chains toned to match the silk on the walls. So much to see; paintings, sculpture and ornate French furniture. Good breakfast in the glass covered courtyard too!
Too much repetition. Impressive home to house the collection, but too many repetitive works of art and various collections.

great hidden gem in the heart of London. A short walk from Selfridges, if you need a fix of art then this is the place. The collection has some truly great art.I was however a little disappointed with the cafe as the service was a bit slow and the scones not quite up to the standard I would have expected.Skip the cafe (there are lots in the area anyway) concentrate on the art instead.

Very Lovely. The Wallace Collection is well worth the visit. Give yourself a good half-day to absorb everything and enjoy. It is quite a collection at that! Especially interesting is the Armoury portion. It's all really beautiful, and photos are allowed (no video or flash).
Fabulous hidden gem. Met couple girlfriends here to have a look around and lunch after. A lovely serene peaceful setting. Food was great.
Art to inspire. Such beauty all around, and take your time and take it in, there is so much to see. It can get crowded, but don't let that faze you, this place deserves your attention.

A great museum, very well maintained and preserved collection of furniture and art work going back to 15th Century. The museum is set in a historic mansion of over 100 years old. It is well located, just north of Oxford Street and close to both the Marble Arch and Bond Street underground stations. It contains a wide-ranging collection of fine arts and furniture going back to the 15th century. Everything is well maintained and the museum should definitely be a must for all those who enjoy the artistic life of London.

Wonderful Private Collection and Afternoon Tea. The museum is in a district with many embassies, so it it s very nice part of London. This collection a gem of a private collection that focuses on pieces from or connected to Versailles with Louis XIV and Louis XVI, European and Middle Easter Armour, Dutch painting such as Rembrandts, and prized Asian export pieces. I love having tea here, the afternoon tea is very good value considering London prices. I highly recommend taking one of their free tours.

Often overlooked wonderful small museum. This great little museum is set in a house on a lovely square. It is full of world-class paintings and furniture. They have just renovated the grand gallery and it just gleams. Go see to Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hal - one of my favourite paintings in the world. The Marie Antoinette Room has more objects owned by her than anywhere else in the world. It is small so it is easy to navigate and doesn't take days to take in. Spend a couple of leisurely hours and enjoy!

Great, and Not Overwhelming. Others have extolled the virtues of this wonderful townhouse museum, collected between about 1760 and 1880 by the first four Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace, the son of the 4th Marquess. (These people had money.) It's a terrific collection -- I personally like Titian, and there are two of them. Also Gainsboroughs, Rembrandts, and the most famous of all, the Laughing Cavalier of Franz Hals. A Poussin. Some Delacroix. Others. And lots of great, great furniture, and some great porcelain. But, what I want to say is this: there is a 45 minute tour every weekday at 2:30 PM. I was lucky enough, and I mean lucky, to happen to be there at that precise minute. What a happy coincidence! The tour was very nice, quite a good guide to what they have. There have 1 PM specific tours, too, I understand. So that's the time to be there - 2:30 PM!
Good to see. Free entry.Near Euston stations,and a nice coffee shop and book shop.Well worth a look.I visited the Forensics Exhibition in June 2015.If you have time before your train,pay a visit

well worth a visit. a really eclectic collection - presented in an easily taken in way and with easy waking distance of Selfridges, the lovely Durrants Hotel and good pubs and restaurants in Marylebone High Street.

Well worthwhile. Well we finally made it to The Wallace collection and we are happy to say it is a smaller museum with a lot to offer the art part of your life. The armory was top rate and the paintings are impressive, even old Wellington was here and there. You can photo most of it unless described on the info plaque otherwise. We found the café visually inviting and was a good cup of Assam with carrot cake. There is a rather nice Rembrandt self portrait in this collection and the museum is well worth a couple hours.Get a 2 for 1 cream tea voucher online(Days Out Guide). It is free admission and is excellent.

The Wallace Collection,A must!!!. The Wallace Collection is truly one of the great museums of London not as famous as the great British Museum or The Tate's etc But a beautiful & intimate museum that is always easy to get into,never crowded & small enough to enjoy in a couple of hours

Stunning Collection. We had read about this collection, and it surpassed all our expectations. What a great collection of art here: medieval and renaissance objects, porcelain, arms and armoury, great masters like Titian, Rembrandt, Velasquez, caskets, clocks, furniture by Andre-Charles Boulle, and so much more, all in this wonderfully preserved mansion. This collection is so worth a visit.

Incredible collection! . A 'must visit ' place if you appreciate art - without all the fuss of the big museums and galleries. The building itself is charming and the permanent collection is breathtaking, one of the finest. A short walk from Baker Street or Bond Street stations. The admission is free. It's worth checking their website before visiting since it could be closed to the public for private events.

A Fantastic Museum in London. This museum is fantastic. Room after room is breathtaking. This is a large mansion owned by the Wallace family in the 1800's. They were avid collectors as you will see. The large gallery upstairs as you walk up the majestic staircase is something to see- rivals that of the Louvre and National Gallery. Masterpiece after masterpiece. There are objects and furniture from hundreds of years ago right before you without any barriers. The staff throughout the museum are friendly and willing to answer any questions. In my opinion, this is one of the best museums in Europe and there is no fee to enter. When you visit London, this should be on the top of your list of places to visit.
A great experience. A great small museum... best dutch painters including Rembrand, furniture, armory, ceramics. You can spend there half an hour or the whole day.
a hidden gem. an absolute gem, tranquil and fascinating, tucked away yet totally central. a wonderful collection of art and artefacts, lovely restaurant, free admission ! A MUST

Still Wonderful, But Now With a Great Cafe. We hadn't been to the Wallace in a number of years, so went with friends who had never been. It enchanted both new and returning visitors -- a wonderful classic collection at a manageable size. But the big surprise was the lovely courtyard Cafe they now have. Lovely food, a spectacular setting and a great way to either start or end a visit, as they do both lunch and tea.
beautiful collection to visit. lots of paintings, French furnitures and other treasure. Even with kids with a collection of armors and old weapons

the amazing Wallace collection. We couldn't believe the free admission; superb display throughout the building; also there are tearooms (not free!) but the visit was ideal for us on a miserable rainy day.

Wallace. Nothing to dislike here. Slightly difficult to locate on foot, but well worth the effort. Beautifully laid out galleries with paintings from many famous, and not-so-famous artists, with scenes to suit all tastes.

Evening Venue. I was lucky enough to be invited to a private dinner and viewing at the Wallace Collection. What a beautiful environment!, we had dinner sitting next to the Laughing Cavalier!We also had our own private viewing of the collection which was like an exquisite Country House in the Centre of London.

This place deserves my first 5 Star overall rating after over sixty reviews!. This high quality exhibition is one of the finest that I have experienced for many years. The magnificence of the Sevres porcelain quite swept me away, whilst the intricate patterns on the hand made pistols are from another planet. I saved the upper floor for another time but I expect to be equally amazed by the paintings therein. Another plus point is the delightful Restaurant and Café where I enjoyed a good quality coffee and observed some good looking plates of food being placed before other visitors. The washrooms are spick and span. Unbelievably this place has free admission but donations are encouraged. An audio guide will enhance your visit.

Famous art. Some impressive art including The Laughing Cavalier and the Swing as well as several Canaletto's are found in this Gallery. The pictures are beautifully displayed in some very attractive rooms. Well worth a visit if you love traditional art. There is no charge so even if you only have a few minutes to look you can pop in and enjoy
Sheep. Interesting to see where he was going to pop up!!!! Liked different disguises, disliked trying to take photo and people were hugging the sheep!!!! Had to be quick.

Very Interesting. We had an evening private showing of the museum, do this if possible, very it inmate and Catherine was the best guide I have ever had, she was so knowledgable about the paintings and history.

How the other half used to live.. This house contains a large collection of art of all descriptions. It is spacious, charming and the rooms themselves - wallpapers, drapes, chandeliers etc - are worth a visit in their own right. The big plus is a beautiful bar/restaurant in the glass roofed central courtyard.
Free entry except for occasional special exhibitions.

Want to see art and life a little off the beaten track. If you have had enough of the mega museums check out the more cozy feel of the Wallace. They have a fantastic collection and since it is in a home, there is a little something for everyone in terms of a variety of objet d'arte, furniture, paintings etc.

elegant education. Have always adored this place.
Beautiful building, the staff are not intrusive or stuffy.
To me this place is a haven from the squashed insanity and squabbles of Oxford Street.
It is a 'must see'.
Great area,also,for just wandering aimlessly and stopping for coffee,interspersed with private galleries..

Hidden Gem near Oxford Street. Spacious, not crowded, some amazing 18th century French furniture, memorable pictures, Hobbema, Ruyp, Fragonard, Reynolds, Gainsborough, Hals (Laughing Cavalier) and for reenactment enthusiasts, the armoury is a must.

Beautiful private museum. I am a volunteer at my local art museum in Houston and this museum was recommended to me by curators. It is off a charming square not far from Oxford Street and has a fabulous collection of European art and decorative art from the 16th to 20th centuries.

Underwhelming. We went with a group of 6, and all of us were a bit disappointed with the collection here. It seemed there were many second-rate paintings, and relatively few masterpieces. The armour collection might interest you, and the tea room cafe looked lovely.

Excellent Collection. Excellent Tour. This museum is well worth visiting. The collection built by an archetypical 19th century gentlemen collector. The weapons collection is especially interesting. Time your visit to take the hour long tour. Our guide clearly loves the collections, is very knowledgeable and brought the collection / house to life.

A must see if you don't relish the thought of the big museums. Loved the extent of the collecttion of furnishings, artifacts, the floor with the armor collection in this once-private home is a must see. Got this recommendation from the guide on one of the London Walks I took.

I LOVE this museum!!. Favorite, favorite, favorite painting: The Laughing Cavalier! Gorgeous museum, beautiful neighborhood. Sort of hard to find if you are travelling by Tube. But, at least you can walk near Baker Street and visit the Sherlock Holmes Museum as well.

A wonderful afternoon!. This beautiful home and private collection is a real treat and a wonderful way to spend a morning or an afternoon. The paintings, porcelains, statues, weaponry, etc are wonderfully displayed and present an amazing collection. The house (Manchester House) is in Manchester Square, not far from Selfridge's, so you can make a day of visiting both places. The Wallace Collection is free, only asking you to make a donation if you wish to do so.
A fabulous building. Well worth a visit, lots of famous paintings and artefacts, including old weapons of war and suits of armour. Plenty to see in this building just off Oxford Street.
Breathtaking Collection. Great treasures of art and craft! Have visited several times, and we always find something new and beautiful. The setting and gallery arrangements are very well designed.

Consistently good, occasionally brilliant. There will be innumerable reviews already for the Wallace Collection so I will confine my comments to three key areas. There are, indeed, some fine paintings though there are many others that are wholly unexceptional. However, I recommend you take time to check out the wonderful collection of miniatures, normally with display covers to protect them from the light, and the arms and armour section to witness some truly extraordinary craftsmanship. I try to close my eyes to the Meissen and Sevres porcelain which is almost epic in its tastelessness. Yuck! I am not a big fan of the in house cafe though others seem to drool over it. Perfectly fine but overpriced and I don't like the atrium within which it is contained. If you build up an appetite wandering around the house, Marylebone is replete with great cafes and restaurants I recommend you check out instead.
An oasis in the centre of London. Brilliant. Love the rooms and the way everything is displayed. Wonderful conservatory restaurant...really beautiful

A glorious treasure trove. Joined friends in Lindon for a trip to the Wallace Collection , I had made the assumption that it was mostly an Art gallery . How delightfully wrong could I be the most wonderful building and room after room of stunning artefacts and incredible art works . More than one visit needed to fully appreciate the full extent of the collection .

A. London Must See. Stunning art collection, just off Baker Street. Formed over five generations and donated to the nation by the last descendant of the family. Paintings on display from Rubens, Rembrandt, Canaletto and Gainsborough amongst others. Also fabulous collections of porcelain, furniture and armour. Entrance is completely free although donations to the upkeep are encouraged. Definitely worthwhile visiting.

just so much to look at. What a wonderfully diverse collection of antiques and painting just off Oxford street that's free to visit. You can see medieval arms and armour to paintings such as the Laughing Cavalier in one huge London house. We spent a few hours just browsing but will be back soon to have a longer look.
Great collection!. Worth to be visited. Incredible collections and inspiring building. The exhibition space is used really well and the permanent displays are amazing.

Well worth a visit if you are in the area. Some good paintings here as well as some figures and porcelains. But the real attraction is the collection of armour and medieval weaponry. It forms the most extensive collection I have seen. Clearly, the Wallace Collection is never going to compete with the National Gallery or the Britsh Museum. However, if you are in the area, I would definitely recommend this place. It's free, it's in a quiet location and it's in a charming building.
Wonderful eclectic collection. Consider lunch there. Often interesting comparative exhibits in basement annexe to the main collection.

An overlooked marvel. Most tourists overlook this extraordinary museum, which isn't generally on itineraries and is somewhat off the beaten track off Oxford street, though easy to find. The gorgeous, grand mansion is reason enough to stop by (free, like most of London's museums) but the stellar, surprising collection of artwork (mainly 16th - 19th century), armor, and decorative arts is world class, and nothing is ever loaned out - this is the only place to see it. The special exhibitions are also wonderful, as is the courtyard cafe and well-edited gift shop. Unlike the larger, better known institutions (British Museum, Tate, V & A for instance) there's never a horde to push past, you won't be jostled. It's a place I return to again and again - highly recommended.
Well worth a visit. Actually, I met friends for lunch in the delightful restaurant! But plan to return to enjoy the Collection
Stunning museum. Top-class art collection, beautiful house and furniture, interesting medieval armour, lovely restaurant

Favorite attraction in london. This museum has a lot of cool objects like weapons and armor which would impress anyone fascinated by the age of chivalry. The house itself is also a sight to see - very elegant rooms on the second floor. It made my friend and I want to go dancing. We spent a couple hours here but we also tend to read a lot of the descriptions so you could just stop for 0.5-1 hour (since it's free) if you just wanted to look at the rooms and displays.
Great history. Better to visited in z morning and let ur child watch brave heart movie first to understand how these weapons r used ☺

Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem. The house is filled to the BRIM with all sorts of lovely artwork, antiques, furniture, decor, and helpful staff who like to tell great stories. I write historical novels and the place is brimming with inspiration. I took a million pictures and got lots of great inspiration, not so much from the artwork (although that was lovely), but from the decor, which was simply stunning. If you're in London and you like art and/or old things, you should definitely make time for this museum. Plus, the atrium restaurant (attached) is lovely, as well, and they have a bookshop/library downstairs.
Delightful. A great gallery and the atrium is good for afternoon tea as well. Across several floors with plenty of favourites including the laughing cavalier.

Stunning place. Gorgeous building - what a hidden gem. Have not tried the cafe but have heard great things about it. I went first thing when it opened and had the place almost to myself which was amazing.
A gem behind Oxford Street. A gem just behind Oxford Street away from the crowds, packed with fabulous art work. Its free and the cakes in the cafe are worthy of the great British bake off.
A must visit, often ignored. The Wallace Collection is a free, compact museum full of everything. There is also a good restaurant.

Superb hidden gem. Impressive collection of art, beautiful building. The staff are quite knowledgeable and ready to answer questions about the displayed objects. The courtyard is a great venue to go for a cup of tea or lunch. Makes the visit more special.

Glorious collection. For me, the Wallace Collection has three aspects: the superlative paintings; the furniture and the porcelain; and the historic London town house in which it is situated.
In my opinion, the highlight of the collection is Franz Hals' masterpiece, "The Laughing Cavalier" (even though the subject of the painting isn't a cavalier, and he isn't laughing).
A lovely way to spend the afternoon. Free and beautiful - you could spend hours getting lost here x a hidden gem which is well worth a visit x
Curiouser and curiouser. Intriguing, beguiling, informative, helpful, attractive...no more needed. Restaurant worth spending a dollar or two, too.
Excellent collection. This is a lovely place to spend a few hours. The collection is exquisite and there are often free highlights tours. The property also has a nice cafe in the courtyard.

A hidden gem. I am so happy I discovered this special collection, it is a great way to spend a few hours while in central London. Free admission, I took the £4 optional audio guide which was worth it. So much to see and not just the painting, the furniture and the dishes, the miniatures all make for a truly fabulous museum.

A great favourite. I first visited the Wallace Collection more than 25 years ago and it was lovely to revisit it this month. It is such a beautiful museum and I always find so many things I never noticed on previous visits ( just like all of London really). It's just like a smaller V&A. Highly recommend a visit here.

Something for everyone. The Wallace Collection is only a couple of minutes from Bond St station and makes a super break from shopping. It has a pleasant restaurant in the covered courtyard. It's great strengths are size - not too big - and the variety of exhibits, all displayed in a lovely old town house. Among the paintings I was struck by the REAL Laughing Cavalier; in a different class from all the photos of it. And it is free.
Wonderful, great collection. A great variety of collectibles: dishes, furniture, weapons, armor, galleries and more. It's free and near lots of other attractions.

Best kept secret in London. This museum, just north of Oxford Street, is located in the delightful Hertford House overlooking Manchester Square. The exhibits are top quality and there is huge range, something for everyone from full horse armour for the boys, to amazing china, miniatures and some world class paintings, .e.g the Laughing Cavalier and The Swing. There are also excellent loos in the basement and a good cafe in the covered courtyard. The museum itself is housed in a beautiful old Hotel, which lends itself to the glamour of the place and to one's imagination. A great place for a private party - if you are a multi-billionaire.

Reynolds display at Wallace Collection. Wonderful display of paints and techniques. Chemistry and colours.
Discovered by X ray.
Artistry revealed to create the masterpieces.
