Hidden gem of a museum. Wonderful eclectic collection of Pictures, armor, and furnishings, I believe there was more authentic furniture from Marie Antoinette's than we saw at Versailles! The armory Collection is the best and most extensive I have ever seen. Some outstanding rare Pictures as well! Ron H.

Best small museum in ondon. We love this place, a fabulous collection of art, pottery, metalwork, armoury etc. Conveniently situated just off Oxford Street in a lovely old house. The great thing about the Wallace Collection is that you can see everything in a few hours and there is a lot to see. If you only visit one museum in London this should be the one. We have been on dozens of occasions and never tire of it.

Wonderful Surprise. This was a very intriguing collection in a beautiful London mansion. There were great pieces of art including Rembrandts along with some pieces I wouldn't put in a doghouse. Great eclectic paintings, pieces of armor, portraits and more. Manageable in a partial day. Nice covered atrium area for dining.

A precious little marvel. Unless you hold no regard for art collections this place is a marvel not to be missed. Splendor and opulence seems ubiquitous in many of the mansion's rooms and the sheer quantity of collected items is breathtaking. I will go again and again.

Should I tell you about it?. I'd sooner keep it to myself. It's a treasure filled with treasures, especially the Poussin (Dance to the Music of Time). Recommend lunch or tea in the lovely cafe, which services specialty cakes and sweets, some out of history, I believe. A fine time spent there. No admission cost.
wallace Collection. Small and easy to view, convenient location for visiting regularly . Excellent free tour 3.30 daily.

Not the usual gallery!. This is a fabulous place with some very eccentric twists. I would recommend anyone to go there and then watch out as you will be forever spotting famous images of objects you saw in The Wallace Collection.

Worth the visit. Absolutely interesting: the house in itself, the decoration of the rooms and of course the paintings - you'll find some you know from publications(I personally am not at all interested in weapons and armoury - so I skipped the ground floor. The best: the visit is free!

Little oasis off Oxford Street. The Wallace Collection has some beautiful rooms containing random and interesting artefacts, well maintained and presented.Moreover, it is generally fairly uncrowded and free beyond a voluntary donation. A cloakroom exists to dump all those heavy shopping bags and on rainy days they hand out plastic covers to stop wet umbrellas dripping on the wooden floors as a matter of course. Staff are friendly and relaxed.This is one of those museums that always has something new to see, even if you have been there before, simply because there are so many detailed items inside.It does help if you have SOME interest in subject matter relating to architecture of the period the building was designed in, pottery, ancient military paraphernalia, artwork and the like or you will be bored. 'Modern' does not come into it. Having said that, the space in the middle has been converted sympathetically to become an enclosed conservatory containing a warm bright cafe area. This is difficult to get seating at due to the number of wealthy pensioners and the fact that the purveyors of the place have a good rating across London (they supply a few different places). It is worth considering though if you want white table linen, table service and a feeling of peace amidst the bustle.Special events at this venue tend to be well run and worth a look in.
out of the way spot. this was great! it was free to attend and had very interesting artefacts, paintings and general information on victorian and earlier life in London.
Just off the beaten track. We like to drop into the Wallace Collection from time to time, never found it over crowded, has plenty of diffrent things of display to suit everyone,.
Such a beautiful gem. This is a beautiful little museum with great collection. Charming interior. And there is Rembrandt's work! Highly recommend, after tired of shopping at Bond Street.
impressive collection. loved the miedeval armory and weapons collection .definitely worth it. visited then went on to primrose hill and camden yard market for some street food.

A Secret Treasure Trove. This intimate collection is an absolute gem. Well known favourites such as Frans Hals' Laughing Cavalier and Poussin's Dance to the Music of Time and Fragonard's The Swing have pride of place, but don't miss the armouries and thousands of other treasures. It is the Collection's policy never to lend and never to borrow, so you will never see any item in the collection anywhere else. The restaurant in the grand central court is well worth a visit.

Amazing sanctuary, incredible collection. This is an amazing place to visit, just back from Oxford Street, full of wonders if you are interested in the 'way things were' in England. There is a lovely restaurant/cafe to relax in before or after either the a free guided tour or a tour in your own time.Full of treasures and history.

My favorite museum in London. Beautiful building. Outstanding and unusual art collection. Great collection of minature paintings and armour. There is a place to eat in the back with a large glass ceiling. Just beautiful!
Amazing setting and collection . From the beauty of the building to the importance if the collection this hidden gem is worth discovering
A gem. The most fabulous place tucked away around the back of Oxford Street.Having lived in London for 50 years I cannot believe it has passed me by, just beautiful, I loved it. Go.

Hidden treasure box. So close to Oxford St but away from the bustle. Worth popping in to look at the wonderful, varied collection. The rooms are beautifully decorated with silk curtains and wall coverings. It also attracts French tourists looking at the(ir) Sevres porcelain and the Empire style furniture.
Excellent and free. Really good for a day visit, and free,BUT give a donation please, near to oxford street and tube stations.
Just stunning. It is compact, elegant and worth a visit. The building is beautiful and the treasures not to be missed.
World class but understated. The collection is outstanding, with many highlights, not to be missed. The building has been very well refurbished, all-in-all a gallery of the highest quality.
Nice gem in central London. this is a nice gem right in central London. Great little museum plus a good restaurant on-site. Highly recommended for a break from shopping!
Very good museum. Hidden museum in a square, behinf Selfridges. Really good: The collection, the house, the restaurant. I recommend the guided tours.

Stunning gallery, fine collection. Oh how the other half lived! There is wonderful art and furniture throughout this very impressive "house." Fans of armour and old weaponry can get their fill as well. While slightly off the beaten path, it is well worth a visit.
Great day out without the hordes.. Stones throw from Oxford St, but hardly any tourists. Lovely orangery bar/cafe. Great art and eclectic antique collection, Go!!
A real gem. One of the nicest museums in London. Excellent art from artists like Rembrandt and Frans Hals. And far less busy than the large museums.

A treasure trove just off busy Oxford Street. I was amazed by the contents of this beautiful house in a quiet square only yards from the "top end" of Oxford St. We had caught the No.10 bus from Kings Cross Station to get here and were really pleased with what we saw. Entrance is free, there is a shop for anything from post cards to swords and armour. The displays of armour from all over the world were extensive but the armoured horses were amazing. There are also rooms of famous paintings which you would not have expected to find in a little known collection like this. There were no crowds and you could spend as much time as you loked looking at the different displays. A gem of a place. Once you leave you can be in busy Oxford St in 2 minutes.

Impressive. It's free, it's just off Oxford Street. Beautifully displayed exhibits, plenty of information, attentive staff. Laughing Cavalier the main pull, but many other works to view. The silver ware, the miniatures and the snuff boxes were amazing.

Sumptuous art collection with exquisite furniture to match- and the food…!. Comparatively intimate spaces mean that it is better to visit this museum and art gallery at times other than bank holidays - but it is well worth a detour from shopping in Bond Street, Marylebone or Oxford Street - at any time! It really feels like what it is - namely a personal collection. The furniture is ornate and exquisite and there are art works by so many well known names like Joshua Reynolds, Franz Hals and Rubens.Try to have lunch or tea in the atrium restaurant, which is beautifully designed allowing you to sit in the covered courtyard surrounded by trees and statuary. The food's great too! Sort of French brasserie style.

wonderful tour for free. Was not disappointed, very beautiful house and collection. Had had lunch just before and skipped the nice restaurant, surely will be be back later to have a more thorough experience. The was a free tour of the major sights with such a lovely lady that I learned and enjoyed more than on any history lesson at school (May 16th at 2.30 pm). Recommend warmly!

good to go. Plenty to see, although they are lots of paintings. However the weapon and armory section is interesting. Looks like it also has a nice cafe type open sunny dinning area. Will go back when I visit London again.

An excellent place to visit for art lovers. A beautiful collection of fine paintings, China collections and armory. Was amazed by everything displayed there. They have a very good restaurant as well with very helpful staff. A must see!!
Wallace's treasure. A traditional house with a artistic treasure inside...Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Velàzquez, Poussin and Canaletto
Wallace Collection. Good location behind Oxford St. Art well displayed in different rooms. Beautiful house. Recently renovated. Free entry.

A different museum experience. I agree with your best reviews here....this place is really worth a visit. The house and it's own history is amazing enough but the collection of works is superb. Girl on a Swing by Fragonard my favourite. Lovely restaurant and all the staff friendly, helpful and knowledgable.

Great day out. The food was excellent. The moules mariner was great and the portion size was spot on. The kids loved the fries and salads and the ice cream and dessert was fab. The bonus was the museum with some surprisingly famous paintings.
Great but little known stop. The Wallace is quite the amazing place. Very interesting art and artifacts. Has a very good restaurant in a beautiful atrium. And the visit is free.

Museum packed with wonder. We spent two hours at this treasure trove of paintings, ceramics and collected objets d'art and only managed 3/4 of the rooms and exhibits. So much beauty! So many new artists we had not encountered before. So many memorable pieces of art. We cannot wait to return.

Armouries visit. I visited last August but had to race around the armouries as it was about to close, so I returned 9 months later just to visit that display. Wasn't disappointed! Lots of items on display with several mobile lecterns holding a book giving information for each item. I also visited the Joseph Reynolds exhibition (on until 7 Jun 2015) which was worth very interesting. Pleasant and helpful staff, free entry (donations appreciated), lovely gift shop, courtyard restaurant cafe and away from the bustle of Oxford Street. Perfect. Look forward to visiting yet again.

Gem of a museum!. The Wallace Collection is amazing - very well laid out and described. The artwork is wonderful, the furnishings are wonderful. The cafe is perfect and very good. This is a fairly unknown museum and I highly recommend it to travelers. Do spend the money to get the audio guide - it adds very much to your visit.

Amazing. Great free exhibition including porcelain, art and armour. Located over two floors which we took two days to view. This is a lot less crowd than the other major galleries, in fact some rooms we were on our own.
armour galore. The best collection of armour in the South of England along with some brilliant paintings; namely 'The Laughing Cavalier' and 'The Swing'.
A hidden gem. Its a fabulous collection of special art in a lovely building. The café is in a light an airy atrium and the whole visit was a surprise and a delight.

A great hidden gem. I went here ages ago...would never have known that this place even existed if it weren't for my companion who led me there. It's a great oasis amidst the hubbub of Oxford Street and Bond Street.I especially liked the suits of armor.
Love this place. This is one museum I visit on a regular basis as it is not as crowded as others and it a lovely quiet haven, it also has a very good cafe.
A must visit!. There really is nothing to dislike! A fabulous collection housed in a beautiful building in the centre of London. Quite simply world class and amazing.
Rococo galore. Gorgeous museum with totally over the top décor, artifacts and paintings plus some pretty nice Canaletto's.

Must visit.... One of my friends recommended me to this place..and I must admit I was not disappointed at all. This place holds some of the most stunning art works. I was pleasantly surprised. It is close to the ever busy Oxford street. Must visit atleast once.

Hidden treasures. What a treasure trove of masterpieces, fantastic ceramics and elaborate furniture. There is also an interesting display of armour and weapons. Chilling but beautifully carved and created.
It's incredible to learn about the acquisitions for this house
Great cafe as well to revive, when you are finally exhausted.
Absolutely gorgeous. Breathtaking collection of beautiful objects. I was lucky to be alone and I was in awe of everything. Don't know why I haven't been before

Stunning. This is one of those places that you never get round to visiting after living in London for so long and wonder why you never visited before. It's a gorgeous place. I especially love the green room.
Hidden gem. Not so many travellers visit since they visits either National Museum or Tates Britain. This should be the place if you would like to avoid congestion.
BSL Provider for deaf people. I enjoyed tour, the museum is an excellent for provide bsl interprter or deaf lecture for deaf and hard of hearing people

A hidden gem. This was not on my list to see in London initially until referred to it by a friend. It was most interesting and worth a visit. Easy to walk to from the busyness of Oxford Street, it is simply packed with treasures. Suits of armour, weapons, great masters especially by Dutch artists, and a nice cafe in the middle. And free entry. Take a look.

What a find a few blocks in back of Selfridges. Previously visited almost all art museums in London. Finally made it to the Wallace. This was quite an overwhelming experience. The fantastic variety of art work was wonderful. Discovered a number of school groups being lectured about various works and found that interesting as well. Decided to take a break for lunch and discovered a truly gourmet restaurant in the Wallace. One of the best collections I have enjoyed in some time.

a free gem in the heart of London. Returned to visit the museum after it's refurbishment and was not disappointed. It wasn't over crowded and used the information cards in each room to learn a bit more about the paintings, antiques and who lived there. Had a coffee and soup in the café, which was reasonably priced. I have a disability and used the lift as the stairs are quite steep and the toilets are one of the best I had seen in a museum - clean, individual facilities with own sink and vanity area to powder your nose. They also have trails for children and audio headphones so would highly recommend to family and friends with children

Lovely visit. There is so much to see here, not just pictures ( not forgetting the Laughing Cavalier - who is not really laughing..). There are some wonderful pieces of furniture ( very intricate marquetry workmanship), hidden under lift able covers fantastic miniatures the detail of which will amaze you, snuff boxes which are as ornate as a faberge egg and much more.Because this seems to still be a hidden gem it is not over busy and the rooms are spacious, some of which have been renovated. My only gripe is the restaurant/ cafe is a trifle expensive but is a work of art in its own right being a glass covered area at the back of the building.

A real gem in the middle of London!. I went here with my girlfriends after a lunch out and we just loved it! Its so beautiful inside and the guide was fascinating. The paintings are wonderful and steeped in stories and history, as is the building itself and the objects to look at are beautiful and timeless. To top off our wonderful time here we ended with afternoon tea in a stunning glass roofed room which makes you feel like you are outside, but protected from the elements. Well worth a visit!

mind boggling collection. If you don't have time to do many different museums, and just want a quick overview of the best of European and some Asian art, including paintings, laquerware, armoury (horse and human), china, glassware, snuff boxes, silverware, then head to this unassuming collection in the London mansion of the Wallace family. Another free museum, bring the kids and goggle at the knights in 100 lb armour, the horses in full metal, then pop them upstairs to view a few Rembrandts, Fragonards, Hals, Gainsboroughs. When your brain and feet can take no more go to the covered central court for tea and scones, or a glass of wine if you need reviving.

A superb collection in a magnificent building that's free.. A bit off the tourist track, the visitors respectful, a gem of a small Poussin, Velazquez, marvelous French Rococo, armor, smalls. Something for most everyone.

Quiet little gallery. The Wallace Collection is a jewel in the midst of busy Marylebone. Up the street from Selfridges, it is quiet and comforting. The collection is amazing as is the new restaurant and the workshops and lectures which are often free.

Every London should visit. A wonderful collection that is free to the public. I can't believe I only found it after having lived in London for 8 years. It's a real gem. I will now send all my friends and visitors there.

Wonderful... and free. Great way to spend an afternoon. Artwork, sculptures and armoury collection dating from 1500-1900 set in a beautiful London town house. Make sure you catch the guided tour you will appreciate the works so much more.
Great for the kids. 120 to find, great fun for the kids. Get a map to show different routes for long walks or short. Enjoy

Very very interesting. Loved this place. Situated on Manchester Square in W1, you can walk there from Marylebone where we stayed.The Wallace Collection is a superb and FREE museum of so much interesting stuff. It has the Laughing Cavalier d much more interesting to me, a superb and expansive collection of historical Armour and Weaponry.It also has a lovely courtyard restaurant which we didn't try but it looked lovely.A brilliant, peaceful trip into olden times.Well worth a visit.
A great armour collection. Many types of armour and weapons, works of art when behind glass and not in use. A room on a lower floor has chainmail you can try on if you can lift it!

So much wealth. This is a collection of another era. Its hard to imagine living in such a place but the walls lined with silk, the hand crafted furniture and objet d'art are well worth the visit. The paintings that also adorn the walls are an interesting snapshot of social history.

A Hidden Gem in London's Mayfair Neighborhood. The Wallace Collection is a former private collection of art that was bequeathed to the British people in the early 1900s. Located just north of Manchester Square, the former Hertford House holds many treasures. The large collection comprises paintings, sculpture, decorative objects, and an extremely large collection of European armor and weaponry. It is easy to get close to the art here. This is a very intimate gallery that clearly makes an effort to educate its patrons and allow them to enjoy the art on a very personal level. Each room has a printed booklet describing the artworks in that room, and the information does a great job with the provenance of much of the art, describing when the works were added to the collection. There are many paintings by well-known artists, including Rembrandt, Frans Hals, and Canaletto, to name just a few. Don't miss looking at the decorative items, including furniture, chandeliers, clocks, and urns. The shop is very nice, the restrooms are clean, and the restaurant's menu looks good, although I did not eat there. Admission to the Wallace Collection is free.

Very interesting!. Lots of beautiful pieces to see from art to furniture to an amazing collection of armoury. Not as well known as other galleries so lots of times during our visit we were the only ones around which felt really special.

A gem in central London.. A wonderful house only a few minutes walk from Bond Street station. A return visit to the Reynolds exhibition. We went round some of the rooms. So much to enjoy, we will go again soon.
Small Treasure. Compact museum, with eclectic mix of displays from paintings to arms and armour. Well worth a visit, situated just off Oxford Street. Restaurant and snack/coffee area under glass.
A hidden treasure. Not vwery well know but not to be m issed in you love art. And a very good restaurant in the covered courtyard. Beautiful.

Surprise Hidden Gem. The Wallace was so interesting because of the range of art work that make up the collection. It was really great to see this art in a less formal setting than a typical museum. The opulent house was full of beautiful furniture and objets d'art that made the whole visit all the more worthwhile. We also had tea in the courtyard which was lovely. The entrance fee is free (with a donation suggested).
Fabulous place to visit, great afternoon tea!!. this is a very good place to chill out with friends. Very nice small gallery and fabulous afternoon tea... Great atmosphere..

Fantastic collection - free and so close to Oxford Street. Beautiful building and such a good collection to view. So peaceful and interesting as well. Although busy, it never felt like it was over crowded unlike the "national" galleries/museums.

Simply glorious . This has to be one of the standout collections in London if not the UK.Located in a lovely London Square, the Wallace is a great collection of paintings, furniture, sculpture and silverware. We shall be going back as we were preoccupied by the paintings so need to go to have a good look at the furniture, sculpture etc.Free entry and of course a chance to see The Laughing Cavalier. Plenty of other greats on show including Gainsborough, Reynolds, Rubens, Rembrandt, Watteau, Cuyp, the list goes on.This is a sumptuous house and well worth spending a couple of hours wondering around at a time. We will certainly be going back, again and again.

Beautiful cafe but bad pink lemonade!. The cafe is an exquisite covered courtyard, possibly one of the most beautiful places to sit in London. We enjoyed a rose wine however the homemade pink lemonade (£4.50 plus usual 12% service charge) was a bit disappointing - didn't taste of lemons or raspberries, more like flavoured water. I tried to liven it up with sugar and squeezing a lemon slice into it but still couldn't drink more than half. A shame as it looked so pretty and pink in the glass!I probably should have just sent it back but I didn't want to spoil the mood as I was with friends. I'll definitely return to try the teas (they had a great selection) and the cakes, which looked incredible.
Wonderful. lovely items and building. And it's free. A real gem. Lots of fine paintings, furniture and collections.

Historic splendour. The house, grounds and furniture are all so opulent. The art and pieces of interest were the cherry on the pie, one of my favourite days in UK. Some of the chandeliers are breathtaking, who cleans it all? What a job. The restaurant is a nice way to end and let it all sink in. Superb collection.

Beautiful and facinating. Beautiful historic home with unbelievable collection of Art , furniture and porcelain. I had lunch on my own in the lovely greenhoused restaurant which was delicious and went on the docent led tour which was wonderful.

Perfection. I have visited the Wallace Collection on many occasions and it still never fails to impress. I like how the rooms are set up and kept, as well as the many fine works of art, porcelain, furniture, the upholstery and wall coverings are a thing of great beauty in their own right. The armour and weaponary section could take a whole afternoon to get around it is so comprehensive, I really do think the WC has something on offer for everyone.

So much to see here; the guides make it live. There is so much top quality art here - almost too much to comprehend, but the guides make it accessible and highlight the mian items. Nice (though expensive and inefficient) cafe)

Overwhelming How Much Art. We tacked this museum on to our day that went from Harrods to Harvey Nickel to Selfridges. We were blown away at how much this museum had to offer. There was just room after room of stunning artwork. And we didn't even hit the armory. We ended our tour with wonderful tea. Well the scone was only so so. But the setting was calming and delightful. Come and enjoy this lovely museum and tea room.

Favourite place in London. I'd live here if I could. Such a wonderful collection of armour, weapons and art and laid out really practically for seeing everything properly. Ideal location for dates, family outings or chats with friends, I can't think of anything it doesn't work for and it's often quiet, which makes the experience even better. Love, love, love it.
great art. it is lovely to have a rest after viewing the collection. Tea and scrumptious cakes in an airy environment fill the spot after a browse of the collection. Friendly service too

Absolutely Amazing. Wow, what a collection of everything beautiful,never been to a museum so well presented and varied in its collections. All so well displayed, the cafe is a lovely addition and the carrot cake is to die for.

Quiet haven of Peace. The rooms are just packed with ornate furnishings and pictures, so a bit of overload there, but it is free and we only spent 20 minutes there. IT was a nice break and there are some very high quality items to view, the Rembrandts were tops for us.

Excellent museum and its free. Whenever we are in the area we try to go to the Wallace Collection. Its a splendid museum and you can get a feel for what it was like as a house. They also have a great restaurant in a fantastic setting. And its one of the few things you can do in London that's FREE.

Small venue, great collection. Many people go to the big museums such as the National Gallery, British Museum, V&A for the wonderful collections inside however it is worth visiting the small venues such as the John Soane, Courtauld, Wallace as they have some amazing art as well. The Wallace Collection is well worth visiting, it is not big but has some amazing art including an entire room of Canaletto's (my favorite). Being set in the Wallace home is unique and adds to the experience. Enjoy!

Very nice places to take in some art. Really enjoyed the Wallace Collection. Like how it's in a large home - unique setting. Worth paying a visit when in London and doesn't take much time to go through, unlike some other museums in the city.
Gorgeous art collection in decadent settings. Well worth a visit if you are into art, museums and all things olde worlde English - love the collection and loved the gorgeous setting.

An intimate gallery. It really is like visiting a stately home as the collection is a private one in the collectors home! a wonderful range of pictures including Canalettos and the Laughing Cavaliet. Cafe in a glassed- in courtyard is expensive.

Wallace Collection. Great free exhibition including porcelain, art and armour. Located over two floors which we took two days to view. This is a lot less crowd than the other major galleries, in fact some rooms we were on our own.
Outstanding for pictures, furniture and decor. Free entry with a good selection of picture, furniture, clock masterpieces - some very well-known. Good place for lunch or refreshments.
who can guess this is all private?!. This huge collection was all for one family before! it is just feel previlage to visit. the richness of the collection is very very good!
Stunning Situation. Very pretty atrium with excellent food. Rather hot in Summer .Service was a bit slow and the Staff did not all understand English.
Fragonnard paintings. The paintings alone are worth the visit to London. A small intimate museum. Restaurant always very busy but good food.

Perfect size collection in a beautiful house. I loved this art collection. It wasn't overly enormous, and it was set in his old house, so the presentation was beautiful. We almost skipped this when in London and I'm so glad we didn't because it was worth the trip. Definitely don't need more than an hour.
Superb. One of the best art collections in the world -seriously good place to visit whether you're a culture vulture or a tourist.

Excellent setting; less than average service and portions. The Wallace Collection is one of the jewels of London; I visit it repeatedly with sustained interest on each visit. The restaurant is 'French'; it is under a beautiful glass atrium with beautiful table settings. Unfortunately this is not matched by dilatory and slightly supercilious service combined with less than generous portions. It is poor value such that I do not eat there as often as I would otherwise.

Amazingly rich collection of art, beautiful setting with so much attention to detail. A must-see, admittance-free.. There's nothing to dislike. It's a classic. Amazing paintings, spectacular rooms, a very tasty place. It takes a long time to actually see everything, so allow half a day on site if you want to truly enjoy the experience. Non-flash pictures allowed, by the way.

One of the best museums in London. Great free museum with some unexpectedly famous pictures like the laughing cavalier. Requires several more visits. Staff very helpful and knowledgeable. Food at cafe/restaurant also superb.

A gem in the shopping district. Took some out-of-town visitors on the Great Oxford Street Shopping Experience, but when it came time for a rest and a break from rampant commercialism, led them off to the Wallace Collection. Followed by a civilised snack at the restaurant/coffee shop. Both were extremely successful, beating Selfridges into a cocked hat!

Hidden jewel and free!. One of the hidden treats of London. Not far from Oxford Street so a welcome respite from the frenetic shopping. Inside it is like a jewellery box of art treasures. Some of the best bits have recently been rehung and are looking great. We were lucky enough to go on a tour with an art historian which was really illuminating though not essential. Often small changing exhibitions in underground gallery which are interesting (in fact it was years before we had time to visit the real gems)Upmarket restaurant in enclosed courtyard is a very nice place to eat too and is open in evenings and for lunch. Think it does afternoon tea too so this would make quite a good treat/present outing for the right person!

Allow time. This varied collection of artistic treasures is worth your time to visit. It is free as well although there is a charge for audio tour sets. The setting is a beautiful house with galleries added specifically to showcase art collected by the owners. The museum opened to the public in 1900. The collection, which can never be loaned, holds French 18th century paintings, beautiful furniture, an extensive collection of arms and arm our, porcelain and clocks. Some of the Old Masters paintings you will never see elsewhere includie Van Dyck, Reynolds, Rembrandt, Boucher, Velazques and others. It is a short pleasant walk from Oxford street on Bond Street. The mansion alone is worth touring there is also a courtyard restaurant which seemed popular.

I could spend hours here. My wife and my three daughters were doing there best to buy oxford street ,I drifted to this lovely place ,I have to say I have been so many times it never stops getting better ,my mother would take my sister and my self and it amazed me then ,staff are polite ,noticed I was deaf and talked to me clearly so I could lip read a huge thank you

Everything for the cultured. The Wallace collection is a grand house smack in the middle of London filled with art treasures - and free entrance! The paintings, armoury, furniture and the building itself make it one of my favourite places in London. The tea room in the courtyard is a tranquil oasis and oddly enough one of London's best kept public secrets. Great for a stroll, excellent for a date or just dream away while gazing at beautiful objects. I find myself returning time and time again...
Great place for afternoon tea. Nice exhibition near Oxford Street. We had champagne afternoon tea and strolled round the exhibition.
One of my favourites in London!. Great collection of weaponry and armour, beautiful paintings and great items in the gift shop. Free and close to Oxford Street if you want to break for lunch!
fraantastic. A feast of a collection, had to be seen to be a ppreciated. We had wanted to view this collection for some time and walking thorugh it did not disappoint

What a wonderful surprise!. It was a surprise to me when I entered this museum. It wasn't my plan to go there but since I was at the St. Christopher's Place, and I've done much of my sightseeing that day, I decided to stop by. It was 4pm so I thought it'll be enough time to check this place out. I was so impressed with their selection of the paintings and objects(?). They had everything in this beautiful building! Sure it's smaller than London's major museums, but it's got things you would see at V&A, Tate Britain and even Tower of London all in one place! They had amazing collection of armories on the ground level. As you walk through the rooms on the upper level, you'll see paintings ,scriptures and furnitures beautifully arranged around the rooms, and I noticed many paintings are in amazingly beautiful and unusual gold frames! Each room has different color walls and chandeliers, and a spacious cafe in the middle. I wish I had more time there! Don't underestimate time. This is a small museum compare to the other major museums, but 1 hour was not nearly enough for me to see all. Very impressive museum. Enjoy your visit!
Great Collection. Situated behind Selfridges on Manchester Sq. A vast collection of Art, furniture and armoury with free entry. Leave at least two hours for visit, guided tours at 2:30pm.

London's answer to the Frick. Too gorgeous for words, really. Luxury noble house, really a mini-palace, in Manchester Square, two blocks from Selfridges. Beautifully appointed rooms and also a nice shop and restaurant. Classic painted mainly 16th-19th centuries. Rooms full of breathtaking Dutch and Flemish Old Masters, as well as French and English portraiture and landscapes, plus other masters. Highlights include Hals's "The Laughing Cavalier", Fragonard "The Swing", Downstairs, a roomful of Canalettos, anothe with massive Dutch still-lifes, huge armour and ceramics collection plus famous portaits of the young Victoria, George III, and also Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester (the love of Elizabeth I's life). Occasional exhibitions, mainly from their own holdings, as well.

Beautiful collections. Beautiful rooms with art work, furniture, and china. Also, collections of guns and armor. Do the second floor first. We spent too much time on the first floor and had to rush through the second floor.

A treasure in London's centre. An impressive collection of paintings, precious objects and the original atmosphere of a 19th century house in London. Old fashioned but intrigiung style of presentation. Café and restaurant in the courtyard are excellent for a refreshing stop.

Interesting antique collection. Hertford House is situated right in the middle of London, within walking distance of Bond Street tube station. The house itself is a beautiful Georgian building; set in small, but immaculate, grounds. The property houses an incredible collection of paintings and artefacts called the Wallace Collection, which is named after Sir Richard Wallace who was the son of the Marquess of Hertford (who was the original owner of the house and the creator of the collection). The collection has been given to the nation on the understanding that the collection is kept intact. The collection is extensive, covering the periods from the 15th through to the 19th century. It comprises many French, Dutch and Italian paintings as well as antique French furniture and a full armoury. There is a lot to see - in fact, probably my only criticism is that there are so many paintings on view in a small space that one can end up with information overload. However, as the exhibition is free - one option would be to visit different rooms on different days. There is also an excellent cafe - which offers lunches as well as a good cream tea. It also has a great selection of cakes, including a wonderful gluten free orange and plum cake!

Museum gem in the heart of London. On our final day in London our friends recommended that we should visit the Wallace Collection. We took the tube to Marble Arch and it was just a short walk to the museum. It was named after Sir Richard Wallace and houses a fine collection of art from Medieval and Renaissance art, to Dutch and Flemish art of the 17th Century, and French art of the 18th Century. The ground floor has exhibits of European and Oriental Armoury. The first floor consists of different art galleries full of famous paintings and fine furnishings. We walked through beautiful drawing rooms, State Rooms, and finished off our visit with delicious teas in the outdoor glass topped conservatory area. There is no entrance fee but a donation is appreciated. You may also like to collect the odd souvenir at the gift shop. It was a wonderful way to finish seeing London.

Interesting piece of history. The Wallace Collection is a must... amazing place were I could go back in time. The premises were luxurious and the amount of things collect is amazing. I loved the blue room

One of my favourite galleries in London. Very beautiful art collection. Love the architecture of the house and the cafe in the courtyard is great to catch up with friends in a quite and fashionable place

Wonderful collection and home of The Swing. The paintings are excellent here. The Swing, The Laughing Cavalier. The armor collection was wonderful. I fully enjoyed this small but perfect museum. It is not overrun with tourists, it is free, and well worth the visit. I highly recommend it!!!!

Excellent collection -- something for everyone. Masterpieces by Rembrandt, armor and weaponry, Marie Antoinette's furniture, religious art, stately rooms -- you can bring your large diverse family here and everyone will find something of interest. And its free! And Selfridges is a couple blocks away. This museum lets you take non-flash pictures and they are stuffy or arrogant. And there is a central atrium cafe for when you need refreshments. And there is a beautiful London square park across the street. Can't beat this place!
Amazing place!. Brilliant collection - something for everyone. Paintings are spectacular and location is magnificent. An elegant building full of treasures.
nice. loved it fresh friendly and relaxing liked it a lots stayed with family sam was nice wand helpful wityh us all

A must see... The V&A is my favorite place, but this is a close second.There are some fantastic pictures, be they the "dark" period.. But something for anyone.Lots of small rooms and many levels, very well laid out.Especially liked the armor collection down stairs.Not that well signed, but well worth the walk to get their.
Good for the history buffs. Really went because my partner wanted to look at this place but I enjoyed it more than I expected to! A very extensive collection - and it's free entry.

Incredible . To be honest we aren't huge fans of art but we loved the Wallace Collection for the building, the interior, the furniture, the collection of armory and the art. And it's nestled in the middle of the Marylebone neighborhood of London. Closest Underground for us was Baker Street but the Bond Street station might be better if you are taking the Central or Jubilee lines. While it is free admission it is best to offer a £4 donation.

opulence personified. If you like 18th century French paintings, furniture, porcelain, etc., this is the place for you. You will also find medieval manuscrip illustrations, 17th c Dutch and Spanish paintings, 19th c British art, and lots more. Surprinsing especially when one realizes it was all collected by one family.
Quaint, lovely. We visited after a recommendation and would recommend to others. Artwork displayed in what was once a private residence and home to the 'Laughing Cavalier'.

London's hidden gem. This more than lived up to expectation! The Wallace Collection is situated in Manchester Square behind Selfriges store. The moment you step into the square it's hard to believe this is in the heart of London.Entry is free but there is a request of donations. Worth every penny you choose to put in the pot but it also means that nobody is excluded from visiting.It houses so many famous paintings , I was delighted to see'The Laughing Cavalier' and paintings by Cavaletto . But the armoury collection is a must see! You can even try on the chain mail .Whilst there we enjoyed afternoon tea in a very pleasant sunlit cafe .Defiantly recommend a visit

An Osasis in the City. I had not discovered tis gem before despite many visits to London,it was so fabulous to step away from this century and go back and feel you were visiting a Family home filled with beautiful, treasured objects. We had lunch in the courtyard which was perfect as well. A lovely quiet day in an incredible setting!

Nice Paintings, Nice Food. I am not a huge art fan, but I was captivated by a number of paintings in this collection, particularly the paintings of animals. There is also a room full of great paintings of Venice. When you are ready for a break from the art there is a lovely restaurant in an enclosed courtyard in the middle of the building, full of natural light but not cold. They serve lunch and afternoon tea from 2.30pm. We all enjoyed the afternoon tea. I was quite surprised to find this excellent museum in this part of London, not far from Oxford Street.
outstanding collection. The Wallace has an outstanding collection of paintings. Not only the amazingly beautiful Velasquez or the Rembrandt.

Don't miss this gem. I can't say enough good things about this home, turned museum. This is the place to send out-of-town guests; they will come back so impressed at the collections of furniture and masters' art. Wait until you see the great hall. Be prepared to sit and quietly soak up the beauty of the room and the art for at least 15 minutes.

A quiet retreat from the West End bustle. A fine old building housing a wonderful collection of artefacts including "The Laughing Cavalier" It was great to sit there and contemplate this famous painting.There's a Rembrandt self-portrait and a fine display of English pictures from the 18th Century, among others.Must mention the café in the atrium where we had smoked salmon and scrambled eggs to die for. Highly recommended.

BEST LITTLE MUSEUM IN LONDON. This museum is by no means large in size but it one of the best balanced i have been to with something for everyone to see. Art , Armour and a lot lot more. Done forget to look at the wax artwork.Amazing.

Exhausting and Exhilarating. Check out their excellent website before you go--it really helps you to prioritize what you most want to see. You will enjoy it much more that way. Do you want to see the armor? Or mostly the paintings? If the armor, start on the ground floor; if the paintings start on the first floor. Don't miss lifting the covers on the cases in the middle of the rooms--the miniatures and illuminated manuscripts are exquisite. If you love postcards, be sure to visit the gift shop, as they have the best selection of any gallery in London (of the paintings in their collection).
Great Discovery!. Amazing collection, the paintings, the armours, the furniture, the chandeliers, everything was beautiful. If you ever have the chance to see it, please do.
camp as a row of tents and lots of fun. gorgeous gorgeous gorgeousgot to see my favourite painting ever - The Swing - for real. what a treat! And free!

Stunning hidden secret in middle of London. A great way to spend a Sunday afternoon - incredible opulent décor and a huge collection of armoury. Fantastic for adults and kids and one to do over several visits.

Superb Gem. This collection is an almost overwhelming array of fabulous objets, so be prepared to linger in order to absorb the grandeur of it all. It is located in a lovely part of London, well worth a stroll. Enjoy the small but well curated Gift Shop. And don't pass up the opportunity to treat yourself to tea in the courtyard.

A gem of a museum. This museum has been going for a very long time but is often neglected by visitors to London. It's a must. Just off Oxford Street and with some beautiful objects. Plus an internal courtyard where you can have a very nice cream tea.

Fabulous hidden gem in London. Beautiful art collection, hidden away close to Selfridges. Wonderful place to while away an afternoon away from the throng of tourists. Great place for grabbing afternoon tea too.

Extensive. An incredible array of art work and artifacts collected over manygenerations by an exceptionally privileged family living in this beautiful house situated in the West End of London a stones throw from Oxford Street.Paintings by Joshua Reynolds, Rembrandt, Canaletto to name but a few, priceless china beautifully displayed, suits of armour, clocks and exquisite furniture all cleverly displayed over the 3 or4 floors of this wonderful house in itself a sight to behold.In the centre courtyard there is large very acceptable restaurantwhere you can eat or drink at your leisure.Amazingly the visit is completely free but you are asked for a voluntary donation on the way out which would be churlish to refuse.Allow plenty of times to view all the treasures as this is truly a very extensive collection

Great small museum next to Oxford. I loved this small museum for years and it did not disappoint again.You can spend here half an hour or 4 hours and enjoy..I loved the armors and the weaponsHighly Recommended.

What a gem. We timed our visit for coffee before the daily free guided tour. The restaurant is in the original inner courtyard, now covered, and is quite up market. The tour was wonderful with a really enthusiastic guide who had insights into everything. The Wallace collection has more character than a museum because it is a family collection with idiosyncrasies which are endearing. We can't last more than an hour and a half so we're going to have to return.

Amazing place, must see . I didn't even know this place was existing, I went there for the first time just because my boyfriend was working there. All rooms are amazing, great classic style, and the collection of armour is really interesting :)
interesting. great art in a superb setting. Thi.s is a special place for art lovers with eclectic tastes as so many different specimens

Great Armor and Wonderful Tea. Thought it would be more like the Frick in NYC, yet it is more of a hodge-podge of stuff. That said, their armor collection is one of the best I have ever seen and the tea in their garden was sublime. Nice excursion in the Marylebone area of London.

Lovely. Beautiful estate with a private art collection.
Great restaurang, so plan to eat or snack here.
Walk around and enjoy the art and house.

Little known gem in central London. This is a London house, filled with art, furniture, silver ware, porcelain, armour and collectables brought together by a succession of members of the family. The restaurant is set in a glass covered courtyard and the selection of food is very good. Only a few minutes to Selfridges. What is more impressive is that it is free to enter.

Hidden Treasure. A gallery set in a former stately home close to Oxford Street. So much to see, paintings, furniture and in beautiful surroundings. The former Courtyard is now a restaurant. Well worth a visit and it is free.

Special Sunday treats!. First visit-an amazing collection of art and armour and pottery and glass and all for free! (Donations accepted of course!) there is also an amazing space in the courtyard (glass roof) with super food and drinks.
Be warned you will plenty of time to do it justice!

interesting smaller museum for a brief cultural fix. interesting range of collections - both for him and her. small enough to drag kids through - giving them brief exposures to culture - they wont have time to get bored. just a stone's throw from the shops and restaurrants of Oxford street (due north of selfridges)

Unexpected Treasure. Maria of the Rhodes Hotel recommended this museum to us on our 2nd trip to London. It is not among the city museums. It is in Westminster, about a 15 minute walk from Kensington Garden. There has a wide range of art and artifacts. The building was once a home. A beautiful garden is just across the street. Worth the visit.

Superb collection of art, ceramics and furniture, and free entry. I had not visited the Wallace before despite many years of gallery trips to London. It is unusual in being in a house setting in central London, with rooms designated bedrooms, dining rooms and so on, yet entirely given to an art collection built up by the former owner. Paintings, ceramics and furniture are combined together in the lower rooms, while the Great Hall on the upper floor is mainly a painting gallery, where the collection includes the famous Laughing Cavalier by Hals, and others by Rembrandt, Velazquez and Titian. The Wallace was opened as early as 1904 as a public attraction, and it was great to find that entry is still free.
A superb hidden gem. This is a must visit art gallery, but you need several hours to do it justice. Every gallery is a delight and the range of artists is mind blowing ....... and it is free!

A Priceless Collection.. Located just to the north of Oxford Street so easy to find, if a little tucked away, this originally private collection is truly magnificent.Housed in a superb example of a prime London town house, you will be able to view wonderful pieces of antique furniture and priceless works of art, including the superb old master, The Laughing Cavalier.Time well spent by us, and greatly enjoyed.

A treat, especially for fans of 18th century art. This museum houses a collection that would especially appeal to fans of 18th century French visual and decorative arts. There is also an extensive collection of arms and armor.The collection is housed in a beautiful former residence. The rooms are well laid out and nicely lit. There weren't great crowds, so it was easy to spend time with individual works and there was good access to the wall text. The information about provenance is particularly interesting to me and the collection illustrates the fate of art during times of political upheaval.
back in the past. All was good elegant/ stilish def be back soon need more time to see all , i would consider bit music under it was to silents

A little known gem in the heart of London. The Wallace collection is a delightful gallery/ museum/ restaurant/stately home right in then centre of London - just a short walk from OxfodStreet but feels likes million miles away. I have been there many times over the years and it is always fascinating. The gallery has a number of paintings that are very well known and that you do not not expect to come across in such a small gallery. And from experience I can say that the collection of armour appeals to young children. The restaurant was very good although I haven't eaten there recently. I would highly recommend visiting even if only to recharge your batteries before heading back to Oxford Street.

Excellent Art Collection. I have visited the Wallace Collection many times over the years and always enjoy it. There is so much to see that you need several visits to take it all in. It is a hidden gem in London that a lot of people do not know about. A short walk from Oxford Street and a welcome oasis of calm and beauty.

A wealth of pictures & artefacts to see. Though a fascinating place to visit there is just too much to take in on one visit. I would suggest getting a floor plan & focussing on the items that appeal to your particular group. There are some very fine examples of paintings, miniatures, items of pottery ,religious artefacts & armoury but sadly too much to absorb. The collection needs some way of highlighting the treasures of which there are many. I would recommend looking at a section visiting the café & then moving to another section. Despite the drawbacks we enjoyed the day very much & will return on another day to see more.

Visit the web page beforehand!. This little museum is an absolute gem and just the right size for people who would not normally visit museums. It's worth it to examine the web page of the collection beforehand to spot the best pieces - furniture from the Versailles and some great 18th century oils.
Beautiful, interesting museum. Such a beautiful museum. Cafe in a great setting, quite pricey food, but the collection itself is very interesting and I wish I lived in the house!

A gem in a City of plenty. We were told about the collection by a local friend, we only had 2 hours to spend there, should be enough but wasn't. We spent too much time admiring the huge, diverse collection of Armour, the paintings and the furniture are amazing too, all in somebodys house!
Beautiful. I love the grandeur of this place. It is also free. It's one of those places I mean to spend more time in but I feel blessed to have this on my doorstep.
What a gem.. Wonderful collection which is free to visit, with a beautiful cafe inside. Enquire about free guided tours.

Everything a gallery should be. Perfect setting for some of the world's great paintings, with a bit of something for everyone. It is free so you can wander in for five minutes or stay for an hour or two. Great conservatory cafe - nice ambience and does a decent cup of tea and a scone.

Best gallery in the world. Beautiful collection in a gorgeous old building with a marvellous restaurant too. Absolutely love the Wallace Collection - I go there every time I'm in London. Where else can you see stunning works of art, furniture, armoury and porcelain for free? Just fantastic!

How fabulous!. We are frequent visitors to London but had never visited the museum before. We spent hours here one Saturday, first taking a tour with a charming lady named Cecilia, she was extremely informative and clearly quite passionate about the collection - and no wonder! There are exquisite treasures everywhere, we only covered one floor because there was simply so much to take in and admire. We had a lovely lunch and our Italian waiter (from near Rimini) was attentive and friendly. We will be back!

Eclectic and civilised. The collection of weapons is vast and eclectic, from the Sikhs to the medieval period. The pieces are shown off well, with the mounted knights staggering some 16-18 year olds I recently took there on a trip. They questioned why I had not taken them there when they were 11 and studying this period! Others may prefer the artwork and there are lots of interesting objects from timepieces to paintings. There is a lovely restaurant there and also a venue for lectures - in all you feel that due reverence is being paid to these wonderful objects and to the creators of these objects.

Stunning Armoury. Had researched this museum on line as heard it was good and it didn't disappoint. Stunning armoury collection, beautifully displayed that you could almost see it being worn. An absolute gem of a find in London once again. So easy to find off Oxford Street with a very beautiful restaurant serving reasonably priced food and drinks. Museum totally free to visit but donations excepted but not expected.Room after room of exquisite art that means I will have to visit again to take it all in!

Quality, manageable museum in London. A fantastic, smaller collection in a once private residence that parallels the Frick in Manhattan. The Wallace collection houses mostly Rococco, so not for modern art lovers.

Day out with friends. Well worth a visit. We took advantage of, and very much enjoyed, the free house tour at 2.30pm. House is packed with fascinating and valuable objets d'art and paintings.Unfortunately, such is the popularity of the restaurant, that we could not get in for lunch (suggest booking at least several days ahead) but we enjoyed a coffee there later in very pleasant surroundings.100% recommended.

Great palace and art collection . This museum has been a pleasure to visit. The house itself is magnificent but what it contains is absolutely amazing. It has paintings from Van dick, Canaletto, Rembrandt among the others and the porcelain collection is also beautiful. Last but not least comes the forniturebwith many impressive pieces from the 18th century some of which belonged to Marie Antoinette Queen of France. The museum is free of charge a d I would suggest to stop by to anyone visiting London.
A real hidden gem.... A real hidden gem and well worth a visit. The collection is stunning, eclectic and very well presented.

Excellent Art Collection. I spent a happy couple of hours looking around the Wallace Collection. It has something for everybody, including fine art by great British, Italian, Belgian and Dutch artists amongst others, miniatures, porcelain, gold boxes, beautiful furniture and armoury, all in a lovely setting. There is a fascinating Reynolds exhibition on until June 2015, showing a small selection of Reynolds' paintings, with infrared and x-ray images of many of the paintings, showing previous versions, changes made along the way, etc.The atrium restaurant is lovely, too, light and airy, with a good selection of teas and cakes, crisp white napkins and smartly dressed staff.A hidden gem - don't miss it!
Beautiful place for enjoying beautiful things in life. They have a vast collection of antiques and paintings. You could literally walk there around whole day.
Best breakfast in London. Wallace Collection is a hidden gem. The collection itself is superb, and best matched with a breakfast in the cafe.

A Gem. A very relaxed place to visit. Interesting collections.Only downside for us was having to uncover some cabinets. I realise the items have to be protected but I feel the staff could do this first and last thing but there again the covers would have to be stored. Free but worth a donation.

London's best kept secret collection.. The Wallace Collection is the most amazing private house collection of works from famous Masters, in terms of fine art, furniture, porcelain and simply wonderful artefacts. As you walk around the house, you are surprised at the works you see before your eyes - which you would only expect to see in say The Louvre or the most famous of world capital museums. The setting in the house is simply splendid and it is a stone's throw from Bond Street. It does not tend to be crowded, so you can walk around at your leisure. When you get tired, visit the atrium cafe / restaurant, you won't be disappointed with that either! If you are looking for a treat - the afternoon tea is superb and it is in a stunning setting. A real hidden gem all round.
Outstanding. A wonderful combination of old home and artwork. Well worth the visit for a relaxing time. Also has a lovely cafe in the atrium.

A hidden treasure in London. very often people overlook the Wallace Collection and dont bother going to see it. However i feel its one of the best collections in London and would recommend everyone to visit. Its highly inspiring and every time i go back i always find something new that i hadnt noticed before.
A fine collection. A real hidden gem in Central London! Delightful and magical! Such a wonderful place to have tea and cake!

Great place for lunch. The atrium cafe or restaurant is a great hidden gem for lunch. The collection is worth seeing once, unless you are really into German armoury or vividly coloured Italian plate. But as it is free you can't complain.
Great for afternoon tea. The afternoon tea here is fabulous. The scones are home made, usually served warm and are delicious.

I love this place. I have enjoyed many visits to this wonderful art collection which is a haven in the hustle and bustle of Oxford street shopping. It is so good I kind of don't want to tell anyone about it. I have often called in between meetings used the cloakroom to store my trolly case and then worked in the cafe with a coffee to prepare for my next meeting. I then go and look in one of the rooms and take in the art and the decor. This is a place to return to, you don't need hours to look around and its free.

Really beautiful.... As beautiful as the Versailles and utterly breathtaking.An incredible collection of art and armour/weaponry with a delightful caffe in the centre.The most incredible part is that it's another one of London's free museums, and we liked it so much that we felt indebted to make a donation upon leaving (the museums usually ask the visitors who can to make a 5£ donation).Would recommend as much as the Museum of Natural Hystory, British or Science.

Wonderful lunch just off the beaten track. A lovely place to go for a great lunch to break up the shopping.I had children with me and they enjoyed the look around the beautiful house too.My son really enjoyed seeing all the guns and swords.There is not entrance fee which is real bonus, as you feel you can just pop in and are not obliged to see everything. I did see they were doing tours and it would be something i would do when i did not have the children with me.
A well kept secret. Small enough to focus on some special works and a good place to relax for an hour or so.Not too crowded either.

Wonderful museum. The most amazing collection of fine art (including world famous masters paintings) furniture, porcelain and wonderful artefacts all set in a splendid house so close to Oxford Circus....I wish I had visited sooner! Would recommend to anyone...with no entrance fee it is an absolute must!
A secret location just behind Selfridges. Amazing collection of French 18th century artworks and incredible armoury. If you want to escape from Oxford St madness this is the place for you.
reasonable elegant afternoon tea. high tea that didn't cost a fortune in an elegant setting. Finger sandwiches were delicious. pastries were fine.

Love this restaurant. What a fabulous restaurant, tucked away in the West End, behind Selfridges.It's almost like stepping back in time - I wouldn't have been surprised to see the cast of Downton Abbey here!Delicious lunch in a fabulous setting - go there!
A real treat. Never realised there was so much fantastic art in this beautiful house in Manchester Square. A must on your list of Art Galleries in London.

Stunning and intimate. This house is a true hidden gem. There is something for everyone, from terrible brutal weapons for the boys to beautiful decoratiions and art for the grown ups. The lovely courtyard cafe/restaurant (covered by a glass atrium) is for our next visit. It is a calm serene oasis amid the hub bub of CentralLondon. Go early enough to take your time and enjoy that courtyard cafe. And free entry to boot!
what a treasure. Tucked behing Oxford street and walking distance to Baker Street - a real treasure trove - what a collction.great resturant too
Wo derful. A hidden treasure. Don't miss it whether you are a Londoner or a visitor. There is so much to see here you could spend a week. Great restaurant too.

Excellent less crowded museum. This is a great smallish museum with a wonderful collection of art. It is away from most of the museums and is a little bit north of the famous department store, Selfridges. Well worth a couple of hours visiting although one could spend longer.

Renovated and even more wonderful. I was so sad on my last visit when the largest gallery was closed down and the works were scattered all over the place. This year the restoration was completed so one could see all the rooms the way they were meant to be enjoyed. Each room has its own personality and art type. There's just enough information about the original purpose of the room (often with photos) and the works that you truly understand the flow of the area.They don't mince words about the checkered family history. :)It's a must-see every time I come to London!
It's a beautiful museum!. I really enjoyed walking around here. Each room was equally as beautiful, filled with elegant furniture. It was very nice here and I will come back again

Nice wine and dessert. My second time there with friends. The starter and main course were ok but nothing special. Selection of wine is quite good and one of the best chocolate fondants! Nice in a day in summer because there's a lot of natural light.

Too Much!. Its a great shame because the house is full of beautiful possessions but there are just so many and they are mostly so cramped in their display that they lose their beauty and you soon get to the point where enough is enough. Fine if you live in London but disappointing on a once only visit.

Eclectic. This fine house in Manchester Square is what the wealthy did in their spare time. They built houses and collected things. And what a range of things! My own interests are the Venetian art but there's so much else.

A wonderful Museum in a great location.. Simply Love this Museum. Sometimes pop in for an hour to walk around to see the collection of Art, China, Art all set in the fabulous building. The location is perfect as it is a short walk from Selfridges on Oxford Street, near to Marlybone High Street with all the wonderful shops and cafes/restaurants down there. Baker street is close by for the Sherlock Holmes fans and Regents Park is a 10 minute walk away, so lots to do in one area.The Museum is free to enter and is a manageable size to wonder round.

Small but beautiful. It is a while since I have visited the Wallace Collection in Manchester Square but I regard it as a gem right in the West End. It is small enough to see it all in one day and the Atrium serves very tasty food. My favourite exhibits are the minitures some of which are quite exquisite.
third time i have visited. it is in a great location easy to find, free entry, and not too big the resturant is nice not a snack bar . have been here three or four times and would go back again.

One of my favourite places in London. Intimate museum with a very well curated collection and is never crowded. One of the better kept secrets in London. The cafe in the atrium is very nice too. Not for non-roccoco fans though!

My favourite london museum. I just love the intimacy of this small museum with its exquisite collection of fine artefacts. The Laughing cavalier and Girl on a swing, plus some stunning canelletos just whet the appetite to seek out even more stunning pieces. Free entry to this little oasis just off Oxford St, makes it one of Londons little gems. No visit would be complete without eating in the atrium restaurant. Can thoroughly recommend.

A bite-sized Delight. If you in central London and have an hour or so to kill, just walk north of Oxford St. (near Marble Arch) to this repurposed home that now houses one of the best small museums in London. With something for every age. And free, like most in London….to boot! I was there with visitors from Germany, and with a friend and his two young sons. Everybody loves the Wallace!

Uncrowded Gem. The Wallace is one of London's best kept secrets. Enjoy this collection in the surroundings of a personal mansion without the starkness of a museum experience. It is quiet, uncrowded and friendly. Don't miss it if you are in the area.

a hidden gem for art lovers. A collection of mainly 18th century art still in the house of the family who collected it. Very opulent and gives an idea of what it would have been like to live as an aristocrat in London in the late 18th century.

Excellent for lunch....... I work nearby so work colleagues and I came for lunch. Wonderful setting, very attentive and helpful staff. Lovely food, tasty, well presented and not overly expensive. My next visit will be to see the collection.
Stunning collection of art and antiques.. If you like art and antiques this is a must visit attraction. I was extremely impressed with the paintings, ornaments and the furniture.

A must see museum. This museum has an amazing collection of works of art, really too many to take in on your first visit, perhaps the most famous being The Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals. You need at least two hours but it would be possible to spend all day there. The collection is housed in a lovely London town house. Admission is free, but a donation of £5 is suggested. The internal courtyard has been roofed over and houses a lovely restaurant and cafe. The restaurant is on one side and the cafe on the other side. We had a very enjoyable light lunch in the cafe, with courteous, attentive staff.

Excellent for tea. The venue is obviously superb. The staff friendly and efficient and the tea / pastries / cakes are delicious. Very good place to bring friends visiting London: cultural (Wallace Collection) and tasty.
very interesting museum. We enjoyed our time spent there. My girlfriend is a professor in art history, and she found the collection interesting.
A collection of fine and decorative arts.. It displays of French paintings, furniture and porcelain. It also has a world class armoury. it is a place worth visiting.

Must visit venue and best loos in London.. Fantastic collection of art works covering a wide range of styles in a wonderful building. It is free to visit but worth leaving a donation to keep this venue alive. Very pleasant cafe/restaurant with tasty food at reasonable prices. The star of the visit are the loos, simply the best in the whole of London, worth a visit for this alone!!

Museum Visit. Had a great time touring this museum such beautiful pieces of Art. The upper two floors were good but boy the armouries in the basement were something else. leave yourself plenty of time .for the basement. Just a 5 minute walk from Baker street tube station

Lovely museum often missed by visitors to London.. Great place for a visit of a couple of hours or so, although only five minute walk from Selfridges often missed by visitors who favour the better known gallery's and museum's beautiful rooms and also has a great restaurant.

the best museum in London. A perfect size - with a lovely restaurant in the middle. Beautiful collections in a terrific setting - a must when visiting London (in Manchester Sq just behind Selfridges on Oxford St) Try and catch a guided tour if you can

Great collection. Huge variety of paintings, sculptures, weaponry, and furniture. Something for everyone and all within a building that is almost as enjoyable to view as its contents. Well worth several visits.

don't go to tea. I was taken to tea, mid afternoon and found the tearooms shrouded in the fug of a greasy spoon. Staff in short supply and slow.Weak tea but good sandwiches.Scones dry and lacking a feeling of being freshly made.A rip off tourist attraction.

Magnificent. It is worth a visit to the Wallace Collection. The Laughing Cavalier was on show as well as Canaletto. The trinket boxes were outstanding with diamonds and intricate painting. It is well worth a visit, especially if you like armoury, there is a lot to see.

Mind boggling!. This collection needs quite a few visits to take in all the exhibits.The various rooms have so much to look at it's a bit overwhelming!Every item is exquisite ,you could spend all day and not see them all.There's a lovely tea room but it closes at 4.45 which is a bit of a shame!
Free and beautiful. It is small but full of paintings and art crafts. Take time to visit this less famous museum. It is also near to the center and there is an excellent japanise restaurant nearby.
Wonderful Gem. Loved this place, such a hidden gem. Definitely worth a visit. Nice place to visit with a friend.I would definitely recommend when you are in the neighborhood.

A wonderful place. The Wallace collection is a treasure trove of beautiful paintings, ornate furniture, and much more. It has a lovely cafe with waitress service. It is free entrance and it is one of my favourite London attractions

Sizable art collection and no entrance fee. This museum is in a large town house and has a sizable art collection although it is some narrow in time frame (approximately 1770 to about 1860). along with many artistic objects and some what extensive amour collection (which is a bit odd for what is basically an art museum). One of the few museums in London that does charge an entrance fee.
Excellent. I really enjoyed my visit to the Wallace Collection. The items on view are wonderful and it is like walking around a private home. Delightful and well worth visiting.

Excellent way to pass the time. I love the art collection here, and very often, when I am in the area and at a loose end, I will pop in for a while. On the few occasions when I have dined here, I have always had a good experience with both the food and the staff.The house is free and very often, there are free exhibitions too.
too much for one visit. would repay return visits. Very many paintings of interest and lots of china /furniture/ armour. Nice conservatory cafe, if a little expensive. Good for ladies who lunch.

Incredible Collection. The Wallace Collection is housed in the most amazing and beautiful home that rivals the collection itself. Such a treat to have the opportunity to go and see these incredible pieces of art displayed so perfectly.

Enlightenment mastery - Joshua Reynolds: Experiments in paint. I am a great fan of Reynolds (I remember studying his Discourses, lectures given whilst first president of the Royal Academy, when I was at university). This is a fascinating exhibition covering a wide range of his work from the early self-portrait to the wonderful 'Mrs Abington as Ms Prue'. The accompanying explanations are clear and informative. Well worth a visit.

Something for Everyone. A "hidden gem!" Can't believe that I've walked by this amazing museum several times without knowing it was there. Located on Manchester Square just a few blocks off of Oxford Street near Selfridge's. Easy walk to Bond St. Underground. The art collection is amazing - collected over five generations - and housed in a beautifully restored 18th Century home. The arms and armour are fascinating and art in itself. Excellent Joshua Reynolds exhibit including x-rays of the paintings showing what is hidden underneath. Café located in a central enclosed courtyard. Admission is free, and donations are welcome.

A perfect museum for the family. I am glad my wife and I finally made it to the Wallace Collection. A superb family collection of paintings , art work and furniture in a private and sumptuous home. The armor colection will enthrall the kids. The current Joshua Reynold exhibition is a plus.

Highly Recommended. The Wallace collection museum is hidden away not far from Oxford Street, but is one of Londons gems and free to enter. A magnificent ex private residence that combines historic décor, fine paintings, an extensive armour collection and a magnificent French café in the courtyard it is well worth a visit.

An wonderful collection. The building is full of amazing items. Superb paintings vie for space and the wall coverings are exquisite. The armour section is full of unusual items. It is close to Selfridge's and the Oxford Street shops so is very convenient.

A little bit of everything. Good museum for museum lovers and museum haters alike. A good place to take children - and us over 60s - as plenty of things to dip into. Excellent cafe restaurant with very helpful staff
Art for the People. Something to aspire to the masters covering Art ceramics furniture creative metal works the skill to create wonderful items. See for yourself wonderful. collection

perfect for the "museum faint of heart". The very concept of being able to view a personal collection of paintings, china and other works of art in what was a private London residence makes this so special, and not intimidating for those who find miles of museum corridors and halls too much, the staff welcoming and helpful
Joshua Reynolds . Well worth seeing some paintings had not been seen before they also have X-rays of the paintings and what was hidden underneath a great collection and of course it's free

Beautiful works of art here & well worth a visit!. Not really close to other major attractions, but with quite allot of beautiful fine art, it's we'll worth getting to & spending time in. For more information on what is there I recommend visiting their online site.
Interesting little place.. Worth a visit if you come to London. It has some interesting things to see. Its quite small but worth a visit.

A real gem. This is a very intimate collection of art, presented in such a tasteful way. There was a guided presentation that was fantastic. For us the Wallace was a bit out of the way, but very much worth the effort to see. Great gift shop, also.

interesting and well presented. So much to see for free! enjoyable and instructive! The china collection is amazing and well presented.
love the armour room! the cafeteria is lovely but not impressive on the staff and food.

Wallace Collection. I had heard of the Wallace Collection and had some idea about it but only visited when I accidentally strayed into Manchester Square. I headed for the armoury galleries first and then went upstairs to the excellent paintings and other art works on display. Rembrandt's self portrait would be the highlight for a lot of people. There are also works by Canalletto, Gainsborough and other artists. A high end cafeteria is situated in the covered courtyard. This is a good attraction for a rainy day and let's face it we can have those in the UK. Bond Street underground station is a few minutes walk away.

Sumptuous and Varied. We came across this superb collection by chance while recently in London and enjoyed the numerous pieces, especially the paintings. The displays are quite unique and reflect the interests of their collectors. We found the use of the audio-guide enhanced our experience significantly as did the volunteers in the various rooms. We had only a couple of hours to spare on this occasion but plan another visit soon.

Jam packed, amazing collection. I was amazed at how much was packed in a medium sized building, relatively speaking.
