I was awed by the armour room...window after window of armour of every size shape and detail. The art and furniture, located upstairs, was overwhelming in number and beauty.There's a beautiful restaurant, located in the inner courtyard, great toilet areas and to top it off, they do not charge for entry (donations accepted)! This is a "must see" destination in London.

Boring. We went to the wallace collection and were roped into a tour. This consisted of an over enthusiastic older lady telling us about the paintings in depth and the story behind them. We had only ventured there to see the arms and armoury, which was not featured on the tour.

Great find in a quiet location. There was plenty to see at this private collection and it was free! We did not try the restaraunt but it was clean bright and airy, with staff moving round quietly and efficiently. The collection was just a bit too much to do in one visit so it is a must to see again. Particularly outstanding was a portrait of the Laughing Cavalier which I have sent many times in books, but it's here for real!

A museum and gallery in Central London just north of Oxford Street...... The Wallace Collection exhibits feature some of the finest British and European artworks collected by a series of aristocratic family members from the 17th. to the 19th. centuries. The museum and art gallery could be described as one of the best free shows in town as entry is free of charge although a modest donation is always welcome for the privilege of viewing such a fantastic collection. Visitors may also sample the excellent fayre at the Wallace Restaurant, or, simply enjoy some light refreshment.

Among London's terrific museums; it's a good choice if you have museum fatigue. "The Collection" is housed in a beautiful, furnished mansion in a lovely neighborhood--close to Oxford Street shopping. Its Old Masters would demand viewing, if it were in another city. With Rembrandt, Frans Hals, Gainsborough, among others, it offers a remarkable display. So many pictures, it can be overwhelming. Restaurant in courtyard. Staircases toilets on lower level.
Well worth a visit. Good value for money and interesting. Had to find somewhere to park the car but fortunately my partner had a disabled badge. Good places to eat nearby

Great place for your eyes and stomach. Great place to visit with a sizeable collection of paintings and objects. Also came down here for afternoon tea with a couple of friends - food for tasty with a great collection of teas to try. I ordered a Japanese blossom tea, which was nice and fragrant. Definitely worth a visit or two.

Great collection, intimate setting.. More intimate than the National Gallery and less OCD than the Sir John Soane Museum, the Wallace Collection is an excellent compromise. Its size is manageable and its setting is relaxed while containing well known works by Rembrand, Fragonard, and Canaletto. My daughter was surprised to find a Fragonard she already had a poster of in her bedroom, and my sons loved the armory.
Great Place. Great Museum to visit. It has many paintings but its small enough to feel as if your in your own home.

The Best Small Museum in London. The Wallace Collection is in a beautiful old Marylebone mansion overlooking scenic Manchester Square. It has a mind-blowing collection of paintings, by Rembrandt, Canaletto, Hals, Velasquez, etc., a lovely glass roofed cafe and restaurant, a wonderful armour and antique furniture collection, and a very good library. Entrance is free, and they let you take photographs.
HIdden gem. Exlcetivs but wel chosen collection of art hidden just off highly commercial Oxford Street. Well worth a visit.
N/A. Feel the food should be much better when you think the beautiful setting, the collection, the building and the setting of the restarant is all great but no the food
Frequently return. Lovely building, some beautiful paintings. Fragonard's Girl on a Swing my particular favourite. What's to dis;like?

Always a Delight. Situated in Manchester Square, close to but much quieter than Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is a haven of interesting art and armour that has something for all ages. The beautiful Hertford House is home to the Laughing Cavalier, canons and mounted warriors or more genteel artwork in its many different and inspiring rooms. It is also complimented by a super restaurant in the Conservatory that serves delicious food. I have used it for business meetings and pure leisure on many occasions and very much look forward to my next visit - strongly recommended.

I need to return. Some remarkable exhibits but the star for me, much to my surprise, was The Laughing Cavalier.Until i saw it here, in person so to speak, I had no idea how captivating this portrait is.

Lovely exhibition and great afternoon tea. Was treated to afternoon tea by my son for Mother's day and what a lovely find. Beautiful sandwiches,scones,clotted cream and little cakes. Very busy and lovely ambience .Service excellent and exhibition amazing
Don't miss the Wallace Collection!. Small out-of-the-way museum but well worth the time to visit. Special Joshua Reynolds exhibit on until June 7, 2015.

One of the best galleries in London. I love the Wallace Collection. It's generally quiet and not as busy as other central London galleries but the collections are stunning. The miniatures in particular are so well curated. It's a joy.
absolutely stunning!. I didn't have any specific expectations, so maybe this is why I enjoyed the Wallace Collection so much. A most beautiful and original spot in London.

A delight in the heart of London. Amazing heart, both on the walls and in the actual structure and furniture (even the railings are art and have a history) - great talks and a beautiful restaurant in the centre to have tea and feel very British ;-)

One of my favourite London stops. This is one of my favourite spots in London. Such a fabulous setting, out of the beaten path. The cafe is a dream, and the service is so professional. It's the perfect place to meet up with a friend or even go solo when you want a bit of peace and quiet. Cannot recommend it more, never failed to disappoint me! I wish there were more gems like these in London.

Excellent. This is one of the best museams i have been too and it really has a variety of paintings and other arts. I recommend this to everyone and its great for a fun family day out. Been here 2 years in a row now.

Hidden gem. It's a pleasure to see in one place so many paitings I've read or heard about and to confront my imagination about their size and true colors with the reality. I was stunned that Fragonard's The Swing is so tiny. I don't like baroque but this paiting is really sweet and charming. I didn't know that they have so many Rembrandts! The only part I didn't enjoy is the Arms and Armour, I was never interested in it. I think it's a great place to introduce kids to great art pieces or to spend a delightful afternoon followed by a cream tea in the cafe within the building.

A gem of a museum. We went to see Frans Hals' Laughing Cavalier. Always an amazing portrait to see. But there was so much more to discover. I loved the portraits by Greuze, Reynolds, Gainsborough and the extensive porcelain collection.We were there on a Friday afternoon and the museum was not too crowded, which was perfect to stroll around the house and get real close to the portraits you wanted to see.We finished our visit in the tea room. Excellent apple and pear juice. The tea was rubbish. Very friendly service.
Excellent museum. This is one of the best private museums in London, the armoury is amazing and the restaurant is pretty good too.

Mixed collection with some real gems. A stately home in the heart of London, with an impressive art and armory collection. Much of what hangs on the walls is mediocre (in my opinion), but there are some amazing pieces mixed in. Some of them are so iconic you will feel that you've already seem them. Notable is the Laughing Cavalier. The collection of armor and weapons is beautiful and impressive. There are some wonderful miniatures and manuscript illuminations. The house is interesting. Worth a visit.
A lovely collection of beautiful paintings and china. Set off Oxford Street but what a different world once you are inside. Lots of rooms to discover and a lovely restaurant in the basement.

Worth a visit.. After you have seen all the usual museums and galleries in London, be sure to put a couple of hours aside for the Wallace Collection which is located in lovely old mansion. I found it mind-boggling that the master of the house amassed all of these works over one life-time. There are many, many treasures including silver, carvings, oils, antique furnishings, glassware and pottery.

a wonderful house and gallery any great cafe.. We did not have long enough to do it justice so will be going back. Every room is a delight and we were surprised to find many iconic paintings. Free entry was a great surprise. The cafe / restaurant is lovely situated in the glass covered central courtyard. Traditional afternoon tea seemed to be very popular.
Time Portal. Walking through each of these rooms transports you back in time. The collection is impressive and in marvelous upkeep. They also have a wonderful programme of events.

A Wonderful Experience. What an amazing experence! A stunning collection of priceless masters all under one roof. A beautifully conserved residence presenting the best in period archicture and decoration. And no charge!The restaurant is excellent, and the staff are helpful. It would have been nice to learn more about the house when I entered, but I realised later that the receptionist was absent when I arrived.All in all, a superb experience. The Wallace Collection is a first-class example of how it should be done.

Quirky but interesting. This is a recommendation if you like the full 360 degree experience - admire grand paintings and lavish ornaments in a grand setting, and you can almost imagine you have been transported back to elegant 19th Century London. And all to be found in a quiet square in Central London. There are some quite famous pieces such as Frans Hals' Laughing Cavalier, and others big names represented such as Rubens, Watteau, Fragonard and Canaletto. There is a decent set of Dutch landscapes. However, my personal favourite is a moody portrait of an (unidentified) Lady with a Fan by Velasquez.

Lovely collection in central London. My first visit there - was pleasantly surprised by both the quality and quality of the items in the collection - a vast array of paintings, miniatures, ceramics, furniture and armour. Nicely laid out in a lovely house behind Selfridges in Oxford Street. Highly recommended.

Wonderful barock/rokoko museum. Everything is so beautiful here. This mansion is full of paintings, furnitures and other objects representate the 17-1800th century. It´s free and you can go by yourself or go with guide. Just some minutes from Oxford street.
Brilliant. This is a free exhibition, with free guided tours, of outstanding importance and is a pleasure to visit, I'm not finished with it yet. Donations are accepted.

A great collection in a lovely part of London. Highly recommended for a visit, quite an eclectic collection in a grand house; lots of French furniture if that's your thing (from aristocrats fleeing the Revolution, I gather - someone said there's more original period furniture in the collection than at Versailles), beautiful silk on the walls, the Laughing Cavalier, and a fine collection of armour, bladed weapons and other weaponry - perhaps useful to entice the younger visitor, too (include armour for a horse). Helpful and friendly staff. Lovely.

Leave your hat and stick at the wardrobe, the Marquess is waiting. If you have visited the Frick’s Museum in New York, you know the “wow” feeling you will experience entering this unique luxury villa.Leave your hat and stick at the wardrobe, and let your horse relax outside in the courtyard because getting in the Hertford House you get in the XVII century when it was used as the Spanish Embassy .In 1797, the 2nd Marquess of Hertford acquired the lease of the house. He used the house as his principal London residence, holding many parties there, the most prestigious of which was the Allied Sovereigns’ Ball held after the defeat of Napoleon in 1814. In 1836-51 the house was let as the French Embassy.The 4th Marquess between 1800 and 1870 lived largely in Paris and used Hertford House as a London store for his increasing art collection. It was only with the Paris Commune of 1871 that his illegitimate son, decided to move back to London, bringing a substantial amount of his Parisian collection with him.He redeveloped the house, creating a range of galleries on the first floor. After his death the house was converted into a public museum and on 22 June 1900 was first opened as a museum. Forget your next appointments, mobile phone and facebook and try to enjoy the glory and the beauty in the silence brocken only by the tic-tac of the golden clocks!

packed to the roof with beautiful stuff. Went with friends to see this and it was so good I went back. A smallish mansion behind Selfridges in London, with free guided tours during the day. It is full of the most beautiful porcelain, art and paintings from all over the world, and because it is a small area you can see things without large crowds and barriers getting in the way. There is a covered atrium in the centre where they do lovely food and cream teas for a very reasonable price. I would definitely go back again!

Great Art collection. Well worth the visit, for the collection itself, plus the frequent exhibitions. You have the added bonus of the location at Somerset House. Round the trip off with a trip to the cafe.

Treasure trove, and all for free. Wonderful building, rooms renovated to original glorious state, and all packed with visual and applied arts from clocks to furniture to paintings to armory to porcelain. It is all free, and a joy to stroll through or look more intensely. A quiet escape from the bustle of nearby Oxford Street, with great cafe in an airy central atrium. Must see, must do. And there are tours of different kinds and lengths each day from experts if you want a bit more.

Hidden gem. The Wallace Collection is one of London's best kept secrets, even though it's really close to busy Oxford Street. An exquisite collection of world-class paintings inside a beautiful palace (each room is decorated in a different colour!). Admission is free! Not to be missed.
A Hidden Gem. What a superb museum tucked away of the main roads and crammed fuill of wonderful exhibits. Well worth a visit

A 'must' for anyone interested in fine art.. Have visited several times in recent years. It's one of those collections where you cannot do it justice in one 'go'. Hertford House is an attractive building in itself but the treasures inside are breathtaking. Go!It is open 7 days a week and entrance is, astonishingly, free.The modern café/restaurant is classy and exceptional, just like everything else here.I love to wander over to here after a lunchtime concert at nearby Wigmore Hall.

Excellent, quite a gem. It is the home of the Laughing Cavalier and a other wonderful paintings, ceramics and armour. You can break your fascinating tour by having a coffee or a meal in their courtyard cafe.

Good value for money. Good modern museum, which is free. There were 3 exhibitions on when we went so spend a reasonable amount of time there. They do a hands on table in the early afternoon which was fun. The café was OK, slightly expensive and if you want basic food probably not for you. However it was full of "ladies who lunch" so must be good for the area. Good museum shop with a wide range of objects and prices.

Not visited enough! A must!. Free Entry, beautiful rooms, simply divine. I like the set up you have free reign of the house in terms of exploration. everywhere you look their is a painting or curio that is worth a thousand stares. Strongly recommend a visit. I have been several times and almost feel reluctant about giving a positive review because it is so undisturbed and glorious. Honestly pay the collection a visit and you will not be disappointed. Pay a visit to the not unreasonably priced tea room to finish off a civilized afternoon.

Art density. I don’t sin against the true if advise to visit only Wallace Collection in London. It’s rare museum give you feeling of refined aestheticism because of fullness of masterpieces. Richest collecting of paining, especially my favorite rococo artists Fragonard (Swing is “visiting card” of Collection), Boucher (luxuriant Madame de Pompadour!), Watteau. Unique collecting of medieval armour (European and Oriental).
wonderful free art museum. Guided tours very interesting. Lovely resturant. Easy to find location behind Selfrages. Wonderful art.
Fantasic paintings in a nice setting. We enjoyed our visit, with a teenager and her aunties. It is a nice size of museum with free admission.

A dream!!. Absolutely a FAB collection...I loved every thing! paintings of such a value are to be admired here...all beautifully exposed in fantastic rooms.
Please do not leave London without having seen this collection!

Amazing Collection!!!. I entered the Wallace collection not really knowing anything about it. I walked in looking a little lost and a lady asked me if this was my first time at The Wallace Collection to which I said it was, she asked me how much time I had and I said 2 or 3 hours. She informed me that this might not be enough time to see everything, she got out a floor plan and showed me areas that she recommended I go to first in order to see the most important pieces. I thought this was extremely helpful and followed her advice. The collection itself was absolutely amazing, there were some gorgeous paintings and I really loved the armoury. I did not eat in the restaurant so cannot comment on this.

A wonderful art collection.. Difficult to describe. Such riches on display, inc all the decorative arts. Silver, paintings, French porcelain and furniture. Medieval art, inc armour/weapons. And a good cafe and restaurant in the courtyard.
A lovely private collection. So close to Oxford Street, lovely provate collection well preserved. A great place to have lunch, afternoon tea.

Super!. Arranged to meet 5 friends here in the cafe for coffee and cakes, then we all had an hour wandering round the collection together. It was an excellent 'taster' and I'll definitely come back to look at the exhibits in more detail. The guides in each room were very helpful and it was a pleasure to listen to their enthusiasm and knowledge about the history of the family. They guide upstairs, who on this occasion was in the room with some of the Rembrandts knew masses about the pictures - it was a delight to listen to him!
Quirky. A cabinet of curiosities where you least expect it. I lived in London more than 30 years before I realised this place existed. It's always worth a visit
free but a great laugh. Great collection at no cost, just off Oxford Street, not crowded - can eat, good shop and of course the Laughing Cavaliar

So Beautiful!. One of my favourite London museums, with a fantastic collection of 18th Century French furniture and porcelain, a lot of which came from the Palace of Versailles but was sold off during the Revolution - exquisite works in overwhelming quantity arranged in a series of beautiful rooms

Gem in Marylebone. I love this collection. It's a former house of a Lord and it has a delightful collection of antiques and paintings and sculptures. It is located in Manchester Square, just a little north of the Oxford Street madness, but it is easy to get to by tube and then a short walk. One of the highlights of the Wallace Collection is the newly renovated cafe, which served a delicious cup of tea in the afternoons, making this a nice location to see some art and then enjoy an afternoon refreshment.

Great collection..... One of our favourite venues to visit when in London...oozing with interest and excitement...beautifully presented...Today we also enjoyed an excellent lunch in the restuarant run by Peyton and Byrne in the atrium a delightful light setting in which to enjoy some delicious food and wine...The menu is imaginative and well presented .Delicious fresh bread.Good coffee.

Wonderful way to while away a couple of hours. The exhibits are beautifully laid out with plenty of seating just to sit and gaze at some of stunning artwork. It's a hidden gem with such a wide range of fascinating paintings and exhibits. Lovely cafe in the centre too, and a good gift shop.
Beautiful objects. Liked every thing. a joy to the eyes and senses. You need more than one visit, in fact you need to keep going back.

Amazing collection of Dutch and Italian Paintings. Beautiful building with the most amazing art and ceramic collections quietly tucked away in Manchester Square - would recommend the audio guide for £4 each rather than the £6 guide book as the narrative about some of the best paintings is very enlightening!

'...my collection is the result of my life...' 4th Marquess of Hertford, 1857. Check out the wonderful collection of furniture, snuff boxes and paintings which include a pair of unusually large views by Canaletto, four views of Venice by Guardi, The Swing by Fragonard, The Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals and the excellent collection of Dutch and Flemish paintings.

Great suits of armor collection. If you are a fan of medieval warfare such as myself, you can't miss it. It has the biggest collection of suits of armor I have ever seen, all beautifully preserved and exhibited. The building itself is another attraction on its own.

Frick on steroids. Less well known, not crowded. Lose yourself for an afternoon. The Wallace is 2 blocks North of Oxford Street near Bond Street. It is a huge personal collection given to the nation about 130 years ago on the condition it was kept in site and not added to. So it gives a fascinating look at the taste and lifestyle if one rich family that was much more cultured and international than the usual British Aristocrat.The Herefords/Wallace were increasingly francophile and their collection shows that as does the rather heavy French furniture and decor which provides a good backdrop to the art. The furniture and objects are high quality and will interest this who like that sort of thing.The large mansion is packed with paintings as well as some sculptures and a host of miniatures, china, pottery, chalices, etc. It is organized pretty much in chronological order so you can pick your fancy or do the whole thing. There is not much by way of explanation so buying the guide might be a good idea. I also chanced on a free docent highlight tour that was nicely done for some of the rooms.As far as I could tell, 3 generations collected fairly steadily and then Wallace got serious and bought in bulk at a time when a lot of family heirlooms were coming in the market. The rooms show this. Some are fairly restrained with the usual single or double row of largish portraits and scenes. And then you turn a corner and the place is packed from floor to ceiling. The renaissance section has good but not exceptional paintings and some lovely medieval book illustrations and goblets plates, etc. There is also a long gallery full of painted ceramic plates and rooms of armour and weapons if you are into that sort of thing. There are some good English c18 and early 19 paintings, largely portraits. A room full of Canaleto and contemporaries. But no Turner, Constable. There is huge collection of Dutch painting with Rembrandt, Rubens, Van Dyck, mixed in with a host of other names in the next level down. You get a tremendous impression of the output and skills the Dutch as well as the change in subject matter. The new great gallery at the back upstairs is impressive. Murillo, Velazquez and co fairly well represented and then you walk smack into Frans Halls The Laughing Cavalier (bought for relatively little as he was unknown in the C19). The collection is heavy on French with a lot of Watteau, Boucher and other C18 "pretty" painters as well as some nice still life. Lovely miniature collection. Ends with a lot of C19 French which is not all to my taste but tells you a lot about the collectors. No interest in the impressionists nor pre-Raphaelites. You get the sense they collected the recognized names.All in all it is well worth the visit and has a very nice restaurant and tea room in a covered central courtyard (reserve the restaurant and cafe at lunch time). Frick gives you a restrained collection of high quality individual pieces. Wallace gives you a riot of a century of collecting "warts and all".

Much improved restaurant food and service. The Wallace Collection is a treat for any visitor, and now the restaurant in the courtyard is so much improved that I can recommend that too. We went for breakfast, which was just right, (delicious yoghurt and granola with fruit) and what was particularly appreciated was the attention that got us more coffee before we had to attract attention to order it. That is the mark of a well run establishment where they watch out for the customers without intruding. All the staff were polite, unobtrusive, efficient and just really good at the job. Hat's off!

a museum with a difference. the Wallace Collection is free to visit and housed in an elegant 18th century Mansion . Here you will see the famous Laughing Cavalier, and Fragonard's girl on a swing as well as fierce Samurai armour, delicate china, and paintings by renowned Old Masters. It also has a nice restaurant

A gem. The art collection is unique. besides, because it is not the first port of call for mass tourists, it is usually quiet. You can walk around, seat, enjoy art or have a drink or a meal in the wonderfull cafeteria/restaurant in the covered courtyard
Perfectly formed collection. One of my favourite pieces is a work called 'The Swing'. It is quieter than other museums and this makes it more relaxing and the cafe looks amazing.
Great collection. Very eclectic mix of items. The armour is extensive if that is your thing! The building itself is good to see too

National treasure. A bit chintzy, and a bit heavy on the Sevre, but simply one of the best small museums in the world. If you love the Frick in NY, then this is right up your street, although on the whole the collection is earlier.

Excellent - one of the best!. This is the third time visiting. It is by far my favourite London gallery. The tea room inside is a pleasure and has the most amazing cakes. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection was one of the highlights of my trip to London. It is part mansion, part art gallery and is simply stunning. There are no labels on the majority of items on display so you can really lose yourself just wandering around and taking in the glorious surroundings. There is something for everyone here: suits of armour, painting, furniture, porcelain, a Napoleonic room, a Venetian room and more beautiful art than you'd think possible. In the basement there is a good little exhibition about the Wallace family who amassed the collection on display.

An intimate museum experience. With all the things to do in London, and so many of them great museums, it would be easy to miss this little gem of a place. The building itself is beautiful, with the galleries fanning out from a large, central staircase. You'll be surprised at some of the art here--it never travels and some of the paintings here are the great staples of an art history course. Uncrowded, intimate and well spaced and paced exhibits make for a perfect place to spend the afternoon. Have a great lunch at "Spring" for a perfect day.

Superb varied collection. For London standards this is a small museum but it is packed with a wide variety of very high quality varied art and artifacts. Entrance is free but you are requested to make a contribution. It is based on the private collection of a very wealthy family. There are superb pictures including many you will have seen recreated elsewhere, stunning porcelain, sculpture and an extraordinary collection of arms and armour. The collection is varied and just the right size that you can view it in one visit without experiencing art fatigue and overload by the time you are finished. I am certainly going to visit again.
great loot!. This is the sort of art loot that is incredible to see up close. quite fantastic collection. you feel lush just walking around in there.

interesting exhibition. we started the day with a coffee and cake in the restaurant which was almost a disaster. Ages to get our order taken then ages for the drinks to come (no cake at this stage). The coffees were finished and still no cakes. My husband found a supervisor who was very helpful and after a while the cakes arrived with a complimentary coffee. very nice once we got it but I wd recommend having coffee before you arrive there!! Exhibition very good-too much to take in at one visit. Lovely miniatures and very ornate furniture and clocks--rather 'over the top' judging by today's standards.
Art. Fabulous. restaurant excellent. Seeing how the super wealthy aristocracy used to live in in their Town Homes in Central London

Surprising in quality. This museum has a remarkable selection of items collected by several curators over the years. The helmets, ivory carvings and of course paintings are delightful. Nice cafe to finish the visit. Free of course.

Magnificent collection of great paintings. World-class collection of great paintings, housed in a wonderful mansion in Marylebone. The excellence of the exhibits is a testament to the foresight and good tastes of its 5 founders. We spent the most time at the refurbished Great Gallery -- filled with masterpieces by Rembrandt, Rubens, Velazquez, etc. Also outstanding is the collection of Venetian paintings by Canaletto and Guardi. Visitors will enjoy dropping in at the nice Gift Shop and dining at the attractive Restaurant located in the middle of the Mansion.

Definitely worth a visit. Had only heard of this place by using Trip Advisor. Like other museums it is free and really enjoyable. I loved the Canalettto paintings and miniatures in particular but there is so much more to see, fantastic China, armour, furniture etc. You can get up close to everything and take pictures if you want. We had cake in the cafe which was fab too. One tip - don't bother with the audio guide as it is nothing like those offered elsewhere like Versailles for instance. The staff were excellent and refunded us for the audio guide so no complaints whatsoever. A fabulous place.

Amazing collection. The Wallace Collection is very eclectic. There are paintings by Canetto, Rembrandt and many more. There is a large collection of arms and armour. It is not very large but well worth a visit!

Treasure Trove. This house on a quiet square in West London is filled to the brim with wonderful art, beautiful antiques and fascinating weapons and Armour. The staff are friendly and helpful. There were extra activities such as regency dance classes, this was in half term. Entry was free and there are audio guides for a small fee. Look out Fragonard's' The Swing' and 'The Laughing Cavalier'.

Wonderful house!. This is a house full of real treasures, with beautiful decor and chandeliers. There is an interesting collection of art and furnishings, including Marie Antoinette's writing desk. Particularly like the painting of Sophie Arnaud, she has a memorably beautiful face. Very nice coffee and cake in the cafe

Brilliant restaurant. The restaurant is excellent. The food is delicious and well worth the cost.I learnt at my visit that the museum is not receiving enough funding in order to keep all the galleries open to the public, which is a great shame. This is a fabulous collection, so I highly recommend leaving a small donation if you do go in order to keep it afloat.

Richard was very good at collecting. I visited the Wallace Collection with my brother. It is the most marvelous collection of artworks I have seen. Perhaps because it is a private collection it is even more marvelous.But I suspect the best thing about it was the tour guide. She was an enthusiastic older woman who had airs and graces about her that I feel put most of the tour group into a daze where they thought they should be prim and proper. Her routine was slick, comical and full of innuendo about the fascinating lives of the collectors of the paintings and the subjects within. I was sniggering the whole way listening to her commentary while the rest of the group seemed to be oblivious, humourless or perhaps (not-unreasonably) non-English speakers.Be organised and take the tour. It is free and entry is free. I bought a small book and a postcard of the famous Jean-Honoré Fragonard painting 'The Swing' which features a creepy old man pushing the commissioner of the painting's mistress on a swing.
Fantastic !. My first time here and I loved it, this is a must see for anyone who appreciates art and beautiful furniture, although too much for one visit so will be going back !
Very interesting!. I visited many years ago, and found it fascinating. It's probably been updated since I visited. The date of my visit is many years before March 2014.

A rare jewel in London!. The Wallace collection, is one of those hidden jewels in London. Free to access and view, it's a delightful experience in every way. The building itself is wonderful, and every corner you face yourself with wonderful works of art. The new main room, full of light does make the wonderful works jump out of their frames, and even the famous Laughing Cavalier's smile is broader in this restored room. Make time though, you might think one hour or two is enough but will find you returning to other rooms, just to sit down and let yourself dwell in some paintings.
Classic Culture. Beautiful house, furnishings and pictures. Okay, after a while I was bombed out. Would have liked a little more explanation of what I was viewing but very gorgeous rooms and art.

Unbelievable Family Collection. I could only compare it to the Barnes Collection in Philadelphia, only the Barnes didn't have centuries of collectors behind it. I had never heard of this collection before and thought it was magnificent.
EXCELLENT. Any art buffs will tell you. As a frequent visitor to the Tate I was somewhat taken aback by the wonderful paintings - so much to see and wonderful variety. I will be back.
Very interesting and lots of variety. I haven't been in a while but have always enjoyed it as there is a great variety of things to see, i.e. paintings, furniture & porcelain.

Always a quiet and wonderful diversion. I was between appointments and decided to spend an hour in the Wallace Collection. I found myself mesmerized by the armaments section, which has an extraordinary collection. I highly recommend it.

A jewelbox of a museum.. This art museum is a little tricky to find, but is one of London’s less well known gems. It is a cornucopia of furniture, ceramics and art work from a range of periods. A particular highlight for me was to see the painting of the Laughing Cavalier and a whole gallery of Venetian scenes, including many by Canaletto. I also enjoyed exploring the arms and armour galleries. An audio tour is available, I regret that I didn’t use this service, as the items don’t have detailed labels. There is a popular café and some of the smartest toilets I have seen in a while. You can happily spend hours here.
Free and so beautiful and interesting. I like every thing and dislike the fact it could be bigger. It good to see lots thing from past even it was a particularly family.
A bit OTTT on style. Still worth a visit, a lot of stuff is after Louid XVI and his wife, so its rather inherently OTT. The china is excellent, if not to everyone's taste.

Quick stop-off. Popped in at the weekend due to having a spare hour in the area, of course attracted by the free entry! We only managed to look around downstairs but it was very impressive to see a collection in such great condition. I will definitely go back with more time to explore further. It's so nice to be able to just pop in if you haven't got much time, or stay for longer if you want to.

Well presented collection. This extensive collection is very well presented in sumptuous rooms. The collection is well themed and labelled. The problem I always have with collections is that it is one person (or family's) taste and may not be eclectic enough for all who see it. We enjoyed it and would like go again and the Laughing Cavalier really does follow you around the room!
Magnificent. Amazed by the collection in this not so popular Museum. Pleasing staff and easily accessible location. Another attraction not to be missed.

A dizzying collection. If you love to linger over classical paintings, rococo furniture, armour, or antique china, you must visit the Wallace Collection. The sheer amount of "stuff" is overwhelming. The free room guides are quite informative and helpful too.
Fabulous jewel in the heart of Oxford St.. Close to Selfridges in a beautiful London Square.Spacious refurbished gallery ,interesting exhibits and building filled with light.

One of my favourite museums. Never overcrowded, a place that has an eclectic collection of fine art, crafts, weapons and suits of armour all in an exquisitely furnished London Mansion. Some very famous paintings are dotted amongst the collection

Wallace Collection. Wonderful little private collection of paintings and armory in the centre of London just behing Oxford street. It is also free of charge. Well worth a visit if you want to have a break from the shopping.

Exciting Discovery in Manchester Square London. Such an amazing museum ,and art gallery small and exquisite.Feast your eyes on many treasures from all around the world.A collection of clocks to interest everyone,and if lucky your visit will coincide with the 'winding of the clocks' and all details of each clock from an expert !!! The room layout is perfect and to wander through each room so interesting.Many small items displayed in beautiful cabinets especially some beautiful colourful china.In addition to all this there is a lovely restaurant in the atrium.I love to visit this house whenever I am visiting central London .
superb collection of arms and armour. the medieval armour is fassinating and downstairs they allow you to try on and touch some examples. its great fun for the kids

My favorite art gallery in London. I really enjoy going to the Wallace over the other London art galleries I've been to. I think it is neat that it is all one family's collection. It is manageable in scope for a day's outing without feeling like you've taken in too much. Would highly recommend. I haven't tried the courtyard restaurant, but it looks inviting.
The Old. If you like cherubs and boring old things this is the place for you. The only positive is the cafe which is excellent

Wallace Museum. Wallace collection was a private collection that became a museum after the death of its owner, Wallace.The museu is set in his house and you can see how the nobility used to live walking around the rooms of his mansion and its stunning furniture, also his collections of paintings, weapons, armor, shields and others related stuff are nothing short of spectacular.

Secret West Ens destination. A wonderful Restaurant so near Oxford St makes this a useful place to know.
Exhibition is small but well selected
Londoner. Quiet, hidden away, a lovely building, a small collection but some gems. The restaurant is very expensive, you are paying for the ambiance.
Fascinating Collection. Love this house with its collections of art and armour. Have visited on many occasions and never get tired of walking round the house.
Londons hidden treasure. the most beautiful setting for exceptional art and so near oxford street..shop for a whie and then feast your eyes and refresh your soul

One of my favourites. London equivalent of New York's Frick Museum. A grand house turned into a museum with an eclectic mix of art and sculpture. And a cafe with cakes. A peaceful and beautiful place to spend an afternoon in.

Amazing!. I vaguely remember coming here with my parents over fifty years ago. All I can really remember from that visit is The Laughing Cavalier but there is so much more to this fine museum. In most European cities a museum/gallery of this standard would be at least 10 Euros to get in but this one is free, not that I would have minded paying.Kids will love the weapons and suits of armour whilst the adults will marvel at the paintings.Places like this make me irrationally proud to be English.

Aristocratic mansion with superb art collection. This mansion holds an exquisite art collection, mostly assembled by Richard Seymour-Conway, 4th Marquess of Hertford, who had extremely good taste and almost limitless resources. As with most museums in London, the establishment is free, and I would recommend joining up with a tour. There is an elegant cafe in the middle of the building, offering upscale items (and with correspondingly high prices).

Hidden gem. Despite having studied in London for five years I had never heard of this collection. We had no plans for the Sunday morning so looked up attractions, London and this was no. 1, so thought we would try it. Neither of us are history buffs, so we did the highlights tour with a guide, Victoria, who had a very engaging gossipy style that brought it all to life. The dalliances of the royals of England and France were particularly prominent in the tour. The colledction covers paintings, furniture and armories. The highlights for us were the Canalettos of Venice and the Laughing Cavalier and the armoured horses.Fascinating and free, donations requested.

A hidden little gem. I've lived in London for years and didn't know this place until my mum found out about it and wanted to have a look. I'm not a museum-lover but this one changed my mind! Lovely collection of so many different pieces and the feeling of visiting someone else's house adds a different dimension to the experience. Plus there is a beautiful cafe inside with see-though walls, perfect place for an afternoon tea!

OTT gallery best taken in small doses. The Wallace is another of London's amazing freebies and still pretty unknown. But there's almost just too much of it- can lead to cultural indigestion. Suggest spend your time with the exquisite Dutch interior paintings and the armouries downstairs. Cloakroom to leave bags and a courtyard restaurant with nice cake but we had unfortunate experiences with the staff in both. To avoid being accosted, interrogated and moved on by an officious waiter you need to know that the restaurant is carefully segregated - posh to the right serving £17.50 afternoon teas and plebs to the left for cake and cappuccino. It would have helped to have a notice or for the receptionist to point it out first instead of saying 'sit anywhere'! The cloakroom attendant said we didn't need a ticket for our case and then of course when we went to collect it a different attendant refused to give it back WITHOUT a ticket......a little staff training on communication might be in order! I'm afraid we didn't leave a donation....

nice visit. this museum is very well kept ,notwithstanding the big amount of visitors due also to the fact that the museum is free , big Canaletto collection and a surprising Marie Antoinette Room , the armouries are a very rich collection if you have an interest in them nice museum shop and a very inviting restaurant in the covered courtyard ( I didn't eat there ) , on saturday a big queue ,better to reserve your table in advance

Overlooked for too long. As regular visitors to London, we confess to having overlooked this amazing museum. We made two visits within a few days, as there is a lot to absorb. The painting collection, which includes Hals' "The Laughing Cavalier", is just part of the attraction. The porcelain, furniture and armour also are impressive, but the mansion is full of treasures. Don't overlook the building itself. Adding free admission and a classy cafe means this venue deserves to be on every art-loving tourist list.
Excellent and interesting. Even if you don't fancy the collections, amazing afternoon teas with delicious food and a great relaxed atmosphere

Allow at least two days. This is the most wonderful collection of history. To be able to stand alone in front of " the laughing Cavalier" is a great privilege. The thing is there is just to much and the Wallace collection needs to be done in Bite sized pieces .. maybe 4 half days . There is a nice conservatory restaurant there as well

Superb collection. Recently refurbished rooms and a great collection of paintings and furniture make this a must visit museum. The restaurant is a good place to take lunch or afternoon tea and of course the museum has free admittance.
very nice. i liked the location, the collection and the lunch.The room for the lunch is very bright, there are few Canaletto's and it is a beautiful permanent exhibitionunliked.. nothing

Gem in London backstreet. A Must Visit for anyone going to London! This private art collection is just off Wigmore St London - near Oxford St, so if you can take the time to drop in and spend a few hours - and lunch or a coffee in the delightful atrium at the rear of the gallery
Nice architecture, but not my art taste. I don't like the classical art, but the architecture is great. It's handicap accessible. It has a gift shop and a lift. Donations are appreciated.
Opulence. A very interesting collection. I felt somewhat overpowered by the number of paintings and the opulence of the rooms. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful period collection. Beautiful Renaissance works by great artists - painters and sculptors. And also ceramics and armoury. French, Spanish, Dutch and English. 14th to 19th century. Well labeled with detailed manuals in each of the 26 galleries. Quiet and comfortable place with a cafe, cloak room and resting places.

a wonderful colour for a weekend. I try to visit all small museums whenever we are in London. this one, 18 Strafford terrace, leighton's house, john soanes' museum... all wonderful treats. Don't miss them!
Excellent ambience, food and service. The restaurant was beautifully set, low key and high quality for a special family occasion. Presentation and taste were key and the staff were not overbearing.
One of the best Heritage Collection. The place offers view of some of the antiques in mint state. The place is awesome and takes you 150 years back in History :)

fantastic free day out. The wallace collection is a must to see when visiting london. 25 galleries filled with paintings, furniture, porcelain and the largest armoury in Europe. Theres so much to see and enjoy. If you like fine art from 15th to 19th centuries you will thoroughly enjoy your visit.

Different. A lovely place to bring visitors to have a meal and a look round the museum. It is different and unique experience. Food is average. But a lovely atmosphere ...bright and sunny conservatory to sit in for a meal especially when it is wet and cold outside.

Just a few minutes off Oxford Street - Must see!. This amazing gift to the world - a beautiful home housing an amazing art collection. The family history is interesting but just strolling around this mansion in central London is almost an other worldly feeling.

Cultural few hours. Looking for somewhere not too large but with enough to keep you engrossed, then try The Wallace Collection. It houses "The Laughing Cavelier " along with many other wonderful paintings, carvings, armour etc. Plus it has a wonderful cafe where you can get a beautiful light lunch, glass of wine,afternoon tea, scones, cakes, etc. All reasonably priced and very good! As is the service, I should not be telling you all about this I should keep it to my self."

Great place to meet up with someone. Have a date with someone? Take them here and then for tea or a drink inside. Its a beautiful place filled with history. Walk around before she/he gets there, so you can impress them with all your knowledge!

One of the finest galleries, museums, and homes you will find. One of the great features of London is its many galleries of all kinds, many (like this one) free of charge. A friend recommended this collection to us, and we were impressed far beyond our expectations. The collection of art is amazing, ranging from Constable and De Valazco to Rembrandt. Many other fine works, including many by accomplished but less well known artists, are on display as well. Most impressive too were the collections of armor, knives, swords, rifles, pistols, and a multitude of similar armaments from the Crusades and other periods ... wall upon wall, in many rooms; simply breathtaking. The structure, being an elegant and substantial Victorian mansion, is astounding in its own right. We spent two hours here and could have stayed longer. We bought a well-done book there describing the collection, family, and home, for about 6-7 pounds, which was helpful and will be a cherished reminder and keepsake. There is a restaurant on premises which looks nice but is quite pricey; due to a time constraint and line waiting, we did not try it. The restrooms are immaculate. Overall, in our view this experience is on a par with the National Gallery and National Portrait Gallery (which we love). Note, there is a good selection of places to eat on James and Marylebone High Street nearby.

House is beautiful- afternoon tea not so... What can I say ??!!! Our waiter was great, the food dry, hardly any filling in the sandwiches, one scone per person, cakes bland. Took 3 hours for afternoon tea. Terribly disappointing and would not go again for afternoon tea an absolute waste of money.I would rate the tea a one - the house however, is beautiful and well worth a visit.

An absolute must. Quintessentially British, this is an absolute must for any visit to London. It is one of the best collections in the world, say nothing about private collections. It is as British and English as the National Gallery, Victoria and Albert or British Museums are. In fact, it is a combination and a concentrated extract of them all: the combination of paintings, sculpture, furniture, china, porcelain, glass, crystal is nothing but stunning. For me, it is a full day of roaming through the rooms there and pure and unadulterated delight it is.

Best Museum in London. This place is unbelievable. A huge house stuffed full of the most incredible beautiful stuff. Sevres porcelain, including items from Madam Pompadour's bed chamber. Amazing furniture acquired at knock down prices during the French Revolution. A room full of Canaletto paintings. Other rooms full of Van Dykes, Rembrandt's, and many old masters including; Frans Hals 'The Laughing Cavalier', one of the most brilliant of all Baroque portraits. Rooms full of armour, guns and swords. Room after room full of miniatures, icons and ceramics. So much to see.I've been a number of times and see something different each time, even though the collection, left to the nation by Lady Wallace, never changes. There's just so much of it. I've taken friends, grandchildren, my husband, and even go on my own. It's fascinating,Free to all visitors, just behind Selfridges, there's also a lovely restaurant and cafe. The food is lovely; tasty and beautifully made and presented. The last meal I had there was the smoked salmon quiche, which came with potato salad and a small green salad. The quiche was beautiful. The staff are also very friendly and helpful.If ever you are in London this is an absolutely must see museum. You will not be disappointed, and I bet you'll want to go back again. PS: Whilst I've clicked good for couples it's only because I couldn't click on all the icons; Family (young children), Family (teens), Friends, Business - for a lunch, Solo. Good for them all.

Lovely courtyard. I absolutely adore stopping off at this place for some cake and tea after a busy day of shopping down bond street. The carrot cake is absolutely delightful, just like the calming atmosphere of the bright courtyard.

Fantastic Small Museum with an unbelievable collection. This is one of the finest museums I have visited. It is located in a quaint old building in the heart of London and is easy to get to by the tube. We set off at around 10am, the museum has a nice place to store coats and bags and has no entry fees. They have a fantastic collections of paintings, armor, chest sets, jewelry, etc. The museum is small and not crowded and you get to see each painting closely the room are nicely designed and there is a nice cafeteria and book store within the building. Overall a very nice experience and would rate it a one of the finest in the world. Walking distance from dozen of restaurants where one can have lunch or dinner or a snack after a couple of hours of museum watching.
Great, if you love 18th century France. Lots of paintings and furniture from 18th century france, great free tours and yet again one of these excentric British institutions.

Everyone should support this fabulous collection. The entry is free, and the collection is always in need of public support. One if the best intact house museums in Europe, this is a must-visit for fans of art, collectibles, interior design and great mansion architecture. Just a few steps from Selfridges but a world away.

Incredible paintings. We came here two days running. I had not been here for about 15 years and had forgotten what a treat it is. Wonderful collection of paintings, miniatures, furniture, china, glass ........everything. Although we do travel a great deal I do wonder, with gems like this , why we don't just stay in London! The restaurant is beautiful and the lunchtime menu just what we wanted. The only downside was two women sitting at one of the tables for hours using the restaurant as an office, on their laptops and banging on on the telephone; couldn't they afford an office? I'd have chucked them out but the management were too nice and polite!

Free entry to famous collection. We made a special trip into London to see this collection on a very cold wet January day. It is not a huge place, all the staff were very helpful, but I found the collection not too my liking as everything was very ornate. Very pleased it was free entry. Much preferred Tate Britain.
A beautiful house . . . . . .. Room after room of wonderful treasures. And one full of just Canalettos ! Amazing and it`s free but really worth a considerable donation.
Wallace Collection. Not the most friendly here! Strictly for 'old money' couples having lunch, the blue-rinse brigade were out in force when I was there.

Worth a visit. One of the best collection of arms and armour I've ever seen. Absolutely brilliant. Some interesting paintings too, and there is a lovely courtyard café where it is most pleasant to sit and eat cake.

Very impressive.. Have meant to visit for years now and was not disappointed. Amazing collection of paintings and furniture. Didn't have time to see everything. Will definitely visit again. Good restaurant too.
Interesting. Lots of interesting objects, Drumond St is over the road if you fancy a nice vegy Indian food. or you can pop down to Soho for some Dim Sum or uck and Belly Pork

Don't miss this wonderful corner of London. Have visited here several times and there is always more to see and wonder at. The Wallace Collection never fails to impress and the elegant restaurant with its attentive staff is definitely not to be missed. Whether you want a light lunch beautifully presented and full of freshness and flavour, or a delicious afternoon tea, reminiscent of Victorian times in this setting, you will not be disappointed. Give yourself enough time to do it all justice - and then come back for more!

Lunch with my daughter. An absolute delight, the place is fresh , light airy and has a contemporary twist in such a beautiful old building. I was in love with the building as much as the food. The service and food was impeccable and they couldn't do enough for you, what a treat indeed. I hope to return again soon.
Spectacular. An unbelievably high quality collection which is compact and unique. A must-see in London, even ahead of the mainstream museums.

Brilliant!. First visit since the Sainsbury room has been refurbished. This wonderful house really is a gem. The paintings, statues and armoury are all very well displayed in superb surroundings. There is a small shop and a really nice cafe in the centre. A stones throw from Oxford street and free. Well worth a visit.

Great for a date. The Wallace Collection is great at capturing the public imagination - sex, death and madness tend to feature highly in the themes of their exhibits. The Sexology exhibition is wryly humorous. Probably not the kind you'd want to visit with your parents, but not as explicit as the name suggests. I'd particularly recommend coming here if you want to find out about the study of gay, lesbian and transsexual cultures before they entered mainstream consciousness.

One of the best kept secrets of London. As a collection, museum. This is one of the best of the world. The combination of painters masterpieces and junk make the visitor to understand the decorative taste of the Earls that build such collection and the combination of amazing furnitures, china, sculptures make it a really special place. I have visited more than 100 times and never get tired of it.The restaurant in the internal courtyard is amazing. The food great. I have notice that recently it was redecorated with smaller chairs and tables. I have not have the opportunity to visit it after the remodulation.

one of the best in LOndon. with the new lights and painting, i think the work finished in 2014, the collection that was already amazing, became spetacular. some of the paintings were cleaned so the colors are amazing.

What a gem. We have been here a few times and love it more each time. This trip we went for a clock tour and it is great to here all about the exhibits. The laughing Cavalier is amazing. Also the cafe is a great place to relax and chill out. This is an absolute must visit.

Haven of peace and 18th elegance. An amazing place just a hop skip and a jump from Marylebone High Street. You can get lost in reveries looking at the paintings and sculptures here - also nice cafe for meeting long lost friends.

Remarkable. The largest set of armory displays I have seen and in great condition. Plus the art, furniture and architecture makes this place a good stop. Nice restaurant in the center. They let you try on armor. And its part of the free museum stops in London. Got to see it

Well worth seeking this out behind Selfridges. Amazing! Beautiful house with stunning collections - armour, paintings and china a real wow. Glass covered atrium provides a wonderful place to eat - whatever the weather!

An amazing opportunity to view World Class art and antiques for free-just 5 mins from Selfridges. This amazing Museum/mansion is located just north of Selfridges about 4-6 mins walk away.The entrance is free of charge and if you have some time to spare I highly recommend a visit.The paintings are wonderful and in particular, some of the best Canalettos on view in London. The taste of the collection veers towards French and Rococo taste but there are other Dutch Old Masters and a collection of Arms and Armour. There are shops and a cafe. Do not miss this one.
Perfect!. My favourite London museum. A gem in every respect. Helpful staff and a good restaurant help to make this one of the best art/museum experiences in the city
Fabulous - delicious food and culture. Loved the fabulous food, we shared the gnocchi and crepes! Both delicious. The service was great, friendly and delightful staff.

Elegant and intriguing. This museum is in a lovely setting, I feel like I'm walking around the house of an aristocrat. It's not too large so you feel free to take your time and ponder the art. Our favourite rooms where the armouries!
Extensive collection. Free entry, great courtyard cafe/restaurant and a good selection of art, ceramics and other exhibits.Perfect escape from the craziness of Oxford Street.
Wonderful!!!. What a wonderful collection -not your main stream museum or gallery but full of rare items all in a great environment - highly recommended

Surprising . The collection is large and varied. Some of the pieces, especially the furniture, are exquisite. And, the entry is free. There is a cafe that looked quite pleasant situated in an enclosed courtyard.

Definitely worth a visit. A beautiful grand house in the middle of London. Friendly staff. We took the free hour long guided tour, our guide was knowledgeable and interesting, pointing out the highlights of the collection. Free entry and definitely worth a visit.

A superb collection. This is one of London's museum treasures. Collections of paintings and sculptures are complemented by equally superb collections of armour and weapons. Not to be missed.The highly praised restaurant is overpriced, and, I have been informed, its management do not pass on any of the so-called 'service charge' to the waiters and kitchen staff. Insist on removing the charge and instead pay your waiter a tip in cash. It's bad enough having to pay VAT, but it's a nerve being asked to pay a service charge which never reaches the servers.
A fabulous free museum in central London. A real cornucopia of art in a beautiful setting - world famous paintings, furniture, armour - it's all here.

Brilliant free attraction. This was well worth the visit, the art goes up to the 1900's, the family stopped buying at that point. You can spend a good couple of hours looking around. The house is very much left as the family intended. Amazing collection of renaissance paintings and sculptures alike.One of the best bits is the atrium restaurant, with a glass ceiling, it's quite. large with lots of seating. Great for food and drinks, including alcohol. Cake looked fab, though we didn't have any. I had a very good camomile tea and my husband an English breakfast tea. Cost was around £4 each, for a pot.

Entertaining talk. The guided morning talk was excellent and to be recommended. It lasted for approximately one hour and highlighted different elements of the collection - furniture, pottery, paintings and armour. There were so many interesting facts and I certainly felt that I learnt a great deal. The recently refurbished rooms have enhanced the hanging of the paintings, but may not be to everyone's taste. The staff were friendly and it was very easy to leave small suitcases in the cloakroom area. We did not eat there but the eating area looks very grand.

Do not miss this treasure house. I have walked past this museum for the last 50 years and while I always meant to visit did not do so until this year. It is a wealth of artistic endeavour including the building, fabrics, furniture, sculptures, painings, obects d'atre porcelain, bronzes. It is pointless trying to list specific items. Entry is free but a donoation is requested. My one piece of advice is to try and select exactly what you want to see before you visit otherwise the result will be stimulus overload and only half remembered glimpses. Be sure to lift up the covers on the display cabinets to see one of the best collections of 19th century miniatures. A very gooo restaurant / coffee shop is available for meals and the occassional light meal. Why did I fail not to visit sooner? Small children will not appreciate a visit but teenagers will.
wonderful. possibly my favourite gallery! a unique experience the feeling of visiting a grand house.make sure you have lunch which is really enjoyable

Possibly the best Victoria sponge in London. A beautiful collection in a magnificent home. The Laughing Cavilier and a Rembrandt self portrait are among the highlights. Admission was free and it is hard to find better value anywhere in London. There is a wonderful glass covered internal courtyard that sells one of the best Victoria sponges that I tasted in London. All up an excellent experience.

Eye opening visit. This was a highlight of our trip to London. I am a history buff with a love for arms and armor. There is plenty of that to se here. All very ornamental and fabulous. It's hard to believe how old the articles you're looking at actually are.
Eclectic. Great collection, rather more varied than the usual museum and staff are helpful and keen to share their knowledge and enthusiasm for the collection.

Make Time To Discover The History Of The Collectors. This is deservedly the number one attraction on TripAdvisor, the collections and setting are stunning. The staff are friendly and efficient. There is so much to see in this treasure house and it is important to stay fresh, not become information overloaded, and take a break using the excellent catering facilities. However, please take time to discover the story behind the collectors that created the Wallace and enjoy the recently added section in the basement.
Outstanding. Don't miss out on this hidden gem in London. Amazing gallery. Take plenty of time to visit, and relax in the cafe after the visit.
Geordie Gastronomes. The armoury was stunning. Beautifully displayed and documented. Lots of famous paintings, time-pieces, furniture and a lovely cafe. Free but please leave a donation.

Better than ever after refurbishment. The rooms and art look better than ever after recent refurbishment.I would say that this is a pretty unknown destination, but it seems to be ranked no 1. Rarely crowded. A delight.

All this and culture!. A fantastic eaterie in a stunning building filled with the treasure of The Wallace Collection.The restaurant is in the glass covered well of the building and is flooded with light.The atmosphere is relaxed and informal and the food while basic is good value for money.It feels like a special day out to go tour the museum rooms and then eat in the restaurant afterwards.

Amazing. No wonder this ranks as the number one in London. This amazing house with its incredible collection is an absolute must. Also to be visited is the cafe, superb food, excellent service and great value.
Fantastic. Wide range of fascinating artworks. Also Cafe is excelent. One day is just not enough. Going back for more!!

Nice, but not impressive. I couldn't believe this is ranked no. 1 attraction in London. It's a nice collection of art and the story of the family is interesting, but there are far more beautiful art pieces at other galleries or museums (Tate Modern amongst others). The building itself is quite imposing, but out of all the free museums in London, this should barely be in the top 10.
Incredible place. Really interesting collections - detail and complexity is staggering. Have visited many times over the years

A great collection. Wallace Collection is a superb, elegant collection of paintings, porcelain, ceramics, furniture and what not. This is one of the most wonderful collections I have ever seen and everything is displaced with great artistic skill.
Excellent restaurant. We just went here for lunch with friends, but the food and service were outstanding. Very different from our experience there some years ago.

Wonderful small art gallery. After its recent refurbishment, the mansion holding this collection looks great. Many interesting artworks - some very famous. Go for an organised tour with a guide - it was excellent (and free!)

Great way to spend a day or any part of the day. This was only our second visit to the Wallace Collection - our first was many years ago and it has been refurbished since.You could easily spend all day here - and with a lovely restaurant in the central covered courtyard, you have places for pauses with refreshments or lunch.There is so much to see - hard to pick out highlights as all have different tastes. The place was uncrowded and you could move round at your own pace. Also, as it is so much smaller than the big museums and galleries, you can retrace your steps to catch up on something you may have missed.

Wonderful Cultiral Oasis off Oxford St. This is a superb, eclectic collection of paintings, furniture, ceramics and militaria; bueatifully presented in a truly amazing building.The cafe is in the covered courtyard and is worth the visit alone.

Hidden gem of a restaurant. There are two good reasons to go here - one is the fabulous art collection of course, but the other is the gorgeous restaurant in the glass covered atrium. It is an oasis of civilised calm in such a lovely setting, which is a treat to visit for quiet lunch when a couple of hundred yards away there are hoards of people in Oxford St desperately looking for somewhere nice to eat and blissfully unaware it is there ( so don't tell ''em).Not cheap - about £25-30 each for two courses but such a lovely ambience that is worth the bit extra. There are two options, the restaurant or adjoining cafe. Both great but better comfy chairs in the restaurant. If you haven't been to the gallery before, obviously do that too and come back again just to eat as a treat. No wonder the cavalier is laughing.
A must see place.. Excellent day program to get lost in the many rooms of this museum.The cafe is excellent. Perfect for lunch. Go and see it it won't disappoint you!

Wonderful Collection. What a fantastic find, with free entry to a stunning collection of art, ceramics, armour furniture and clocks. Donations to maintain the collection are of course very welcome. In addition a wonderful tea room with a choice of the café area or a more sophisticated restaurant all within a glass covered courtyard. The collection is like the V & A but on a scale that can all be viewed on a single day. The audio tour at a modest cost adds greatly to the experience.
A hidden Gem. Fantastic exhibition and tea room hidden behind Oxford Street. Great to have a bit of culture in the day away from the shops. A perfect place to meet!
High Tea on a Grand Scale. I took 14 university students to high tea after viewing the collection. It was a delightful experience and a highlight of their London stay.

Only minutes from Oxford Street but worth three hours of your time. heard of this venue from a friend, and whilst I've visited London and Oxford Street many times in the past I had never realised that the Wallace Collection was so near and so accessible.Stroll up Duke Street beside Selfridges and you come upon Manchester House just off the square. The outside gives little indication of the art treasures inside. What I loved was the feeling of openness and accessibility to some of the most outstanding and excellent examples of international art from the past 500 years. The works are extremely well displayed and the visitor is allowed to view many of them up close without the usual restrictions of barriers getting in the way.We visited on a Monday and found we were able to stroll around the house and enjoy looking at the exhibits without feeling overcrowded or hustle. Not knowing what to expect in advance, we planned to be there less than two hours. In the end we were there for well over three hours and found the whole experience totally absorbing. A visit is a must.

One of London's hidden gems. A short walk north from Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is one of London's hidden gems, housing one of the best collections of art in London. The stunning collection is displayed in historic rooms, furnished with a fine collection of French antique furniture and clocks. The central courtyard houses a good restaurant and temporary exhibitions are shown in purpose-built galleries at the lower kevel. The Picture Gallery has recently been restored and is an amazing space.

A hidden gem. I complained at the desk that the route to this gallery was not well signposted. I was told that they cannot cope with any more visitors and the people who really wNt to be there, find them, I think this says it all. It is an amazing collection of art in the form of paintings, furniture, jewellery, porcelain etc in a grand old home,

Well worth a visit!. One of the best things about the Wallace Collection is that it's in a house! The artworks are accessible and numerous. The restaurant is also good, although the service was a little slow.
A Gem. A Gem in the center of London hidden and precious so unique that is highily recomended for all art lovers

Free and fabulous!. The recent refurbishment and rehang of this gallery has been a complete success. It is much brighter than before, with natural light introduced into the Long Gallery where many of the most famous paintings (e.g. The Laughing Cavalier) are to be found. Considering how close this gallery is to Oxford St, it's surprising that more people don't regularly visit, but its relative emptiness is another plus factor. So ignore this review please and continue not to go!
Some Digs. A wonderful collection of art and weaponry in a fantastic setting. You can smell the opulence of how "some" people lived in London. A great experience.

a hidden gem that not a lot of people know about... FREE!. I re-visited recently as a friend reminded me about it (hadn't been for years) and realised how good this museum is.There is something for everyone - armour (me!), Louis Quinze furniture (her), and lots of art and ceramics. It's a real mix, so there always seems to be something different around every corner.Other: It's never been crowded whenever I've visited - so if you are in London at the height of the tourist season, and getting fed up of being jam-packed in museums - I suggest that you give the Wallace Collection a go. Well worth it!Point to note for disabled access: ALWAYS call before you visit, as one time we visited the lift ('elevator' for our US cousins) was not working, and then we called a few more times in the following week and it was still up the creek (this was quite a few years ago).

Jan Weenix paintings and the Laughing Cavalier. Wonderful collection and never busy. I prefer the Wallace Collection over many of London's more well know sites. A must if you like baroque art or have an interest in armour!

Too much to enjoy fully. The Wallace is undeniably impressive but maybe I am a philistine but when I go to somewhere so compacted with fantastic artwork I feel the overload is oppressive.I was standing in a room with one of the most famous portraits in the world ( The Laughing Cavalier ) and found I could not really appreciate it due to the saturation of art.Sometimes less is more
A Wallace at the Wallace collection. Fabulous I love it ,very old fashioned of course ..with a very nice restaurant ..not cheap though ..
Nice!. We went for afternoon tea, it's a lovely atmosphere, friendly service and one of the better food offerings of the may places that do afternoon tea

London's Equivalent of New York's Frick Collection. A private collection housed in the collectors house in Manchester Square. This museum is well worth a visit. The paintings are some of the best in the world. Like the Frick look out for Fragonard. Also Velazquez and Poussin are featured as well as Frans Hals' "Laughing Cavalier". There is usually a side exhibition that is also worth seeing.

Fantastic not-so-known Collection. We found the Wallace Gallery by luck just driving around. We decided to get in because of the elegant building and such a surprise it was!!notable collection in a incomparable place.
Wonderful. Beautiful house, fabulous art and delicious food. Absolute gem. This was my first visit but hopefully won't be my last.

little gem. We called in to the Wallace Collection to fill a few hours when in the area. It was we'll worth going plenty to see and easy to find. You can probably skip through it in an hour if you are short of time.

A wonderful museum. Having seen that this museum was No. 2 on TA my wife and I could not resist visiting as part of our anniversary weekend in the Capital.We were not disappointed!The initial welcome we received on entering to the helpful staff around the whole museum this really is a truly fantastic place to visit ... and all FREE.!Please do make a donation to help ensure it for future generations.Every room is so well presented, the guide book (a MUST at just £7) very informative and the displays ideally laid out. A totally enjoyable experience.Please do visit the cafe/bistro – the service is to high standard with quality beverages and food on offer.
Exceptional. Collection, taking you for a visit through time. Culture as well as a great place to stop for a bite

Astonishing. Probably the most opulent collection of Boulle master pieces and exceptional quality 18th century furniture, mainly from France. And a surprising collection of armours.This is an incredible gem not to be missed.
Amazing. Great free museum inpatient lovely square just joff Oxford street. Great varied collection in a beautiful house

Cracking collection,Gromit !. Ive visted this collection twice and it is well worth seeing.The layout of the house and the permanent displays are first class.The middle eastern and Indian armour sections are impressive and the lady on the swing painting deserves a look, not just the Laughing cavalier,but this is too is wonderful.If you are en route to Amsterdam,this could be a good place to see a few Dutch masters before hitting the Rijksmuseum.

Wonderful. The Collection is wonderful. Service in the café area was shambolic and rude. We'd planned to have a meal in the restaurant area later on but decided that more of the same behaviour would spoil our day out so we went elsewhere.
Inspiring to see a man collect all that. Mr. Wallace would be remembered to be a man with eagle eyes for the best. You can also eat at the restaurant at the back.

What an absolute gem. i have lived in London for many years and can't believe this is the first time I have visited this wonderful collection. Normally I find armour and arms boring but this was the best bit, very interesting and amazing workmanship. Fell in love with a Rembrandt and a Rubens and of course the Laughing Cavalier, all in one room.

Paintings and armour - what can be more fun?. Great armour and weapons collection - fun for the kids ( young and old). Very good collection of French 18th century with several Vigee Le Brun paintings. Also a minature of her 1782 self portriat. Be sure to see Frans Hal's the Laughing Calvier in the Grand Galley - the lace work is wonderful.

Brilliant. I visit almost every time I am in London. A great collection of paintings by many famous artists. I say hello to The Laughing Cavalier. The building is a beautiful house well maintained and decorated. It is just off Oxford Street so easy to find and free.

Beautiful building and art work. Very convenient location as you shop along oxford street to take a break at this old home converted into an art museum Beautiful inside decor, well maintained, free of charge
hidden treasure. loved this place , hidden gem just off oxford street . it has an abundance of art work and old armourments . its free to get in and compares with the bigger museums around here

The very best of London. Only in the Britain could you spend such a fantastic hour or two without charge. A sublime collection of furniture and an even better gallery of paintings.Everything from Gainsborough to Rembrandt, Velasquez to Murillo and a whole room devoted to Guardi and Canaletto paintings of Venice.
