Breathtaking!A delightful coffee shop or lunch venue on the first floor and I'm not sure how you can spend a better morning in London. I'm lost for words.It's so good that everyone leaves a donation, if only out of embarrassment that it should be free. The very best of London.

laughing all the way. Great building to visit even without the added joy of seeing the actual laughing cavalier.The gallery is in Manchester sq just behind all the shops in Oxford street so is very handy if you want to combine shopping with site seeing .
An oasis behind Oxford St. The calm away from the storm of the West End. A wonderful collection to visit free of charge then a fabulous restaurant all under one roof.

Lovely small museum. Now that you have visited all the big sights, duck in here some rainy afternoon. You will be charmed by the first-rate collection (not nearly as many snuff boxes as I was led to believe), and it's free! Go on, be classy, buy the guide book!

Well worth popping into!. We went along on a Sunday morning and just so happened to be in time for a free highlights tour. A charming, extremely informative and interesting guide took us around this beautiful mansion room by room, entertaining us with anecdotes which seemed to bring the whole property and its contents to life! I can see why this is so high up on the list of Tripadvisor atrractions in London. And it's completely free! There's a nice place for coffee in the airy enclosed courtyard too!
Great slice of culture. Love this place, the perfect place to get yourself lost for a few hours. The picutures are amazing and the space stunning, its almost a secret place to loose yourself

The Wallace Collection. A free art gallery with an outstanding collection of works. Situated in Manchester Square in easy reach of Baker Street this museum is easily accessible from the very heart of the capital. marvel at the paintings on disply...too numerous to mention but also the excellent display of armoury on the lower floor.The Wallace collection boasts a very nice restaurant...perhaps a little pricey and good toilet and cloakroom facilities.
An oasis. I liked the landscape paintings. I liked very much the elegance of the place. I didn't like two of the staff, their insensitivity disturbed the calmness of the place.

Outstanding. The Wallace Collection has never made the cut on previous trips to London...just couldn't find the time. That was a mistake! I'm so glad that I did find the time on this trip. The Wallace Collection is the complete package because not only do you get to see fantastic works of art, you also tour the magnificent mansion in which it has been housed for the last several hundred years. Truly an outstanding experience! I plan to return on my next trip. there is also a café in the covered courtyard and an excellent shop.

Great find. Fantastic place in the heart of the West End of London. Beautiful artwork and historical artifacts in an exquisite house. Admission free. The dining area is lovely for afternoon tea or meals and the quality of food good.

my preferite spot of London. The best secret spot collection of art in London . I discovered few years ago and now with the new gallery , the paintings have really the perfect location. if you like art , from the 1400 to 1660 centuries this the place! I suggest to enjoy the free tours around 1-2 pm , really interesting

One of the best art collections in the finest settings. I met an old friend here who I hadn't seen in decades. As distracting as that might be, we both agreed that this was a perfect setting of beauty in which to reunite. She had been before, and I had always wanted to go; despite having lived in London for years, I had never got round to it. It is impossible to see all that you want to in a day, but what treasures. The cafe in the courtyard was a lovely place to take a break from the surfeit of beauty and it was marvelous seeing paintings I'd seen in books for years and in an exquisite setting. An absolute must-do.

a lot of period art in one place. Nice to be an a home and look at art even if very ornate and over hung, a bit heavy for my taste. The light atrium for lunch was good but the service and waiters not particularly attentive however the food was healthy and nice sized portions

Amazing. Compared to other free museums and galleries, it was the best one. Since it is a private collection unchanged by museum employees it reflects the old atmosphere better. It is immersive and all displayed items look in place. I absolutely loved the combination of pictures with the furniture and rooms' interior overall. Take a free guided tour for an even better experience.

A great surprice. It´s a lovely collection, it´s a good experience, it´s a great surprice. Good recomended.The Wallace Collection is a state art museum, private centric beautiful home, located in London. Located at the offices of Hertford House, Manchester Square. It was founded from the private collection of Sir Richard Wallace, who was bequeathed by his widow in 1897.

Wallace Collection - Outstanding.. London's best kept secret! In the top five galleries we have seen in Europe. The Wallace Collection is just outstanding in their presentation. Expert comments from the guides and staff, all of whom were attentive and helpful, stunning collection of French and English art, furniture and porcelain. The armery collection from the Middle Ages is extensive and very interesting. Whorthy of note is the Coffee Lounge/A-La Carte Restuarant in the centre of Wallace House, excellent French Food and service.Guys - Take the ladies, I'm not big on galleries, but with the food and the armery/weapons section, the Wallace Collection is a must. It is also free.

Lovely museum with an outstanding restaurant space. If you like 17th - 19th century European art this is the museum for you. Set in a beautiful town mansion close to the south end of Baker Street, this is easy to get to, and delightful to visit.Even if you are not a fan of classical art and furniture, visit the restaurant, in a covered courtyard. It is absolutely delightful. Good food and very good service.

Rich works of art in an intimate setting. A gem of a place in a square behind Selfridges. Beautiful house full of French furniture, fine Sevres porcelain and French, Dutch and English paintings, and a collection of armour, all displayed in intimate settings.Free entry, but donations are encouraged.

Visual joy. The beauty of the rooms, and paintings and objets de vertu.The lectures are worthwhile. The frequent Saturday all-day art classes in the studio are of the highest quality and good value.I don't like the restaurant. The hard floor is very noisy.

Not for me. I love art and treasures and had wanted to visit The Wallace collection for some time but this particular collection just wasn't for me. Room after room of mostly huge 'glitz' Italianate OTT furniture and gloomy paintings..though the famous Laughing Cavalier and the Rembrandts plus a few others lightened the viewing. There were some rare early pieces of glass and ceramics which caught my attention but unless you like galleries full of armouries and religious pieces, it can be somewhat tedious and tiring traipsing the corridors. I've rated it four as I'm sure most people would enjoy the collection more than us....just not my taste. The cafe was situated in a nice environment and the loos were very modern and clean.
Constant delight. The Wallace Collection is a gem. There is so much to see that even after three visits there is still lots I have to discover.

Wallace Collection - Outstanding London. This is a glittering treasure trove of artistic pleasure, paintings, statues and the magnificent architecture of the building itself! This get my vote for 'Outstanding London'.Make time to see this one, Reubens and the 'Laughing Cavalier' await! We made time to have coffee in the graceful dining area and went back there for lunch. Well worth it! We followed up the visit with a respectful view of the church nearby, St. James's RC Church and a stroll around Regents Park. The pleasure enhanced by a crowd free atmosphere on the day we were there.

A wee gem !!. Stumbled across this place quite by accident, because we were staying in a nearby hotel.
Had never heard of it, but wandered in for a look.
Amazing art work and decor.
Well worth a visist; we will go back again,next time we are in London

Fabulous collection. "The Laughing Cavalier" has always been one of my favorite paintings and this was the impetus for visiting the Wallace collection but there is much more to see than this. The house is magnificent as are the art and armory displays. Compared to other London galleries it is also quieter. One of our London higghlights.

Loved the Wallace Collection!. The building is filled with beautiful artwork, furnishings and porcelain. There is no admission cost. Location is convenient and close to Oxford St. Highly recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection!

Do the docent tour. Thanks for other TA reviewers I discovered this gem. This art collection can be easily walked in 2-3 hours however I especially liked the docent tour (1-1/4 hours) because she provided interesting details and insights on specific pieces in the collection.
Wished I had planned ahead to have lunch there as their cafe looked delightful.

Vanishing Breed. There are not a lot of these boutique type old family museums left. It gives you a broad insight into the aristocratic classes of a time gone by and English living in a forgotten age.

Another disaster if you want to have lunch.. Great place to visit and the artifacts etc in the building are wonderful. Free entrance and the site for the courtyard cafe is lovely. However, once again the guy who is a judge on the TV programme - Great British Menu - should reflect and improve the menu and the quality of the food served in the cafes he owns/ runs. I also visited the Imperial War Museum ,in London, thus month and the cafe there ( also run by the same guy) is terrible- quite a disaster!The common features of both cafes are over priced food which is poorly cooked and not very tasty! Please sort it out Oliver, before judging the food prepared by chefs on TV - you really need to focus on the food served by the cafes you run because your poor food is letting these places down!

Follow Up Visit Only Reinforces The Quality. This is the second proper visit I have paid - the place is absolutely stunning. Immensely satisfying. How anyone can criticise it 'it's not perfect but' is beyond me. An absolutely stunning and truly world class collection. The detail of the whole building is sublime. There is something wrong with anyone who is not stunned or impressed with the Wallace. One of the world's must see collections. See Naples and die? Not in the same league!
FABULOUS COLLECTIOM. Couldn't believe that there was no entrance fee to this collection. Very well worth the visit. Loved the house, architecture and artworks. Thank you,

excellent and informative. It is well worth spending a day in this magnificent house far from the madding crowds of Oxford st (Bond st is a close Tube station). The house is crammed with works of art from the 1500's to 1850 including famous Old Masters, French furniture, armour for humans and horses, fine china, ancient clocks and fabulous rooms lined with silk. Hard to believe a well to do family could collect so many things! Lots of information about each piece. The cafe has excellent food and service. Highly recommended.

One of my favorite museum in London and free. I have been there several times with my kids and friends and I always loved the collection. It is so diverse that everytime I discover something new and interesting. When we have visitors, I always send them to the Wallace Collection. Their armors collection is so unique that kids and adults will love it. It is free but contributions are welcome to support this unique place.

Excellent...and free!. A wonderful art collection in a beautiful house. If this was anywhere else in the world it would costs ££££s to get in but because it's London it totally free. Please give a voluntary contribution to help it continue.

Visual delight. The gallery has been refurbished and now shines with light and rich colours. The paintings are a delight to see and set in beautiful rooms. There was plenty of information available and admission is free. There is now a restaurant in the centre but we did not try it.Easy to find just off Oxford Street and a pleasant alternative to the manic sales.

Unique Collection You Can See Nowhere Else. The Wallace Collection is far from perfect, but I can't help but give it the top "excellent" rating because of its historical significance and artwork that can only be seen here.The Wallace Collection was amassed by several Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace. It is housed in what appears to be a huge mansion circa 1800 and under the terms made when the collection was donated it must stay there. The result is both good and bad. On the good, the collection is magnificent and we all get to see it for free. The impressive setting is also exactly what is needed to show off much of the art. On the minus, it's kind of a time machine frozen in the early 1800's, and it's hard some times to find the best of the best among the many, many pieces. Some rooms have walls virtually covered by oil paintings going up three or more levels, so it's impossible to see everything in one visit or, in some cases, to find a particular piece you might want. We found the staff extremely helpful, however, so if there is a particular painting or piece you want to see I wouldn't hesitate to ask.Most of the art dates from around 1400 to the early 1800s. There is no contemporary art, nor, frankly, would it fit into this setting. They have maps and materials there, but before you go you might want to take a look at the museum's excellent website, which has various "tours" set up for you, including one of the collection's highlights.You have already seen photos or images of much of the art in the collection as it is virtually iconic. These include the "Laughing Cavalier" by Franz Hals and "The Swing" by Jean-Honore Fragonard, along with other works. The art includes pieces from Rembrandt (although you don't need an expert to see that several are from his studio, not from him), Titian, Rubens, Hans Holbein, Velazquez, Poussin, and Jan Steen. If you are a little pressed for time, perhaps the "best of the best" paintings are in the newly renovated "Great Gallery" on the second floor. The room itself is extremely impressive, and beautifully displays these magnificent oils.You also do not want to miss the great armor galleries on the back of first floor. This is the greatest display of armor we have seen and even the members of our family with no interest in military matters were fascinated by the ornate details of many of the pieces. They also have one of the few (apparently only three exist) complete sets of horse armor from before 1500. There are many examples of jousting and ceremonial armor. There are also examples of armor from Asia.Several of the rooms have pieces under cloths to protect them from light damage. They encourage you to lift the flaps and you should do so as many are exquisite, including a miniature by Hans Holbein the Younger (of Henry VIII fame).We expected a nice museum and were surprised at the fun and quality of the armory and the overall experience of visiting here. We'd gladly come back to find the treasures we missed the first time.

Interesting. This place was free, donations accepted. Beautiful building, some interesting art inside and a lovely tea room what a treat. Would recommend if you have done all the big famous galleries etc..
Wow! A total gem.. Unfortunately, a large portion of the armory was closed (which is what we originally came for) but we stayed for the rest! An amazing collection––and it's free!!

A London must for fine art in a personal setting.. Over the years I have visited the Wallace Collection several times, always experiencing delight at the excellence of the many-faceted collection expertly arranged on various floors of what was a large private residence. It ranges from enormous paintings to tiny miniatures, most of it to a very high standard. I don't appreciate the collection of arms, but among many other collections, enamels and 18th century painting are well represented and there are also interesting temporary exhibitions. I shall try to go to see Reynolds in 2015. A snack in the glazed-in courtyard sometimes proves a bit of a struggle, but most relaxing after a two-hour visit. Entrance is free.

LOVELY INTERIOR. Excellent and free of charge nice outing for all ages. Very interesting and location good too. There is a nice dining restaurant and afternoon tea area also. Wonderful that this venue is free of charge too.

wonderful. This is a wonderful, delightful, collection presented beautifully. However do not eat at Oliver Peyton's restaurant. The food is most unpleasant. Tastes reheated but arrives at the table cold.

A Favourite. The quality of the Wallace Collection and it's relative intimacy for a museum is a great combination. there are some wonderful items here. I have been several times for a variety of purposes - to visit the museum, for lunch in the restaurant, for corporate drinks parties etc. It is lovely.

A fascinating collection.. We decided to walk to the Wallace Collection from Paddington mainline station and it was just the most amazing discovery. Tucked away in a quiet corner of London near both Hyde Park and Oxford Street, the house is simply bursting with beautiful paintings, a staggering collection of armoury, amazing wallhangings and more. After our fill of these wonderful artifacts, we ended our visit with a cream tea in the fabulous courtyard tearoom. A visit is definitely recommended
Well kept secret. Hidden away behind Selfridges , we had not heard of this collection before but really enjoyed our visit. Very interesting collection. Cafe was lovely if a little pricey.

Great gallery. I used to work quite close to the Wallace Collection and visited it during my lunch hour ... always wishing my lunch hour was longer! I would echo other reviews by saying this is definitely London's best kept secret. It costs nothing to enter although donations are welcomed. They have some amazing artwork, a very impressive collection of armour and weapons dating back to the 14th century, plus numerous other items. Well worth a very short diversion from Oxford Street.

My Absolute Favorite Museum Experience in London - A Well-Kept Secret Worth Seeking Out. We visited London in March and found this well kept secret which is a MAJOR FIND! It is a museum within Hertford House in Manchester Square. It was bequeathed to the nation many years ago and its well worth seeing and spending a few hours within its walls. My FAVORITE museum in all of London. Go don't hesitate you will love it. Best of all its Free!

Surprisingly enjoyable experience. Visited the Wallace Collection with a group of work colleagues and had an organised tour. The guides were exceptionally knowledgeable and enthusiastic, and I must admit I enjoyed the experience far more than I thought I would.The small cafe/restaurant is lovely and well worth a visit regardless of whether you intend on going around the exhibition.

Lovely place. This is just a super little museum to visit. It's free and just the right size to hold interest. It's very pretty. The courtyard restaurant is perfect or a. Snack or lunch and a glass of fizz.
Best exihibit in London. Beautiful collection of art, unique furniture and my favorite- the ancient armours.A must see for everyone!

Worth a detour!. We had not been back to the Wallace Collection since the extensive renovation, and it was a pleasure to return. The extensive armor collection is now relegated to lower floors, making more room for the amazing collection of paintings, including wonderful Rembrandt portraits and my favorite, the "Persian Sybil" by Domenchino.

A must see collection of classic art. A must see in London for any lover of classic art. I much prefer something more contemporary but you have to appreciate how gorgeous these pieces are.Absolutely stunning collection to enjoy. Definately worth a wander around.

Feast for the eyes. Gorgeous collection and stunning interior that I can't get enough of! I was there for about an hour or more but it wasn't enough. Perfect for interior excoriation inspiration. I'm totally in love and going there again this week again!

sumptuous existence. I love this place, it is so wonderful to just wander round the stunning rooms and see the exhibitions. The staff are quiet and polite, not in your face, and the whole space is a slice of history which is amazing and free!

A personal house. Real people live there and collected lots and lots and lots of things of all kinds- porcelans, furniture, all kinds of small ( and big) weapons. You will need time and patiente to see it well. If you like that sort of musuem go , its worthwile .

Unknown Gem. London's best kept secret.
Superb art, amazing setting, and all for free... Donations welcomed.
Worth a visit if you are near Marylebone.
D.

Wallace Collection Late Night events. Well worth the visit this gem of a museum in the middle of Central London.
A rare collection of Dutch painters;' artwork hung in rooms fabulously refurbished much like the orginal decoration and a warm and welcoming cafe'.

Wow!. What a place! Something for everyone, for sure - & of course not everyone will like everything - I bypassed the suits of armour, for example, as my interest lay with the smaller pieces on show - enamel boxes, glassware, porcelain & china etc. It was a family home & the collection was amassed over the years by the family, which I find interesting in & of itself. The rooms have been kept in original condition as far as possible, & some of the wall coverings are just beautiful. It's worth taking your time as you walk through the different rooms & galleries as there are unusual & interesting pieces everywhere. Didn't use the restaurant, but the room is light & airy & looked lovely.

A hidden gem!. As a frequent visitor to London I couldn't believe I had taken so long to find The Wallace Collection. It's just off Oxford St , great to get away from the hustle & bustle. Another fabulous free gallery to explore before having a choice of either a coffee shop or a brasserie (Peyton&Byrne) to eat in. We choose the Basserie, enironment ,service & food all very good. You are sit in an atrium which is just lovely to have all the natural light.I would suggest you order some side dishes as the size of main courses are rather small but delicious. We had luggage with us so we were delighted to see they're was a cloak room available , you are asked to make a donation which I do think is reasonable. Overall a great experience for all ages.
Art and weaponry magical place to visit. Somewhere for everyone to find fascinating pictures and objects, a wealth of historical wonders. I shall be back in the new year to see more
Superb collection of gorgeous treasures. Another great free London Museum, lovely place to spend an hour then have a coffee and cake in the atrium
Free old art and armour. This gallery is free and in an impressive mansion not far from Oxford Street. It has Rembrandt's and many masters and an armour collection. A good way to spend an hour or so

Magnificent. What a beautiful building , housing an amazing collection of clocks, Serves porcelain , furniture and other treasures too numerous to mention. Beautifully displayed with outstanding tours offered - I did the clock tour , which was most informative and given by a well versed guide. The decor of the rooms in absolutely brilliant , and the designer, John O.Connor is to be congratulated on his styling .

One of the most inspirational places in London. I can't gush about this place enough. Whether you are a creative soul looking for inspiration or just catching up with friends in a gorgeous environment then you HAVE to go to the Wallace Collection.Everything about it is just DELICIOUS!It's free to get in so you get to experience the incredibly decadent surroundings for absolutely nothing at all.
So much to see. I went to view the armoury but was also impressed by all the old weapons. Stayed to view the paintings which offers a really great collection
I'm a big fan. It's a free gallery in the heart of London - it has an amazing collection to see as well as the gallery rooms are also beautiful on their own.

Art-filled Stately home in Marylebone. Beautiful stately home filled with treasures. Many famous works by Rembrandt, Rubens, Velasquez. And quite a few rooms full of ancient armor and weapons. The center court is now a lovely restauran

Amazing private collection in its original setting. I didn't think I'd like this place very much - I'm not really into objets d'arte but went along with friends. Walking into the first room changed my mind. It was a room with all manner of daggers, swords, armor and other weaponary dating back to the 14th century and from far and distant places. I was impressed. This is a fine collection of a very eclectic and diverse nature - from illuminated manuscripts to tiny finely detailed ivory carving, Italian painted crockery, miniatures, furniture, clocks and paintings. The paintings are impressive and ofbviously collected for their subject matter (Dutch and Flemish still lives and small vignettes of ordinary people's daily lives as well as scenes by Murillo and portraits (including ones by Rembrandt, Frank Hals, Fragonard, Reynolds and Valasquez). There is much to see here and requires multiple visits. There's also a lovely cafe in the enclosed courtyard for a sustaining coffee and pastry or wine and lunch. Well worth the visit.

Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection should be on every tourist's itinerary. It's a gorgeous museum housed in an former personal home, and while it's very manageable, it also boasts an extensive and interesting collection. I'm only sorry we didn't get to stay and eat at the charming cafe!

An oasis off the beaten tourist track. I love the Wallace collection, and often slot it in to any oxford/regent street shopping trip, or as a lovely meeting point. It is central yet uncrowded; small yet packed with treasures; open to the public yet feels intimate. It has some beautiful pieces, such as the strawberry girl, and the fall into Dante's inferno, and my children were engaged with the armour for the maximum 30 mins museum time. There is a lovely shop, and the cafe is great too, so a resounding yes, coupled with a "shhhh don't spoil it!"

This is an absolute gem inbetween Oxford Street and Marylebone. This is an absolute treasure trove of priceless paintings; beautiful china and everything collectable and there is no entrance fee.Each room is a visual delight having been beautiful restored fairly recently. Somewhere to visit over and over again. I shall be back! There is a lovely restaurant in the Atrium area - fine dining; not a cafe.

a gem. the london equivalent of the burrell collection in glasgow this gallery has a varied and interesting collection of artefacts. Of the paintings two rembrandts and of course the laughing cavalier stand out. Decent cafe for when one flags

Fabulous collection of artwork and furniture. Lovely morning enjoyed looking around this collection of artwork by the likes of Sir Joshua Reynolds, Rubens etc lots of amazing clocks the cabinets and other pieces of furniture amazing. The people who work/help here were all without exception deleightful and knowledgeable about the collection. Great gift shop lovely clean toilets . The café is in the center easily accessed.

Lots of stuff!!. This place was jam packed with so many decorative objects and pieces of art. We had just missed the tour so we opted for the audio guide which helped a little. The numbering system on the wall to punch in and listen to a guide was not so clear. The numbers were not clearly displayed and sometimes you had to hunt for them. Some rooms had no objects/art for the audio guide at least none that I could find. It was a lot to look at. I enjoyed it but couldn't stop thinking of the phrase, "he who dies with the most possessions, wins!" Like I said, so much stuff!!

Overwhelmed. Hertford House is not huge but the various rooms - State Room, Drawing Room, were nice. We admired the curtains and the fireplaces, as well as the intense colours that separates each room. It was interesting to note the 15th - 18th century silverware, ceramics, paintings, all came from a private collection. Equally interesting is that Conway had bequeathed the rich collections to his illegitimate son, which would have been scandalous in the old GB days. And of course the generosity of Wallace's widow to leave it all to the people of GB. After a circuit tour of the various museums and galleries, one could began to appreciate the distinct brand or reputation equity of each collection. Hertford House can be included in a circuit tour along with Hyde Park, Sherlock Homes Museum, Mdm Tussauds and further down to Green Park and Buckingham Palace. A must visit.

Amazing Collection. so much good art, silverware and ceramics in one gallery. This is a must see. It's fascinating seeing some of the old masters (some of which will be familiar). Many of the artists names are familiar to just about everybody. Take your time not just to look at the art but the superb building itself. Perhaps the amazing thing is that it is all free. This place is hidden gem.
Very nice. You get to walk around a house with a lot on unteresting stuff in it. If I told you anymore it would spoil it for you.

must see in london. fabulous collection in beautiful surroundings, very central - i'd say the only thing is the restaurant has become v pricey - but who care - there are so many other places to eat nearby - the pictures are world-class and lower ground has special exhibitions also for children - rooms decorated as they were years ago - gorgeous shop too ...

best little museum in london. This is my favourite in all of London. Minutes from Selfridges a lovely house packed full of beautiful pieces of art /furniture and ceramics. Inside a really lovely cafe/restaurant. No obligatory fee but donations welcomed. No wonder the cavalier is laughing

Things to do in London. although not strictly a museum, the Wallace Collection houses a most fabulous and fascinating selection of items. I did however find it a tad overwhelming with all the 'stuff' on display. The house itself is gorgeous and it is quite simply a must visit. and it's FREE :)

A gem of a Museum. Wonderful small collection and gem of a museum not to be missed. The size of this collection means that you can spend a little more time viewing it properly and not go away thinking that a return visit is necessary to gain the best of your visit. Beautiful furniture and collection of paintings.
Interesting Private Gallery. Good selection of paintings and other works of art in pleasant surroundings. Nice conservatory coffee bar although service a bit slow.Easily reachable from Oxford Street.

An Outstanding Collection. We arrived about 90 minutes before closing and were mildly chastised by the young French woman for not giving ourselves sufficient time to see the whole collection. It felt like I was in Paris. We chose to inspect one floor and return at some time in the future for the rest. The collection itself is an absolute gem with stunning pieces of art and furniture on display. The fact that the museum is free to enter makes this all the more one of London's hidden gems. Each room was well attended by staff who were clearly keen observers of patrons, safeguarding the works well, which is great to see. It was refreshing to see staff wearing Wallace Collection tops/uniforms. I have visited London on many occasions and am now delighted that I've discovered the Wallace Collection.

You have to love old art.... I am not a huge antique fan, but this place was impressive. I enjoyed trying to picture what it was like living in the 1700 and 1800's in such a house. You could get. glimpse of that in a few pictures but art has been collected in the home for centuries. Enjoyed the basement display of the previous owners plus the hall with armor. This is a free museum but they do encourage a donation, which is more than reasonable.
Beautiful Collection!. A great collection to see. Not as grand as other museums in London. I enjoyed my visit and was able to view the collection in about an hour.

A pleasant surprise ! . Never knew about this place until i saw an internet ad and what a place !! Super central, behind Selfridges, but a world apart ! Fine collections with wonderful architecture and a posh cafe' too.
Cannot believe it is free as well: a must see for all London residents n visitors :)
A Grand Day Out. There's a great selection of paintings, furniture, silverware, etc. and the cafe is lovely too; I recommend the afternoon tea and Champagne.

London's best kept secret. Love it! Great tea room atrium. Free! Eclectic collection , elegantly displayed, not compulsive sloppiness like the Sloan house on Lincoln Inn. Loved a couple paintings, so framed the prints for my home.
Fascinating.. Not as well known as some of the many tourist attractions in London, and all the better for it. Don't leave London without seeing it.

Excellent free exhibition with good refreshment in restaurant and marvellous ambience.. Brilliant and a very interesting exhibition. Also they stage interesting demonstrations in costumes for schoolchildren and hold their attention. Very good place to visit and also a return visit to see all that is on offer.

A Hidden Gem. This little known art gallery is bursting with some of the finest art in London - works by British and European masters especially the Dutch golden age. Gorgeous interiors, well informed staff, very old fashioned, in character with the works. Outside is a drinking fountain, one of several donated by the gallery founder, to the people of Paris to improve their health. Utterly amazing. Atrium restaurant, and good gift shop

Hidden museum gem not far from (horrible) Oxford Street. The Laughing Cavalier, room after room of oil paintings, suits of armour and priceless antiques. And all free entry. The Wallace Collection is manageable, inspiring and great for just a quick dip-in.A cafe in the courtyard is also reasonable, and by far and away one of the nicest rest stops in this part of town.

GREAT MUSEUM. I used to work opposite and was a regular visitor. Not so much nowadays but it's still a great place to visit. The Collection is close to all transport connections but Manchester Square itself is usually a quiet oasis.

Your "must see" collection. Opened again a few years ago after thoroughly renovations and upgrades this fantastic collection and building is simply "a must".Never have I experienced such a huge collection of famous Dutch painters !!!Just overwhelming!!You can easily need a whole day, - and if you are interested in arms and armory and thousands of weapons etc; well - add one more day

A Hidden Gem for History Lovers. This was a private home at one time. Lady Wallace willed it to the City of London. This private collection is a jewel for anyone who enjoys seeing beautiful items of all types. There is china, paintings, arms and armory, furniture...you name it; it is here. All are carefully documented and labeled. I have to go back; this place is three floors and I only finished two rooms! (Can you tell I read ALL the labels?)It is easy to reach and is in a nice residential area with a park across the street. There is a small restaurant in the middle of this squared home; it has tea, cheese and crackers, etc. It is a nice spot to take a break from reading the labels! I was disappointed that the audio tour devices were not working properly; somehow every item was deemed 'on the children's menu' and would not play for me. (They have a tour especially designed for school tours.) They did refund the price of the audio tour; I hope the adult items information is working right when I go back!
Gorgeous!!. This free venue is wonderful. You can wander around at your own pace, or join one of their guided tours. And the restaurant is a delight.
a wonderful collection. The collection has been re-hung and is quite stunning, worth travelling many miles to view. There is also an excellent restaurant.

A cultural retreat a few minutes from Oxford Street. Delicious afternoon tea in a relaxing cultural surrounding a few minutes from buzzing Oxford Street.Service quite slow although we had booked a table for a certain time so would have expected the afternoon tea to be lined up sooner. Worth it just to sit in the lovely atrium and then visit the painting afterwards before tackling the shops in Oxford street once more.
Nice little place for meeting up. Nice little place for having afternoon tea and snacks. The atrium is the place to have a meeting and then afterwards take a stroll down to the oxford street.

A disappointment for some. I recently visited the Wallace Collection for the first time in the hopes that I might see an artefact that had been shown on a TV history programme. I found the lack of signs/labels next to many of the artefacts difficult to manage especially as the only way of finding out about them was through referring to one of two books on lecterns in each room. The content of each book varied and was not at a convenient height for wheelchair users or the vertically challenged! My other disappointment was when in a very beautiful room an alarm went off and staff came running only to find an embarrassed partially sighted visitor who explained that the artefact she was looking at high up above her head on a mantelpiece had a label that she could not read because of its height, she had taken it down and so had inadvertently tripped the alarm. Staff were very abrupt with her and took the label away from her to replace on the mantelpiece rather than let her finish reading it. She was clearly embarrassed and turned to explain her sight difficulties to me. The splendid new café had staff who had problems finding the hot chocolate drink they had on the menu but once found I was kindly offered a complimentary one. A plus was the staff in the room where I had specifically headed for who went to great lengths to find the artefact I was looking for.Such a beautiful building and its wonderful contents needs to have all staff equal to it and facilities that anyone can use.

Peace from the madding crowd. The Wallace Collection stands behind and within walking distance of Selfridges on Oxford St, London. The Picture Room stands out on the first floor : The laughing Cavalier and Fragonard's The Swing stand out in particular. Downstairs you can wander around the rooms viewing historic antique furniture, pictures galore and the ever auditory presence of ticking clocks. It is pure peace from the hustle and bustle of Oxford St and as with many of London galleries and museums it's free! In recent years the central courtyard has been covered with glass and whilst surrounded by palms and peace, waiters and waitresses will serve you. This museum/ art gallery is often overlooked. It shouldn't be.
A must for art, architect lovers. Excellent items on display, beautiful rooms with endless treasures. Restoration excellent. Lots to take in.

Wonderful and unexpected atrium restaurant in a beautiful Art Gallery. The Wallace Collection not only boasts an eclectic and delightful art collection, beautifully displayed in the recently renovated ( by the looks of it at least!) rooms, but also a Cafe and Restaurant set in the light and elegant atrium area. The restaurant serves excellent food ( about £30 for two/ three courses, or Afternoon Tea English style).The cafe is a more price friendly, but equally appetising, choice. Even on a grey London day the atrium feels light and inviting. A favourite refuge of mine in London. Both for the art and the cafe.

Wonderful small museum. While it has been a while since I was last there, the Wallace Museum is a wonderful small museum and just a few blocks away from the craziness of shopping on Oxford Street - it has a fine collection of art - paintings, furniture, porcelain and armour. Worth a visit.

A surprise just behind Oxford Street craziness. Good art collection in a rococo's atmosphere. Paintings, historical utensils and armours shows you more about the english society. try to have a break after visiting it at the cafe.

Remarkable collection, not to be missed. The combination of the quality and range of the holdings and the impressiveness of Hertford House itself makes a visit to the Wallace Collection particularly rewarding. Because admission is free, it is possible to return at leisure a number of times until one has really got to know the collection well. It's looking particularly spectacular at the moment, some of the rooms having recently undergone restoration, particularly the largest gallery (home to Hals's "The Laughing Cavalier" and Poussin's "A Dance to the Music of Time," which provided Anthony Powell with the title for his novel sequence). The whole experience provides fascinating insight into the power and wealth of the private collector in the 18th and 19th centuries: the good fortune of the collection's having survived in tact as a gift to the nation -- with little added, except relevant ancillary archival material, and nothing sold off -- gives it a particular historical unity and significance. A small exhibit in the basement provides a very interesting survey of the family responsible for its creation. There is a handsome, once open now glass-roofed, inner courtyard where (quite expensive) meals and snacks are served, sometimes rather slowly, and a more than averagely creative gift shop. Given a few of the earlier comments here, the staff seem to have undergone attitudinal refurbishment along with the house: they have been uniformly pleasant and helpful in my recent experience of them. In short, this is one of the most satisfying gallery experiences to be had in London or anywhere else.

HIDDEN GEM...A DIAMOND IN LONDON. So many people pass this by and miss a wonderful experience. The Collection is simply magnificent and its history is a story all of its own. Centrally located, easy to get too, this is an amazingly (and wholly wrongly) overlooked diamond within the London museum scene. Visit. you won't regret it.

Sensational museum and art gallery. This personal collection of furniture, paintings and artefacts, displayed in a house behind Selfridges, is well worth a visit. Although a museum, the house still resembles a home. Each, colourful, silk lined room is beautiful, and appears to have been personally decorated and laid out. You can walk all round, easily viewing the spectacular furniture and priceless paintings - there's Fragonard's Swing, the Laughing Cavalier and other famous works of art on display. In the basement is a huge display of armour, in amazing condition. We were also glad we visited the restaurant, in the covered, outside courtyard, as the food was delicious and the service good.

Free - so well worth a visit!. As with many collections created by wealthy individuals, (the 4th Marquess of Hertford in this instance), this is a bit hit-and-miss. The highlight is undoubtedly the deservedly well-known 'Laughing Cavalier' by Frans Hals - whose rogueish glint is so well captured by the artist. There are also a couple of good Rembrandts and Van Dycks, among the other worthwhile works.Because there are so many paintings, in many rooms they are hung two or three high on the walls; fortunately, many of these don't deserve very careful inspection - undistinguished landscapes, mythical scenes or hunting still lives - dead hares and pheasants, etc. Otherwise, I was most impressed with a number of beautiful polished marble tops - natural, except for a brilliant piece of work in the Venice/Canaletto room where a sort of stone marquetry technique has been used to create three pastoral pictures from different coloured stones - the first time I've seen anything like it. Superb!
Wallace Collection - Free Art Gallery. The Wallace Collection has a most amazing collection - and it's all free. Also, there is a very nice restaurant with great food, or just coffee.
Unique Collection. Tried the Sunday morning tour with a curator who had bags of anecdotes and made the place come alive. Great fun and educational.

A little gem in London's trendy Bond Street area.. A fascinating collection of artefacts by the well travelled Wallace family. Probably one of the best places in London to have afternoon tea. Easily rivals the Ritz for a special treat. Remember to book well in advance.

Great Art. If your bored on a weekend and want to do something fun, take a stroll round here. cool picture and you can relax. I wouldn't recommend the restaurant as the coffee was cold. but the Gallery is the place

Dont bother with the cafe. A fantastic collection in a beautiful house. It was a joy to see The Laughing Cavalier but don't bother with the café it is overpriced, the menu is poor and the service slow.

Perfect for a trip in London. I must be the only person who dislikes shopping in London so after finding myself in the pouring rain on Oxford street, I decided to visit The Wallace Collection, what a find the collection of old masters is amazing but equally worth looking at is the décor which is absolutely beautiful, the staff are friendly, the café is nice. But I could not get over the fact it was all free (not the café you pay for that) Leave the shops behind and go and get some culture you will not be disappointed.

Richly rewarding. The Wallace Collection is housed in a mansion so is not as overwhelming as larger museums. We had a wonderful tour which really brought out the highlights and added fascinating facts for our edification. The cafe is attractive but didn't have much variety.

A great London gallery. This is an interesting gallery in Manchester Square, just north of Oxford Street. It houses the collection accumulated by one family in a building which was once one of their homes. The collection was given to the nation many years ago and is certainly varied. There are paintings, miniatures, furniture and pottery from the 15th to the 19th centuries. While I enjoyed the ground floor I preferred the upper floor, on which can be found The Laughing Cavalier and many works by Watteau, Fragonard and Rembrandt. Returning to the ground floor I found the displays of armour rather depressing, if impressive. Although small, the layout of the building is a little confusing, and I would recommend you buy the guide book, which includes a plan (with rather small print), and perhaps leave the change as a donation. If you need some refreshment there is a well-regarded restaurant, but I did not try it on this occasion. Well worth a visit of an hour to two hours. One of the great things about it is that it is much quieter than many London galleries, and you can take your time to enjoy whatever pleases you.

Beautiful building. Amazing location. didn't really do the whole tour, my mother had lunch there, I was dropping here off She loved it. I was really impressed with building, the restaurant location is great . Can't comment on the quality of the food. I would definitely go back

Fascinating - You've heard of it and it's worth visiting. This is more than an art gallery, it's a relic of how the upper crust lived in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The collection was assembled by the Marquesses of Herford over a period of more than a hundred years, particularly by the fourth Marquess, who was one of the great collectors of the nineteenth century. It has hundreds of items of furniture, paintings, sculptures and ceramics and a really amazing collection of arms and armour from all over the world. The breadth of the collection means that anyone with even the slightest interest in the history of art or arms or social history will find themselves wanting to spend more time than they have available. It contains the originals of many works of art that you will have seen before in reproduction, for example Frans Hals' 'Laughing Cavalier'.

Great smaller museum and cafe-must see.. Fit this one into your agenda! Really terrfic, smaller museum - less crowded with a wonderful collection. Cafe is very good, too. Doesn't take all day to tour - we had about 2 hours and very much enjoyed our time at The Wallace.

Great small museum. This museum is a lovely and refreshingly quiet place to see interesting art including some beautiful Sevres, and some of the best marble tops in town. One in particular, on a console below a Canaletto which takes people's attention, is so delicately done,marquettery style, it's worth the visit for it alone. Delightful! The paintings are of variable quality, but the whole place is a pleasure to walk through. Very welcoming staff too. Well worth a visit or two.
Little visited and don't know why. If you love history and art and a great morning or afternoon tea this is for you. A true gem with no huge crowds.

Excellent - and it's free!. This is a well presented mixture of art, armoury and other artifacts. As it was all collected before 1900 there is nothing particularly modern. This could of course be a distinct advantage, depending on your personal taste. The main collection is spread over two floors, and it is well worth spending a couple of hours there. There is a shop and cafe, and also the opportunity to make a donation for your visit.

a gem in London. very interesting and nice collections, although the addition of so many furnitures and pieces of art does not really look like a true house, according to today's tastes. The armory room is superb as most of the pieces in the collection. Worth a visit

Loved the Wallace Collection. I recommend the Wallace Collection , The Mansion has been refurbished and the paintings re-hung, and the rich, glowing colors of the silk damask really set off this beautiful collection of paintings, furniture and artifacts. The place has no crowds - if you like viewing art in peaceful surroundings, this is the place for you! nearby you have St Christopher's Passage & Oxford Street.
BEAUTIFUL GALLERY. Amazing collection of art, furniture, guns and great architecture. Great cafe at the back. The Wallace is a hidden gem at the back of Selfridges.

What a gem of a place. Visited with a friend of mine yesterday and was a little unsure as to how long we would spend inside, seeing that we have done some of the major London Museums previously.Plenty to see with the added bonus of a daily 30 min talk on their 'pick of the month also during the week at 2.30pm there is a free tour of part of the collection with a guide. We had a delightful French lady as out guide, perfect English and a really good sense of humour. This tour lasted for 90 minutes and the information and explanations given to us about the furniture and paintings was exceptional. 10/10 for this as the guide was very knowledgable and did not refer to any script.Give it a go it is very well worth it. They do have a very nice Restaurant/Cafe as well.
nice saturday afternoon. if you are in the aera and tired of walking or shopping around, come in and check out the collection, enjoy some time off the busy streats, sit down, relax and enjoy

Wonderful art in beautiful surroundings. I cannot recommend this place enough! The mansion has been refurbished and the paintings re-hung, and the rich, glowing colours of the silk damask really set off this beautiful collection of paintings, furniture and artefacts. The place is surprisingly uncrowded - if you like viewing art in peaceful surroundings, this is the place for you! As a bonus, Marylebone High Street is within a stone's throw, as is St Christopher's Passage & Oxford Street.

The Wallace Collection. This is a great place to visit in central London. It houses various collections of furniture, porcelain, armoury, paintings etc.It is free but appreciates donations.It is housed in a very impressive private house, so is more manageable that some of the larger museums.

First class museum for free. This museum is located in a spectacular single family mansion, close to Oxford st. You will have the opportunity to enjoy paintings ( Titians, Rembrandts, Rubens, several Canalettos ) , furniture, and a wide range of artistic objects. I particularly liked the furniture pieces that belonged to French kings and queens, the Sevres porcelaine collection and the arms and armours collection. The house itself is a work of art and has a very good cafe in its inner patio. Great way to spend half a day in London, or even an hour or two if you dont have a lot of time.

culture and perfect lunch. Amazing Collection. Right in the centre of London just a step away from busy shopping in London. I've been very interested in this type of art, and if you have visited Versaille outside of Paris and you liked it this is a must see. Paintings, weapons, porcelain, furnitures, scuptures. A lot of Culture and history. I had a light lunch at the place and I can highly recomend to go here for lunch. I will come back for sure in the future.

incredible collection and beautiful cafe. One of central london's most interesting collections of art, objects, armours, and all sorts of interesting artefacts from time past and far continents which belonged to a british aristocrat and was donated as such, to be displayed in his stunning mansion. the cafe, within the courtyard is a beautiful place to have coffee, tea, or a meal, lots of tables, beautifully laid out and a covered transparent roof that gives in plenty of natural light. highly recommend

Nice break from Oxford street. This is a private house turned into museum. The collection holds all kind of objects: paintings, sculptures, coins, porcelain, furniture and armory. There is no admission as the Wallace family donated the house and the collection to people to enjoy. It is just few minutes' walk from Selfridge's. the courtyard was converted into a restaurant very nice place to have lunch even in winter since it's covered with glass cover.

Quick Tour. I can't believe a single wealthy family owned this entire collection! Nothing has been added or changed at the original owner's request and the collection is available for free entry. What a deal! Hertford House, home of the collection, is an absolutely massive property. At the front door an employee told me I had to check my backpack (free). A tour would be starting in half an hour if we were interested but that would likely take a very long time and we only had an hour. I knew this place was huge and that wouldn't be near enough time to see everything but I was determined to try. We started out by going right from the lobby and heading into the first room of sculptures, carvings, coins, and paintings. I am sure each room had a theme or time period represented but we were not paying enough attention in our rush to get through. There were more historical items on the first floor and up a flight of stairs I found several large art galleries. The rooms themselves were also extremely grand. The largest gallery was big enough for double-stacked paintings or ones as tall as fifteen feet. The art was fantastic and so was the furniture in the house. With the exception of the occasional chair or bench for visitors there was rare furniture in each room with signs saying “please do not sit on the art”. In addition to chairs there were couches, grandfather clocks, tables, vases, and a couple fantastic 17th Century armoires. On the second floor there was an interesting sun porch that didn’t really fit the rest of the house. It was a different color pallet than the bold colors of the rest of the house and there were palmy plants everywhere. It was like a cabana. Maybe Lady Wallace went on a trip to Cuba at some point and tried to bring it back with her.Back on the first floor the last few rooms were the armor and weaponry collection (because why not, they were rich). There were thousands of weapons including axes, spears, swords, crossbows, pistols, rifles, shotguns, and a cannon. A lot of the weapons were both pretty and deadly. Many of the pistols and rifles, for example, had ivory handles with painted designs. The spears were probably more useful for ceremonial or gift-giving purposes than killing simply because of their carved and/or sculpted handles. The armor displays were also expansive and ranging from plain plate armor to super-intricate ceremonial armor. A couple shields were basically beautiful paintings that just happened to be on shields. A courtyard at the center of the building has a large cafe (we didn't have time). It is covered with a glass roof now but it would have been a nice outdoor escape in the center of the building when the Wallace’s lived there. The bathroom was under the cafe in the courtyard. Each stall was unisex and enclosed with a full door and sink. I really like the European system of public restrooms. They’re not all as nice, of course, but it’s great to have privacy. Even the hallway outside the bathrooms had art displayed. At the bottom of the stairs near the bathrooms there were more art galleries (yes more, I couldn’t believe it either) and a studio for making new art (presumably for artists flocking to the Wallace Collection for inspiration). There were a lot of books for sale in the gift shop but not much else in the way of souvenirs.Visit the Wallace Collection and try to set aside more time for it than we had available!
Beautiful building. Beautiful building and setting in a great location. Lovely collection in light airy space with a great cafe/restaurant

Exceeded expectations. Recommended by a friend, we expected a few paintings and exhibits which we could view in an hour. Delighted to find an extensive collection of paintings housed in a wonderful building and very professionally displayed and explained. Spent the whole afternoon here, well worth a visit.
Top museum. This is an excellent museum which is likely to be ruined by its own success. Each exhibition seems to be more crowded than the last.
Wallace Collection. Wonderful exhibition in fabulous surroundings.A hidden gem in London which should be seen. Easily accessed it really is a wonderful place.,

Good for half an hour. This free museum is attractive and easy to navigate. If you like this sort of art, you may love this place. Otherwise, a pleasant half hour stroll through a nice house with a cafe in the center.

Just gorgeous collection plus good disabled access.. An absolutely beautiful collection of fine art. Amazing arms and armour collection and of course the home of the Laughing cavalier. It is all set in an elegant house and it is free!. The café is a bit pricey. Food is good but service could be better. There is a small lift for wheelchair users and a very nice disabled toilet.
Amazing collection with lovely food. Like Rome's Borghesie Gallery, BUT no limit how long you can stay...so better!The luncheon place is absolutely scrumptious, like the art! A not to be missed!

Refreshed and re- hung. i was anxious to see if the renovation of the Large Gallery has been successful,always an event ,some better than others.This was handled superbly ,the stripping away of the dated seventies lighting to allow natural light in has been a revalation ,the softness of tone enhancing the viewing experience .There must be some form of filter control as the Collection is at pains to state that the natural light will not have a detrimental effect on the artwork,so we'll done them.The brightness of the new damask wallpaper ( probably a kings ransom in itself ) will subtely blend in given time .There is evidence that the gallery closure was also a time for an overall house clean and prettying up ,other major rooms benefitting accordingly .I approved as it all felt refreshed without being shop window bright.On a wet Wednesday afternoon the gallery was half full at most and pleasing for that.With a superb armour collection and a couple of rooms of collectors cabinets there is much to see and admire here ,as well as a top notch restaurant in the central court / atrium.5 mins walk from Selfridges ensure this is easily accessible by public transport

Important 18th century collection. Dizzing array of art and decorative porcelains, clocks, furniture from the 17th-19th centuries. We especially enjoyed the terrific collection of Dutch genre paintings. Quite a good cafe in the covered central courtyard, reasonably priced and good quality.

One of my favourite museums anywhere. This museum is for some reason not very well known. Whilst this is awful for the Wallace Collection, it is wonderful for anyone who visits as it is never crowded and a little piece of heaven in the centre of London. If you have a teenage child who is desperate to haunt Oxford Street, you can escape and look at the pictures and porcelain. Heaven.

A very eclectic collection - interesting and free and not too crowded.. It is a while since I have been here and came with 2 friends who live outside London. We spent a good two hours here as there is so much to see. The nice thing is that the collction is very eclectic within a museum that is a manageable size. The highlights are the arms and armour, sevres porcelain, Canaletto paintings and numerous other paintings by the great masters of the 17th and 18th centuries. The Sainsbury Gallery - first floor rear has just been re-opened after a substantial refurbishment so the space has changed considerably to show the paintings off better. Don't miss the small exhibitions in the basement. Probably eat elsewhere as the restaurant looks as though it is overpriced.Wheelchairs and pushchairs appear to be allowed and there is a lift to all floors.

Superb Collection of Decorative Artifacts from the Renaissance. The Wallace Collection is a fantastic collection of mostly European decorative arts from around the Renaissance and slightly later, and some eastern weapons in the armory, with superb and comprehensive collections of several categories. Well presented and arranged. A few paintings by masters as well. The armor collection is a little disappointing for medieval enthusiasts but if you're into the decorative, it's the place to be. Clean and accessible. Highly recommended, great gift shop and a wonderful little café with good prices (high tea starts at 2:30, plan accordingly!). Admission is free but please donate!

Simply stunning. We went on a quiet Saturday, and spent the day there. The rooms are stunning, each with beautiful hand made silk wall hangings and curtains made in Lille. I loved the lilac room. Each room has a colour taken from one of the art works that it contains. There is porcelain, ceramics, armour of breathtaking complexity and intricate detail, paintings and so much more. The collection of gold and bejewelled snuff boxes was delightful, and hand magnifiers are provided to see the tiny art works and craftsmanship up close. There is an audio guide, and the room attendants were very knowledgeable and helpful.The Laughing Cavalier is here, although I felt he was more the smug smirker!The restaurant provides very good quality teas and coffee, with delicious cakes in huge portions.The restaurant does two and three course lunches, for which you are advised to book and they were very popular.Entry is free, a charge is made for the audio guide.

Not to be missed . This is a unique venue for a wide range of stunning works of art. Often overlooked, it offers a chance to reflect on some exquisite pieces away from the crowds. An added bonus is the resturaunt, which has an al fresco feel. Excellent food and service.

Good place on a rainy day. Wonderful museum if you are interested in medieval armor and weapons and French furniture and art. It wasn't crowded and had a lovely cafe. We spent the whole day and loved it.

This is one of my Favorites in London. I love The Wallace Collection. Wallace house is a great way to spend an hour or half a day, depending on how much time you have. The Wallace House has the most amazing collection of Art, Porcelain & Armour among many other items that I've seen in any museum. The guided tours they hold are great or you can just wander around the mansion by yourself. I have been back to The Wallace so many times now & each time I find something new. Its a little hidden gem in Manchester Square which is roughly 2 blocks behind Selfridges, but well worth the effort. The nearest tube stop is Bond St & about 10 minute walk from there. If your in London & want something a bit different to do that is free... then The Wallace is for you!!!
Excellent, less known museum in a beautiful villa. Excellent, less known museum in a beautiful villa. Visit it, it's a must! Oh, and all those Canalettos... You won't regret it!

Excellent on all counts. Another free museum, but please, donate!!! Mostly from East Asia, India. Some extremely elaborately carved ebony pieces. Armory, paintings, war gear, interior, Larger and more varied than I'd expected. A must-see!

A haven of peace and exquisite beauty in the hub of the city. The Wallace Collection is housed in a Georgian building not far from Oxford Street. When one enters its portals, the atmosphere one imbibes is that of peace and beauty. The art collection is astounding beautiful, with paintings from most centuries, favouring the 17th and 18th, and the bronzes are to stare at with wonder.I often visit, especially when I need a break from the pressure of my occupation, and it always leaves me feeling refreshed and happy.
Superb!. Worth the time to find and visit this gem. Huge collection in a small space with excellent representation of different periods. Wish there had been an audio guide.

Really, not to be missed. It's amazing the amount of famous artists that are represented here. It's an easy size museum, in a beautiful home setting. It was free to enter. Not terribly crowded, so you can walk right up to the Rembrants, Wattaus, Cannelettos etc., where in other museums you would have to fight big crowds to be near them. Amazing collection of porcelains, small boxes of different types, and many other "collectibles". Had lunch in the restaurant, where they have one side as a café, the other a more expensive restaurant. It was very good, and nice setting. Really wonderful place, not far from Bond Street underground station.

A Hidden Gem. This is a fantastic museum in Manchester Square, walking distance from Marble Arch / Oxford Street. They have everything from armour to Old Masters such as Rembrandt and Titian. Most people would recognise The Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals. A very eclectic collection. Something for everyone.There is also a restaurant for a sit down to eat or just have a drink.
A fabulous museum. At the back of Bond Street this is a hidden gem and it's free entry. Spent several hours there and still need to go back and finish looking

A "must see" in London. A superb collection of art and French furniture in a compact building which is not to be missed. The entrance is free and there is also a very good restaurant with reasonable prices and excellent service.

Wow!. This enormous mansion is situated on a square just off Marylebone High Street North of Oxford Street. It is free and the private collection of painting, porcelain, furniture and other collectables is extensive and of superb quality. Free tours are offered from time to time and are very worthwhile. The painting collection alone is amazing, Rembrandt, Franz Hals, Gainsborough & Sir Joshua Reynolds are represented by masterpieces here. There is a cafe here that is supposed to be good too though I have never tried it. For anyone who has visited the main attractions in London, seek out this one.

Fabulous Duck Shooting in the area..... It is hard to imagine that when Hertford House was built, the site was chosen because of the fabulous Duck Shooting in the area!!!This is such a wonderful house/museum/gallery and amazingly tucked away behind Selfridges! it is well worth a visit - even a deviation away from shopping on Oxford Street - into this tranquil haven. The house is beautifully maintained and chocka full of awesome things - from Limogues Porcelain, Furnishings and even armour. I know the main gallery with the Laughing Cavalier has recently been restored and I haven't been back to see this. But there is just so much to see. I've been loads of times, and have also been with a private tour guide which is well worth booking for the stories about the family and the collection. There's a restaurant on site too which i haven't eaten in for ages, but have a memory of it being expensive which other reviewers might be able to dispel!As with so many of our museums and galleries, entrance is free, but they'll appreciate any money you'd like to donate. I've suggested a 2-3 hour visit, but you could easily spend all day here....

a hidden gem!. The Wallace Collection is one of those not so well known museums in London compared to the most popular ones. I came across it by accident but I'm so glad I did. It was fascinating, a real find & I'm looking forward to making a return visit
Hidden Gem. This is a super collection of art and armor and FREE !! Well worth a visit and just off Oxford Street

Just the right size museum. We really enjoyed the Wallace Collection which is housed in a lovely old home, Hertford House. The collection is impressive especially in its Titians, Canalletos and 17th C. Dutch painters. 18th C. French paintings, sculpture and decorative arts are also very well represented. We particularly appreciated the fact that they had more benches to rest between works of art than most museums. The Wallace also has a lovely dinning area. Although we just had something light, it was very good.
Great place to visit. Great collection, free of charge entrance and amazingly friendly personnel. Totally recommended for visit.
Amazing art and restaurant. We had brunch and a cruise through the amazing collection of armor and art. The museum is free and is in a stunning old mansion.

Travel back in time. Free "museum", beautiful collections (a lot from 17th and 18th century France), you can pop by for 10 minutes or stay there there for hours (there is a restaurant if you choose to spend the whole day there; quite fancy it seems). In each of the room there is a leaflet telling you everything about the objects in it, where they come from, what they are about. Tere is everything there, from German religious sculptures from the 14th century to Early Modern Arabic weapons. Breathtaking!

Gorgeous!. This is one of London's best kept secrets, as far as I'm concerned. Oh there are plenty of stately homes to visit, but this one is a 3-minute walk from Selfridges!The sumptuous decor and the magnificent collection of art all housed in a glorious and well-kept mansion make this the perfect place for an afternoon stroll. The people working there are all as enthusiastic about the collection as I am. To top it off, the restaurant in the atrium serve fine French cuisine, as well as a traditional English tea. I've had better scones. I make better scones! But the prestigious surrounds and airy high ceilings make it a worthwhile oasis in a sea of shops off Oxford Street. Well worth a visit.

Great museum a few blocks from Hyatt Regency Churchill. I wanted to view some paintings to round out my very short London visit but was too tired to go cross town to National Gallery. This gem of a private collection was very near the hotel and completely absorbed my attention for two hours. There were beautiful portraits, including a Rembrandt of his son, and numerous allegorical scenes, dutch/Flemish works, illuminated manuscripts, decorative arts, and rooms of armor and weapons. The educational materials are adequate, with an audio tour that discusses some of the objects, and in each room a more extensive reference discussing each painting and object. "It is probably best known for its paintings by artists such as Titian, Rembrandt, Hals (The Laughing Cavalier) and Velázquez and for its superb collections of eighteenth-century French paintings, porcelain, furniture and gold boxes, probably the best to be found anywhere outside France. Less well known is that the Wallace Collection features one of the finest groups of princely arms and armour in Europe and, alongside this, you can enjoy splendid medieval and Renaissance objects, including Limoges enamels, maiolica, glass and bronzes."

wonderful personal collection. Completely free, this is one man's collection of (mostly) paintings and sculpture reaching across six centuries, in a delightful and charming grand house, just off Oxford Street. You will never see any of these anywhere else on loan, as nothing is permitted to leave. Marvellous restaurant smack in the middle of the building.
Wonderful collection and presentation. A great day out, what's not to like! In addition the cafe is very nice and in a covered courtyard so worth a visit at anytime.
Gallery. This incredible gallery is FREE.It has an enormous collection of art, arms, porcelain and lots of other treasures.I highly recommend it.Do go see it.
Wonderful art gallery. It has a wonderful collection of paintings and other objet d'art. It's completely free and has an excellent restaurant too.

A Hidden Gem in London. The Wallace Collection is located in on Manchester Square in London, about two blocks behind Selfridges on Oxford Street. It houses a major art collection (including the world famous 'Laughing Cavalier'), as well as sumptuous rooms, an amazing collection of porcelain, astonishing furniture, and a massive collection of arms and armour. It's recently completed a major refurbishment to the art exhibition rooms. And it's free. On top of all this, it also has what might be one of the best cafes in the whole of central London - the central court has been glassed over and made into a beautiful, calm and excellently run cafe/restaurant. Food and coffee is reasonably priced, and it's rarely crowded. Add in the first rate guided tours twice a day (also free) and the Wallace becomes a really attractive 'stop over' for those enduring a busy and stressful day shopping in Oxford Street. Try it - you won't be disappointed.

Lovely Little Museum. I wish I had more time to spend in there. Delibeartely went to see The Swing by Fragonard, as it is one of my favorite paintings. While there, I also admired other beautiful works of art, which are so many there (yes, The Laughing Cavalier, too), and I advise every London visitor to get off a beaten path every once in a while, and check on this little gem of a museum.

Fantastic medieval armour collection.. Hadn't been for years so decided to pop in after refurb. The downstairs collection of medieval armour and weaponry is fantastic. Some of the best and most unique I've seen.......and I've seen quite a bit.  Probably items the museums couldn't afford. Highly recommended for a family visit.

Interesting and pleasant atmosphere. We had a really good visit, seeing all kinds of furniture, paintings and a very interesting armoury.Well worth visiting and the covered courtyard café provides a pleasant place to rest our feet for around 20 minutes. It was not crowded when we visited, so it was doubly pleasant.If you like French paintings and elaborate furniture pieces, as well as an armoury of rare rifles and swords, this is the place to go. The size of the premises is between small to medium and is quite well organised.

Almost ideal attraction. Since its refurbishment the Wallace Collection of paintings and other artistic items is a wonderful treasure trove - with free entry - in a very favourable position in Manchester Square behind Selfridges, Oxford Street. However, like some other galleries, a little more thought might have been given to grouping the paintings more carefully according to their logical connections. The restaurant, albeit a little expensive, has a limited but imaginative and beautifully presented menu with cheerful if somewhat slow service (we were first there on a Sunday but the two course meal still took over 90 minutes with consequential costs in the outrageously dear car park five minutes walk away. Overall a gem, meriting repeated visits.Cato
Very rich private collection. I am an Art Historian and I had this time the opportunity to visit the collection that I raccomand for its importance between the London MUseums

Great place. Brilliant surroundings and excellent food. Take care to visit the Wallace Collection before it closes at 5.00 because the restaurant is open later. Set in an atrium with a glass roof to the sky

Unique house. This man had enough to indulge his passion which was collecting paintings and curious objects. Beautiful fragonard, watteau and many others. Stuffed with interesting collections. It takes at least 2 hrs to go thru. However the outdoor covered restaurant rates 5*. My sister and I had excellent lunch there that I would go out of my way to dine at again when I'm next in london.

Restaurant adds to eclectic venue. Had the joy of dining with a family group following a special ceremony and this was a chosen venue. Have long valued the artistic value of the Collection but did not realise they now operated a fully fledged restaurant in the courtyard/atrium. Sadly I suppose many others do not realise until word spreads as plenty of spare capacity. Yet the pricing of a two course or three course meal was very reasonable for the location and the actual dishes were fine cuisine with superb presentation. Wine and drinks are available and our group dined really well without breaking the bank. I believe the chef is newly appointed and I trust word passes around to keep the enterprise viable, we would certainly return and soon. If I had one reservation it was that although the waiting staff were generally amenable and did a lot well, it always irks me if a group had orders taken systematically that when the course is served it is not placed directly to your place but the meal is called out. The food outweighed that criticism all the same.
always a treat. The ambiance and the collection itself always make this a treat. The Collection is well signed and the idiosyncratic setting could not be more pleasing

Inspirational. Personally I loved the armoury section which contains amongst various weapons knights armour and horses armour. Knights sit atop huge life size model horses in full regalia. Its really something very special to see. Another treat is a beautiful painting of the Lady of Chalotte - I hope its still there. Not to mention opulent spaces and beautiful snuff boxes. The cafe is expensive. Make sure you have plenty of money to hand if eating there!

Wonderful. Ask directions after leaving the tube. Worth the 10 minute walk. Furniture, art collection, complete sets of armor & weapons. Need a minimum of an hour to view the extensive collection. Well worth the visit to this free attraction. Pictures are allowed. Would not recommend for small children, probably would be bored.
Must see. If you only have time to visit one Museum in london this is the one. the most eclectic collection iv'e ever seen

Newly reopened. Had read about the reopening of a large part of the gallery and spent a very enjoyable half day there.
