The exhibits are well displayed and the contents are from paintings, crockery, cutlery, coins, arms and armour - all well displayed. The new top floor is a joy. Very attractive restauant.

Absolutely amazing!. An incredible collection of art and antique furniture in a beautiful home. Even seeing the exceptional window treatments was gratifying. Loved the Sevres, the Fragonard, Cannaltto, Boucher, Reynolds so much beautiful art. The exceptional furniture is in excellent condition, so grateful for such thoughtful philanthropy! The cafe is fantastic! Lots of wonderful free programs at the Wallace Collection too. A treasure.

Wonderful Wallace. A wonderful gift bequeathed to the nation ! This collection has something for everyone - young and old alike. Family - have you spent too much money ? Leave the shops and enrich your minds with this collection of art, armour and artisan - all free.With new exhibits held regularly, this collection never fails to amaze and there is always something for the younger children including holiday activities and fun activity pack for them to complete.This is also one place where the refurbishment has improved the exhibits and enhanced the overall display by adding more space and improving some of the previously tired decor. The Wallace restaurant in the central courtyard is also a touch of luxury in palatial surroundings - a great place for a romantic meal or a family treat. As a Londoner, the beauty of the collection being free is that you can take the family again and again to focus on different parts of the collection and absorb it in more detail. There are fun rooms in the museum where the children can try on costumes from the past and enjoy interacting with some of the exhibits. In addition the galleries are a cultural treat but some younger children might find this challenging to get round, although sometimes they have special activities to encourage children to engage with the art. It is a reasonably sized place if you don't want to traipse for miles around one of the bigger museums and usually less crowded - a best kept secret - just minutes from Oxford street. A wonderful gem of a place.

Magnificent collection. It's almost too overwhelming to visit this site without stopping midway for a break in the teahouse. Everything they've done and redone to make this venue as beautiful as they have is to be commended. I am not sure who was in charge, but they deserve to be commended.

Unbelievable collection of ceramics, period furniture, armour, weaponry and paintings. A must-see.. It is difficult to ration your time in this vast collection, especially if you are trying to allocate only a 2 hour time frame. Best suggestion is to divide it into perhaps two separate visits of 2 hours each. This is a very special collection and it has been beautifully curated. Highly recommended.

Hidden gem. Tired of shopping in Oxford Street / Marylebone High Street? Need a culture fix? Stroll round to Manchester Square and into the wonderful Wallace Museum, a beautiful mansion with several floors of art (Gainsborough, Reynolds, Canaletto etc) furniture and even armoury - don't miss it!

Delightful. I first found the Wallace Collection a few years back when the building work was being undertaken - and to my regret I haven't been back for ages. However, I'm very glad to say that's been rectified - the museum itself is full of eclectic treasures - and it is immensely enjoyable to wander round. The restaurant/cafe is clean, well-run and stylish as well as light and airy.The fact that this lovely place is so easy to get to - just off Oxford Street - is an added bonus, and I agree wholeheartedly with previous reviews that this is a peaceful haven so close to the hustle and bustle of London life.

Something for Everyone. This is a brilliant place to meet for lunch or tea in the courtyard. The galleries always have something new so every visit is different. Children and families are catered for with special events in holidays and week-ends. And, as it's not far from Oxford Street you can take in shopping as well!

Wonderful collection. Visited for the first time recently and already looking forward to returning very soon. Great collections of paintings, armour, ceramics etc. Free entrance, good gift shop and friendly staff throughout. Easy to get to by short walk from Oxford Street or by bus to nearby stop.

A Gem of a Museum. I couldn't believe how peaceful this was. So many different kinds of gallery, the collection is astounding. The front of house staff were very good and helpful.
I sat outside in the courtyard drinking coffee and was impressed with the building itself. I will certainly return.

A Haven of Tranquillity just off Oxford Street. If you enjoy history and art this is a "must visit" collection. The ceramics alone are wonderful, but add to those miniatures, arms and armour, furniture, and a comprehensive range of pictures, portraits, landscapes, allegories, and there is something for everyone. The large main gallery has just been refurbished, and has been described as the most beautiful gallery in the world. Go and see what you think, and look at Hans Hals' Laughing Cavalier, who is smiling smugly and irritatingly, not laughing at all.

Beautiful collection but menu??. The location and collection are exquisite. We had tea served in the center court. Overdone scone, hard desserts, server was clunky and awkward. Really wanted to love the entire experience but tea was a bit of a bummer.

Probaby our favourite art museum in London. London is blessed with fine art museums and galleries but the Wallace Collection is probably our favourite. This is one of the finest collections of French art, furniture and ceramics in the world. You can further see some incredible works by Dutch and Italian Old Masters and an impressive armoury collection at the the historic Hereford House, where the Wallace Collection is held. We recommend taking one of the free tours given here each day by volunteers. They do a nice job of explaining the history of the collection and how it was accumulated by Richard Seymour-Conway in the 19th century, before being passed on to his illegitimate son, Richard Wallace and later bequeath to the nation by Lady Wallace. Tours walk you through the various rooms, showing the collection highlights, which include rare ceramics and furniture from Versailles as well as a wonderful assortment of paintings by the likes of Boucher, Fragonard, Decamps, Poussin, Watteau, de Houch, Hals, Rubens, Rembrandt, Van Dyke, Canaletto, Titian, Velàzquez and others. The paintings alone rival any small art collection in the world. In the end, this is an attraction that art lovers will simply not want to miss when visiting London and we highly recommend the free tours which we believe to improve the overall experience one can have of visits to the Wallace Collection.

A beautiful collection. I have been to visit the Wallace Collection many times and always enjoy wandering around the beautiful house. An extra special treat is having a drink/ snack in the restaurant inside. It is set in the most beautiful room and makes for a lovely afternoon.Large collection of paintings and armory. Also so close to the high street shops so makes a great pit stop if you fancy a break from the hectic high street.
beautiful and interesting. wonderful city palace- great art collection.you can even go with your kids after mm toussot... after paying all that money. the wallace collection is free....
A bit of a sleeper. Wonderful smaller museum a little off the beaten track. Nice restaurant during decent weather. Paintings a bit on the dark side - I prefer impressionists.

Wonderful collection and lovely setting. The collection is not the biggest in town, it's on 2 floors of a mansion in central London, The art collection has a few gems and the furniture collection is also worth a quick look. The glass-enclosed courtyard is a great place for lunch or a snack. The audioguide was very detailed and reasonably priced. I found the staff to be courteous and professional, I disgree with some of the other rather petty reviews saying the staff were curt, I found them to be all professional. The entry is free, it closes at 5, so give it at least an hour or 2 before.

Excellent mix of some fascinating objects. We spent some time here (with a break outside for lunch). Really enjoyed wandering round the extensive display of amazing items. Definitely worth taking the guided tour to learn more about the history of the art, furniture and artists.

Overwhelming. Even though I've been to most of the museums in London somehow I had always missed the Wallace Collection, maybe because it is sort of off the beaten track tucked away on a side street of Baker Street. i was fortunate during my visit that I happened to arrive right when the free tour commenced (1130 in my case). I would highly recommend this. The free tour is comparable to what you have to pay elsewhere, and gives you an exhaustingly complete history of the collection and highlights of the display.I was utterly unprepared for the sheer enormity of the collection and left after several hours feeling like I must have missed half of it. Best thing about the museum is that it isn't crowded and nothing is roped off - you can get right in front of the artwork if you want, although I'm sure an alarm would go off at some point!Simply amazing collection and not to be missed. I even liked the ground floor restoration exhibit that many advise to skip.
Hidden gem. Excellent exhibits and not too huge a place that you can't view everything in one visit. Beautiful restaurant as well.
Interesting. The collection is quite extensive and walking around you can see how meticulously maintained the space is. It's great for an hour or two or for a longer stay.

The Laughing Cavalier. Need I say more - That's a good enough reason alone to miander around the gallery and take it all in - Allow a couple of hours as there's lots to see and make time for a coffee in the central atrium

a well kept secret. It was by chance that someone recommended The Wallace Collection. How glad we were that they did! It is absolutely brilliant! Everything about this place is awesome! Original works of art by famous painters along with objets d'art sit amongst beautiful period furniture, much of it French in origin. This charming house is well worth a visit. And whats more its FREE!! This was definitely a highlight of our visit to London.

Greatest museum in London. What a breathtaking museum. It's almost a 'best kept secret', because it's always quiet and empty, and it's for free!!!! Not only the painting collection is amazing (several Canalettos) but the house itself is absolutely gorgeous. Do go to take a break from busy Oxford Street, and stay for coffee in their restaurant. You might not want to leave!
Dreamy place to visit. What a stunning house to find in central London. Opulence in every room and a place to return and return. They even do cream teas nd lunches now.... Stunning!

Good for relaxing. This is a central attraction that gives the opportunity to see a beautiful place full of antiques, porcelains, and knight armor.It is very close to the heart of the city, a hidden gem to relax and enjoy a very nice collection.

My favourite museum!. I've visited the Wallace Collection several times over the years, and returned yesterday after a gap of 2 years. It was such a pleasure to re-discover all the delights of this imposing former home. The work they have undertaken since my last visit has really enhanced the visitor experience and improved an already fantastic museum. We spent a very happy couple of hours here wandering through the various rooms and found something to enjoy and discuss in every room.

One of the best Museums in London. I've visited nearly every museum in London and this one is at the very top. Not only is the collection shocking but the home itself is an absolute must see. The paintings, sculpture, French furniture and Arms & Armor are mind boggling. This is one of the greatest private collections I've seen anywhere in the world.
Amazing collection of paintings and artefacts. Amazing collection of paintings and artefacts set in a beautiful setting all for a very reasonable entrance fee a must see!

A must if you are in London. I love this museum and I always recommend it to my overseas visitors.
It is such a brilliant collection and you will definitely find something you like.
I have been there so many times and at each visit I discover something different.

Once a private house. A beautiful example of British architecture, once the private house of British aristocrats and now a museum housing many beautiful paintings and artefacts. Original and well run.
unforgettable Must do. this collection is a personal collection, as such it has a character that some of the big galleries don't have. If you are into art in any way - visit this place
Well worth a visit. This is well worth a visit, as there are so many beautiful paintings, furniture etc. I loved the miniatures.

Wonderful collection. The Wallace collection is truly a wonderful experience, such brilliant and diverse collection, the new glass roof, adds to this great experience,just hard to describe, except wonderful and it's free, but please gives a donation as this is a wonderful place and central to Marylebone and Oxford street.

Grand House with Awesome Collection. Hertford House to the north of Manchester Square behind Selfriges is an imposing building which is home to a treasure trove of 'stuff'. Collected over 5 generations to view the eclectic mix of furniture, paintings, ceramics, arms and armour and sculptures is a truly awesome (in the correct sense of the word) experience. It is possible to get up really close to some of the items, paintings or furniture for instance, and really see and appreciate the craftsmanship and skill that has gone into its creation. After around 3 hours sensory overload set in and there was so much more to see. Got to go again soon, and I'll happily donate again at least £5 to this stunning collection.

Fabulous Gallery.... I never tire of visiting this collection. The Gallery is newly refurbished this can only enhance the experience. There is a free guided tour at 11 a.m.every day, a wonderful way to appreciate this amazing place. It is also so easy to get to. Situated in Manchester Square behind Oxford Street.

Wonderful art and other treasures, located just behind Oxford Street. This was an unexpected find, so close to Oxford Street, and its free to enter! The house is full of interesting items, and the rooms provide a fascinating insight into the lives of its owners. A real gem, and well worth an hour or two, or longer if you sample the restaurant there.
The best museum. Firstly it is not a big museum but one of the most important ones indeed.You can enjoy the collection without the crowd level as other museums.it is near to underground lines .

Fantastic for art lovers. Absolutely brilliant collection of fine art and artifacts. There is also a small Armoury. London is so lucky to have this collection. You need at least 2 hours to appreciate the place. If you like art/paintings then you have to go there!

Beautiful things in lovely museum. This gallery has very ornate furniture and many, many paintings set fairly closely together. Museum in a sensible size, does not fell overwhelming. We went there in the morning and it was very relaxing it wasn't crowded. A wide range of paintings, furniture and beautiful weapons... And there is an elegant dining area with great teas, cream and otherwise, an ideal "meet" venue with good food.
very interesting. It is free and this a very interesting house to visit and the collection is very good if you have time you should go and visit it.

A highlight of my trip. Extraordinary museum, exquisite pieces and detail, paintings include treasures such as Gerrit Dou's Astronomer by Candlelight, a couple of excellent Delaroches, unusual Murillos, and Rubens. Will go back on next visit.
Calm and magnificent in the west end. Great place to visit just off Oxford Street. Magnificent art great cafe and a lovely place to spend a couple of hours.
Fabulous Collection of Artwork. Wonderful collection of artwork, it's just reopened. Free but they request a 5 Pound donation which you should be very happy to give, well worth a visit.

A must to see. This is without any doubt one of my favourite museums in London. It has a stunning collection of fine and decorative art, including also antique arms & armour. A true gem! The staff in the rooms are knowledgeable and helpful. The restaurant in the courtyard is welcoming and provides a pleasant culinary experience.

Great setting shame about the catering. We went for a cream tea. The setting is really lovely and we did have a nice time but that was despite the service and the tea!The service was incredibly amateur. We were served tea about twenty minutes before any food arrived, by which time it was cold. However, before it had time to cool, one of the staff managed to spill tea on one of our party. The scones were ok, though they could have been fresher, and there was not enough jam...I mean who saves money on the jam? And then the cakes were pretty poor.There are far better places to go for tea in London

Art Buffs Delight. A must for anyone interested in art. Covers most styles, most countries and also includes furniture and porcelain. The minatures are fascinating. Good restaurant also. Not to be missed when in London.
Afternoon tea. Tea in the conservatoy was delicious,lovely cakes and tea leaves in tea pots. Light and airy . Plenty of art and culture to see,beautiful house

Re-vamped gallery.. Excellent tour provided by The Art Fund of the newly re-vamped Simon Sainsbury gallery on the 1st floor .A joy to visit especially to see "The Laughing Cavalier" housed in new splendour-a picture I have enjoyed many times after being introduced to the collection by my late Father when I was at primary school. Lunch was another matter-what there was of the main course! One would have thought that in such super surroundings - the newly re-done restaurant - the staff could tell a soup spoon from a dessert soup- 2 out of 5 of us had soup spoons! Had a brief look around the rest of the collection-a "must" visit if one is in London.

One of the best in the world. I rate the Wallace Collection as one of the best museums/art galleries in the world. Housed in a large mansion just off London’s famous Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection contains some of the finest examples of 18th and 19th century French art to be seen outside Paris, but also provides a taste of 16th century Italian masters, 17th century Dutch masters, and some English ones too.It whets the appetite not only of those with an appreciation of art, but it also has magnificent displays of porcelain, furniture, and armour, including early oriental armour.The collection is small compared to the great galleries and museums, but that is part of its attraction. However long you spend there, you will not be exhausted when you have finished, and you will be able to enjoy most of the wonderful exhibits.The restaurant is light, airy and expensive. It caters for vegetarians, but like so many places that profess to do so, it forgets those who do not eat eggs or non-vegetarian cheese.There is limited disabled parking (3 spaces), which should be booked in advance, and there is a lift to take you upstairs. Wheelchairs are also available to borrow, and there are very lightweight stools that you can easily carry around.Weekdays it is usually fairly quiet, and even on weekends it does not get overcrowded.
Short visit. Very beautiful pictures. Needs loads of time to see everything. Went to the coffee shop. Lots of different kinds of cakes. A bit on the expensive side. But hey it is london after all.
Wallace a great couple of hours of your time. Free museum tucked in behind the busy high street it's interesting quiet and an oasis of calm in a busy city

Love this Museum. I used to be lucky enough to live round the corner from it, and was in and out all the time. Not so often nowadays, alas, but it never fails to please. My favourites are the Rembrandts and Van Dykes, but it's all worth a look, including the beautiful house and the revamped restaurant.

Very Interesting Museum. I'm not one for museums normally, and this was only for a work fuction, however I found the whole collection very interesting, largely because some things you just won't see anywhere else. Definitely worth a hour of your time.

Wonderful Museum. We spent hours looking at all the fabulous treasures housed in the Wallace collection.The staff were friendly and knowledgeable and answered all our questions.We had a lovely lunch in the restaurant there too.A 'must see' when visiting London.
A GEM!. It was an outstanding collection of fine French décor with superb paintings furniture and porcelain. It is an oasis in the middle of London and is a must do!

A Collector's Dream!. This tucked away tourist attraction is a 'must see' on your London visit. If you are interested in history and art don't miss this. It is very well presented and explained and time is needed to see everything.

Small but Mighty.. This collection is special not only because of the specific pieces but it welcomes visitors to be surrounded and stand among them and enjoy each as if you were living with them. Paintings, sculpture, porcelains, etc. This museum allows you to relax and enjoy. No rushing, no crush of people. Intimate and lovely.

Worthwhile Visit. Directly behind Selfridges in Manchester Square, the mansion is beautiful and the collections are large. One could easily pass 2 hours here. There are a few Rembrandts and porceline collection is outstanding. The mansion itself w. huge fireplace is very elegant. Worth the visit.

Unbelievable. Unexpected, very nice space and art, also for Dutch visitors with even Rembrandt, Jan Steen and other famous Dutchmen hanging there.
The house is well kept and with very different rooms offer an special atmosphere that we did not know from other museums

Top 10. Well this is an awesome thing to visit, isn't it? Well worth a visit, you should definitely include it in your trip plan. Warning:there was a problem with getting there since the tube station was closed.
Lovely. Such a grand place, quiet tucked away near Oxford Street. Afternoon tea is lovely, in such a light pretty room!

Outstanding relatively little known place. A perfect place to visit for all groups except perhaps young families. An off the beaten track gallery with an excellent armoury for the boys. The rooms are packed with exquisite art works and beautifully preserved furniture and artifacts. Free to enter. Although we didn't have time to go to the cafe it looked superb.

Wow. Can't believe I'd never been here. Good eclectic collection, loved the house too. As it was a nice and sunny day I took a glass of champagne in the court yard. The facilities here are excellent also. Would recommend.

and the cafe is lovely, too. A glorious gem in the centre of London but do make time to enjoy the excellent cafe/restaurant in the covered courtyard. It is open for breakfast, and the staff serve you at the tables so you won't have to wait while they brew your coffee. An oasis of excellent service in wonderful surroundings.What more can you want? Small but perfectly formed.
amazing house and collection. Free, a far ranging collection of art that is well displayed.French Louis XV furniture. Home itself is worth experiencing even if not an art fan.

Wonderful gem just north of Oxford St. I've lived in London for 14 years and really have no idea why I've only got around to visiting the Wallace Collection now. Not only is this a cornucopia of different objects but includes great artwork and a fantastic armoury. The house itself is fantastic and on a beautiful square set back from the madness of Oxford St.Going in, I was aware that The Laughing Cavalier was the star attraction, but for me, the star of the show is the French art. I've often seen prints of Fragonard's The Swing, but until I saw it for real, had never realised how "naughty" it really is. That suitor really has chosen a prime location!!I spent several hours at the Collection and can thoroughly recommend a walk up to Charing Cross Rd along those back streets. Not only is it much quieter than Oxford St but there are beautiful quaint shops and fantastic little cafes.

World Class Collection not widely known. The Wallace Collection is in a very Central Location close to the Bond Street part of Oxford Street. In many ways it is better than visiting one of the great museums which are so big that you would need a week to (maybe) see everything. The Wallace Collection includes some great Masters in a wonderful setting, especially now that it has been refurbished.if I had just one day to visit an Art Museum, I would go here rather than visit the National Gallery.

One of the Best Museums, and it's FREE!. You'll want to take your time through this museum, a former home of a couple who loved to collect and enjoyed a lovely home. You will find many rooms marked: boudoir,gallery, study, etc. Walls are covered in vibrant silks, and filled with marvelous paintings, small gold box collections. Be sure to view both levels, as there is much to see! Well displayed rooms of knights and horse in armor,with shields. Fascinating to note the different styles of armors, shields,meshing, and weapons. As many mention, not especially easy to find, so give yourself extra time to discover it, as well as enjoying the collections. Mansion was turned over to the UK government, and it's wonderful that they allow tourists to view without payment. Take advantage!

Marvellous collection of 18th Century art. The rooms of the Wallace Collection are full of over-the-top 18th Century European art, much of it French. There are many great paintings by the likes of Velazquez, Rubens, Poussin and Watteau, but also many space-fillers by less distinguished artists. And this is a must-visit museum for lovers of Sevres porcelain. The real stars are the rooms themselves, with their extravagant decorations, which are well worth seeing. Personally, if I only had time to visit five museums / collections in London this would not be one of them, but it would be in my top ten.

excellent. There is so much to see and learn here. The exhibits are truly staggering. We enjoyed a tour which was led by an outstanding french lady, and oh boy, did she know her stuff! Thanks for a great visit and allowing us in.

A little magic in Marylebone. Set in an imposing building in Manchester Square, the Wallace is a beautiful light airy space with lots of stunning piece to view. The cafe/restaurant is well worth a visit to. Highly recommend.
A walk down History Lane.. This Museum had everything, going back 15 / 16 centuries & well preserved, you could spend a whole day here & still not see everything, highly recommend a visit.

An intriguing intro into London history and design. I chanced on a talk by a volunteer guide talking about 16th C Dutch genre painting. Her knowledge was comprehensive and she led you through an understanding of artist intent, mores of the times, and set the scene of domestic life in 16th C Holland.The collection of ceramics glass and armory is wonderful. To do the collection justice you need at least four hours.

Some disapointments. I started my afternoon with lunch in the museum's café/restaurant. Incredibly, it took nearly two hours to complete my two course prix fixe meal. The hostess was very pleasant, but the servers either ignored me or promised they'd bring whatever I'd been waiting ages for -- and then left me waiting again. Even getting a glass of tap water took nearly a half hour. After I waited 45 minutes for dessert (the tarte tatin), the waiter admitted it had been burned. The hostess immediately asked if she could substitute something else - but the waiter should have figured this out much earlier.Finally, with less than two hours until the museum closed at 5 p.m., I left the restaurant and headed to the museum's entrance where I purchased the audio guide. The guy selling the audio explained that the "masters" tour (promoted on the museum's web site) had been replaced by a much more efficient tour. Instead of listening to an entire long description, visitors could simply key in the number displayed next to the work of art. As I meandered to the upper level to start (as directed) I discovered that hardly any of the displayed works were covered in the audio guide. One room, crowded with lots of small works on every wall, didn't have a single audio description. Other rooms had only one or two descriptions. The descriptions themselves were quite good, running a couple of minutes each - but there were surprisingly few. Besides that, some of the numbers were incorrect and others didn't work because they were part of "the family tour." When I pointed out these problems to the audio guide guy, he initially denied it. So I showed him a nearby painting with an erroneous number. He conceded I was right and said he'd "pass the information along." No mention was made of refunding me the fee for the audio rental. (There is no entrance fee for the museum.) I had the impression that both in the restaurant and in the museum no one really cared much about the visitor's experience. (Well, the restaurant hostess seemed to care, but you can't expect her to do everything.)The museum is jam-packed with artwork, but I'm not an art historian, and consequently I rely on audio descriptions to make the most of my visit. The skimpy audio tour combined with my lunchtime restaurant experience left me wishing I'd spent the afternoon elsewhere.

Great Collection. Every time i go to London have to make a visit to the Wallace collection . Most of the rooms have undergone a renovation and it is an amazing collection covers everything from armour to paintings.The restaurant is a fabulous place to have lunch I had a great salad

Not y cup of tea. There was certainly an extensive collection of antique furniture, paintings, even weaponry, but I personally found the whole thing a little boring. I usually enjoy exhibitions and museums, but this one somehow didn't do it for me. Each to their own, I guess.

tucked away. tucked away in a small square behind selfriges is a great collection of art . it has just had a re vamp of the main gallery letting more natural light in so that you can see the paintings . the most famous work here is the laughing cavalier

Beautiful Setting but Poor Service Taints Experience. I thought this was a lovely place to take two girlfriends visiting from Paris, and it was. This being said, the food was VERY slow in coming, as well as our drinks (from the waters and juices at the beginning to the coffees in the end). The quality of the food is just slightly above average but this mixed with the poor service makes it really not worth the price.
Wonderful Collection. Great collection of art and armaments in a gorgeous mansion located on a leafy square just north of Oxford Street shopping.

Not the Tate. I always think of the Wallace collection as slightly old fashioned, in a good way. It is not one great gift shop with a few pictures attached. It is a serious gallery. You won't be crushed to death by the crowds. You will be able to spend a long quiet time looking at beautiful things. Make some time to go there.

Great selection of masterpieces in bright setting. Fresh from a 2 year 5m refit of the long upstairs gallery, the Wallace Collection is a first class art showcase, with masterpieces too numerous to name. Fans of Rubens and Rembrandt will not be disappointed and the layout aids appreciation of the timeline of art development with short but helpful narratives on each door. A lovely courtyard cafe to break your visit adds to the pleasure.
For arms and armourry fanatics. Great property housing a museum with interting paintings and a fabulous Arms & Armour collection. Great cafe/restaurant inside.
afternoon tea. I was only once there for an afternoon tea and it was amazing.attending the collection I decided to accompanied with a cup of tea chat and a nice dessert in beautiful surrounding.

We visit worldwide private collections and we loved this place. We booked in advance a 5 o`clock tea at the terrace. They have many dozens of spicy teas and great traditional cakes and sandwiches. Very impressive and calm tea spot. The Wallace collection is very reach in any aspect. My wife, my daughter and my grand-daughter enjoyed every minute and made many photographs inside. It is located in walking distance from Oxford street. So book a table at the tea restaurant and enjoy cultural 2 hours.

A tranquil oasis. It's been sometime since I visited here last but it is still a peaceful and tranquil place to while away an afternoon. The courtyard restaurant looked great. It's like going to the little forgotten brother of the British Museum...a little more disorganised and dusty but calm and lacking the crowds.

A Gem of a museum. My daughter introduced me to the Wallace collection and now that I know where it is it will form part of my visits to London. There is so much to see in a relatively small area and so will require several visits to take it all in. The cafe is an added attraction

Variety. Tucked away so you might find it hard to find. So close to Oxford Street though. So much variety and beauty under one roof that it's quite hard to comprehend how so much variety has been squeezed in. Definitely worth a visit. Has a boris bike dock close as well so add it on a cycle around Hyde park.
Genteel Museum. An interesting and eclectic collection which was surprisingly engaging. Nothing famous or fantastic - just like exploring a granny's attic.
Wallace collection. A great afternoon trip,,all items displayed and explained very well,audio tour was excellent,,,well worth a visit,,,beautiful paintings,statues,etc,,,

Forgetable lunch. We went to the restaurant upon a friends recommendation. We were six at the table. Even though we had been told that it was imperative to book in advance the place was not even a third full. There was staff galore yet it took over 20 mins to fill our first food order. The menu was nothing special and limited and then we were told that a number of items were no longer available - what we did get was just average. I am really not sure what all the fuss it/was about. The second sinks order took even longer, so we gave up on pudding and coffee as the afternoon was nearly over. The price certainly does not reflect the service or the quality. Huge disappointment.

Elegant museum. I have been to London many times but I only got to know this museum in this trip. Due to the excellent rating in TA, I went there today and am totally impressed. It is not a traditional museum, and it gives you a very new and different perspective (perhaps from a very rich private collector family in 18th-19th centuries ;-) ) in appreciating arts. The whole building and interior design seemed to have brought me back to that time. I will certainly visit again!

A little gem. I have been living in London for 30 years but had never visited this attraction. On a whim I dropped in with my 2 sons. First impressions are that the giftshop is small but once you get into the collection you forget about this. There is an excellent collection of armour but probably the collection is best known for the paintings in particular the Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals - who is not laughing and is not a cavalier! Thereplenty of other old masters and for me less interesting, ceramics and sculptues. In the centre of the buidling is an excellent cafe/restaurant which is a great spot to have coffee and cake. Its free so well worth just popping in for a short visit each time you visit Oxford Street
Wallace Collection. Wonderful..but some of the rooms closed for restoration. Loved the restaurant in a beautiful atrium.

Fantastic museum. I have visited the Wallace Collection quite a few times and every time I find something else that I have missed. Perhaps my favourite is "The Laughing Cavalier" by the Dutch Golden Age painter Frans Hals. I have never understood why it is called "laughing" because he most certainly is not. Without doubt, the Wallace Collection is one of the best collections in London. Highly recommended.

A glorious gem!. As luck would have it, we were due to leave London on the very day that the Wallace Collection's Grand Gallery was scheduled to reopen after an extensive and expensive refurbishment.We had emailed beforehand to enquire whether, arguably, the star attraction at Hertford House, the painting of The Laughing Cavalier, would still be on public display, or whether it had already been placed in the gallery ready for the big reopening.Unfortunately, we missed an emailed reply from Bernadette kindly offering to let us see the painting with, presumably, a sneak preview of the gallery itself.We still visited the house, an imposing edifice in the beautiful Manchester Square, a mere stone's throw from bustling Oxford Street.And even without the cavalier beaming down at us, we were taken aback by the stunning brilliance of the collection, displayed superbly in myriad rooms, adorned with old masters, magnificent items of furniture and China, plus a veritable cornucopia of clocks. This is a clock watcher's paradise!Imagine our surpise when, on the train travelling home the following day, we stumbled across Bernadette's invitation!Still, we'll be back next year for a more thorough tour of the collection, including a duel with that famous cavalier!

3 times in one week!. What can I say - I'm hooked! I've been here three times this week. Paintings. Armor. Pottery. Furniture. Porcelain. It goes on and on. And it's FREE!! I gladly gave a donation. The Met museum in NY "suggested" $20 the last time I was there. This place recommended £5. So I gave 20. Go. Go again. It's fantastic.
great gallery. a beautiful bullding Well displayed and described Artworks. Helpful staff. An ideal place to stop for lunch or a quick bite and drink. Very pleasant ambiance.

Laughing Cavalier. I've been lucky enough to see lots of masterpieces at lots of famous museums, but the Wallace is totally fabulous and not too big to enjoy. The Sevres porcelain and Laughing Cavalier are my favorites, but there are so many wonders in this lovely museum. I just stare in awe at the details and personality that Hals put in this incredible painting. It's a must see!

Small is Perfect!. This is a great collection, if small, and one not to be missed. The location is excellent as it is very central and the whole experience is one of peace and calm.....not to mention the excellent restaurant/café right there at the Wallace Collection where you can stop and have some very good refreshments. Don't miss it!

Do you want to do it like Downton??!. That's right if the lovely ladies of Downton Abbey we're going to London I'm sure they'd be staying in a place just like this which used to be the London town home to a very wealthy family.They had amassed a huge art collection and when the husband died the wife left the collection to the city of London with the stipulation that the whole collection must stay in one place and can never be on the loan so all the paintings are there all the time and also their collection of fine furniture statuary porcelain and other numerous items.There are so many paintings most of them well known so you will need several hours to take this all in and the best part ,Yep it's all free ! Of course a donation of your choosing is well appreciated.Also there is a lovely restaurant in the middle courtyard where you can luncheon , have a drink,or a spot of tea.And though you may feel the urge to go in your finest silks,gloves and finery ,they will take you as you are !!
In the heart of London. Lovely small museum. In addition to the paintings there was quite a bit of armour and weapons. We had lunch in the enclosed courtyard which was pretty good.
Superb. A superb museum. Full of interesting paintings, weapons, porcelain etc etc. This is a gem, the atmosphere is also peaceful and serene. A must see if you are visiting London.

A hidden Gem. A beautiful building with amazing Art, Armoury and lots of 'pretties'. Also a truly decadent restaurant. Was a great place to wander b4 Oxford St opened on a sunday. Very disabled friendly too

Best collection of arms and armour in London. Not so many people know about this museum compared to the more famous ones in London . It has a wonderful collection of arms and armour and some spectacular furniture and art. It is housed in a former grand home in Manchester Square which is easy to find

Great art, snooty atmosphere. Newly renovated, the place is gleaming and some of the rooms are truly beautiful. Magnificent paintings on display, and a marvellous armoury towards the back.Very formal looking cafe/restaurant. Staff were welcoming but it doesn't seem the sort of place that would permit relaxation. This theme carries through to the galleries: staff here were snooty. We were made to feel like a threat to the exhibits. I was ticked off by one who came across like a headmistress scolding a schoolboy. This was for holding a rucksack, something one of her colleagues had just suggested I do instead of wearing it on my back.Don't be put off though. The Wallace is worth visiting and its free, which is appreciated.

Why more people don't visit amazes me.... This is a really nice, small museum. It has some fantastic paintings, Velasquez, Poussin, Rembrandt, etc. exquisite antique weaponry, sculpture, ceramics, furniture, etc. yet feels very intimate. The guards are helpful. My son had hurt his knee earlier in the day, and the guards made sure he knew where the elevator was to all floors and showed him to a sofa he could sit on while I continued looking. The gift shop has thoughtfully chosen items.

A must for any visitor. The Wallace Collection is situated just behind Selfridges off Oxford Street. A private Collection of paintings and artifacts that are stunning. There is a beautiful painting of the young Queen Victoria - although my favourite is Brizo - a dog. Interesting place to take friends, and enjoy quiet time looking at such a beautiful Collection. For anyone who knows Paris - the green waterfountains with the four nymphs found all over this City were given by Richard Wallace to the people of Paris.

A treasure!. Haven't been since the refurb, but this museum, close behind Oxford Road behind Selfridge's, is one of the great unsung treasures of London, chock-a-block filled with truly great paintings, furniture, clocks, china, snuff boxes, knickknacks, and armour, plus a fine shop. Not to be missed. The date of my visit is prior to the one listed here but it's ALWAYS a good time to visit!
Charming museum. Lovely museum away from the crowds. Fabulous collection displayed in a beautiful home. There is a restaurant is in covered courtyard - lovely ambiance

A Gem of a collection. London has the most top 10 visited museums in the world, but you can beat the queues and masses at the British Museum and Victoria and Albert by visiting the Wallace Collection. Expect an explosion of some of the finest examples of french fine and decorative art. I would compare the Wallace collection to the Frick Collection in NY, they were both once private collections, both housed in the former houses of their once owners, and both have art of the highest quality. Highly recommended!

Great bijoux art gallery. This is a great place to meander - it wasn't packed when I was there and it's very eclectic, like going round a very posh house. The staff were really lovely and it's so small you can have a brush against a wide range of pictures and furniture and the indoor cafe is lovely. Service was pretty slow when I was there - but again it's peaceful.Nice place to retreat to if you are shopping in central London.

A unique collection. This remarkable collection in a must if you like 15th-19th century art. I visited the museum under the impression that I could pass a couple of hours and return to my business activities. I was amazed at the wonderous collection of paintings, furniture, chinaware, etc. Having only allowed a couple of hours, I just had to return again the following day and view the collection in a more relaxed and appreciative manner. I discovered there are guided tours, and, naturally, took the opportunity to join a party. What a marvellous and enjoyable morning.

A must see in London. Incredible collection of art, furniture and other treasures hidden in a London mansion house 2 blocks from Oxford Street. Fragonard, Boucher, Boulle , Riesener - all their best work together under one roof ! Quiet , relaxed atmosphere. Regular free tours and specialist lectures . charming restaurant in central courtyard.

A secret Gem, tucked behind Oxford Street. This museum is wonderful. It is displayed in a lovely grand house overlooking Manchester Square a short walk away from Oxford Street and completely free! The rooms are gorgeous as are the paintings, cermaics and furniture. We didn't have time to see the armoury but will come back for a longer look and try the restaurant. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Well worth a look if you want to take a break from the crowds and shops.

Splendid. This museum is a secret in London. I can't tell you how many people I mentioned it to who didn't know of it, but then why should I be surprised in such a museum-rich city. They have a gorgeous courtyard restaurant and I had a splendid high tea there with a kir royale which was one of my favorite meals on that London tript.

I wanted to like it more. It was lovely. A couple of hours looking at art and a pretty cafe in the center for tea. I couldn't help feeling I really needed to know more about art history to really appreciate the collection.

Really worth a visit, particularly the armoury displays. This was quiet in the week and was a lovely walk from our hotel. I's not far from Bond Street Tube Station. There are some great cafe's and tea room around the area to stop off at on the way.

Stunning Collection and FREE!. The art collection inside this New York residence is stunning but so is the house! Even if you are not an Art fan go and see the interiors...the incredible curtains, wall hangings moldings and floor details. The extravagant home is built around a courtyard where lunch is served.
Excellent collection. Amazing collection of arts and armor. This is a place not to be missed. It's definitely in my top 5 must sees in London.
Lovely covered quadrangle. Great setting-no entry fee currently to visit Wallace. Food and service good. Can be a little pricey

A gem in London. If you have never been to see the Wallace Collection, definitely put it in your plans during your next trip. It is an amazing collection of armor (better than the Tower), paintings - many Dutch masters, porcelains and furniture by the same family. It is free admission and the museum food in the court yard was very good as well.
Must see great collections.. Free entry. Small and impressive museum with excellent range of collections, beautifully restored. Great dining space.

Nice museum if you happen to drop by.. We were early for hotel check in so had a little time to walk around and stepped in Wallace Collection. It is an above average museum, worth a visit if you are really interested in history and art. The best part is that it is very quiet.

When in Oxford Street, shop less and view more. Why not spend an hour less window-shopping in Oxford Street and enjoy a top-notch art collection instead? Just around the corner behind Selfridges, the Wallace Collection is a remarkable collection of mainly 17th and 18th century paintings by some of the greatest artists of the times, presented in exquisite rooms with original rococo and neo-classical furnishings. Entrance is free and there is a 45-minutes-long free tour nearly every day (usually at 14:30 and on some days at 11:30) which is highly recommended, especially if you are guided by an elegant elderly French lady lauding anything French (from the rocaille busts and portraits of pre-Revolution French nobility to the Sèvres porcelain) right in the heart of Great Britain.

Great Museum. I went to this museum to see the painting "The Laughing Cavalier" that my Great Grandmother had a print of in her home. Then I discovered that I had heard of the museum before as they have a world class arms and armor collection, as well as a fine collection of Old Masters and Pre-Revolutionary French furniture, ceramics and other objects.

A definite MUST SEE.. Near Oxford St., this is a rather small Museum (with a nice cafeteria in the glass-roofed courtyard) that you can visit in a relatively short time, if you need, BUT is literally crammed with works of art and memorabilia mainly from the XVI-XVII-XVIII centuries. And I mean crammed: a room full of Canaletto and Guardi from floor to ceiling, astounding furniture, a great collection of ancient weapons and armours (so kids will be happy too even if not into museum-visiting). Free admission, a bonus.

almost overwhelming. The Wallace is a cornucopia.any single room repays an hour.I would advise care planning ,you could easily spend all day with Canelletto.The staff are courteous the food dear,but not outrageous{for that try west country pasty at London Bridge.].A true delight .

A place of tranquility. Located a mere 250 yards behind Selfridges, the Wallace Collection is a place of tranquility which is unknown to most. One can amble around the beautifully decorated rooms full with art and history (my personal favourite is Caneletto room showcasing the beautiful venetian landscapes), or take respite in the calming orangerie for a coffee and cake in the Wallace Restaurant. Highly recommended as one of my favourite hidden gems in London, which does not fail to delight my friends and family I have taken.

Wallace Collection is a house with brilliant art not a museum. Great art, furniture,weaponry, glass and ceramics displayed in a way which allows you to see how they would have been used in the house. You can get close to the pictures, and see the layers of paint used by the artist. But your close eye for detail may provoke a warning from one of the attendants..Superb pictures by Greuze, Gainsborough and Reynolds, and a series of marvellous views of Venice by Canaletto. Love the new restaurant too.

An ode to tastiness. Wallace collection is an astonishing combination of true tastiness and generosity. Started as a private collection, it was donated to public and is available free of charge to everyone with a condition to preserve and maintain. It should be emphasized that currently not a single piece of exhibition could be taken out, so, it is solid as stone combining masterpieces of XV-XIX centuries with original interiors.If you are tired of huge and crowded museums where you're lost and confused after 20+ rooms representing thousands of pieces, Wallace collection is a right choice. It was collected with love and taste and preserved carefully. Without a single sign of redundancy, this exhibition will allow to to enjoy the very best masterpieces of art and miniature drawings (mainly French) wisely diluted by porcelain, armors and furniture. If I am allowed to say so, Wallace collection is resembling the best from Victoria and Albert, virtually a concentrate where all water and waste are thrown apart to supply you with the best sensual experience you may search for.This is an excellent place to visit anyway, but if you are limited in time and want to get best from the time available, go directly to Wallace. Yet, if you have enough time to rest, don't miss a cozy (but pricy) cafe in the very centre of the building where you can spend your lazy half-an-hour with a glass of wine and recent impressions.

WONDERFUL "OLD WORLD" ATMOSPHERE WITH A VERY BEAUTIFUL COLLECTION.-!!!. We were able to slowly wander about and enjoy the paintings.The armor department was very interesting- This collection should be on everyone's list-!!!

Such fun for adults who are kids really. Ask for the kids treasure hunt it's fab for adults too. It made walking around a museum fun whilst you learn as you see more understand more because it is designed for kids. Learning becomes effortless

Tasteful Opulence. There are objets d'art in the Wallace collection that museums would kill for. Paintings, clocks, things that belonged to Marie Antoinette, etc. The best part, however, is the architecture and design of the space itself. Each room is a different color; red, green, aqua, rose, etc., contains a beautiful chandelier, and looks like the inside of a Faberge egg. A large interior courtyard contains a restaurant with white linen tablecloths and delicious carrot cake. If you appreciate beauty, this is the place for you.

Small but perfectly formed. A private collection that reflects the personal interests of several generations of the same family. There is everything from an amazing collection of armour to exquisite miniatures. Many of the more well-known museums can be overwhelming due to their size, however this collection is a manageable size and can easily be visited after a shopping trip to Oxford St or Marylebone High St. It is a bit like going to see the home of a wealthy and eccentric relative, quirky and charming and well worth a visit. The courtyard cafe, which is under cover, is also lovely. When I visited I had the wild mushroom omelette which was delisious.

A hidden gem in west end location. Step away form the bustle of Oxford street and savour the tranquility of this old family home and its treasures on a beautiful square in a residential area. enjoy a lunch in the courtyard and see some famous paintings by gainsbouough.

Wonderful collection of art. What a great collection of art in one location. We spent several happy hours walking through the beautiful rooms. Too much art to remember, so we gladly bought a book in the gift shop to refresh our memory.

Revelation. Well worth visiting to see a variety of beautiful and interesting items - paintings, furniture, clocks, armour and fabulous Sevres china.It is well set out and it was easy to walk around.It is in Manchester Square which is behind Selfridges in Oxford Street.There is no entrance fee.

I'll be going back!. This is a peerless collection of art and furniture presented in rooms decorated in the correct period style and colours to complement the exhibits. Works by Rembrant, Rubens, Gainsborough and many others all on display. There are no roped off areas and you can look as close as you like...but don't touch obv! On 19th September the refurbished Master's Gallery re-opens and that will be a sight to see.As for the furniture here - yes, some of it really did belong to and was used by Marie Antoinette!My final advice is to join the guided tour and, if you are lucky enough to have Brian C.as your guide, you will be all the better informed by his amazing and amusing expertise.

My New Very Favorite Place. For background you need to know that I am an American art history major who learned a lot and then lived in London and saw an awful other lot. You also need to know that I had never seen the Wallace Collection until last July, and that I loved my day there greatly because I found such perfect examples of the art of the Baroque period that I burst out laughing several times.

Eclectic, quirky and wonderful. The Wallace Collection is an under-rated gem if you're visiting London. The mediaeval armoury is as impressive as that at the Tower of London and the eclectic range of objects d'art and baroque furnishings make for an intriguing visit regardless of your artisic sensibilities. The restaurant is very pleasant, but at 20-30 quid + for a main it's also very expensive and trying to get a booking confirmation either online or by phone required a significant effort. Given the restauran'ts reputation for quality vegetarian options, I have to say that I thought the food was rather pedestrian (the ragout I had was pretty bland to be honest). Next time I'll just hve a glass of wine ,but the ambience and artworks still made it well worth a visit.

A Real Collection. We often go back to the Wallace collection whenever we visit London. There are clocks, china, armor, paintings (The Laughing Caballero) is in the collection. There is something for everyone.

keep your serious face on. I visited the Wallace Collection several years ago with my adult daughter and a friend. It's all quite splendid, but hard to keep a straight face when you see things like the vase with an elephant wearing a necklace and holding candles in his trunk. Or, the famous Fragonard painting "The Swing" which clearly shows a randy fellow looking up his girlfriend's skirt? We also enjoyed my misreading on a miniature. I read "man and boy eating wax". Say what? It meant "man and boy eating - it was carved from wax! Clearly, it was time for tea and scones!
Lunch at the Wallace. A very pleasant lunch in a charming atmosphere. The museum required more time than we had allocated.

Poussin with Passion. The Wallace Collection is one of the finest small collections in the world--comparable to the Frick in New York, or the Phillips in Washington DC. Above all, since it is small, the experience of the collection can be taken whole. The Poussins in particular are worth three Michelin Stars. An added plus: the Wallace Collection has the best loos in London!

Searching for Vikings and Saxons. The museum element is fabulous, I have been visiting since I was about ten years old. The exhibits are in great condition and it is well worth visiting this unique building.

Interesting Collection. This house (behind Selfridges) contains an interesting collection - why not have six long case clocks and five massive marble topped side tables - just ot fill up the room and create symmetry!There are some nice miniatures and some recognizable master. The rooms are a bit maze like. Interesting to listen to other visitors and groups comment on the collection.There is a nice tea room on the lower floor and the bathrooms are just about the nicest I have encountered in a museum facility - basically a private room.It is free admission.

Avoid The Weekend if Possible. The nearest tube station is Bond Street. Head west down Oxford Street, turn right at Selfridge´s and you´ll find the Collection on the north side of Manchester Square. As "la Wallace" is the no. 1 London attraction in the French Guide Michelin, the French weekend invasion begins on Friday evening, so mid-week viewing is strongly recommended.

Hidden Gem. This collection is tucked away in Marylebone behind the main street and was such a pleasant surprise. The collection itself is quite extensive, and if you like porcelain they have the worlds largest display of Sevres outside of France. The collection assigned a very knowledgable woman who took us around (free of charge) and it gave life to the works that otherwise would go unnoticed. I would recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection, as well as the shops and cafes in the Marlybone area on a Saturday afternoon.

Fascinating display.. A beautiful London House, full of the most interesting paintings and priceless porcelain etc. Easy to get from Baker St., tube. Such a surprise to come across this fine collection.

One of London's Special Places. I love this collection every time I visit it and particularly enjoy taking one of the free tours that are led daily by experience and interesting Volunteer guides. I always learn something new and exciting. The restaurant is excellent. Ensure you book a table ahead.

Superb house, art and restaurant. The Wallace Collection is a must for lovers of art. Housed in a fine mansion the collection includes some special paintings, miniatures and bronzes. The house itself is very fine so allow at least a couple of hours to wander through admiring both the surroundings and the contents. Leave time for a lunch or just a glass of wine in the conservatory style restaurant.
The Wallace Collection. Great Museum and it's free. Lots of great works of Art and the room are of interest, all with wonderful coloured themes .

One of our favourite galleries in London. A rich collection, with focus on 18th century, mainly French school.Note that the best hall is under reconstruction (as of August 2014), and several highlights, such as Hals's "Laughing cavalier", are exposed in the basement. Don't miss them.
excellent. Beautiful house and artwork. great way to spend an hour or two. easily one of the best free things to do in London

Fabulous Collection. The Wallace Collection is a treat of a museum in London. There is a rich array of art as well as a grand collection of pottery, glass and armor. The courtyard serves lovely food. We enjoyed the Lady with Fan among other great paintings. Like most museums on London there is no fee, they all ask for donations and the guidebooks are great.
Hidden gems. A well kept secret and some very interesting exhibits particularly the armourery I came across it by accident when walking in the west end

Amazing exhibitions, can't believe it's free!. What a real hidden treat, most people have never heard of this place, but this makes it even more special. From Charles Darwin's walking cane to Pocahontas's shoes, it was fascinating.
Hidden jem. Very interesting collection of paintings, porvelain and armoury displayed in a grand town house. Very easy to find behing John Lewis in Oxford street
An unexpected gem. A lovely place. We enjoyed a fine meal in the cafe and wandered through the museum. Rembrandt, yes two of them. As I said,a gem.
wonderful collection. Wonderful collection in a wonderful home! The way things are displayed in this house makes the visit very personal, like paying a visit to friends.

Wonderful place to visit close to Selfridges. There is a marvellous range of artwork and clocks from 17th Century Dutch, to and Baroque and Roccoco work from France. Beautiful interiors and 15th Century treasures such as illuminated letters from old manuscripts hidden from the damaging daylight in draped display cabinets. You lift a leather cloth to reveal the treasures below. There are famous paintings such as Frans Hal's famous 'Laughing Cavalier' and Rembrandt's self-portrait along with Fragonard's The Swing. Also Reynolds and Gainsborough portraits of famous beauties. So many treasures in such a beautiful house. The courtyard is currently being worked on, so there was no restaurant when we went but it is so close to many others that did not matter. It was good to offload your bags in the cloakroom, while you looked around and amazing that there is still no entrance fee, just donations are welcomed.
great drawing exposition. the building is magnificent and the itinerant collection of nude bodies drawings from the 19th century in France was great. I love the place and the atmosphere.
Absolutely anazing!. Wallace's collection is of the great value. Small but very impressive museum. Absolutely must visit!
worth a visit, cost nothing. where did he get the £400,000 to pay for the collection of knives swords etc that was purchased from the French chap who worked for Napoleon?

Wonderful way to spend a wet afternoon (or any) in london.. The fact that this collection is as it was when left by its collectors.It was bequeathed to the British nation by Lady Wallace, in 1897 and has many items that will be familiar. Staff are knowledgeable and helpful.

Classic gem. Lovely historic townhouse (Hertford House) with wall to wall displays of fine paintings, furniture, porcelain and armour located a few streets back from busy Oxford Street. I enjoyed wandering from room to room and it was wonderful to see both ‘The Laughing Cavalier’ and ‘Edward V and the Duke of York in the Tower’ (childhood favourites of mine). I was also pleasantly surprised to see works by Canaletto. I almost missed the armoury and only managed to spend 10 mins in there before it closed. Each room has a leaflet with details of its treasures and information as to its purpose when it was a home. There is a small shop although the girl serving could do learn some customer service (chatting away to a colleague and disinterested attitude) and a lovely looking restaurant outside which stays open for dinner on a Fri / Sat. Free admission (donations welcomed of course) with friendly, knowledgeable staff. Open daily from 10:00-17:00 (except 24-26 Dec) and photography allowed (no flash). Check their excellent website for more details.

First rate exhibition. Free entry to this gracious house seemed too good to be true. The collection is static in that it is neither added to not disbursed being kept as it was when left to the trust. The items are of excellent quality and are displayed well.The building shows that it is being cared for. It was not crowded at all - felt like a well kept secret. There was what looked to be a good cafe under a covered courtyard. Easy to find just a street or two north of Selfridges.
brilliant. Fantatstic collection in an impressive setting: don't miss the armory collection, worth a visit on itself

Hidden gem. The collection of French royal collection furniture and porcelain is quite unusual. The 5 masterpieces on display pending completion of the display for all masterpieces was very intriguing. The setting is complementary to the collection and a brief dessert is available in the garden cafe.

Hidden Gem near Oxford street .. The Wallace collection is set in a grand old Building and has one of the best displays of weapons , armour, and art work in London .Their are guided tours but you have to book up for them .Admission is free and it also has a spectacular restaurant set in a grand space in the building .

One of my favourite places in London. If you have a Saturday afternoon to while away and you are someone who likes a relaxed, refined atmosphere in which to admire some absolutely jaw-droppingly smashing art, the Wallace Collection at Hertford House is for you.I hesitated to write a review because this was one experience I didn't really want to share! In the first place they have a lovely restaurant and cafe, very good food. They even let us have our champagne afternoon tea at the wrong time (lunch), yes i know, not very refined of ME, but shows how flexible and professional the service is. As for the art, well, it's not just the art, this is indeed a collection. The house itself is the framework; each room demonstrates a theme, and each theme is executed exquisitely well. Please, take the time to admire the furniture and soft furnishings. Take the time to imagine how people lived in the period. This is not a place in which to go rushing by. One caveat would be to bear in mind that most of it is 17th- 18th century European work, which I am personally rather partial to. I would certainly want to visit this place again.

Superb except.... The Wallace Collection was amazing and so beautiful. Definitely worth seeing if you're in London. However, when I went to purchase something I had a bit of a dislike. As an American, I believe quality customer service should always be present. When I went to pay for the item, the lady was not welcoming, she examined my money way too long, and didn't even end with a proper customer goodbye. I felt like telling her that if I were to give her fake money it would certainly be her country's or countrymen's doing since I received the money from London. She needs learn some manners and it's not my fault she works in a gift shop.

A hidden gem. This is a wonderful gallery with an excellent collection including baroque, rococo and Dutch master works. It is not very busy and has a very good restaurant. A great place to meet up with friends.
Lovely London Museum. Walkable from the Chesterfield Mayfair and worth the visit. The art and layout of the establishment are very enjoyable.

Interesting place. This is not a large museum, based on a private collection. There are a lot of good pictures is not the most famous artists of XVIII-XIX centuries. Porcelain.Cozy and friendly atmosphere.I like this placeI was here in August 2007

Glamour,exquisite furniture,picture and porcelain collection. A house furnished in the best royal taste of furniture,pictures and porcelainby what has been salvaged from destruction from the French Revolution of 1789.The house oozes luxury and glamour.The arms collection keeps young and old entertained for hours.The setting of the restaurant is great even when the food quality and service can improve.

Fantastic collection. This is a real gem worth seeing. These collectors bought everything imaginable and you will definitely find something of interest. It is housed in a wonderful large home and one can easily imagine the fun they had buying and displaying everything on every single inch of this facility. It's just amazing.

Amazing collection of beautiful art, furniture and paintings. The Wallace collection is a gem just north of Oxford street. A beautiful house crammed full of the most delightful and sumptuous art, furniture and paintings. It is well worth a visit and indeed would take several visits to take in all that is on show. It has a lovely cafe in an atrium in side the building. Highly recommended oh and it is free!

Hidden gem. Some outstanding works of art here - popped in and was amazed to find works by Canaletto, Titian, Rembrandt. So this is where to find the 'Laughing Cavalier' and 'The swing'. Fabulous collection of snuffboxes. Definitely worth 2 hours in this quiet part of London - yet close to the shops/ restaurants for the rest of a day in London.

Superb collection of artifacts and unique pictures. Incredible collection - especially if a fan of Marie Antoinette.. trinkets and mirrors belonging to her and other notable french kings and royalty of past - the best thing is that NO items are loaned out meaning in order to see these items one has to go here

Impressive eclectic collection of art and artefacts. Lots of pre-revolutionary French art, ceramics and furniture. Also lots of mediaeval arms and armour from all over europe and asia. With lots of other stuff (including some good paintings) all in a lovely house. Restaurant is good to.
Eclectic but quality. A wonderful art collection in a beautiful building. Out of the way, so crowds are not usually a problem. Eclectic and fun, but good quality art tastefully displayed.

What a great museum. This eclectic mix is one of London's hidden treasures.Located 250 yds behind Selfridges on Oxford Street, in a delightful square this beautiful house is stuffed full of gorgeous paintings, porcelain, rare antiques and fantastic arms and armour Topped with a super atrium for tea and cakes A place you must visit

Amazing - and so easy to get-to.. The location is just a few strides away from London's busy Oxford St.A marvellous old Town House just crammed with things of beauty. Rather like the Tomb of Tutankhamun, 'What can you see?''Wondrous things'.Indeed. that's about it. Fabulous things, collected just because they are exquisite, charming and/or a delight to the eye. This is not ideal for anyone with perambulatory limitations but its great for everyone else. Do go.
Worth visiting. A beautiful mansion with exquisite paintings and furniture. The rooms are beautiful. Not to be missed

One of my favorite museums. I have been to numerous museums in London but have never been somewhere as intimate and unique as the Wallace Collection. This gorgeous mansion houses the personal collection of the Wallace family, including masterpieces such as "The Swing", "The Laughing Cavalier", an extensive collection of European armor, and numerous Dutch paintings. The museum itself feels like you are walking back in time through this exquisite house. All the furnishings are original from the 1700 and 1800s and add an air of comfort and hominess to the entire museum experience. I particularly enjoyed the Wallace Tea Room. I had not had tea in England yet and this tearoom was the perfect place to have it. I cannot wait to come back to the Wallace Collection and explore more of this lovely home and have another enjoyable tea in the tearoom.
Exquisite. You will not be disappointed by this exquisite building and its bounty of contents. Staff are helpful and knowledgable in the content.

Wallace Collection - Stunning. I am an event and wedding planner and this venue is one of my favourites. I was lucky enough be shown around this stunning museum on a site visit for a wedding on behalf of clients. I was truly wowed by the exquisite rooms and the magnificent way it has been looked after. The museum holds some fabulous works of art. Paintings, furniture, ceramics and much more beauties to behold. I always love it when you can step off a busy bustling London street and disappear into a different world. Just off of Oxford Street one of the busiest roads in London this really is a little gem. Love it.

A lot to see. The Wallace collection is free, and there are free guided tours, and there is a lot to see so give yourself a few hours to appreciate the exhibits.The courtyard cafe is lovely if a bit pricey with two different menus which confused a lot of people, but the service and the atmosphere was pleasant.We started the tour but the guide went into too much detail about just a few items from a script instead of giving a more wider insight into some of the artifacts.An enjoyable visit.

Must see in London Town !. The wallace collection is a one off ! There is nothing like it in town .It is easy to spend a couple of hours here before or after lunch ,perhaps both! Highly recommended,I must go again soon,never tire of it .

Outstanding small museum / gallery. An outstanding small museum cum art gallery set in a former grand town house off Oxford Street. I visit once or twice a year for the amazing collection of arms and armour, the art collection (including the Laughing Cavalier) and an exceptional collection of portrait miniatures.... and it's free!

Wonderful small gallery. We thoroughly recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection.The collection is displayed in a grand London house and you canwander from room to room seeing fascinating displays ofpaintings, clocks, ornate furniture, china and even armour andweapons. There is so much to see in this beautiful house. The cafe in the courtyard is a pleasant place for a drink or meal and the gift store has some interesting souvenirs.

Check this out for yourself. Visited for an hour: had visited for a shorter period previously. Probably still didn't do it justice. Lovely house overlooking Manchester Square. Liked the porcelain; especially as en route for afternoon tea elsewhere.Will visit again.

Gorgeous. Accompanied a school trip to here. The place is absolutely gorgeous, the decor and old furniture is so breathtakingly beautifully. The kids were in year 1. So they did enjoy but only because of the school activities,but I wouldn't recommend it for young children. You can't touch anything even by accident. The people there get quite cross if you do! Not too friendly.The house is quite a gem tucked away in the centre of London.Visit there if you enjoy a bit of history, architecture and art.
Go !. Wonderful collection in an amazing building...do go and visit! So much to see and enjoy for all visitors.You won't be disappointed.

Wallace Collection review. Whilst the collection is fabulous, it is not suitable for young children, and is often too warm in each room. We found the restaurant to be extremely expensive - as my wife pointed out - we are not buying the cutlery / plates, just using them. Still, it is really an excellent collection, but is only suitable for those who are interested in art.

A gallery that is easy to miss. This is a real gem among galleries in London reached by walking up the street to the right side of Selfridges. Very impressive town house setting with a very impressive collection of French and Dutch paintings. Huge armoury collection as well and lots of pretty miniatures and snuff boxes. Town house setting quite striking and no where near as crowded as the better known museums and galleries.
Great Museum. We have visited this museum nr oxford street a few times, its really interesting to look round, and has a brilliant cafe

Beautiful Place. Incrediable Art and Armour. Entrance is free. This place is underrated in my opinion. With so much to do in London it is easily overlooked so no crowds. Had a wonderful 1 hour tour with a knowledgeable and graceful hostess. Leave a donation. So worth it.

hidden gem behind Selfridges store. Free entry , amazing paintings , ceramics and armoury in a nice square off Oxford Streetclose to tube / buses . Nice museum and great restaurant in the atrium in the centre of the building serving a wide range of food and drink . Our cream tea in the afternoon was delicious included scone and clotted cream with jam and three cups of tea each at a very cheap price for central London . Worth a visit for that alone

Hidden Gem. My husband and I visited as we had a few hours to kill before an appointment and what a pleasant surprise in the heart of London.A fascinating collection beautifully presented and free entry too. The restaurant was impressive and an oasis of calm with pleasant staff and good service. Definitely recommend and will go again Joy and Peter Allen

Nice restaurant, friendly staff, good food. The restaurant has special food, not the average sandwich. Well prepared, but rather expensive. In the sun this restaurant can be very hot, but the atmosphere is very good, as it give a view on the former outer wall of the building.

Something for everyone and a lovely cafe/restaurant. The collection is extensive (and eclectic) and I only did one floor on this my first visit as I wanted to do it justice. The cafe/restaurant area is truly lovely. The staff are amazingly sweet and attentive. The food and drink on offer very good - I had a tian of crab which was light and fresh and very tasty and the bread that came with it was crusty and warm fresh from the oven. I loved everything about the place and will be back next time I'm in London. Oh and it's free!

Stylish gallery. Tucked away in the wesyt end it would be easy to miss the Wallace Collection - I lived in London for years and didnt know it existed. But having found it on the internet I visited and was really pleased with the building and its contents. Well worth a visit and highly recommended.

STATELY HOME ( AND FREE ! ). This is a magnificent house 5 minutes from Selfridges so in the heart of the West End . Worth it just to see the 'Laughing Cavalier ' . A rich range of beautiful objects . Lots of space .Really good cafe too . Highly recommended .

Def worth a visit. Free to start but donation would be gratefully received. Lots of wonderful paintings to see Reuben's etc. we were lucky enough to be in when they were going to do a tour. So well worth it bought everything to life.

Do not miss.. Not been for over 40 years. Housed in a Georgian townhouse, the collection was mainly put together in the 18th and 19th centuries. Though probably best known for The Laughing Cavalier by Hals, there are many other old masters on display, by Titian, Reubens, Rembrandt, and many more. There is one of the finest collections of French gold boxes that you will ever see, outside of Paris. The Arm and Armour collection has to be seen to be believed. The on site restaurant is also worthy of a visit.
