Wonderful Small Museum in Center of London. The Wallace Collection is always worth a visit. It is easy to find, Manchester Place, just behind Oxford Street and has a wonderful collection of paintings, furniture, furnishings with a very plesant restaurant to boot. And of course it houses the sparkling Laughing Cavalier by Hans Hals. I always go to say hello. He makes me smile every time.

Eclectic, free and well worth dropping in - another of London's often-missed gems. The collection is vast - but the house itself is manageable and given entry is free, one can pop in for an hour or so and just wander round seeing a few pieces or immersing oneself in it all. Amazing paintings as well as armour and ceramics and statues - all a short walk from the shopping of Selfridges as Oxford Street.
A Must See. An absorbing collection of various art forms in a peaceful & beautiful setting. Really liked the miniatures and some of the ornaments. Fantastic courtyard restaurant in the atrium.

A great collection from all around the world. I had the biggest crush to someone long dead when I visited here - crush to Sir Richard Wallace, who not only brough together such a tasteful and big art collection but also gifted it to London. The museum is free to visit, very informative, lovely to see. Must visit!

Make sure you get an audio guide!. Really good. You will need an audio guide unless you know your art. It gives a great insight into the pieces even if you dont know your art or dont have a mad passion for art. There is also a great (but pricey) tea room which does great afternoon tea, coffee and some slightly overpriced yet tasy main meals. Just a short walk from oxford street tube

We have been back so often, I have to give it five. The Wallace Collection is set in an attractive building in Manchester Square and displays wonderful art, furniture and porcelain as well housing a sizeable armoury. There are regular and varied exhibitions. You can wander round by yourself or join a guided tour at advertised times. We have visited several times and have been on two guided tours. They were different as the specific knowledge and interests gave a different emphasis to each of the tours. I've lost count of how many times we have visited but we shall go back again when the Great Gallery reopens after being refurbished. And it is free!
Outstanding!. Absolutely must see when in London! Stunning interior, incredible artefacts from all over the world, glorious paintings. Just a really unforgettable atmosphere and experience.

Superbly preserved collection!. Wow! A beautiful collection of paintings in exquisite rooms. Free entry with plenty of beautiful paintings which are well spaced out. Fragonard's "The Swing" is popular ( not to my taste but I can see the appeal) otherwise Velasquez, Rembrandt and Titian among others are all worth seeing. This is lovely tranquil gallery to walk around and the eating area looked lovely although we didn't have time to stop there.

Wonderful collection. The Wallace is a real gem-free entry and a lovely collection, particularly if you are a fan of the 18th century and/or European armour. Lovely cafe in the courtyard and a nice size gallery, conveniently located near Oxford/Bond Street
school trip. light airy and very interesting ,with knowledgeable staff on hand the children loved it and so did the staff and parents

Great collection. Spent an hour here on a rainy afternoon, but easily could have spent a whole afternoon. The armory collection is impressive, especially the full suit of armor dating back to circa 1380.
Will certainly be returning for a longer look on my next visit to London.

Hidden treasure. Don't miss this collection of art and armour tucked away in a quiet street just a few blocks from the hustle and bustle of Bond Street station. The armouries at the collection are outstanding and better than Leeds Armoury. Even though a large part of the armoury was closed when we visited, what we could see was still amazing. Rare and interesting art, sculpture, furnishings are laid out in grand rooms with spectacular furnishings - and it is FREE!

Feel guilty. Managed to do the ground floor. Which I must say was a bit. Owing for me but having come across the lovely conservatory with fabulous seafood, we got distracted and didn't make it upstairs to see the rest of the exhibits. Will definitely have to go back when I am not hungry!

The place is fantastic. he Wallace Collection -- This place is all about the building, and the art. It's a great place to spend a couple of hours, there's lots to see. Also, it's close to Baker Street, which is quite a nice area to walk around. This place is free too!

Drowning in luxury. Free to look at interior design, paintings, furniture, porcelain, armour. Something for everyone. So much to see. Send him downstairs to look at knives and sabres whilst you indulge in Canaletto et all. See Queen Vic as a pretty young lady. Don't miss this.

Just great. The Wallace collection is a collection from one family, and that on its own is remarkable. It's the kind of place even kids will enjoy to visit. There are knights armour on display old swordsand weapons but also more refined things such as art, furniture, coins and tapestries. Best thing is that all this is free - no entrance fee.Next time you're shopping on Oxford Street, take a short break and enrich your culture and history knowledge for an hour.
Best Collection. No barriers just like a home but with awesome contents .If you like museum collections this is above all of them .Visit this then decide on the others .This is a must see.

A great place to wander around. If you get any free time in london its great to just wander around this place, theres alot to do and theres also a cafe area but its nice to just have meetings here with friends.

Amazing. What a gem! Can't believe that it has taken so long for me to visit here, and now can't wait to go back. ALLOW yourself plenty of time just to wander, then to revisit the 'specials'. And it is free, which is incredible in this day and age....a MUST do if you are in London.

My favourite museum. I like the eclectic mix of paintings, jewelry, armour etc. You name it they have it. Also the fact that none of the art can be loaned out, so you know that it will always be there. There is something for everyone here.

One of my favourite places in London. This is free, always empty, and beautiful. Who knew the Laughing Cavalier was almost directly behind Selfridges? Off the beaten track yet still in the heart of London, always new artworks and (Marie Antoinette's) furniture to discover. The guides and volunteers are incredibly enthusiastic and knowledgeable and very willing to share their wisdom with you. The restaurant is delicious and a lovely place to spend a lunchtime. Do go!

NOT to be missed. This has a fabulous collection of things. It is one of those museums off the beaten path of most tourists. It can be done in a couple of hours and then you can sit in the delightful restaurant on premise have some tea and a very fine meal. They were in the process of renovating one of the rooms when we were there so we will need to return. The curation of this museum is excellent there is a log of every item and you can look at the materials on each item in some depth. Also the people working there know the collection and can add a great deal to your visit. This is one of the best museums in London. It is uncrowded and attended by people who appreciate the history of it and its contents and are not there to check off an item in a guide book before hurrying on to the next thing they really do not care about. Go and enjoy a really fine museum

Best Free Show in Town. Amazing collection of art, furniture, arms and armour etc. in a fantastic former family home. Get up close to old masters including The Laughing Cavalier and many more. Interested in art... you must visit.

Crazily enjoyable. Take a very large house in the centre of London, cram it with art, furniture, armour and anything else. Add lectures and tours, a lovely outside cafe/ restaurant and what do you get - one of the best days to be had in London.Kids love it - they can try the armour and gawp at the weapons, adults always find items to fascinate themThis is truly worth visiting, often

Mind- Bogglingly Unbelievable, Superb, Fantastic etc.. Words cannot describe the wealth and breadth of this collection. Mind blowing if you are actually looking. Many of the exhibits are the best in the world bar none. I gave up after a few hours on the ground floor as I was literally incapable of taking any more in. I shall return and see the rest, probably in two visits. It is a truly world class stunning accumulation of some of the finest objects created by man. This place needs hours to do it justice. One of the galleries was closed, five important paintings including The Laughing Cavalier ( who is not a Cavalier and not laughing), are in the lower area. The 'Cavalier' is hanging there, no glass, no barrier, you could actually touch it if you were so stupid, unbelievable. I feel rather worried, now I've seen it close up, glass it in so no nutter can attack it! Words, and I, cannot do it justice. Unless you are a total philistine, you have to see it.

Varied collection, house, small, free. It has it all - the mansion's rooms with fireplaces, wallcoverings, furniture, drapes, accessories - with a collection of not entirely interesting paintings (to me -- but the Grand Gallery was still closed for work), plus the outstanding porcelain (if you're into that) and armory. To top it off, there are a variety of ways (most free) to find out more about what you see: an app that lets you point your smart phone camera to get written or audio info about a very few items, an audio guide (for a fee) that covers a few more than that, and inside every room is an extensive written guide to talk about the room and all the contents, plus there are a few items with an adjacent explanation; they might even have guided tours. Personally, I think it's nice for a rainy day. There are a fair amount of chairs/benches throughout so you can sit and read the info. It's small, easy to maneuver, with 2 or 3 stories (depending on how much you want to see - maybe you skip the bottom floor). It's small, easy to maneuver, with 2 or 3 stories (depending on how much you want to see - maybe you skip the bottom floor). The restaurant is under glass roof, so well lit, but on a nice day there's no fresh air or view. I will go back again to the the Grand Gallery, and if in the area, wouldn't mind stopping in with a friend to look at a few things.

Excellent small museum/house. I am so glad I made time to go here. The house itself is beautiful and the art is wonderful. The decorative arts (furniture, clocks, chandeliers, etc.) plus all the rest make for an excellent all-round experience. Take time to go. I did not eat here, but it looked good.

Amazing place. Great wonderfully restored mansion in the center of London in a quiet square, Although the great hall was closed I tremendously enjoyed my visit, do not forget the audioguide with lots if information.The rooms and the art objects (paintings, furniture,porcelain,clocks )are beautifully displayed, take time to look at the wonderful miniatures which are covered in order to protect them from light. An absolute delight for the mind and eyes

Glorious Art & Super Scones. This is one of my favourite galleries and I have been coming here all my life. Before my children ran away to boarding school I brought them here weekly and like me they never tired of it. I'm always hungry after all the excitement of the art and was delighted when they installed the restaurant. The food is surprisingly fabulous for an art gallery. I am never disappointed!

a gem. Such a beautiful collection of paintings, armour, porcelain, and furniture to browse through, that I loved, the restaurant for tea, that I didn't, we were first in there, the only one's in there, waited forever... better places to have a cup of tea, but do go for the collection
Make time to see. This is a beautiful little museum and it's FREE! Will take about an hour to see most everything, including some Rembrandts and exquisite snuffboxes (trust me, they're cool).

Such a treasure!. So glad that our rich forefathers went into collecting art and that there was such a philanthropic vein in their blood. The Wallace Collection is an absolute treasure and I couldn't believe that you can visit the place for free today. Such as collection to satisfy the whole family. I loved the porcelain and paintings. There is a good collection of Joshua Reynolds' and Gainsborough. Lots of items to delight children. There was so much to see. So we will have to visit again and again!
a fine gallery. A very pleasant gallery, well laid out, not too large, with an excellent courtyard restaurant. Informative and pleasant attendants.

A real gem in the heart of London. This fabulous collection is often overlooked and hence one never feels that the place is too crowded. I was genuinely thrilled by the extensive collection of armour and accoutrements of war.

A feast for art lovers. I loved every second I spent in this museum. There is an extensive collection of excellent paintings which you will never see outside of Wallace collection as they never travel - they are not allowed! If you get a chance to go on a tour with one of the tour guides, do it, it's worth it. After nearly two hours spent there I still have a feeling I haven't seen all pieces yet so I'll be back there soon.

Wonderful collection in a great space. This is probably my favourite art museum in London, obviously not as big a collection as the National Gallery but free from the hordes that go there. Very eclectic collection with a number of works by Parkes Bonington, as well as Hals , Titian and Rubens. French painting is also well represented and there is a wonderful collection of miniature paintings and a huge display of armour. It's a lovely building with a very impressive atrium housing a restaurant which I haven't tried unfortunately. The great gallery is closed until September but it's still a fantastic experience.

A fabulous collection of Canaletto's. Situated in what once was a house this free museum is beautiful. There is once particular room filled with Canaletto who is one of my favorites. All the rooms have different color schemes, the furniture and art all fit in together. Small enough to not take up your entire afternoon.

Like stepping back into Victorian era. This museum is situated in Manchester Square, in Marylebone, and is not to be missed. The cost of entrance is free, it's open from 10 - 5 weekdays and has a charming atrium for coffee and a light lunch, should you wish to take a break from looking at the exhibits. Downstairs houses a stunning exhibit of armour and weaponry, while upstairs you can find world-class Sevres china along with top-quality art from all corners of the earth. The museum was once a private home and it's a delight to look at from the street. Highly recommended.

Wonderful Collection. It is like stepping back in time in a very wealthy person's mansion. What a wonderful and eclectic collection. You should spend a couple of hours. The cafe looked good, I would eat there the next time.

Conveniently located, worth more than just a visit.. Very conveniently located, behind the Selfridges on Oxford Street, adjacent to Manchester square, a beautiful mansion, Wallace certainly had quite a penchant for collections. A private collection left to posterity for their enlightenment and education, one visit is certainly not enough to do it justice.The foundation is doing a good job, keeping it free, though a donation is always welcome. A lovely restaurant situated within its precincts is quiet, unhurried and well stocked.Quite enjoyed viewing the armory, the porcelain ware, paintings and period furniture.

ok collection. This collection is housed on a beautiful mansion. The quality varies a lot, there are some fantastic paintings like one by Frans Hals, but overall the collection has too many french and italian paintings from the 17th century, aka boring. Overall if you like paintings from that era you will like it, but other museums are more worthwhile in london. The opening time at 10m is too late for my taste but i canno complain because it is free.

An underappreciated gem. In New York, it's the Frick. Paris, the Jacquemart-Andre. Every city has one heart-stoppingly great museum that only the locals seem to know...and love. In London, it's the Wallace Collection, magnificent collection of seventeenth century art, furniture, etc. together with the best, most accessible collection of arms and armor I've seen. The house is constantly (but unobtrusively) being improved, and the garden restaurant is a quiet oasis for tea or whatever. Quite wildly underappreciated; not to be missed.

Good but not my taste in art. I really only came to see Fragonard's 'The Swing'. It was amazing to see this painting in person. It is such an interesting work. It was worth the trip to see it. The rest of the collection is not really to my taste but was well laid out. The staff were helpful. The gift shop is one of the most comical I have been in. There are loads of tacky souvenirs. For people who enjoy art of this period it would be great, think little old ladies. If you are one, go for it!

An escape from the shops!. Discovered this hidden gem when tiring of shopping, I had not planned the visit and was delighted to find this wonderful collection. So restful in such a busy part of London and the furniture and setting is stunning, such a beautiful building. Loved the art and also loved the cafe!

Exquisite!!. Absolutely loved this amazing collection of art and period furniture set in a beautiful old mansion. Lovely restaurant- tea and scones if the afternoon are delightful. Admission is free, but you will want to leave a donation for sure.

One of my favourite galleries. I was lucky enough to have lived around the corner of the Wallace Collection and would happily revisit periodically. Quiet and beautiful with stunning art and a lovely cafe. Between The Wallace, both Tate's, the Courtauld, the National Galleries and the V & A, London is an art lovers dream!

A hidden gem. Having worked in central London I used to pop into the Wallace collection during my lunch break. There is so much to see that you are discovering new things all the time. The Gallery is never too crowded to spoil your enjoyment and the collections are so varied that it is always enjoyable. Love the Canaletto's + Laughing Cavalier. The restaurant is excellent if you fancy a bite to eat as well.
amazing collection, worth to make a trip. Outstanding collection of art, number of rare pictures and beautiful objects. Great fun for family and friends to visit. Good location.
Wonderful collection of art & ceramics. Not crowded and unusual former residence is awesome also - convenient to Bloomsbury - ceramics are especially intricate
Excellent Art. We found the Wallace collection to be one of the best art museums in London. The collection is worth seeing.

Escape from Oxford Street. Just a 5 minute walk from Selfridges one finds this absolute gem of a gallery ..... and, of course, it's free!
The building exudes charm and I dispute the comments of those who complain about the layout.
For an educational escape from Oxford Street madness ..... head to the Wallace and also drop into the fabulous, glass covered courtyard restaurant.

Fantastic building stuffed full of treasures!. This is well worth a visit and is free! All the rooms are decorated to the highest standard and show off the treasures beautifully. There are paintings, ceramics, suits of armour, etc and a very good restaurant in the atrium for tea and cakes or more.

Laughing all the way!. This is an excellent find, tucked in a small square a few hundred metres from Oxford Street [Bond Street tube is closest]. A huge collection of European art, poreclain, and weaponry. It's free to enter, offers a audio tour, or some guided tours during the day. Even if you don't want to enjoy all the items on display then go have a cup of tea/coffee in the atrium restaurant/cafe; or even lunch, it's excellent.And of course make sure you go see the 'Laughing Cavalier'
Hidden Gem. So close to Oxford Street,easy to break the monotony of shopping with a visit.They do great events for kids as well, free worth checking out.Great café.

Amazing exhibits, but dated and not laid out very well. Honestly, this museum does not do justice to its amazing exhibits. It's very dated and it looks like no attempt has been made to organise the exhibits into any kind of conceptually coherent narrative. I advise them to go to the V&A and see how the professionals do it. However, the building itself is quaint, particularly the atrium and the gardens. It's a nice little oasis in the middle of Marylebone. That being said, the exhibits themselves are amazing and it's worth a visit for an afternoon.

Hidden gems. We visited this museum in summer after a recommendation from friends. Its just off Oxford street in the Centre of town. The museum is an old mansion. With a atrium coffee House in the middle. The collection is excellent with many fine pieces of armour and weapons. I would recommend this place to those people who want something a little bit different.
A Hidden Gem.. Lovely collection a bit off the beaten path in London. Worth the time finding on the map and exploring for an hour or two.
Fascinating. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem just off Oxford Street. It houses some well known old masters and its free...

A hidden gem. The Wallace Collection is a wonderful, small museum in London with one of the greatest collections of French porcelain, 17th and 18th century furniture and works of art. It is a hidden gem just north of Oxford Street, and well worth the journey. At no cost to the visitor, it is a richly spent hour or two, and offers a nice opportunity for lunch or tea as well. Comparable, or even better than, the Frick Collection in New York City.

Worth a trip. With so many awesome museums in London, it is hard to compete – but the Wallace collection was an excellent compliment. The building itself is a work of art – the house is beautiful and the art and artifacts are wonderfully displayed. Plan to have a nice lunch in the courtyard.

Perfect for an afternoon!. Just the right amount of everything. A warm and inviting and not crowded space with an amazing eclectic collection, including one of the best collections of European and Asian armor, swords, jousts and horse armor. We were two adults but I know any kid would be thrilled by this.also enjoyed lunch in the garden.

Wow. My wife took me here for a birthday drink and I've still had a smile since.! Stunning interiors, the exhibits are unbelievable! fabulous courtyard, but unfortunately didn't have any food.
You leave with your mouth wide open - just stunning!

Wallace Collection. Everyone who visits London should visit this collection, it's one of the most eclectic diverse collections of art and other historical memorabilia that I've seen and no entry fee either.

Best Museum I've ever been too. Small, but expertly done. The building itself is regal and impressive, and the exhibits are all perfectly curated. There is no "filler" here, like the larger museums. I will visit this place every time I go to London from now on.

Just gorgeous - and make sure you book for lunch in the Wonderful Atrium. This is a fabulous small collection, busy at times but not stupidly so - you can see real treasures here from across the world and represented in different media, so look closely. The shop is also filled with tasteful pretty things and not tat....so stuff you might actually want to buy for yourself or as gifts. It's not aimed at children, which I find appealing personally, and lunch in the Atrium is a sophisticated affair you will want to linger over, or a rather nice afternoon tea - whatever you choose, allow time to linger, look and ponder. It's worth it. And of course, it's free to look round.....so a proper treasure.

Wallace Collect Art Museum. This was an enjoyable visit for myself and my partner although the downside was there is no wheelchair access to the upper art gallery displaying the Dutch masters which my husband was particularly interested in.
Great collection!. One of the hidden places in London, but a must see. It has a great collection of antiquities very well conserved. From knight's armour to Chinese porcelain and Victorian clocks.

A hidden gem. A true gem. Intimate, were curated, and full of impressive art. The arms collection, while small, is well represented across the Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Don't miss the the excellent lunch in the atrium.

Always enjoy a visit. A little oasis off Oxford Street. Seats outside if it is a nice day before looking round. Lovely gallery and a very nice café! Particularly enjoyed the cream tea - plain or current scones available - not many places provide that.

Hidden Gem. This is a little way out for tourists but well worth it. Free to get into and a good two or three hours worth to see.Paintings, furniture and armour make up the collection and ensure it has something for everyone. Went to particularly to see the swing and was not disappointed.

Charming home & private collection. On the advise of a friend, when we neared the Wallace Collection after our very long walk from Camden (yes, Camden), we ended our first day in London with a visit to the Wallace Collection. The mansion is lovely! You feel a bit as if you have stepped back in time as many of the rooms maintain an authentic feel. This private collection of armaments, portraiture, furniture etc. was charming. We arrived late in the day on a Saturday to few other people, so had plenty of space to wander and enjoy at our leisure.
amazing free museum near bond street. family collection - great armory collection downstairs and some nice painting upstairsfree entry - can pop in there while on oxford street

Nice Collection of Art. This museum is in a 3 story London townhouse. The inside walls are covered in vibrant, rich, colored fabric so that the collection of French 18th century and Old Master paintings are beautifully showcased. Antique furniture abounds throughout the museum; there are porcelain collections, and a room filled with armory. Didn't have time to try out the charming tea room/cafe in the inner courtyard, but it looked very nice.

A surprising hidden treasure trove. Hidden among the streets behind Oxford Street is an historic home housing one of the largest private art collections you are likely to see. The collection is diverse (includes paintings, arms & armour, furniture, ceramics and sculpture) beautifully displayed in 28 rooms of the house and is well worth a visit.There is also a wonderful restaurant good for coffee and/or lunch. Lifts allow access to the different levels of the house.
Still my favourite. This is the best museum/gallery in London. Even though the great gallery was under renovation, the museum still has an amazing collection, for the public to view, at no cost.

A gorgeous collection of art and antiques. Our hotel concierge recommended the Wallace Collection, which I hadn't heard of, and I'm so glad we took his advice. The rooms are a feast for the eyes with delightful color and beauty everywhere and a calm relaxing environment. Plenty of room to move through or linger over spectacular art. Lunch was delicious in an open, light-filled courtyard. It made for a beautiful rejuvenating day.

Awesome museum. We went there with high expectations, and all were fulfilled. There was so much too see, and every new room brought with it new and awesome things to see. The staff reception was good and there are no complaints about it. Check the guns and swords exposition!

Excellent!. Its free!! One of the great London museums. Wide variety of the collection ensures there is something of interest for most people. Lovely cafe, especially on a nice day. As a bonus, the museum is in a pleasant setting. Can be busy, so be early!

A hidden gem in London!. What a beautiful place! We spent 6 hours(including a tea beak and lunch) Free admission, friendly and informed staff! Outstanding restaurant. Excellent food, beautifully prepared and presented. They accommodated my dietary needs very thoughtfully. I highly recommend the Wallace Collection at Hertford House. Portraits, art, ancient icons and illuminated pages, miniatures, armour and weapons, busts and statuary, so much to appreciate.
Great surprise. This lovely home was near my hotel.We found it by accident.It is a beautiful home filled with beautiful things Great fun to visit
Saw the Laughing Cavalier. It is an upscale, interesting block behind Selfridge's. A mansion venue, which is very manageable to see.
Surprise for art lovers. Free entry and so much to see, a little gem. Free guided tour by very knowledgable guide. If you are in to art this is for you.

Heaven in the shopping hell that is Oxford Street. The snuff boxes, the "Laughing Cavalier", the Canalettos, the garden, the staircase, the Cafe and all for free
The building itself is so delightful and try and join in one of the free guided tours at 2pm. The guides are volunteers and love the place

Great place. I went last week and great place hide a way off the tourist track and nice and quite
Great coffee shop and a bit pricey

Amazing collection. The price is right, free. Plenty of items to browse through. Very good collection of armor. Charming neighborhood. Convenient to underground stations Marble Arch and Bond Street (when reopened)

´One of the most outstanding small art collections in the world´. .... is how the collection is described in the introduction to A Guide to the Wallace Collection. It is certainly an amazing collection of art - the Laughing Cavalier, a room full of paintings by Canaletto, paintings by Rembrandt, etc, etc; arms, armour, furniture all set in the magnificent town house of the Hertford family. The Collection is literally priceless with the Laughing Cavalier valued at over £100,000,000. The Collection was formed over 5 generations and was given to the Nation in 1897 by Lady Wallace.

Hidden gem. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem in London. It is home to a marvelous private collection of artwork, ranging from paintings to china to jewelry. Admission is free and there are guided tours available. We didn't eat at the restaurant but it seems to be nice.

wallace collection. Worth visiting i liked everything and disliked nothing what else can i say. A good collection of Sevre Porcelain and the Painting of the Laughing Cavalier by Gainsborough are worth seeing
wallace collection. very nice roomsfull of characterpleasent restaurantno entrence feeworth even a second visitnot over crowded during the week

Unexpected surprise. Really worth spending time here. One of the best armorys we've seen. Beautifully displayed. The restaurant was stunning but can't vouch for the food because we didn't stop to eat but the venue was full and certainly looked lovely.

Must see if you appreciate beautiful art. This is a free admission to one of the most beautiful collections of classical art you can see. The house is beautifully maintained with friendly staff. You are welcome to take photos but without the flash. There is a great outdoor dining area as well.
Hidden gem. Amazing collection. Easy to find. Private mansion and collection. Taste of the owner and his wealth have amassed a stunning display.

Don't know why this isn't a MUCH more famous attraction. This is an incredible place. Really outstanding collection of just about everything - paintings, furniture, armor (3 armory rooms!!!! with really neat stuff). And, incredibly, it is all free. It also has a just wonderful cafe right in a middle attrium. I just can't say enough about this place if you are into historical collections. They have personal belongings to such famous people as Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. They have some of the most famous paintings including Rembrandts, Fragonards, Gainsboroughts and more. Just a lot more than that, too - too much to go into. One thing I would caution, however - if you can take it in in 2 days instead of one, I would do that. A good alternate would be to get there in mid-morning, see half of it, eat lunch in their cafe, and then see the rest. It is like eating 10 rich chocolate cakes all at once, if you know what I mean. We took over 3 hours to see it and could have been there longer if we weren't so tired. This is longer than we spent in the British museum or the National Gallery. The rooms have lots of places to sit down and that helped (we're in our late 60's). Also, not crowded (although we went on a weekday). This is a first class attraction and I hightly recomment it. By the way, if you walk there using a map like I did, it is easy to walk right by it. The entrance is on a small street across from a small park and not on the major street that goes right behind the building and has NO signs to indicate this is the place..
Worth a visit. Really lovely way to spend a Saturday afternoon as an alternative to the more obvious galleries in Central London. The room of Canaletto's is a must.
Fascinating. A beautiful building with an amazing art collection. Love the paintings of old Dutch boats. We even held an office party in the restaurant area about 5 years ago.

Mon dieu. Quite a spectacular collection. When all my friends and family had their heads chopped off in the French revolution, this is where all their furniture ended up. Have you noticed how many Devine chateaux are completely bereft of good furniture .

A Treasure House to Remember. Brilliant place to visit. We could have stayed for a week. So much to see; everywhere we looked so much beauty on show. There is also a huge gallery dedicated to armour. Fascinating place. It is easy to reach; not far from the Hyatt Regency. There is a very good gift shop, where I bought some superb postcards of paintings and other bits and bobs. There is also a very pleasant conservatory at the back of the house where they serve very nice looking food. We only had time for a coffee sadly.
Great Courtyard For Afternoon Tea. You can look at the Wallace Collection but you can also just have a great afternoon tea. Excellent choice of both tea and food and good service. All very civilised.

One of my faves..... This museum/gallery is a bit of a hidden gem. Some wonderful works of art and a fantastic collection of armoury. It's free which makes it even better. A great day out, and they also have a great Peyton & Byrne cafe there which does a good afternoon tea.
What a pleasurable repeat visit. Well set out in a building building so close to the shopping area but an oasis of calm. Fascinating exihibts, charming personnel and well worth a visit

Beautiful House. Its a small mansion in the heart of London- Ive been 2 times now- taken both my childrenIts free to get in- you are able to make a donation but its not forced on you. All the rooms are laid out so elegantly with staff able to answer any questions nearby. I wouldn't go with kids younger than say 7 or so- My 11 year old didn't want to go but loved it once there.On the day we went there was an exhibit of one of the staffs favourite pieces from the collection of wondrous objects within the house. It was a small painting of a dog- but it was gorgeous- The staff all vote for a particular thing each month and they do a feature on it- great idea!! My dd adored it. You wont be there for hours but it is a lovely detour to see stunning furniture/ porcelain etc

magic in Manchester Square. There is nowhere else in the world where one can, at no cost, linger in front of works by Rembrandt, de Hooch, Gainsborough, Bouchard and Corot in the intimacy of a town-house before enjoying beautifully presented food, served by impeccably polite young French staff, in a bright and spacious courtyard. What a wonderful way to while away a few hours within a stone's throw of Selfridges.
Hidden Treasure. Hidden behind the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street this is a must to visit. Wonderful art collection and a fabulous dining area.
Stunning!. An extremely rich and diverse private collections of paintings, sculptures, furnitures and armors and weapons. One of my favourites in London. Definitely worth the tour!

A magical little Island in busy Central London. Perfect size Museum that presents a diverse range of amazing Art. The perfect get away place on a day trip to London, ideal for 1 or 2 hours of cultural break.

Astonishing wealth of art. While the elaborate furnishings in this gorgeous mansion might not be to everyone's taste in terms of how they want to live their own lives, it is certainly a treat to see what life was like for the 1 percent of a certain era! This museum could really be called "The Wallace Collections," in the plural, because there are so many things on display: pairings, armor, guns, illuminated manuscripts, fine china etc. My favorite item was a painting by Caspar Netscher, The Lacemaker; other stand-outs include a small, nearly hidden Memling and many wonderful Dutch genre paintings. And, to top it all off, the collection is free.

This is a gem!. I suppose many would consider this a second tier museum however, it is not to be missed. The collection is outstanding and the presentation in a home so intimate. I cannot say enough about this collection; the painting miniatures, paintings, furniture and decorative arts are outstanding. The furniture collected by the Marquise of Hertford at the Petit Trianon "yard sale" was wonderful and the largest collection of Marie Antoinette's furniture anywhere. We had very little time before we had to get to airport and it was maddening. Make time for this beautiful museum. Lunch in the courtyard looked so inviting. Gorgeous. Go.

Favorite. This is probably one of my favorite places in London. To think that it was someone's personal collection and home. Yes, I am jealous! But one can feel at home and at peace there very easily. Enjoy.

What a beautiful place!. This place is just off Portman Square. We loved it! The artwork on display is just awesome, as are the furnishings, china and other beautiful collectables. Admission was free. Don't miss this if you have the opportunity. It doesn't take very long to visit and it will leave a lasting impression.

Must visit in London. This place is such a great find- don't tell too many people!It is free to look around and is not full of tourists like the other museums and collections.A beautiful building and a great (though expensive) cafe in the middle.One of those places where you must head back again.

A lesser known but amazing art treasure in London. A must see! This place was recommended to me by the hostess of the b&b I am staying in. What a treat! Admission is free, and if you go at 2:30pm, you can also get a free guided tour providing an excellent background on the place, the artists, and the family who has made this happen. There is also a lovely cafe in the attached sun room, with good choices for food and drink.You will see an astounding collection of paintings, china, suits of armour, from roughly the 1700's to the 1900's, all beautifully set out in the various rooms and galleries over 3 floors. I was only there for 2 hours and will have to go back to do justice to the collection.

A wonderful collection of art and artefacts. A very good collection of paintings and other artworks, and children would like the extensive armour too. You can even try on chain mail! And it's all free.

Totally Stunning. Its takes your breathe away! this wonderful place full of such treasures that were given by the Wallace family to the City of London is not to be missed, right near Selfridges its easy to get to. The famous painting from the Laughing Cavalier to wonderful armour, a collection of gold snuff boxes - there is someting there for every one to enjoy - and Its free to go in. Its what I call a WOW factor

Lunch at the Wallace Collection. I took my niece and children for a birthday lunch. Everything was excellent particularly the care taken by the staff. It was a good idea to have a children's menu available. Thank you for the candle in the cake! I would certainly recommend it.

lovely place. Met a friend here for lunch, she couldn't have picked a nicer place! We had a look round the private collection, some lovely paintings, I even have a print of one of them at home! You can leave your coats and bags in their cloakroom for £1 which makes it so much easier looking round. The place where you eat is large, airy and bright. Its undercover but you feel like you are eating outside. We had a 2 course lunch menu and the food is delicious and very beautifully presented. I would definitely recommend it and cant wait to come again

Fascinating exhibition with so many aspexcts.. I thought this was just an art gallery, but its NOT. A wonderful armouriy as well as objets d'art and the famous art collection. CAfe available too. Very convenient for West End.
Stunning and beautiful. . I love this place. Furniture, paintings and objects that they have a history to tell. I can't wait to go again and visit something that is now in my heart.

ART is for ALWAYS. If you have an opportunity VISITEven if you are NOT an Art-freak this is a place to seeEasy accessCool surroundingsLet the sounds of London melt infront of sumptuous and interesting artDr Peter Tillman (ex Londoner, ex Jersey now Chch NZ) Senior

Definitely a hidden gem in London. Amazing little museum in central London. The architecture of the house is stunning and the paints and objects in exhibition are true masterpieces. For lovers of art is a must go.
an outstanding collection. If you keen on paintings from the 16th to the 19th century then the Wallace collection is a must. Furthermore you will find arms and coins.Do not miss it!

Truly amazing collection. This a know as well known of a place, but we are really glad we went. It is a terrific collection accumulated by generations of the same family and eventually turned into a museum. What a great place!

Amazing museum. Well, I have to thank unpredictable London weather at least once: had it not been a rainy morning, we would have embarked on one of our planned outdoor side trips from London. It was raining heavily, so we decided to stay in town and go to one of the museums in London that we have not visited yet (it is not our first time in London). I am so glad we did it: Wallace collection has it all: wonderful paintings, collection of the most elaborate china and miniatures, and fantastic furnishing. You can also enjoy their spectacular collection of world class armor, both European and Oriental. The rooms decor is fabulous: no words to describe how elegant and ornate the design is. Admission is free and it is very easy to get there from Marylebone station or just taking a double-decker.

Almost hidden away. Great collection of paintings, china and many other artefacts. There's usually an excellent temporary exhibition. Don't miss the excellent cafe/restaurant. Usually calm, quiet and a very professional service.
Exquisite museum with beautiful artefacts. Marvellous. Have been on several occasions as there is so much to see. The restaurant is very nice even in winter and a lovely atmosphere.

What a Gem. I love this place, one of my favourite museums, it is full of treasures of every description, very opulent. You can spend a whole day there if you want or just a spare half hour. Don't miss this one.
lovely museum. one of my favourite London's museums. Collection of pictures, arms, furniture is magnificent. To have coffee or lunch in the spacious forcours is just great

My hidden gem in London. This has got to be one of the best collections in London and its so hidden to the world, they really don't know what they are missing.I have been here so many times, but every time I visit i notice something new. Maybe a piece of china, maybe a painting, maybe a religious artefact. Being a history buff, my heart beats a little faster whenever I see the Charles 1st & Henrietta Maria portraits. The Sevre collection is one of the best in the world and is delicate, its hard to imagine how it survived so long.It smells like a country old house, with oak panels and dark wood, but its filled with treasures from around the world and most of them priceless!Please go and visit this little gem in London, plus the Oliver Patton restaurant is a add treat.....
Perfect size. A gem of a gallery with a wonderful selection of pictures and off the beaten track. Go at tea time, marvellous selection of teas and pastries set in a superb little cafe.

Stunning Collection.. I visited The Wallace Collection yesterday and the place absolutely took my breath away. Beautiful collection of fine art including Fragonards "The Swing" which is a favourite of mine. There is also a gorgeous and fascinating collection of weapons from the 18th/19th century including pistols, long arms, swords, daggers and even a beautiful crossbow. Every room is beautiful and I felt so lucky to be able to see all of this amazing art and historic objects for no fee ( you may leave a donation)Do not miss The Wallace collection!

Quite a different gallery but essential!. My partner and I like coming here - so many interesting things to see and beautifully set in fabulous rooms...you can step back in time and feel a real sense of history here. So many patrician donors of wonderful art also - a real treat and a great tearoom!

Very Interesting Collection. Very interesting art museum tucked up away from Oxford Street. I visited with my mother in law and we spent a great deal of time in each room reading about the various pieces on display. The museum provides binders that are stored in each room detailing all of the artwork, which proved very helpful and informative. The armour display is very impressive and the art collection is well organized by historical period/geography. The house itself is very beautiful and the interior decorations really add to the overall experience. Highly recommended.

An exceptional collection of French history. We were not going to visit but a gap in our schedule led to an exiting morning. The collection is basically french paintings, furniture, crockery, etc, that has been collected by the Wallace family and left as a House Museum. the restaurant is in the center of the building and covered by a glass roof - definitely worth a coffee and croissant. The thing not to miss is the guided tour - these people made a good exhibit great with their knowledge and stories. We were very glad we made the effort.

Well worth stopping by .... The art is, of course, fabulous - but so are the beautifully appointed rooms which are a perfect complement to the exhibits. Be sure to take an audio guide which will fill in gaps even for the most ardent of art historians.

Churlish to give it less than full marks. I have been trying to see this collection for some years, always something has got in the way, but finally we have seen it. Allow at least 1/2 day if possible, and better still, book onto one of the escourted tours. The staff are wonderful- passionately supportive of their collection, even promoting the private hire of the venue for corporate events (as the government funding has been cut back, and entry is free). Do make a donation. We went at a time when the great gallery is closed for refurbishment until late August; however they have shoe-horned most of the art (but not all of the military collection of guns and armour) into the other rooms.This means sometimes the highlight pictures are not where you expect according to the prinited guide. Go early and book on the 11:30 or 2:30 walking tour- these take a little over an hour. We only saw a small fraction of the exhibits on the walk, but you learn the history so much better with a guide. We ate at the restaurant which is part of a group who supply the British Museum amongst others and the food is great- perfect setting in the newly glass roofed- atrium, great space between tables, good service, very acceptable food; not cheap, but then we find London and other major cities more expensive than provincial restaurants- soak up the location, make time to enjoy the food and wine and make it part of the trip (or just grab a snack if you treat teh food as fuel or don't have the time) . If we had the kids with us i would perhaps think twice about the cost, but since entry is free and should say be £15 each (at least) then look at it as a saving towards the meal, perhaps. Anyway back to the exhibits- other than the pictures, there is wonderful porcelain, furniture and a very impessive collection of armour and weapons over they years, so this should be a wide enough range of items to keep most people happy. We are so lucky this was given to the Nation (with a condition it cannot be loaned, or added to, which is very unusual).

A boggling collection of art and artefacts. Ah, how the wealthy collector lived! This superb collection is free to visit (do make a donation!) in a splendid town house north of Oxford Street. Room after room of armoury, paintings and furniture are there to be explored. It's a nice balance between having enough there to give you a really good flavour of a period and a particular slice of society, and not so much there that you become jaded and bored. The staff is knowledgeable and very happy to chat about various objects. The cafe looked lovely and has good reviews, but we didn't have the time to test it. We really enjoyed our meander around.
Easy to forget to visit but the best of the best!. For the reason you will never forget your visit to the Wallace: It is moving and great to be away from the obvious collections, very special!

Better than Versailles, amazing art. This is what Versailles would look like if the French Revolution had not happened. More furniture from Marie Antoinette than is available in one place! The collection is so large, it can't be visited in one day, just sampled. What can be better than high quality art, in a grand setting. It gives you a taste for what it was like for someone with so much wealth and taste. And then, he inherited even more. Amazing. Plan on visiting over and over again.

A hidden Treasure. Tucked away behind Oxford Street is the Wallace Collection, an art gallery where you can while away a few peaceful hours looking at some familiar images such as "The Laughing Cavalier" that you probably had no idea was there.

Wonderful free attraction for art lovers. The Wallace Collection is not as well known as many of the London art galleries but is really worth visiting. The collection is displayed in a very large, historic house that is less than 5 minutes walk from Selfridges on Oxford Street. If you feel like mixing retail therapy and culture this is a great place to visit. As it is free to enter one can just drop in for a short while. There are a wide variety of things to see: many interesting paintings including some famous ones such as -'The Laughing Cavalier', Fragonard's 'The Swing', a 'Self Portrait' by Rembrandt and paintings by Reynolds. There is a good collection of Sevres Porcelain items, arms & armour, some furniture and the house itself is an interesting building.There is a pleasant gift shop, lift to all floors, very clean toilets and an attractive courtyard restaurant. Note - this is not a self service café but a proper restaurant with waiter/waitress servers. One can buy breakfast, lunch, afternoon tea and on Friday & Saturday evening meals too- it's not the cheapest of places but is very nice indeed. However, as one is so close to Oxford Street one can find plenty of alternative eating venues if this restaurant does not suit you.Currently, the great gallery is being restored (I believe it will reopen in September) but there is still a great deal to see and the most famous paintings have been rehoused in other parts of the building whilst work is in progress.This gallery does not contain modern works of art but if you enjoy looking at paintings that depict life in a more photographic way then you will find much to enjoy.Overall, this is one of my favourite galleries, I always enjoy my visits here.

A must visit. Outstanding collection in the heart of London and free to visit but they do suggest a modest £5 donation. Amazing collection of Boulle work and outstanding artworks. We took a free guided highlights tour and also took in a talk on the Boulle Four Continents Clock with a knowledgable and friendly member of staff. The restaurant looks fabulous but as there was a queue we headed (unfortunately) elsewhere. This visit was part of a packed cultural visit and was a clear highlight of our week.
Wallace collection. Really interesting and free to get in! Excellent way to spend a Sunday afternoon. The staff were very helpful.

what a find. found out about this place on tripadvisor and so glad we did,so much to see painting armoury plus many other antiques, the rooms ,in fact everything,on arrival there just happened to be a guided tour which was free ,the lady who took us around on the sunday morning was so charming and full of intreasting storyies thank you,but even if you just wonder around the beautiful rooms on youre own the time will just fly by,entrance is free to, with a donation box if u wish to give a donation.

Excellent art and first class food and drink as well. For those who need a break from Oxford Street mayhem .... direct your feet a short distance behind Selfridges to the Wallace Collection.The art works are, of course, the main reason to go here - they are splendid and varied. The bonus is the glass-covered courtyard where one can order high-class light meals and some pretty good wines as well. I often just drop in here to relax in the courtyard with a snack and a red wine - sometimes a champagne. I strongly recommend that you do the same!

Slightly cluttered but a real gem. Wow, what a range of stuff to see. The Wallace family certainly were busy over the five generations it took to amass this collection. Set in an old manor house, each room is full of quality artworks and other collectables. It is certainly worth spending several hours here, but knowing what you are looking for or at helps a lot. The brochure (for sale in bookshop) titles Directors Choice is helpful in this regard. Each room is decorated in a style befitting the contents on display, we loved the Dutch Rooms (including several Rembrandts) and the Round Room. Entrance is free and there is a lovely coffee shop in the courtyard. It is near Bond St tube station. Only criticism is that it is probably too stuffed with items on display, making it slightly overwhelming to take it all in. But if you love privately collected antiques, this is the place to go. But it is not the Prado or British Portrait Gallery!

A hidden gem of London. Generations of family collected paintings, silver, porcelain, armor, etc. Rembrandt Hals, and other great masters. Housed in old family mansion. Wonderfully displayed, manageable size for a few hours of unhurried enjoyment. Free entrance. In the Mayfair section about a fifteen minute walk from Marble Arch and Oxford Street.

Great for a hour or 2 while your wife shops in Oxford St.. Only 2-3 mins walk at the back of Selfridges. Great collection. Try to get a guided tour as they are really informative. Totally free. Good restaurant/coffee shop.

Fantastic Collection and Story - and Free. We were amazed at how good the collection is given we had not heard of it before. The entry was free (voluntary donation) and so was the guided tour which brought the history to life. Well worth a visit for a couple of hours - and the cream teas are good too (but not free!)

The nicest venue possible. The Wallace Collection is a gem and the food served at the restaurant in the courtyard is a delight. Good service and resonable pricing. The courtyard is enclosed and so a beautiful place to eat. Puts a lot of other museum restaurants to shame.Happy to eat there again

Lovely and well presented collection. Within easy walking distance of the Bond Street tube, this collection of old masters is beautifully presented. There is no admission charge, and though popular, there was plenty of room to step back and appreciate the works. The Hertford House is an imposing mansion and gives a good glimpse into the past. There is a lovely courtyard cafe. Sadly, the second floor was closed during my visit due to lighting problems. Next time in London I'll return to finish the viewing.

Love antiques? Best museum in London. If you like antiques and think you own a few, a quick walk around this museum (which is a 5 minute walk behind Oxford St) will make your collection look like junk. (Well, it did mine)Free to get in, great location, nice (but expensive) cafe. This place is one of London's best museums.

My favorites are the miniature boxes and armory. It's a bit of a walk from the nearest Tube station, but worth a little trek. Free admission, and this is one of my favorite smaller London museums. Have been many times but always enjoy it. My favorites are the dozens and dozens of miniature boxes. The armory room is large and impressive. If you love house museums then add this to your list. Have not eaten in the cafe (it is expensive), but it looks like a wonderful place for tea with ambiance.

Fantastic, Eclectic Collection. You could visit every week & never be bored. A real "hidden jewel" (along with the John Soanes Museum) that most visitors to London don't take the time to visit ... I say: VISIT!!! And, be sure to have a nosh in the cafe ... fab.

Great Art Collection on a rainy day!. Had heard of this FREE collection and meant to visit many times whilst in central London - finally did so on a showery, cool May day.Largely baroque/rococo paintings and furnishings, but some real well-known gems among them, such as the Laughing Cavalier and Fragonard's 'Lady on a Swing'. Spent two hours there and could easily have doubled that - there's a collection of armour for the menfolk to admire too! Plus a lovely cafe/bistro in a conservatory-style setting. All highly recommended.

Didn't live up to the hype. I came to the Wallace Collection to attend a private viewing (it was a work thing). It was impressive but felt quite stuffy and didn't really allow you to step back and get a clear view. People seem to like it but it didn't work for me.

One of the best art collections we've ever seen!. My husband and I visited this outstanding art collection this afternoon. We've seen art collections in many countries, and this is one of the best. It has an incredible treasures, including Old Master paintings (including Rembrandt, Rubens, and van Dyck), other Dutch and French paintings, furniture, sculpture, other pieces of artwork, and princely arms and armor. All set in an opulent two-story home. And it's free (donation of 4 pounds suggested). Take the free 90-minute tour, which was interesting, informative, and enjoyable. Don't miss this during your next trip to London!

Amazing collection in a beautiful setting.. This museum is filled with paintings from the renaissance up through the 18th century. In addition there are rooms filled with armor, porcelain, furniture, etc. I found the paintings to be focused on the rococo period in France as well as portraits by the greats: Michelangelo Rembrandt, Reynolds, and others.

Beautiful Respite. Happened by The Wallace Collection while searching for The Golden Hind (amazing fish n chips). Died for the amazing illuminations and endless examples of Europe's best art and armour. We loved the quiet respite from the day's sightseeing. Definitely visit this FREE museum at the same time you check out London's best fish n chips!

A moment of calm. One of the most impressive small art collections in the world. This house was once the home of the Hertford family, based in both Paris and London, and the collection of treasures reflects this with paintings by Canaletto and Gainsborough and also Dutch paintings including The Laughing Cavalier. The house and collection was handed over to the nation in 1897. This priceless collection is housed in a beautiful building overlooking Manchester Square, just off Thayer street behind Selfridges. It is free to get in but a brochure is offered for £5.99 and is good value. The collection is over 3 floors (and has lifts) and even includes a collection of Oriental armoury. Walk straight through from street level and you will enter the old courtyard garden, now covered by an Atrium roof, which is the restaurant. All types of tea, coffees, juice cocktails and a good wine selection is offered at good prices. Wines from £4.50 a glass, salads from around £8.50, hot meals or just a pot of tea is served by friendly liveried staff. A wonderful place to relax away from the busy London streets outside.

Stunning collection of treasures. If you like antique clocks this is an amazing place to visit. The collection is unusual with some serious determined shopping having taken place back whenever you could actually buy this stuff. Lots of gilded treasures and beautiful porcelain. Moderate sized exhibit so you can a tually see everything on display without getting cultural overload as can happen at the bigger london galleries. A must visit venue.

A house to treasure. A grand house with superbly furnished rooms containing wonderful works of art, porcelain and sculpture. The exhibits are wonderfully displayed and lit. Thankfully there is a lift and there are chairs in each room for those with aching feet and legs. The shope is excelllent and the staff there friendly and helpful. Most rooms are staffed by friendly and helpful people although one lady was unnecessarily sarcastic in response to a simple, but valid query. The restaurant is every attractive, with attentive staff, but the chairs were not comfortable enough to persuade us to lunch there.

Everyone should visit. I love the Wallace Collection. I had never been before until recently but my mum took me there for a birthday treat as she has been going for 25 years! I am so angry she hadnt told me about it earlier! It is free admission. So much amazing stuff to see. you are allowed to take photos- just dont use flash. Amazing interiors. So much inspiration. And lots of famous paintings! theres stuff for men too- like armour and weapons! So something for everyone and theres a lovely restaurant. Its quite expensive and the portions are very small but its a lovely atmosphere and free to get in so cant complain. its a great place to meet friends and can have a nice coffee and a chit chat before heading out shopping! I just love it.
Rude Staff. Looked great, but not worth having a bunch of stuffy old broads follow you around henpecking you about not breathing too hard or getting near anything. Skip it.

Best afternoon tea. If you want a stylish and very English Afternoon Tea, go there and see the exhibition,..probably the best collection of french art and then after this enjoy the deliciuos food in the courtyard of the wallace

Great museum in a lovely house. Worth a visit as the house is absolutely gorgeous with a great collection of art, furniture, etc. The glass atrium is also great for a spot of lunch after a shopping spree at Selfridges as it's only a few minutes walk from there and away from the Oxford Street madness.

Excellent and enchanting. The Wallace Collection is set in a former private house of a wealthy family. They fell on hard times and had no choice but to donate the house and all their riches to the public. Although there are so many interesting pieces on display in this little museum, what gets me most is the story behind it. Once you have marvelled at all the fascinating pieces, be sure to have something to eat or drink in their atrium restaurant. They have a very wide range of teas, you could have Afternoon Tea, or maybe you prefer to have a proper meal from the kitchen. Not to be missed!

Wonderful location. Restaurant is in a covered courtyard central to the house, bright and aired, very comfortable and spacious seating - separate bar and snacks area,also looked very good.Great service by the nicest gentleman waiter, very old school and charming. Food good, altogether a very pleasant place to eat

One of London's secrets!. After a long walk due to the tube strike we found this little oasis just behind Oxford Street! This was free admission but did wish for a donation which was the very informative guide priced at £5! Well set out in individually decorated rooms, this beautiful collection was well worth a visit. Tea was very welcome in the atrium restaurant and reasonably priced for London.
what a great place. first its free and there is such a lot to see art ,armour, furniture its in the top 10 I think also close the the hotel (marylebone)

A charming oasis in London's West End. Time prevented me from looking at the collection because primarily I met a former colleague here for afternoon tea and a catch-up recently. It is very close to Bond Street tube, but once inside you could be miles away from the hustle and bustle of the West End. The atrium restaurant is charming, so too the staff and it is a little retreat I shall happily use again when next meeting friends in London.
Don't miss it!. Great atmosphere, fancy and ancient house. You can find a beautiful collection of paintings, sculptures, knickknackery, sevreses and enamelware.

Great place ! To see the art, meet friends, relax. Beautiful art collection, well kept, nice food available. Pleasant surroundings in central London away from the hustle and bustle of the high street.

Versailles of London. Beautiful pottery amazing paintings from Dutch painters. The history behind the every little object worth visiting the collection. Romantic & dramatic stories behind the furnitures of Marie Antoinette's and attractive paintings of Madame Pompadour. From ceilings, to walls and walls to floors it is a beautiful and elegant place to visit. A must see if you like little romance and elegance of French history ...Also there is a restaurant at the courtyard. Good for an afternoon tea. But service is too slow and if it's late they run out of some selections.

A Beautiful Refuge From the Crowds. Highly recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection. The collection is very extensive and deep. The rooms are beautifully decorated and recently redone. Be sure to look under the leather covers at the fragile miniatures on display in a couple of the rooms. One could easily spend 2 or 3 hours looking around. I took a guided highlights tour with a knowledgable docent at 11:30. Had a very pleasant lunch in the cafe. Part of the collection is closed for renovation and won't reopen until September. There is still plenty to see and enjoy. And it is all free of charge!

Too perfect for this world. Have you ever entered a place, taken stock of it, and then decided it was mind-blowingly perfect? I almost don't want to review this place because I don't want it to change. I went there three days in a row (April 2014) and, if you want to get away from the hoards at the National Gallery, this is the place. Especially if you want to experience atom-rearranging art. This place simply staggers the imagination. For me, the best is the French 17th and 18th century art, although there are other things that will draw you in. Just north of the Oxford Street shopping scene (a horrible zoo of too many people in my estimation), this place is like going to another world, a far more wonderful world. The restaurant (especially for lunch) is first-rate too.

Awesome. This is a beautiful place, visited it after seeing it on Bargain Hunt. A bit hard to find but managed to do so. Not a large place but what they have is all quality, lots of Sevres, paintings and armor. Take time to linger in each room and savor what is on display. The restaurant is also extremely nice and again quality. Would go again if nearby on Oxford Street just escape the crowds.

Excellent Addition to a Day Trip to London. As we were in the area we added this free attraction and were captivated. My Dad recommended it over 60 years ago and it has taken me all that time to get round to it. As were having a meal later elsewhere we only had a glass of wine but the menu looked good and the location superb. There is a guided tour, also free, at 2.30pm each day though we wandered around alone.

HIDDEN GEM - A FREE MUSEUM!!!. This is a Georgian home which has a diplay of four generations of paintings, armor, and other art collected by one family. We were there for about 3 hours and didn't see it all. Plan to concentrate on just a few rooms and then come back. The audio tours are excellent as was the dining room in the courtyyard. We will definitely be back next time we go to London.
lovely for tea. good spot to escape busy Oxford street, perfect for afternoon tea with the girls, quite expensive but good value for money.
What a beautiful place. We went there and were lucky enough that a free guided tour was about to start. The place is quite stunning and ought to be a must-do when in London.

Gorgeous little gem. This is one of my very top favourites places to visit in London, and I have lived here for 25 years. The house itself is beautifully preserved and magnificently decorated. The various collections are outstanding - a beautiful paintings collection, lovely miniatures, wonderful furniture. The courtyard restaurant is a delight. I can highly recommend this to both get a flavour of how the upper class lived in those days and to enjoy the wide variety of paintings.
A gem!. Fantastic place. Very near just few blocks from Oxford street and still hidden. Interesting collection and a great cafe.

An Olde English Museum. Great museum with a hugely eclectic mix of exhibits from armour to paintings and an excellent tea room/restaurant. Not overly large and therefore not intimidating. Position wise couldn't be better as it's just off Oxford Street and Baker Street, and the building is delightful both inside and out.

A wonderful treat. An thoroughly enjoyable experience and a great alternative for the casual who wants to explore more of London's historic art beyond the obvious choice of the national gallery. Hertford House itself is an exquisite Georgian Town House, and the collection itself is perfectly enchantin5th through 18th century French paintings alongside wonderful antique furniture and armour. To top it all off a very easy to reach location - thoroughly recommended!

Love art? Don't miss this!. A nice walk off of Baker Street, the Wallace Collection is fabulous and free! No flash photography is allowed but other than that take all of the pictures you want of one of the finest homes art collections in the city! Enjoy!

An oasis of art treasures in central London. The Wallace Collection is tucked away in Manchester Square, a few steps away from Oxford Street. It is a treasure house of art, including Laughing Cavalier by Hals, Rembrandt's portrait of his son Titus, The Swing by Fragonard, to name just a very few. The porcelain collection is exquisite and of course, there is the armour collection and the beautiful pieces of furniture. The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming. There is plentiful seating, to save your back & feet. You can have a delicious meal or snack in the central atrium area. If it is sunny you can sit on the very comfortable benches outside and look at the blossom in the square. And all of this is free. Don't bother about Oxford Street, go and refresh mind and body at the Wallace Collection.
Lovely afternoon tea. Loved the tea and the ambiance! It was very lively and light coming from the roof was cherry on top of a lovely afternoon

Delightful, unexpected gem. What a little delight! This is a marvelous, eclectic collection. It is in an amazing house, and we stumbled upon it. It is free and such a little delight to come across. I'm not sure if I would have liked it as much if we had made it a destination, but we had a ball!

Love it!. This is a very eclectic collection withnsomethingnforveveryone. It is a must do for me each time I am in London and I try to do a little each time rather than move from room to room indiscriminately.Last time I took in the ceramics..a wonderful display carefully set out with informative sheets available so that you are aware of the history accruing to the objects..this was made by...and presented to...by say Marie Antionette. Always I must look at "girl on a swing" Fragonard's masterpiece, and enjoy the Laughing Cavalier. Take your time and savour!
Free gallery. A good way to spend a few hours in London. So many interesting paintings and artworks from all eras.

Probably one of the best collection of Boucher paintings in Europe. A beautiful building, entirely renovated, hosting some of the most famous Boucher paintings, an impressive collection of ancient weapons, and beautiful porcelains.The restaurant needs to be avoided at all cost, though.
Visit. Lovely. Most informative guided walks and talks. The staff were genuine. It is a bit of. Walk but worth it
Don't miss the Wallace collection in London. What an amazing collection, easy to get to and ALL FREE! Don't miss - the art collection alone is amazing!
wonderful. The Wallace Collection is a true gem in the very heart of London's West End, which, the day we visited, could have been aptly renamed the wet end.

Amazing. I am not a particularly arty type but we were doing one of 'London's Hidden Walks' a great book (two actually) to use if you want to seek out interesting parts of London that often the general tourist don't get to. On the walk we discovered the Wallace Collection which is free to visit (donations welcomed) and was the family art collection of the Marquess of Hertford. It could occupy your day if you looked at every item on display. For me the paintings were fabulous, Titian, Canaletto, Rembrandt , Gainsborough, it goes on. There were also other interesting items, furniture, sculptures, collection of armour and weapons and more.Added benefit there is a licensed restaurant so you can break you visit with a coffee, light snack or even a full meal if you wish.
Little known gem of an art gallery. This uncrowded gallery is a dellight to stroll through. Onve you have seen the British Museum and explored the National Gallery, come here.

A "WOW" not to be missed. I have been meaning to visit the Wallace Collection for years on my visits to London but have never managed to make it there: this trip I did.The Collection is located a bit north of Oxford Street and Selfridge's: it's worth the short walk. Prepare yourself: this place is PACKED with a fantastic collection of porcelains, miniatures, an unbelievable array of medieval armaments form many cultures, paintings, furniture (getting the idea: packed). The space is relatively small, compared to the V & A or the National Gallery, but what an experience. Frankly, I began suffering from sensory overload after about an hour. The Collection deserves more than one visit.I would make the Wallace Collection a destination place or a cultured diversion from the shopping on Oxford Street.

Worth a Visit if Only to See Fragonard's "THE SWING". It wasn't until my 22nd trip to Europe that I made it to the Wallace Collection. What a delight! I was all but held hostage by my guest in the Armory collection, which is quite extensive and can take hours to tour if you buy the guide book at the door and stop to read the full history of every piece... not my cup of tea!But it was all worthwhile when we got to my little crumpet (and my only reason for the visit), Fragonard's "The Swing". I soaked it in for at least 20 minutes, and I continue to enjoy the memory 20 years later. I still have the fridge magnet on display that is a 2x3 miniature of the painting. And I still go back every few trips to refresh my memory!I was quite surprised to finally find it in Manchester Square, London. It would be more at home in Paris, but I can see it more often in London.If one doesn't insist upon examining the minutiae of the extensive armory, the art collection can be well-enjoyed in an hour. It's a wonderful quickie for the culture-vulture with a full itinerary, and the entrance fee won't make you Ba-Roque (I know: that was terrible.) Enjoy!

A fine collection. A superb collection of all things baroque. Too much to see in one visit. There is a fine collection of miniature paintings as well as some of the most well know paintings of Western art that are not to be missed. It's popular but not overcrowded like the National or the British Museum. Go and go again!

Great museum. Excellent location just by Manchester square and in my Marylebone neighborhood. A great way to spend the afternoon and step into one of the many restaurants in the village for a bite. Kids enjoy it as well

Well worth your time. If you would enjoy viewing 15th through 18th century French paintings, furniture and armor in a beautifully maintained Georgian town house, this site is definitely for you. I took the Tube to a very active Bond Street and walked several blocks before turning onto a side street leading to Manchester Square. Once I turned the corner, I was in a different world for there were few people or cars in this 18th century garden square in the Marylebone area. Hertford House is a beautifully maintained red brick mansion. The extensive collection is called the Wallace Collection. Besides viewing the impressive collection, it was a very pleasant experience seeing it displayed in such a beautiful setting. The visit was also very easy on the pocketbook for the admission is free.

Hidden Away. This is a gem of a collection, rather off the beaten track but close to Baker Street and Marylebone HIgh Street.
Once again it is free, it's not huge but there are imressive colledtions of porcelain, furniture, daggers and paintings.
Definitely feels like a family home.

An eclectic treasure trove.. I just love this place - favourite discoveries: The Laughing Cavalier and also Rembrandts's self portrait which is displayed at such a perfect height that you feel you've gone back in time and met him face to face. There is a great armoury room too with armour for horses as well as men. The café is lovely but expensive - such a beautiful, light setting. There are children's discovery trails to do. Be warned though that most things on display are within children's reach and tempting to touch but it's a no-touch zone!

a beautiful collection. Wonderful building, with so many fascinating collections. You could spend ages wandering each room. Go along for one of their 1-hour talks and you will see things so differently.I particularly love the Sevres display.And this is all available on a donation only basis. Amazing.Great courtyard restaurant.
A gem just off Oxford Street. After the mayhem of Oxford Street this is a haven full of interesting paintings and objects, especially 18th century. A good cafe restaurant too.
A gem of a place. This hidden museum, just behind Selfridges is worth a visit. Great object d'art and lovely restaurant and bar at the back. Small, but so very interesting.
My favourite small collection. So easy to get round with its eclectic mix of exhibits. Home of the Laughing Cavalier & so much more it's a MUST. Lovely atrium cafe.

A little seen treasure. This lovely little museum is a rare treasure.
