Like a hidden gem, right near Oxford Street, it is not on the main path for museum visitors, yet it houses some of the most amazing collections in London! Be sure to see the collection of rare old erotic postcards, the armory and the furniture and nick-nacks from Marie Antoinette

Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection lives in a beautifully elegant period house in Manchester Square - just north of London's Selfridges store. It has one of the most beautiful collections of period art and furniture and is a delightful way to spend a few hours in relatively crowd-free surroundings admiring exquisite art.
A bite size house with lovely art. An easy to tour and view a unique collection of beautiful paintings, furniture, pottery. Lovely restaurant.

A hidden gem. I'm always surprised that the Wallace Collection isn't better known and more widely visited by tourists. It's a real treasure house - and it has an excellent restaurant in what used to be the garden.
Elegent Place for Coffee/Tea. In the centre of this building is an amazing restaurant/cafe with a glass atrium roof and seems to be where the aristocracy hang out.
Wallace Collection. The building is well maintained, there is a lot of paintings but the best one is "The swing". After that, wall around the area, is great or go shopping to Oxford Street

A hidden gem. Or possibly, a hidden gem a lot of people manage to find! An old mansion belonging to the Marquesses of Hertford and then bought by Sir Richard Wallace, the ilegitimate son of the fourth Marquess. All great collectors, so a family collection, not a curators' one. Fantastic display of armour, some stunning paintings. The Laughing Cavalier. Fragonard's The Swing. Watteau. Poussin's A Dance to the Music of Time. Sheer quality. And it's free. Hidden away north of Oxford Street and Bond Street, so if you've had enough shopping, drop in and see the Cavalier. And the Poussin. And whatever else takes your fancy, but don't miss those two.
Art Lovers. I went there some years go. OK if you are in the area and can do it without a detour especially if art is your thing

A compact collection to visit. The Wallace Collection is an excellent compact collection in a fine building. It's iconic centrepiece is of course "The Laughing Cavalier" by Franz Hals but there is far more to see as well. Situated just off Oxford Street a visit cab be combined with some shopping if you are pushed for time on a visit to London.

Hidden Gem. This is one on London's smaller museums, conveniently tucked away round the back of Selfridges. It has an eclectic collection of art, furniture and collectibles. The highlight for me is the armour collection, complete with several full suits of armour including that for horses. It is a fantastic place to go and escape the mayhem of Oxford Street.
best of traditional art. great collection in a beautiful space. Only takes around 45 minutes and there is great food at the end
Lovely setting for lunch. Had a delicious lunch here, really nice setting, staff were great and the food was amazing, recommended highly.

So many things to see. The Wallace Collection can be found in a fantastic "mansion" situated in Manchester Square just behind Selfridges on Oxford Street. The building is crammed with all sorts of items from jewellery to armour and weapons, porcelain, magnificent furniture and hundreds of paintings including many by Canaletto. To do the collection justice you would need to spend hours and hours however if like us you were short on time it is possible to have a quick look round but allow at least 1 hour 30 mins. There is no entrance fee (donations welcome) nor tour guides but you can hire an audio guide should you require more info. At the moment one of the larger galleries is shut for renovation. There is also a very nice cafe/restaurant situated in the inner courtyard although we did not take advantage of this. All in all a very interesting visit with quite a few recognisable paintings (mainly pre 1800) including the "Laughing Cavalier". Well worth a visit and a lovely place to get away from the crowds and shopping!

"Old stuff" worth visiting. This private collection is not really a museum, but definitely worth a visit. The restaurant is very nice as well, but you should book a table in advance or you'll probably have to wait.At our visit some parts were not opened due to renovation, but there was still enough to see to spend 2 or more hours there!

A perfect gem. Possibly London's best kept secret, this wonderful gallery takes more than one visit to appreciate. The last time I went I spent an hour in just one room, looking at the collection of Canalettos. Paintings by Dutch artists are very well represented and really worth examining closely. The armour and weapons are fascinating too and I haven't even started on the furniture or china yet. That'll be another couple of visits. Wonderful!

What a collection!. This mansion house is crammed with all sorts of interesting items - paintings (Hals, Rubens, Gainsborough, among many others), fantastic chandeliers, marquetry desks, early painted book pages, jewellery, armour.....and so very, very much more. It's brilliant (although you wouldn't want to have to dust it, as my mum used to say).

Lovely..and Free!. The Wallace has a gorgeous collection of porcelain and fine old paintings. Leave at least an hour to take a look. We went to the reasonably priced restaurant on the first floor for tea and found it a peaceful, pleasant respite.
Wonderful museum. Set in a beautiful former residence, the museum houses some wonderful works of art. The courtyard has a lovely, bright restaurant. Definitely worth a visit.

London's Frick Collection. A townhouse museum left by a wealthy person at the turn of the 20th Century makes the Wallace Collection the London equivalent of New York City's Frick Collection. Worth a visit.

Great for a lazy afternoon. Good mix of somewhere lovely to eat and some interesting history. Tucked away you might not find it - but definitely worth checking out - It's in a great square just off Oxford Street.

a great national exhibition in heart of London. This amazing collection was left to the nation and is well worth a visit. Situated just behind Oxford St it is easy to get to. There is a great care for afternoon tea and some evenings it is open for dinner
Art and Tea. The best tea room in London that awaits you after seeing the great art and collectibles of the Wallace Collection.
Superb lunch location. this is the perfect place to meet friends for lunch. We like the atmosphere, the location and the menu is interesting and reliable

Best hidden gem of london. A great historic house, free to visit and enjoy and not crowded like many others. Just. Behind Selfridges and amazing collection of Treasures including furniture, armoury, art and wonderful building and staff. Whole family enjoyed our visit aged 6-46 .
Lovely Collection. A lovely collection of art, displayed in a gorgeous Georgian townhouse (aka mansion!) A little off the beaten path, but worth the effort.

Amazing collection of art - a steal with free entry!. Unbelievable collection of art and artefacts (armoury, sculptures, furniture - some belonging to Marie Antoinette, porcelain etc) including pieces by Rubens, Canaletto, Gainsborough and Van Dyke in a beautiful mansion which has been preserved wonderfully. The jewel in the crown (although many may dispute this) is undoubtedly the painting 'The Swing' by Fragonard - which inspired the art animation in Disney's 'Tangled', as well as making a cameo in animated form in Disney's Frozen. I visited with no expectations and was blown away by the quality of pieces in there, as well as the interiors of the mansion itself, and could not believe it was free entry. The restaurant also looks charming, as well as the private garden across the street which was lovely in full bloom. This is definitely a hidden gem in the heart of London and certainly underrated. If you are keen on viewing art by a range of masters, as well as having a peek at the interiors of a stately british home from a past era, this is for you. Leave the little ones at home though, they may find it a bit boring (but they might find the extensive armory and weapons collection thrilling).
beautiful, also 2nd time round. intimate, yet spacious, this beautiful collection in the middle of the city feels like a private visit to one's home.

One of the best atractions in London. Very nice and big collection of art. Many good paintings and collections of old furniture, pieces of art, of several things. Very nice house decorated accordingly. I can just recomend it.

Small Museum, Lovely Restaurant Atmosphere, Average Service. This is a compact museum with a lovely beautiful restaurant for tea or lunch. We had a late lunch at the restaurant and found the service lacking. We had a hard time finding something on the menu that our 10 year old would like. I would try it again for tea.

A wonderful discovery!. We had been meaning to visit this wonderful collection for several years and we are so pleased we finally managed it yesterday. The quality of the collections in each room were all exceptional. I was a little disappointed that some of the rooms are undergoing some essential works, but where else in the world can you visit these museums for free and marvel at the way the families have put together these extraordinary objects?

Superb art collection. I enjoyed this fabulous art collection (1797 to 1897), crammed with fabulous artworks. The sheer volume and diversity of the collection requires several visits. Hertford house itself is worth a visit. The Wallace restaurant is very pleasant, although the food is average.

Beautiful private collection and museum. While we were vacationing in London we were told "you got to go see the wallace collection" So our second day in London we hailed a cab and went Manchester square to go see the wallace collection. As luck would have it we were just in time for a guided tour. Let me just say that our tour guide was top notch. He had a vast knowledge of this extensive private collection. There were many questions asked and he was able to answer each one while taking time to explain in detail all the beautiful things throughout the tour. I must say that I was very happy to be so lucky to have been able to have the privilege of seeing this beautiful collection.

One of the top museums in London. In a city overflowing with great, free museums, the Wallace continuously shines as one of the best. It is on our list every time a friend comes in from out of town - we go 5-6 times a year. First, call and book a table for late lunch (2:15 or so) in the atrium courtyard. Even on on a cold day it feels summery. Hit the museum a bit in advance of the 1pm guided tour to have a quick browse, do the one hour tour - it is different every time depending upon the guide and what they feel like chatting about that day. Food is lovely, setting superb, then you can see more of the collection or move on. And if the men in the group are tired of pairings, it has of the greatest collections of arms and armour anywhere.

Gem of London. I'm a New York City tour guide on vacation in London. The Frick Collection is my favorite museum in New York so naturally I always wanted to visit the Wallace Collection. The Wallace Collection is located in a fine manor home in Manchester Square. The Collection is free to enter and there are two tours of the highlights at 11:00'AM and 2:30 PM respectively. The Marquesses Hertford (pronounced like Hartford, Connecticut) spent five generations amassing the fine art, objet d'art, and furniture. The tour guide was superb. Imagine a social X-Ray in chic Chanel with a French accent appearing to be a curator at Sotheby's who volunteers her time at the Wallace Collection in an attempt to educate Philistines. She had more class in her pinky than I'll ever have. At one point after she casually discoursed on fine lacquer techniques I asked, "Everything is so perfect and exquisite but the floors are rather plain. Were they added later in a renovation by the conservators?" I stumped her but an assistant came forward with books showing originally there was a lot of carpeting. Then the patient guide went on to illustrate some delicate craftsmanship on a secretary. Another American stepped up behind me and whispered, "Thanks for asking. We were wondering what's up with the floors too." Photos without flash or click are allowed! Bring those I-Phones. If you love French Art and furniture design with an emphasis on Rococo and French Regency this place is for you. Kids will be bored to death. This is probably not a family visit. I used the Central Line (red) to Bond Street. Walk about four blocks west on Oxford Street and make a right turn up Duke Street. It's a five minute walk to Manchester Sq.

A stunning gem in the heart of London. Spent a fabulous couple of hours here whilst en route to an appointment. Well we were both blown away. Free entry into a stunning collection of artwork and collections that will leave you opened mouthed. Warm and friendly welcome and worth buying the guide for £6 and use that to wander the gorgeous rooms. Didn't use the restaurant within the house to be fair so can't comment on prices or service but if you are in town go here.

Interesting look into private home and collection. I was thrilled to find that I had arrived just in time for the guided museum highlights tour. The guide was extremely well versed and we learned quite a lot about the time period, the family and the pieces in the collection. We spent some time afterward wandering the collection and it made for a very nice afternoon. Highly recommended if you have some free time!

Must view. Had the benefit of a private tour which can be arranged and is well worth it. Stunning collection of paintings which I had not really appreciated over the years until this guided visit. Living just a mile away my mind was opened by this great visit. Good and inexpensive food also available. Oxford Street shopping 5 minutes away

Afternoon Tea. Lovely place. Took my mom for afternoon tea while she was visiting me in town. Sophisticated but relaxed atmosphere in Wallace Collection is definitely a great way to spend the afternoon.

Hidden Gem. Suggested as a part of a day in London, this sensational find is one we could have spent all day in. Words cannot describe the beauty and elegance to be found inside, We live in Oxford and visit the Ashmolean often, the Wallace Collection is certainly on a par. One astonishing room after another, capped by finding myself looking at the 'Laughing Cavalier', no glass screens or unsightly security just simply in a corner of a room. If you like art and history this is a must see. Lovely restaurant, not cheap but high quality. The toilets are the nicest I've ever visited!

Exquisite. This collection truly was the highlight of my London trip. Room after room of old, beautiful paintings from the Rococo era, highly decorative furniture, jewellery and ornaments, rooms full of preserved armour and weapons, it's a feast for the eyes. Each room is as lush and as ornate as the last, I took my time wandering through them and soaking up all it had to offer and I still feel as though I want to go back for a second visit. Entry to the Wallace Collection is free, and boasts a fantastic little gift shop.After you've spent time observing all these treasures you can go into the Wallace Restaurant- beautiful food and exceptionally friendly customer service, this will be a place I make sure to try and visit again.
Outstanding. My Dad first brought me here when I was little and I've been coming back every since. A stunning collection, always something to amaze you.

Fabulous Museum. A real little gem in a quiet backstreet of London. Beautiful re-furbished rooms, wonderful paintings. A little bit of everything. Fabulous café - but a little expensive. Highly recommend a visit.

Fabulous Gallery. I had heard about this gallery from friends and finally made it in. We took a free tour (check the website for start times and arrive early during peak tourist season as there are limited places on the tour). Our guide was so knowledgeable and interested in what she was talking about it made it very educational and entertaining. A free gallery gifted to the people is a gem of a find in the City. I had booked in for an afternoon tea as a birthday treat, and it started as soon as our tour finished, I will have to return to see a bit more of the gallery. Book in for afternoon tea there for after your tour...it is AMAZING!

Staff make a difference. The Wallace collection is impressive and free to view, though make sure to come without any midsized bags or larger if possible. The paintings are worth the journey and if you are lover of all things gold, as well as the rococo movement then you best come see these exquisite pieces. Artists of all walk should appear, but be warned stay away from the staff as they are notoriously pretentious, rude and fairly ignorant in terms of their actual job. Most take a rather snobbish approach to the concept of tourists and basic civil pleasantries as I heard one member of staff scolding an elderly lady about her walking stick and that she should probably check it the coatroom when it is quite obvious this women was simply using as the crutch it is and she would have been unable to tour the building without it. A great collection that should score higher, but staff do indeed make the difference.

Beautiful and free. A hidden gem just of Oxford Street. Beautiful house and contents. Staff friendly and helpful. Afternoon tea in the Courtyard was lovely and only £17.50 per head. Would highly recommend. Only negative would be the gift shop is on the expensive side. Would be nice for some less exclusive lines.

Rude staff . I came on a Saturday with a friend and inquired about the free guided tour, only to be told that there is only one ticket left. I said to the lady in a friendly way that does it really matter if one more person comes along, as it's just myself and a friend - and she responded and said no in a very rude way and told me that if I had read the website properly it says they only have 25 tickets for the tour and that maybe we should come back sometime during the week instead. We said fair enough and went for a walk around the building on our own. As it was a warm day and I was thirsty from walking around, I had a bottle of juice that I took out of my bag. Immediately I was approached by one of the staff members saying "Excuse me! What are you drinking?" In a loud voice and made me show him the bottle only to say that no soft drinks are allowed inside the house. I did not feel welcome on my first trip to the Wallace Collection, and although the building and it's interior is fairly impressive I wouldn't recommend anybody to go.

a hidden little gem of art and porcelain. A beautiful house to visit with free admission! The cloakroom was very handy for my coat while I explored the treasures contained in this beautiful house. I purchased an audio guide, very informative on the major pieces. The porcelain was gorgeous! The rooms upstairs were sumptuous! I wish I'd spent longer there.

Excellent and free. Situated just off Oxford Street in Manchester Square in a beautiful building. There is an excellent display of Sevres porcelain, furnishings and a variety of paintings including several miniatures. There is a lovely cafe in an enclosed courtyard and a cloakroom to leave any coats and bags so you can enjoy your visit to the full.

Fabulous in the true sense of the word. Visited this stunning collection yesterday for the first time despite living in London all my life! We loved the whole experience - a fantastic collection overflowing in this beautifully maintained house. We had no idea of the scale of the treasures to be seen here and literally gasped at the beauty and scale of the collection, particularly the miniatures and the snuff boxes. And it's free, with the opportunity to have tea in a lovely setting afterwards. What more could anyone want? Our visit actually made me less unhappy about paying income tax!

Fairly interesting, even for those not mad about art. There is a variety of artwork on display in the Wallace Collection, including furniture, ceramics, paintings and weaponry. Not a huge amount of any of them compared to places such as the V&A or national gallery, but its good to have the mixture within a relatively compact building. In each room there are leaflets/folders containing a few pages of commentary/guidance which helped explain the exhibits. I particularly liked the horse armour, and the bronze frieze (in the basement). Now I want to go back for a longer visit with my wife, to try a guided tour and perhaps sample the cafe food and drink.

Fabulous Gallery. We took a free tour and the guides were so knowledgeable an interested in what they were talking about it made it very educational and entertaining. Book in for afternoon tea there for after your tour...it is AMAZING!

A Hidden Treasure. Just a 2 minute walk from Bond street underground station, The Wallace collection is an amazing collection of art, porcelain, furniture and Armour.It is more akin to a stately home than a museum,I used the the audio guide which was very informative. The staff were all very pleasant, I will be returning,as you can not do the collection justice in one visit

Fine art dining. Looking for a different experience then why not try lunch at Wallace Collection. What I love about this restaurant is it sits in the middle of an art gallery so pre or post lunch you can wander through the gallery and take in a little culture. The building is stunning and the restaurant sits in a glass covered atrium so you get the feeling of being outside yet not exposed to the unpredictable English weather.
wonderful place. a very good collection of art works and armor and a very nicestaff ,so very pleasant ,makes for a lovely visit.. i would returnanytime.

Great looking cafe and perfect for afternoon tea. Go here if you are in London - it is a cafe attached to a free museum and its beautiful. Its in a courtyard surrounded on all sides by the museum and covered with a glass ceiling. I would describe the food as above average and service is ok but go here for the surroundings and ambience.
Beautiful house and very interesting. The furniture and art is amazing. A great place to go on a rainy day, or any day. Its central location makes it an easy visit for most tourists.
Excellent. An absolute must, tucked away behind busy Oxford Street, this oasis of calm and fascination is a real treasure.

Wonderful space, shame about the invigilator.. I was blown away by this museum (though it felt more like visiting someone's extremely opulent home). It's a real treasure trove as well as a wonderful escape from the madness of Oxford Street. Unfortunately my visit was marred by a dour-looking female invigilator with a very brusque manner who barked at me not to touch the furniture when I had merely brushed it with my coat and there had been no notice asking visitors not to touch the item in question anyway. I have to say however that the rest of the staff we encountered were all very pleasant and courteous, and if it hadn't been for the ill-mannered invigilator I would have scored the experience a 5 out of 5. However there is so much to see and the place is so beautiful that this by no means will stop me from returning.

Well worth a visit. Stocked full of interesting art and artifacts. This a little treasure off the beaten track. It has an interesting looking cafe - it was full when we went. Give yourself plenty of time as there is a lot to see and take in. We shall be revisiting.

A refreshing visit. I have't been to the Wallace collection for a while,and it was a delight to go and meet my niece,who is studying art history at the Cortauld,for lunch(which,incidentally is very good).It is always good to. Take a tour with someone who has knowledge and love of their subject.the collection is wonderful and while we were looking at a fragernot,the envigilator volunteered a history of the painting.Absoloutly brilliant delivery and content!A pleasure to share the knowledge and enthusiasm.A wonderful place to visit for everyone,and eat.
Fantastic collection of porcelain. A great visit especially the one room full of beautiful porcelain. The restaurant/café is very good here as well. Well worth a visit as its free to get in.

Opulence and Art. A beautiful house at the back of Selfridges with exquisite rooms. Just the décor and curtains are worth the visit apart from the actual art on display. Specialist exhibitions are held regularly and the restaurant is airy and pleasant.

Totally Unexpected. What a gem. Something for everybody and free. The collection was well laid out and some unexpected masterpieces. All of this for free. Take children there is a good armoury collection and there was a talk given to schoolchildren. Many thanks

Awful. I had one of the worst afternoons of my life here. If you enjoy repetitive collections of armour, bad 17th 18th century generic European oil paintings, and gaudy large ceramics in an expensive tasteless setting this is right up your boulevard...

Interesting gem, only ten minutes from Selfridges. A lot to see and do. Some of the displays were over the top but you could spend spend hours here. I probably preferred some of the smaller collections on the ground floor and the workshop downstairs was very accessible. Good interpretation friendly guides. Posh but fine cafe, restaurant posh and expensive but staff were lovely. It's free so everyone should visit, at least once

Fabulous collection of art and furniture in a lovely rowhouse.. I wandered into the Wallace Collection while killing time one afternoon in London. Wow, am I happy that I did. The house itself is stunning. The gorgeous entryway leads into what is such an architecturally beautiful space, it is hard to describe. Then the exhibits themselves are top notch. Art, antiques, porcelain, armor -- the Wallace Collection has it all. The docents that work there are so friendly and helpful - and the museum has binders with explanations for many of the objects in each room. Truly worth the visit, especially since it is free. In fact, I bet you will enjoy it so much that you will want to a small donation on the way out.

The Wallace Collection in a word SUPERB. Well wort a visit a FREE to enter stately home in the middle of London.Good selection of exhibits from paintings, porcelain, furniture to suits of armour.The highlights tour does just what it says on the tin and comes highly reccomended.The toilets are suberb!........

London's Great Treasure House. What a cornucopia of great artworks,antique furnishings, ancient arms, miniatures , superlative gold boxes etc etc. You can visit this museum in Manchester Square a dozen times and still not have seen everything they display. A must for anyone interested in the finer things of life,And they have a wonderful restaurant in the atrium.!

One of Top 10 Museums in London. I've been to London many times before, and I don't know how I've missed going there before. It's a small museum with private collection, but the townhouse itself is an art and has very interesting story behind it. Most items exhibited there came from France, but there are items from other parts of the world including Asia. If you visit, I highly recommend that you join a free guided tour, which was very informative and filled with interesting stories, it made the visit much more special. http://www.wallacecollection.org

Lovely collection of paintings and antiques. This is a small museum that houses the collection of four generations of marquesses. As such, it represents their tastes and isn't necessarily professionally curated. There are some really nice paintings here from big names like Velazquez, Ruebens, Rembrandt, Boucher and Fragonard. I am not an antiques expert at all, but there were handy and informative books in every room explaining all the pieces (including armor!), so if that is your thing, you could easily read up on it. It's free and close to Oxford Street (near Selfridge's), so if you're in the area, it's definitely worth a visit. There was a nice courtyard where you could eat too if you want to combine the visit with lunch.

Don't miss the Wallace. This was our second visit to the Wallace Collection and home. We went on a docent led highlights tour which was excellent. They possess some of the best art like the Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals but not that many tourists know about it. The have a beautiful covered courtyard where we had lunch. Excellent food and great service too.

Wallace Collection - One of the World's finest small art museums. The Wallace Collection is one of the world's finest small museums, with an outstanding assortment of art treasures from the 15th to 19th centuries, housed in the historic Hertford House. Here you can see truly wonderful artworks, an exquisite holding of 18th century French paintings, furniture and armour as well as a large holding of Old Master paintings. The majority of the Wallace Collection treasures was accumulated by Richard Seymour-Conway, who left the entire house and its contents to his illegitimate son Sir Richard Wallace, for which this museum takes it name. In 1897, Lady Wallace then bequeathed the property and art collection to the nation, with the simple conditions that the collection be left as it was, nothing added or removed, even on temporary loan. At that time, this was considered the single greatest bequest of art treasure to the nation. The museum was opened to the public in 1900 and has been free to visit since that time. We recently visited the Wallace Collection and participated in one of their free tours. This was an absolute treat. In addition to the remarkably items seen throughout the building galleries, we were treated to a rich history lesson about Mr Richard Seymour-Conway and how he acquired the many items, the stewardship of Sir Richard and Lady Wallace and how the collection came to be bequeathed to the nation. This was a marvellous lesson and highly recommendable experience for anyone with an appreciation for fine art and museum visits. Unfortunately the Great Gallery where Old Master collection is found is presently closed for much needed refurbishments. It is scheduled to reopen sometime in 2014, much to the delight of future visitors of the museum. Many of the works of art normally shown here have been redistributed through the museum so that you can enjoy them. Hint: There is a small gift shop where you can pick up a souvenir or art book. There is also a courtyard restaurant if you are interested in having a rest for food and drink. Tip: The Wallace Collection has a well designed website that provides information about the property and history of the collection. You can also find details about the galleries and treasures on display at the Hereford House.

A Superb Lesser Known Gallery. I once lived near to the building that houses The Wallace Collection. I used to nip in there every time I had a spare hour. I grew to love the place. It has a friendly, real-world feel about it. Like it's still someone's house. It's so much nicer to look at art in a place like this.

Really nice art collection. The museum is just about the right size for spending a pleasant afternoon there, enabling you to see it all in peace and quiet. It seems a bit hidden away, and there is not a lot of people - which is a bit of a surprise given the great collection.

Visiting the Wallace Collection. An relatively unknown art collection just behind Oxford Street. A marvellous collection well worth seeing with some really fantastic master paintings. Wonderful restaurant and coffee bar to relax and have a meal it just a coffee, excellent service.

A Must See! Exquisite, Beautiful, Overwhelmingly so. So much beauty to take in! Rembrandts, Gainsboroughs, Rubens and so many more priceless paintings, sculptures and artifacts in a very special museum in a home setting. The home itself is an exquisite place reminiscent of Downton Abbey opulence and style. You must see the Wallace Collection. It is possible to simple visit for an hour or so to get a taste of this very special place.
Wonderful. Lots of collections to see, easily reachable by tube and helpful staff. You can spend more than 3 hours here and there are really impressive collections.

Charming hidden gem. We often visit Manchester Square and enjoy seeing the Laughing Cavalier and Dance to the music of time. If you've got kids they'll love the spectacular armour. Superior cakes and sandwiches in the lovely atrium (Oliver Peyton I think?) Lovely place hidden off Oxford St . a must!!

Amazing art collection !. You may think you've seen a lot of these paintings before (Laughing Cavalier, barmaid at the Folies Bergere etc) on everything from birthday cards to table mats but in 'real life' all the paintings are stunningly different.The house is a comfortable size to get round and it's never so crowded you can't see the paintings.A real treat.

imagine a glorious bygone age. this is the place to escape the maddening hoards on oxford street and get up close and personal to some amazing pieces of art. if you can get hear for one of the evening showings by candle light you understand better the why and how of the paintings for thats how they should of been seen.and dont forget to have a tea experience and discuss what you've seen before heading back to the modern world
I love this place. Lovely place for coffee or a glass of wine and have a look around. Very relaxing but interesting, and it has never been too crowded when I have been here.

Hidden Gem, don't miss it!. I am thankful that this family house is free and open to the public, it is a feast to the eyes. Amazing collections which includes: pictures and miniatures from different eras; armours which belongs to Medieval times to Islamic and Chinese times; furniture that is a work of art; sculptures; colourful handmade ceramics and works of art like jewelery boxes. It is exquisite! Make sure you eat properly because you will need all the energy you have to wander around the place. It would take 2-3 hours to actually enjoy every little detail there. Get off Bond Street tube station and walk to it, takes around 10 minutes. It is truly a hidden gem and I highly recommend it.

Great collection. Visited for the first time recently and was very impressed by the collection. The rooms are spectacularly laid out and a pleasure to wander through. Lunch at the cafe was good too. Yet another amazing free museum in London!
Excellent collection to visit.. Free entry ! Central London. Lovely cafe/restaurant inside. Very interesting historical collection. Well worth a visit.
Magnificent collection. Well worth a visit. Very helpful staff who are on hand to talk, point out best points and explain the history and provenance

Hidden gem. This is a lovely, free, attraction situated on Manchester Square, just behind Selfridges on Oxford Street.Compared with the Kensington Museums and the National/ Tate galleries, this is very bijou....but the artifacts are displayed beautifully, intelligently and one can drift from room to wonderful room. In truth one could do justice to the whole building in a couple of hours....but, if you were to look closely under the covers, or have a specific interest in say porcelain or jewel boxes, you could easily spend all day there. You don't need the stamina of a Roman legionary to walk round...it is small and intimate..personally, I love graphic art, so for me the highlights were the Gainsboroughs, Fragonard, Rembrandt and, the start of the show, Fras Hals' Laughing cavalier.Although I have some reservations about the cafe/ restaurant (I have commented separately) its location is delightful and for a quick cuppa and cake/ snack (not a full meal!!) it is worth a visit.I have awarded four stars as not all the rooms were open....but I'll be visiting later this year and know I will again be thrilled by this hidden gem.
Pride & Prejudice?. Stunning and very impressive find in London. Must see! Just makes you a happier person. The pink walls are so beautiful and amazing. Its just a great place to be at.
Bit of a hidden gem. Amazing place just behind Oxford Street with a good collection of historic art, set in a fantastic building complete with period furniture and features.

ITS FREE. And it's right near to Selfridges. The art and other items in this collection are top notch and very interesting. It's a wonderful building and well worth a visit. The tea room if you can get a booking is adorable

Great place but don't stop for tea. This is a really interesting gallery even if the wallpaper makes you feel you've wandered into 'Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas' but DO NOT venture to the cafe especially if pressed for time. I have let hope triumph over experience on many occasions as the setting is lovely but they need a self service as they are beyond slow and careless.. things ordered just don;t appear and it is expensive.
Oasis with great food. Having been to see the galleries before, it was the first time my girlfriend and I booked to eat there. Excellent food and service. Look forward to visiting again.

It's Great: if 18th century French rococo is your taste. I find it interesting that most of the other reviews are along the lines of: 'it's great! it's wonderful! you'll love it!' My take on it is: well, you MIGHT love it - but only if your taste runs to 18th century French rococo - or is it baroque? (can never keep those 2 straight). In any event, keep in mind that this is, strictly speaking, the Wallace 'Collection', not the 'Museum': it's what one family liked to collect... and what they liked was lots of Sevres porcelain, those little spindly chairs, tables with lots of marquetry and chests and armoires heaped out the wazoo with that gilded stuff.The art collection also veers heavily to the 18th century, but you will see some great Van Dycks and Rembrandts, as well as English painters of the century, including some lovely portraits by the usual suspects: Reynolds, etc. Guided tours are given regularly, and do an excellent job of putting the collection in context and giving an appreciation for some of the objects you might otherwise overlook.For those who are not particular fans of the rococo/baroque, you might still be enchanted by their outdoor restaurant/tea room. The space is covered in glass - you have the wonderful pleasure of sitting outside in the middle of winter. Great for afternoon tea, particularly if you are weary from Oxford Street shopping. (note though, that the restaurant closes at @ 4;30, so best not to leave your tea drinking until too late).As others have noted, this is an incredibly tranquil spot, just a short 5 minute walk from the Bond St. tube and the hurly-burly shopping area. It is well worth a visit, even a short one, (easy to drop in/out because it is free) and gives you the feeling of knowing about a secret hideaway.

the wallace collection. one of the nicest small museums...the restaurant is expensive but i usually have a light lunch sitting outside in the sun.there are some exquisite items and paintings.the menu looks good but i have neverveaten there ...
Highly recommend. This very interesting collection is well worth a visit. Absolutely amazing quantity and quality of exhibits. The coffee/cakes there also very good.

Wonderful Dining Experience. My husband and i wouldn't have known about the Wallace Collection if it wasn't for our local relatives. A very interesting museum to visit and the restaurant is a hidden gem! The day we visited, the sun was shining through the glass ceiling of the restaurant, we drank delicious PIMS, and had a wonderful meal, all making for a memorable visit to the Wallace Collection. Thank you.

A must see!!!. Hidden behind one of london's busiest streets the Wallace collection is amazing. 5 minute walk from bond street this is a mix of amazing art, furniture and culture. You are simply blown away by how amazing the collection is and how well it is presented. The staff is friendly and helpful and if you think that it used to be someones house its even more amazing.

Don't miss this at all.. Another wet day activity. What a beautiful collection, one of the best I've ever seen. You must make time to go and see this. plenty of comfortable seating areas too. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Outstanding...

Interesting museum in Baker Street. Free entrance very interesting art and armour artefacts curators were helpful and friendly, but the shop was awful expensive that's we're they get you!!!! We left a donation in the box
A short visit. A verry interesting and nice place to spend some time. A good place to learn and admire the old but luxurious way of life .
Interesting museum. Pretty sure this was free entry....interesting and not so crowded as the more well known museums in our great city. Worth a visit

Stunning. This has got to be one of the best things to see in London and my only regret is that I did not see it sooner. The house itself, the decor, the furniture, the armoury and the objets d'art throughout are all in pristine condition and beautifully presented. The lighting is unobtrusive but very effective and everything is accessible with no barriers to separate visitor from artefact. The highlight was the guided tour. Our female guide was clear, humorous, characterful and factual. She made the experience educational and enjoyable. Visiting the house and taking the tour are both free of charge but that has not biased my review. Highly recommended.

A treasure ...... Tucked away just behind Selfrige's .... charging no entry fee....and yet housing one of the best collections of armour you will find anywhere ....all beautifully documented in their magnificent published catalogues sold in their shop as well as online : "must-haves" for anyone interested armour. They have other collections on display as well - including an impressive selection of paintings and furniture.....to be explored as you wander from one gorgeous room, through to another.....
Very informative. Well worth a visit. Very interesting collection. I couldn't see everything in one visit but will definitely return.

What a collection. We visited one morning with only a vague idea of what to expect. We were certainly not disappointed. The collection contains hundreds of paintings (including the Laughing Cavalier) and hundreds of other items, like furniture, armour and weapons. There is just so many beautiful things to see. The house itself is also very stunning. There is a beautiful courtyard restaurant for those who wish to spend longer. And to top it all off, entrance is free. What is not to like? Do not miss this fabulous collection.

Lovely little museum off the beaten path. A London townhouse converted into a small museum- mainly the collections of a titled family. European art, a large arms and armor collection, miniatures, etc. Restaurant in an atrium area. About a five minute walk from Selfridges. Free admission.

The perfect afternoon culture & tea treat. The house entrance is free and you can wonder around looking at the great art and furniture and then relax in the indoor courtyard restaurant and have tea. The service and treats were lovely.
Great venue. The venue is great - light and relaxed. It is quite pricey for what it delivers. My light lunch was very small.

Completely Beautiful. I'd visited the Wallace collection back in 2007 on a school-led trip. It always stuck in my mind as a place I'd love to take a day and revisit, and I finally did last month! I had four hours there and it still wasn't enough to really take in what this collection has to offer. Personally, I think it's best to explore alone and at your own pace (especially if you're like me and always have your sketchbook handy). Besides the hundreds of beautiful items and paintings, the house is an attraction in itself. If you're a fan of interior design or historic architecture, I'm sure you'll appreciate the beauty of the house alone.

An unusual set of armour, antiquities and paintings. This museum is the result of one very wealthy man's interests and collecting habits. Consequently the museum has excellence in a few categories as well as a few one-off gems that appear unexpectedly.The armour collection is fantastic and if you are interested in medieval armour then this will be something you will always remember. Interestingly NASA came to this museum to study the joints on the various different types of armour, through the centuries, to get ides for how to build the (knee, elbow, neck, etc) joints on their space suits. They also have the Laughing Cavalier painting here, which is something I had seen copied in advertising and in popular culture but had never seen the original. This is a museum that will stimulate your intellectual curiosity. It also has a great cafe where you could have a romantic meeting.
Outstanding collection... Well worth a 2 hour visit, fascinating. Beautiful ex-residence full of wonderful art gems. There's a very good restaurant, The Wallace Restaurant, on the premises.

A great selection of classical art in a beautiful stylish setting.. Wallace Collection is one of the best hidden gems of London classical art galleries scene. Some great masterpieces in the collection including some Rembrands and Reynolds, shown in the opulent setting of this very stylish elegant building just behind the very full on noisy Oxford Street, 2 minutes from Selfridges. The central courtyard with its covered glass canopy has an elegant light and airy cafe for a tasty cake break.
Lovely Gallery. Very good historic gallery with lots of wonderful art pieces and a full armory downstairs. Quite the sight!

Brilliant. Free to enter, and a sumptious venue. Dozens of the best painters and well known picture, with a luxurious setting. We spent a couple of hours and only saw part of it. We will be back, spending longer next time and will have lunch in the attractive cafe

Take the tour it's incredible!. Take the tour it's incredible!Had a couple of friends come to London arriving at different times on a Saturday, so instead of going to the pub, we decided to see the Wallace Collection to kill a couple of hours.As we entered a free tour was about to begin so we joined, and enjoyed an afternoon of amazing stories about this incredible collection.This is the sort of collection you put together when you have access to unlimited wealth and can plunder the world.When in London do not miss, it’s the greatest free day out, enjoy.

Cultural Treat. An absolute hidden gem, just off Oxford Street. The Wallace Collection is one of those small, manageable museums that one can dip in and out of, without feeling guilty of not visiting the whole collection. Very user friendly, beautiful restaurant and lots of courses on offer.

Sophisticated private collection, apart from usual touristic sites. I've heard about the Wallace Collection being a top attraction in London, from Tripadvisor. In fact, Wallace Lord bought part of his masterpieces from another collector and lady Wallace opened the museum more than 100 years ago. Most of the pieces there are extremely precious and leave you with no words! It's such a beautiful and exquisite art collection (Boucher, Velazques, complete armures from Xth century) all sheltered in a beautiful building, with large stairs, red carpet and valets at the entrance. It's simply amazing and going through those stairs towards the first floor, I felt like a princess!At ground-floor, you can leave your backpack or other stuff you don't need during your visit and be very careful on making pictures, as flash is forbidden. Get a good camera with you!

Inviting, worth seeing!. In London, you of course should see either the British Museum and/or the National Gallery, but in addition to these you should go and see this beautifull, small museum! Inviting, quiet, lavishly done. And a good shop!

Worth to visit. A beautiful private house full of treasures. The Watteau collection is already a delighting surprise and there is so much more to discover. Even if I am not a fan of 17th/18th century, I was impressed.
Wonderful place but avoid the restaurant. fabulous collection, eclectic, varied, spacious, civilised. The restaurant has the slowest worst service ever, avoid!

A hidden treat for free!. Not far from Oxford Street, The Wallace Collection is free and has a wonderful tea room with lovely food, although it is quite pricey. There are never too many people visiting so its an enjoyable wander. Beautiful paintings to view and Marie Antoinette's belongs are exquisite. I never expected to find these outside France.

Beautiful place, lots to see. If you want to spend 2-3 hours in a beautiful house with amazing pieces of art staring at you from virtually everywhere , Wallace museum is the place. Try a free tour, which is very informative and not too long.

I like this ace. Probably my favourite museum in London. The building is itself interesting, being a former residence, but it has lots of interesting exhibits and some really good artwork. There is a restaurant which is good for food and atmosphere. Well worth a visit and not far from shops either

Treasure trove. What an amazing place. A wide range of items, a lot of which is French, set out in gorgeously decorated and maintained rooms in this wonderful house.Check the website before you go to make sure you don't miss out on the free guided tours - well worth attending. Everything was free (even the cloakroom) so make sure you also make a donation! There is also a very good restaurant - it's a little pricey, but worth it for the ambience.

Dinner on friday; great food, staff,. The restaurant itself is worth a look but the food is good, original, well cooked and served. Tables are not close to each other; nice place for diner for two.Lunch is excellent but very crowded

Lovely. Nice collection, full of beautiful china and recently renovated. A new Cafe/Restaurant, book if a large group and you want to eat at
1.00. Near to Marylebone High Street so good shopping afterwards.

The best small museum in London. I love this museum. It has some real gems in the collection of 18th century French paintings, furniture, clocks, porcelain. It feels like a real house, as indeed it was, and the scale means that you can do it in one visit. To do it justice, though, several are recommended. Nice restaurant in the enclosed courtyard. A wonderful haven near the bustle of Oxford Street.

Fabulous place. The treasures in this beautiful house never tire and you can go over an do per again. There are fantastic paintings, beautiful furniture and stunning Sevres porcelain. A must if you are in London

Eclectic Collection and Beautiful House. The Wallace Collection was a welcome break from the typical large-scale museum. It is housed in the owner's home, a quick walk from the Marble Arch tube station. The collection is varied and eclectic; for me, that kept me from experiencing museum fatigue. The highlights were the armor, Marie Antoinette's items, the Dutch paintings and the guns. The fact that you get to walk through the rooms of the house was interesting as well. There is also a small, but lovely gift shop.

A treasure trove in the West End - and all for free. Paintings, porcelain, sculpture, furniture, armour, swords, weapons - this is an amazing cornucopia of treasures all amassed one collector family. The Wallace Collection is five minute's walk from Selfridges and yet worlds away from Oxford Street. If you're local (and because it's free) it's easy to pop in for a few minutes from day to day, to take in another room of delights. The shop has excellent 'different' gifts and souvenirs. There is also a lovely atrium restaurant/bistro which is very popular - booking is advised.

What a place, do visit!!!. I had been looking forward to finally visiting this museum...(i couldn't believe it was free)...the rooms were set out well....& everyone had something to catch your eye...lots of fantastic treasures...loved the paintings & was so pleased to see the 'Laughing Cavalier'...The Armory was brilliant & couldn't believe the size of this collection. Please do visit..wish we had been able to sit down in the central cafe, but it was closed early due to a private function.! I would return in the future & thoroughly recommend folks.....

A hidden jewel - great if you like decorative arts. The Wallace collection is one of my favorite places in London. Whether you are into paintings, miniatures, furniture, clocks, porcelain or armory, the collection has something for you. The free daily lectures on the history of the family, the winding of the clocks or specific works are very interesting. There is a cafe where you can get a sandwich or high tea. The prices are reasonable for London. And best of all, the museum is free - a big plus as London is a very expensive city!

A gem at a minute s walk from the Selfridges. The Wallace Collection is not a pretentious museum. It concerns the interior setting, art objects and collected items,for example Armors, paintings, porcelains, gathered through the years by  the families who actually lived in this magnificent old London house. Last but not least, a wonderful cafe and restaurant in the interior central courtyard. Not to be missed.
Romantic visit. I would highly recommend a visit to the Wallace collection. My boyfriend and I popped in on a rainy day and didn't want to leave. Very English but romantic somehow. Absolutely lovely
A world class collection. This collection was given to the nation over 100 years ago. It consists of a spectacular array of paintings, ceramics and furniture, all of international museum quality.

Wow. Thanks to trip advisor otherwise I would never have heard about this wonderful museum ........3 minute walk from selfridges , free to get in and an hours worth of stunning rooms ........ A must do !!!!
Quaint but impressive!. Enjoyed ourselves greatly at this quaint but impressive place! Not to be missed is also the cafe/restaurant inside. The Parisian high tea is so good!

A Gem. If only all galleries were like this one. You will not be disappointed at any level. Escape from the madness that is Oxford Street into the magical calm of an exquisite collection in a beautiful house. Don't leave without a coffeee in the atrium which is a gem in itself.

Doesn't Get Better Than This. Thank you to my fellow TA reviewers. It really doesn't get better than this. A marvelous museum full of wondrous things to see. I've lived in London and have travelled here for the past 40 years and I can't believe that I had never been to the Wallace Collection!!! Now that I've discovered it, thanks to TA, I shall make sure that I will visit it every time I'm back in London. It's a GEM.Had lunch in the covered courtyard with my family. The food was superb and so was the service. If this is your first time in London then you have plenty of things to go see. But if this is you second time in London, then you MUST visit this hidden treasure.

A superb attraction.. My late mother used to love going here, and it is easy to see why. Just a few minutes north of the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street, this superb gallery features painting by Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Canaletto...you name it, and of course 'The Laughing Cavalier'. As well as the paintings, there is a fine collection of furniture, armour and porcelain. It is hard to believe that one family, the Hertfords, collected all of these treasures.Yes, it is free, but you don't mind making a contribution. The Frick Collection in New York, for which we were charged 16 dollars, isn't a patch on this collection. As already stated, there is a fine restaurant as well.

Went for the male nude exhibition and had a wander through after.. I went to see the Male Nude Exhibition, which if it is still on I thoroughly recommend (but be advised it won't take long) and afterwards I had a wander through the rest of the collection. I am not really an art person, but there were some very impressive pieces here. Obviously the Laughing Cavalier is a big draw, but there are plenty of other pieces that will catch the eye. A very nice looking Cafe although I did not try it. The house itself is also quite spectacular. If you are not an art person, but looking for something dry to do on a wet London day, then I can recommend this as somewhere to while away a few hours.

What is there not to like?. What is there not to like about the Wallace Collection? It's free, it's a few minutes’ walk from Oxford Street and it contains some of the world’s best known paintings, such as the “Laughing Cavalier” by Franz Hals and “The Swing” by Jean-Honoré Fragonard, along with works by artists such as Titian, Velasqués, Rubens, Rembrandt, Poussin, Canaletto, Gainsborough, Lawrence and Watteau. Other exhibits include collections of ceramics, arms and armour, furniture and sculpture. But beware the pricey restaurant, run by Peyton & Byrne. It's OK for a quick coffee maybe, but better meals deals can be found nearby.
Nice & quant. Its a nice restaurant surrounded by lovely art from Wallace Collection. Great place to meet up friends for lunch and coffee. Good service.

A feast for the eyes. I've been to this museum twice since moving to London and I've enjoyed both visits immensely. There is so much to see that every time you go you will notice different pieces and learn something new. Each room is gorgeous, and very well presented. The history of the collection itself is very interesting, I recommend reading the information provided as well as talking to the staff there, they were all very well informed and friendly. The Male Nude special exhibit was worth a visit as well. We saw visitors of all different ages, with the art as well as armour and fine art, there is really something for everyone.

Private treasures. Stepping into the Wallace, is like visiting a private residence, - a very special one! Recent restoration has made it more user-friendly, but it is still bursting at the seams, and obviously the quality of the exhibits varies. There are interesting, occasional special exhibitions and the new courtyard restaurant is a pleasant oasis when viewing needs a short respite.
Perfect collection. paintings well displayed good lihghtimg so many famous paintings and even more leser known ones every art lover should see this collection

A surprising gem. We visited the Wallace Collection on a recent trip to London. It's truly impressive - the amount of artwork and weaponry is staggering. We went the day after going to the Tower of London and it was nice to be able to see so many artifacts without being jostled around by huge groups of tourists. The cafe area is also beautiful, in a converted courtyard area. Will definitely return and plan to spend more time (and have lunch) the next time we're in London.

Magnificent!. Really surprised at the range of art here. Aside from a room filled with Marie Antoinettes actual desks and bureaus, the most impressive collection is the armory! Hundreds of pieces of knights armor, prince's armor, sultan's armor and numerous swords, shields, chain mail, etc. really impressive. Nice atrium cafe/restaurant inside with a tea time service. Will definitely be back!
A haven away from the crowds. Great for a couple of hours with really interesting collection set in a lovely building. Cafe is wonderful

A treasure house. The Wallace is in a quiet square just behind the mayhem of Oxford Street and contains many exquisite works of art from the 15th Century onwards, collected by 5 generations of the Hertford family. They include: paintings, furniture, ceramics and armour from all over Europe, particularly France. The restaurant, in a covered atrium serves delicious food at reasonable prices. I can't wait to go back.

Well worth a visit !. I'm travel from Asia, no one ever mentioned about this museum until I saw it at Tripadvisor. I brought my family for a visit and it turned out to be well worth it.Many of the items at the Wallace Collection are uniquely refined and you would not had seen them in any of the bigger museum.
Interesting. It's a very nice, interesting and yet free! I go there frequently and it's definitely worth a visit. It also includes a gift shop and the museum is owned by the Government.

lovely. This is my second visit. It is a fabulous house with lots of many treasures that has been handed over to the state. It's a good place to go if the weather is poor and it's so close to Oxford Street.

Worth a visit. Although we visit this area frequently, this was our first time stopping here. The exhibits were interesting, as was the building they are in. There is a charming covered courtyard restaurant located in the center of the building. It looked like a very appealing stop for lunch, had we not just come from lunch elsewhere.
Great but... Little bit hard to find for me, but i liked here!There are so many pieces not just painting but also lots of things.

Hidden jewel. A lovely collection just off Oxford Street, giving the chance for the viewer to escape the hustle and bustle. Well informed staff and the space to just look and consider paintings, statues etc. and then a conservatory to have refreshments in. I have been here alone and with family, either way it works well. It's free to enter but donations are welcome

A Fabulous Surprise. I had been to this museum many years ago but took my husband to see it while visiting London. There is so much to see and you cannot rush through it. The history is wonderful and the guide was exceptional giving us lots of interesting tidbits. There is a lovely garden restaurant which we were unable to visit.

Fascinating period buildind and FREE. Terrific. Great building and well restored rooms. Displays excellent and friendly staff. Paintings and exhibits may not be ineresting to everyone however the building is worth seeing
Quality, not quantity. Very nice collection, from religious icons to modern paintings in a small amount of time. I recommend!
Free collection. Instead of Christmas shopping went along to see this unique collection which was fascinating the glass was splendid. Ended up staying over 4 hours there.

Not to be missed!. I have lived in London all my life and for the first time visited the Wallace Collection only recently. I have been to museums and art galleries all over the world and I have to say this is one of the very best I have visited. I was amazed at the quantity and the quality of the works of art on display. We totally miscalculated how long the visit would take, so its looks like another visit in the not to distant future to take in what we missed. And can't believe it was free!

A little gem. When in London, go and visit The Wallace Collection. There is no entry fee and twice a day you can join the Highlights tour which is, again, for free. The Wallace Collection has some very fine pieces of art, without being exuberantly large. Being from Holland, it is "strange" to walk into the room that is filled with Dutch painters like Rembrandt, Dou, Hals and others. This collection, that by will cannot be lend out nor extended, also contains a large armour collection. Nowhere did I see so many armour from different periods in time, so nicely conservated. As said: if you have the chance to join the highlights tour it is definetly worth your while. The story of the collection is told by people who give their love and working life to it and who are able to tell the interesting bits without being "boring" or "uninterested". Just the opposite.The (glass covered) inside garden hosts a restaurant which has a decent coffee and a nice array of dishes to choose from. On some evenings the restaurant is open to host you for "an evening dinner under the stars".
Wonderful place to visit. Wide variety of collections in a superbly decorated old mansion.Very good food if a little pricey for many.

Wonderful gallery.. This was a part of London which we hadn't visited before, first we had a stroll down Marylebone High Street which was very interesting with a lot of little individual shops.We had lunch at Natural Kitchen which is highly recommended and good value. We then went to The Wallace Collection which is really amazing and free! 25 Amazing galleries of French decorative arts and Old Masters in vast Georgian town house.A must to visit! The Peyton and Byrne restaurant is very popular, all in all a great place to pass a couple of hours.Bootle45

Beautiful. A really pretty smallish museum that is well worth a couple of hours out of your time. Glad we didn't have screaming kids around, it was very warm though. Stunningly beautiful rooms with lots of interesting furniture, objects and paintings.

Remarkable beauty in every corner. The Wallace Collection is an awesome collection of some of the most beautiful artwork I had ever seen. There are rare museums I know that can match the incredible beauty of the porcelain vases, oil paintings and antique furniture all under one roof like what you can see here. To turn a glorious mansion into a bewildering display like this is hard enough, but to cram it with precious artifacts from around the world is a feat to behold.Everyone was walking through each colored room in reverence. Best of all, there is no entry fee.I am glad I visited the Wallace Collection. I will make it a point to spend more time there on my next London trip.

Not a place for a childrens party. I feel almost guilty giving a bad review as the Wallace Collection as it is truly beautiful building with a spectacular collection however my experience was totally ruined by the presence of a children’s party (for very young children). This is not a place to have your children’s party, or indeed to bring young children at all, it is not set up for kids – parents I would suggest soft play. Any appreciation I would have had was totally ruined by screaming children running everywhere, had I wanted to spend my afternoon in a McDonalds I would have gone there; the management should be ashamed of themselves for taking the booking. Avoid until the building and it’s collection are treated with the respect they deserve.

Awesome small museum. I rarely give places 5 stars unless they are really special. For me, the armaments rooms here are amazing. Outside of Leeds castle, and along with the Tower of London, probably the best in the UK, and these just form a part of the wider collection of arts and crafts on show. Definitely worth a visit ...

One of the best museums in London for sure!. By far, this is one of the most beautiful museums I ever been. At the beginning I thought it was going to be a small museum but once inside, I couldn't believe the size.It's massive, with a beautiful furniture and a great collection of art. If you go into the lower ground floor, you will find loads of battle gears on display and also a cafe, which is also very nice after a lovely walk around the building.I strongly recommend the free tour that they offer and by the way, all the staff is very polite.It's very easy to get there and it's near Bond Street tube station.Extremely recommended!
An annual treat.. The Wallace Collection has a very special place in my heart. I visit on the first of January every year. It is nothing less than food for the soul and I love it.
A regular stop every time I'm in London. Check out the Wallace Collection for a fine eclectic assortment of paintings, furniture, household items and more!A regular stop when visiting London.

And I live in London. For years and years, I have been intending to visit the Wallace Collection - I finally made it on Thursday the 28th of November 2013. The place is amazing - astonishing; and I cannot wait until I visit again. There is so much to see that I will not even try to list. My personal interests were to see the paintings and the Sevres porcelain. Neither of these collections disappointed. Other items were equally enthralling and I was sad to leave for another appointment. As has been said, it is 'easy-peasy' to find - minutes on foot from Bond Street Underground station. There is a splendid restaurant and entrance is FREE. Hard to believe that all these items belonged to a family; albeit an aristocratic and very wealthy family. A gem amongst gems in this great city of London.

If you like the ornate, this is your museum...and it's free. The Wallace Collection is a national museum based in an old town house in Manchester Square. The collection was put together by the third and fourth Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace in the 19th century. There are rich displays mainly of French and English paintings, furniture, porcelain and tapestries, much of which dates from the 18th and 19th centuries. There are sculptures, busts and a large array of arms and armour. The overall effect is definitely rococo, with huge paintings, imposing staircases and many of the exhibits are unashamedly ornate. The museum runs a Treasure of the Month and there are special exhibitions such as The Male Nude, and Special Talks & Lectures. There are links with the Arts Fund and art classes for adults as well as family based activities. All in all a fascinating place, entry is free and it is very close to Oxford St.
A nice house to visit. this collection is a well preserved house, with it´s contents, mainly painting, there is a nice bar also.

An unexpected delight. I'd never heard of the Wallace Collection before this year, and it's now my favourite museum in London. Very easy to find, just two minutes walk from Oxford Street, in a beautiful building on Manchester Square. The collection is fascinating, with some recognisable paintings and beautiful pieces. I don't usually like armoury exhibitions, but this one is a must-see.

Excellent. Must see private collection, 17th and 18th century artifacts presented in an impressive house in Central London. You'll need few hours to visit and also can enjoy a coffee, wine and lunch in the garden...
Expect the unexpected!. What a great place to spend a few hours amongst great art ....and be surprised at its most famous piece of art...

Very Interesting. Liked the fact there was a real variety of things to see and that it wasn`t rammed as many of the "main" museums are. It is free (you give a donation of as much as you wish upon departure) and the facilities were clean. The staff were discreet and happy to help and answered questions knowledgably. Would recommend a visit to this collection.

A Treasure in the Heart of London. This building in the heart of London an easy walk from the shopping area really should be visited several times. I thought it might be small enough to look through in one visit but its well worth a repeat. Some fabulous paintings and furniture as well as artefacts to be seen.

Incredible story if one man's taste. I liked the fact that you could see that it used to be a home and that the people looking after it now have replaced things like old curtains and wallpaper as Like for Like. There is a first class French restaurant in the conservatory - but not for hot days. The ambience is amazing - shows what a man with taste and money can achieve. Many old masters on the walls all kept in pristine condition - a feast for the eye
A Great Museum In A Grand House. A wonderful collection of so many quality possessions including paintings, ceramics, armour & weapons,special displays and even miniature paintings in wax.

Beautiful outing, central London. A beautiful large house, near London's Oxford Street, packed with a collection of family art treasurers from all over the world. Suitable for all ages over 9 years, with a variety of self audio tours depending on one's interests. Comfortable seats in most rooms so one doesn't get too tired. Fantastic restaurant and café in central glass roofed conservatory - ideal for a special celebration. Free entry - audio £3. A find to visit over and over again.

Hidden gem. Agree with all the reviews. Its an amazing place to spend a few hours or pop into when you are nearby. Its an amazing house with amazing works of art. If you can, try to take a tour (all free) to get some inside information on a few items. Take a break with an afternoon tea in the atrium.

Worth repeated visits. We have been to the Wallace Collection on several occasions and always find it a wonderful experience. The combination of great art in a setting of a fine London mansion is unbeatable. At the moment, part of the house is being restored, but that should not deter you from visiting. We had lunch in the courtyard restaurant. The setting is lovely, but we found the food overpriced and rather ordinary.

A masterpiece. Had seen this place ranked so highly on TripAdvisor so decided to see what the fuss was about. Each room displayed a wealth of art which was most impressive. By the end it started to feel a little 'samey' but the collection was undoubtedly a masterpiece. Pleased to have seen the famous Laughing Cavalier. The knights in armour gave some relief from the paintings!

Magnificent!. This is a magnificent private collection that was turned into a national museum according to the will of Sir Richard Wallace's French widow.You'll get items from the 15th till the 19th century, from paintings to armory displayed in several impressive rooms.Creations from Rembrandt, Canaletto among many other are on sight to be admired.The guided tour was very informative and helped us understanding a bit more of the collection itself and the social backstage that also led to it.During this last visit there was an interesting exhibition "The male nude"! Very interesting as you can see some different draws from the same model done at the same time by different painters. Different perspectives.The restaurant has a very trendy but traditional atmosphere but we weren't impressed by the service before or during seating down. Waiters chatting while we stood there, standing up, for several minutes, waiting to be seated didn't give us the best impression. We were expecting a lot more from the atmosphere and the prices. It's such a cozy patio that is a shame about the lack of attention to detail and customers.The shop is very nice and has a welcoming feeling. It's divided mostly by specialized books and special edition items and then there's another room with more of those items and commercial ones to match everybody's taste. It's ideal for Christmas shopping. I bought a nice piece of jewellery with "The swing" - inspired. What impressed me about this particular piece was the fact that is different from everything else being sold in other museum shops and the reasonable price. A find indeed!We cannot forget that places like this need to be conserved and rely on donations and sales from the shop. We are happy that our purchases helped to maintain this beautiful private collection.A place to return and enjoy, specially because some pieces are taken away for sometime and back again. the clocks are a good example of this. Some dozens are displayed and some are away to rest for ten years. This is a good way to conserve the pieces but also makes it more dynamic and interesting as you can see different things in different visits.

An Overwhelming Collection. On the last morning of a recent visit to London, my wife and I decided to squeeze in a visit to the Wallace Collection, a national museum in the heart of London, because of its proximity to our hotel. We found ourselves overwhelmed with the sheer volume and quality of the Collection, which includes a massive arms and armor collection and room after room of paintings by Rembrandt, Hals, Velázquez, and Canaletto (a newly acquired taste), among others, Sèvres porcelain and other exquisite ceramics, and wonderfully preserved and ornate furnishings. We staggered out after little more than an hour, happy but unable to absorb any more in such a short visit.Visitors should plan to take a break from viewing the Collection by visiting the spacious and airy restaurant in the covered central courtyard of the Collection's townhouse. Prices were reasonable, and a pause for brunch or a drink is almost essential to give yourselves time to absorb what you are seeing. The National Gallery might attract more attention, but the Wallace Collection is not to be missed.

London's Best Kept Secret. What a marvellous way to while away a few hours. Stunning paintings, furniture, china etc and wall coverings to die for all within a beautiful setting away from London's hurly-burly.Add to this the lack of crowds and it was time well spent.We also treated ourselves to afternoon tea which was excellent with a great choice of teas to accompany a variety of sandwiches,cakes and scones with cream & jam.The Wallace Collection is a "must visit" (and free) but keep it quiet !

The Wallace Collection. The Wallace Collection is located at central London and it is just done renovation lately. Very friendly staff with throughly tour intro about the collection. It's free entrance and deferentially worthy to pay a visit.
A very relaxing private gallery. A little-known oasis of calm in central London with some excellent works and a very good restaurant. well worth a visit.

go see. What a lovely museum. Can't believe it's free too. There is something for everyone,from armour to powder boxes. From "The Laughing Cavalier" to "The Swing" . The staff are friendly and helpful. It was my first visit, but I returned next day, there is so much to see, and I wanted to see all my favorites again. Will bring the family next time. There is also a restaurant in the atrium, which I will try .

Amazing!. A hidden gem tucked away in a square but so close to Selfridges. I was amazed by the sheer opulence of this collection of Art, furniture, porcelains, suits of armour and much more. Look at the curtains, tie backs and wall papers especially - they are really beautiful. Entry is free and you can make a donation towards the upkeep of the collection if you wish but there is no pressure.

Wonderful collection. Situated in central London, The Wallace Collection is housed in a magnificent building. It has fabulous display of 'Old Masters' painting, wonderful porcelain and exquisite 18th century furniture. Clocks, Statues, vases, trinkets adorn every room. The wonderful wall paper and curtains are a joy to see.the is a FREE museum, where you can easily spend 3 hrs walking around admiring the wonderful collection.The only downside to this was the very overpriced café and restaurant. By all means enjoy a cup of tea and cake in beautiful surroundings, but resist having a lunch. Watch out for the 12.5% Gratuity Charge added to your bill. If you don't pay it or reduce it staff and management start to get nasty. You have been warned!

Sumptuous house in the heart of London. beautifully presented house - now a national museum collection - with a great restaurant and shop in the heart of London. free entry (sometimes there is a charge for a special exhibition). A great place to while away a happy afternoon in the west end or meet friends for lunch and a look around. Although well known for the French C18 collections it also has a good arms and armour collection and fine dutch paintings

Wonderful collection. A wonderful collection of art, ceramic, weaponry, and miscellaneous collectibles in a sumptuous elegant house. There is a restaurant, good food, but service though polite, is very slow and disorganised.
