Gorgeous venue. I love the wallace collection, its breathtakingly elegant. The art work and design throughout the collection is stunning.

A Must For Art Lovers. Behind Selfridges in delightful Manchester Square is the Wallace Collection. This house holds the most amazing array of treasures, not just paintings but also furniture, sculptures and weapons. We loved Venus spanking baby Cupid. The walls have recently been renovated with the most sumptious coverings designed to perfectly compliment the paintings hangin in the room. One could imagine that this divine place used to be proper London home. In the inner courtyard is a wonderful cafe. The gift shop holds a store of unusual books and souvenirs. it is a little bit like going back in time being here. Oh, and one must mention how helpful the attendants arre if one has a question!There is no entrance fee only a requested donation which one can only more than happily give.

Hidden gem. This is a small museum, by a square just north of Oxford Street, however rarely mentioned and often forgotten. There are marvellous collections of miniatures, ceramics aso, but probably the best, is the collection of arms and armoury, simply amazing!

A Gem of a Collection. A varied collection in a beautiful house close to the West End - yet tranquil inside. I have visited the collection three times so far and plan to visit again. It is worth exploring just a couple of rooms each time to fully enjoy such a varied collection.. There is a wonderful cafe in the atrium in the Centre but this is frequently full. However, having enjoyed a quiet browse it is only a short walk to Marylebone High Street to enjoy afternoon tea in one of the cafes.

Fun group of collections in former private home. This was a nice group of art collections in what used to be a private home for a family with way too much money. The collections are eclectic from armor to majolica pottery. There were some very nice illuminated pages kept in glass cases protected from light beneath covers: be sure to take the time to lift the covers and press the button on each case to turn the lights on for a bit. I liked seeing how the collection looked when the space was still a home. This was well worth the trip to a spot slightly off the tourist path.

well worth a visit. What a wonderful experience, I love this place, the collection is just amazing, it is not a huge museum but they have such a an amazing items you could spend hours here and the best thing is that its free! the cafe is great too !

Not a mainstream blockbuster collection, somewhat esoteric but that’s why it pays exploring.. Returned here recently after a 15 year gap,to refresh the memory, and was not disappointed. It is a large collection but including acres of less popular, less fashionable material like old furniture, china, armour (Oriental and European!) and of course muskets. So not a lot of paintings and many of the paintings are relatively obscure. But... this is exactly why it pays delving, for art that is less obvious and available. There are some standout paintings like Franz Hals, and others, like Velazquez and Bronzino. But there is the marvellous collection of miniature paintings, many of historic people, and the china and porcelain, even some of the weaponry, especially that decorated minutely. Also the collection is generally not crowded, has an other wordly ambience, and a good cafe in the central atrium.
A charming hidden gem. I love this place, a beautiful house with a great permanent collection. A lovely atrium to have a cup of tea too. Worth a gisit
A hidden gem. It could be overlooked by the other national museums but it holds it's own.it had a lovely,intimate feeling about it and didn't feel precious.

lovely visit. This is not one of those giant museums but a rather more intimate affair though it did use to be someone's home which does put things in context. Felt a little bit like wandering around a very very very very very rich friend's home! Excellent cafe to boot. A cultured respite from a busy Oxford st shopping day

An amazing collection, fine cafe, beautiful afternoon. It was hard for me to believe that this stunning array was a private collection, and as many others have commented, FREE. Not just paintings, but jewelery, china, armor, firearms, and more. It does, of course, look like a museum, but you must appreciate that a single family acquired all of these treasures. You'll recognize Rembrandt and many of the other artist names (or you should), but the diversity is what makes this so much more than an "art gallery". There is a delightful cafe in the central courtyard, so you should plan to spend some time here.

Wallace Collection a must for art lovers.. The Wallace Collection not only contains an excellent collection of art and French furniture and china, but also displays it in a grand old English home. There is also a good restaurant.

fabulous ecclectic collection of all sorts of stuff and free. if you haven't been here, you should make the effort - just behind selfridges off oxford street. i didn't have long enough but will be back.toilets best in london!!cafe beautiful and good food - portions tiny however and not cheap AND i do object to having a gratuity (12.5%) added to the bill
The Hidden Gallery. This is a great art gallery which includes 'The Laughing Cavalier' as well well as some marvellous Canalettos.AND ITS FREE!

Culture for free!. Beautiful house full of paintings, furniture and objets d'art. Tranquil surroundings (unless there's a school group on an outing but even then they're pretty well behaved). Similar vibe to the Frick Collection in New York. Free admission and a stone's throw from Selfridges - what more could you want? I'm a Londoner and this never loses its appeal. Go!

Absolutely gorgeous cafe!. What a beautiful place to have afternoon tea. We strolled around the collection then had afternoon tea in the central cafe which is spacious and airy; a fresh place after the busy streets of London! What a delight.

Afternoon Tea at The Wallace Collection. I had tea here on a Sunday afternoon with three friends it was absolutely excellent the service the food the setting . It was also extremely good value costing £25 per person including a glass of champagne . We have had tea at a number of the posh London hotels and whilst this was not quite as swanky it was certainly very enjoyable .

A wonderfull collection. A great mixture of painting and china with some unexpectedly great armour. The rooms themselves are really quite beautifull and staff were informative and friendly. An unexpected treat.

Lovely museum. Been here a few months ago when m brother came to visit London. The museum looks really nice, the small room downstairs where you can try different helmets and clothing that warriors used in the past is really fun! Also, the restaurant look amazing, a bit expensive but it's worth it!

Amazing food. After visiting the collection we went for dinner at the restaurant. I had a three course meal of the vegetarian menu and it was amazing food and excellent value for money. My husband ordered off the ala cart menu and was equally impressive quality. Service was quick efficient and very discreet to match the environment. Cannot recommend it enough

Worth a visit. The Laughing Cavalier. It is art history in good order and well worth a visit - not contemporary but maybe easily understood. However there are depths within the art if you chose to look.

Hidden gem. Quite an idiosyncratic collection that you can really sense was put together by a family of private collectors. Some amazing treasures and some objects of astounding ugliness in a setting that almost feels like a private house

well worth a visit. A beautiful house full of amazing objects and its free too!
they have a super little café with some yummy treats. I cant wait to go back

Stunning Collection in a Few Rooms. This was our first visit to what is a stunning collection. The Sevres pottery is especially outstanding. It was a little disappointing that so many rooms were closed and displays incomplete due to continuing upgrades & refurbishment - it might have been better for the Collection trustees to have embarked on a longer series of smaller changes rather than a very large one which seems to be quite disruptive.

Very Interesting Afternoon. The building that houses the Wallace Collection is itself something that must be seen - great to step back in time and see the elegance laid out. The armoury is amazing - such a diverse collection spanning the countries and years. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

A hidden gem in the heart of London. I got aware of Wallace Collection existence only recently, despite having travelled to London many, many times; so, this time, as in London I decided to close this gap.Absolutely not to be missed! A mansion full of art treasures: mainly paintings (arguably the second largest painting gallery in the UK after National Gallery) but also some amazing XVII-XVIII century porcelains and ancient armours (both from western and eastern world) collections.Last but not least....The admission to the Collection is completely free. A unique situation in London!!

Fantastic collection of beautiful art pieces.. I loved the Wallace collection there is something there for everyone. From beautiful paintings to odd curios and military arms and wearpons. There are some beautiful items here and whats more it has free entry. If you are going to visit allow at least 2-3 hours here.
A visit to a beautiful 'family home'. Went with friends and received a guided tour with a very knowledgeable curator ... a great little 'museum' tucked behind Oxford Street, well worth the visit!

Well kept secret!. We stumbled upon this very impressive house in Manchester Square just off Marleybourne High Street. What an impressive collection of art and furniture, with very helpful booklets in every room to describe in detail each piece.There is also a very nice looking restaurant which would make for a very stylish lunch.

A haven of art near Oxford Street. This is a former private house in the West End that is packed with paintings, furniture and other objets d'art. You can easily spend an hour or two here looking into one of the last large town houses in London.

amazing. The collection is very versatil, with different items (pictures, sculptures, arms) from different places and times. You can donate whatever you consider to visit a great place just 500 meters from Oxford street.
A gem of a place. Wonderful oasis of calm and beauty behind hell of Oxford St. Odd mix of extreme frou frou and fol-de-rol and vicious weaponry. Always a treat to visit.

An undiscovered Gem. A very great art museum. The Wallace Collection was the personal art collection of the Wallace family. The paintings and artifacts are fantastic. After the British Museum, British Library, & the Victoria & Albert Museum this should be your next stop.
Not to be missed for art lovers and history buffs!. Incredible! One of Europe's richest families with a unrivalled passion for collecting and then donated all it to the people of England!
Beautiful place. The Wallace collection is just stunning. The paintings, decorations and historical objects will have you in disbelief that the experience is actually free!
Excellent. Very good collection of paintings. Not busy when we were there so it was a nice break from all the crowds.

Breathtaking collection. I didn't know what to expect which made it even more stunning. Not a collection to be absorbed on one visit there is just so much to see. Variety in every room from artwork, sculpture, medals, furniture and even horse armour. As an extra the restaurant is excellent. Like the Courtauld Collection it is one of those places you will go to every time you go to London. As a bonus unlike similar places in Paris, there are no queues and it is not crowded. Wonderful collection.

Well worth a visit it's a beautiful collection. The rooms are just as beautiful as the collection. We particularly liked the boxes. Paintings by famous artists. A large collection of armour. Short walk from Bond St tube. You won't be disappointed.

It really worths a visit!. I came across this museum by chance and I am happy about my decision to stop and visit it.The Wallace Collection is located in a nice, well-kept square just a few minutes far from busy Oxford Street.The museum’s collection includes, among others, a display of armours and horse armours. I have also looked with interest at the collection of famous Italian maiolica from Urbino, Deruta, Gubbio, Pesaro and Faenza. In addition to the famous painting The Artist's Son Titus by Rembrandt, there is a rich collection of paintings by Boucher, Canaletto, Delacroix, Delaroche, Greuze, Rubens, Rembrandt, Steen, Tiziano and Turner to cite just few examples. Each room is enriched with beautiful furniture coming especially from France. Close to the shop there is the beautiful Oriental Armoury room with rare Indo Persian swords and arms. Here I could admire the treasure of the month, a small but precious Mughal dagger, an oriental object enriched with beautiful gems.A bright courtyard hosts a charming tearoom.The museum is open every day from 10am to 5pm and admission is free.

Charming small museum. A friend suggested the Wallace Collection as a must see, and we agree!Beyond the artwork - a quirky collection, it was especially interesting to see the inside of a stately London home from a century or two ago.An easy walk from the Bond Street Tube stop, and a wide variety of restaurants nearby.

AMAZING. Never before seen so many Renoirs , Gainsborough's etc in one room, absolutely bursting with amazing things, very well worth a visit, it will take at least two hours but there is also a good pace for lunch in there.

Fabulous place to visit and eat. We went here on the recommendation of trip advisor .really a great museum to visit .no admission,not many people there .fabulous paintings including several rembrandts arhat you can get really close to .the house itself it really really nice .close to Selfridges so,you can stop,by there and do some shopping .had lunch in the restaurant ,the best food I have had in London. The only restaurant I have ever been in where you can order pol roger by the glass .i had partridge followed by profiteroles ,my wife had lamb ,it is not cheap but the food service and location are fabulous .

Nice surprise. We came across this after an afternoons shopping in Oxford Road, The museum is set in a quiet square and in a lovely building. There is lots to see with some wonderful paintings and an Armoury collection. There were rooms of very ornate mainly French furniture and some of the jewellery collection was quite exquisite. It was a nice way to spend a pleasant couple of hours especially as the admission is free.

Hidden Treat. I had heard of the Wallace Collection, but I must admit I came across it by accident after being dragged around Oxford Street shopping. It is set in a quiet square and is a beautiful building.There is lots to see with some wonderful paintings such as the Laughing Cavalier, and a wonderful Armoury collection. I wasn't too keen on the very ornate furniture collection but some of the jewellery etc. was quite exquisite. It was a nice way to spend an hour or so especially with it being free admission.

Hidden Gem just behind Oxford Street. Location is perfect; just a stone's throw from Selfridges. A very well designed and planned collection. There is a good restaurant where you can take a break and ease the feet! This National gem has wonderful displays of 18th century painting (French), a lot of furniture and porcelain, some great Old Masters and, if you like armouries, this is a good one. Additionally, admission is free.

What a delightful surprise.... We happened upon this tucked away museum and were blown away by the richness of the collection. Its almost overwhemling! We thuroughly enjoyed the salon style hangings in the galleries, so that you can view art the way it would have been hung in a real home. We will return to this hidden gem.

Great for kids, especially boys. Excellent for everyone.. The enormous collections at the British Museum, and the National Gallery are overwhelming and each need a day to visit. This museum is small and houses an excellent collection of furniture, art in the setting of a home. You can see how the rich live. Boys, who will normally hate going to museums, will love the ancient instruments of war such as armour for men and horses. You can visit it in about 3 hours.

Quirky and Interesting. We love visiting the Wallace Collection from time to time. The collection is very eclectic but interesting. They have excellent cakes in the tearoom. It is just a short walk from Oxford Street.

Fantastic! A mini British museum of art.. The Wallace Collection is a museum in London, with a world-famous range of fine and decorative arts from the 15th to the 19th centuries with large holdings of French 18th-century paintings, furniture, arms & armour, porcelain and Old Master paintings arranged into 25 galleries.Many of the paintings are by famous artists - Rembrandt, Rubens, Boucher to name a couple. Very tastefully done. This 'home' was established in 1897 from the private collection mainly created by Richard Seymour-Conway, 4th Marquess of Hertford (1800–1870), who left it and the house to his illegitimate son Sir Richard Wallace (1818–1890), whose widow bequeathed the entire collection to the nation.It is a couple of blocks behind Selfridges. In the center of the courtyard is a lovely French restaurant. Take a couple of hours here rather than the bigger museums. Less crowded and friendly guards ready to answer any question or spend a few minutes discussing the collection.

A Must Visit In London. One of those small museums that you are glad you visited. wonderful collection of paintings including Old Masters and perhaps the finest collection of arms and armour in the world. Be sure to take the free tour offered by one of the volunteer guides. A great way to get a good overview of the collection before you focus on your specific areas of interest on your own. And as always, admission is free. Good quality restaurant on the premises for that needed cup of tea when you have absorbed all of the treasures

Sophisticated Splendor. Having been told by an ex-pat friend that the Wallace Collection was by far her favorite London museum, I was pleased when with the rain pouring down we found ourselves inside the gorgeous building and grounds off Manchester Square. It does not rival the National Gallery or V&A in size, but the content would equal (and in some cases surpass) any fine arts museum in the world. It is a carefully curated collection with many pieces sure to be recognized. Fine examples of objets d'arts from around the world are displayed in rooms of true grandeur. In many instances, the architecture and design of many of the rooms and hallways overshadows the displays, or at the very least, vies for your rapt attention. This is a sophisticated collection, deftly arranged and very pleasing to the eye. The lack of heavy crowds makes the browsing even more delightful. So, don't tell anyone else, but make your way to the Wallace Collection and delight your senses and expand your world.

A most unepected lovely day out. I visited the Wallace Collection with a friend, we were meeting for lunch, which was excellent. After lunch we looked round the collection and I was really pleased to see just how much is housed in this building. It is a small and very comprehensive collection of items. I even found myself interested in the armour section. Children would love this, they even have armour for horses. A great day out. I will certainly visit again when I am in London.
Brilliant Collection. Wonderful enchanting museum. So much to see, leave enough time even though it is a rather small building

If you are in the West End do not miss this place. As far as I know this place is not well known despite being only a quarter of a mile from Selfridges. This attraction is free and you can spend half an hour here or half a day. There is a magnificent collection of Dutch Old Masters, paintings by Canaletto, pottery, weapons, furniture, armour....You do feel that the security guards are a bit on your back and I would not recommend bringing children here unless they are very well behaved but even so this place is so worth coming to.There is also a modern cafe, toilets and a shop. I am told the cafe is good by friends who come here often.

A Splendid Night. Friday night at the Wallace Collection drinking wine, seeing incredible paintings, furniture, artifacts, and listening to a fabulous quartet...I can not imagine a better night in London.

a hidden gem !!!. Our Taxi driver refered us to this place - what a surprise! a true hidden gem. We did not have time to explore it in details, but I was stunned with the amount and veriaty of the medieval armor display, including a horse shield... Impressive!

Excellent Collection of Art and Armour. We found this museum by chance and spent a far too short 45mins in the museum. This was enough for a quick intro to the museum for the adults and enough time for the children to get bored !!.Conveniently located just off Oxford Street up Duke Street (next to Selfridges) onto Manchester Square, it's a beautiful old building, with some fantastic pieces housed inside some sumptuous rooms. The armoury section in particular caught my eye.There was a large cafe / restaurant under a relatively modern atrium serving afternoon teas and much more besides.Will definitely return - maybe without the kids in tow.

Beautiful but stuffy. Took 4 teenager girls here. They obviously weren't welcome. There were trails for children under 10, but nothing suitable for young teens-what a wasted opportunity. The girls are all very well behaved, and walked sensibly and quietly around the rooms, but we all felt uncomfortable under the glare of the guards in each room. I imagine they thought we were going to touch the paintings/furniture or worse! Used to the welcome given at National Trust properties, it was a big disappointment.I'd go back again, but by myself or with my hubbie.

One of london's hidden gems. A cracking museum, tucked away in Manchester Square just off Oxford Street with a very nice courtyard restaurant. We always take friends there when they come to London, possibly because it's the last thing they expect!

A real gem on the West End. The Wallace Collection is a true gem in the very heart of London's West End, which, the day we visited, could have been aptly renamed the wet end.This private art collection is freely accessible at no charge for everybody and should be a must see for both art passionates and people in general. It doesn't seem overcrowded like the British Museum, does not suffer from the stuffy atmosphere that plagues so many other museums and the visitor has a true feeling of being really appreciated. The collection, which mainly has been acquired in France is amazing and ranges from medieval to late 18th century. They have an extensive display of medieval armors, rare paintings, clocks and various precious furnitures.I was truly impressed by the Venetian landscapes and the way artifacts are presented with wall tapestry of different color for each room.Food is served in a beautiful large veranda inside the building. We did not eat there, but the dishes looked delicious.Go there if you can, the Wallace Collection will not disappoint you!
I didn't even know this was around. I discovered this one day by accident. I had a lovely time there and had a glass of champagne in the restaurant to finish off a delightful experience.

A hidden gem in London. We found the Wallace Collection almost by accident while recently visiting London. It is one of the best kept secrets. The museum is fantastic covering a wide variety of areas. We thoroughly enjoyed a full half day here and did not finish the exhibits. The armour collection is beyond amazing even if this isn't one's area of interest. The paintings are beautiful too and the setting for everything really makes a difference.Lunch in the courtyard is delightful too. Cost is reasonable....so don't pass on this. A bonus was that it was just 10 minutes walk from our hotel near Marble Arch.

Really enjoyed our visit. I had not heard of this place until I saw it on Trip Advisor but it was well worth a visit. Situated close to Oxford Street, behind Selfridges, it is in a peaceful square. There is a large collection which includes art, ceramics, furniture, armour, clocks etc etc. Many of the rooms are beautifully decorated and it is all free. If you like this type of art collection then don't miss it.

Excellent in every way. Great location behind Selfridges. The rooms and collections magnificent . The armoury room wonderful. The cafe and restaurant surrounds very welcoming under the glass roof. We ate in the cafe and the food and service were excellent.
Worth a visit. A real find, especially if you like 18th Century furniture and art and a good restaurant for lunch. Too much to absorb in one go so be selective!

Treasure trove. This place is sublime. There are artefacts in here that are exquisite and beyond compare. I saw things here that really feel that they should be in even more renowned international galleries or museums! Please go and be pleasantly surprised! More people should be made aware of the Wallace Collection!The way everything is set out has been done with loving care. You feel so far away from the hustle and bustle but are only a minute or so's walk from Oxford Street. I haven't been to the restaurant and have heard mixed reviews so can't comment.

Over the top and quite remarkable!. We enjoyed our visit to the Wallace Collection, as much for its eccentricity and excess, as for the huge number of artworks and furnishings crammed into the residence. Entry is free, but they encourage you to buy a guidebook as a 'donation', which is fair enough. We began our visit by having lunch in the open air restaurant in the courtyard. The setting was wonderful but the service was very poor and a number of people around us just gave up and left before their orders were even taken, based on the fact that you might well wait for ever. There is a snootiness among the staff in some English eating establishments that takes some beating, and such was the case here, which was a pity. The food was also only very average, despite the prices. The collection itself was remarkable and included a couple of real gems such as Franz Hals's "The Laughing Cavalier". Amazing to come across a masterpiece like this in a private residence. We always enjoy the limitations of a private collection - not too much to take in all at once (e.g. the Villa Borghese in Rome and the Frick in New York). The fact that the Wallace Collection was given for the public to enjoy was a wonderful gesture and we were certainly glad we saw it. However, it IS excessive in its opulence and you had the feeling it was almost collecting for collecting's sake. Nevertheless, definitely worth a visit - and so near to Oxford St.

Peace, Tranquility and Culture near Oxford St. Escape the bustle and commercialism of Oxford St shopping into another world. Brilliant rich exhibits and boutique nature of the museum plus the most wonderful upmarket brasserie to enjoy a snack or coffee and meet friends.

A treasure all should include in their visit. Furniture, art of all varieties, available in a lovely venue, lunch in the courtyard was nice, restful, the docents knowledgeable of the collection, and readily answered questions

A true gem. Oustanding collection in a beautiful building. Free entrance. Some of the paintings are among the real TOP. A must see, certainly for those who wish to visit a more quiet and intimate museum.

Sunny autumn afternoon. If you are an art lover it's one of the best places to go in London.
Fantastic art, ceramics, enjoy the ambience and have a glass of bubbly in the bar

Minutes from the West End - a trip back in time. The recently rearranged and refurbished Wallace is a delight. Whether you catch the free tours (twice daily, check the time) or wander round on your own, it's a great place to visit. There is an impressive collection of paintings, wonderful crockery and objects d'art. When you're finished, have tea in the wonderful restaurant in the atrium.

NO CHARGE. This was a very interesting visit and we have been twice..
especially as there was no entrance fee. Excellent bronzes
and paintings to view

Best gallery experience. So many iconic paintings - The Laughing Cavalier (Frans Hals) Dance to the Music of Time (Poussin)... Canalettos, Guardis, British painters - but also the japanese works, the ceramics, the armour... wonderful eclectic collection. Nice restaurant, too!

Wallace Collection London. Absolutely stunning collection. Guides are very knowledgeable too. Such an amazing gift to the nation from his wife. Life sized horses and riders in chainmail armour. Middle Eastern and Chinese vases, clothes etc. rooms decorated tastefully and art works galore. Well worth a visit. Our son took us there, he lives in London. Not on the usual tourist route. Also toilets and restaurant there. Everything you would need for an enjoyable 3 hour visit.

Absolutely Lovely!. Spent most of my time this trip to London with a novice London visitor--refeshing/revisiting sites ie--Tower, St Pauls, Westminster, V&A-etc......what a treat the Wallace was!! Awe inspiring the moment we walked up to the home, wonderful docent/tour guide and had a thoroughly delightful afternoon that we both agreed was the highlight of our 5 day London trip. Outstanding array or Art---Hals, Boucher, Rembrant, Gorgeous china---amazing Armour collection--second only in the UK to the Tower. Would recommend this outting for anyone!!

Beautiful collection. Very warm welcome and staff were very helpful. Free admission, I bought the guide book (under £5 but well worth it) Incredibly diverse collection of so many works. All beautifully displayed. Next time we'll book at the restaurant which has a good reputation too.

Beautiful place, awful staff. We were there in a group of approx. 20 for a baby shower. You have a two hour afternoon tea sitting - what that means is you drink tea/champagne for 1hr and only then do they start to bring out the goodies (scones were a little overdone but tasted good). Lots of tea top ups throughout, which is wonderful until they rush you out and refuse to let you use the toilet and are remarkably rude about it - "but we've just drank tea continuously for the past 2hrs"..."well that's not my problem". Nice. Definitely brings the level of class down a notch or two. But don't fret, just use the loo no later than 4.30pm or, alternatively, you can always walk down the road to Floor 2 of Selfridges!

Fantastic: just one 'but...........'. In a fine period house in Manchester Square along Duke Street, the Wallace Collection is a truly remarkable tribute to the taste of the family that put it together. There are paintings by iconic artists ('The Laughing Cavalier' by Frans Hals, various Rembrandts including a self-protrait and a study of his son, van Dyke, Sir Joshua Reynolds, Velasquez, Titian, and so on and so on: there is a fine collection of armour and weapons: there are miniatures, snuff boxes, glassware and porcelain of breathtaking quality. And all this is in rooms full of furniture of the very highest quality. The jaw drops from the moment you go into the spectacular entrance hall. And the glorious thing is ... it's all absolutely free (although donations are encouraged: buying the excellent guide book is a useful solution at this point, as both parties benefit). If there are 12 of you a pre-booked group tour would be well worth it- the guide we listened to in one room yesterday was first-rate- but there is also an audio guide for individuals. The 'but' ? Well , the restaurant in the covered courtyard really does have some problems with its service to sort out: my wife's (somewhat dry) lemon cake arrived a long, long time after the coffee (we were on the point of leaving) and the two people next to us had been there ages before their main courses arrived. The restaurant is a disappointment but definitely the only one. You really should go !!!

So this is how the upper crust lived. Gorgeous, opulent home filed with incredible art work, sevres, sculptire and weaponry. Beautiful to stroll through and there is no admission fee (donation suggested). The rooms were exquisite on their own and every space was filled with somethind beautiful to look at. Read the history of the family who build this collection and lived here before visiting.
Worth a visit. It had good paintings and artefacts. Lot of variety for the displayed items. We spent an enjoyable time over there.

It is free - go see it - for the lovely building and Collection.. Can't fault a visit to the Wallace collection - you can see it in under 2 hours (unless you want to see every piece in detail) and you get to see a lovely home too.
It's free and not crowded and easy to access from Oxford street or marble arch.

Wonderful collection. This is not a "museum" I would have chosen on my first visit to London if I had not been referred by a friend who said it was a hidden gem - and it was. We went on a Sunday when there was a 11/2 guided tour of the highlights of the collection given that was perfect to get the overview and determine what to see next. It is a stunning and varied collection displayed in a beautifully preserved house just behind Selfridges. There are priceless paintings, furniture, porcelains, armour and more. You won't be sorry you went.

Tea at the Restaurant. Not the Ritz but a very well presented reasonably priced tea in pleasant surroundings.The old courtyard very light and airy with a glass roof. Sandwiches with no crusts of course scones jam and cream or cream and jam and small fancy cakes. Good choice of tea £17-50 ph.A very pleasant afternoon 2-30 to 4-30 and they do not rush you out. A nice end to a visit to the Collection. Suggest you book as it gets full. Shopping in Oxford St round the corner - perfect

Best single collection I know. Best collection in any aspect: Paintings, furniture, ceramics, arms, and all in the very center of London, perfect size, not cumbersome with too much on display, free admission, daily tours of highlights also free, what more can you ask for? Just do not miss.

Great for an art lover.. Stunning collection just located near Oxford St. Perfect for an afternoon to relax and look through all the art pieces. I could not believe it was free as the collection is so vast and amazing, it was so hard to believe it was free. There is such a great collection here. Excellent to visit , and unforgettable, the extravagent art works remind us of how wonderful art is and that art always has a place in peoples hearts.

A true Gem. Whenever I am in London I always try to find a few hours to visit the Wallace Collection.It is such a peaceful contrast to nearby busy Oxford Street and wonderful collections of art and furniture. The Strawberry Girl by Joshua Reynolds is one of my favourite paintings and an unmissable part of a visit to the collection.There is a fantastic cafe/coffee shop in the central atrium/courtyard which provides an excellent lunch. There is also a very good gift shop, so be prepared to spend there, even if admission to the collection itself is free!I suppose I have been visiting the Wallace Collection for more than 30 years now and still get a buzz every time I go.One of London's finest museums without doubt.

unbeatable. absolutely amazing collection of paintings and arms. Italian, English and Dutch authors including Canaletto, Van Dyck, Reymonds, Ostede and many others. The building is beautiful itself, so worth visiting anyway
Great collection of art. Some wonderful paintings all in the original context of a home.Beautiful décor and furniture.Handy to central London.Free admission, so no better value.

Armour to view. If you are interested in armour, the Wallace Collection may be one of the best available in England.The Tower of London used to be good but its collection has been somewhat dispersed, although they still have the famous Henry VIII suit. A lot that was in the Tower has been dispersed, some of it to Leeds. This leaves the Wallace Collection as possibly the best collection easily accessible. There is also the building and the fabulous art collection to enjoy. Particularly good was the Wallace Collection shop which has really good books on armour, which are not available at the Tower of London or Leeds Armoury.

A hidden treasure. After ten visits to London I found the Wallace Collection. Itoo, found it a "Minnie" Buckingham Palace. I really liked it more. It was less growded and just as Opulent .Easy to get to and YEP even free. I would go back again.

DO NOT MISS!. This collection was stunning! I just wandered around with my audio guide (3 pounds only!) going from piece to piece, room to room in awe. Hard to believe it's free. It was like a mini Buckingham palace!

Amazing Collection. This relatively unknown museum, hosts some quite amazing artefacts, and is worth a visit. It is located near Oxford Street in the heart of London. Its suitable for adults not really the place for young children and would bore your average teenager in 3 seconds flat. However if you love antiques, or works of art and a beautiful house with plenty of history, its worth a visit. It is FREE entrance but a guided tour would be recommended if you have an avid interest.

This is a must visit!. Visited this place due to trip advisor reviews and wasn't disappointed.Located in Manchester Square just north of Oxford Street this is a golden opportunity to escape the hustle and bustle of London. For such a fantastic free museum this place was remarkably quiet and tranquil and you were able to take your time and have a clear view at the fabulous collection of items including art, furniture and armour. Didn't realise this was where the iconic Laughing Cavalier has it's home and it was lovely to see this fabulous painting so close up. Highly recommend going to see this hidden gem of a place.
A gem of a gallery!. Don't miss this wonderful collection in a lovely part of London. The guided tour was very well done.

Private Art Collection. This private home is filled with antiques and magnificent art. It has recently been refurbished and is open to the public free of charge. There is a covered courtyard which houses a very fine restaurant.
A gem!. Fabulous collection of art, furniture, china and armoury, only a stone's throw from Oxford St. The restaurant in the covered courtyard is lovely for a special lunch

Superb. Walk through state rooms with furniture that belonged to the French Aristocracy and sold to Wallace after the French Revolution. Unique French art collections displayed in stately home atmosphere gives a unique feeling of living with art rather than just looking at pictures. Get up close to the laughing cavalier and be inspired by the delicate brushwork. Surely the best attraction in the world and its free................
Not to be missed. The rooms housing the collection are beautifully decorated and all exhibits were of great interest. We also enjoyed lunch in the restaurant.

Very Impressive Collection. The house itself was very nice, exquisite window treatments, papered walls and huge chandeliers. The collection of armor was impressive as was the artwork and inlay furniture

Oasis in the middle of retail jungle!. This is a really nice place to take a breather from the craziness outside. Go to the restaurant for a nice pick me up refreshment to revitalise your senses before a bit of cultural therapy. The rooms are excellent and do wonders for the grey matter!

The most wonderful collection in London. The National Gallery boasts one of the finest collections in the world, both in depth and quality. The Wallace collection is different. It is diverse unique but most of all full to its unctuous best with some of the most beautiful works of art ever created. The collection of rococo and baroque masterpieces is rivalled only by the sympathetic hanging , the beautifully curated rooms and the splendid setting. Stand before the raft of the medussa and try not to be blown away.The addition of a relatively new central atrium cafe makes it even more appealing!

Well worth visiting while in London.. I've visited here a number of times and each time it gets better. Pity the gallery was under construction but it didn't spoil my visit. All the rooms are very well layed out to the original period. Staff as always where very pleasant and helpful. Great location just off Oxford Street. Great place to take youngsters. Large cafe but with a limited choice but again that didn't spoil my visit.A place you must visit.
Unexpected treat to suit a lot of interests. Pictures, furniture, miniatures, armor - this private collection has it all. Just off Oxford street - a real treat from its hustle and crowds.
Nice mixed collection. Not too bad, a very nice collection of paintings. The entry is free but they try to push the paid guide or audioguide or guidebook quite strong. The cafe was also quite nice
Dont Miss This Treasure. This would be one of the most eclectic and enjoyable collections I have found in London. Also the cafe is great

Perfect for kids who don't like museums. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem in London just off Oxford Street. When walking in it feels as if you're going to stay for a visit. All the rooms have incredible works of art (Rembrandt any one) with no lines to view them. While I enjoyed looking at Marie-Antoinette's porcelain boudoir set the kids enjoyed the most amazing collection of armor, swords and weaponry dating back to 15th Century. The entire museum can be browsed in an hour but to really understand the thousands of pieces on display next time I'm going to take a tour. I can't wait to go back.

Great collection!!!!!. Amazing collection!!!!!! The collection is absolutely fantastic!!!! Rembrandt, Fragonard and so many other great artists and beautiful furniture and collection of Sevres Porcelaine. That was really a great moment in London!!! The entrance is free, you can donate something if you want. I know London well and didn't know about this place, if you like art and beauty this is the place for you!!!!

Parisian Brits. Quite terrific collection by 18 I think British artists connected to Paris. But then there always are special shows at the \Wallace Collection.The standing exhibition is outstanding. Beautiful building in Manchester Square justnorth of Selfridges. An absolute must if you are in London.
A gem in London. A great museum . Eclectic pieces. A real oasis in central London. This was our first visit but will not be our last. Our grandson will be coming with us to see the armour next year.

Enjoyable gallery in beautiful surroundings. We enjoyed the everything this gallery had to offer. The works of art, porcelain and collection of armour were all fascinating. The coffee and cake delicious! A warm welcome and great service.

Amazing Collection and Amazing Stories. We visited specifically in time to join one of the hour-long "highlights tours," and were delighted with the time spent hearing stories that would never be on a little plaque next to a painting, sculpture, or piece of furniture.The collection is housed in a extended townhouse in a nice neighborhood. We spent an hour on the tour, and maybe another hour just looking around on our own.Definitely worth a trip.

Excellent way to spend a rainy day. I know this collection well as I used to live just around the corner, but the place has improved out of all recognition in terms of dining and also the way the collection is displayed. There is something for everyone and I couldn't recommend this London treasure any more highly. It really is a hidden gem, that is often overlooked by tourists and Londoner's alike.

A little gem - but not so little. I hadn't really taken much notice of this before and it was my mum who wanted to visit when she came to stay. Well I'm glad she did, it is a gem of a collection, really interesting range of pieces and a beautiful building. A lovely way to spend a few hours and they have a lovely cafe in the middle.

The Wallace Collection: a hidden gem. This is one of the greatest collections ever amassed by a private individual now available for all to see. The vastness of the collection always amazes me. There is always something previously overlooked to absorb ones interest. The Bonningtons are particularly worth a visit. Hertford House is a place of both visual stimulation and tranquility in the centre of London.
Not to be missed. My second visit, and again did not leave enough time to enjoy this amazing collection to full advantage. Two hours fly by !
Excellent Attraction. Located just off Oxford Street this is an ideal place to spent half a day browsing the many well furnished rooms.

Eclectic collection. What a surprise such a variety of things to look at, like walking round a family home with a lot of stuff in it. The staff are great they really know the objects on display. An easy way to pass a couple of hours or more and to go back and see something else next time. The restuarant was nice as well.

Great place, overly cautious borderline rude staff.. This place is amazing and completely exceeded my expectations. I was having a great time when all of a sudden I heard a rude voice addressing me. Some female employee was having a fit because I pointed in the direction of a mirror. I was simply telling my husband to look at some the the beautiful details. Never in a million years would I touch anything in this place or any museum. I can understand her concern, but she must have been blind and crazy. I would have left if this place wasn't free!

Girl in a Swing - and more.... From the Landseer downstairs to the Fragonard upstairs this is an unmissable collection presented in a London house with atmosphere of 18th Century and many more pictures to view. The Laughing Cavalier is also there I recall.Spacious setting in which to view wonderful. A London treasure.

Very stylish. You can view some wonderful art in stylish period rooms and feel like you have been taken back centuries. Try and fit in a guided tour, the guides give amusing and interesting information that add to the feeling of actually being there. Loved it

Nice neighborhood museum. Great place to pop in and enjoy some art and culture. Even though it is in central London, it is often overlooked by most tourists, so it is a great treat as well as retreat.
The jewel of the London Collections. At last a comprehensive collection dedicated to French art. Little known and so much more precious. Go discover!

Not to be missed. Not everyone knows about this gallery experience in Hertford House, Manchester Square. Other museums and galleries are better known but not better experiences. The collection is wide-ranging in content and displayed in elegant surroundings. Staff are helpful and friendly. The quality of the exhibits and paintings fantastic. We also enjoyed a cup of coffee in the restaurant in the covered courtyard - it looked a good bet for lunch another day when we will allow more time. We went to the current exhibition of watercolours of Paris by British artists which was delightful. Everything (except the coffee) was free. All in all a visit to the Wallace Collection should be on your agenda.

Magnificent collection. The Wallace Collection is housed in the Hertford House at Manchester Square. It was collected by the 1st, 2nd and 3rd Marquesses, and his illegitimate son who became Sir Richard Wallace. It was bequeathed to the nation in 1897. Much of the collection is 18th century Paris. There was a free guided tour that was given by a most informed docent, who loved her job. The furniture and paintings were exquisite. My favorite painting was of The Laughing Cavalier. It is free to tour and certainly worth a look.

The most amazing collection ever!. Art , muesum and history all under one roof. What is there not to like! I particulary loved the paintings of Rembrandt myself. I could stare at his work all day. I do feel that you need to spend two to three hours here. Give yourself time to explore this muesum , as there is treasures everywhere. The afterwards have a nice cool drink from the cafe-shop. Its worth the visit. Go and be mesmerized!

Palatial. There was a constant stream of visitors but it was never crowded. One can leisurely wander the splendidly furnished and furbished rooms in peace and tranquility. Everything is perfect in every detail. The café is bathed in natural light under a glass ceiling. The exhibition is world class, but free.
It's free and it's brilliant. The most sublime afternoon looking at the most sublime art you will ever see.WowIt takes about two hours to see the galleries .

A Hidden Treasure. Wonderful house filled with treasures. Owner donated 50 water fountains in Paris and a model of one of the "Wallace Fountains" is outside the house. FREE guided tours and no admission to the house.
Great Museum. A museum in an actual mansion someone lived in. Beautiful art and grounds. They also serve refreshments. A unique experience.

Classy with both modern and historic objects. The location is across from a small park in an older, immaculate, commanding structure. There are several levels and a good elevator of stairs. The collection of armor and weapons is substantial as as the painting. Great lunch restaurant open to the air in the center. I fine example of an endowment that works and serves the public.

Jewel of a Museum. The Wallace Collection is housed in a what was once a private mansion in London. The owners had exquisite taste in furniture and art. Enjoy paintings by Rembrandt, Rubens, John Singer Sargeant, Canaletto, Hobbema and Jakob van Ruisdael. The Sevres porcelain collection is worth the trip.
Excellent. Should not be missed on a trip to London; prefer this to the National Gallery and the Queens Gallery; small and intimate

Wonderful Visit and Docent Tour. I have been going to visit The Wallace Collection whenever I am in London since the 1980"s. It is one of my most favorite Art Museums in the world. Being in a Mansion where the family actually lived and the Collection while being fabulous is still small enough to enjoy your visit. There has always been tours by the staff and I often time my visit around these tours. We went for a highlight tour and the docent who gave the tour was the best. The Wallace Collection is located at /manchester Sq behind Selfridges. Also a wonderful place to have afternoon tea.

Jewel in London's Crown. After quite a few trips to London, I realised on our last visit that we had never made it as far as the Wallace Collection. I'd heard about it 40 years ago, but the glamour of the National Gallery, Portrait Gallery, Tate Galleries and so on had always tempted us to revisit those well-known places. Finally, we found ourselves in London on a very wet day and decided to find our way to Manchester Square, actually not too far from Oxford Street. We were astounded! The collection is housed in a wonderful old building and every room is a treasure-trove. There are wonderful paintings, porcelain, furniture - and I believe armour as well but I have yet to see those rooms. I couldn't believe that there was no entrance fee and yet the house was not too crowded. It truly was a quiet haven close to the heart of the busy Oxford Street area. We had afternoon tea in the stunning glass-covered Orangerie and although it was not cheap, it was truly a part of the Wallace Collection experience! We will certainly return to Manchester Square on our next visit to London, and meanwhile, I am spreading the word!

Hidden Gem in London. The Wallace Collection is a chocolate box of delights hidden away just 2 minutes off Oxford Street. It is not too big so you can easily fit a visit in between shopping if you really want to! I adore The Swing, Mme de Pompadour and The Laughing Cavalier all such fabulous paintings and my favourites amongst the treasures at The Wallace. Spend a day here or just a few minutes (as I often do just to see my 3 fave paintings!) either way you will be enchanted. Great facilities - lovely cafe/restaurant and learning facilities.

Stunning House With Amazing Collection. This is a brilliant place to spend an hour or two, perusing the vast and eclectic collection of artefacts, art and antiques in a gorgeous, huge house just off Oxford Street. It's relatively off the beaten path so quieter than other museums. The cafe in the covered courtyard is nice too.

Art at your own pace. After visiting most of the top museums London has to offer, including the National Gallery, I have to say that the Wallace Collection is my favorite art museum in the city. While the two museums I mentioned are both free, the Wallace Collection had a more intimate feel and it was less crowded, so you didn't feel like people were pushing you to move on to the next piece. You could have as much time as you wanted admiring each work of art, and photography was also freely permitted, unlike in the National Gallery.At the same time, since this is a collection, the exhibits aren't just limited to paintings or art. Each room is beautiful in its own, with different colored silk wallpaper, exquisite furniture, chandeliers, candle holders, statuettes, vases and various other decorations that are very enjoyable to see.We were suggested to go upstairs first and work our way down, which was great because just walking up the grand staircase was impressive on its own and most visitors feel like taking pictures before even entering the first room, due to how wonderful the place itself looks.The ground floor holds armory and pottery and various other items that we had not seen in any of the other museums we visited.If you only have a short stay in London and can't visit all the art museums you'd like, I recommend you choose the Wallace Collection because it won't feel overwhelming and it brings together all the beautiful art you might be looking for.

Like a hidden treasure. Stumbled here and thought I had found a treasure. Great paintings, armoury and other objects. I have been back a few times when I need a break from shopping and it is never as busy as the other London galleries. Nice cafe too but the menu is limited and expensive for what you get.

Fantastic Collection. This is my favorite art museum in London that I've been to so far. It was neat that it was an intact collection from one family, as everything was in fantastic shape and you could see unique examples of furniture, porcelains, armor, and master painters. It was also not too crowded (and I visited in August) and was very manageable as it is in the home that the collectors owned. There are maybe around 20 rooms to see altogether. You could spend lots of time in there or could just pop in and out, as it does have free entry. The guides in each room were extremely helpful and took loads of time to explain paintings and other works in detail.We did not eat at the restaurant, as we didn't have time. We did look at the menu and it was pricey. However, there were lots of people eating there and the setting was quite nice.

A fascinating collection of beautiful things!. I loved the Wallace collection, it was smaller than I thought but not too small, it took about 2 hours to go round but it would be impossible to appreciate everything as there is so much. And the gift shop is really good for gifts etc, would recommend

Amazing private collection. This is undoubtedly the best historical military exhibition in London. The magnificent suits of armour and weaponry are superb. The ancient craftsmanship that went into them is unbelievable considering the workers had no proper tools or electricity. .

Wallace with thanks. This is the most magical space in Manchester Square, a grand house with a sweeping staircase and wonderful Fragonard paintings, beautiful furniture, Canaletto and the Laughing Cavalier. Paintings, swords, lances, suits of armour and an amazing restaurant.

Well Worth Wandering around Wonderful Wallace Collection. A wonderful place to lose yourself into a rich world of beautiful rooms filled with super artifacts wonderful art and a outstanding collection of armoury. Over three floors with at least twenty rooms to explore and a lovely orangery run by Peyton & Byrne just don't forget your wallet. This is a hidden gem away from the hustle and bustle of London . Overlooking Manchester square just a short walk to Selfridges on Oxford Street this is a must see if you love museums.

A peaceful jewel in the heart of London. this is one of the great lesser known attractions in London , minutes from oxford street it is beautifully breathtaking peaceful and full of fantastic artefacts

Another Hidden Gem. Electic or what. Where else can you see top quality paintings, Frans Hals "The laughing cavalier" Fragonards "Girl on a swing" plus beautiful ceramics and even medieval armour. Don't bother with the cafe/restaurant though, looks good but overpriced, rubbish food and apalling service. Many cafes just next door.If you don't want to jostle with all the crowds try the Wallace Collection, you won't be disappointed
outstanding collection. This is well worth a visit if you're in london, and it also runs excellent workshops for kids in the school holidays

A tranquil haven a sones throw from Oxford Street. This place is quite simply amazing. Free of charge and so conveniently located just behind Selfridges and a welcome break within minutes from the hustle of Oxford Street. Some great gems to see including so many masterpieces it is a really well kept secret that you can return to again and again. The orangery is the perfect place for a very nice cup of tea in a delightful location. Go if you can!
Awesome. Staggering collection of fine art and armour, sort of Vienna in miniature. Allow plenty of time for this. It doesn't seem to attract the crowds that other galleries do.

Great place, great location, grim restaurant, mediocre audio guide. It's not off the beaten track as another reviewer has said, it's just behind Selfridges a few minutes walk from Bond Street, we're not talking Suburbia here. The building and the collection are great, this is probably my favourite place to visit in Central London apart from the British Museum. Unlike the Museum it doesn't get too busy, definitely go and see it if you live in London or are visiting. There is a nice display of armour and weapons there which can help keep sulky teenage boys happy, this is cool as kids can make a trip to an exhibition a day of misery. But don't eat there, the restaurant is over priced with a limited menu featuring average food and the service is rubbish; a definite no star. Plenty of good restaurants in the nearby Marylebone High Street so you won't go hungry.The audio guide could be a little better and a few more items could be included but this is a quibble, really good place that everybody should visit. And it's free but it is vey good Kharma to make a voluntary contribution

Beauty and peace on a quiet square. If you're overwhelmed with the crowds and offerings of museums like the National Gallery and the British Museum, do walk over to lovely Manchester Square and into the Wallace Collection.Sadly it's sedom crowded but you get the benefit. To relax even more enjoy a drink or a spot of tea at the glass covered courtyard before heading back out into mainstream Lonon Museum craziness.

Good things come in small parcels.. This private collection has some real gems, spans a wide range of art history. They apparently hold the largest collection of marie antoinette's artifacts anywhere. Moreover there is a fabulous collection of miniatures. A bit off the beaten track but well worth a visit.
A little gem in london. Hidden away and totally worth finding! Beautiful Paintings and museum that was both unexpected and a nice surprise! Go Visit!
Excellent Collection ,. Best kept secret in London, amazing art collection set in a stunning house. Also a lovely courtyard cafe which is an oasis not far from Selfridges.

An absolute gem - don't miss it. Masterpieces of painting and furniture and fascinating arms & armour collections all housed in a beautiful historic house. It is truly splendid. And, amazingly, it's free! There is also a fine cafe/restaurant.

It's free, it's good - go!. It's in a beautiful location with plenty of cafes nearby in the heart of London. You can actually even dine inside the Wallace collection in a very fancy looking cafe. Fabulous collection of 17th century painting. Love it!

The best free visit in London?. We went to see this collection on winter's morning, thinking we could spend an hour or so there...but realised after the first room full of treasures we would need at least half the day, even longer to inspect every item. If you have even only a shallow knowledge of art and art history you will be blown away by the richness on show here - rooms crammed full of paintings many national museums would crave. There are lovely clean bathroom facilities and a cafe in the atrium - which we guessed has a good reputation as one needed to queue for a seat at lunchtime...we cannot say from experience as we did not have the time to wait. Well worth a generous donation!
Very nice. Worth a visit. We liked this museum because it was walking distance from our hotel. I could not find a comfortable place to sit.
worth a visit. fabulous collection of 16th and 17th century painting. Wonderful collection of old armor and weapons.

Superb art gallery / museum. Reminded me of a smaller version of the V&A museum - but was a lot less busy. An excellent collection of paintings - most famous being 'The laughing cavalier'. I was able to stand in front of each picture without queues. Excellent porcelain collection. Interesting range of arms/armour.Lovely courtyard café. I expected to spend an hour or so - turned out to be three hours - and I will go back.

fantastic. great place to have lunch and on a friday evening can have cocktails and dinner perhaps before going to the theatre ,
the house has been left to the trust so it has free entry , well worth a visit

A gem of a freebie. Beautiful and not overly huge house a few minutes north of Oxford Street with a wonderful collection of porcelain, an armoury and interesting rooms filled with art and furniture......and it's free! Visit http://www.wallacecollection.org/ for more information. A real must see!
Interesting but not as awesome as expected. Wonderful artwork but the audio tour was quite underwhelming. Most items were not explained and I might as well of just walked through myself.

amazing look at life in 19th century. a small museum which was a private house of a family of collectors over 5 generations
the owners collected an eclectic range of art and furniture, and a beautiful peaceful courtyard where a casual meal
can be taken. It is off the beaten track and therefore not overcrowded. An insight into earlier times

Amazing. Something for everyone! Paintings china furniture and the home itself.
For you men the best collection of arms and armor I have ever seen!

Hidden Gem - DO NOT MISS THIS!!!. The Wallace Collection was recommended to me by a friend who lives part-time in London as one of her favorite smaller museums. If you are familiar with the Frick Museum in New York City, it is similar in that it is in an beautiful old mansion and is a wonderful collection of artwork. It was absolutely heavenly - quiet, not crowded and filled with tourists - just enough people that you didn't feel alone, but not so many that it distracted from your visit. We chose to eat lunch there, too, in the lovely atrium area - it felt like we were outside, but is actually covered, so no problems with rain and weather. The food there was excellent! This is a lovely place to visit, easy to access and a real treat if you like art - some wonderful pieces are there, including Fragonard's "The Swing". I have been home for a few weeks now from this trip and I am still dreaming about the wonderful Wallace Collection and the delicious lunch! My husband also loved it!

Wonderful collection of art treasures. Beautifully arranged in an impressive house just behind Selfridges, it has to be one of London's little gems. A vast private collection now on show to one and all. Wander in from the hussle and bussle of life on Oxford Street and soak up the timeless atmosphere imagining life of the privileged in days gone by. Such an array of art, furniture, sculptures to behold in what feels like a very private gallery. Craftsmanship of all sorts to appeal to many....just go and enjoy!
Nice Collection to See. Nice Museum close to Oxfort Street with an extensive collection of antiques and art. It really worths a short visit.

You just cannot miss this!!!!. I was told about this by my wife aunt so we thought we would give it a go, what a find, most of the stuff came out of France around the revolution, France's loss our gain. A fantastic art collection with Rembrandt,Caneletto's and many others, with beautiful sculptures, furniture and clocks. the rooms are decorated beautifully and the armouries are great, so good we might go again later in the week!!!!!

Laughing Cavalier. It is the most interesting collection of objects and painting I have seen in one place, so diverse. I could look at the Laughing Cavalier for ages, so much to see in one small painting. Nothing to dislike in the whole place. Amazing.

Historical excellence. The Trustees are congratulated for their policy of retaining complete collections and presenting in a warm and friendly atmosphere. Clocks, furniture, porcelain - treasures for all to see.

Even under renovation it is a must see. The long gallery where the laughing cavalier is usually hung is being renovated so I thought I would miss seeing some of my favorite pieces. Instead, they were hung in other rooms. It was like going to a party and not knowing who you would run into as you turned a corner and entered another room. A joy of an art collection in a magnificant setting.

Wonderful place, be sure to have afternoon tea in the atrium. This is a relatively little known (among most tourists) museum that is truly incredbile. After enjoying the museum, be sure to have afternoon tea in the atrium.

A great hidden gem. I'm a London local. This is a great place to pop in on a lazy weekend afternoon. Lots of incredible Louis XIV furniture (more than you will see at Versailles) and a nice collection of paintings including lots of twee Fragonard, Reynolds, and the like. There's an educational bit in the basement which I believe was about inlaid woodwork when we were there. There's also a sit-down restaurant in the courtyard but it's so bustling I've never been.

A bit boring but worth a visit!. Although the collection and the guide were boring, I like the building and the fact that they keep it free! The cafe is very nice and the shop is very interesting! I recommend this place!

exquisite gallery. We almost missed going to the Wallace Collection, because of an awful street map & faulty directions given by a couple of friendly locals who weren't sure where it was, but I was so glad that we didn't give up looking, & once we found it (tucked away beside a park in Manchester Square, just of Marylebone st) it was so very well worth it! The house in itself is a piece of art- if classic architecture & old english mansions even slightly interest you, then this is the place to visit! Twenty-eight rooms filled with a wide range of art work- something that will interest everyone- french porcelain, antique furniture and many paintings, ranging from Rubens to Murillo to many other european artists; The richly coloured wallpaper only enhance and add to the whole feel of the place, there is also a huge armoury collection-located just behind the cloak room and small gift shop, with knights, horses, swords from all over europe; it was the first time that my wingey 15 yr old who hardly enjoyed anything on all our 20day trip around the UK, grabbed the camera and started snapping away (you're allowed photos with no flash in the Wallace House) The staff are helpful and proud of what they do, one lady even offered to take a photo of the 3 of us in the armoury; there is also a cloak room to leave your bags, where you can leave a small donation here or at the entrance. There was also a lovely restaurant located in the middle of the courtyard, which we would have loved to try, but were in a rush for time. Our time here was very relaxing, and well worth 2-3 hours we spent; a privated art collection, with free entrance, I hardly ever give ratings with "excellent" but the Wallace House well deserves it!

I could not believe my eyes!. I have visited some homes of rich collectors of art, but this small museum is not only in a nice building with great furniture, silver and china - it is chock-full of painted masterpieces! Velazcuez, Murillo, Rubens to name a few. My favorite Watteau - a lot of him, Fragonard and Greuze - not so easy usually to find out of France. One aged gallery attendant was a please to talk with. I was able to explain to him how horrible I believed Boucher was (my only complain - too much of him as well). It is really a great small museum. And it is free. Worth a second visit.

Amazing Art Work Collection in a lovely Mansion. To feast your eyes on a wide collection of art work and architecture, please include the Wallace Collection in your London itinerary as it will not fail to impress. Photography without the use of flash is allowed which is a plus point.

Beautiful china. You give a donation to enter or buy a guide book, then you can wander around the house looking at all the lovely China, Furniture, Paintings etc, it really is worth a good look around if you like looking at Historic houses.

Hidden Gem. It is tucked away off of Oxford Street, but it is simply the best museum in London. There are so many different aspects to the museum, but just go and look at the paintings, and laugh with the Cavalier. The arms on display are a different class, with a particular favourite being one of Napoleon the firsts shotgun, look it up.It is as if the museum has gone to every other museum and had first pick of what they want to diplay.

A Hidden Gem. What a great surprise to find this brilliant collection ! This is a wonderful mansion filled with a great art collection. Go on the guided tour to get the most out of your visit and then walk around the collection afterward. They have a nice restaurant for lunch and eat outside if you can.
Love it!!. Wow. If you want to feel a part of london and its history come here!! The collection of antiques and art plus the tea will not fail to impress

One of best collections in London!. Every piece is world class: old masters by Rembrandt, Rubens, Van Dyck, Gainsborough, fantastic arms and armour collection and wonderfully ornate rooms just off Oxford Street. It feels like an opulent home, but it is, amazingly, free to enter - take a break from shopping and go here instead!

Gift to the nation and the world. Viewing this private art collection that was donatated to the British Nation who shares it with the world was very worth while. Heavy on French furnishings of Louis XIV, XV and XVI. Free with donation sugested. Cafe attached.
Best museum. Best art museum in London. Not to be missed. The cafe serves a very good lunch (though not cheap) and the art is astonishing in its quality.

A Gem. Fabulous room settings and collections in a wonderful building. A place to revisit as there is so much to see, it is Impossible to take it all in. Revisiting is easy as there is no entrance fee. Famous paintings like The Swing and the Laughing Cavalier are real and on the wall here. Charming cafe and the shop has unusual items, Ida for purchasing small gifts. If you want an exquisite place to get out of the rain, or to kill time, or to meet your lover, go here. Of course serious art appreciation takes place too. Something for everyone, mercifully free of rubbernecking tourists. Not to be missed!
a hidden gem. Very interesting collection to view, most people don't make the time to seek out this small collection but it's an excellent way to spend an afternoon.

beautiful setting for lunch with good veterinarian options.. lovely restaurant tucked away amongst the beautiful museum collection in a large conservatory. On a sunny day made a for a wonderful lunch. Good veg options and service with a smile. Would recommend it for a special occasion or just a different day out in London. only :( thing is that with the heat there was quiet a strong sewage smell near the toilets which is near the front of the restaurant, which luckily couldn't be detected in the main dining hall.

A fine free small gallery. The Wallace Collection in Hertford House, Manchester Square is just a stones throw north of Selfridges and is a lovely free small gallery that houses one of the world's favourite famous paintings. "The Laughing Cavalier" by Frans Hals. There is a fine collection of 17th and 18th century European paintings along with weapons and armour along with ceramics of a similar vintage.I sometimes like to spend an hour or two there in the middle of the day as an escape from the shopping around Oxford Street.
A Wonderful Find. Not only is this museum free, it is close to Oxford Street, and a wonderful varied collection of Art, Furniture and China. What a treasure !

A gorgeous place. Beautiful, beautiful !!! Another free museum in London that is a jewel. Do not miss the Marie- Antoinette cabinet and how it was restored. Like many museums, there is a lot to see...so if you have the opportunity split your visit. Otherwise, just pick the highlights.

Second favorite Museum in Europe. It was a cold, wintry day the last time I visited, and the crowds were very thin. I could not enjoy the outside area, but it was almost like having the whole inside museum to my self. It is the perfect size for me, and I love the fact that each room seems to have its own color and decor. This was my second visit, and both times I enjoyed the experience so much I went through twice. And i love the vivid colors of the Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals. Highly recommended.
charming museum in great part of town. check out the cafe, lovely setting, try afternoon tea - museum's collection not to everyone's taste but enjoyable just to wander round the building
Great fun. Trying to find all of Wallace collection is great fun for kids. Also as a adult having your photo taken with different ones is great fun

The Wallace Collection has the best paintings after the National Gallery. This Museum has a wonderful collection of paintings of major and minor grand masters often overlooked by art lovers. It includes paintings like those of Meissonier and Vernet which are little gems but it also has several more famous artist and Grand masters. After your visit to the paintings go to the very splendid restaurant for an up-market lunch. Enjoy!

Very Accessible. There is nothing I disliked about the Wallace Collection. I am a wheelchair user and all parts of the collection that were open were accessible. I especially loved the 18th and 19th century paintings but it was a shame the Great Gallery was closed. We felt the prices in the cafeteria were overpriced and so did not avail ourselves of the refreshments

Spooky exhibits, good food and cute giftshop. The "medicine man" exhibit was a bit unsettling for me. The food is very very nice: a good place for a quick lunch. Giftshop to fascinate a 9-year old boy. Can you say nose-shaped pencil sharpener? Stuffed e-coli?

Super collection to see. Loved everything - amazing originals you can see near by - Flemish collection is outstanding - recently refurbished silk wall covering fabric takes you back in time. Café on site - great place to take a break in be between galleries. Have a great time. We did - oh yes and they have hands on activities for children.

One of London's Best Kept Secrets. Superb collection of 18th and 19th century French and North European treasures, paintings, ceramics, silversmithing and jewellery. Beautifully laid out in a sympathetic manner, approachable for both children and adults. Some excellent interpretation events at weekends, worth looking up programme in advance. Free access.
What a fab collection - and free to boot. This is a super exhibition, especially the horse armour. Wonderful - set aside several hours for this.

Feast for the Eyes. Inside this magnificent house, you will see some very famous and some not so famous paintings, armour from around the world, as well as French porcelain and furniture. The collection was acquired by several generations of the family and it reflects the personal tastes of the collectors, which tended to 18th century France, although other schools and centuries are also represented. At the time I visited, there was a temporary exhibit of early 19th century watercolours that was of great interest. Knowledgeable staff members are easy to find and happy to answer questions; there is information about each room and its contents in binders in that room. There is also a small guidebook for sale at the entrance. The house itself is part of the experience--it invites visitors to step backwards in time to a vanished way of life. The restaurant and cafe offer pleasant surroundings and good food when one has become overwhelmed by the collection. I visited in July 2013, at a time when the British Museum and all the other well-known attractions were bustling, yet the Wallace Collection was uncrowded and exceptionally pleasant.

Worth seeing more than once. One of the last great private collections displayed in an urban residential setting. A uniquely curated collection that provides all the rewards of a museum with all the warmth of a residence, there is a little something here for everyone. You'll especially enjoy this collection if you're interested in the art and science of weaponry.
Hidden treasure. Quiet and wonderful - there's always something which you haven't seen as well the wonderful Rembrandt, Velasquez and Fragonard.

An excellent museum in a beautiful London townhouse. This gem of a museum, housed in Manchester Square (tucked behind Selfridges in Oxford Street) was once the home of the Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace (son of the 4th Marquess) was bequeathed to the British Nation 1n 1897 by the widow of Sir Richard.It boasts a display of magnificent antique collectables and an armoury that is extensive and interesting that could easily rival many European armouries. It is the home of many paintings by Boucher, the world famous 'Girl on a Swing' by Fragonard, also the world renowned 'Laughing Cavalier' by Hals. In recent years the central courtyard has been glazed over and a lovely refreshment area installed within, thereby giving a feeling of taking tea 'alfresco'. Daily lectures, talks and free admission, Open 7 days a week.

A must see. Hidden awat behins Selfrides is this gem of a collection. You can easlity see the lot in a morning or afternoon. Eat in the atrium area and ensure you see the armoury at the rear of the collection.
