Hidden gem. Not a very well-known place, and a bit away from the main touristy areas (it's off Oxford Street), but that means that if you go you will be able to take your time and really see everything properly. Great range of items.

The Laughing Cavalier. The pleasure for me of this house is that the contents have all been collected by one person. And stumbling across the Laughing Cavalier was lovely.If you are interested in people this is a fascinating place to visit.

Hidden Gem. A hidden gem behind Oxford circus! The Wallace Collection is a national museum which displays the wonderful works of art collected in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries by the first four Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace, the son of the 4th Marquess. It was bequeathed to the British nation by Sir Richard's widow, Lady Wallace, in 1897.
Marvellous weapons. Worth a visit for the marvellous collection of medieval arms and armour alone, but there are great paintings and Sevres porcelain collections too. An excellent visit.

A magical place. Just north of busy Oxford Street, this wonderful place is full of delights. Paintings, furniture, ceramics. You will see things you have already seen illustrated. Aren't the originals so much better?
Wallace Collection. Nice, compact museum in the centre of town, near all the shops. Lots of paintings and suits of armour. My husband often takes my sons there whilst I go to the shops.

One of the best sites in London - but one piece of practical advice. Superlatives abound for the splendid Wallace Collection. However, there could be better signage regarding the toilets when visitors first enter. There is a closed door indicating the lift (elevator), but this and the associated stairs take you down to these important facilities (and the lower galleries with the temporary exhibitions, restoration explained and other attractions) - this is not indicated. Also the toilets are individual cubicles along a corridor, so push on the door (unless it is indicated as occupied) to enter.That boring, though useful, bit of information out of the way, please go on and enjoy the many delights of this 'public palace'!
Good gallery. good gallery if the visitor is specifically interested in art and certainly this specialised collection featuring other things of historical value

Look At The Ceiling In The Billiard Room. I was just starting my tour of the collection.I went into the billiard room and looked up at the light fitting.There on the ceiling above was asunburst effect.It must have been a 19th century precursor of art deco.The effect is almost identical to the sunburst effect that you will see on many super cinemas of the 1930s and in particular the Paramount chain in the states and the UK.Excellant collections of art and armour.

Great way to spend an afternoon. The armor collection cannot be beat. They also have an amazing collection of French antiques and art. It's a little out of the way from the Tube but well worth a couple hours.

wonderful experience for anyone. A truely wonderful place. Fantastic exhibits, great location, very helpful interactive staff and a superb restaurant. I am not into paying over the odds for food, but this is an exception. Linger over a coffee or a glass of wine. The food is good, pricey but it is worth every penny to sit in such surroundings. Highly recommended for anyone. Enjoy the paintings and the French armour. Children can try on the armour too. I love it here.

What a gem!. Quite and relaxed. Very cool on a very hot 34 degree day!Incredible collection. So interesting. Blew the British museum out of the water in my opinion. Had a lovely afternoon tea in the courtyard. So glad we didn't miss out on going to visit

Wallace Collection at Hertford House - a must do.. Would've never heard of this if not for Trip Advisor! Took Jubilee tube to Bond St -- not very far from there (walked thru Selfridges) and a few blocks North of Selfridges to Manchester Square. No fee & non-flash photography is allowed. I believe there were audio guides, but we didn't use them. AMAZING painting, armor and china collections. The rooms are lovely - all in different silk coverings & color schemes. Very well planned out, with history placards describing each room. There were Reubens, Fragonard, Rembrandt, Van Dyck's, Broughills, Titians, Raphaels, Vermeers and more. Lovely, intricate furniture - Wedgewood inserts on desks, beautiful clocks (that all kept perfect time). Easy to walk around in and enjoy. Very thoughtfully curated and displayed. There was a large armor room with suits of armor, swords, chainmail and more - from European as well as Indian & Asia cultures. There was an amazing looking additional armor room closed for refurb that had some really large, impressive looking horse armor too. SO many muskets, sheilds, swords and more. Gorgeous detail, gems and carvings.Lovely display rooms with china, curios, protected iconography and biblical papers lovingly preserved. One room just full of snuff boxes & cameos. Everything from painstakingly carved wooden religious items, to gold=plated iconography, illustrated pages from Bibles & Hymnals from the 1300-1400s, onyx statues and more. Quite a bit of statuary in marble as well as onyx. there is a cafe/ restaurant in the middle in a greenhouse type area - lots of people there & then menu looked lovely for tea. There was another exhibit about Paris in the downstairs (go to middle courtyard & down the stairs) that we didn't have time to catch as it was almost closing time ( 5pm) .There is a little giftshop as well as facilities - nice area & hidden gem that I would have had NO idea was here! (Thanks TA!) You could easily spend 3-4 hours there. After your visit - go back 1 block east of Selfridge's to Jame's St. for a great lane/ street of outdoor cafes.

hidden jewel. it's beautiful but i don't think many people know about it. Fab decor (think Versailles) and wonderful art (Laughing Cavalier and The Swing). Finish your visit with a meal or snack it the restaurant. Excellent

One of London's Great delights. I have lived in London for 45 years and had never visited or indeed up to a year ago heard of the collection. i headed of to this delightful part of London and found the impressive building.The building alone is worth the visit. The collection is wide and sometimes strange but fabulous, there is a very good restaurant and I have now been Twice!Admission is free, donations requested

Free admission. Lots to see here. Free admission. A guide booklet is available for purchase-very inexpensive and a nice keepsake. I say adults would appreciate the exhibit more so than children under 12. You can easily spend 2 + hours here. Outdoor eatery has a glassroof. We had refreshments there. I recommend the fresh raspberry lemonade. We were so glad a shop keeper told us about this attraction.

A must see for art lovers!. This modest gallery is off the beaten track so is sometimes overlooked by visitors. That is such a shame as it has some wonderful works (Laughing Cavalier etc) in lovely surroundings. Highly recommended.

A lovely house in London. The contents are the result of a number of generations of collectors who occupied this house.Paintings, furniture of good quality in a lovely house situated walking distance from Bond St.A free tourist experience if you enjoy lovely things.Downstairs a collection of weapons and armour etc. from all over the world would appeal to those interested in militaria.No translations of labels would be irritating if a non English speaker.

My favorite museum in the world. I first visited here in 1973, and I return every trip to London. This museum does not disappoint! A little gem, with high-powered paintings! I recommend this to all of my friends. I have taken my mom and she loved the Watteaus.

A hidden gem in London. It was a rainy day, I had no plans and thought I should do something cultural. So I set off to find the Wallace Collection. It is really worth doing the guided tour as you find out some amazing facts surrounding the paintings. What a collection, we are so lucky to have something so amazing in London, what a wonderful day out, I will take my daughter next time.

The artwork was amazing. The artwork was amazing and to see everything in the lovely rooms of this amazing mansion just added to the experience. The armory collection was huge and would be fun together with children who like fairytales of knights and such. I would recommend visitors to start the tour by making a reservation at the cafe/restaurant if you would like to eat there as it gets very busy.

Fantastic Exhibition. The beautiful building, wonderful collection of paintings and antiquities, nice coffee shop, clean toilets and it is all free, except for the coffee shop. The suits of armour were amazing. What a little gem of a museum this is.

Small 5-generation collection of art. I love small museums of collectors where besides art, what you see and feel is the personal interest and distinctive tastes of a passionate collector. The Wallace is exactly that kind of place and it is located in the beautiful setting of the house inhabited by the collectors. There is a lot of to see, but you won't like everything because it is so diverse, so you can walk faster in certain rooms and focus on what really touches you. The temporary exhibition on watercolours of Paris in the 1800's by English painters is worth visiting too. Even using the ladies room is a pleasant experience.
beautiful!. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem, with Fragonards, Titians and an amazing collection of cameo boxes.

Quirky museum. A nice independent quirky museum in a peaceful London square away from the hustle and bustle of busy streets. A unique collection of various interests. The cafe is lovely and nice for afternoon tea.

Nice museum, and a hidden gem (terrace at the back of the museum). Lovely place to visit. Nice museum and then... there is this magnificent terrace where you can enjoy lovely food and drinks !
Combine culture with holiday feeling...

hidden treasure. This museum was reasonably close to our hotel so we thought we`d give it a visit. What a great museum. Two floors of the collections of the Wallace family. You can take photos (no flash). There were displays of two fully equipped knights on horeseback, a small canon, Impressive armoury rooms and also really good paintings (Rembrandt for example), beautiful decorative collections, etc. They also have a lovely restaurant in their courtyard. Well worth a visit.

A bit stuffy, but a lovely collection. It may have been an off day for me, but I'm also not a huge fan of 18th century French art and that is the bulk of the Wallace Collection. Housed in a lovely Regency building, it is a lovely couple of hours stroll if you are in the Marylebone area anyway, but I'm not sure I would go out of my way again to visit. The do have a lovely (if overpriced) tea room as well.

What a wonderful collection. Just behind Selfridges is one of the must visit museums and all for free. In a beautiful London mansion is housed a stunning collection of fine art, furniture, armour, sculptures, clocks and porcelain along with a very nice restaurant. It is worth two hours of anyone's time in my opinion and I look forward to returning

Yet another massive fan. I have been to the Wallace Collection a number of times, with friends or family for an afternoon wandering around. Minutes from Bond Street station, and free, it's tucked quietly into a regent Marylebone square and is one of my favourite places to go in London, full-stop. Construction began on what was originally called Manchester House in 1766. The building was bought into the Hertford family in 1797 and in 1871 when one of the family, Richard Wallace, moved there from Paris he brought much of the family's art collection with him. Following his death, the building became a museum in 1900. Not unlike the Frick Collection in New York, this is an enthralling attraction on three fronts. Firstly, it is a world-class collection of art, including paintings by Titian, Hals, Rembrandt, Rubens, Canaletto, Gainsborough, Reynolds and van Dyk. All in one place, these are some of the most eye-catching assets you might find in any single art collection in London, not to mention the furniture and works of sculpture which abound throughout the building. Secondly, it is a beautiful piece of architecture and interior design in its own right. It is the product of several developments, begun by architect Joshua Brown, with subsequent additions and changes throughout the 19th century, and developments including a roof over the courtyard added only a few years ago. The interior design is also intricate, with every room in perfect proportion and displaying gorgeous use of colour. Thirdly, in especial similarity to the Frick, it is a fascinating snapshot of a home once occupied by a wealthy family. It offers visitors a window into the social history of the city. The art that is housed in all this splendour is an insight into knowing tastefulness, conspicuous consumption, and the pursuit of wealth that lasts beyond the human lifespan, all of which characterise the life of Victorian aristocracy. If you fancy some fine art, a resplendent setting and a bit of social history while you're at it, and you want to be able to access it for free, you really can't do better than this jewel.

if you have time to visit only one museum in London, then this is it. This smaill museum displays the best quality of artwork, furniture, porcelain, glass, and more; set up beautifully in what used to be the Wallace family manor. Allow yourself at least 2 hours here to absorb the pieces on display leisurely.

What a family collection!. Off Manchester Square, 100m west of Marylebone High Street is the 'Wallace' Collection. Generations of wealthy & powerful family members 'collected' Euro treasures and here they are! Priceless and irreplaceable objets d'art. Curiosities, Paintings. Sculptures. Porcelain. Furniture. Weapons. & so on & so forth. As mentioned in earlier reviews, a 2nd visit is in order, next time will hire the headphones (admission is gratis by donation only). Lighting was NOT bright enough for the writer to view all displays easily, but was surprised at the QUALITY of the displays and delighted by the friendly / helpful nature of staff at this National museum. Highly recommended.
Great hidden treasure. Not in the typical turistic tour but an absolutely straordinary museum with a great lounge bar where enjoy the best tea.

One of London's hidden treasures. Housed in a beautiful London town-house, this is an art collection bequeathed by one family and free of charge. You can view Old Masters, fine paintings, furniture, miniatures, surprises around every corner, the building is almost as beautiful as the art itself. I visited with my sister and our 'quick visit' turned into three hours and we still didn't quite get through it before they closed. There's a cafe on a terrace that would be an amazing lunch spot, perhaps next time. The largest gallery room was closed while we were there but you won't miss it as paintings have been moved into other rooms. Each room has a theme and there are guide sheets available to talk you through the highlights. The decor of the rooms themselves is worth noticing. I feel lucky to have found this jewel of a place and intend to make more time to spend there soon.

Wonderful House Tour. We had a morning to tour something in London before embarking on our cruise. We searched Tr[p Advisor for things to do in London and found excellent reviews of this collection. It was a brief walk from our hotel. The collection of decorative arts and painting is outstanding. There are notebooks in each room providing information about all the furnishings and art work in the room.

Amazing Armour Collection!!. If you enjoy to see guns, swords, armours and more you surely must go there and check it out.
This collection seems to be bigger than other I've visited before.

Highly recommended........ Decided to visit the Wallace Collection to fill time before a tour at Portcullis House.We were so impressed with the quality and diversity of the collectionthat we have already decided to return soon and spend more time there.If you don't particularly like guided tours the friendly and helpfull staff in each roomwill give you all the history and information you need.Well worth a visit.....and it's free....

see this. lots of very interesting art, history and special exhibits... a good place to visit when you go to London off season- say the winter or early spring when days are short and weather not so good. Sooooo many great London museums
hidden gem. private collection, interesting and beautifully displayed. versatile tastes will be satisfied, because of the diversity of artifacts
Cultural Oasis. Excellent collection of Marie Antionnette's furniture and art. A good restaurant in the basement makes the visit a very special occasion.

Great place for breakfast. A hidden gem near Marylebone, wonderful breakfasts or afternoon tea.Also take a trip downstairs to try on armour! Cafe probably not so small child friendly as rather reserved.

Eclectic private collection, free admission. A short walk from Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is chock full of paintings, statues, armor, clocks and other artifacts. Well worth a one or two hour visit.,

Charming Collection. I was fortunate to arrive just in time for a free guided tour of the highlights of this lovely collection. The tour guide was full of interesting explanations and anecdotes which really brought the place to life. The tour started at 2.30pm and lasted about 45 minutes. Afterwards I was encouraged to continue my visit alone and thoroughly enjoyed myself. They have wonderful paintings, furniture, porcelain and a large armoury. You can happily spend a few hours here and the best thing is: it won't cost you a thing!

Perfect size for an enormous collection.. This is probably my favorite museum in London. The extent of the collection is very impressive, but one does not feel overwhelmed by size of some of the better known super sized experiences. Because I have some limitation with walking I found this museum was perfect to see a great collection within my ability to walk and stand for lengths of time.

Interesting and Eclectic for a couple of hours. The Wallace Collection is set back behind Marylebone High Street and houses an idiosyncratic collection of armour, furniture, art and other antiquities that allow you to while away a pleasant few hours as you stroll. The museum also houses a unique cafe that serves quite a nice lunch under glass in the style of the British Museum's atrium. I have visited many times with older friends (its not very child friendly) and my parents and they thoroughly enjoyed it. My only gripe is the staff can be stuffed shirts. I suspect that there may be some inconsiderate visitors that require marshalling, but once of twice I have bristled!

beautiful house, grand furniture, fine art and more. less than 5 mins walk from Selfridges on Oxford street is this amazing home full of fine art, furniture, clocks, porcelain, armory and many famous paintings too. It is not at all crowded and there are many seats for leisurely viewing. No bus loads of school chilldren here to distract you either

Forget the big guys, this gallery is a gem. Beautiful house, fabulous collection of works of art, an airy stylish restaurant and all for free.
The restaurant is a bit pricy but saves you trying to find another.

This Hidden Intimate Gem. We found this museum by chance and only peeked in the first time around. It looked like a grand walled mansion on the outside and I thought perhaps the focus of the collection would be fancy paintings and furniture. I was very wrong and would have missed a wonderful collection if I went with my first impression. I had by this point been the major museums in town: The V&A, The Tates, The British Museum which are all multi-day excursions that overwhelm you. I loved the Wallace because not only was it manageable within a morning or afternoon visit but because it had a very good collection. It had the architecture, the jewellery, the relics, the furniture, the paintings, and my personal favorite, weapons and armor. They even had a section where children (and adults) can try helmets and mail shirts. The cafe had very good food with reasonable medium/high pricing. If you are looking for a more intimate half day museum visit that doesn't skimp on anything visit the Wallace Collection.

Stunning - A MUST See!. A great collection of art, set in amazing setting - 5 min walk off Oxford Street. The restaurant on site was stunning, service a little slow but great place to take in the atmosphere.I would definitely come back here - the rooms are stunning.

Great spot for art and lunch!. Loved our 11:30 tour today - beautiful home, fabulous art, delicious cafe! Amazing pieces of art, furniture and porcelain - love seeing items that were once Marie Antoinettes, as well as paintings by Gainsborough, Rembrandt, and many more! The tour is free, but lunch is not - delicious, but not inexpensive. Cute French cafe in an outdoor garden setting.

So much to see. We went for my boyfriend's mother's birthday and she really enjoyed it. There were amazing paintings, silverware and exhibits. We went for afternoon tea in the beautiful glass ceilinged atrium and loved the food.

an out of the way museum..worth the trip. fascinating look at the 1% crowd's houses. well thought out layout and lots of gorgeous porcelains. And a lovely lunch spot/tea room in an atrium. great gift shop as well

Not just for a rainy day. The Wallace Collection is situated a minute's walk from the rear of Selfridges and must be one of the unsung heroes of London destinations, tucked away on the north side of Manchester Square. There is a delicious collection of art from various European centres and with names of artists that trip off the tongue of even those least educated in art. Free to the public, but do make a donation, the works from the 16th century (earlier indeed) to the 19th century are appealing with only a limited number of less interesting pieces and far more of those that really buy the eye. We were there only briefly, mainly to show a friend the Laughing Cavalier. For that alone it is worth a visit. As per the title, don't leave it for a rainy day. There is a very good cafe/restaurant on the premises but I chose not to use it today as time was limited. If you do intend to eat then I would recommend earlier rather than later as, with a lot of venues, staffing levels for those taking lunch there may be a tad stretched - but perhaps that has changed since my visit previous to this one.

Art and history in a lovely bite sized museum. London has its fair share of great museums that you'd need a whole day to explore. This one, is an exception but only in its size, not quality - you can easily make the most of your visit even in a couple of hours, yet if you wish to linger longer, there is more than enough great art, Sevres porcelain, object d'art and historic architecture to spend a whole day soaking in. Just the right size for small kids - and there are lots of free activities to keep kids busy.Best of all, it is completely free. The mansion is in itself worthy of a visit, opulent and lavish in its decoration and furniture. The art collection is top quality, and the big artists are represented by their better or larger works, so you are not going to be disappointed. The Atrium restaurant is a welcome end to your visit, food and service were both high quality.
Worthwhile. Wonderful art, furnishings - a gorgeous house and a most amusing guide. We had lunch at the restaurant which was lovely - like being outside as it is a covered courtyard.
Brilliant. So much to see in a beautiful environment . Should add to your list of places to go when visiting London .

Small museum with good collection. Good fixed collection with a changing exhibition (last year had Damien Hirst). Right size for doing the whole museum and then has a very good cafe in the atrium - which also does dinner on Friday and Saturday evenings.

Always worth a visit. Outstanding of collection French 18th century painting, furniture and porcelain with superb Old Master paintings and a world class armoury. Special exhibitions and great free guided tours. All housed in 25 galleries in a historic London townhouse. London has so many fabulous art galleries but visitors should remember this jewel in W1 and it's free!
A taste of sophistication. A nice small collection in a beautiful building. Good cafe. Variety of objects d'art and paintings to see.
Well done Wallace. Lovely, historic, measure for measure of class, great venue for fun and friendship, history and elegance.

Best Armoury in London. We've been here at least twice now and have plans to return, a fascinating collection in a grand house. The museum frequently has wonderful exhibitions and it's well worth checking out the website for info on these. Generally if you love art you'll love this mini Aladin's Cave of culture.

Hidden gem. This collection is amazing with a great variety of beautiful and interesting items (paintings, furniture, porcelain, armour, decorative items, etc) contained in a wonderful building. My partner normally gets bored after an hour in galleries but was very content to spend time and wander here. Make sure you check under the leather covers on the cabinets as there are some fabulous items there. A great collection of Sevre porcelain. While I am not into armour and war items the collection here was surprisingly interesting. Entry is free. While the cafe/restaurant is slightly pricey it was very pleasant sitting in the courtyard and the cake I had was delicious. I will definitely go back on my next trip to London.

A lovely, underated museum.. Behind Selfridges, in darkest Oxford Street lies one of the underated museums of London. Primarily a museum of Painting and sculpture, it is a very pleasant environment, with a large central courtyard, with refreshments and a large pond.Very central to get to, as Bond Street tube station is only a few hundred yards away, it is lovely to dip into and spend an hour or so, return again for further browsing

Fantastic collection of art. Astounding collection of Baroque and Roccocco art and furniture, minutes from Oxford Street. Great, volunteer led guided tours available daily. Lovely atrium restaurant too, An oasis in the West End.

Tea and scones with abundance of culture.. I simply loved this venue. A lovely garden cafe and cream tea. Interesting musuem and a lovely garden to take in the sun with a glass of lemonade. All right in the heart of London. 5 minutes walk from Selfidges, Oxford Street and Marylebone village.
A great small collection. A terrific collection in an environment which is peceful and uncrowded (at least when I was there). I think it is one of the gems of London galleries/museums.

Lovely. Beautiful collection of amazing things in the heart of London and yet in a very quiet location. The Wallace Collection is free but it is well worth making a donation although there is no pressure to do so. Lovely restaurant.

Gobsmackingly Gorgeous. If you want to see the absolute best of the Fine and Decorative Arts in London, head straight to the Wallace Collection. Admission is free-of-charge but visitors are encouraged to make a £5 donation. All of the collections displayed are of staggering high quality - Old Master paintings (English, French, Italian and Dutch schools); French porcelain (as recently featured on BBC 4's programme 'A Passion for Porcelain'); armour and weaponry; early Italian maiolica; miniatures; be-jewelled gold boxes and other exotic knick-Knackery; furniture; clocks etc. etc. You will need at least 3 hours to do this museum collection justice - longer if you eat in the classy restaurant on- site. What a privilege to have such an amazing repository of the Arts displayed just a stone's throw from London's Oxford Street. The house is beautiful - lavish decoration and interior fittings. The shop stocks an amazing range of arts-related books as well as other souvenir items.
Fantastic .. Brillant,really worth seeing.Full of wonderful paintings and porceline.An absolute oasis in the middle of London.Will always go back to see it again.Loved it.

A superb private collection. After seeing the armor collection at the Wallace, you are unlikely to see another of this quality and variety. Although armor collections usually do not hold my interest very long, I found it hard to leave this one to see other varied treasures at the Wallace, including two small and delightful Rembrandts as well as larger canvases by him and a good collection of other painters, especially Watteau and Fragonard. There is also an excellent gift shop.

Wonderful & Varied Collection. This is a wonderful Museum with loads of antiques and paintings. Many different periods are represented in the beautiful surroundings and so close to Selfridges and Oxford St.

Simply wonderful. If I had one day in London,this is where I would go.I guess it's the combination of history,tradition ,beautiful architecture and the superb art and furniture displayed in a way that is not overwhelming but simply there for you to enjoy.
Worth seeing. Beautiful furniture, elegant rooms and the guide told interesting stories. One is away from the madding crowd .
A unique collection. The paintings and Boulle furniture are superb. There are some amazing ivory carvings and other minkiatures.

Great Location. Wallace Collection is a definitely a must-see if you're visiting in London. It's not over-crowded so it's as if you got the whole place to yourself. There are no barriers between the art and the visitors which allows an extremely up-close examination of the paintings and objects. The staff is very helpful: ask them any question and you have an expert to yourself. Its restaurant/cafe is also a nice place to relax and read over a cup of tea.

Museum special, afternoon tea one of the best. We come here for afternoon tea after going through the museum. This is, as others have said, a hidden treasure! The ending for us is always the tea. The selection of scones, cakes and sandwiches with a glass of sparkling wine puts the finishing touches on a great day in London.

One of a kind!. Hertford House is now one of my favourite places in London. It houses one of the most exquisite private collections of fine art and decorative art in the world. It also has one of the finest collections of European Arms and Armour.The collection -- known as the Wallace Collection -- was assembled over five generations of one massively wealthy family: the first four Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace. Today there are a whopping 5,500 works of art in the collection!There is no admission cost to this museum and there is a free on-site tour available inside. Our tour guide Rebecca really made the visit a great experience.No way on a single visit can one really appreciate everything there is to see at Hertford House.

Beautiful period house. The house has wonderful miniature collections, a huge armoury, and interesting paintings, including The Cavalier, a wry glancing gentleman who was probably on his way to a good party, or an his way back from one. While the collections are great, the real show is the house itself. It is decorated in it's original style, with original furniture wherever possible giving a peek back into a different time in a holistic fashion.
Really worth a visit. If you want to see weapons and armour, this is the place to come. There is a nice selection of things to look at, and best of all, it is not crowded like many other museums.

Worth a visit if time permits. Really easy to get to, took a bus from Trafalgar Square ( #13 ) and got off at Gloucester place , near the George street intersection. A 5 min walk along George street , turn right on Manchester Street and you see the board directing you to the front entrance . I was given a free floorplan to get started. At first glance, it doesn't look very big, but once you're inside, there are quite a few rooms to cover. I spent a little less than 2 hrs , and it was really worth it.The house itself is amazing , and the balustrade along the stairs leading to the first floor is quite stunning . The decor in each room is beautiful and complements the paintings , chandeliers, furniture and intricate clocks ( in some of them ) . There were hand books with explanations for the paintings , which are quite different to the usual stuff you'd find in some of the bigger museums. What I really enjoyed, is that you can get really close to the paintings to have a look, without any rope barrier between you and the painting. The armoury section was interesting . Photography was permitted everywhere as long as no flash was used. The only thing I found a little annoying, was the lighting for the bigger paintings. If you stood close to the paintings , there was so much glare that you couldn't view it well. So in most cases I'd have to go to the other end of the room, which no doubt gave you a better view , but with my short sightedness was a slight drawback. However, this is such a small issue that I wouldn't worry about it. I didnt get to try the restaurant, but it looked beautifully laid out and inviting...maybe next time . All in all a must see if time permits. On exiting the museum, diagonally across the road on your right is a short cut to Baker Street ( I think it was Fitzharding Street) from where you can catch a bus. I didn't realise I could just cut across and did the long route , returning the way I came from George street. Walked back to Orchard Street and popped into M & S before hopping on the bus again.Note: I was there exactly at opening time 10am . Apart from me, there were only another 3 or 4 people and it made moving around easy. I'm not sure how crowded it gets later on , but would recommend getting there early.

A "hidden gem". The Wallace collection is an excellent museum and bistro style café in the heart of London. A fascinating collection of historic artefacts and some really good artwork make this a really interesting place to visit.Moreover, the bistro/restaurant is excellent! Great food and a wonderfully relaxing place to simply grab a coffee or a quick bite to eat.

Hidden gem off Oxford street a haven of calm from all the bustle of the shops. Just a short walk away from behind Selfridges you can enjoy peace and calm at the Hertford Hse. You need to allow at least an hour and half but more if you can! The rooms all have interesting deco, of the era and items to compliment, a bygone time of great opulence for the wealthy. It has a substantial collection of paintings none of which are modern. We did not feel overwhelmed by over visitors even though we went on a Saturday afternoon. It has an impressive cafe/restaurant which we did not use so cannot comment. The biggest bonus was this visit was free....how do they do it!

Excellent and it's Free!!. We just happened to pass by and we saw that it was free so we decided to have a peep. Wow!To start the building is beautiful. the decor and furniture very opulent and plush if a little too ornate and gilded but so interesting to see. Rooms and rooms of exquisite porcelain and paintings, miniatures and chandeliers , drapes , columns , so much to see! Beautifully maintained and very elegant. I will probably go again as there is a room full of Canaletto 's paintings that I would like to spend more time observing. Amazingly the entry is free but you can leave a donation.

An absolute must for art and history buffs. The collection was amassed in both England and France, and is tended by a very knowledgeable group of guides. We asked a young man about how the collection came about, and discovered a rich trove of knowledge. The armoury collection is the finest you could imagine, with full suits of armoury and weaponry from Europe and Asia. Read the small signs at the entry to each room, and look out for the Marie Antoinette collection. The furniture is stunning, with glorious pieces in every roo, and the paintings are amazing. If there is not just one Canoletto, but too many to count.

Hidden treasury in a very busy area. If you are in London and want to visit something not too touristic, I would definitively recommend the Wallace collection, hidden just behind Bond Street and Marble Arch.The atmosphere is perfect, to let you immerge in another century, the collection perfectly preserved.Last but not least, try the restaurant at the back, a real gem.

A Real Gem Tucked Away in a Residential Neighborhood. After many days seeing some of the more prominent sights in London, I went to see this collection which is tucked away in a residential neighborhood. The manor in which this collection is housed is historic by itself. Add to it an interesting, wide-ranging collection, a small crowd, and it's like going to the Phillips Collection in D.C. - only with more history, and a great story behind it.

A light reprieve from the usual museum fare.. I like the Wallace collection for its organized format travelling room to room, you did not get weighed down with data but saw the unusual , I really liked the armor collection, quite unique.

a wonderful mix with some outstanding pictures .. If you don't know this place , it is well worth a visit, it is a collection of painting , objects & furniture , housed in a purpose-built replica of an Italian Palazzo on Manchester Square. It is small enough to see everything without being exhausted and rarely crowded. There is a very nice restaurant in the glassed over central courtyard - best to book a table. Altogether , very civilized.

Real gem. One of my favourite London Museums. An eclectic collection, with some famous paintings. I am sure that there must be times when it is busy but i have never been there when it is. It is nice to be able to walk around without the bustle of other museums.

Terrific out of the way museum. If you do not have time for the National Gallery go to the Wallace Collection. It has a wonderful if eclectic collection of art and is worth spending some time viewing it. It is situated in a quiet neighborhood and has a lovely tea room
Lunchtime off Oxford Street. Stumbled upon the Wallace when cutting through from Oxford street and spent a wonderful lunchtime there. The quality and depth of the collection is amazing.

Great for a rainy day. The house itself is decorated in such a way, that I found myself marvelling at that in equal proportions to the art. I heard a talk on armours which was quite interesting. Girl on a swing and the laughing cavalier are some of the famous pieces housed there. Definitely worth coming back to take in all that is there, plus I plan to sample the award winning vegetarian menu. Bonus is there's no entry fee!

Lovely Collection,. Was here many years ago and just went for return visit on Saturday, June 8. No entry fee, you buy a guide for 5 GBP. Lovely collection of Sevres porcelain, miniatures, and incredible French furniture. Lovely enclosed garden café and restaurant for breakfast, lunch and dinner too!

Guns,nudes and delicious food. We visited the Collection with a varied age group of 5 from 9 to 75 and there was something for everyone. The 9 year old boy loved the Armour and guns and the older members were fascinated by the art collection, but being philistines rather than art historians, were curious about the lack of clothing on at least 75% of the models depicted! After questioning the many helpful guides we came to the conclusion that the majority of the paintings were 17th century pornography painted for the delight of the upper classes. All very interesting but the very young girls in suggestive poses are not really acceptable in today's climate so must be viewed as part of a history that, although cannot be erased, has to be looked on as unacceptable today. The restaurant in this magnificent building is worthy of a 5* rating. The youngest member of our family party (who ate an octopus starter and a whole Dover sole) is nut intolerant and the care and help given to him by the excellent staff was second to none. The quality of the ingredients and the way they were cooked were amazing and we recommend anyone wanting a meal in top class surroundings books here straightaway. All in all a fascinating way to spend a Sunday, or any other day of the week.

"SNUFFBOX". As lovely as their fine little snuffboxes!! Absolutely adorable! I'll come back to London and definetely visit this gem! (Not mentioning the restaurant which is great as well!) Each room reveals hidden wonders!

Best kept secret in London. I was totally blown away with the collection! The museum has one of the best collections of armour that I have ever seen. Well worth the time to visit. Make sure you stop by the cafe as well.
A nice little museum. Unlike major museums, a short tour and clarifies the lives of people who lived in structure, throughout their lives, their clothing, etc.
Wallace Collection. A truly fabulous collection with people on hand to explain the finer points of the canvasses - well worth a visit

Great Collection. This museum isnt as well known as other spots in London, but well worth the visit. If you like armour and weapons, there is a room for you. Oils and objects d'art were extremely good

A little gem hidden away. A personal collection of an eclectic group of armour, paintings, furniture and fine china, this collection also houses some very fine Old Master paintings.
From what I read, the collection of armour is second to home and is sure to inspire the kids.

Treasure trove behind Oxford street. I love the collection of this museum, its got the best armour ever from all over the globe, as well as great exhibitions and permanent artworks. Afterwards we enjoyed afternoon tea in the covered central foyer, service was efficient and friendly. It felt like a very special treat, when all I wanted to do was get out of shopping!

A really great little find. This was a really fantastic collection, easy to get around and not over crowded. Some amazing paintings and furniture in lovely rooms, with armour to marvel at too. A great place to visit if you don't like huge museums.
Great Little Museum. This is a great place, jam packed with stuff. It's a little off the beaten path, but definitely worth a visit.

Great collection and very child friendly. We brought our children to the Wallace Collection for The Little Draw, which allows children to go into the collection, sit and draw. The children really enjoyed finding a piece that they really liked and drawing it . They also enjoyed seeing the armor collection, which encourages children to put on replica armor and chain mail, as well as some of the various weapons that are on display. The staff are very friendly and tolerant of excitable children. The collection is very nice and in a beautiful setting. It all adds to such wonderful experiences you can have in London.

Why didn't I discover it earlier?. This is my fourth trip to London and I was wondering why I did not vist the Wallace Collection in my previous trips. This is a true gem tucked away in a quiet corner in Manchester Sq, away from the busy streets in Oxford Circus. The collection is interesting, not as huge as the big museums (which sometimes could come across as too much) and yet enough to warrant a nice and comfortable visit. A truly unforgettable visit.Must make it a point to go.

The best old french furniture outside Paris. The old master paintings here are outstanding as the French 18th century furniture. The Gallery is one of the must see monuments when you are visiting London for more than 5 days.
It is a pity that the court has been covered by a glass roof so that there is not enough fresh air around in the restaurant.

Little Jewel at the heart of London. I loved seeing the Wallace collection with my mum. She was very impressed. It was very comfortable and lots to see. All paintings and other objects to be seen where all well organised and explained. Plenty of resting areas. We also enjoy coffee at their impressive coffee/restaurant

Hidden Treasure. This little treasure is located near the shopping district on a quiet little square. When I walked in, I was overwhelmed by the beauty of the entrance way. There are so many objects and paintings to see. There is also a huge armoury, albeit, a large section is closed for renovation until 2014. The room with all the Cannelettos just blew me away. Nice little gift shop as well.

The best small museum in London. Beautiful collection of fine arts - very intimate, well organized with plenty of worthy and professional explanations. A delightful two hours tour. will definitely return among our next visit to London.
Beautiful collection, must see. Beautiful collection, that one should not miss.Some really nice painting and amazing collection of clocks and watches.

Second only to the Borghese in Rome. Why isn't more said or written about this remarkable museum and grand home on Manchester Square in London? Perhaps we had not done our homework properly, but it took 5 visits to London before we visited this magnificent property. It is truly astounding. Firstly, the "home" is over the top handsome and furnished with some of the most beautiful furniture I have ever seen. Then you add an astonishingly varied collection of great art, sculptures, china, armour and the like all tastefully presented in many different rooms. This is one treasure trove of beautiful things. There is also a lovely courtyard where light refreshments are served. Worthy of note -- admission to the Wallace Collection is free. If you love beautful and priceless treasures in a gorgeous setting, do visit this National Museum jewel. For my money, it is second only to the Borghese Gallery as a collection of great treasures amassed by a private family.

What a wonderful place. Visited the Wallace Collection in May 2013 - the first think that strikes you is how peaceful the little square is and how wonderful the building is - you can imagine all the things that have happened there, it feels like you're touching history! There is a non-fussy feeling about the House, and you are left to wander on your own, or you can join an informative guide for a tour. The decoration of the house itself is so beautiful, and you can just marvel at that alone, without even taking notice of the exhibits - the chandeliers especially are absolutely amazing. The exhibits themselves include portraits (The Laughing Cavalier) and interesting, funny paintings of everyday scenes. The collection of suits of armour is second-to-none, I especially loved the horse armour. This place really allows you to imagine yourself back in time, and I wish I lived nearer so that I could visit it more regularly, there is so much to see. AND IT'S FREE.
A real gem in the heart of London. We spent the whole of Sunday morning here, as we thought it was going to rain (it didn't). The place is facinating and the restaurant/cafe is just gorgeous.
Excellent lunch in the atrium!. Wonderful surroundings. The atrium is now a larger restaurant area which can be visited independently of the collection. It makes an excellent venue for lunch or tea.
A treat. I like that despite being a museum you still feel you are in a private house , a grand one but still a house

Largest Private Museum In Europe. It is rare to find a private museum that has such a large variety of beautiful objects within its confines. A true pleasure it is to walk through the House of Sir Richard Wallace. Although his past may be filled with controversy, the pieces or art and luxury featured here give us access to a whole other world, before our time.This is an experience I want everybody to have.
Excellent small museum collection. Fantastic collection of the masters works, not crowded at all, easy to get to on bus #74. Worth the visit.

Wow!. Generally unknown to tourists, but deserves to be on every itinerary. Free, good restaurant and the collection is unbelievable. Paintings by every conceivable great artist, rare china, jewellery, antique weapons and armour ... Not to be missed.

Least known of fabulous museums in London. Shhhhh....don't tell anyone......it free and fabulous. Inside tea area a great place to relax.Can't think of a thing I didn't like.Home of the Laughing Cavalier.

lovely armor. Because my son (alas) dislikes paintings, we looked at only a few of the paintings (some very interesting paintings by Rubens). But he loved the armor collection (even though one of the three rooms devoted to armor was closed for renovation). Since admission is free, going to see even a small part of the exquisite collection is eminently reasonable. I'd highly recommend the collection, to anyone who has any interest in any of the fields their collection includes.

Hidden Gem. An unexpected treasure in an unexpected location. Whilst in general art is not my first choice of things do and see, the house is well worth seeing, the variety of art is interesting as is the armour and the atrium restaurant was a fantastic location for lunch

Mrs. We decided to see the Wallace collection on our last day in London as it was a very rainy day. We were not disappointed! Found it easy, a short walk north of Selfridges. The artwork was amazing and to see everything in the lovely rooms of this amazing mansion just added to the experience. The armory collection was huge and would be fun together with children who like fairytales of knights and such. I would recommend visitors to start the tour by making a reservation at the cafe/restaurant if you would like to eat there as it gets very busy. We didn't want to wait so we left and had our lunch at the corner of Wigmore and James St. at Ayoush, a moroccan restaurant. Fabulous tagine!

What a little gem!. I've come to London so many times having grown up in the shires, and yet this was the first time I had visited this museum. Just behind Oxford Street (near to Selfridges) is the one-time mansion of a family of great collectors - and it has been wonderfully kept together. There is some exquisite fine art (including the Fragonard swing), much French "court of Versailles" furniture, armoury including unusual Sikh helmetry, ceramics, enamels etc etc. And all free for entry - though I certainly would recommend you make the suggested donation or buy a guide book - it certainly is worthy of support. And in the atrium in the middle of the house is a light and airy restaurant with a tempting menu. We spent a good 3 hours here, and still did not feel we did it all justice. But what a delight to take a break from shopping, get away from the hurly burly in the contemplation of some wonderful art, then refresh yourself with afternoon tea - or meet up after a long days shop for a relaxed and tranquil dinner?
Great free museum. Love this place, but was not impressed by the food in their cafe, but it is a lovely room in which to have lunch
a house with incredible amont of art pieces. a house full of different kinds of art, in a castle that the Wallace family had collected. Free admission

A hidden gem. London has famous museums like British Museum, V&A , National History etc. However just up the road from Selfridges is the Wallace Collection. It is superb and has many exhibits like Ranjit Singhs sword which cannot be seen elsewher

excellent collection. Not an art fan and just went because my friend was in town and she had specific items to see for her art appreciation class. That said, it was a very good collection and I had a very good time wandering through it and enjoyed the pieces quite a lot. I may grow to enjoy museums and art galleries yet!

Awesome!. Allow yourself at least a week to see every display in this magnificent collection in Manchester Square, Marylebone. Particularly notable is the amazing collection of arms and armour, of all ages and nationalities, which must be one of the best in the world.

I'm sorry I waited so long to visit this museum!. London is a very large and very old city, and it has many hidden gems and treasures. If you spend a week in London, you can visit several deservedly famous museums or historical buildings every day and never make it down the list to places like the Wallace Collection.But it's smaller museums like the Wallace Collection or Sir John Soane's House that, I think, really give you a feel for England. Both of these museums are former private residences that have been converted into museums in order to display the original owner's collections of art and antiquities.The Wallace Collection is a mansion near the Bond Street tube station. Admission is free, and the collection is amazing. The sheer quantity of artwork by famous painters that line the walls is overwhelming. And the furniture and clocks and other items in each room are equally deserving of your attention. The massive collection of armor is comprehensive and very well preserved.I've visited London a dozen times, and I'd never even heard of this museum. It was recommended to me by a tour guide at the Museum of the Order of St. John (also worth a visit). I'm glad I finally got to see it.

Great objects and works of art in a distinctive setting. The feeling of being in the townhouse of a 18th/19th C patron of the arts is what sets this gallery apart.The paintings themselves are mostly fine, and in some cases less fine examples of the "old masters" - you will not find anything here from after about 1820. The galleries are all actual rooms in the house and titled accordingly - Landing, Salon, Drawing Room East etc. This is the only place in London to see really decent Canalettos, Bouchers and the like. From the catalogue the armoury (which I did not see) looks splendid and would undoubtedly appeal to small boys of all ages who did not fancy viewing the paintings.On a distinctly non-artistic but necessary point, the loos are some of the finest I have encountered in a public building in the UK.

Great collection. Loved ths furnishings here. Thesigns leading into each room describing what was there was a nice touch. Help put the pieces and art in perspective Without too much detail. Took about two hours to go through Without a guidebook. Totally worth it. Best part it was free

A gem of a museum. We walked from our hotel in Mayfair to this small museum. The staff provided considerable information about the collection. I particularly enjoyed watching several school groups as they listened intently to their guide.

Outstanding collection to rival The Frick (NY). The beautifully furnished rooms of Hertford House in London's West End are home to the Wallace Collection, a plethora of paintings and objets d'art unrivalled anywhere in London. Magnificent examples of Sevres and Limoges craftsmanship nestle alongside porcelain miniatures and illuminated manuscripts, overlooked by a variety of old masters including French 18th century, Dutch landscapes, Titian and of course The Laughing Cavalier. However, for me the most outstanding items on show were the exceptionally elegant majolica pieces of which there were many. The furniture in the 1st floor rooms was finer than that which can be found in most European stately homes and the armory will be of interest to enthusiasts of antique guns, swords and armour. Just five minutes walk from Marble Arch tube station and it is free.

Excellent, well worth a visit. We visited the house on the reviews from Trip Advisor and we were not disappointed, it is a beautiful home in a great location, and the collection is well organised into different categories. There is no cost to visit, so if you enjoy art or antiques it is a definite must!There is also a restaurant in the centre which looks great, but we didn't actually eat at.

An Exquisite Gem in the heart of the West End. Just a short walk off Oxford Street is a priceless gem of a museum; FREE entrance!!! Exquisite miniatures; fabulous paintings - almost luminous "chocolate box" - Boucher "The Swing" is my favourite ... very girly? OK! Check out the vast collection of armour, swords and other death-dealing paraphernalia ... hungry? The inner courtryard provides delectable snacks, meals and time to relax. The upper gallery has many surprises including a self portrait by a yummy Rembrandt!!! and ... the Laughing Cavalier ... the lace is too real ... check it out!We have visited on many occasions since we discovered this hidden treasure and gleefully take all visitors to London ... it's a "don't miss" museum for everyone ... and its history is pretty interesting, too!

A hidden gem!. I came across the Wallace Collection almost by accident in a guide book because it was near where we were staying. So if like me you havn't heard off it before and wonder why not, don't worry. A short stroll from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is housed in over 20 galleries in a beautiful period town house property. Originally members of the Wallace family's private collection built up during the 18th and 19th centuries, this is an outstanding treasure trove of art, paintings, furniture and militaria. It is a very enjoyable way to while away a few hours in a very pleasant environment and appreciate beautiful things and learn something into the bargain. The beauty of this museum is also it''s size. Big enough to be interesting without being too big and difficult to get around it's well worth a visit and best of all, it's free entry!
Overawed!. Incredable collection-must be seen! Until you have seen the original Laughing Cavalier you don't realise how cheeky he looks.The two-tiered restaurant is excellent.

So much to see. Hundreds of things to see in this collection so allow half a day. It wasn't crowded as you can sometimes find in museums in London. Location is perfect for a spot of shopping on Oxford afterwards.
Fabulous collection. If the crowds put you off at all the Art galleries and Museums go here.Priceless collection with all the great Artists and China collections in one place..

Too bad. I was a fan of this place. I visited it everytime I had a chance to go to London. This time, there's a big renovation which they said would last for another 2 years. So, I don't think you should make it as a priority for your visit for sometime.

Don't miss this!. An amazing collection -- reminds me of the Frick (in NYC) in that the art -- lots and lots and lots of it, all kinds of stuff -- fills this handsome house... very personal collection. The Fragonards! The Rubenses! And "The Laughing Cavalier," a painting that amazed me as a 10-year-old when I saw a print of it. And there it is, the Real Deal. Allow a good chunk of time for the visit because there are hundreds of beautiful things to see (including a great collection of armour and weapons, which kids might appreciate, too).

Wonderful ambience with lovely cakes. I use this restaurant often for coffee, but this was the first time to have a lunch there. It is always crowded but I never have a problem for seating, and the natural light coming down from the ceiling lightens up all the restaurant but softly. Their cake and dessert are always enjoyable, and perfect for tea. I, however, did not find lunch that good. We had 2 courses for 19 pounds but they were cooked either with too much garlic or tasteless. They never disappoint us with their desserts and their service is always wonderful so it was a shame. I recommend tea than dining for lunch.

One of London's hidden gems. Love this gallery! Each room displays incredible furniture and artefacts as well as paintings so you see how the styles of each era are reflected in a variety of mediums. A wonderful place to loose yourself in and great scones in the incredible atrium cafe for afterwards!

A bit dull, but the talks are very interesting. The museum is a bit stuffy, but we attended a talk on the civil was, which was very interesting and captivating. The speaker had all his facts memorised, was dressed in typical garb of the day and handed round typical weapons (replicas!) of the day for people to get an idea of what it was like. Fascinating.
A gem. To walk into a room that has 9 Cannaletos and 9 Guardis on the wall should be enough but every room in this building hassomething to delight or intrigue you.

Beautiful House, Priceless Art. The Wallace Collection is housed in a wonderful house in central London. In its heyday it stood in the middle of marshes where they did duck hunting. On several floors you can see amongst other things, Fragonard's The Swing and Rembrandt's The Laughing Cavalier. It has superb interiors and there are very knowledgeable guides to expand your knowledge. There is also a fabulous collection of armour. The central Atrium has a contemporary restaurant where you can enjoy lunch, dinner or afternoon tea. An experience not to be missed!

Back in time. The house is on a quiet square north of busy Oxford Street so like entering a different world, one from the nineteenth century. It reminds me of NYC's Frick, being in a mansion that feels as if it is still inhabited by residents of yore. The building is worth the visit butv hen to have the artwork!!!

Just Great. every step you do in the big halls of the house made you wonder again and again how one man succeed collect so many beautiful things in one life time.The best - every room has it`s own surprises. I loved the knights armors and the paintings in the rooms next to them.Atmosphere - the house itself made you feel your life is full with beauty. very nice staff.Tip - small cards with the paintings from the gallery in very low price in the shop. Don`t waste your time and attention through the tour in taking pictures.Prices - very reasonable (about 5£ for person)
Good for a wonder.... Popped in for lunch on day as they did afternoon tea when I went. I had a wonder around and was pleasantly surprised by the artifacts on show.
Fantastic collection. A great collection of art and antiques with some interesting history & genealogy thrown in. Worth a visit to see The Laughing Cavalier alone - that painting really has a vibe.

Enchanting!. The fabulous array of art, porcelain, arms and sculpture housed in the Wallace Collection puts other London museums in the shade. I was entranced and read every word of the beautifully written guidebook as I gazed at all the beauty. After that I was lucky enough to join one of the free guided tours with an extremely knowledgeable guide. I shall definitely return time and time again.

Wonderful collection. I spent a short afternoon enjoying this collection and could have spent several more hours but ran out of time. The collection is very diverse with the Laughing Cavalier a highlight. I enjoyed the entire layout and was only sorry that the restaurant was full so I didn't have a chance to have tea

Love it!. If you have a spare hour, by all means visit the Wallace Collection. It is in a lovely home and the paintings are exquisite. It's just a jewel of a gallery - you will love it as much as I do.

Wonderful afternoon tea in a beautiful mansion house. My daughter took me for afternoon tea at Hertford House which is also the home of the Wallace Collection which is situated just off Oxford Street not far from Selfridges. The tea is served in the restaurant located in the courtyard which is a beautiful setting for a delicious high quality afternoon tea. Entry to the house is free and its definately worth allowing enough time to walk around the house to see the whole collection of art work, china, furniture, armoury and much more. We didn't have time to see everything but that now gives me a good reason to return which I intend to do on my next visit to London and I will time it to include one of the guided tours that they offer.

Beautiful Atrium. Nothing to dislike per se, just that the surroundings are the most memorable part of the meal. There were no outstanding dishes but equally no awful ones. Service is polite if not friendly .Definitely worth a try .

Beautiful house with a lot of history.. This collection is ticked away beside a lovely square.
It is a very eclectic collection and well worth a visit. Entry was free.

Free entry into a treasure trove of art, sculpture and furnishings.. We approach by walking up the sweeping drive to the imposing exterior of Hertford House on Manchester Square, London W1U 3BN. But the best is yet to come. Enter under the portico and have your breath taken away by the staircase bedecked by wonderful works of art. This is the diamond amongst the costume jewelry of the other London Museums. On the menu at this feast of fabulous oil paintings you will find Fragonard's 'The Swing' , Hals 'The Laughing Cavalier' as well as works by Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, Velàzquez, Poussin, Canaletto and Gainsborough. Wonderful clocks and ornate urns adorn the fireplaces and crystal chandeliers rain down from the ceilings. There is a small but well equipped lecture theatre and a delightful, airy courtyard where you can sit and relax while enjoying a cup of tea, coffee or a tasty cake. There is a lift to the first floor and good clean toilet facilities. Very well worth a visit but do leave enough time to enjoy the experience to the full.
Fabulous collection. A very interesting collection of very fine pieces...the ceramics and scultures are fabulous..also The Laughing Cavailier is a "must see".

A museum with a great collection to view,well worth a visit. Set in a private mansion house in Central London this is not one of the better known museums but should definately be on your list to visit.The art particularly paintings is quite extensive and beautifully displayed,it is also the home to the famous painting the Laughing Cavalier and many others and there is no fee for entrance.The collections are spread over many rooms but for me the highlight was the arms and armour collection.Wonderful swords helmets and shields from British India and the days when England had an Empire very nostalgic.Definately worth a visit.....................

Magnificent Fine Art Collection. For anyone interested in fine art, the Wallace Collection is a must-see. Situated just a short walk north from Oxford Street, the collection is housed in beautiful Hertford House, originally the home of the Marquesses of Hertford. The French 18th century paintings, furniture & antiquities are displayed in original room settings & include masterpieces by Rubens, Watteau, Fragonard & Canaletto. There is no entry charge but donations are invited. Guided tours take place daily. It’s not really suitable for young children but some older teens may find it interesting. I’d suggest you allow about 2 hours to see the whole collection, longer if you’re an enthusiast.

A very special collection. The Wallace Collection is stunning, a real treat always. The museum is impecably maintained and laid out. The staff are very knowledgable. THe cafe was fine for beverages and baked goods but otherwise expect to wait a considerable time.

Fantastic Museum. We really enjoyed our visit to the Wallace Collection. We decided to do the tour which provided a great background to the collection. It was one of the highlights during our visit to London.

Wallace collection. Visited it with my son trhat pasted the afternoon looking at the armours. I came here because it is exposed my Mum's favourite painting The laughing cavalier " No entrance fee .There is even a Canaletto.

An Oasis in Central London. The Wallace Collection is one of those museums which slips off most people's radars when they think of central London museums which is a shame as it is a great little oasis just off the madness that is Oxford St.I have only had a chance to visit the armoury section (with a little boy who is mad about Knights) but it has an impressive range of medieval armour from Europe and Asia.There is also a decent cafe (Peyton & Byrne) in a glassed over courtyard which is great for a cake & coffee break.

The best - and worst - of British. There's no doubt about it: the Wallace Collection is a genuine hidden gem, a truly amazing collection of paintings, ceramics and armour in a private house in a smart but otherwise unremarkable square close to Oxford Street.However, as many other reviewers have pointed out, it's badly let down by the hopelessly mismanaged café. On paper it looks wonderful. The setting is a beautiful space filled with natural light. But the service is woefully slow and simply can't cope with even the small surge of customers who arrive for coffee and breakfast after the museum opens in the morning. The web site makes it sound marvellous. Sadly it's a fine example of how modern British management is better at flattering itself than serving customers.
Best all-around museum to visit in London. Amazing collection, centrally located, free admission - this museum should be on everyone's London itinerary.

Amazing slice of upper class life. Best gallery we went to in Britain by far - smaller and more out of the way than the big name galleries, of course, but therefore all the more amazing ... intimate, engaging, stunning. Highly recommended.

Beautiful House in great location. Manchester Square just behind Selfridges. Lovely to sit outside in the sun. Amazing paintings and furniture. Must take a guided tour. Restaurant and cafe in central atrium. Book restaurant. Good food and wine.
Fantastic collection, well worth a visit. A wonderful place to visit with so many treasures that it should suit anyone. Have been a few times which is the beauty of it being free!

The Wallace Collection--Wow!. What the Getty Museum is to Los Angeles, the Wallace Collection is to London. They have a huge collection of arms and armor from many places/periods (in fact, one of the largest and best in England), they have an excellent collection of decorative arts, paintings (including several Dutch Masters, Watteau, Rembrandt , and Rubens), French and Italian landscapes, porcelain, and Wedgewood. In a word, WOW!From the moment you enter Hertford House, just off Baker Street, about a mile south of Baker Street Station, your eye travels from one fantastic item to the next. The arms rooms, and there are several covering Asian, Indian, European arms and armor, you can't help but be impressed by the exquisite workmanship. They collected the best and most beautifully executed works of the ages. This is a must see for anyone into arms and armor, or into decorative arts, or fine paintings. Hals' "The Laughing Cavalier" is here, and it's always a treat to see such works up close where you can appreciate the finest details. I encountered someone who was looking for the hidden signature on a landscape. It was like a glorious treasure hunt! I was disappointed that they were out of stock in the gift shop of a book I was most anxious to get my hands on, but it turned out to my benefit. I checked one of the prominent book sites, and found them there, available in the US. So, do your research in advance, and if there are any books you're interested in from museum exhibits, check your book sites first, rather than risk having to lug them around in your luggage.

Perfect way to spend an afternoon. I absolutely loved the Wallace Collection, it is full to the brim of interesting gorgeous artefacts. The fact that its free is mind-blowing, well-worth a visit for all ages.

A great match for any gallery. Great setting with some excellent artwork - I was pretty much open-mouthed most of the time inside. The location and free entry are excellent for a pop-in on any day.The rooms are very well decorated with the right amount of furniture/paintings/sculpture/clocks, marvelous. The main hall is just stunning!The only regret I have is not trying the restaurant/tea room but I'll be back soon to try it, no doubt.

Treasure House. The Wallace Collection is a treasure house of art ,not to be missed when in London. There is no entry fee and one can take a guided walk round the collection. It is easy to find,being in Manchester Square,behind Selfridges store in Oxford street. The restaurant is very pleasant . The collection was gathered over five generations and housed in Hertford House ,the London Townhouse of the Marquesses of Hertford- wonderful!

revisiting an old friend. I have been to the Wallace Collection many times , firstly as a university student, then to revisit paintings I love. It's free to get in although donations are welcome. Set in a large house in Manchester Square off Oxford Street it's fairly easy to get to . It's very impressive, go to the website to see more about the collections and to get directions and maps. Staffed by an impressive range of peeps all very informed and happy to talk about the exhibits. There are a number of guided tours , these seem to happen all through day but again check the website or ring to find out more. .There is a lift , the stairs are a nightmare (my knees are crap) and there is a swanky restaurant set in a lovely light and airy atrium on the lower ground floor. noisy , so turn your hearing aids down . I didn't eat there, it looked impressive but possibly expensive.
Dont Miss This!. A stunning collection tucked away in a beautiful square in central London,a short walk from Oxford Street. and set in a fantastic historical building.

One time watch!. I went here with few of my colleagues. There is no entry fees and the place is quite maintained. It will give you quite a idea about royals. I specially like the sction of weapons and armours. One can definitely give one visit to this place!
wallace collection. outstanding private collection in a fabulous private mansion. the porcelain collection is over the top. the home is wonderful. this is a rare treat...

small amazing collection in central London. It has taken me years to visit the place, what a regret! Lovely collection, amazing history, great guides. I went on a Friday morning, had the general tour led by a fantastic guide. We also then went to one of the smaller talks that they host in spefic collections. Another great free London museum/gallery.

Pleasant experience. Wonderful rooms full of paintings, furniture and objet d'art.
Nice cafe atrium area - not wonderful pate but quite pleasant to linger over a glass of wine.

Don't miss is London. The Wallace Collection is a national museum in an historic London town house. In 25 galleries are unsurpassed displays of French 18th century painting, furniture and porcelain with superb Old Master paintings and a world class armoury.The Wallace Collection presents its outstanding collections in a sumptuous but approachable manner which is an essential part of its charm. We always try and visit a few times each year and it simply gets better. Museum is free entry, a great cafe in the middle and packed with interesting and beautiful pieces of art, ceramics and porcelain etc. close to Selfridges and the main shopping in Oxford street. A treasure in the middle of London.
Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful antiques and paintings. I recommend asking for a magnifying glass to view the collection more closely.

A wonderful place. This is one of London's best kept secrets. The gorgeous house is just behind Selfridges. The paintings and objects are displayed in the most beautiful room settings. The restaurant is under a glass dome. Beautiful. I hope the food and service have improved since I last visited.

Hiddem Gem. A must to visit in London !! A very beautiful house holds this small and precious art collection. A small and charming museum with a nice cafe and shop. I love the Fragonard painting " The Swing" exposed here...indeed an excelent option to spend a couple of hours and very close to Oxford Street.

What a collection!. Free to enter, tucked away behind Oxford street, and very easy to miss...I missed this place despite living in London for years, and only found it fairly recently..Particularly liked the weapons section! Amazing displays of knives, swords, shields etc from way back when...

Brilliant!!. Wasnt able to visit on this last trip to London..but do visit when I can....Its one of the hidden gems..room after room of glorious arts....jewels, minatures...Last visit was on a grey afternoon, and to sit on a comfy sofa in a room..full of Canalettos....turn through 90 degrees...and yet more....and turn again...simply wonderful.It wasnt crowded...and there was room to move...sit a while and simply look around....Its good for me....Had a lovely afternoon tea...Personally..I could stay all day...(

A gem in the heart of London. Enjoyed all aspects of the collection. Good guide book, worth buying to work your way through the collection.
Could do with more of a cafe for refreshment as a break between floors, than a restaurant (although this looked very nice and upmarket). Helpful staff.
French art in a beautiful setting. This is a gem of a museum. The art is mostly French as are the surroundings. The house itself and its history are interesting in itself.

Surprising collection and worth a visit. Only two blocks from our hotel, we stumbled on this museum and decided to visit. We were delighted with the broad range of artwork from home furnishings to outstanding paintings. The collection of medieval amour and weaponry is a real treat and more extensive than one would expect in a museum of this size. One can see most of what they need in an hour, but can take longer. There are no lines to get in, and like many London museums, it is free admission with a requested donation.

If you love all things French. I love the Wallace and go most weeks, it is a lovely place to meet friends for lunch or tea. I first went more than 30 years ago and it has changed a great deal with a very smart shop and the old courtyard was roofed over to make a very smart restaurant. If you are interested in armour, French porcelain, paintings, furniture, miniatures etc. you will be in heaven! Very good access for wheelchairs.

an elegant museum to visit. all the collections were well preserved in beautifully decorated rooms, I like the staterooms very much, one can also enjoy english afternoon tea in the maison. Wonderful place to go!

Fantastic small museum. The Wallace Collection should be one of the top ten sites to see in London, but it appears to be a hidden gem. Looking through a guide book I noticed that the Wallace Collection was filled with a private collection of art and could be classified in the same manner as Sir John Soane's Museum. I thoroughly enjoyed the entire collection as well as eating brunch in the cafe.

Explorer. Been here several times before, always a pleasure to just stroll around looking at all the interesting works of art that have been aquired over time. Again it is a gem for anyone who enjoys culture and looks to see.

World class! Not to be missed.. In the Wallace Collection you will recognize world famous paintings such as Fragonard’s “The Swing”, Velázquez’ “Lady with fan”, Franz Hals’ “The laughing chevalier” or Gainsborough’s “Mrs. Robinson”. They are but a few master pieces that you will find along with Sevres porcelain, armours, miniatures, all collected by four generations of men. The location is a grand house and the interior is impressive (you got to love the curtains). I will return!

A very agreeable surprise. Other reviewers have said it all. This was our first visit. We hadn't thought of going there but staff at the Royal Academy recommended it, and it was a very agreeable surprise.
