Uncrowded, relaxed, able to wander from room to room admiring the superb paintings, including The Swing by Fragonard, the Laughing Cavalier by Hals, etc etc. Good tea room in the (covered) courtyard. Close to Oxford Street, so a good place to unwind after the bustle of shopping.

"Breathtaking". My daughter and I visited the Wallace Collection during a recent holiday in London. It's just a few minutes walk from the chaos of Oxford Street and the gallery itself was so quiet in comparison to almost everywhere else we visited. The collection of art, furniture, china and medieval armoury is astounding and every room is like a jewel unto itself. We had lunch at the restaurant, which is situated in a pleasant inner courtyard. The menu was a bit limited and unusual but we did enjoy our salmon quiche and profiteroles! In my opinion, the Wallace Collection is one of London's best kept secrets and most beautiful treasures, and all free of charge (astounding).

splendid, hidden gem. A beautiful building that one can enjoy in an afternoon, or day (depends how much you can take in at once). It lacks the feel of a museum.
the restaurant is my number one spot to take out of towners for lunch; a glorious setting.

Outstanding collection in a gorgeous setting. This privately gathered collection specializes in classic European paintings and furnishings. It's in a private mansion near Marylebone and admission is free. We didn't have a lot of time but were able to see the highlights by using the handy brochure and map of the galleries. The large gallery is closed for renovation but the major works have been dispersed through the other spaces. Highly recommended.

Fantastic. Brilliant collection of art and a lovely place to wander around. Situated off the busy Oxford street in a quiet square it feels a world away from the hussle and bussle of the shoppers!Definitely recommended!

Great place to unwind. This is now my favourite gallery in London. It's free, it's vast and it's a veritable gem of an eclectic collection of art, armour and furniture. Whilst there aren't many headline attractions in terms of the paintings, the collection still houses some work from highly regarded artists from various centuries and of multiple genres. A guided tour is recommended to really get to know everything and its significance to the founder of the collection. Expect to spend upwards of two hours exploring everything here and taking the time to relax and unwind amongst the exhibits. For a moment, it feels like a million miles away from the busy streets of Oxford St. and Marylebone High St., both just round the corner. This experience can be enjoyed further by having a rest in the restaurant which features a clear roof offering an abundance of light to the diner. I didn't have it but I had the afternoon tea is wonderful. This is a unique surprise in central London and would be a must on any itinerary of the West End attractions.
Very good ,well worth a visit. FANTASIC ART AND FURNATURE. Try and go later in the afternoon as there is more space to look around.

Quiet oasis; wonderfully varied collection. This is well worth the very short walk north of Oxford St. An amazingly quiet museum for one so central, it presents a delightful variety of material- paintings, armour, porcelain, furniture, clocks. As a personal collection, it it not huge, but at least you can see around it in half a day without becoming mind-numbed, and it contains some outstanding pieces.

The Old Masters. Many galleries of contemporary art have bloomed in London, it's nice to be able to view Renaissance art again. The Wallace Collection displayed art of the Old Masters. The place is easy to find, off the shopping street. There is a cafe inside the building with high quality food & drinks. One can view the exhibits, rest a while at the cafe & go back for another view.
A steal. I love this place. It's central, bursting with beautiful art, has a wonderful atrium - a great space to pause, relax, alone or with friends. I have always thought it seriously underrated.
Day out with my Daughter.. Great place if you love looking at Art, great area for lunch and afternoon tea. The structure is Edwardian and a good rest from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street.

Best kept secret in London. This museum is a great place to take young adults (and husbands) that don't love museums. Its free, you can see the entire exhibit in a relatively short time and it boasts one of the best antique weapon collections in London. In addition it has a lovely gallery of art with several "masters". This was the private collection of a gentleman who later donated both his home and collection for the enjoyment of the public. Its truly is a gem.

Amazing collection and good food!. It's jaw droppingly amazing seeing all the intricacy, detail and rich heritage captured in the different rooms of the collection. You can easily bask and imagine yourself living at that period, what that would be like considering all this wealth status around you. It's worth a visit if you're around London.We then had a light lunch at the restaurant which offered great service, and good food. Do not expect massive portions here. It's smaller than usual but it is impeccable.
Great place to visit if you have a spare hour .. A free collection to visit in the heart of London . Peaces of art , paintings of 19 century , old clocks , statues and a changing collection gallery .
A wonderful private collection that is free to visit.. So much to see, art lovers will visit again and again.Armoury collection will appeal to chidren.House itself is well preserved.
One of the Great museums... This must be on any tourists venue who enjoys fine works of art..A geat place ...!!! I never miss it when I visit London..
Fantastic collection. The collection is fantastic and the setting delightful. A real treat and an oasis of calm, just off Oxford Street.
culture trip. a fantastic house and gallery, with the most amazing collection of paintings and ceramics. The cafe was a bit expensive for a cup of coffee, etc.

Hidden gem. This large house full of art and other collections was donated to the City of London. The armour collection is extensive and very interesting, and includes horse armour. Paintings and furniture treasures abound. This is the home of the well-known painting, "The Laughing Cavalier".

A real gem. Variety of exhibits and time and space to examine them without feeling crowded. Delightful Dutch School paintings, French furniture and porcelain. Allow plenty of time. Restaurant looked nice but had no time to try it.

Superb Collection. We visited the Wallace Collection during our recent visit to London and were only made aware of its existence through reviews on tripadvisor. It is a wonderful collection of art, furniture and porcelain all collected over many years by one family - one of the many highlights being the painting of the Laughing Cavalier. Amazingly there is no entry charge. A must visit - you will not be disappointed.

Hidden Gem. This collection is a hidden gem. In a beautiful old building you will find some amazing treasures all collected by one person with extremely good taste. Well worth a visit if you have a few hours to spare in London.
Manageable collection and great house. Lovely period home in Central London with an amazing collection of 18th and 19th century furniture and paintings. Well worth a visit.

What a hidden jewel. So close to all the nonsense of Oxford Street is this fantastic haven. We only scratched the surface. Van Dyke and Canaletto a plenty and all that 17th Century history. Spectacularly presented a must for a return.

Small but exquisite. Tucked away in one quiet back alley just off Oxford Street, it provides a nice escape from all the hustle in Central London. Much less crowded than the National Gallery so you can enjoy your visit at a more relaxed pace. Although it's a bit smaller than I expected, the collection is very rich and the decoration of the house is extravagant. You can rent an audio guide for £3 from the museum shop which is really worth the price. It's detailed but takes a long time to listen to every interpretation carefully, so plan your time wisely, maybe hit a few famous ones first before searching for your own favourites. It's home to some very interesting paintings and art crafts, worth a visit for people who come to London on a regular basis but not so much for first timers I guess.
Lovely place. Been here for afternoon tea several times. Only problem is that you sometimes have to wait awhile for a table.

I love looking at the French art which were rescued after their revolution.. Duke of Manchester did a great service to a francophile, like me by giving this collection and the House to the nation. I also like the restaurant in the courtyard.

London's Best Kept Secret. Visiting London, shpopping on Oxford Street, need a break and bit of calm, maybe lunch? You are minutes away from this and more at the Wallace Collection in Manschester Square, just behind Selfridges. The collection is made up of exqusite objet d'art, furniture, curiosities, paintings ect including several well known masterpieces incluiding the Laughing Cavilier and The Swing, all set in the spendor of an intact Georgian Town Palace. And, best of all, it is free to the public. In the enclosed and roofed courtyard is an excellent cafe featuering beautiful cakes and pastries, cream teas as well as more subsantial fare for the hard core shopper needing refueling. The collection is expertly displayed and there are guides and experts throughout the house who are happy to explain items or help you to find the most minute and incredible detial in some of the carvings in the medievial collections. THe overall decor can only be described as sumptuous. It truly is an amazing place that few Londoners let alone out of town or overseas visitors know about. Therefore you can stroll casually and through uncrowded rooms, taking your time and enjoying the splendors of a byegone age before popping back into the 21st century hustle and bustle that is London.

WOW. I was so amazed to know about the Wallace collection for the first time in a part of London that I thought I knew like the back of my hand. This amazing museum is beyond words. Do your self a favour and go there, its free of charge

A perfect place!. Very easy to find just behind Selfridges. Take the Bond St tube to Oxford st and follow the road turn right onto Duke st walk for a few minutes before you come across Manchester Square a beautiful, tranquil and perfect setting. The Wallace collection is a magnificent place to visit, free entry but donations are welcome. Something for everyone here an abundance of stunning clocks mostly French mantle - superb paintings The Laughing Cavalier being one of them and a truly wonderful collection of Cannalettos.The armoury section is second to none so much to see and all very interesting.A good few hours can be spent here, with also a place to eat and drink I rate this as one of the best things to see in London.

Culture in London. If you want a break from the bustle of Oxford Street the Wallace Collection is a haven. Lots of beautiful paintings and antiques and the refectory is lovely, enjoyed a large glass of white wine in there.
A hidden delight. It is a very special place to visit like a stately home but a museum with some fabulous art and artifacts and a terrific place for lunch as well in the conservatory
Lovely Gem. Well worth spending an hour or so wondering around the museum and it was free! The restuarant looked very inviting too, but we were booked to eat somewhere already - next time maybe.

Hidden gems. One of the delights of the Wallace Collection (and Apsley House), beyond their over-the-top extravagance, is strolling past walls crowded with largely unexceptional paintings and suddenly coming upon a real treasure. Here, beyond the Murillos gathered in their own gallery on the lower ground floor, there are the East Galleries, which amid so much else contain lovely works by ter Borch, de Hooch, Steen, and Metsu. As you meander into a connecting room you suddenly notice, in addition to the Ruisdael, two Rembrandts--a wonderful self-portrait and a fine picture of his son. All the rest of the silver and porcelain and amazing firearms are great fun, but just icing on the cake.

“Worth the visit”. This was my first visit to this amazing building and I was blown away by it. Lovely home and interesting collection .Free entry and a good selection of exhibits makes this a refuge from the busy outside.
Wondewrful Setting. I dare you not to like the setting or Oliver Paton's restaurant!! Tranquil haven and last time I went some decent porcelin on show. Support this excellent venue

Wonderful collection. Great collection of paintings including those by Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Rubens and Canaletto. The beautiful 19th century building also has a wide collection of historic furniture, exquisite trinkets, china and armoury from around the world.
Unbelievable collection. An enormous amount of art and collectors items of different kinds such as armors, porcelain and furniture. All gathered during 4 generations by one family

A hidden treasure. What afantastic house and collection, please pay £3 for a audio guide its worth it and theres a cafe/restraunt all this for free. One of the guides said its never crowded as not many people know its there.

Staggering collection. Everything is beautifully done from the building to the collections. I would suggest breaking it up in to 3 trips of 1 hour so you don't get exhausted. Truly original and eclectic.

An intimate collection in a grand home. The collection was extensive yet manageable. I love this kind of gallery because it gives a glimpse into the privileged lives of the collectors. This collection was left it to the State on condition that it not be broken up and remain in the home.
fabulous. the entire collection is really beautiful, rooms were full of beautiful art such as Titian, Rembramdt, Gainsbo

Amazing, world class art and artefacts FREE!. As you go round you'll recognise loads of the paintings - Rembrandt, Velasquez, Rubens - but it's the small treasures that I love. Been many times and have a different favourite each time. Restaurant is fab as well, great food & service, pricy but good value.

Well worth a visit. Located just behind Oxford Street, this free museum is often overlooked by tourists but is definitely worth a look. Armour, paintings (including the original Laughing Cavalier), weapons, and - at the moment - a Murillo exhibition to complement the one at Dulwich Picture Gallery...

A MUST-VISIT place. The Wallace Coll. is a place that, were it in a foreign city, it would be nearly top of the "Must-Visit" list, but which, because there is so much else to see in London, one tends to forget about . People I know seem often to say, "Oh, I haven't been there in years!" It is a supremely elegant space in which to experience such a wide variety of artistic gems (and their courtyard cafe is a delight!!!!)

So much you need to revisit. An excellent museum of French renaissance furniture, paintings etc. There is so much it is hard to take it all in. Personally I'd do a few rooms at a time and come back. Free tour at 11.30am - well worth it. Looks like a lovely restaurant in the center as well.

Very extensive and beautiful privately owned collection of art. This small museum is located one block north of Oxford Street in Hereford House on Manchester Square. My friend and I took a tour of the Wallace Collection and we were very impressed with the abundance of the art, china, furniture & porcelain collection owned by this one family. The collection consists mainly of art from France which was shrewdly purchased by this family during the French Revolution, when they could buy if for very cheap! The woman tour guide we had was a French woman who had an extensive knowledge of all the pieces and collections and explained all areas in detail. The beauty of the items is unbelieveable. We were very impressed by the collection, and quite enjoyed our time at this museum. They also have a nice gift shop.

A gem. Museum wise -awesome, well worth taking yourself off the beaten track. I cat recommend eating here - it looks nice but its pretty expensive. Wander up Marylebone High Street and visit one of the cafes/bars less expensive.

Lovely atmosphere, collection was okay. The Wallace Collection is housed in an old mansion, and has a variety of artworks and ceramics and armory. Easy to see in an hour or so, be sure to save time for lunch or afternoon tea in the stunning indoor courtyard cafe.

For the Ladies who Lunch. I must admit this place did not do it for me,. Designer salads for the ladies who lunch. Smallish portions at fancy prices served by fairly haughty staff.The setting however in the atrium is quite splendid.

A Venue not to be missed. This museum is a hidden treasure and it is free! I enjoyed the various art and armor displayed in each of the rooms, but particularly enjoyed the furnishings and snuff box display. We had lunch in the glass-domed courtyard and it was fun with good service. It was an elegant day. I loved it.

Hidden gem behind Oxford Street. A beautiful house full of top-class treasures from armour to porcelain and nick-nacks owned by Russian royalty and famous paintings such as the 'Laughing Cavalier'. A short walk down a side street next to Selfridges. There is a covered courtyard cafe (pricey) and a small shop.

Hidden gem in London. Amidst London's various large and popular museums, this one certainly gets lost, albeit deserves rightly to be on the top. It is unique, in the sense that it is a family's own museum, with a leaning to the French art collection the family collected over the centuries. It is a beautiful house within which the museum lives, and it has a great cafe that is worth a visit- and my suggestion is to have the afternoon tea there. (Although tea itself is a simple but delicious affair, the environment is absolutely stunning)Great date place btw!
Wonderful. we loved this museum, so much interesting art in it. really worth travelling to see. The museum is very well laid out and although we did not eat in the restaurant it looked very nice.

Hidden gem. I'm a big fan of arms and armour, so the Wallace Collection is wonderful, as far as I'm concerned. It's a world-class museum in this field and relatively unknown, compared to places like the Tower or the British Museum. The art collection is also quite special. Well worth a visit.

Delightful. What a treasure to visit. It's quiet and there are no hoards of tourists to contend with.There are so many paintings to see from the Dutch masters to the French, Italian and Spanish. We only spent 2 hours there but you could easily spend the day.There are rooms laid out with beautiful furniture, including some of Marie-Antoinette. There is also porcelain and of course the armoury consisting of both European and Oriental origin.Delightful visit indeed

Love the colour-themed rooms. I have visited this Collection at least four times now, as we have a flat nearby and I take visiting friends for a quick whizz round this delightful Art Collection before usually sitting down for a coffee in the Cafe itself. Each time I find something new - as well as the huge collection of cherubs, ladies who often don't manage to keep a shoulder of their dress on (??), stern male portraits, a selection of hares/pheasants/guns etc. - and of course The Laughing Cavalier. There is an amazing collection of artefacts kept under light-filtering covers upstairs, which you can lift and peek at. The colours in each room are amazing: vibrant and beautiful. Each window has a unique set of curtains hung in its own unique way - gorgeous!

Quiet museum in heart of London. I watched a short video - a documentary following Vivienne Westwood around London - in which she recommends visiting The Wallace Collection, just off Oxford Street. It's a really interesting collection (15th-18th C paintings upstairs and an armoury downstairs) - including some really famous artwork (Fragonard's 'The Swing' and the Frans Hals 'The Laughing Cavalier')Well worth a diversion from the business of Oxford Street for a spot of culture. Oh, and like most London museums, it was free. Brilliant :D

Only in London. Only in | London, I believe can you see a museum of this class and pay nothing for the privilege. A real gem. For people who happen to drive there, the bonus is that parking is generally no problem, although it comes at a price. Another plus is the restaurant in the atrium which is really nice and generally quite good.

A delightful respite from the Sunday bussle on Oxford Street. We visited one Sunday in cold February on recommendation of a friend. Wonderful exhibits. One particular room attendant spent 20 minutes explaining the history of the family. We were in awe at the knowledge and enthusiasm displayed - he must repeat the story at least 5 times a day. A touching experience. We topped it off with a light lunch at the restaurant in the light box in the middle of the building - a delightful respite.

Worth the visit. For me it was 3 for 3. Lovely home, interesting collection and cheap (free, donation requested). What's not to love? It is deserving of its high rating, though my wife prefers places that have a unifying theme. The house is basically a very impressive private collection of art, furniture and artifacts put together by one (extended) family.
Great little museum. A great museum in the West End of London. Free entry and a good selection of exhibits makes this a refuge from the busy outside.
Must see. The buidling is as impressive and beautiful as the contents. Nice atmosphere and not crowded. Cafe is worth a visit too! Lots of treasures in here that i didn't expect to see.

Hidden Gem. I've lived in and been visiting London regularly for years and have never come across the Wallace Collection. The collection of paintings and furniture is exquisite and the setting in the house is wonderful. There is a gorgeous restuaurant which is perfect for taking a rest from the collection. What is more the Collection is free to visit and makes a wonderful diversion from the other stresses of London.

Amazing collection. I loved walking through each room of the house, as they all had a different theme, depending on the period of the paintings and the furniture. The house is French inspired and has a luxurious feel/look. On display are many of Mary Antoinette's once possessions. Gorgeous collection of furniture and paintings. It is like visiting a rich arosticrates house I imagine. The amoury in the basement is impressive.

fabulous and free art venue. This is a gem of a place, not far from Selfridges. There is a glass covered courtyard restaurant that is peaceful and has lovely, if a trifle expensive food. it is a good place for a relaxing coffeee after the chaos of near by Oxford Street. The permanent collection of art works and furniture is world class and contains paintings of international reknown. There are small temporary exhibitons too, Currently one is of the religious works of Murillo and another of silver tobacco boxes. The latter sounds dull but it contains amazing historical stuff that this visitor had never seen or heard of before. There are occasional free tours of the collection and lectures too. There is also a shop.

Unbelievable assortment of wonderful things - for free!. Having just come back from Vienna and paying 15 yoyos into museums really puts London into perspective. Where else can you see baroque masterpieces like the Laughing Cavalier and look at the largest collection of Marie Antoinettes furniture all together in one room... FOR FREE!The suits of armour rooms downstairs will keep little boys happy. All in all it is a wonderful collection of things just a stones throw from Bond Street tube. Well worth a peek.

A Little Gem. If you ever played the board game "Masterpiece", you'll find one of the "old masters" right here. In one of the most accessible spots in London lies a grand old house with a fabulous art collection, AND a unique place for a lovely tea. (But please, don't tell anyone else about this place, tables even mid-week are becoming harder to find.)
Visiting the Wallace collection. A very eclectic collection, well curated and displayed. The free tours are particularly interesting. The setting is good and it is never too crowded

Not huge, but full of the charm. The exhibitions are fun and attractive. The splendid residence possesses the refined collection appropriate to it. They have a lot of pictures which Canaletto drew Venice on.

The laughing Cavalier made it for me. gem of a gallery - free and packed with some great paintings. My favourite being that Laughing Cavalier -smaller than I expected but big on atmosphere. Well wort a wander around. I was gripped by the silk wallpaper such beautiful colours.
a treat for art lovers, and it's free. We enjoyed a very interesting tour of the house guided by an extremely witty lady. Worth a detour if you have a couple of hours to spare.

Serenity and opulence a stones throw from Oxford Street. This art gallery has some of the greatest masterpieces from 17th century Europe! At every turn there is an iconic masterpiece we are all familiar with, but never knew it was in London! Cannot recommend the Wallace Collection enough - visited many years ago, and it is still quiet, wonderful and has free entry. An absolute gem in the heart of London! (I am almost reluctant to post this, as I don't want lots of people visiting and spoiling the ambiance!)

Excellent. Although we've been here before we returned again yesterday and we enjoyed every minute.Free entry and an amazing collection that will enthrall.The only dowside was its popularity as the place was packed and service in the retuarant was slow as a result.Put this place on your must visit list if you're spending time in London.

a hidden gem. Not the best known of all the museums London has to offer, but thta also means it can be nice and quiet and no masses of people trying to get a look at paintings. Beautiful collection of some of the works of Reynolds and Gainsborough (some top-paintings !, but also an impressive collection of armoury, antique religious paraphernalia and all within the setting of this grand mansion. Very civilised place that does not charge an entrance fee but leaves a conribution to the discretion of the visitors
Little gem in Marylebone. Beautiful artwork displayed throughout a townhouse. Less crowded, more relaxing and more enjoyable than some of the better known museums.

Underrated. Hidden gym. It is a great place to visit. the art collection is unbelievable and often overwhelming. The building itself is incredible. One of the best art galleries I have managed to see.
Sevres!. I go to look at the colour of the Sevres porcelain. Its utterly out of this world. Opulent without being pretentious

A Hidden Gem in a Great Neighborhood!. The Wallace Collection is located about a block away from Oxford Street almost behind Selfridges. A nice break from the shopping madness of Oxford. The house itself is lovely and the collection is stunning. You can probably have a good visit in 1 to 1 1/2 hours. It's a very relaxing and educational experience. Afterwards you may want to explore nearby Marylebone High Street or St. Christopher Place. Both are charming.

Amazingly varied collection. There is something for everyone here - arms and armour, french furniture, porcelain, clocks and super collection of paintings. The cafe in the (covererd) central courtyard is also very pleasant.

Well worth a visit!. We were stunning by the private collection of artefacts basically in a large house in the centre of London. They have the Laughing Cavalier and quite a few Rubens, Rembrandt paintings to name a few. It is well laid out with different styles and countries in different rooms. They also have a large Sculptures, works of art and Furniture. Well worth a visit

an eclectic experience. I love the Wallace collection. I lived in London for several years so imagine my surprise, 7 or 8 years ago, to find a three star Michelin rating on something I had never heard of.... Sure enough, in the prior Michelin, the Wallace collection was not even mentioned! There is the most interesting set of things to see. You can go slowly or quickly - and there is a lovely cafe to have lunch or tea. I recommend it for a quiet and interesting afternoon in London!

Is there anything more lovely. This is one of the most amazing collections of french paintings of the very romantic louisxv type it is a compellingly lovely collection and stunning ad very memorable It is also free so big thanks to Lady Wallace for the price and exquisite taste Do not miss it

Home of the Laughing Cavalier. Formerly a private collection but bequethed to the nation. Very well laid out gallery with one of the best stocked and displayed armories in London. Good collection of art - this is where the Laughing Cavalier is displayed.

Selfridges and real history. What an amazing attraction my wife could spend hours in the selfridges shoe dept after 2 hours my resolve starts to fade but then I come alive with a trip to this secret hidden jem each room is outstanding you feel the power. And history it's like an episode of Mr Ben total escapism

Its got to be top of the list. It is hard not to fall in love with the Wallace collection - there is something for everyone, be it the carravagios, be it the amazing sculptures, the armery or the minatures... even the inner court yard cafe (with excellent cakes and food) and the outer garden are splendid treasures on their own. Every room is filled with several treasures - that even after 20 or 30 visits one still discovers new paintings and objects every time, or just simply rediscovers Look out for the piercing and "observing" eyes of the "Smiling Cavalier"

Hidden gem. this was like the Tardis, it went on and on, each room different, but all filled with amazing art and furniture. very helpful and knowledgeable staff.I was unable to see all of the collection due to my mobility, but it was a great experience.

A gem of a museum away from the crowds.. One of my favourite London Museums. An eclectic collection, with some famous paintings. I am sure that there must be times when it is busy but i have never been there when it is. It is nice to be able to walk around without the bustle of other museums. The web site gives all the opening times and details of current exhibitions. Well worth a visit.

Its still free........... I love the Wallace Collection....not only is it still free, I have never visited it overcrowded. Its a delight to walk through the rooms and linger over cabinets, and the suits of armour are stunning......the cafe is good, but I always finish off with a stroll up to Selfridges Food Hall for a meander and tasting session
Interesting collection of artworks. Very interesting guided tour made this a well worth while visit. The house itself is ornate and atmospheric.

A Feast of art in Marleybone. Always a wonderful visit to the beautifully housed Wallace Collectiion: 17th-19th century paintings, arms and armor, furnishings and more. Enjoy a meal or snack in the lovely Orangerie. Free admission--what a bargain!!

Little Known Hidden Gem. Tucked away behind Wigmore st and Baker St is one of my favourite art galleries. This review is about the restuarant in the glassed in central courtyard.There is a nice choice of lighter dishes, ssandwiches etc or a full a la carte if you like..Prices for the quality of the food are very reasonable.It can get very busy so you may have to wait if you have not booked.

What a change. Last visit was thirty years ago when the place was a dusty collection of ill sorted items. What a spectacular change! The building has been entirely renovated with tasteful decor varied according to content, in part thanks to generous private donors. The Sevres porcelain must be the best outside France and the art is hung in various ways according to style - even the hanging chains are coloured to match the wallpapers. Really too much to write about, so suggest a visit to www.wallacecollection.org before a visit or to refresh memories thereafter. An absolute must when in London!

one of the best in London. This is an opportunity to see the interior of an elegant 18th century mansion house which now contains a superb collection of art and artifacts. Never as busy of some of the more well known galleries. A treasure not to be missed

A gem of an art and antiques colletion. A very personal collection opf art, of all types and antiques. Very good indeed. Only surpassed by the Frick Collection in New York and the Isabelle Gardiner Museaum in Boston.Nothing to dislike

Hidden gem. I had heard about this place but had never been there as I didn't know where it was. We passed it on a day out and decided to go in. It is brilliant. There is an amazing collection of first class art works including The Laughing Cavalier. The restaurant looked good although we had already eaten.
Fabulous. My favourite place in London, we are so lucky to be able to indulge ourselves in so much beauty. One of the gems of the city, a great place to have lunch,too

Stunning collection. This is one of the loveliest places in London; left to the nation by the Wallace family, it is chock full of beautiful items that you can while away an entire day admiring. The restaurant is beautiful and does the most fantastic (and filling!) afternoon tea that I've had in London. The collection is a short walk from Baker Street station, but it feels like you've found a peaceful haven in a busy area.

A part of the collection probably missed out. This is a wonderful collection in beautiful surroundings.However, I would advise visitors - if they still have enough energy after seeing the more famous artworks - to at least breeze by the exhibits of ancient armour, swords, etc. Very good examples of how form doesn't necessarily follow function - these objects were made for defence or offence, but the aesthetic dimension plays a major role in their fabrication.

Hidden treasure. A friend of mine returning from his first visit to London in 10 years told me about the museums and galleries he had visited. He had gone to all the places that I, as a regular London visitor, had recommended. I asked what gallery/museum had impressed him the most, The Wallace Collection was his reply. Never heard of it I said, so on my latest visit to London I sought it out. A few minutes walk from behind Selfridges and I was there. What a lovely place to visit and the cafe/restaurant in the courtyard must be the best of any of the big galleries. You must visit, it is a grand house with a great collection, and in a convenient location, you will not be disappointed.
Best kept secret museum. A treasure.... private collection in stunning London palace... Canaletto collection is amazing. A short walk from Oxford street.

Surprisingly rich, expansive, delightful collection.. Wasn't expecting much beyond a grand house filled with pretty aristocratic trinkets but boy was I wrong! The wallace collection was housed in an absolutely incredible building, every room is gorgeous, and the collection itself is simply priceless. Ended up spending most of the day there, as there was plenty to see. the art collection was fantastic, and the huge armor collection was a particular highlight for me. can't recommend highly enough.

See world class art for free!. The gallery is in a beautiful building and has a lovely warm feel to it. The star of the show is 'The Laughing Cavalier' but we also loved the collection of miniatures and tiny silver ornamental boxes. There is also a lovely courtyard cafe.

ART & GREAT FOOD. One of the best galleries in London with a great restaurant in a sublime setting. Treat yourself to the sensational food here and make the day complete. Right in the centre of London (Manchester Sq) a stroll from Oxford Street. Franz Hal's paintings will enthrall you.
amazing and free. revamped room decor and fresh curtains show the paintings off very well. good food in the cafe and nice programs and catalogue. The paintings are stupendous and all for free.

Wonderful Free day trip in London. There is a huge collection of paintings, jewellery, furniture, glassware, dinnerware and just about anything you can think of from a period house. It takes basically a minimum of 4 hours to view all that is there the been seen. It's quiet and out of the way so the day I was there is wasn't very crowded, which I found relaxing.There is a lovely covered cafe built in the centre of the house interior garden. The service here was a little slow. It was the end of the day and I felt that the servers were more interested in leaving that looking after a single women customer. The food and drink was very good and I would definitely recommend it, but don't go at the end of the day.
Lovely Museum. There is so really great furniture, mostly from France. The armor collection is great fun. Don't miss this little gem

Lovely museum.. Very elegant house, knowledgeable staff, and beautiful exhibits. There are many rooms to visit, and a tour guide at certain times. The restaurant has a nice but pricey menu, but the surroundings are pleasant. Bonus is that it is very near Oxford Street and other shopping areas.
Stunning. We were blown away by this stunning collection, must be the biggest secret in London. Just off Oxford Street and very easy to find, The art work on display is priceless,

Significant art collection. One of Londons gems; a eclectic and significant collection of art in a beautiful house. A must place to visit for anyone eccentric vaguely interested in art. Toilets the best ever.

Wonderful Paintings in a Wonderful Setting. I came here specifically to see two particular paintings but was pleased and surprised by the number of well-known paintings that are in the collection. I also enjoyed the miniatures on view. And it is impressive to see paintings on display in decorated rooms. I also enjoyed my English afternoon tea, which was very reasonably priced.

Restaurant in the courtyard. Beautiful gallery full of great pictures, but don't overlook the restaurant in the middle of it! Many gallery restaurants are stuck away in the basement somewhere, but this one is in the large central courtyard of the building. It is covered over and even on a snowy day feels cosy and summery with natural light. The service is variable and when I went recently several items on the menu were unavailable. (I once went there for brunch and they had run out of muesli and had to send somebody out to buy some!) In spite of everything, it is worth it to go just for the restaurant!
Brilliant. Wonderful location, gallery and museum. Loved it, One of London's finest. Beautifully decorated rooms displaying some amazing art and objects.

Good variety on offer. I stumbled across this building completely by chance and was very surprised of its content. I am not a massive fan of art but there was a good variety of things there to keep me interested.

Very enjoyable.. We were impressed by the size, quality, and depth of the collection. The house itself is gorgeous and we also liked the restaurant a good deal. Our waiter wasn't great, but he wasn't horrible either.
Amazing collection...... What an absolutely amazing collection. Not to be missed on the London tour route. Not only pictures but a great armoury.

Small but perfectly formed. We had been meaning to visit the Wallace Collection for some time, and were delighted when we finally made the effort. It wasn't over-busy but had enough visitors to create a good atmosphere in a beautiful building. We latched onto a free tour (we normally avoid them) which was very interesting and informative, and certainly worthwhile. We then went freelance and somehow managed to miss the famous Fragonard painting but others in the Collection more than made up for it. The quantity and quality of the armour was stunning, and came as quite a surprise add-on to the art.Very pleased that we hunted it down.

Great collection of pictures and furniture - and tearoom. First time I've visited in 40+ years so I'd completely forgotten its attractive setting in 1 of London's many beautiful squares. It's also pleasingly disabled-friendly. I was unavoidably late in joining my friends for a tour but found it really interesting - and the guide obviously had real enthusiasm for her subject. So much so that we were a bit let getting to the tea we'd ordered. And what a tearoom! It's in the covered courtyard so lots of natural light, space and interesting plants. Also an extensive menu for all meals. The only trouble with the late start was having to depart sharp-ish to let the patiently-waiting staff get home!

What a Gem! Possibly my fave Museum in London. The Wallace Collection was an extraordinary surprise for me. I just loved my day spent there. I had been to all the 'big' museums in London many times and wanted to try something new. It is in a beautiful building with a lovely ambiance and a great collection. It is bite sized so you get a real full and lovely experience without it feeling overwhelming. My friend who lives in London proclaims it to be here hands down favorite museum and she will just wander in on some days to disappear for a few moments into it's loveliness. It also has a very cute little boutique shop and I use my pen and glasses cleaner embued with my favorite painting in the collection every night. Reiminds me of my happy day at the Wallace.
Lovely Gem!. Had a day wallowing in bookshops but dropped this in and stayed there for gorgeous lunch, highly recommended little gem of a collection.

Ecclectical museum, very interesting. The Wallace collection is in London... thanks to a(nother) Revolution in France (when Sir Wallace decided to play it safe and to come back to England). This gentleman was a collector of any kind of art and it is all well represented in the display. For instance, it offers UK's second largest collection of armours (after the Tower of London). I have been there 4 or 5 times, and each time is was not crowded at all. Just go there, and you will be surprised.

A joy to revisit. I hadn't been to the Wallace Collection for a few years and decided to revisit - what a joy! A beautiful and well presented house obviously cared for with love and affection. Very helpful and knowledgable staff . A delightful experience and a chance to see some beautiful works of art.
Fantastic. What a fantastic place, spent the day wandering through the beautiful house looking at the most amazing Art. Everyone should visit. Great restaurant too

London Gem. Absolutely stunning art collection and breathtaking space.
I would recommend having cakes and coffee at the cafe which has a lovely setting with lots of light coming in. Avoid the restaurant and stick to the cafe.

Charming treasure trove. We visit this amazing private collection every time we go to London and just love everything about it. The visiting exhibitions are also well worth seeing and this time we were lucky enough to join an art lecture downstairs in the theatre. The staff are gracious, the shop contains lovely items at reasonable prices, the restaurant was great and the treasures in the collection are divine. I would recommend this to all visitors going to London.
Wow. I liked everything about this museum, oh and a bonus - it is just behind Oxford Street shopping woohoo!

A welcome awaits you. I really love visiting here. The staff on duty in the rooms are so pleasant and make you feel really welcome. There is something here for everyone and it is worthwhile asking to be put on their mailing list as a very varied selection of talks, courses and guided tours are on offer. Even if you just want a quiet haven less than five minute's walk from the hurly-burly of Oxford Street you will find a superb restaurant and a brilliant gift shop which may well inspire you to delve further into this delightful museum.

the best kept secret. Presenting the Wallace Collection in Hertford House, the London townhouse of previos owners-is so original.This small look like Palace-Museum in location one of a kind - is so perfect.Collection now is is a national museum with huge- for two centery collected art tresury, as a kind of gift to British nation by Lady Wallace, in 1897.I bought book in gift shop.When I heard thet they begun to re-appraise Murillo - pointing his importante position in European Baroque, I realise what a chance is to see this .Lately so many books and exbitions are doing to promote and restore with the artist as well- the painter’s reputation. Murillo’s expressive technique - warm and specific colours in his late stage shows how he was using sfumato techniques. Murillo was very famous for his paintings of religious and everyday life pictures and it is perfect chance to see this perfection from so gifted master.This fabulos colection and whole place - hard to find anywhere- need to be seen.You need time to see and enjoy , explore and have a grate time.It was not my first time but not last as well to visited this grate place.This is the best kept secret.

Great collection, beautiful building. It was worth finding this place - what a fabulous collection! I'm not an art junkie, but these were great pictures and even I recognised many of them. The interiors of the rooms would have been worth the visit on their own and the afternoon tea in the cafe was divine!

Around the world in 80 minutes. Probably the most condensed collection in the world. Allows you to visit just one museum and then never bother again in your life. Old world, new world - and armour, amour and history. If this was a shop it would be the Harrods of antiques, culture and weaponry.

Manchester Square Museum. Situated in Manchester Square this is a free and absorbing museum. Excellent paintings including works by Canaletto wonderful collection of snuff boxes furniture and a very large Armory. The exhibition includes The Laughing Cavalier by Frans Hals - you will not see this painting in any exhibition outside this collection - it is always in the collection here. A short stroll from the bustling streets of the West End. Not to be missed.
A collector's passionate work. Wonderful. A collector's passionate work. WonderfulIntimate and small spaces full of grandiose beautiful objects and furniture, paintings and art.

A must and it's free. A most beautiful building in central London - I never knew existed. Holding the most amazing collections dating back pre 16th century. It has something for everyone who appreciates delving into the past. A big WOW factor. Need to go back.

(restaurant review only) Calm & Refined. We only popped in for a spot of lunch, and dodn't really have time to look at "The Collection" which is pretty big and eclectic - Paintings, Ceramics, Works of Art, Armour etc etc. Entry is free.The Atrium there houses a restaurant on one side and a cafe on the other, it's esentially two halves of a big covered courtyard.The place is light and airy, and the food (in the cafe side) was excellent. I say cafe, but it is effectively a restaurant with a limited menu. There were 5 of us and we had variously - soup, mussels & chips, quiche, and tea/coffee/elderflower cordial /gin & Tonic ! It wasn't cheap (what in London is ?) but it was very good, in a lovely setting, much nicer than a typical coffee shop or starbucks. Definitely a place to return to.The toilets were nice & clean too.

Fine collection. Free entrance and a nice restaurant in the atrium, need to say more? Remember to reserve a table at the restaurant and spend some time with the collection, both are an experience.I you are interested go for the audio guide.

A not to be missed Gallery. Most of the rooms are beautiful examples of period decoration in rich colours. A large collection of pictures, period furniture , objets d'art and armoury. A fine variety. Well worth a visit. Free entrance and not far from Oxford street.Pleasant courtyard restaurant.Temporary placement of the Laughing Cavalier painting needs better lighting.
A wonderful gallery, a delightful space. The Wallace is wonderful gallery, with a delightful ambiance. It was a joy for me to walk around this space...pity I was not in period costume.

Amazing house, free and in Central London. This is an amazing place. It doesn't take long to go round so you can still do a bit of shopping. The rooms are stunning as are the collections. Well worth a visit.

A wonderful rich assortment of perfect items. Pictures, sculpture, objets d'art, suits of armour, swords, plates - a varied collection - but each piece was of the very highest quality. Three hours only got us round the ground floor!

A Hidden Gem!. The Wallace Collection is amazing! It is in a very large private mansion and includes an impressive art collection as well as furniture, decorative art pieces and armour. And you can visit without having to pay an admission fee. As well, there is a very nice restaurant/cafe in the courtyard under skylights and a small shop with a good collection of books and collectables. Well worth a visit and a donation!

A real hidden gem. The best collection of French art and furniture you will see outside of France. Some of the paintings are of National Gallery Quality and the furniture is some of the best in the UK.Every first time visitor to London should make this a priority place to visit, you wont be disappointed.

When you realize this was a private collection from one family, it is even more breathtaking. I've visited the Wallace Collection numerous times over the years. And there is so much to see that each time, it is a fresh experience. The ground floor and first floor rooms with the paintings and miniatures and bible calligraphy pages is what I visited most recently. The objects in the cases are protected by leather coverings, that you pick up one by one to examine. So it is kind of like opening a present each time. Fun and beautiful. And the French and other European paintings are amazing.

Nice lunch and stunning house. I visited the Wallace Collection for lunch and to spend a couple of hours and really enjoyed myself. Lunch was great, with efficient, pleasant service in a beautiful glassed-in courtyard. There is a nice wine list, by the glass, and interesting small plate options to eat. After that, I wandered the house, viewing fine paintings (including a famous Rembrandt), stunning furniture, and examining Marie Antoinette's toiletries. The French porcelain on display (much of it Louis the XVI and Marie Antoinette's) is some of the finest examples I've ever seen. There's an extensive armoury collection, too, but that's not my thing, so I skipped a lot of it. I recommend it more for adults than kids.
Good. Really Good place to spend time with family and friends. Took my family here over the weekend and they loved the experience.

little known treasure in central London. very interesting collection. The most relevant part is the armoury and the french paintings, the Canalettos and the Velazquez. Sadly two of the three armoury rooms were closed! The collection also has excellent facilities if you are visiting with small children(e.g. changing room)The canteen is also very good.

Great free activity for 1-2 hours. Very much liked the amour and weaponry rooms in particular. The atruim is great for a cup of tea and a cake afterwards. The lawns in front are also a nice place to eat your sandwich in the summer.

One of the most beautiful museums in London. This place is truly a jewel. The rooms are breathtaking and the amount of information provided in the audio tour is most impressive. The collection of 18th Century French furniture & decorative arts will make your head spin. Additionally, there are also medieval and renaissance works to view. One can also view Franz Hall's famous 'The Laughing Cavalier' and a verified Rembrandt. There is also a lovely courtyard cafe, which i didn't try. Easily one of my favorite museums in London.
Love the wallace collection. Great building and atmosphere, you feel taht you are visiting a home and not a museum. Ben a couple of times and always enjoy coming back for a new visit every 2/3 years

My favourite museum. My favourite museum in London.Where do I start?I love it all,the ormolu clocks,the dutch paintings,the miniatures,the furniture.....I feel at home there.And they offer free lectures, well worth it if you want to find out more.

Small but wonderful !. A very beautiful building full of treasures! It is free to visit it. l liked the paintings very much and the furniture.l spent almost 2 hours to see everything.The restaurant is a perfect place to relax.
Grear and its free. House and museum collection are both excellent and well worth a visit - its just behind Selfridges in Oxford Street - shopping and culture what more could you wantChris

Hidden Gem?. Visited London many many times but only discovered the Wallace Collection this year. Fabulous house. Each room is decorated in a striking colour and filled with wonderful art and antiques. Best of all was the afternoon tea int he lovely restaurant!

Amazing place, one of the best private collections of art and objects. Wallace Collection is one of my favourite museums in London, the collection is very diverse, fine art from different periods, beautiful objects, and the house is an attraction on its own right. The collection is not too big, you can spend leisurely 1.5-2 hours and view the whole house. Admission is free, but you can make a small contribution at the door.
Another secret gem. Huge abd varied colectoo in London Town House. Not just the Laughing Cavelier! And its free!Excellent cafe.

Fantastic collection. A museum slightly off the core tourist track but with magnificent history, superb paintings 'Laughing cavalier', Rembrandt's portrait of his son etc and a Sevre porcelain collection that can only be matched in a few other places.

Hidden Gem. Free entry, recently refurbished rooms with beautiful silk wallpapers, variety of art works, miniatures, porcelain and armoury. Have attended some of the art workshops held for adults at the weekend, all very good. Lots of good events for families and schools and evening lectures of interest. I cannot believe that some visitors to London still don't know that the Wallace exists!

Art and architecture in an incomparable venue.. It is a treasure house of art and furnishings that rival museums for quality and variety. Impossible not to be impressed with the walk-through tour (self-guided). You can get face to face with Rembrandt, Hals, VanMeer, etc. The collections of Sevre and Chinese Porcelains as well as magnificent 17th and 18th century French furniture are not to be missed.
a fabulous museum. Wonderful collection of French furniture, paintings and porcelain Amazing clocks and fireplaces glorious room settings..A lovely central atrium area for a "bite"

My favourite place in London. A perfect place to see an amazing collection of French and Italian painting with beautiful restaured furniture, curtains and wall fabric by the Lyon silk from Prelle. Without forgetting the best place for an afternoon tea in central London.

Step back in time with swords and armour!. This place always makes me think of the past.. in a violent way. Which has shaped the world we live in today. The armour and swords are breathtaking - and scary! A most see for all.
Tucked away magnificence. Wonderful collection which you could take all day to enjoy. In between viewing you can have a cup of tea in the restaurant.

lunch at the wallace restaurant. Four of us had lunch in the museum restaurant yesterday and it was delicious. Three ate a la carte and one had the set menu. The carte was, I thought, much better value for money; the dishes on the set menu looked rather simple and the portions quite small, though my friend said he enjoyed it very much. My starter of poached egg and wild mushrooms was a wonderful, deeply flavoursome experience; a perfect beginning. But the roasted brill I had for main course was even better - a thick and sizeable piece of fillet, perfectly cooked, with the lightest of sauces, accompanied by tender pieces of violet artichoke. This dish cost rather less than twenty pounds - much less than you would pay in many restaurants. The two others at the table had roasted rump of veal, also with a delicious sauce and accompaniments. The house wine was of good quality, given the reasonable price and the espresso we finished with as good as any I've had in France or Italy and better than some.

Culture and nice place to meet for a pleasant lunch. Many people pop in for morning coffee, lunch or afternoon tea. However, they miss out on one of the most attractive inheritance exhibitions of all time.

Wallace and.... A real treasure; worth the effort to get there. We've been before and always see great stuff. Wealthy people collecting the best of the lots of things, then turning around and donating it to London. Wonderful cafe in the lower area (better sheltered than the Brit Museum).

fantastic small museum. I visited this museum twice in the past year - once by myself and then again with my mother when she came to visit me in London. It's really two experiences in one. First, it is a fantastic collection of art and artifacts mostly from England and Europe. Rococo artists such as Fragonard and Boucher are well represented. There is a very large and interesting arms and armory collection, a gorgeous collection of miniature boxes - basically something beautiful and historic at every turn. Having also served as the private residence of a wealthy family it offers a glimpse into that lifestyle. You could spend many happy hours here.

Treasures, treasures, treasures. Do go to visit the Wallace Collection if you want to feast your eyes on a huge range of intricate and unique treasures. It is worth several visits as more than an hour and a half really is overload.

Oasis off Oxford Street. Stumbled upon this by chance, what a find! Crammed with works by household name artists and staggeringly beautiful pieces from 14th century onwards displayed in a traditional period townhouse setting. Contrast with the ultra modern basement with contemporary exhibition and lovely atrium restaurant.Very friendly and welcoming staff and all free.Easily accessible, just behind Selfridges, don't miss it.

A hidden gem. The Wallace collection is a hidden gem off the beaten track for many tourists,and I would recomend you find the time to leave the hustle and bustle of the city and come and spend time contemplating some of the best collections of artwork by Renolds, Rembrandt and Canalleto up close and personal it is a real treat

a wonderful experience. This museum in the west end of london is vey easy to access--tube to bond streetThere is a collection of magnificent furnishings and art.. A great deal to see. also a good restaurant.The building was bequeathed to the city of London by the Wallace family--it is gem. It needs 2 visits to take it all in.-- not to be missedI have been quite a few times and I enjoy it each time. You feel like you are visiting a beautiful manson

The marmite of museums?. I visited with a friend who thinks this is the best afternoon out ever. He would easily have given it 5 stars. It didn't do so much for me though. I won't say don't bother, it definitely is an interesting place, but whether you love it or not is very much a matter of personal taste. For lovers of the baroque, the ornate, the 18thC and, frankly, camp historical bling, it's a very heaven. But modern minimalists may want to take a rain check!

Don't Miss This Small Museum. Having visited London many times, I thought I had just about seen it all. A friend suggested I go here, compared it to the Frick in New York City. Right! Just North of Selfridges Department store, this museum is a place to visit more than once.

Best small museum in London. For its size this is a treasure house beyond compare anywhere in the world, in my opinion. It houses a superb collection of historic porcelain, metalwork, clocks, armour, paintings and furniture. For so many of the exhibits most of the national museums of the world would dearly love to own - such is their artistic and historic merit.As well as its permanent collection there is a brilliant conservation display, a great restaurant, library and lecture theatre.Easy to get to being a short walk north of Oxford Street.

Wonderful place!. This is a wonderful place. Right in the busy shopping heart of London, very close to Bond Street tube station, and Selfridges on Oxford street.
Beautiful collections of art and armoury, displayed in beautiful rooms. Please take your time for tea or lunch in the wonderful restaurant.
London's best kept secret. The Wallace collection is superb! It is free to the public and you can find it behid Selfridge's dept store. Wonderful painting, furniture, armour etc.

A favourite. There are many fine collections in London but none has the intimacy of the Wallace. Wonderful.
Since Oliver Peyton took over the restaurant in the atrium the food is first class. What a wonderful place to wile away the day, the morning enjoying the collection and then a long leisurely lunch that lasts all afternoon.

Best art gallery ever!. This gallery is a treasure. Packed to the brim with beautiful things all displayed in beautiful rooms. If you tire of looking at the art then just look up at the ceilings and admire the exquisite chandeliers. Each room is painted and decorated differently. The gallery was once a family home and you can sense what a beautiful and elegant residence it would have been. The armour collection has to be seen to be believed. Kids will love the basement area where they can try on the armour ( my kids loved it!). As for me... I loved Fragonard's painting "The Swing"...just beautiful! I can't believe you can experience all these fabulous treasures and there is no entrance fee.Really a wonderful, wonderful place.
A little gem. You will be delighted if you get the chance to visit this collection. I had the most wonderful afternoon looking through the various exhibits.

Hidden gem. This is a wonderful collection of Old Masters, armour, porcelain, furniture, etc...located in elegant, eighteenth century, Hertford House just a few minutes north of Selfridges in Oxford street. The collection is not so large that it overwhelms and it is free. Afterwards you can enjoy tea in the glassed inner courtyard.
worth a visit. worth a visit - a quiet haven in busy London - beautiful, interesting & free but not well advertised

A phantastic location for a great collection!. I make it very simple: Great collection, great location - what else to say? Everything works together and even if the collection may not be the largest collection you feel like being in a home rather than a museum

Hidden treasure. Well worth a visit to see some of the best private collections in Europe. It's free and opening hours are convenient. Great for husbands who are not to keen to accompany wives shopping at Selfridges :) , especially when followed by cake and coffee at nearby Marylebone high st.

Superlative. This old house, previously owned by a wealthy banker, the contents of which have been donated by Mr Wallace houses some really excellent artifacts and art pieces. The nature and design of the house also complements the features and art within it.When it came to the restaurant, this was very nice too. Actually one of the most professional and attractive restaurant environments in London that I have been to. The staff are impecably dressed and polished, the food is standard with a selection of your more savoury and non-mainstream dishes.

"Very good". Apart from all the other museums and galleries I also enjoyed my visit to the Wallace Collection. The only negative thing was that it was very dark in some rooms. Especially (or deliberately?) in the room where Nicolas Poussin's "Dance to the Music of Time" was. Frans Hals' "Laughing Cavalier" is really one of the highlights in the Wallace Collection.

A must visit. This is the best little gallery in London. The venue, art and furniture were great but I really enjoyed the armour. well worth a visit but do allow yourself enough time to do it justice.

Wonderful Hidden Collection. A wonderful collection made over many years and bequeathed to the country. The collection cannot be split up. It has great history particularly to the kings of France. The square is just off Oxford street and the guide tour was fasinating. We did not manage the armoury but will definitely viist again.

Small and beautiful. What I love about small galleries that evolve from private collections is that you actually really like all the paintings included! On a par with the Frick Collection in NYC.
In a beautiful building just off Oxford Circus so you can get some High street shopping in if you are a tourist!
Well worth a visit! And it's free!
Wombat. A must. It's free, a fine house filled with treasures. Very pleasant restaurant too. In a lovely square behind Selfridges.

Best mixed collection in London.. I didn't really know what I'd think, but the admission was free so I wasn't gonna complain. Instead I was blown away by the whole collection. It was awesome, and a really good mix of different interesting things, from the art work to the furniture. The coolest thing though was all of the armor and weaponry!
Just excellent for an afternoon tea. Best place in London for an afternoon tea...? It is indeed. Take a walk around the mansion (which is free by the way) before moving into a courtyard.
A hidden gem. With armor and fine art, as well as some decorative pieces, this lovely preserved town home of the Wallace family is a national treasure. Don't miss it!

Awesome Armoury display. It has a very impressive display of ancient armour and weaponry. Swords, spears, suits of armour etc. Always hard to find museums or educational places to take my young son so discovered that they had an armoury collection so thought would give it a go.Delighted that we did as they had armour that I had never seen before .You have the fun of going into the basement and trying on chainmail, helmets etc.For the less bloodthirsty there a fine range of ceramics and paintings as well.One of our favourite museums in London.
Impressive art in personnal ownership. The exhibition contains a large collection, owned by one family.The entry is free of charge too.The restaurant at the back is also a must, with decent prices.
Always perfect. Stunning and exactly the right size for a museum. Armoury is amazingly beautiful. Its an inspirational place for creativity.
A wonderful collection. This is probably London's best kept secret. The most wonderful collection of paintings that can be seen in an extraordinarily beautiful building.
Elegant and eclectic. Beautifully presented in a logical way with explanations and in very elegant surroundings. It is free and worth every penny!

Just Great. A super little museum which is well worth a visit, Wonderful exhibits and paintings without being too much to take in.
The restaurant that is in a conservatory is very very good with friendly and professional service. Well worth a visit

Just lovely. Interesting exhibitions in what feels like a National Trust property; close to the heart of London and, yet, when you're there you feel a million miles from the hustle and bustle. It is just lovely!

A great educational trip. I have taken art students from school to take part in the educational learning that is offered here.
It is an excellent resource and a great experience for pupils.
It is well worth looking at their educational packages.
The building itself is also very interesting.

A fabulous museum. I wish i had visited this museum before as I will return without doubt.
The exhibits are stunning and the layout is sympathetic as a whole experience.
If you wish to see a vast variety of beautiful interesting things, then visit this museum.

Fantastic collection. No admission charge to this wonderful jewel in the centre of London. The collection is vast and many well known and loved paintings can be seen. The rooms in the style of Versailles are especially sumptuous. An excellent restaurant also

A good place to visit. This is a great museum to visit. Lots of amazing exhibits to see including the Laughing Cavalier. You really need more time to see it all. There is a nice restaurant - very busy - if you need a break and you are not far away from Oxford Street also.

Wonderful to See!. We took a guided tour of the Wallace Collection. The guide was interesting and knowledgeable and made our visit much more meaningful. The rooms were filled with magnificent furniture and magnificent works of art. There also beautiful tapestries, wallpaper and draperies. All in all, a wonderful experience.

Fascinating. A less well-known gallery and art collection in London, but a grand set of rooms and an interesting collection of art, furniture and other curios. Centrally located, it is also available for very stylish private functions, I found out.

A quiet and beautiful refuge. The art is mostly not to my taste. Too much French baroque. But the collection overall is wonderfully eclectic. The house is perfection. And to find a place as quiet and beautifully lit as this in central London is a miracle. Visit the restaurant for afternoon tea: that's worth travelling from anywhere to experience. The tea is excellent, the service is impeccable and the restaurant itself, in a covered courtyard, is a symphony of elegance and light.
excellent museum. Great place to look around and take in bits at a time.Firly easy to find from bond st station with excellent pubs and restaurants around.
One of the many hidden gems of London. A beautiful museum full of interesting and unusual things. Wonderful place to take the children who will love all the suits of armour!
Best sword collection around. Love this place! Not into the furniture and paintings (not my taste) but the Indian sword collection is tops!

A piece of tranquility in a busy city. We had a lovely time on a rainy day in this beutufull museum based on five generations of family collections of beutifull ceramics dating from 15th century to 19th century, 2500 objects of arms and armour, sculpture collections, european oil paintings and a beutifull collection of french furniture all organized in magnificent rooms.The lovely restaurant is a big bonus and adds to the experience.

Excellent!. Amazing art collection, wonderful pieces in beautiful rooms. The amount of artworks is really impressive, great for an art enthusiast such as myself! Every time I travel to London I make sure to go back, the Wallace Collection is a gem, even more amazing is the fact that you can enjoy all that for free! There is a restaurant and gifts shops inside as well. It's near Oxford Street and easy to reach. I don't think I'll ever get tired to visit this place!

For the porcelain lover. If fine porcelain is your interest, this is a must. Some of the pieces are like those in the Buckingham Palace collection. "Old School" art and very "fancy". Not for everyone, but if your interests are this period, it's for you. Highest quality pieces.

tea in the conservatory. one of my favorite times is to have afternoon tea in the conservatory and then wander through the exhibets and enjoy the collections...very diverse and the rooms are so authentic in their settings....some I remember from old design textbooks and they are lovely to see in person...no rush ,just wander and absorb history and beauty....then go shopping on Oxford street!!

Great place for business events. Very good location, lovely building and an amazing private collection. Very unique experience. The function room was superb and the food and service excellent. We will use this venue again the in the future. Suitable for harder to please guests.

Fascinating tour. Beautiful building tastefully decorated a pleasure to tour round it , treasures at every turn but 'The Laughing Cavalier was worth the visit on it's own, You could get so close to see the detail of the art work was special. Lovely selection of coffees and teas in the restaurant beautifully served. So glad we went

A wonderful museum. If you are in or near Oxford Street, do visit the Wallace Collection. The museum has a wonderful collection of very varied art displayed in an architectural gem. When you get tired of the museum visit the restaurant which is very good

my favorite museum in London. I love the size, collections and decor of this magnificent mansion museum. Lovely location, could spend many many hours pouring over its treasures; including Fragonard, Rubens and armour!!

Cosy... yet packed with interesting exhibits. Spent the better part of a day at the Wallace Collection. Amazing collection of Renaissance arms and armour. While not as large as the Royal Armouries, the Wallace more than made up for it by quality. The curators did a fantastic job. I only wish there was a catalogue app that I could refer to as I'm looking at the exhibits. I'd pay money for that.

An amazing collection, housed in a beautiful building, with no crowds of tourist.. The Wallace Collection is to be found in Hertford House, Manchester Square, a few minutes walk north of Bond Street tube station. More relevantly for me, it's a gentle stroll from Marylebone Station, where I arrive when I come in from the country.Visiting this extraordinary collection is a perfect start to a day in London. I'm not interested in the extraordinary collection of armour and weaponry, and probably don't spend enough time admiring the beautiful furniture and porcelain, mostly French and from the 18th century.What I, and most visitors, go for are the paintings, many of which are unsurpassed in any museum anywhere. You could spend a day just in the main hall which, among many masterpieces, contains 'The Laughing Cavalier', by Frans Hals, The 'Dance to the Music of Time' by Poussin and, amazingly, three paintings of Mrs Mary Robinson (the actress known as 'Perdita') by Gainsborough, Reynolds and Romney. There's glory for you.But what draws me in more often than not are extraordinarily complete collections of paintings from 18th century France and the Netherlands of the century before. Here are a few of my favourites: from France, the exquisite portrait by Francois Boucher of a young Madame de Pompadour in a salmon pink dress, and the saucy 'Swing' by Fragonard; and from Holland a moving pair of works by Pieter de Hooch - that tender painter of children - one of a little girl helping her mother peel apples, the other of a little by delivering bread to a housewife; and a moving portrait of a lace maker, by Caspar Netscher.And all these gems can be seen for free! So you can just stroll in, spend five minutes in front of one of your favourites, and stroll out again.

the laughing cavalier. This is indeed one of London's most amazing hidden gems. A collection of art in an amazing stately home, sitting on a quiet square between the Marylebone road and Oxford Stree and only a few minutes walk from the incredible and avante garde Selfridges store. Give yourself enough time to have tea in the atrium tea room and make sure you ask about the laughing cavalier.

Lovely surprise!. I had never heard of the Wallace Collection, but we visited as part of a class trip. It was a great surprise. It's a museum within a mansion. There's a ton of beautiful art, but I also enjoyed seeing the lavish way the rooms were decorated, with ridiculously ornate furniture, richly colored walls, etc. I think it's definitely worth a visit if you have time to see it after the basic London attractions.

Superb in every way. What a wonderful collection of amazing art, mostly collected on Grand Tours by one family. I'm not sure why a previous reviewer said that it's not well placed for tourists as it's just a hop, skip and a jump from Oxford Street so very easy to take a quick (5 minute) diversion.Each room holds a different surprise and there are detailed information sheets for each one, allowing you to understand each picture and/or artist without the need for buying a large book. It was through the information sheet that I learnt about the tricks which Canaletto employed to ensure that his paintings were saleable to a foreign, not local, market. If you like Reynolds, Frans Hals, Rembrandt, Fragonard, Sevres porcelain etc etc, then this is the place to come. It's also incredibly quiet. I visited on a Saturday afternoon when the whole of Oxford Street was pedestrianised before Christmas and yet there were only a handful of people in each room. The restaurant looked incredibly popular too.

a gem full of good art. This beautifully furnished gallery is crammed with first rate art, from Rembrandt to Fragonard, as well as beautiful 18th century furniture, porcelaine, sculpture, etc. Well worth a visit.

Absolutely amazing!. Exquiste building with a superb collections. The staff were friendly and helpful. A large range of information was available about every room and it's contents Each room was exquiste.. Need a day to explore, rather than cram everything in. Will definately return. No entrance fee either!

Worth finding. It is not widely known nor frequently visited, but I found it well worth the effort to locate. The exhibits are beautifully presented and it was far more comprehesive than I was expecting.

Poor organization. This museum come Art Gallery is not well placed for tourists, being off the main streets. They have a quite splendid collection of paintings, especially Canaletto's and Pousin's which is totally marred as they are arranged, higgledy-piggeldy, all over the place, defying any kind of logic, and without any meaningful chart to aid one in finding a particular painting.
Gem. Beautifully located in Marylebone and offering peaceful unhurried art -and for us, morning coffee or a very early glass of wine in lovely surroundings.

All the clocks work!. We visited this on the recommendation of a friend and were not disappointed. Amazing to see so may different and interesting objects collected by several generations of the same family.
There are many clocks here and most of them are still working and show the correct time.

A Lovely Place. Do yourself a favor if you love 18th century art and run to this museum. It is a delight. The house itself is more than lovely and the perfect setting for the Fragonard, Watteau and Boucher paintings which hang on its walls. jThe French furniture collection is outstanding and several European painting masterpieces by Titian, Rubens, Velasquez are breathtaking. Afternoon tea in the Wallace Restaurant is an added treat.

Hidden Treasure. This collection is one of the best kept secrets in London. It has some special exhibits that in another city would be considered the star attractions. It is wonderful that the collection is still together and so accessible - only 2 mins from Oxford St.

Aim for one of the tours. Absolutely fell in love with this grand town house, packed with the private and personal collection of generations of the Wallace family. The tour at 3.30 whet my appetite to know more and so a returned the following day to see the stuff that I had missed. My favourites were the Dutch masters and the one I'd like to bring home was The Lace Maker by Casper Netscher (1639 - 1684)

Such a collection.
