I have been to this place several times and every time I find something new and different my most recent visit I fell in love Catherine the Great's severe's porcelain' ice cream service! but always a favorite is Fragonard's "The swing". oh there are so many to choose from thats why this place is a must for these visiting London

Well worth a visit. Beautiful eclectic museum ! Staff are keen to engage with visitors and impart little gems of information about the various articles in their charge. Great range of art and armour to general curiosities all housed in wonderfully decorated rooms. There is a beautifully situated restaurant/cafe which serves somewhat pricey food.

An Alternative to Large Museums. This mansion in central London contains some excellent works, including paintings by Boucher, Watteau and Fragonard. Each room contains a book with commentary on the works displayed. Admission is free, donations are accepted. This collection does not match the scale or variety of the Frick in New York City or the Barnes in Philadelphia, but it is worth a visit, and is a nice alternative to London's large museums.

A hidden GEM on Manchester Square. This is a beautiful, small museum filled with art treasures of the great Dutch, French, Italian masters along with a very fine collection of decorative pieces and Sevres porcelain. The rooms are stunning...It is well worth a few hours.

Hidden Treasure. The Wallace Collection is just a couple of streets above Oxford Street, just behind Selfridges and admission is free. There is something there to interest most people. There is beautifully made Asian armour, plus plenty from other countries, and interesting old firearms and weapons. Glass-topped cases feature in many rooms and on pulling back covers to protect the contents from constant light, there are all sorts of wonderful objects to view, including exquisite illuminated manuscripts.As a boy, I had a round print of the Laughing Cavalier by Franz Hals in my bedroom and, having seen the original at the Wallace Collection, it was nice to see that those eyes follow you, too! The hall of original paintings is breathtaking, as is the room of Canalettos. The restaurant is excellent, as is the gift shop.It is hard to see how anyone could visit London and not put the Wallace Collection near the "must see" list.

Better than you think it will be. The easy to understand highlights map make visiting this beautiful house and grounds a treat. On the way back to main Londontown, you can stop at Paul Rothe & Sons on Marlybone for a quick soup!

My favourite gallery with even more!. We lived 2 blocks from the Wallace Collection. I would visit at least every month and took every visitor who stayed with us. It has been refurbished in recent years and is stunning. The wall fabrics, furnishing colours are amazing. Some of the best porcelain, majolica ware, miniatures in the world. Then there are the paintings, a great variety including Canalettos, my favourite Frans Hals The Laughing Cavalier, several Rembrandts, magnificent portraits by Gainsborough . A comprehensive collection of armoury. Great daily tours. and it is all free, free, yes free!!!Nice restaurant.Clean toilets. Put on the top of your list of things to do, you only need an hour or two.Close to Selfridges/Oxford St or walk from Bond or Baker St Stations.

The Best Museum in the World. The collection was gifted to the state and at present it is a free museum of baroque and rococo styles, porcelain, coins, furniture, weapon and other articles of art. One will find pictures by Fragonard, Canaletto, Reynolds, Rubens, Boocher, Hals, Rembrandt, Velazquez and other greatest artists.The palace rather than house or manson is fully furnished. You may walk there, enjoying masterpieces. A good idea to have a cup of coffee with some cake in the domed restaurant in the centre of the palace.

A hidde treasure. Tucked away behind Oxford St, this is really worth a visit. Because it is off the main visitor route it is pleasantly uncrowded even at busy times. The collection is gorgeous and well presented in the family mansion, rather like The Frick in New York.The catalogue is good but the visit would be even better with an audio guide

Fabulous French Mansion. 18th century collection of magnificent French art and collections, including Severe, Fragonards,and too much to mention here. Beautiful restaurant for lunch.An interesting change from all that English history while in London. Outstanding audio guide to get the most out of your visit.

Beautiful art, quietly angry staff. The Wallace Collection is a hidden gem – a rare place that is privately owned, yet free to enter, consisting of some precious work from artists of great repute. I wish the staff was a bit nicer though. They remind me of British Airways cabin crew: the tight smile (if there is ever a smile or acknowledgement), a barely hidden snootiness and a feeling of Little-Britain (or League of Gentlemen) type provincialism. The staff there have the face of someone barely tolerating visitors, walking about with loud, angry, accusatory steps, thumping over the laminate flooring. That kind of angry, emotionally-dead Englishness is slowly dying, but at the Wallace Collection it lives on, fustily. The British were probably like this in India in the dying days of Empire (sulky, refusing to emote, unable to feel, all hidden behind a mask of passive anger, cloaking a lack of achievement). Thankfully most of London is no longer like this – most of London is more real, alive, human, even trendy. Walk through Charlotte Street in Fitzrovia or Soho Square and you see the real London – people who work, read, eat and emote. Real human beings who feel real emotions. The staff at the Wallace Collection isn’t like this. The staff at the South Bank centre are nice, so are those at the legendary Curzon cinemas.

A Hidden Gem. This Museum is tucked away in a quiet backwater just off Oxford Street, near Selfridges. It has a wonderful collction of artwork by well known artists including Canaletto. there is also an extensive display of armour and swords, furniture, manuscripts and Majolica. There is a restaurant in a covered in courtyard which looks absolutely lovely, but too expensive for our pocket; ok if you want a 'posh nosh'.

Wonderful gem. If you have been to the Frick in NY...very much in the same realm. I enjoyed it - almost overwhelming to take in. There is also a lovely french cafe that has great food. I would highly recommend.

Full of compact gems. I went here for a corporate beano, having kicked myself for not visiting when I worked just round the corner. It is a delightful gallery because of the gems which pop up when your eyes wander a little. Fragonard's 'The Swing' is a classic example, and really benefits from being able to look at it in your own good time.

A nice little oasis in the heart of London. Hidden at the back of bustling Oxford Street, this is a lovely place to spend an hour or two. There is of course the beautiful art collection and furnishings, but also a nice little cafe at the back in a courtyard with a glass covered roof
A Tucke Away Gem. If you're staying near by, are into museums and have a morning or afternoon to wander around this amazing house don't miss it.

Lovely place but bad service. The venue is amazing and worth a visit but prepare for a frosty reception. The staff were very rude in the cloakroom and when we wrote to complain the letter back was dismissive and rude. Its a shame.

Wonderful!. We strolled along Oxford street, then went to this gallery and I would have to say this was one of our nicest experiences in London. The art is amazing, the furniture pieces were beautifully preserved and the rooms were rich in design. This was an outstanding venue.

Wow what a little gem!. Just off Oxford Street this is a fabulous little haven. Hals, Reynolds, Ruebens, Rembrant, Canelleto. All originals, all diamonds, all well kept and well presented. If you are in the West End find an hour to explore this top quality collection of outstanding pieces. In every way this is a slice of culture that is worth investing your time in. One of London's best kept secrets, and it is free!

great knowledge, wonderful collection. we took the guided tour given by a wonderful guide whose knowledge of the exhibits was perfectand background information on the people and times the pieces were from was wonderful.the manor in which the exhibits are shown is very inviting, and it really is like being in someones home.this free museum/gallery is great.

A bit of everything: allow plenty of time for this well kept secret. The sheer scale and amount of exhibits is a little daunting at first. If on limited time, plan ahead as to what you want to see most. I took nearly 2 hours just on the arms and armour! Alternatively, see the whole lot over more than one visitAll well presented although you'll need a guide book to learn more than merely what the items are.This collection is not as well know as London's "classic" museums but, for anyone interested in art, arms,(lots of) miscellaneous "stuff" and the sheer sze of collection that one family can acquire, this is hard to beat and worth seeking out.

Free, central, uncrowded....and interesting with good cafe !. The Wallace collection shows what an art / antique agglomerator can do in a large town house, or in this case also over successive generations. Especially enjoy the armour and weapons collection. They often stage free talks and demonstrations and have an excellent courtyard restaurant and gift shop. All this is within easy walking distance of Oxford Street and is free, but largely ignored by the tourist hordes. I would actively schedule a lunch stop if going to be in the area and browse a bit at a time over return visits.

Culture and quality just off Oxford Street. This is such a wonderful place to visit. Lots of famous paintings and artists all under one roof in a sumptuous setting. I'd recommend not trying to do the whole collection in one go - although you can easily.There is an excellent restaurant popular, it seems, with ladies who lunch.But the most notable thing is the excellent shop which has managed to balance offering a serious collection of art history books with also offering a fantastic selection of gifts. It must be the best museum shop in London that actually sells gifts uniquely related to the Collection and which you won't find anywhere else. Perfect for buying presents for the person who has everything.Highly Recommended!

A gem of a museum, away from the crowds. Tucked away just behind busy Oxford Street, the Wallace Collection is an absolute gem of a museum. It's not very big but has a lot on display so you will easily spend over an hour there.It has a few big names as well as a lot of less known artists, but the quality of each piece is amazing, unlike some museum who boast major artists but only have minor works to show. Pay particular attention to the furniture, the collection displays an impressive number of matching pieces from the Boulle school. You can recognise them as they use the same wood cuts but in opposite effects, a highly precise technique that took months to craft back in the 18th century. There is an impressive armoury which will delight little boys and grown men, and some of the armours are placed at ground level so that one can watch their reflection in the cabinet glass and imagine they're inside it.A very nice cafe/restaurant in the center courtyard has a glass ceiling makes it perfect in winter to catch a bit of daylight. The restaurant is very popular so book when you enter the museum.

A great way to spend a few hours. I have only recently discovered this museum and it is a joy. There is so much to see here and the great thing is that it is free! As well as all the numerous exhibits there are also talks and presentations. There is also an excellent courtyard restaurant.

a nice building. interesting to visit!. they have some collections including paintings and heritage furniture. the building itself is very pretty and well-reserved. but the best thing is probably because it's not that famous for tourists, you can have better quality when visiting with less crowds.

I love this Gallery. I go to this gallery every time I visit London. I like the size and scope of the collection. There is nothing I dislike about it. And youcan have a great coffee or tea in the atrium restaurant
Always a pleasure. No matter how many times I've visited the collection continues to be impressive, interesting and educational.

Great place for lunch. The Wallace collection is rather an odd mashup of armour, glass wear and paintings but well worth a look. Probably the greatest asset of the collection is the building with it's fine covered courtyard restaurant which in itself is a destination for many.
A joy. This has a wonderful collection and it is relatively uncrowded. It is a real joy to discover many familiar paintings . The restaurant is great too, in a lovely courtyard setting and good food.

Interesting and eclectic museum in central London. Free entry. The Wallace Collection is one of London's most overlooked museums. Many Londoners have never visited. However, tucked away behind Selfridges department store, it is a treasure trove of the art collected by one family and it is located in their original London home - Wallace House, which is a palatial venue and worth seeing in its own right. The collection of porcelain, paintings, armour, sculpture and furniture is eclectic but all of the highest quality. The great thing about its free entry is that one can pop in for a few minutes and revisit another time and have a entirely different experience. The courtyard cafe is also a nice venue to eat.
History of the collection amazing!. Viewing the items many of which were from the Louvre at the time it was a home is a treat. Give a good afternoon to enjoy the whole display well.

Slow Leisurely Lunch. Galleries wonderful. Restaurant OK if you have a lot of time so great for a leisurely lunch. Avoid if you wanted a quick bite! Food inspirational but well priced and with a great attention to assembly!

hidden gem in Marylebone. Well what can you say. Free admission and some of the most famous art anywhere all a stones throw from Oxford street. How is this place not always crowded. Too good to be true

Wonderful collection!. The collection is superb. The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming. A nice change from larger museums which can be be a chore to get through.
The Wallace Collection should be on the "must do" list!
Wonderful museum. Very interesting museum with a lovely restaurant in the heart of central London. Definitely worth seeing.

Fabulous place. Lovely hideways from the crowds to contemplate beautiful collection of art work. And the tearoom is fantastic value. The restaurant is a bit pricey for the food, although very good but vey tiny portions.

Amazing, and digestible amount of art, in many forms. For free!. We visited this collection on a weekday, and the House was not at all crowded. The art here is in many forms, paintings, furniture, clocks, armor, majolica, sculpture...something for everyone. I highly recommend the audio tour as it added greatly to my understanding of several of the pieces. Although the National Gallery, National Portrait, Tates, and all of the great museums are also available in London, this is a wonderful, digestible amount of art that can easily be appreciated in a few hours, depending on your interests. I highly recommend this as an option, although it probably is not for small children.

Great place to drop into for a bit of calm.... This a great spot to get out of Oxford Street if you're all done in with shopping. You can marvel at the miniatures & cameos or laugh with the Cavalier, or simply wander & take in what you fancy. When you're done there is a great covered dining area where you can have tea or lunch, though it does get busy.

Hidden gallery. If you're looking for a place to quietly escape the central London melee but still want to soak up some art go to the Wallace.A secret spot a short walk from Oxford St this gallery is pure refinement and the collection of Marie Antoinette belongings is a real treat. Enjoy a lovely Peyton tea afterwards - this man has the monopoly on museum amuse bouche.

Beautiful. If you are into French Furniture of the 18th Century and beautiful paintings this private collection is for you. The Wallace Collection has the largest and best pieces from 1700-1789 of furniture from Versailles and Le Petit Trianon sold by the Revolutionaries in 1793 at auction. The Agents of the Wallace were on hand to buy porcelain, dinnerware and furniture belonging to the Kings of France and to the unlucky Marie-Antoinette. A must see in London.

A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. To my shame I had never heard of it and a friend suggested we go. What a beautiful building which is presented to such a high standard. The rooms were stunning. Masterpeieces on every wall - just too much to take in. Friendly staff. Free entry. Will recommend and return. There was just too much to see in one visit.

Excellent "Small" Museum. We loved this museum! It is advertised as a "small" museum, but there are a lot of wonderful treasures here. Combine your day at the museum with shopping on Oxford Street a few blocks away (you can check your purchases while you look around). A beautiful building, with art displayed in every room. An amazing collection - paintings by all manor of famous painters, miniatures, lovely Sevres and Majolica porcelain, sculptures, furniture, illuminated manuscripts and jewellery. I even enjoyed the display of weapons and armor (beautiful engraving and jewels on the hilts of the swords and pistols).And it's free!! This museum is well worth a visit, as is the gift shop (we didn't try the restaurant).

Hidden gem. Was recommended this by a London taxi driver as a little known attraction.
The building and decor is stunning, and worth a visit alone. My particular favourite is the armour.

Intimate Museum. This is a gem. You might have to look at little to find it, but it is a nice change of pace from the grand museums. The Original London Walks used to do a walking tour of this museum, and is worth doing as a part of your visit if the timing works.
Well worth the time to visit. This is a wonderful treasure trove of collectibles. It also has a lovely cafe when you need a break and a sit down.
Yes to swords. Any history buff will get a kick out of the wealth of artifacts at this collection. Sword swallower's delight to boot.

A perfect place to visit , calm and full of interest.. This is just the perfect collection to visit. The size of the museum means that it gives a personal feel, and you can easily get round all the rooms. Being a collection means that there is something for everyone, the ceramics and beautiful and the paintings are really interesting , with some well known and some much less so. It is very interesting to see all the different styles. As it is free entery you feel happy to go in and just study one area , and visit again to spend more time looking at other things. As well as all the works of art I find the house very interesting , and each room can give you the feeling of being taken back in time and imagine living in such a house. Of course the resturant in the covered courtyard gives a welcome break and is a lovely place to sit and relax over tea or coffee, although the service can be a little slow. I will Keep returning to the Wallace collection

Terrible Tea. Sorry to report that tea this afternoon at The Wallace Collection was disappointing. We had two English Cream teas and a Cornish Cream tea. Sadly, these arrangements had seen better days. We were underwhelmed by the finger sandwiches - think 'care in the community' - no flavour but edible. The sandwiches were accompanied by three miniature cakes that had seen better days. We sent them back requesting a swap - the elderly little cakes for one slice of carrot cake. This was refused. Although the particularly ancient strawberry tart was retired and replaced by a morsel of apple cake. We ate our expensive little fossils with no pleasure. A lot of money for mediocre food. The addition of a 12.5% 'optional' service charge was contemptuous.

A great oasis in central London. This is a super museum containing one mans collection. You will find old masters here like the laughing cavalier and others which you will immediately recognise. There are arma and armour, ceramics, sculpture and more. The waft of good coffee as you come in is welcoming. If you only have a few minutes still visit it is great to unwind from the pressures of Oxford street. Otherwise spend a day no crowds, plenty of space most civilised. I cannot recommend it enough.
Great free tours. Very much enjoyed intro tour and lecture about its world-famous Sevres collection. Restaurant has great coffee and walnut cake.

Wonderful smaller collection in a beautiful mansion. Slightly off the beaten path but well worth a visit. Like visiting a wealthy friends' private collection. There is a peaceful restaurant in the (covered) courtyard, perfect for lunch or tea during your visit.

A lovely gallery. It is a lovely gallery with a fine collection of art and several Rembrandts. I also liked the change of pace from an overwhelmingly large museum to a pleasant stroll through the rooms. Loved the restaurant!
Worth a visit. Lovely place tucked away on Manchester Square not far from Oxford Street.Spent a pleasant few hours perusing the collection and enjoyed coffee in the lovely courtyard style cafe .

This is sooooooooo smart I can hardly believe it. Guys and girls if you want style, if you want to feel like a member of the aristocracy, if you want to be treated like a human being rather than just a tourist this is the place to be.I went to an exhibition about swords, small but perfectly formed as they say.There is a huge amount of opulence here and it just shows how the owning classes lived.I swear the most of the staff are out of the Eton College because they are very knowledgeable though of course new members know less than established staff members.In the central inner courtyard, which is covered, you can imagine you're in Claridges and be served delightful afternoon tea with cakes and little sandwiches and someone.This could be the place to propose to your partner, to do business about some artistic endeavour, or a first date when you want to impress your girlfriend or boyfriend.

Sword play. I went to see the sword exhibit with my boyfriend and then we had an afternoon tea at the restaurant there. The exhibit was well done and very informative (about the history of sword and raspier), shame there was not more but then if you wanted to know more, there is a weapon exhibition upstairs for that. There is also plenty of furniture from Marie-Antoinette to have a look at.
Best jewel in London. On a quiet street just off Oxford street, step into the 17th century. Magnificent collections that must not be missed!

Okay. Not the Frick.. Nice small art collection displayed in "home" format. We thought it would be more like the Frick in NYC, and it fell far short of that. But nice if you want a very brief exposure to an art collection. There's a very nice restaurant in the (enclosed) courtyard for a typical museum lunch of tiny portions of ladies fare. We went bc we've visited London several times and knew their wonderful large museums. Dont know that I will recommend it to friends.

Great place. If you're a fan of art-history and want to great place to have some good food and experience a beautifully designed building with a great collection of art from particular eras that you won't see the likes of which anywhere else, the collection itself is not very well known and I really think this is better than some of the big galleries and evidence of that is the never-ending ques that you will always find in front of this place since it is quite popular with people have been there - so defintiely make a reservation before going so that you don't regret having to wait for a few hours in a que !

Love the museum look of the place. If you're a history buff and like good food, then this is the place to be, round the corner from Oxford street, and a great place to meet up with friends to spend a lovely afternoon chatting away. Be warned you have to make reservations well in advance, or spend a few hours in the queue.
Beautiful art in a beautiful setting. Not too big to take in on one visit, but beautifully laid out in a wonderful building. Well worth a visit to see the famous 'Laughing Cavalier' painting.

Wallace collection in London. Wallace collection in London is not well known, but it is absolutely "MAST VISIT" attraction.If you are short in time and have to choose, do not hesitate and visit this magnificent collection.It is free of charge!Do not miss it!!

A find. We had never been here before and it was a delightful find. Paintings, furniture, ceramics and even snuff boxes. Take a guided tour to get more out of it. Not so much for a first time visitor, but for someone who has already hit the London highlights.

Hidden gem!. This is a must see in London! Wonderful experience, a true masterpiece in terms of arts and architeture.
It was one of the highlights of our trip in Europe!

Not just a museum. This fantastic house just at the back of Oxford street is not just a musem but a house full of everything, You will not be bored at all its not to huge that you will come out in a daze. I recomend this wonderful place to all my new and old friends.

Lots to look at. Do you know the best thing about this place was the restaurant, I cannot recommend too highly the cornish cream tea. Fantastic value for the price and the ambience in the restaurant was just lovely.
Decadence. Fascinating. There is lots to see but there is too much to take in in one visit. The collection covers a broad selection of art and artifacts.
From a time and dynasty almost forgotten. The Wallace collection is a reminder of decadence, class and refined living. The collection is a hidden treasure in the centre of London.
History and High Tea. The Wallace Museum is a must see, its free to get in and serves a great reasonable priced High Tea, the Armour Collection is incredible and cannot be missed if you enjoy history
What a gem of a museum. Small enough not to tire you out with printed guides and good varied selection to see.Friendly helpful staff.

A treasure trove. I visited the Wallace Collection for the first time recently. It is simply quite staggering and as others have mentioned a hidden gem. I do not pretend to be an expert in matters of art but whatever your interests you cannot be less than moved by this museum. The exhibits are displayed in rooms which have been tastefully and expensively decorated and includes paintings, furniture, ceramics and an armoury amassed by a private collector . Lack of time did not allow me to spend as much time as i would have liked at this superb museum but I will be revisiting on a next visit to London. There is a lovely courtyard cafe / restaurant within this museum and although prices are a little high I would recommend a coffee or tea as a minimum.

A very special place. Take the docent tour with delightful Mrs. Webster. This wisp of woman sparkles with stories about the collection and the family who amassed it. She brings the pieces alive with little comments such as “oh, these belonged to Catherine the Great,…. Marie Antoinette’s sewing tables….Louis XV gilt chandeliers…the bidding war between the Baron and the 4th Marquess over Frans Hals “The Laughing Cavalier….hidden inside this ornate jeweled snuffbox….” This incredible museum demands that you linger. I spent 6 hours the first day and returned for an additional two hours just for the Grand Gallery which is closing this month for renovations and will not reopen until 2014. Tip: the staff has great knowledge of the pieces so make sure that you engage them in conversation.

The perfect size for an art gallery. A lesser known treasure in London, and not as intimidatingly large as the National gallery, the Wallace Collection has just the right amount of art to let you see most of it on a day visit, with some extraordinary gems like Franz Hals' Laughing Cavalier. It also has one of the prettiest dining spots in London in its light filled glass roofed inner courtyard.
Nothing short of amazing. An incredible place and one of the only museums that I can visit and want to go back again the next day. Definitely my favourite museum in London

a jewel box palace museum. I don't really want to write this as the Wallace is my local and I don't want crowds there... It really is a jewel - very ornate, very polished and created to sparkle. You have to like the period it celebrates - be warned... And I never thought I liked armoury till I went to one of their specialist exhibitions, when I was bowled over.

Another great London museum. The Wallace Collection was highly recommended to me on a visit to London and it did not disappoint. There are lots of Sevres porcelain pieces but my favorite are the Boulle furniture pieces, so ornate and beautiful! Also, the armor and weapons displays were very interesting. The Wallace Collection has a more comfortable, homey feel than most museums. Entry is free and it's open daily from 10AM-5PM. There is a restaurant in the courtyard. Really enjoyed this attraction.

A true London gem. The Wallace Collection is a free museum in the former home of an earl with a passion for collecting. The museum is largely displayed as it was in the 19th century, thus it has the feel of being invited into the home of an eccentric Victorian collector. The museum has a lovely collection of paintings from the Renaissance to the 19th century and an extensive trove of objets d'art and other decorative arts. Several rooms are dedicated to 18th century French decorative arts and there is also an extensive collection of medieval and early modern European and Asian armor.The gift shop is also fantastic, selling items which replicate the design elements of the artifacts on display.I would highly recommend a visit to the Wallace Collection!

One of Londons great free galleries. As I got just back from holiday in Venice, I wanted to see some of the art depecting Venecian scenes. This gallery makes a terrific break from oxford street shopping and is free, though it is nice if you can leave a pound of two as a donation to help keep the gallery open (it's run mainly by volunteers).

Guided tour at 2pm. Be sure to get In on the tour. The guide really brings to life some of the major paintings and objects.. I want her to be my art teacher! Wonderful! Also, go downstairs, try on the ancient helmets and chain maile, such fun! Surprisingly few people in the afternoon. Since it's free, you feel so happy to purchase a nice postcard or two from the lovely gift shoppe.

Amazing!. Much to my shame, I had never heard about the Wallace Collection!When I went there with a friend today, I was amazed to see such an amount of beautiful items... Being French, I was astounded to discover that the Wallace family had brought back from France stunning pieces of art like Sevres porcelain, Boulle furniture, marvellous paintings by the likes of Boucher/Watteau/Canaletto/Rubens amongst others (not to forget Hals' famous "The Laughing Cavalier": amazing: his eyes follow you whichever way you go!), and so much more!!!I am going to recommend it to everyone I know.Definitely worth a visit!!! I'll go back!

A wonderful collection that was FREE. I was lucky enough to catch a tour of this collection of furniture and art put together by the Seymour-Conway family, the Marquesses of Hartford. Many of the rooms had been recently refurbished and featured many famous works of art (including "The Laughing Cavalier") and many objects that belonged to Marie Antoinette

So happy I didn't miss this. We spent two hours wandering around gazing at the fabulous paintings. The rooms are so impressive, the walls are all lined with silk hangings and the drapes at the windows all match in rich jewel colours. i was almost as impressed with these as the paintings. Fabulous to see such well-known masterpieces on display, the gallery guides are helpful and informative. There is a lovely cafe if you feel the need of a break as well. I shall definitely go back again as there is so much more I didn't get around to. Would advise anyone to visit the gallery, easy to find and well signposted.

Stunning collection! & Free!. I visited this museum on a Saturday morning recently as I was staying nearby. Hereford House has a stunning collection of galleries filled with armoury, porcelain, clocks, furniture and pictures including Canalettos. There is a fabulous restaurant in the inner courtyard, and the house although austere from the outside is also interesting in its own right, grand staircase, dining room etc. I would recommend a tour (which had just started at 11.30am and which was very informative, eg interesting facts such as the house had been originally built for duck shooting as it would have been surrounded by countryside initially.)

A hidden trove just north of Oxford Street. Say you're staggering up Oxford Street, haunted by the knowledge that, as Wordsworth had it, 'Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers'. There's solace nearby. Situated more or less behind that remarkable temple to commerce, Selfridge's, is a temple to art: the Wallace Collection. The aesthetic harvest of a forward-looking family, housed in their imposing home, the Wallace Collection makes for a mind-bending stroll. You walk through a succession of ornate, exquisitely decorated rooms studded with treasures, from intricate ivory carvings to fine maiolica; cloisonne pillboxes to 16th-century armour; and most wonderful of all, Frans Hals' Laughing Cavalier and works by Velazquez, Rembrandt, Titian, Poussin, Fragonard, Watteau and many more artistic luminaries. Balm for eye and soul, and absolutely free.

Certainly Worth A Visit!. Down in London on a theatre weekend break our group of 9 had an hour spare on a Sunday morning so went to the Wallace Collection. The first good point is that it opens at 10am, and it's free to get in! Found the staff very helpful and friendly, and the house is full of all sorts of stuff, not just paintings but armour, furniture, porcelain, grandfather clocks- allsorts! There were some fab Canaletto paintings, plus the wonderful Laughing Cavalier, which you were actually allowed to take photos of (without a flash but the room is well lit). Easily accesible from Bond Street tube station, I would definitely recommend the Wallace Collection, whether you had half an hour, or all day to spend there!

A Beautiful Place. Went with husband and 2 friends who were regular visitors - it was a treasure trove of a place and can't wait to go again! We took the tour which lasted about 1 and a half hours...and was free, as is entrance, but we gave £5 each on exit - it was worth every penny. beautifully renovated rooms and many of them to go to so more visits to cover them all plus the art gallery. I can highly recommend this lovely venue
what a mad assortment of stuff. I liked the idea that a slightly bonkers englishman went on the grand tour, and said "whats the best?" " Right I'll have 3 of those"Nothing to dislike.
worth a visit, or two. Defnitely visit here and take in all that this wonderful collection has to offer. You'd need a few days to see everything.
Get Wallaced. Terrific. This is one of the gallerys that not so many people know about. You will not be dissapointed. It has some fantastic works and many popular well known pieces. Visit and enjoy.

Magnificent collection of French 18th C Furniture and Art. The Wallace Collection is a must see in London. Probably the finest collection of 18th Century French Furniture in beautiful rooms. Free guided tours. Also see the collection of arms and armour.
Paintings & armour. Lovely old house in the middle of town. No charge. Wonderful historical paintings especially Canaletto also antique guns & suits of armour
A massive private collection. We really enjoyed our visit to the Wallace Collection. It is a varied assortment of collected art. The cafe is a MUST do. Would be great for a corporate event.

Worthwhile Jewel in the London Array of Museums. We spent several hours touring this positively wonderful museum tucked away on a charming little square near Oxford Street shopping as well as not far from The British Museum. The exhibitions of 18th and 19th century paintings, sculptures and others artworks (furniture, porcelain) were truly representative of some of the great masters collected by the Marquesses of Hertford and Sir Richard Wallace. The restaurant in the downstairs courtyard looked like a great luncheon spot. We plan to return the next time we travel to London.

Well worth a visit. We really enjoyed our visit here, especially seeing the "Laughing Cavalier" painting. Everything was displayed and maintained wonderfully. We were surprised there was no entrance charge although you can make a contribution to the upkeep. The prices in the shop were a bit steep and were they slightly less so I would have made several purchases, however this did not seem to deter people.Location excellent just being a short walk from Oxford St. I think they should advertise more and get more revenue from the cafe and shop to help maintain the artworks.
I Met Danni Minogue Here. I visit here to sketch and get inspiration for my designs. I have also met a few celebrities here whilst sketching. Danni Minogue was one a few years back.

A super art museum, free of charge!. Great collection of traditional paintings. I think the discreet location tucked away behind Oxford Street means it gets a lot less visitors than it deserves. That is good, because if more people knew about it, it would certainly be packed. The restaurant inside (which I didn't try) looks fantastic.

Fantastic collection. This is akin to the Frick in New York. A wonderful mansion house with an extraordinary collection of artworks (including china). A lovely cafe and restaurant in a covered Atrium with very good food. And not too full of tourists!
a real treat. It's wonderful to be able to visit a place like this for free. Many of the paintings are a joy and the arms and armour are a very impressive, even frightening, collection.

Wow! Such a sumptious collection!. Visiting this collection is free (although a donation is suggested). The collection is large but can be easily done in half a day. Might be best to visit twice as the extent of the art can be a bit difficult to take in. Cafe is excellent. China is amazing and we understood that the rooms has been recently redecorated so the colours in the wall paper and furnishings are fabulous.

Superb collection of historic rooms. We stumbled into this place after walking around central London. It is a magnificent museum and it is highly recommended. The rooms are so ornate and beautiful - full of interesting period furniture, vases, paintings and decorations.

Little gem in the heart of the shopping!. Came across this by accident when I ventured off the oxford street to find a loo! Just gorgeous museum, amazing paintings, beautiful courtyard serving food.... I can not believe this little secret haven is so close to shopping heaven!

Outstanding collections of everything from paintings to armour. This is one of the most amazing collections of items you will ever see in one place. There is something here for everyone. .It is in an exqusite mansion, nearly one block long and filled with the most unimaginably beautiful items from ivory carvings, glassware, china, paintings, unique clocks and furniture of the most beautiful designs and oh, so much more--rooms full of mid-evil armour from all over the world!! And that is just a small amount of the kinds of things they have!!!. And it is FREE!!! And just a few blocks from the marble arch bus stop on Oxford street.Do yourself a favor and go visit this museum.

Great free museum, with an eclectic collection of fine art and oddities. This is a great museum to hide away in for an hour or so. The collection has a broad range of paintings, sculptures, furniture, porcelains. All of the collection is fine art, so if you prefer contemporary art and unmade beds, then this probably won't be for you.The fact it is free is a real bonus!

Small museum that if off the beaten path but SO WORTH it.. Have you ever found a small "gem" that was tucked away from large crowds of people in the middle of the city? This collection is worth seeing. My husband and I were the only ones there when we visited. It was near the end of the day so perhaps it may be more crowded earlier in the day. It was like stepping back into the Middle Ages.

I want to live here. This is a beautiful small gallery and is an absolute treat. A full on hidden gem, this house is lovingly maintained to the extent that you actually feel like you could live there. The art work is generally classic, don't expect anything too modern but it is delightfully curated and the art sits wonderfully in this environment. It is not huge and is off the tourist track but if one is passing through Marylebone I would thoroughly recommend popping in.
Even Better. The renovations make a wonderful experience even better - the tours are well done and the cafe incredible!

Best al fresco ever. I'm usually not a fan of outdoor dining. Too hot (or too cold), too windy, usually too noisy. The restaurant at the Wallace Collection is in an interior courtyard with a glass roof that must be forty feet above the ground. All the advantage of outside dining--light, space--and none of the dis. The food is solid if not spectacular--like the Wallace Collection itself.

Absolutely stunning. From the moment you walk into this stunning building, you are in awe of all of its treasures. Because it is fairly small as museums go, it is not overpowering. It invites you to take you time and enjoy all of the beautiful and stunning works of this fantastic collection.This is a full day out. Take time out and enjoy the wonderful restaurant for lunch and/or afternoon tea. We had a wonderful time here.

Love This Delightful Gallery. I have enjoyed visiting the Wallace Collection for years and quite simply, love it. It is a stunning gallery in every way - the building is amazing and one never becomes bored repeatedly looking at the amazing collection of beautiful paintings, furniture and porcelain held within. It is never over-crowded and is very peaceful - as others have found it; a delightfully quiet haven away from the crowds. I will continue to visit for as long as possible. With regard to the cafe there, which, I am sorry to say does not live up to the standard of The Collection itself, read a review under separate attraction "The Wallace".

Lovely museum, a haven away from Oxford Street. The Wallace Collection is a fantastic museum. See Frans Hals' The Laughing Cavalier or a self-portrait of Rembrandt or Fragonard's boudoir painting of the lady on a swing with her lover hidden in the bushes looking up her skirt! Where else can you see Sevres porcelain, illuminated manuscripts, French paintings and furniture, Canalettos and a lovely cafe, in a small museum? It's a stone's throw away from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street AND it's free! Definitely worth a visit

Still life gems. Among the dusty and dreadful furniture are a great collection of somewhat dirty, but well worth seeing the Canalettos, Rembrandts, Jan Weemix, Van der Velde, and Jan Steen paintings, on the 1st floor. Ground floor Armory is also quite extraordinary.

suprise collection. the quality of the art and the displays of armour, the building as a whole was impressive at times there was too much to look at , visiting 2 galleries before probably didn t help but a must and a revisit for sure

Excellent Museum to visit. While walking around London I happen to find this museum and decided to visit. WOW....stunning collection!!! When visiting London you can sometimes be on "museum overload". The museum is the perfect size to walk around and look at the excellent collection of art and to also look at the actual building which is quite nice.Very nice courtyard with dinning facilities and just a place to sit and relax and enjoy.I highly recommend this museum and aftwards stop off at Selfridges for a little shopping.
Outstanding !. This is one of the most complete collections of Sèvres porcelain. Every section is superb and very well presented. Take the time to enjoy this jewel.

Fabulous and little known. A nice sized collection of some great art and some delightful curios. Also has an extensive collection of armour but this does not interest me. I also had a very pleasant afternoon tea. The collection is easy walking from Selfridges and Oxford Street.

Great Museum even greater Restaurant. What a complete gem of a place, an amazing collection of finds from around the world by one family, but if i'm honest, the restaurant was the highlight for me. Very attentive staff, keen to engage and make your visit memorable by attending to your every need. The food - i had the cod - was the best fish i'd ever tasted, followed by the Pear Tarte Tartin, with hazzlenut ice crean - sublime!

Time required. Don't go just to fill a couple of hours - you'll be there at least half a day. We went to look at a particular exhibition about the Rapier in the 17thC, and thought we would add on a couple of bits in the armouries because we're into that sort of thing. We went round the paintings the sculpture, the china/pottery. All of it fascinating - something for any interest, and in some parts even if you aren't interested you still have to look. Because it's a collection and not a museum (in the sense of the British Museum say) it has a personal feel and a little quirkiness that adds to teh charm - not to mention the Canalettos, the Ruebens, the Gainsboroughs....I could go on. Exceptional, well presented and laid out, the cafe/restaurant is light airy space and a nice place to sit and just have a coffee (or a meal). Thoroughly recommended for all ages.

Eclectic collection of fine furnishings and weaponry. Trip Advisor app wasn't great on this one, neither was local signposting, as we walked up and down a road indicated on the TA map for several minutes, only to stumble across the museum in a nearby square.Once found and making a small donation (voluntary), you are free to roam the many rooms of this former residence marvelling at the fine furniture. Understandably, with so many fine antiquities close at hand, the staff are always nearby, but my wife found their constant directions to move away from "this chair" or "that cabinet" a little neurotic, as we didn't have any intention of touching the said items. If the museum was busy I should think the staff would be having kittens, (or restrict numbers in each room?)Fine furnishings personally hold a limited appeal to me, although the craftsmanship in these items was stunning. The medieval weaponry and armour collection has to be the finest I have seen outside the Royal Armouries in Leeds. Some truly fearsome looking weapons and the mounted Knights were stunning, giving a small insight as to how awesome these warriors must have been. A great way to spend a few hours away from the frenzy of west end shops.

Finest private art and furniture collection ever!. This mansion, just a block or two from Selfridges, houses an incredible collection of art, furniture and jewelry, all collected privately by the Wallace family over the past 250 years. Not to be missed!

Surprise Visit. This was a real surprise to us as we thought that it was of William Wallace. When we were in we discovered a great collection of arms, furniture, displays from asia and much more, a very pleasant surprise after all.

Out of the "rat race".. This museum is situated just behind Selfridges and is well worth taking sometime out of the "rat race" on Oxford Street. Good selection of objects on display. Should be something there for most people. My favourite was the armory.

Beautiful Museum. Each room is exquisite and beautifully appointed. Some of the paintings have been cleaned or restored, and all decorative arts are obviously well cared for. The collection has a few major painting gems mixed in.

Stunning and amazing. This is one of my very favorite "small" museums in London. Small, meaning that one can get through and feel like you have seen most of what you want in a day and yet return at a later date and have the same feeling again.
Loved It. A unique collection, a fabulous insight, a privilege to walk around and a highly delightful way to spend a few hours relaxing and enjoying part of the past

Beautiful little discovery in central London. I went to the Wallace Collection at the recommendation of an aunt, who lives in London, and likely wouldn't have learned about it if it wasn't for her. Located on a quiet square just off Bond Street in a beautiful 18th century mansion, this small museum has a wonderful collection of 17th and 18th century artwork with exquisite interiors and furnishings. Their collection of Sevre porcellain is quite lovely also. While this period of art isn't my favorite, it was wonderful to spend a couple hours in just to see it. We ate a small late lunch in the cafe, which is beautfiul situated in the glass topped courtyard of the house. The service was a bit slow for us, and my quiche was borderline cold, but the tea service looked delicious as did some other plates I saw as we were walking out so I wouldn't judge it too harshly on my food alone and would definitely go again to try something else a bit more substantial.
Great private collection. Stunning and well maintained. Try to get there in time to take a tour - the guide we had was very well informed.

Nice collection, lovely rea room / cafe. It is not the largest collection, so only takes about an hour and half to view, but there are some interesting pieces and there is also a good history of the family, who I do find interesting.The cafe / tea rooms are definitely worth a visit!

Lovely art collection, and a great restaurant to boot!. I was treated to a day out here as a birthday present from a friend - and had never heard of it so didn't know what to expect. It is 'round the back of Selfridges' so right in the heart of London, but in a quiet road that seemed like another world from the busy-ness of the shops.It is free entry, but we bought the guide book and then did a self-guided walk round this glorious town house - enjoying the decor, paintings, porcelain, furniture and armoury equally. We also enjoyed lunch at the restaurant - which was of an excellent standard (although reasonably pricey). It is in a lovely setting - what must have been a garden area once, but which now has a high glass roof so it feels light and airy while being indoors.We were admiring 'the Laughing Cavalier' - one of the most famous paintings here, when a guide approached us to tell us all about the forthcoming refurbishment - and not to worry that he would still be on display elsewhere in the house for the duration. She was very friendly and informative. We enjoyed all the house - particularly the fantastic collection of Canallettos.All in all, a very pleasant outing indeed.

well worth a visit. a nice friendly museum in a quiet square near selfridges.Very well laid out museum for the size of this large house.Lovely eating area at the rear .Enjoyed 3 hours of interesting artifacts and took advantage of the audio units.Free entry.Overall well worth the visit,dosent get too busy like the larger museums can do.

Breathtaking. From entry to the collection to departure there is a myriad of treasures, paintings (incl. "the Laughing Cavalier"), arms and armour, porcelain, furniture, sculpture, silver and gold works each of which seems to have a more extraordinary provenance than the last. To make the day complete is the excellent cafe/restaurant in the glass covered courtyard. A must see.

Fantastic place,. I pop into this gallery at least a couple of times a year it has a fantastic resteraunt that serves up great afternoon tea,it has the most brilliant paintings my favourite being fragonords " lady on a swing" .Just go there look at the building that in itself is is superb "JUST ENJOY"

Wallace Collection London. This is my second visit to this house. I was entertaining a friend from Miami, who really appreciates works of art, and thought this would be ideal. as we only had 3 hours together. The collection of paintings, porcelain, sculptures, silver by the Wallace family, and housed in this lovely house, is fantastic. After walking through the house for a few hours, we were able to go to the restaurant on the premises and have a British Afternoon Tea (for my American friend's benefit, as clotted cream is not available in the US!!!) Afterwards, we walked the short distance to Selfridges, before returning to our hotels. A very enjoyable experience all round!

"Very good". The collection is from a private collection of art created and now housed in the magnificent setting of a London townhouse. The quality of the collection is very good - some of the masterpieces of world-class are available. The best part is that admission is free; taking pictures without flash is allowed.

London's best kept secret.. This was my first visit to the Wallace Collection in Manchester Square, London: very close to Selfridge's and easy to find. It's a remarkable art gallery with hundreds of magnificent works of art by some of the most famous painters in history. I went to see Titian's Perseus & Andromeda but was delighted to find The Laughing Cavalier, A Dance to the Music of Time and The Temptation of St. Hilarion, to name but a few. It's a great gallery with the paintings on display in very pleasant, furnished surroundings, unlike the cold, sterile galleries at the National Gallery.There are also displays of armour and weapons dating back to the Renaissance. Hundreds of halberds, rapiers, arquebuses and horse-pistols. All really well preserved.
A beautiful collection of paintings. A wonderful collection of paintings in a beautiful setting, not too large or overpowering, a little gem.

Excellent small museum. Is a small museum but with an amazing art collection. Nicely situated and is worth a visit - while most tourists just go to the main museums but in my opinion should fit in the must-visit list too (if you like art in the first place)
Highly recommended.. This is an incredible private collection. Huge array of weapons and armour along with captivating works of art.

Treasure house. One of the finest collections of 18th century gilded French furniture by Boule and others - the clocks must be seen to be heard. Also extensive collection of 17th and 18th century art including the laughing cavalier. Free entry and tours by really informative guides. Excellent restaurant serving 'French' food in lovely covered garden area.Not to be missed!

Not only a museum but a lovely place to eat. A really nice place to spend some time. The collections themselves, the paintings and the whole ambience is wonderful. Whilst there visit the restaurant which itself is a pleasing experience. (lovely cakes) Enjoy a good meal or just have a coffee. I would recommend it.

A hidden gem. A relative recommended this place and it was one of the highlights of our trip to London. The quantity and quality of the artwork of this family collection is jaw dropping. It helps give you a sense of the extreme wealth of the 19th C British aritocracy. The staff are very friendly too.
Wonderful experience. The Wallace Collection was fantastic with children able to try on pieces of armour. We then had afternoon tea which was amazing.

A lot to see. Lived in London for 10 years and didnt know about this place, basically a large house near Selfridges qith a very large collection of fine art, if you can get the free guided tour, a very lot to see.

Would not see again.. This was close to my hotel, so I decided to visit. Not what I expected. Will not return or take friends who accompany me to London. It was just not interesting. The collection was somewhat small. There are far too many wonderful - free - museums to enjoy in this city. Don't waste your valuable vacation time here.

Hidden treasure in London. In a city that hosts the National Gallery, The Bristish Museum, the Tate, the VA museum etc probably the Wallace Collection is not the first thing to visit.But if you will go there you will be just amazed by this "little" unknown collection that insludes paints of Canaletto, Caravaggio, Rubens, Guardi in a former private house.During our visit we had a free tour (I think is every day at 14.30) with a lovely lady that gave us a lot on information that you probably will not find on art books.And on the top of that it is free.
Fantastic hidden gem. What a fantastic exhibition of masterpieces, we arrived just in time for an interesting tour around the house.
Take the tour. Spent a wonderful, enthralling morning here. The tour guides are so informative and the items on display incredible.

Tucked away in Manchester Square. I first visited the Wallace about 40 years ago, when my father was working nearby. He took me - and showed me The Laughing Cavalier (yes, it's here). Went back 20 years later, when a relative worked as a security guard. Great collections of Chinese armour, beautiful snuff boxes, etc etc etc. Just an incredibly wide and fascinating mix of stuff which Mr Wallace collected on his travels.

Well worth it!. An amazing museum that is not given enough prominence. It is free, has several rooms decorated in the original style, has loads of art work and also other artifacts. A nice, posh restaurant in a glass covered atrium and just a stone's throw from Selfridges and Oxford Street.

one of London's best. The Wallace has a superb range of exhibits from armour and faience to old masters and ancient clocks (almost all working perfectly). The displays are unadventurous but the stuff is of such high quality that this place is a must for lovers of traditoinal painting and decorative arts.
A must see when in London. Absolutly amazing place. Full of some of the best art in London. Best of all it's FREE! On par with the state gallerys and housed in the most beautiful building.

Perfect hidden gem. Wonderful collection - and some great temporary exhibitions - in a lovely building with great restaurant. And tourists come to London, walk down Oxford Street and eat at garfunkels....

One of the highlights of my trip. If you're looking for something cultural to do in London this is an excellent choice. We did the free highlights tour at 11:30 and what a treat it was. Our guide was so knowledgeable and passionate and for good reason, an outstanding collection of some of the finest 18th century paintings (Fragonard's "The Swing", Rubens, Franz Hals' misnomer the "Laughing Cavalier", Rembrandt) and interiors/decorative arts (chinese porcelain, brass-tortoise shell armoires, chandeliers). Unfortunately we had to leave early and didn't get a chance to visit the armoury downstairs. But given that it is Free Admission this is a must-see!
Great!. Lovely museum and fab restaurant in the heart of London and yet felt like an oasis only 2 blocks back from Oxford Street - well worth a visit

A hidden gem. A fantastic collection, hidden in a beautiful square just off one of Londons busiest shopping streets. Well worthy of a few hours of any discerning visitors time. A lovely restaurant in the centre for afternoon tea tops off any visit!
Birthday visit. Eat in resturant-nothing outstanding on menu and overpriced.Setting lovely but shame about the service

A very clever place for curious people. They make an effort to change their exhibitions every few months and the subjects are always so fascinating. We live just around the corner and always make the effort to go, the perfect way to spend a few hours on a lazy Sunday afternoon - learning through thoughtful and creative exhibits It also has a good permanent collection which includes the personal collection of the founder from all around the world

This small museum is in a large mansion that itself is worth a visit.. Some of best of the best--Canaletto, Boucher, Rubens, a huge armory in the basement. If you like the old masters you will be thrilled. Terrace dining is upscale with an interesting menu. We love this place. Not far from Harrod's.

A hidden gem. This is a super little museum/gallery, some very interesting pieces set in an attractive builiding. In the middle there's a lovely little restaurant. A charming way to wile away an afternoon.
Wonderful. Fantastic experience , what a hidden gem. Such a great atmosphere and not busy ,so I could see so much. Loved it all

Great way to spend the day!. This is a great little colection of art and pieces that were orignally part of a private collection - definitely worth a visit by everyone. I have been numerous times and just love going back!I find that sometimes at the bigger museums and galleries I can get a little overwhelmed by the scale and number of pieces on display - so the Wallace Collection is great as it's a reasonable size - you feel like you could actually see it all in one day if you wanted to!They do great free guided tours which definitely add to the experience - these are usually twice a day! There are great stories behind all the pieces and the actual house.Also has a lovely covered courtyard restaurant serving delicious food and drinks.

A beautiful collection in a very lovely house.. The Wallace Collection in Manchester Square is housed in a very gorgeously urban stately home that is as much a star as the objects and paintings themselves. No wonder that my friend Vivienne Westwood has derived such inspiration from its treasures over the years. I also love the lively programme of events offered every season, and the thought given to encouraging the very youngest of visitors to enjoy their time there.

London's secret treasure. A great art collection with a delightful courtyard restaurant.Amazing individual lavatories, charming staff and, although the restaurant is pricey, you can stay for a long time without being harassed and there is a delightful atmosphere.

Amazing collection!. The Wallace Collection was truly the most memorable part of our visit to London.Aside from the famous art collection, the fabrics and moldings that lined the walls were awe-inspiring, and the staff were extremely friendly and knowledgable, answering any question we asked with an abundance of information. An amazing surprise was a room filled with Marie-Antoinette's furniture from Le Petit Trianon! It's apparently the largest collection of its kind, and very special to see in person.All in all, great place, great experience.

Delicious small museum. Just the right size to gain culture and insight into British objects d'art and armour and French painting. A beautiful fascinating mansion with an outstanding collection. Have lunch in the courtyard, a very nice respit. It's right behind Selfridges, so worth the trip. use the Bond st. tube stop.

Not to be missed. The Wallace collection is well worth visiting, it has got something for everybody, famous paintings, Marie Antoinette's furniture and art collection, weaponry, really too much to mention.It also has a very classy French Restaurant in an inside courtyard, bright and welcoming, with exquisite food and excellent service. Good to use if you need a breather from all the beautiful things you see or just to meet friend before you embark on the delights of the exhibition.There are events which you can attend free of cost, e.g. I attended a delightful chat with Marie Antoinette, a lovely charming lady who could not read or write "all that well" and still has no clue where she went wrong.

an incomplete review!. On our visit to the Wallace Collection the fire alarm was activated and we all had to leave. We didnt wait for the fire engine and the all clear to go back in as we were short on time. What we did see (less than half) was very interesting, and when we return to London I fully expect that we will re-visit the Wallace Collection, and use the lovely looking cafe.

Superb ...... Wonderful collection of paintings, furniture and loads more. Beautiful building .... Just lovely .... And my top attraction by far in London ... Not to be missed. Free entry and lovely book for £6 as souvenir .... Well worth a visit!

The Noble Art of the Sword (Wallace Collection, 17 May - 16 Sept 2012). I recently visited The Noble Art of the Sword at the Wallace Collection with a group of friends. If you have a group, one of the staff will take you on a private guided tour - we did this and it gave us additional insight into the relationships between fashion and fencing in Renaissance Europe. Highly recommended!

A Hidden Gem. The Wallace Collection is an amazing museum to visit off the beaten path and outside of most tour guides. It is situated just a short walk North from Oxford Street and is housed in a beautiful "townhome" (very large to be called that!) set on a wooded square. There is so much to look at at this collection - I had no idea they could have so much and still be such a well kept secret! I think they have more armor to look at than the Tower of London! The upstairs section has been preserved as the family might have lived in it and is full of the artwork and collectibles the family amassed over many years and that the trust has collected.I highly recommend eating at the restaurant in the atrium. The natural light is beautiful and while there is a definite "museum mark up" the service is very attentive and everything we ordered was perfectly cooked and delicious. It's a relaxing space to unwind from sightseeing.
Magnificent collection. Fantastic place! House is great in itself, and there are a collection of art and armoury that is a must-see in London if you ar into that sort of thing.

Not to be missed. A gem. Wonderful collection. Great house. Lovely area of London. Put this at the top of your list, especially if you have been to London before and seen some of the most famous sights.
A jewel box of a museum, what a gem. A private mansion, all yours to visit and do not miss a lunch or high tea in the courtyard (conservatory - winter garden). Charming, refreshing and human scale.

One of London's Jewels.. If you want to see a truly superb historical collection then this the place, and it doesn't cost a dime ! (Donations are welcome, though !)From wonderful room settings of furniture; china, weaponry and armour; to one of the finest private collections of art under one roof, this is a must for any visitor to London.Each room is set out (almost) as the Wallace family designed it, showing a real passion and joy in the art of collecting. I spent an hour in the Long Gallery alone.The central courtyard has a restaurant and there is also a well stocked bookshop.This is never in the lists of major "Must see Places to Visit in London" It Should Be !!Don't Miss !
Nice small museum. Nice collection displayed in luxurious mansion. Worth 2~3 hour visit.
Fantastic meeting place. The restaurant has the wow factor and so close to Bond street, a hidden gem indeed.

First visit - what a pleasant surprise. This museum is a pleasure because you definitely get the feel of someone's collecting passion. Lots of stuff to see and admire. Take a break and have tea in the courtyard (good, not great.) Did I mention there is no cost?!
A gem only five minutes from Oxford Street. A wonderful museum filled with superb paintings, armoury and miniatures. Not to be missed.

Hidden Gem in London. Having lived in London for 45 years I've just found a wonderful place to visit I didn't know existed. Only a short walk from Bond Street tube in Manchester Square sits a beautiful large mansion packed with amazing works of art and the guide Diane who did The Highlights Tour was simply fantastic, so enthusiastic and knowledgeable which made our 75min. tour really enjoyable and so interesting. One whole room devoted to personal belongings of Marie Antoinette - I have never seen such opulence outside of royal residences. We had to dash off for the theatre so will go back again with more time to wander independently and appreciate all we've been told about. Original paintings in an incredible gallery (The Laughing Cavalier), china, clocks, furniture, something for everyone except small children I would guess.

Definitely Worth a Visit. Not necessarily the first place I would have thought to go, but was really pleased I did. Really interesting exhibition with a lovely restaurant in a covered courtyard out back. Good for afternoon tea if you fancy or dinner. Worth seeing.

Guided tour. I went to the museum because of the guided tour; I wouldn't be able to appreciate the different paintings and pieces of old furniture if walking around the gallery on my own.The guided tour as well as the museum is free, and the guide was very knowledgeable. I really liked that she admitted that she tought that some of the paintings were quite ugly. The courtyard restaurant looked very nice. I didn't eat there, though.

Pleasant lunch in gem of a gallery. The bright open covered courtyard is a very pleasant dining space. The food is good but not exceptional. This is a perfectly acceptable lunch location if you go to the fabulous gallery, but not somewhere to go just for lunch.

My Favourite Gallery in London. This bijou museum is housed in a gorgeous mansion in the centre of London. Some of the principle rooms are laid out as there were when inhabited by the Wallace family. The collection of art, china and other artifacts is mouth-watering. There are very informative tours held most lunchtimes, they are free and last for about an hour. Highly recommended.

Must visit. Free entry and a great day to visit when the English weather is at its best i.e. cloudy and gloomy. Oh yes there a nice court yard with a great café. Take a map from the front desk and spend as much time as you like exploring the amazing collection of all sorts of stuff from paintings, medals, porcelain, furniture and medieval war weapons. The collection of war weapons and armour is fascinating. If you are fan of old medieval battles this is the place to visit.

Hidden Gem. Wonderful building and good for kids too. This is hidden away off the bustle of Oxford Street and near Selfridges. Wonderful mansion converted to a spacious museum/gallery. Big enough to be worth visiting, small enough to be manageable.Eclectic and well-themed/presented collections, lovely (but pricey) courtyard restaurant, and a fascinating (really!) collection of armour and arms from around the world. This was an unexpected hit with the kids.Separately in the lower ground floor, there's a kids/education area, including a 'try on the armour' exhibit - seeing the kids struggle in chain mail and with a helmet weighing a ton was great fun and they found this memorable.One of my favourite places in London.

Hidden Gem. I shouldn't really give it away but If you didn't know it was there you wouldn't find it. It's just behind Selfridge's!! An not on the tourist route. The Cafe side is cheaper and less formal than the Brasserie side. Excellent for a leisurely lunch when shopping with a pootle around the Wallace Collection to aid the digestion.

I die for Fragonard!. The Wallace Collection is an unmissable gallery any art lover should visit, my favourite painting in the gallery for me is Fragonard's The Swing, but there is loads to see. Do not try and do the whole gallery in a day... go many times, go often...

Absolute heaven. A fantastic dream of a house just full of the most amazing items, yet so quiet and relaxed - I almost feel sad to make it busier by telling people just how good it was - this is one awesome collection of priceless antiques

one of the best hidden jewels in london and incredible value for money. The house is fully and tastefully furnished with beautifully crafted antiques and paintings.The rooms are never overcrowded, and the cafe restaurant in the inner courtyard may be pricey but definitely warants a stop for a cup of tea.

Much to see in a small space. The Wallace Collection is a gem. Many things to see in a relatively small space, so you can actually see it all in a day (unlike the National Gallery). Not only paintings, but luxury furniture, china, and arms and armoury. Free admission.

What an unexpected treasure this is. We were recommended this museum by a friend and what a wonderful little treasure this place is. There was so much to see, with rooms full of ornate furnishings, paintings, china and an armoury section. They have a cloakroom to leave your stuff which was wonderful as it had been raining, a lift for disabled visitors and guide books in every room describing the pictures, ornaments and giving background history. They also do an audio tour for £4 which we will definitely do next time as there is so much to see. There was plenty of seating in each room for resting which makes a pleasant change.The coffee shop is situated in the courtyard which is located centrally in the building. It has a wonderfully high glass roof to keep you sheltered and it was airy and comfortable. They had a good selection of cakes and snacks as well as afternoon teas available, all served to you by waiting staff. We will be returning again as we ran out of time on this visit and would recommend at least 3 hours to really appreciate this museum especially if indulging in the coffee shop as well.

A must visit. The Wallace collection is the sort of place that you keep meaning to visit but never do. After ten years in London, I visited. I was amazed that it's still free.The collection is superb and had afternoon tea here which was simply incredible.
Must see!. Fabulous collection and wonderful Eggs Benedict Royale in the lovely restaurant.

Excellent.. Not sure why we hadn't been before. Very close to Oxford Street and not so big that you need to spend more than a couple of hours. Sumptuous objects. Very impressive and interesting, particularly the French items brought after the French revolution. Had an excellent lunch in the cafe. Uplifting, civilised and enjoyable way to spend part of a day.
Fabulous experience : a must do!!. Loved this collection of fine art and antiques. Its situated perfectly in London so that you can shop and then walk casually into this gorgeous home.

National gem - a must see. There's so much to see and do in London but don't leave until you see this amazing collection of decorative arts and armor. Admission is FREE (though there is a suggested donation)! This collection boasts works by Titian, Rembrandt, Fragonard ("The Swing"), among others. The armor rooms are fascinating and include swords, daggers, muskets, and an amazing intricately carved canon. Another plus is it's location at Manchester Square not too far from shopping and cafes along Oxford Street.

A stunning and inspiring gallery. Dragged my teenage kids to this museum to kill time before Oxford St opened on Sunday morning! Opens at 10. Shops open at 12! Trip down memory lane for me. I used to visit regularly during lunch hours working round the corner 20 years ago. It was free then and it still is (plus donation of course). The kids walked into every room - going wow! They admitted this was far better than they expected. An outstanding eclectic collection of amazing paintings, armour much more, beautifully presented. Nice cafe in central atrium with an extensive selection of teas - I tried white silver needle tea - very nice. Kids loved the armour dressing up zone in the lower ground floor. Easy to visit and totally inspiring.
A beautiful setting for a fabulous collection.. It was great to be able to take pictures, and the staff were helpful.

Love , or not. My wife absolutely loves to go to the Wallace. It is a short walk off Oxford Street behind Selfridges. The setting for the cafe is lovely. i find the walls too crowded with the collection.

Great find. Haven't been in 10 years and the place had truly changed. The special sword collection (reviewed in the Economist) was small, but very interesting. Took a 22 year old who was also impressed. Lovely cafe in the courtyard and had a very fine meal (although was unable to have tea and scones because we were 15 minutes early - my American mind screams with agony over this type of service). The rest of the collection is wonderful to walk through and we had a very enjoyable 1/2 day here.
A "gem" just behind Oxford Street. Free entry"Must See" - The Laughing CavalierExcellent Restaurant in the basement

An astonishing treasure-house in the heart of London. This is one of London's greatest gems. The glorious arms and armour collection, the beautifully-laid-out furniture, china and statuary, the wonderful pictures - everything is magnificently displayed and beautifully curated, with just enough information and skilled staff on hand to offer more. The collection of Marie Antoinette's possessions is particularly well displayed, giving a real feel for what rooms of the era might have looked like. The house is an artwork in itself, carefully balancing the transformation into a modern museum with the preservation of its history. The staff are absolutely charming, among the most helpful and pleasant in any London museum.

Small, eclectic collection in a beautiful townhouse. Wallace collected a variety of objects d'art covering a wide range of interests. Armour, paintings, sculpture, miniatures, furniture, etc.The collection is not overwhelming, and can be enjoyed over a one or two hour period.The manchester Square townhouse has been beautifully restored and developed as a museum, with a very pleasant covered courtyard housing a cafe as well as art demonstration, research, and teaching facilities.

A cultural place worth a visit. This is a perfect place to go in London if you have done all the other main "big" museums and it is raining. The exhibits are interesting and range from painting to artefacts from all over the world. There is a nice restaurant in the middle of the building which feels like outdoor but it is cover, good food but a little expensive definitely not for someone on the budget. I thoughrouly enjoyed my visit to the Wallace collection and would recommended it

Near Oxford Street - try the Wallace Collection. Went here as a child and wish I had returned a lot sooner - a beautiful house with lovely collections. Well worth the short walk north of Oxoford Street.

liked a lot. close to hotel. not too big to see in an afternoon. donation asked for but not required. open every day-even bank holidays. very good docents. nice gift shop for its size. nice, nice staff. when i unthinkingly rested my hand on a table, very courteously reminded not to do that. not a lot of crowds. i really enjoyed the art. i'll be back there.

A great place to eat in Central London. If you want a great place to eat lunch in secluded elegant surroundings, minutes from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street, you should try the restaurant at the Wallace Collection. The restaurant is set in the now glass-roofed courtyard of Hertford House, former home of the Wallace family, which also houses the Wallace Collection. The collection itself is well worth a visit.
