It's an eclectic mix of mediaeval religious iconography, armoury and historic weapons, Meissen and other pottery and paintings which include The Laughing Cavalier and Fragonard's "The Swing" - an erotic painting which seems tame by today's standards, but was quite racy in it's day. And once you've filled up on culture, you can sit down and enjoy fine food in this elegant ( if noisy- all the surfaces are hard and the space is large and loud) restaurant. It's hard to believe you are just a couple of blocks north of Oxford Street when you visit this place. It transports you to another world, which is all to the good. So, if you're anywhere near Oxford Street and you fancy a different lunch experience, head to Hertford House on Manchester Square. You'll be amazed and surprised: it's one of London's best kept secrets - until now.

Put this on top of your list if you like army stuff and old paintings. Housed in the Richard Wallace's old home this small but perfectly formed collection is the wrok of five generations of collectors. The ground floor is mainly weaponery of every variety and uspstairs is mainly European paintings and ceramics and furniture. After you have walked the floors, looked at more paintings of venice than there are canals have a coffee or a meal in the great restaurant in the covered courtyard

Majestic House- grand collection- antiquarians paradise. If you like 18th century furniture and objets d'art, that is the place for you. Wandering through every room in this noble family house is a similar experience to visiting Windsor Castle or Hampton Court without the military discipline of the tourist troops marching inside these two. Relaxing and lunch in the garden is a must in the summer
A Hidden Gem. A hidden gem! A great spot for a quiet, relaxing luncheon.

A marvellous collection. This is one of London's hidden gems. Situated on Manchester Square, just behind Selfridges Department Store, this collection includes work by Rembrandt, Rubens, Poussin, Velasquez, Canaletto and a host of other old masters. There is a wealth of French rococco painting here, including work by boucher and also Fragonard's The Swing.There is a wonderful cafe/resaurant in the enclosed inner courtyard which is well worth visiting on it's own
magnificent house!. magnificent house, beautifully decorated! great location! and the museum is free! if you want to enjoy a typical British house, you should definitely go there!

Worth several visits. Some truly famous artists and paintings plus terrific minatures, wonderful room settings, it just goes on. Such an eclectic mix and not just for adults, our 12 year old grandaughter loved it too.

Beautiful and accessible museum. A wonderful place to while away a couple of hours looking at this very attractive and eclectic collection. Have lunch in the light and airey central courtyard to complete a memorable visit.
A gem just off Oxford street... Quite unexpected after the tacky and busy thorough fare that is Oxford street-here you can step back in time to a more elegant age.

The laughing cavalier and one of the greatest eclectic collections.. Easy to get to, and a beautifully laid out collection that is perfect for a one or two hour visit. Dont miss it if you like beautiful things in the centre of London.

Stunning small gallery and mansion house. This beautiful mansion located right in the heart of the West End near Selfridges, is worth seeing just for the house alone. The art collection too is magnificent with a few very famous paintings. Well worth an hour or two with a good cafe also.
A pleasant surprise. Perfect if you are in the area with some time to kill, there is also a decent restaurant for romantic dinners.
Awesome hidden gem!. Like the Frick in NY or the Barnes Foundation in PA ? Go check out the Wallace Collection.
Very interesting indeed. Glad that I went to view this place. The collections of armoury within are mind boggling!
Dinner with friends. Are here on a Friday night and it was virtually empty but the food was great and the rooms are beuatiful
Dinner. We were able to enjoy a dinner here as guests of a British company. Was a wonderful place to enjoy the art collection.

A feast for the eyes, followed by a feast in the restaurant!. This was a case of double the pleasure! What a wonderful way to spend a day.....first there is a feast for the eyes when taking in the myriad of splendors that are housed in this exquisite home that make up the incredible Wallace Collection. One stunning room after another, the different color scheme in each is a treat - wall coverings, fabrics and opulent trims, not to mention the ceilings....and that's before you start to look at the art, the sculptures, the ceramics, the weaponry and armor. Don't try and see it all in a day, you will simply have to come back again and again. Once you have made your way through, head for the restaurant. Do not miss this! A awe inspiring space, situated in the courtyard and covered in with a glass roof.....not your average conservatory! Decor is right up there with the Wallace Collection, sublime seating arrangements, huge potted trees and then the food! A feast, be it tea & cake or lunch or dinner!

Unbeatable 18th century French collection and arms and armour. Based in a splendid 19th century mansion once the home of Richard Wallace, who devoted his large fortune to this collection, it has the finest 18th century French furniture, paintings and artefacts, housed in the splendid rooms in which he once lived and entertained, all beautifully restored and decorated. The museum also has a collection of European and Mioddle Eastern armour which is said to be second only to the Tower of London collection. It is situated just behind Selfridges-so is probably London's most conveniently located museum. Free entry-but why don't we charge foreigners as they charge us?

Brilliant collection of armour and art. I visited the Wallace Collection with my mother when she came up to visit me in London recently. It didn't really sound like my type of thing (I don't have a pre-existing interest in armour or stately homes) but I was taken aback by how interesting I found it. The rooms have recently been restored and they are just stunning - beautiful rich colours and gorgeous ornamentation. The collection of armour was ever so fascinating although almost sinister in places. The prviate collection of art was also surprisingly worthwhile. Even if this doesn't sound like your thing I'd urge you to try it - entry is free and you really have nothing to lose and everything to gain.
Ideal for a rainy lunchtime in town. Free exhibition, The Laughing Cavalier is a highlight

A hidden gem!. There are delights around every corner at the Wallace Collection. I love the armour!There are a wide variety of paintings, much pottery to admire as well as other ornaments and furniture.I have made many visits here and always make some new discovery.

Great value for London! (Free!). What a breath of fresh air, after fighting crowds of people in Madame Tussadus, and paying a premium to do so, it was lovely to stumble across this fine gallery on our way back to Oxford Street. Lovely collection, nice a peaceful inside too. And a lovely looking restaurant in the centre of the building (bit too fancy for us though).
a hidden gem. It is worth gpoing to visit the collection and there is a fabulous restaurant in the courtyard.

A masterpiece stumbled upon. We found this place by accident strolling through the backstreets around Oxford St. A beautiful collection including Frans Hals Laughing Cavalier, Titians, Rubns, Caneletto, velasquez, Gainsborough, Rembrant. Can be very busy so go early

Beautiful paintings in beautiful setting. This museum should be on the not-to-be-missed list. The combination of lovely paintings in the setting of an old historic house is a magical combination. Careful to come on a weekday, though; it gets a bit crowded on weekends.

Incredibly rude staff.. Spectacular location but unbelievably rude staff. We had an event there and I had several complaints from friends. Jobsworth, charmless and unfriendly. I popped out and they were reticent to let me back in to pick up my disabled mother because they were about to close. Unnecessary.
London trip. Have been to London many times, but had never been to Wallace. It is an excellent museum with great collection of armour and paintings. Highly recommend.
Amazing collection. Worth a visit if you have the time, many interesting arts collection. Good cafe after you finish the tour.

Excellent surprise! Will go back!. We stumbled upon The Wallace Collection by accident whilst wandering around and didn't really have any expectations.Wow! What a fantastic and absorbing visit! We only had an hour or so, but we could easily have spent more and will go back. We loved the huge number of paintings well displayed throughout the galleried roms, the highlight being The Laughing Cavalier. So nice to be able to wander around at your own pace without an irritating audio guide. Thee are helpful guides I each room that you can pick up to tell you more about the exhibits.The courtyard restaurant looked really appealing, and very busy. The toilets were a delight and all staff we encountered were cheerful and very helpful.Incredibly this experience costs only a voluntary donation. It's a privilege to have seen such a national treasure collection. Do visit!

Almost a perfect interlude. It's free; that was a surprise. Enjoyed the ground floor galleries [going to do the upper galleries on another trip]. Decided on a lovely pot of tea and a pastry at the excellent restaurant/cafe; plus, a bit of peace and relaxation. We were put on a long table, with two mums, and five children, who kept running around, and rather spoiling our break. We had to inform the waiter that we intended to move tables. But why were we 'dumped' there in the first place?
Compact and Informative. Compact and Informative. Lots of Paintings. The Rapier and the Sword interested the 80 yr and the 11 yr men in our group.

a hidden gem. A beautiful house beautifully restored stuffed with beautiful things - amazing paintings opulent porcelain. (I can do without the armor but even that's impressive) and to make the visit even more delightful a cafe and restaurant in the covered courtyard/atrium. You could even just go for a stylish lunch coffee or tea and escape the hub bub of Oxford st. as entrance to the house is free. Serive was a bit slow and sniffy but food excellent.

fabulous place..stately house in the centre of London. This is brilliant a real treat..so close to these wonderful treasures..beautiful surroundings and free. Difficult to believe this place absolutely perfect. Have tea in the restaurant so beautiful, it is expensive so we just had tea and a cake..lunches look good..but you pay for them..service is good too.

Colourful and interesting. A trip to the Vallace Collection is always interesting - the rooms are stunningly decorated and very colourful.The collection itself is very cute and interesting as a lot of it is still in the setttings of when the house was build and the collection started. The Wallace Collection has been on my list for many years and finally I managed to get around to going and I didn't regret it. There are also lots of talks and guided tours, some which are done in period costumes. At the end of your visit remember to go to the restaurant in the courtyard as it's very nice and a good way to end a great visit.
Princes Trust. Saw a wonderful Concert there & HRH Prince Of Wales was There with The Late Princess Diana!!Sublime & a lovely Historical Place!
Sunning decor. Been here on many occasions over the last 20 years and love returning.

Lovely find. Recommended to us by friends. Would never have found it otherwise. Went to take a break from shopping on Oxford st.....turn at Duke st just near Selfridges. Nothing to do with Wallice Simpson as I had originally thought. Just a lovely collection of museum pieces with a magnificent garden restaurant in the middle.....glassed roof so don't worry about the weather! We spent a bit of time wandering, had lunch then back to our shopping. Nice break in the day!

Great collection of art, and a fabulous eatery. Visited the Wallace restaurant for breakfast over the Jubilee weekend. Service and food were very good and great value. Waiting staff very smart and efficient. Had a look round the art collection afterwards. A treat.

hidden gem. I love the fact that this museum not only has traditional artwork such as paintings, marble works, etc. but also antique clocks that you hear chime as you peruse the galleries. This museum is not huge and overwhelming like some others and yet there is much to see. There is an audio guide available as well as printed leaflets in the galleries to tell you about the works. This is definitely on my "must do again" list.
Wallace collection. Didn't have enough time to do the collection justice but what we saw was great.

Great hidden gem!. Never had visited this place and, after I read a art history book, I decided to visit, as there was lots of Wallace Collection' s paintings as an example in the book. I loved it. very intimist rooms and it feels nice and cosy in there. Not crowded, as it's not so well known. The art deco and chandeliers inside are a great surprise too.

Simply amazing collection of art in a wonderful house, a must see.. This is quite simply an amazing collection of arts, furniture, porcelain, minatures, armour (the list goes on and on...) that I have ever had the pleasure to visit, all in a beautiful and accessible house in Manchester Square. A fabulously displayed and obviously well-loved treasure house that is a must-see in London. Moving from room to room in this beautiful house was quite unlike anything I'd experienced and I will definitely be returning here as well as buying the book of the collection. It is bursting at the seams with countless treasures of sheer beauty. Highly recommended!
great visit. loved the armour collection, and especially the armour for horses. Great place to visit

Great neighborhood gem!. Great works of art by some well-known masters (Rubens, Rembrandt), all on display in a formidable mansion in Marylebone. A great way to spend a leisurely day. Stay for lunch and dine in the covered atrium, which is open and bright even on a rainy day!
amazing.. i have been to so many wonderful art collections and museums. This one was stunning. i realy liked it.

An unusual and unique Museum. The Wallace Collection is perhaps not on the list of "must see" museums in London and yet it should be. It's located in Hertford House, in Manchester Square. It's a very short walk from Oxford Street and yet it's a million miles away in terms of culture and refinement.The Wallace Collection has over 5,500 items categorised as fine and decorative arts - and I think that includes the amazing collection of armour! It attempts and I think succeeds in trying to retain a sense of what the paintings, sculpture, furniture and china etc would have looked like when the collection was part of a family house prior to the bequest. In effect, this is a what a house would look like after its owners returned from a gigantic splurge on their "Grand Tour" of Europe. I always get the impression that a lot of effort and investment has gone into presenting the works at their very best.The art collection is excellent. It has a really excellent collection of Canalettos and I saw my very first paintings by Meissonier here - who was the painter of choice in Paris before those upstart Impressionists came along!

Fantastic Museum and so convenient. Not well known, yet just off Oxford Street in the heart of London's west end. Full to bursting with an amazing range of all types of antiques from the 17th and 18th century.If you have ever wondered where all the furniture and effects have gone from the beautiful but empty French Chateaux, then look no further. It's all here, when the Parisian Mob sold the lot off during their Revolution.Good restaurant too

A very interesting and unique musem. Just off Oxford street, behind Selfridge's is this impressive museum. Not only is the building itself impressive, but the vast collection it houses is very unique. Give yourself a couple hours to explore and stop into their atrium cafe for an English tea - it was a great treat to cap off a great afternoon.

wonderful place. It's a lovely museum. I was really impressed with the art and the furniture. It's much less crowded than all the other galleries and it allows everybody to take their time. It was great to see my favorite Rembrandt there.
Go for an hour - spend a day.. This amazing gem of a museum is well worth a visit. Excellent displays all in a period setting. The cafe is worthy of a visit in its own right.

A must for lovers of French Art & Interiors of the 18th century!. Housed in an 18th Century private house (not far from Oxford St.) it is an absolute gem of French taste in interiors of the highest quality. French furnitures, clocks & Sevre porcelain. It is also hung with beautiful painting from many European countries, snuff boxes of exquisite decorations, arms & armoury. Only go if you like Art and beautiful objects in a peaceful setting.

A really lovely collection. I liked the Collection because it included both art and furniture. And some really beautiful examples of both. The whole collection is not too big so I didn't get sated as I can do in some larger museums/galleries. I highly recommend a visit.

Wallace collection (go back in time). Came upon this by accident, but what a gem. the works of art and surroundings are such a treat. so relaxing after the busy streets. The cafe and restuarant area are second to none. very welcoming.

Ok food in.idillc setting. The wallace collection is a stately home and gallery.they have built a beautiful conservatory and i.have had tea several.times. The set tea is ok but the service was really indifferent. The sandwiches and cakes were ordinary..and the sandwiches were slightly stale.i think at this price they could take more care.and train their staff to take more interest. We wanted a glamourous afternon tea this was not it.and it was very slow
Splendid house and collection. Such a beautiful house to wander about - love the painings.

A Treasure House. The Wallace Collection, Hertford House is a very short walk from Oxford Street and shouldn't be missed by anyone who'd love to see how a privileged few were once able to live. It's free. It was originally a wealthy man's country house but he spent very little time there. Instead he travelled Europe, snapping up the most magnificent collection of art and armour and sending it all back to London.. The famous "Laughing Cavalier" painting is in the superb ballroom. There are Canalettos aplenty and if you've ever had any kind of interest in the Rococo, for goodness sake, make a beeline to The Wallace Collection. It has an excellent shop, a lovely restaurant and the best toilets in London, with the possible exception of the toilets in The Queens Gallery. The Wallace Collection is great.

Don't wait as long as I did to discover this brilliant collection. Over many visits to London, I somehow managed to miss this superb collection, perhaps because I never expected to find a museum of this caliber just blocks from the commercial bustle of Oxford St. Still, better late than never - this is a wonderful addition to any list of London highlights.The perfect jewel box of a mansion - with its beautifully proportioned rooms, elegant pastel moldings, and sumptuous wall coverings - is worth a visit on its own. But world-class collections of art and historical artifacts make this a truly singular destination. The galleries of paintings include many remarkable works, including groups by Canaletto, Fragonard, and many, many more. Displays of miniatures - some lovely, some intricate, some simply bawdy - are handsomely presented, with explanatory texts detailing the subjects. Admirers of ceramics will find an excellent display - the Turkish pottery, Italian majolica, and lustreware kept me lingering, and lingering. The ground floor is largely dedicated to an impressive array of arms and armor, from a wide range of European weapons and mail to magnificently worked Indian and Persian ceremonial armor; life-sized models of horses display the protective devices crafted for valuable mounts.A short walk from Marble Arch, just a couple of blocks above Selfridge's flagship site, the museum is served by numerous Tube and bus lines. It's open 7 days a week, including public holidays, and - amazingly - does not charge an entrance fee.
Wonderful place to visit. I loved the eclectic collection. The building is also lovely to visit

One guy owned all of THIS?. In a lovely little mansion in Marylebone, the walls are lined with paintings in gold frames. You have seen some of these before -- the Old Masters -- and they are exquisite. It's shocking to me that they were all in one home -- such unimaginable wealth!! -- but now you can see them for free (do make a donation). If you can take your eyes off the walls, the furniture and porcelain are equally breath-taking. Most memorable for me: a portrait of a toddler by an unknown artist, said to be recently cleaned. I wonder what would happen to the Old Masters if they dared to clean them -- would some darkened, muddy colors become as vivid as this? Most memorable for my husband: the armor and weapons, which take up half the ground floor. I will have to go back to see them because he says they are absolutely incredible. Take advantage of the collecting mania of the very rich of a previous century, and see the Wallace Collection when you're in London.

No more a best kept secret.. I've been selfish too long, enjoying my occasional visits to this grand house partly because it is never heaving with other visitors. So it's time to share.The collection of paintings (mainly 16th to 18th century, festuring the likes of Reubens, Canaletto, Fragonard, Hals, Watteau and Gainsborough) is surprisingly huge and well displayed in the impressive side rooms and Great Gallery. The fine porcelain, sculptures, furniture, armour and weapons also reward attention.The nation should be grateful for the clever collecting of five generations of Marquesses of Hertford and to Lady Hertford who bequeathed the results to us.The now glass-enclosed central courtyard houses a pleasant restaurant that I recommend as a midway refreshment source as you spend a joyous at least three hours exploring these marvels. The fact that tranquility reigns throughout the house a mere five minutes from bustling Oxford Street is a delightful bonus!Oh, and did I mention that it's free? Any donation will be both deserved and warmly welcomed.

Absolutely fantastic - London's hidden gem!. This is a wonderful place! Located in the backstreets of Manchester Square, proves why private collections far exceed their well known state cousins in stuffy museums. A melting pot of sculptures, paintings, clocks and furniture gathered across many centuries - there's something for everybody. And the best part...the awesome collection of armor in the lower levels. Absolutely fantastic!

The Wallace Collection, Manchester Square, London. A most outstanding art collection of Sir Richard Wallace, Marquess of Hertford & Lady Hertford who bequeathed the collection to the nation. The 4th Marquess was one of the greatest art collectors of the 19th century and what we see today was essentially his collection.The state rooms & various galleries display exotic 17th & 18th century Roccoco furniture - Louis IV, V & VI, crystal chandeliers, Sevres porcelain, ornate clocks, Oriental & European arms & armour, sculptures in bronze & marble and a vast collection of paintings of the famous masters, just to name the better known few - Rembrandt, Canaletto, Boucher, Fragonard, Watteau, Delacroix, Titian, Van Dyck, Poussin, Frans Hal, Thomas Lawrence,Thomas Gainsborough & Sir Joshua Reynolds.Alight at the Bond Street underground tube station, cross Oxford Street & walk up Duke Street next to Sefridges, cross Wigmore Street & over to Manchester Square at the end of Duke Street. Take a couple of hours off from your Oxford Street/Bond Street shopping spree & the Wallace Collection will be well worth the effort.

A little known gem. This wonderful art collection is free! It's tucked behind Selfridges on Manchester Square and still feels like a (very extravagant) Victorian home. Some might go to see the Canaletto's but I prefer the clocks, the pottery and the Stubbs. The house is set around a central courtyard that has been glazed and houses a lovely cafe - an oasis in the centre of London. Well worth at least 2 hours of your time.

A great place. This is an absolute gem. The collection of furniture, paintings, snuff boxes etc are of the very highest quality. The staff were helpful and informative. It will be first on our list of places to visit on our next trip to London

London's Treasure House. Just behind Oxford Street, a former LARGE private house that was donated to the nation, it has recently been refurbished. Our nine-year old loves the children's holiday workshops. Wonderful furniture, decoration, paintings, sculpture, even armour! Another hidden jewel - if it had been in a provincial town, it would make it famous and a centre of tourism, but in London, it is just hidden unless you are told about it. You would not even stumble across it walking around the West End. DEFINITELY worth a visit - and, if you fancy a treat, the cafe is excellent.
Nice for a quiet afternoon. Great place to spend a quiet afternoon. Great for adults but not the best place for youngsters as there are mature themes. Excellent weapons colelction too.

A fantastic museum. I have lived in London for over 10 years, and I can not believe that I had missed this. A fantastic museum with an amazing collection. The tours are very informative, but if you want to know more about a particular painting, ask one of the very friendly attendants.

A great afternoon out. Lovely mansion/town house in the centre of London. Great paintings and luxurious furniture to see. Especially, I liked Dutch paintings of everyday scenes and the Canalettos. Staff are very friendly and will love to answer your questions. Restaurant/cafe a bit disappointing, as they don't serve hot food.

A Must See. The Wallace Collection in Hertford House is the most perfect collection of exquisite objects in London. The rooms are a beautiful setting for the treasures. Do try and have a snack or meal in the lovely restaurant outside and the shop will ensure the most lovely presents and card for birthdays and Christmas.
Wow!. This is a must! Amazing collection of paintings. Wonderful place

Not to be missed small museum with superb art.. Not only is the art collection great, it is not too big and it is free. First rate medieval and renaissance and armor. The restaurant has the best deal for afternoon tea and you can split it. We went back twice for the art and food.

Not my cup of tea. Visited late last year with friends - a bit disappointed. There just seemed to be room after room of the same items, I really can't get too excited over cases and cases of swords or early firearms that appear only superficially different from their neighbours. I found the staff slightly 'superior' as if they didn't actually want visitors very much, but recognised, grudgingly, that they were supposed to be a museum with all that that entails. The restaurant seemed a touch expensive - all in all I prefer the Victoria & Albert

Best kept secret in the area.... Literally 2 minutes' walk off busy Oxford street, this museum is very interesting, set in a beautiful building and a nice refuge from the busy shopping areas. Definitely worth a look - even for half an hour or so. There is no entrance fee but they do accept donations, and umbrellas and large bags must be checked. There are guided tours at various times throughout the day, and the cafe also looked very good - though I have not eaten there (yet).

Its a pearl for a Museum. Many generations of collectors, in a family with big money that spent them on many different things.Painting, war-items, porcelain, and a lot more, much worth a visit, but dont be in a hurry, take your time.Its allowed to take photographs, but not with flash => Flash is not allowed !Been there two times, april and october in 2011, found it when the rest of the family visited Madam Tussaud and we strolled past the museum from Oxford street.Free entrance, donations wanted..., restaurant inside, but we brought sandwiches the second time we went, and ate them outside, so I cant advice if its good or not, looks expensive anyway.

A must see in London. An extraordinary museum in a beautiful place : a a beautiful house in a quiet square , not far from Oxford street.The collection is impressive, great value and good taste everywhere, speaking about artworks or the house itself.You may spend there a few hours ; free entry, nice restaurant in the interior courtyard.

Excellent Armour & Weapons!. Armour and Weapons aren't really my thing, but they made a fun look-see. So much is there and varied too.Not to mention some lovely art & objects & clocks in a spectacular home!

Hidden gem just off busy Oxford Street. We stumbled across this by accident but very glad we decided to take a look. Amazing property and collection of artworks, a far cry from the crazy shopping going on just a block away on Oxford Street.Well worth a couple of hours of your time, free entry, donations encouraged.

You can't miss this.... Absolutely incredible..what a beautiful house, fabulous collection and 5 minutes walk from Oxford Street..the only thing I don't understand is why is this place not more famous? I've lived in London all my life and never heard of it before...whether you live in London or are a tourist, you absolutely must go here....
Beautiful!. Spectacularcollection of mainly French decorative arts and art, in a beautiful London mansion!

A strange gem. Stumbling across the Velasquez portrait of the Duchess of Alba was one of the greater surprises I've ever had. I won't mention what it was like to see the acres of flesh from eighteenth century France first thing on a Monday morning. More recently, the Wallace collection has become more user friendly and it makes a nice place to relax after the hustle of shopping in Oxford Street.

Lovely gem. Lovely medium size museum without the full on crowds of the larger more well known collections. Being in a former home adds to the experience of viewing the collection. The combination of the paintings, decorations and furniture in many of the rooms adds to the experience. The central atrium with restaurant is a bright airy space to stop and restore and reflect even on an overcast early spring day.

It's a gem and it's free. I don't know how the family made its money, but they certainly were avid collectors. The historic town house is itself worth seeing and there is a cafe in the central courtyard where you can have a pleasant afternoon tea. The collection contains an impressive array of Sevres porcelain, as well as paintings and lots of small expensive objets. Then there is the armoury, with all manner of weapons. There is art in the armoury too, with some of the weapons being truly beautiful. This may not be as fine as the Musee Jacqumart-Andre in Paris, but it is a similar sort of experience. This is a national museum, so there is no charge for entry and there is a lot that would interest children as well as adults.

Amazing British collection.... What a true delight! Amazing restoration, well done. What splendour in a very comfortable surrounding. The atrium restaurant/tea house is beautiful and helps the foundation keep this house immaculate. The 5GPB entry fee was money well spent.I really felt transported back in time for the time I was there. Thank you.

A "must see" collection in London's West End. The big attraction for us was the fine selection of Old Master paintings, absolutely free of charge. The café was a haven after two long hours viewing the exhibits, though rather pricey.

Outstanding! Do not miss!. Very few people know about this wonderful place, and I very much want to change that. I definitely disagree with Rick Steves's assessment that it does not measure up to the other museum options in London. There is something here for everyone: The vastest collection of armor that I've ever seen, period rooms, Old Masters, miniatures, majolica, amazing furnishings and decor. Though I didn't eat there, the restaurant in the courtyard looked lovely.I loved seeing Fragonard's "The Swing." As well, there's Rembrandt, Pisarro, Watteau, and Rubens, among others. The size of the collection is extensive but manageable, so that it can be reasonably "done" in a day. There are also extensive descriptions of the rooms and all their contents available.

A Jewel - hard to believe entry is free!. Tucked inside the Marylebone area, this is a very stunning museum, hosting the most impressive French paintings and furniture in London. Every room is striking - from floor to ceiling, each room curated with elegance and glamour from the 19th Century Romantic era.

Beautiful collection. I went for a private viewing and a friends leaving dinner. The collection is dazzling and the custodians so knowledgeable. It feels rather like wandering around a grand house. A must see in London.
wonderful collection. Recently done up and fantastically over the top but a great collection of art, furnture, arms and armour and such like. Fab restaurant too.
Wallace - a must have. This is such a nice collection, though hidden. It took us a while to find it. There are numerous great painting and a huge collection of arms. Moreover, lunch is to be praised.
A London Gem. This a lovely, small-scale gem. It's size is manageable...beautiful Sevres porcelain and Fragonard paintings. Nice cafe too.

Armour!. I have a strong interest in medievil armour and the wallace collection doesnt disapoint, Here and leeds armouries are the two finest arms & armour collections in the UK.
The upper floors are the art collection.

Welcoming and Impressive. The Wallace Collection in Hertford House is without doubt a magnificient collection of art set in well lit grand rooms. Among the paintings one can admire at close quarters is the famous painting by Frans Hals,"The Laughing Cavalier ". The miniatures are intriguing, the arms and armoury collection is wonderful and the furniture and ceramics are something to be seen to be believed. Although this is a small museum,count on at least an hour and a half to two hours to get a proper perspective of all that there is to see. There is a restaurant set in a courtyard now closed in by a glass ceiling. It is about a ten minute walk from Bond St Tube station in Oxford Street.

Paintings, ceramics and furniture, something for everyone to see. This is the second time I have visited and it was just as wonderful the second time around. Lots of wow factors everywhere you look. For me 'The Laughing Cavallier' is the highlight and well worth seeing. My daughter loved the trinket boxes and the ceramics. There is something for everyone and a very nice coffee shop too.There is no entrance charge but they do ask for a donation to be left in the collection box on the way out and they suggest £5 per person.

So much to see!. The guided tour is brilliant. There is so much of interest to see and it is extremely well presented. The staff are very knowledgeable and helpful. The courtyard cafe is well worth a visit.

Highly recommended. I had visited the Wallace Collection as a part of a walking tour several years ago and wanted to bring my wife. It is an amazing collection of artwork. Some of it is not exactly our taste but it was truly amazing in any event. Several Rembrants, Van Dyke's. What I did not see on the first visit was the medieval armor and weapons collection. I have never seen such an extensive collection in any museum. An excellent place to vivit!
Gem in the middle of London. Ever since the cafe was built in the central courtyard (2003 ish) this place has been perfect. A wonderful and hidden museum

One of the finest small museums in the world. As you wind around the rooms every corner turned reveals a new facination, Paintings, gold boxes arms and armor, fine porcelain and much much more. The perfect afternoons delight for the eyes.

Recommended from a local Londoner-glad we went !. Really enjoyed walking around the Wallace-they have a nice collection of everything here! This isn't really on the tourist radar, and that I love about it. It's set back off in a residential area, fairly straight forward to find. It's free- no charge. They have a beautiful area for dining-we stayed and ate lunch- if you like anchovies the Ceasar salad was full of them-( I don't )No photography inside- understandable, except downstairs where you can try the armor on. I have a funny photo of that! Thank you Wallace Collection!!

Held our function here. This is a fantastic place for a function. We were here for a celebratory event. Guests could view the art on the ground floor (Wallace provided a tour guide) before wandering through to the airy modern area which I understand was the former stables! We enjoyed a variety of drinks and the canapé were lovely! One of the best places we have booked for an event. Only downside is the toilets are downstairs but I'm sure there was a lift. Would return just to see what's upstairs.

What a gem!. Make sure you allow time to see all and make time to have either lunch or a drink (or two) or tea ... in the beautiful atrium. We visited on a day where there was a power cut so did not see the collection at its best, that said what we did see was just captivating. Well laid out and beautifully presented. This collection is far bigger than I expected and has so many facets. Do go and enjoy, I loved it and will be going back.

Beautiful!. This is the most wonderful "house" museum I've ever seen. It definitely trumps anything I've seen in the states. The decorated rooms are spectacular, representing a full spectrum of colors. Loved the armor exhibit where you can try on some of the (heavy) displays. The best part was the sheer magnitude. There were so many spectacular paintings and decorative art pieces, truly breathtaking. It was also a great way to sneak a peak at the aristocratic way of life! I would say this museum makes a nice complement to some of the larger and overwhelming museums around London.

Wonderful collection in intimate setting. The Wallace Collection in London is not to be missed! A haven for art lovers, it houses Italian French and Dutch paintings and a marvellous collection of furniture and porcelain. It has a great restaurant and bookshop as well and is conveniently located just off Oxford Street.

Will go again. Had been told about the Wallace Collection some time back, but this was the first time - had a slot - and visited. What wonderful Art work, furniture and collectables. The array of various types of clocks,believe once a month one can go around with whomever winds them up - would like to do that one day. Unfortunately our time was limited, but will definitely go back for a further viewing.When one visits the "bigger" well known museums in Central London they are normally packed, this was a pleasure to wander with no one in the way. On reading what others have written about the "staff", Maybe we were at a different place, they are there to do a job and look after the exhibits. We found them very friendly when we asked the odd question .There are files available in each room which one can carry around and read about the exhibits etc. in that particular room.Would have no hesitiation in recommending anyone to visit .
exquisite smaller stately home in london. an historic landmark "house" (i.e. mansion) filled with exceptional 18th & 19th century painting, furniture, etc. quiet and not crowded

Overrated. This was a major disappointment. The paintings were haphazardly arranged and many were difficult to view, being well above eye level. Too many visitors in a limited-space mansion made for a hurried visit. Pales in comparison to the refined elegance of the Frick Collection in New York.

Worth a visit. Although I loved seeing the weapons and Armour displays, the format isn't very visitor friendly; very few of the items on show have notes on them explaining what they are or why they are important.It's still worth going to but if you don't already have a good idea about what is on display either don't go or get a tour guide

An Exceptional Collection Worth Your Time. Located in the adorable Marylebone neighborhood, this extensive collection is a MUST SEE and it is FREE. I found the audio guide very helpful. My friends and I took high tea in the courtyard. The service was good, but the food was not impressive.
A Hidden Gem. Everything about this collection and the way it's run is so special. A wonderful eclectic collection and a delightful place to lunch.

Superb collection with added Dutch.. A vast and varied collection, which includes weapons, armour, ceramics and furniture. I went for the newly opened Dutch galleries so concentrated mainly on those three rooms this time. Jan Steen Celebrating the Birth particularly caught my eye. As one set of stairs was closed off I had to pass miles of Murillos, Rubens,Titians, Rubens, Rembrandt, Velàzquez, Canaletto, Poussin and Gainsborough. Which was no hardship at all. One could visit just one room and spend an hour there go outside or visit the wonderful restaurant and go back for more. It never seems crowded and the visitors seem more genteel than at other free public galleries in London.
Lovely. Lovely, but don't visit with a travel bag. There's no where to store baggage.

Intelligent collection in a beautiful setting. Small collection but extremely choice, presented in a beautiful house. Outstanding Fragonard collection - but an extraordinary Hals - colors! - as well, plus Rubens, Velazquez, and more. Good restaurant too. A lovely way to spend an afternoon.

Great discovery!. I found it by accident near Oxfor Street whiles walking between streets and it was a great discovery..very interesting indeed. It reminder me about Braveheart, the fantastic Mel Gibson movie!lol! :)
a must see. Really enjoyed. A lovely setting for a varied collection. Give yourself lots of time to enjoy the paintings. The staff are so helpful and plenty information in every room.

Really shouldn't share London's best kept secret. My all time favourite place to go in London. Set in quiet and unnoticed Manchester Square, a visit to the Wallace Collection is quite simply one of the best things in life you can do with your clothes on :-) I often come here just to avoid the crowds and have a quiet latte in the open air cafe at the back. But the building and the collection are wondrous in itself and the very knowledgeable tour guides take you through this treasure trove. One of my favourite paintings is the laughing cavalier and it's never a crowd in the way to see this glorious work or for any other gem here for that matter. The staff are always friendly and goes what? It's free! Yes, really and unbelievably. I shouldn't tell you all this so I can keep it all to myself....but, hey, life is short

A Step into History. Cannot describe as everyone sees and enjoys in different ways but to have the pleasure of looking at all these wondrous things is that have been collected makes a person speecless.This after over 40yrs of visits.I just want to always keep coming back.

Leisurely afternoon tea in great surroundings. The Wallace Collection is my favourite galley housing a very eclectic collection of fine art so when I needed a venue for an afternoon tea this seemed a nice/special/different choice.Having read previous reviews I was forewarned that the service was poor but as we were a group of gossipy friends having a leisurely afternoon together this didn't seem important. Sure enough we were shown to our table and half an hour later we managed to attract a waiter over to take our order. After another long-ish wait our glasses of pink Champaign arrived followed by the tea served in cute cast iron teapots. Another 10 minutes or so later and the three tiered afternoon tea plates arrived.Bottom plate was a selection of finger sandwiches - a few smoked salmon, a few egg and ham and mustard which were OK but nothing spectacular. Top plate was the scones (slightly over done) with decent dollop of clotted cream and "red" flavour clear jam/jelly (perhaps made by Chivers?).Middle plate was a selection of mini cakes including a smashing lemon tart that was to die for. What looked like a mini 1970's retro Blackforest gateau didn't seem particularly fresh but tasted OK as did the mini Victoria sponge.All in all at £17 for the main afternoon tea menu (or £25 if you wish to include a glass of Champaign) the food was OK but was more than made up for by the surroundings. Ours was a sunny day and the courtyard venue and the tour before hand made it extra special and we didn’t mind the long wait too much. The 12% service charge added was treated with derisionAfternoon Tea is served between 2:30 and 4:30 pm. The gallery closes at 5pm which doesn’t give you time to look around afternoon so come early. As this is a Government owned museum I'd suggest any disgruntled customers feedback poor performance to DCMS and ask how they justify tolerating the poor contract management of the restaurant. Clearly the contractor is taking the museum and tax payer for a ride and badly letting down the attraction.
it was ok but. the paintings fab but the armouries,(i have no interest)were less so .
A hidden treasure. Not on the priority list of many tourists - but marvellous. Let's keep it a secret and not tell anyone.

lovely gallery, in a lovely setting. We went to the wallace gallery on a weekday around 11am and it was pretty busy even then with students and tourists. Having decided we wanted to grab food we headed to the courtyard. The courtyard area is beautiful setting and is great for a coffee or even a business meeting as several were taking place whilst we were there. The cafe itself is run by Peyton and Bryne who have several catering outlets around London.We decided to have brunch and after attracting one of several waitors attentions we were seated and each finally ordered our brunch. When it came it was beautiful the eggs royale were excellently cooked runny on the inside and firm on the our and the boiled eggs and sourdough were lovingly and quickly consumed. With coffees it was around £15 a head which is not the cheapest nor the most expensive in this area and definitely worthwhile if only to sit in the atrium courtyard on a sunny day. Just a word of warning the waiting was a bit haphazard with us several times getting up to attract the staffs attention. Back in the museum the collection was vast and very different there were a large collection of various items including weapon displays that could challenge the army, minatures paintings and gentile living examples of serval eras. All made it a devine way to spend a chance day off. There are also talks and tours to watch out for and the clock tour was particularly interesting.There is a clockroom for jackets etc, and whilst there is no charge a small donation is appreciated for the muesum.
charming. set in a period house with an exquisite, small but perfectly formed collection the house is beautiful and part of the whole attraction

Good gallery let down by dreadful staff. The refurbished rooms are fantastic. Our visit was marred somewhat by the gallery staff whose attitude and behaviour was really off putting - they kept following us around (I was being pushed in a wheelchair). and at one point a staff member looked over the shoulder of my wife who was peering closely at a small sculpture. Add to this that the staff tended to congregate for chats made the experience off putting. Shame because the gallery is fantastic but the gallery staff and restaurant hole this wonderful vessel beneath the waterline - hence the poor mark.
A trip in History. Went there for a birthday treat enjoyed all the Art (Laughing Cavalier )and Historical Pieces then Afternoon tea in the garden

Worth a visit. Beautiful museum in a sensible size, does not fell overwhelming.We went there in the morning and it was very relaxing it wasn't crowded.A wide range of paintings, furniture and beautiful weapons.
Beautiful surroundings. Great collection of artifacts many although not exclusively military set in such wonderful surroundings
charming place to spend a wonderful day if raining and even if not. Wallace collection : the book to buy after the free visitJust look admire dream walk slowly

A Classy Act.. The rich colours of the drapes and wall coverings in this wonderful collection are worth several visits. And it is Free to get in! Do visit the wonderful conservatory for a reasonably priced lunch/ afternoon tea.

Off the beaten track. This gallery is not considered as a must by most tourists in London. However, if you are going to visit jus one place that is not on your list of obvious places to see in London, visit this gallery. It is not the usual place that looks overwhelming when you see how much 'you have' to see. It is a nicely decorated smallish gallery with great works of art. Very relaxing to visit.

Fantastic. Visited on Sunday morning with some friends.Amazing paintings in a beautiful setting.Even the drapes are gorgeous.Restaurant is a covered courtyard,very nice but a bit pricey- 2 boiled eggs and a slice of toasted soldiers £6.50.

Great small gallery - free to visit. Great place to look around - lots of fabulous works of art in beautiful historic building. Like most of London's best museums and galleries, admission is free. Much more manageable size than the bigger galleries and a short walk from Oxford Street.

An incredible, beautiful collection.. The Wallace Collection is, in essence, a museum of amazing variety. It contains items from all over the world, from as early as the 1400s (I think). Sculptures, china, paintings, arms and armour, furniture, carvings, medallions - and all have one thing in common. All are exquisitely crafted and each, in it's own way, is beautiful. We spent 3 hours there, and covered perhaps half of the collection.Entrance is "free", although a donation of at least five pounds per person is appreciated (if not expected).I don't believe this would be a suitable attraction for young children, although older teenagers with an interest in history and/or art, or just an apprecation of beauty and craftmanship, may very well enjoy this remarkable place.
Probably the best free museum experience in London.. A closed collection, so its changeless, but so what? The quality of the items is top notch so we've been several times in past few years.

Best small art gallery in London. You cannot beat the Wallace for its fantastic collection of furniture, paintings and Sevres..mainly 18th century french art and objects. See also the one Wallace Fountain in London outside the building.

one stop wonder. Ever needed to visit a gallery or collection in London with friends who do not have the time or inclination to trek round the numerous worthy and interesting galleries in the city? I recommend the Wallace collection for a brilliant taster of paintings, furniture, china, and armour. We pop in there occasionally with friends visiting the uk.last visit was with friends from India, and it was a perfect taster on a very busy trip.I enjoy the occasional exhibiton, and the little shop is just right. the Cafe is ideal for a treat, and a very nice environment for a chat.Do not overlook this little gem on a visit to London. Easy to reach on foot if you are on Oxford St. No charge, but donations accepted.
Hidden gem. A superb collection in a historic house, often overlooked but well worth a visit.
Beautiful collection. A less well known collection than the famous galleries in London but no less interesting and enjoyable for that.

Beautiful Treasures. I stumbled across the Wallace Collection when I was lost one day. It is just a short wander from Oxford St. What an amazing collection of furniture, paintings and ornaments. Well worth a visit.

French furniture and Van Dyk portraits - beautiful!. It's a manageable size, the collection is not too big, on 2 floors of a mansion in central London, it's free, and it closes at 5, so give it at least an hour or 2 before. It's not really for kids (wait, the back 3 rooms are full of armor and ancient weapons), but it's stuffed with large and small furniture, porcelain, and paintings, some of which are famous and stunning.There's a beautiful glassed - in atrium cafe/restaurant in the middle, but I can't vouch for the food. We didn't stop to eat.
Charming. The house itelf is very charming. In the patio you find a wonderful place to have your lunch. The gallerys permanent collection is really worth a visite.

Small but brilliant. One of Londons smaller museums but very worthy of a visit. It houses amongst one of the best collection of European Armour I have seen and a collection of snuff boxes that I wish I owned.

Amazing collection of art. What an amazing place! It is filled with beautiful art and other fine collectibles. They have one of the most extensive and amazing collection of Sevres porcelain I've ever seen. Definitely something to add to the must-see sights of London even though there is no shortage of things to see and do there!
eclectic collection. a wonderful range of furniture, paintings, clocks, china, armoury etc, etc. Well worth the visit.
well worth a visit. love the house and the beautiful things in it and looking out of the window across Manchester square is lovely and just off Oxford street great

The Decorative Arts experience in London which encompasses Paris". I am a Sevres porcelain admirer. The collection here and the wonderful feeling of the whole museum/house is amazing. The Laughing Cavaleir painting a delight and the Sevres porcelain collection to die for. The museum was left to the country by Robert Wallace and is a joy. If you like olde worlde armour, you will be in heaven, if you want some superb artworks you will not be disappointed. NO ENTRY FEE and such a joy> Went here first in 1969 and have been here many times since and recommend it to everyone. Nice restaurant too. Enjoy!! Love the staircase!!

Another London gem. Never been here before and that was a great mistake.It is a real art treasure in the heart of London, with so much to see. A great restaurant in the courtyard. The admission is free. Do not miss it!

A real gem and so close to busy Oxford Street. After some heavy shopping at the sales in Oxford Street it was nice to escape to the tranquil surroundings and admire some serious works of art .The Canalettos were especially good. And it is free.
Art Gallery. This is another London treasure and well worth a visit, also excellent restaurant.

Outstanding in every way. Set in a beautiful house 3 minutes off the bustle of Oxford street this is a gem not to be missed. It is a place of oustanding quality with delights in every room. Stand out exhibits for me were The Laughing Cavalier, the Canelettos and the sumptious ceramics.Try not to miss the small oil 'La Ferte, about 1825' by Richard Parkes Bonnington which is a knockout!For me the very best small National Museum in the country.

It was great, the armor, pottery, art and food.. Overall it was great. Every detail was good. The food was marvelous as well as the setting. The armor, one of the best collections in the world, was fascinating. Most of it seemed impossible to move in, but it was great. The paintings were unique and too nice to put in words. The pottery each had its own background which made it even better. Overall, it was worth going to. Enjoy your own adventure there!rubystar2245
Varied Collection. All types of things here in the collection, my personal favourite is the armour. Central location with a good restaurant centrally makes it an ideal "meet" venue with good food.
Fantastic exhibition. I could spend days without getting bored here. there is so much to see.
My best experience in London. Amazing art; furniture from Marie Antoinette, Life size models of horses in stunning armour, it just goes on and on............go there: do not miss it!

Wonderful and varied collection. Only a stone's throw from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street lies this charming house with its wonderful collection of art, porcelain, clocks and armour. The restaurant serves tasty lunches as well as morning coffees and afternoon teas. The admission is free.

Obsessive collection. I love the Wallace Collection - it is a small gem in London. The objet's and art within are all of an excellent quality. The Armouries are fantastic - and I love the ornate set of Farriers tools above all. There is some Iconic art with a naughty girl on a swing, a Dance to the Music of Time and a Laughing Cavalier. However, how many pieces of Boulle furniture, or pictures of dead birds and fruit does one bear need??
good place to spend a couple of hours. Lovely house and paintings, its free, nice inside courtyard cafe,Would recommended to the culture buff.

Beautiful house with equisite works and fabulous restaurant. Extraordinary beautiful house set in Manchester Square, just behind Oxford Street, free entry to a magnificent collection of classic art and armour. Superbly curated, and currently (2011-2012) being restored the two floored gallery offers predominantly on the ground floor arms and armour, up a sweeping staircase to a selction of classic art crowned by the very sumptuous Fragonard "Girl on a Swing". The relatively new restaurant had become a must-go-to meeting point, for business, friends or lovers, set within the now covered courtyard, great lunches, perfect afternoon teas.

One of my very favourites. Anyone shopping on Oxford St should slip round the back and visit this wonderful Museum. Wonderful Painting and amazing furniture, helpful Staff and a lovely Cafe on top. Living here 12 Years and always take Visitors to this one, a truly hidden Gem.
Loose yourself. Fantastic collection of paintings and artifacts displayed in a very accessible way. Clean and organized, will re-visit.
A Mixed Collection. What an amazing mix of things there are in this collection, something for everyone and a nice Restaurant to eat in.

First class collection, so-so restaurant. I love museums in historic houses and this is one of my favorites. It was not crowded when I went, which made it possible to see the art collection and soak in the sumptuous surroundings. The furniture is as stunning as the paintings. I would not recommend the food at the restaurant, unless you just want a quick snack.

Hidden gem. I strolled into this museum during an afternoon when I had nothing to do, and ended up leaving a big donation after seeing the beautiful collection. If you visit this museum, you can see an impressive collection of paintings, but an even more impressive collection of weapons and armoury. Definitelly worth visiting
Comevfor lunch - stay for art. We highly recommend both the restaurant and gallery.
First visit!. Great collection - can't believe I had missed this art collection - it is now on my recommendation list for friends that travel to London!

My London Favorite. I suppose I shouldn't sing the praises of the Wallace Collection too loudly, if I do everyone will find out about it and it will get too crowded. Even though the collection doesn't change much from visit to visit, I see so many things for the first time on each visit.
andrewinlondon2011. Put this on your MUST DO in London. Great paintings and fantastic Majolica plate collection.

a real gem close to the hubbub of the West End.. We were recommended to visit the Wallace Collection. A real gem and whilst donations are requested, it is free entry. Fabulous collection in a calm and unhurried building - you just wouldn't believe you were so close to the noise of Oxford Street.Restaurant expensive but lovely courtyard setting and worth pushing the boat out for a special occasion afternoon tea.

Best little museum experience. The Wallace Collection is a beautiful respite from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street. I have been coming to London for years and this was my first time visiting and I will go back again. There is a fantastic collection of arms and armor, as well as jewelry and the entire residence is stunning. We did not have time to eat in the gorgeous cafe in the atrium of the museum, but will definitely schedule it for next visit as it is beautiful. Would be a great place for lunch or tea when shopping in the are. Admission is free as well so you can visit for as little or as long as you like. This was my 17 year old daughter's favorite museum visit of the trip.

Why isn't this place totally overrun with visitors?. Just behind Oxford Street by a couple of streets, a gracious old mansion containing a fabulous wealth of art of all descriptions. The Canaletto collection is most impressive (either they cornered the market or he was prolific [Yes, he was]) and there are some paintings here so famous you wonder they're not in the National or the Tate they are that well known. Then there are the clocks - the girl who walked us around was really knowledgable and gave a splended presentation in her broken French English - I think she spoke far better English than she would admit and played on her accent and supposed lack of vocabulary! Some very intersting stuff in the shop, especially for children to help them get a liking for the graphic arts - some good things for Christmas presents! This is a place to visit in small dollops time and time again - AND - it's free - unbelievable.

Really excellent place that is well hidden but worth visiting. This is a really fantastic under-loved gem full of beautiful paitings by top notch artists in a lovely setting. The restaurant is also really peaceful and very nicely located in the centre of a building in a large covered courtyard.I would not hesitate to recomment this place and not just because The Laughing Cavalier hangs there. You can get up (very) close to the paintings, unlike others eg The Louvre where the Mona Lisa viewing is disappointing by comparison
What a gem.... Wonderful free tour with a guide that really knew her stuff. Such a beautiful house.

London's best kept secret.. The Wallace Collection is a national museum in an historic London town house which is massive and a destination in itself. . There are 25 packed rooms of French 18th century painting, furniture and porcelain with Old Master paintings and a world class armoury that would be hard to match anywhere. Admission is free and the collection is available 7 days a week. Each of the rooms has guide books and the collection of armour, swords and such is accompanied by texts describing in detail each of the objects on display. Pistols, crossbows, lances etc were collected over many years from many areas and is a must see. Allow sufficient time as this is not a walk through and the collection is extensive.

Great Location; shame about the restaurant. This is a true hidden gem in London and has one of the best settings for afternoon tea in London. What a pity, then, that tea is such an expensive shambles. I have been twice over the last year. The first time we ordered with an hour to go before closing, only to wait until five minutes before closing for our £17.50 tea to be delivered and then to be told that we would have to eat up as we needed to be out of the building in ten minutes. The second time, yesterday, we were served wafer thin slices of cake (none of which were our first choice, these all having been sold out) for £4.50 by staff who seemed to think they were well above serving us.I love this place, the art and the building, but I won't be visiting the cafe again any time soon.

Amazing!. This house has an amazing collection os porcelain, wonderful paintings including the Laughing Cavalier. Everything is arranged in the rooms so thatt yoou can get really close to the exhibits. The restaurant in teh covered courtyard is very pleasant.

Free and great art in a beautiful house. If you have been to London several times and feel like doing something different and new but cultural then go to the Wallace Collection! They organise free tours (11h30 and 2h30) where they tell you about the story behind some of the objects in the house and link it to the history. Absolutely wonderful! Once the tour is over go and have tea in their inside court. The food is delicious. If you live in London or go to London often then go before they close the art galleries (restoration work is going to go on for the next few years) as there are some outstanding collections worth seeing!

An Unusual Look at History. The free museum in interestingly located and houses an interesting collection of old body armor and weapons, predominantly from Italy and Germany, with an obvious and interesting contrast in styles. The art collection has a few gems and the furniture collection is also worth a quick look. The glass-enclosed courtyard is a great place for lunch or a snack.

Beautiful. If you're staying at the Hyatt London, The Churchill, you should definitely visit the Wallace Collection only 2 blocks away. Incredible paintings and beautiful pieces. You can spend an hour or a day. Wonderful courtyard cafe.

A little of everything. I visited the Wallace Collection on a Saturday. Overall I enjoyed the visit to the museum.The audioguide was very detailed and reasonably priced, entrance is free. I found the staff to be courteous and professional, I disgree with some of the other rather petty reviews saying the staff were curt, I found them to be all professional. The items were of great quality but could have been displayed a bit better. They are upgrading a new wing which should help but until then the labelling could be better and finding some of the star attractions does take some searching. However it was overall an enjoyable experience and without any crowds which makes a nice change.
Love the 'Laughing Cavalier'. Loved the furnishings, ceilings, sculptures, the art, everything! Two floors of history! Highly recommended.

It's great, one of the only places that doesn't rip you off in London!. Amazing, sublime, friendly staff and a great place to visit. It is free and should remain so. Thank you Wallace Collection. Don't start charging people please.Amazing Lous XVI and Empire antiques, a real feast for the eyes.Thank you for a good trip, and thank you for not excluding good members of the public with an entry fee!

Amazed with the quality and quantity of the collection.. The Wallace Collection was recommended to me by a neighbor who had recently been in London. I visited the Hertford House that houses the Collection near Duke Street. It is free entry but they do ask for donations. I toured an extensive collection of armor for men and horses, knives, spears, bows, shields. Overwhelming. There are porcelains, Louis XV ironwork and furniture, bronzes, works of art of major artists (Rembrandt, Titian, van Dyck, etc.), clocks all housed in rooms with period wallpaper, out of this world chandeliers, and luxurious window treatments. I compare the treasures to the items that I saw at the Heritage Museum in St. Petersburg and the artwork in the state rooms of Buckingham Palace. Bought the guide book so that I could enjoy the collection after I left the house. Heartily recommend this attraction.

A real hidden gem.. I love the Wallace Collection. It's a real hidden gem tucked away near Baker Street. Some absolute amazing artifacts. A very nice resturant aswell.A great place for a long afternoon away from the less informed tourists. Really compact so really good for your legs. Enjoy....

Great potential poor execution. Had to wait a good while to get attention of staff at "wait here to be seated sign" with plenty of staff on shop floor and a 2/3 empty restuarant. Told from moment we sat down at 1545 that they were closing at 5pm. Maitre D was very pleasant but too busy waitering rather than delegating his staff to attend to customers. Poor service, staff bickering and fussing amongst themselves.Cream tea was not worth £20 and was less than average. The only thing that saves Peyton&Byrne is the locations they use - they need to work a lot harder to maintain a reputation

Great potential, very poor execution. I popped in to the cafe with a friend to have tea. The cafe is very pretty - lots of light and comfortable chairs. However we stood for quite a while at the 'wait here to be seated' sign even though there were plenty of staff and not too many customers. It then took an age for anyone to come and take our order, another age to get our tea and another unacceptable delay before our cake arrived (which was delicious). Having waited so long we were then hustled out of the cafe shortly after we finished because 'there's a private function tonight'. Very poor - for such a lovely setting the service really lets it down.

Lovely atmosphere, beautifully laid out with some great pieces. We were up in London for a birthday treat for my wife and popped into the Wallace Collection in Hertford House. Staff were very welcoming, took our soaking wet coats and umbrellas (summer in London). We had a good time wandering around the collection, in particular the' Time Regained: Works by Artist Goldsmith Kevin Coates' exhibition which were superb, especially the George and Dragon he made for No 10 Downing St. We had a cup of tea in the Wallace Restaurant in the courtyard which is covered with a glass roof, which had a lovely atmosphere and can be booked for dinner on Friday/Saturday evenings which we thought would be a good thing to do. All in all a great visit. The paintings were in fantastic condition with strong, bright colours considering some of them were over 500 years old. Huge collection of weapons and armour, sevres and paintings and furniture. Some of the biggest chandeliers we've seen. It must have been a fabulous place to live, when it was a private residence. Lots of lectures and family activities scheduled throughout the summer holidays. We put £10 in donation box as we thought we should support it!

A great museum and beautiful square most tourists miss.. Most tourists seem to be enthralled by the shopping and hordes on Oxford Street and that's all they see in this area. Big mistake. Go a few streets north and visit the wonderful Wallace Collection. See especially the marquetry desk (1760). Then stroll around Manchester Square to see some of the most exquisite Georgian houses in the world.

Wonderful collection in a quiet setting. I visited the collection with a couple of friends. We met from 3 different directions so it was a good meeting place and easy to find. I am amazed it is free - a rare thing these days. There is a lot to see so rather than spend all day there we chose to miss some parts out and perhaps go back another day. It wasn't busy despite being holiday season.The café was overpriced even by London standards; the coffee was in small cups and the cake was dry either from poor storage or age. The service presented the usual problems trying to communicate with unable/unwilling east europeans. Would definitely go elsewhere to drink and eat next time and there are many places nearby.

Sublime art and works of Art. Free Admission.. One cannot add much except to the continuity of the excellent reviews.The website and the house catalog(ue) are exemplary.It is a wonderful house to visit. Magnificent rooms and displays which are close to Bond Street and not as populous as the pay-to-enter treasure palaces on the tourist trail in central London. It is also in a very pleasant, if exclusive, area to visit, shop and eat. Relaxed strolling with many individual shops and eating places.A "must place to visit " if you have come from the States. It's FREE entry to this massive former aristocratic house.Titian and a few other notables. Names trip off the Rubens palate.Exquisite armour and silver from Japan, India and Europe......Modern elevator/lift system.Enjoy the exhibition. Wallow in the most prestigious shopping, dining and architecture in residential London. Wallace has lovely friendly shop staff and you can leave your coats/bags while you visit. Excellent WC/toilets facilities. Some of the best in London. Oops, we know where to go.Catering area should be outstanding. Disappointing operation. Local alternatives in abundance.We were truly overwhelmed by the appeal to all of the International importance of the art on display from pictorial to craft metal.

Nice exhibits but restaurant staff ignore you completely. Came to the museum with my girlfriend last week. They have a great collection of stuff although they could certainly do with including more than one piece per room in their audio guide.Then tried to get lunch in their restaurant. Joined a queue and we all stood there for ten minutes trying to catch a waiter's attention, but they were all deliberately ignoring us, even though there were plenty of tables free. Eventually I rang the restaurant up from my mobile (I was standing near their phone) and asked them when we might get served. When the waiter realised it was me on the phone he just hung up on me. After five more minutes the manager came among the queue to tell us they were expecting a large party. Why they couldn't have had a sign to that effect I don't know - instead they were happy to waste all our time waiting for tables that weren't going to be available. When I complained to the manager she did offer us a free drink... in fifteen minutes' time. We decided we'd had enough of standing around and went elsewhere for lunch. There are lots of good places on Marylebone High Street / Thayer St just nearby, so I'd suggest you go there. You can get back into the museum afterwards as it's free.

great unsung museum- and it's free. a magnificent collection of art sitting in a posh london neighborhood all the result of the onerous english death taxes. the entire collection was given to the nation to avoid selling it all to pay death taxit is the home of the world famous painting--- laughing cavalier by frans hals--- go see it.

Best Museum. My wife and I loved this museum and went twice. The art work, furniture, porcelain, chandeliers, main staircase and everything else were beautiful. I enjoyed reading the explanations at the room in the basement how they make marquetry. This museum is one of the best decorative arts museums I have seen.

something for women something for men. this is the best museum in London-in mine and my boyfriend's opinion of course:)
we've visited that summer almost every London museum and this beats all!!!
while I've looked through sniff boxes, sculptures and ceramics(in beautiful, beautiful rooms!) my boyfriend took pictures of enormous amount of weapons and armours;)
(which I liked too...somehow)
greatly recommended:D

Wonderful collection - let down by the restaurant. The Wallace Collection is indeed an amazing gem and has so much to see, housed in a wonderful house. And entry is free! I would agree that some of the staff can seem rather intimidating... There are cloakrooms to leave coats/bags in and the whole process runs very smoothly.We tried to have tea in the restaurant and were so disappointed by the experience. In fact we never managed to eat, but it was not for want of trying! We queued for over 25 minutes, during which time no-one took our details (e.g. party size) or seemed remotely interested in us. There were empty tables but waiting staff did not seem in any hurry to clear them and no-one seemed to be in charge of the front of house. I wrote to the managing director (Mr Peyton) as the wesite says that he would like to hear feedback but he never bothered to reply. I hope they sort out the service there, as we felt that it lets the museum down.Overall, well worth a visit and an oasis of calm after the noise of nearby Oxford Street.

Excellent Gallery. Restaurant needs serious attention. The Wallace Collection is exceptionally interesting, with a remarkable history and fine contents, mainly eighteenth century pictures and furniture. It lives in a magnificent house just off Baker Street. Admission is free; a remarkable thing in these philistine days, but one is rightly invited to give something. However, this is a review of the restaurant. Six of us went for lunch. We were in no hurry, which was all to the good as the meal took five minutes short of three hours, in a restaurant that was well populated but not full. The beautiful setting deserves exceptionally good food and service. Unfortunately, places, like people, don't always get what they deserve.We all had the set lunch, so that the kitchen should not have been unduly stretched. First courses were bland and uninteresting. Tian of crab is a good test of a kitchen, because one can produce either a fresh, tasty, thoughtful event, or just wing it, knowing that crab meat will carry one through somehow. Ours belonged, in every respect, to the second class. The main courses were much better. We had high quality salmon and tender, excellently cooked pork, with an intense jus. Desserts were disappointing. Tarte tartin is one of my favourite things: this one was ungenerous in size and not what a tt fan would expect. In England, by and large, restaurants serve imitations of good food and haut cuisine. Wallace is no exception. I did not detect a human being who really cared about what went out from his/her kitchen? But are people in this country concerned with what they eat? (A young French friend is shifting his small catering business from quality to volume because 'that's what the English want'.) The wine list looked interesting but we thought both a sancerre and a loire red did not justify their prices, even allowing for the usual restaurant mark-up. If there was a sommelier to consult, we did not see him.The service was poor, with long delays between events and - always the acid test - no attention. This is a management problem, of course.The staff were willing, but appeared to be half-trained and without direction. People were helpful when actively summoned, but rarely proactive, because one suspects they did not understand how 'front of house' should work. I did not see a head waiter at all, let alone someone who was alert to difficulties, related to his diners, and trained his staff. Should you eat here? Yes, if it is convenient, but don't expect more than a refuelling stop.If the Wallace Collection owns this restaurant then it should appoint an experienced maitre d' now; give the chef far more freedom; hire young staff willing to be trained and try for real food. If the place is out-sourced, find a company that actually cares about food and service or take it in house and start again. Galleries can run fine restaurants if they want to. (Try the Rex Whistler at Tate Britain.) The Wallace Cafe could be every bit as good. What a pity it isn't!

Wonderful collection cafe disappointing.. Don't agree about unfriendly staff in the galleries; I appreciate their discreet and unobtrusive presence. It's remarkable that it's free as well, and the collection is like no other in London or probably England. The cafe is a different matter unfortunately. With its setting It ought to be a wonderful experience, and it is also an unsusual treat to have table service in a London gallery.
