For these reasons I wouldn't t mind paying the higher than average prices. But there was a long queue to be seated even though many tables were free, the woman at the desk asked "Can I help you" as though it were not obvious why one had been standing there for 10 - 15 minutes; the cake arrived separately and several mintes before the pot of tea, and it was necessary to go to the till to pay the bill because of inattentive waiting staff. The whole experience reminded me of the indifferent or snooty kind of service you often get in southern Italy or occasionally Paris.

Absolutely Outstanding Art Collection. The Wallace Collection is now one of my "must see" recommendations for friends traveling to London. Not only is there a wonderful collection of art, furniture and porcelain but also an amazing armor collection. They offer free guided tours. The tour I went on was led by Victoria, who not only gave information about some of the different pieces of the collection, but added in history and some very informative explanations (such as how porcelain is made). The history of some of the pieces in the collection is so rich, it made the art pieces almost come alive. Before this tour, I was only marginally interested in medieval armor, but Victoria gave such a good description of the pieces in the collection - how it was made and how armor changed over the ages - I was really fascinated. Bravo, Victoria!! After the tour, I had a wonderful lunch at the French restaurant at the Wallace Collection. The pate plate accompanied by a lovely French wine that was recommended by my waiter were the perfect ending to my visit.

Dreadful Staff. I actually visited the Wallace last year and wrote in and complained about the staff. I had a shoulder bag as I was going shopping afterwards. As I was going round the museum I gradually realised I was being followed. Each room I went in, a member of staff appeared. Eventually someone appeared and he began writing in his notebook. I looked round and saw I was the only person in the room. Obviously, they thought I was going to nick something. Pathetic really. All they have to do is to tell people to hand in their bags when they enter.There was a horrible atmosphere throughout the museum. Groups of staff huddled together whispering. It didn't seem like a happy ship.My complaint was answered after a couple of months saying it had been forwarded to the Director of Finance (I think) who was in charge of the staff, who would be in touch. Needless to say I never heard from him/her.

Collection is great, museum staff rude, brunch service okay. We had come to the Wallace Collection with our then 5 month old son in a stroller/pram. We started with a short tour of the front of the house and had brunch in the restaurant. The staff was incredibly patient and careful around our son and helped accomodate us. I even asked for my eggs to be recooked (scrambled was incredibly runny, too much for my taste). We weren't expecting exception service, and the food was good, but the service was slow. Onward to the collection. We had a great time looking and reading up on the collection. My good review stops there. The staff followed me everywhere I pushed the stroller. At one point my husband was carrying our son in the baby bjorn and the staff would run up and tell him 'no touching!' every time he would point at an object and talk to our son. My husband was no where NEAR close to any of the objects to touch them. My son would, of course as babies do, reach out his arms and babble, especially at the paintings and suits of armor. Again the staff would run up and tell them again 'no touching'. I got fed up with it after the 3rd time considering my baby has a short reach and my husband was standing at least 2 feet from the object. I seriously doubt my baby has magical superpowers that would turn him into Elasto-boy to make his arms stretch far enough to actually touch any of the art work or armor, but the staff at the Wallace Collection behaved and acted as if that was happening. On the second floor were all the painting and serious Baroque/Roccoco collections, but we didn't stay long as the staff followed my stroller everywhere until I parked it in the corner. I felt I was being treated like a shoplifter for just having a baby with me. I found this all heavily ironic becuase the Wallace Collection has a fantastic elevator/lift and a really nice baby changing room on the bottom floor. I did not have the opportunity to really enjoy my time at the Wallace Collection because my husband and I felt like bringing our child along should have been a crime, when instead the staff should have been more understanding.
A Hidden Treasure!. A "must visit" collection few steps from the oxford st. n amazing sinery of rooms furnitures, paintings, porcelain. Don't miss it.

Amazing collections. It is a fantastic mansion with enormous collections from armour and weapons to porcelin, gathered over generations and across the continent. The insight into the life of the aristocracy was also very interesting. As an aside, the soldiers must have been very small to fit into the suits of armour.Prepare to spend several hours here to even scratch the surface of the collection.

Supercilious Staff....Excellent Ice-Cream. My friend reserved a table for us last Saturday at the cafe at The Wallace Collection as she had been to the cafe before and thought that it would be the ideal place for us to enjoy a light snack and a glass of bubbly before trying on dresses for my upcoming wedding. As we wanted something light we decided on the ice-cream and sorbet to go with our Champagne.When we were seated we had to wait for over 10 minutes before anyone came to take our order - in fact, nobody came - my friend had to ask the Maitre d' if anyone was serving our table and so he came to take our order himself. When we enquired as to what the sorbet was the maitre d' looked at us in disbelief and then told us that he didn't know. When he asked one of the waiters, the waiter looked baffled as to why we would want sorbet and in response the maitre d' said "I know" and rolled his eyes. We felt like naughty school-children and my friend felt humiliated that the location she had chosen was turning out to be so awful. Once our order for ice-cream and Champagne had been taken and after our cutlery, napkins, water glasses etc had been snatched away and a single ice-cream spoon had been slammed down in their place, the maitre d' came and knelt down at our table and told us that 'for future reference' we were not really 'allowed' to simply order sorbet and ice-cream but that as we already had there was nothing he could do - really we should have ordered a main meal and ordering sorbet & ice-cream was insufficient for a reserved table. My friend pointed out that when she had made the reservation there had been no mention of the fact that we would need to order a main meal and that she didn't really understand what the problem was. He then reiterated for 'future reference' that what we had ordered was unacceptable and so I informed him that 'for future reference' I would never be visiting the cafe again after the way that we had been spoken to.The ice-cream and Champagne was lovely and despite the embarrassment we had a great lunch-time snack but when we wanted to pay we had to ask 3 times before our bill was brought over (which was £50 by the way so that was pretty expensive ice-cream!).We left feeling like we had behaved improperly yet all we had done was order items that were on the menu. We didn't realise that we would have our food choices dictated to us. I will definitely never be going back there after such a horrible experience and if I could score zero I would.

One of London's best... Many times now have I been to the Wallace collection to view this fabulous collection, or for the various lectures that take place here.With regards to the staff, I have never had any problems.. I have always been greeted and spoken to, and chatted about various items etc - and everyone has always been very helpful - even walking me through to an area I was asking about.Sometimes it is all down to how the individual visitors attitude and what how they make their visit..etc.

beautiful location for afternoon tea - good price. the location for high tea was beautiful. it was in the restaurant at the back of the building that had a skylight...really nice. the afternoon tea was good..i imagine its the same everywhere but we didn't pay the ritz prices..it was about 20 pounds per person.

Badly let down by poor visitor experience. I would like to endorse the views in the review posted in July 2010. I too found the gallery staff curt and unhelpful. I also agree with others who say that the restaurant is overpriced with very slow service. It is a great pity because the collection is excellent.Other UK institutions such as the National Trust have made great efforts to improve the quality of their visitor experience in recent years, without in any way putting the collection in danger. My personal view is that the management of the Wallace Collection should look at this experience, study current best practice, and take steps to improve.

Museum is a gem; Peyton's cafe was disappointing. Visited the Wallace Collection a few weeks ago when we had some time to kill before a matinee performance at the Royal Opera House and it was a very pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. It's just a short walk from Selfridges on Oxford Street and entrance is free. There is also a free guided tour: although we didn't have time to do the full tour we did listen to the start which gave useful background to the collection and the family who created it. The exhibits are very Europe-centric (France in particular) but interesting nonetheless. When we visited there was a special exhibition of bronze sculpture in the basement which was staged in a very atmospheric way but unfortunately we didn't have time to visit the upstairs rooms; hopefully we will have chance to return.We stayed to have lunch in Peyton's Cafe, which is in the enclosed courtyard. The location is spectacular - comfy seating and natural daylight without the worry of rain but the food and drink we were served didn't live up to expectations. We started with a smoothie and fresh lemonade to drink - the smoothie was fine but the lemonade was very acidic. I have ordered fresh lemonade in other places and even made some of my own and I have never encountered anything as sharp - it seemed to be almost neat lemon juice with not even the slightest hint of sweetness. To eat we both chose scrambled eggs and smoked salmon. This was slow to arrive despite being simple to make - other tables whose orders were taken after ours were served sooner even though the cafe (and restaurant which is on the other side of the courtyard) wasn't that busy. When the salmon/eggs did arrive it looked rather un-appetizing: the eggs were grey-ish as though cooked in a pan with dirty oil, although it tasted ok. The smoked salmon was in flakes rather than thin slices which was rather decadent but unfortunately it contained several bones. We finished with cafe latte which was well made but didn't really make up for the disappointment with the lemonade and eggs/salmon.I would definitely return to the Wallace Collection again to experience the full guided tour and see the upstairs galleries but I am wary of visiting the cafe again except maybe for a cup of tea or coffee.

A Curate's Egg. This museum is difficult to rate properly. The building and the collections are fantastic, it is easy to find and it is, of course, free. This place has such potential that it is a tragedy this is not being realised due to what I can only assume is a lack of effective leadership and vision.When I visited the visitor experience was very poor indeed - I would rate it as the worst venue in London as far as quality of service to the customer is concerned. Staff were unfriendly, snobby, and gave the impression that they were doing you a favour by letting one of the 'commoners' visit their Museum. Indeed throughout the entire visit the universal impression gained was that the entire offer was begrudged and forced with staff looking down their noses at the visitors and some of the warders being downright rude in the way they spoke.The restaurant was reasonably well laid out but was spoiled by a lack of consistency in the quality of what was served (plates were different sizes for the same meal, cutlery was dirty and the soup was cold). The waiter was inattentive (we had to ask for the bill three times), exuded snobbery, and clearly felt that he was working at the Ritz rather than a publicly-funded visitor attraction.The collections were not displayed or interpreted to their full potential with a very traditional approach to presentation (think 3 decades behind other museums). Information was limited at best and objects were often impossible to identify properly. This museum clearly has serious problems behind the scenes and needs a massive shake-up to bring it into the 21st century.The staff on the galleries had no idea about active interaction with the customer, sitting slumped on their chairs and scowling at the visitors (one was asleep when I visited). The shop was limited in scope and the staff there did not offer assistance to customers actively.Would I recommend visiting? Strangely enough the answer is yes as the collections and building are worth a look in themselves. It is also worth visiting if you want to remind yourself how not to deal with customers and fancy a glance through the window of time into how museums used to be in the 1970s....On a more positive note the toilets were clean and well presented.

If you are into excellence beyond expectations, this is perfect.. My favourite museum in London. They simply get everything right. You roam from one room to another in a chateaux-visiting fashion, each furnished with exquisite objects of arts. It is easy to overindulge in its sumptuous richness, once you feel a little too full, head to the cafe. It is such a contrasting oasis. The high dome gives the much needed open space, soothing natural light and refreshing green trees, you can rest well and recharge leisurely. A little pricey, but the cafe offers delightful bites.The best of all, however, is the free daily guided tour. I had mine with Ms. Marie-Claude Elliot. So charming and witty, her presentation is a work of art in itself. The tour was highly entertaining, rich in fascinating information and insightful musings. It is the highlight of my London trip and no doubt the most enjoyable hour I had there. I cannot recommend the Wallace Collection highly enough. To be fair though, for many visitors who are not UK residents, this museum is low priority, if not easily skipped altogether. After all, this museum is undoubtedly more French than British. And understandably, people wonder why do French things while being in London for a limited time. However, if you are into excellence beyond expectations, this is perfect.Finally I would say it is not quite child-friendly. For visitors with children, I did not find anything catering to the young. Too many objects are within the reach of little hands, especially those that are highly curious, the parents might end up keeping their eyes fastened on their kids that they couldn't see much of anything else. The rather compact space neither helps, kids who like to move about might be frustrated being kept in tight tow.Big bonus: it is unbelievably free of charge. But after such an indulging visit, this is one place I bet you would feel highly merit the suggested donation.

Beautiful things in lovely setting. Fascinating place. I have always hated roccoco style but understand it so much more now, and there's lots of other amazing stuff too, and an elegant courtyard cafe.

Great art museum. The WC houses a great collection of beautiful classic art. If you love the National Gallery you will love the Wallace Collection as well. The place is simply amazing and it's also free admission. Easily accessible from several tube stations and bus routes in Central London. Enjoy ;-)

Most enjoyable. We visited the Wallace Collection during a trip to London at Easter. We were most impressed and thoroughly enjoyed our time there. It is situated in pretty Manchester Square, less than a 5 minute walk from Oxford Street - so very central for public transport. A bonus is that entrance is FREE! It has a good web site for opening hours etc.. Compared to our national museums, art galleries etc. it is small and "intimate" but there is plenty to see and enjoy. On my next visit to London I'll definitely treat myself to a return visit. We also visited Kenwood House but this was a disappointment after Wallace, though the walk on Hampstead Heath was enjoyable enough.

One of the world's great small museums. The Wallace Collection will never match the National Gallery for selection, but I enjoy it far more because it offers charms that no large museum can match.For one thing, it displays art in the proper context. Artists never created works for the endless gallery of the mega museum. They created them either for churches or massive private residences like the one that houses the Wallace Collection. They intended their works to hang (or stand) with both furniture and with very different works and that is how you see them here.The second big advantage here is unity. Unlike large museums, which try to meld the often competing tastes of hundreds of curators over many generations, the Wallace Collection centers on the acquisitions of just two men. Visitors thus see more than great paintings, they feel the spirit of the men who built the collection and learn the traits that those men thought essential to great art. It's exciting to look at two very different pieces in the Wallace Collection, both bought by the same man, and suddenly see the uniting principle that caused the same guy to buy both.Truly brilliant.

Great collection, shame about the lunch. This was a very enjoyable collection, great themes in the paintings and interesting furniture all splendidly set in the grand old family house. Not so much impressed by the current Damien Hirst exhibition or lunch - lovely atrium and coffee/cake fine, but we found the lunch food disappointing for the price and service was slow and offhand.

Not to be missed by either the arty or the frugal!. A short walk from either Marble Arch or Bond Street is the Wallace collection. There are some amazing finds, from Madame Pompadour's Sevres china tea sets to jewelry from the medieval era to an astounding collection of armory and portraits. There is something for everyone's taste. And best of all, admission is free. They serve a wonderful tea, and you're not crowded. It was nice to be able to just be able to soak in the ambiance and take my time. I'm still sure I missed things, though, there's just that much to see. Set in the original house, you are spared the sterilised tour experience.

If you really want to feel what it was like to be in a posh London 18th century home. The pieces are over the top, but the layout within the home helps you to imagine what life for the privelage might have been like. After you've done all the typical tourist attractions, come to this musuem-its a gem for your London experience. And stay for the cafe! We had tea, but also saw families and business meetings happening in the atrium cafe.

Outstanding Collection -Difficult to Beat. The Wallace Collection in London, little known but truely a gem and not very well known. You need to search it out and perhaps do a little walking or just get a cab.The children may well love it, fantastic collection of armour, paintings pottery etc everything, will take you way more time to see it all than you expect. Do allow at least 4 hours to visit, really great collection my family loved it and we will go again for sure and we live 6000 miles away

Stunning. Its great. You should go, even if you only pop in, (admission is free and its in the center of London, near to other tourist attractions), but there's a good chance you'll spend much longer than you planned for there. The collection and interior of the house are beautiful and magnificent. You can see Fragonard's 'The Swing'. I recommend looking at the website.http://www.wallacecollection.org/index.php

Amazing. The Wallace Collection had been on our to-do list for several London visits and we went there on a Sunday morning in June and we agree with the previous reviews that.. “It is simply amazing!”……… Although much larger than we were expecting it is very intimate and comfortable to visit . As all the previous reviewers have said the collection is fantastic, however the quality and style of the décor and finish of all areas of the building is also to be admired. The museum has a restaurant in the enclosed courtyard offering excellent food at all times of the day and we will be back to this very stylish oasis just off Oxford Street many times to enjoy lunches or afternoon teas etc.

An absolutely stunning 'must-see'. A hidden gem, tucked-away in a leafy square just behind Selfriges store on frenetic Oxford Street, but not to be missed.Personally,not enamoured by flouncy flashy French styles of art, but nevertheless entirely 'gobsmacked' by the sheer scale and quality on display here.Such an experience too to come face to face with Rembrandt's selfportrait as well as the Laughing Cavalier.Swish elegant covered - courtyard cafe too.FREE admission !Cannot recommend too highly !!

A Must-see. The Wallace Collection had been on my to-do list for several London visits and I finally made it in January. It is simply amazing! The collection reflects the acquisitions by one family over 4 generations and it is immense. Yet the museum is quite manageable and friendly for a day's outing. All in all it is a quite intimate experience.The paintings themselves are lovely featuring Hals, Rembrandt, Titian, Boucher & Fragonard among others including a strong showing of Dutch & Fleming works. I especially enjoyed the collection of Sèvres porcelain, one of the finest in the world, while partner spent his time viewing the amour. The museum has a restaurant in the enclosed courtyard, audio phones available for a donation, free admission, and knowledgeable room guides.

Amazing!. I was blown away by the Wallace Colletion. I'm not educated in art history but the art work here is amazing. Beautiful rococo work. It helped that I was with people who knew a lot about the collection but well worth the visit even if you dont know everything about what is in there. Lots of boulle furniture, armor, sevre and paintings including the Swing. Must see!

A lovely surprise in London. I had heard of the Wallace Collection many times, but had never visited it in my many visits to London. Only now do I realize how much of an omission it was. The Collection is located in Hertoford House, a beautiful mansion in Manchester Square, in the heart of London. It contains mostly French XVII and XVIII century objets d'art, such as vases of Sevres porcelain, Titian portraits, seventeenth century bronze statuettes, XVIII and XIX century miniatures, just to mention a few examples. It is a paradise for anyone who appreciates the decorative arts. It is definitely a must see.In addition, there is a new restaurant on the premises, fashioned after a typical French brasserie. It offers main dishes, like seabass, steak tartar, etc. It also has an array of terrines, cheeses, platters of oyster, clams, and prawns. On the way out make sure you survey the scene around Manchester Square. The park is lush green even in late winter, and surrounded by XIX century mansions (although none as large as the one where the collection is housed). In short, the Wallace Collection is a gem. I can't wait to get back. Anna L. Josephs

Never boring - always something to find. I love this museum: the basis of the collection seems to have been 'is it for sale and do I have my wallet with me', but this means that it is full of suprises and after several visits I am still finding new treasures. It is pretty crammed, but the relatively small size of the house means that you can whisk around quite quickly, or just speed along to your favourite area before gallery fatigue sets in (anyone trying to do the National gallery in a short visit will know what I mean). The acid test: I took daughters 12 and 14 along, in the middle of a shoping trip, last week - despite initial 'we'll endure it for the sake of her credit card' looks, they really enjoyed it (and it is not too far from the coffee shops of Marylebone High Street. for a recovery break) The youngest has now developed a facination with minatures (of which there is a very good selection) I've been trying to persuade my husband to pop along in his lunch hour to see the armoury - not my area of interest but a good example of the amazing range of subjects on view. A friend and I spent a quick post lunch visit playing 'spot the painting that you recognise as a book cover illustration'. The restaurant is lovely - surely one of the best settings in London, but was closed when we visited on 1st September, being apparently refitted. Hope the food remains as good as I have expereinced - memorable risotto. My 2nd favourite gallery after the Courtauld in Somerset House. And it's free.

a little too much for me. This gallery has very ornate furniture and many, many paintings set fairly closely together. I found it a little overwhelming -- beautiful but not restful. If you like ornate art, though, you might love this. And there is an elegant dining area with great teas, cream and otherwise.

what a treat. Visited the Wallace Collection for the first time this weekend, despite living locally for many years.Hertford House is a beautiful 18th Century building, and there are lots of stunning objets d'art. The highlights for me were the Laughing Cavalier and the overly ornate French furniture.Given that there's free admission, you really have no excuse not to while away an hour or two at the Collection.

Gem on Manchester Square!. This impressive Edwardian mansion on Manchester Square (three blocks from Selfridges) is a gem! Yes, there is plenty of third-rate art and an overabundance of objects d'art scattered throughout the Wallace, but there are also occasional gems - paintings, minatures, armor and furniture. The Wallace also gives the visitor a good impression how the later Victorian and Edwardian elite in London actually lived. Plan to spend 90 minutes here, and then do some shopping on nearly Oxford Street.
